site_title: Johnson & Johnson told by jury to pay US$300 million more in talc-cancer case
summary: A New York state-court jury ordered Johnson & Johnson to pay $300 million in punitive damages to Donna Olson, who claimed the company's talc-based products caused her rare asbestos-related cancer. This verdict brings the total to $325 million, one of the highest in over two years of litigation. Johnson & Johnson denies its products contain asbestos and plans to appeal the findings, citing a history of overturned verdicts. The company faces over 14,000 claims related to ovarian cancer and mesothelioma linked to asbestos exposure.

site_title: Malaysia shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 14.26 points to 1,650.76 on Friday, closing higher. The index saw 22.3 million lots worth RM256.1 million traded, with losers beating gainers 464 to 395.

site_title: mm2 Asia posts 7.1% drop in Q4 earnings; DBS upgrades stock to 'buy' as value emerges
summary: Singapore-listed film production company mm2 Asia reported a 7.1% drop in Q4 earnings to S$6.2 million, with revenue slipping 6.5% to S$78.2 million. Despite a surge in full-year revenue, net profit fell 14.5% to S$19.1 million due to increased expenses. DBS Equity Research upgraded its recommendation to "buy" as it sees emerging value at the current share price, with a target price of S$0.34. The company's core production and cinema segment is valued at S$144 million, which is considered undervalued by DBS.

site_title: China in barter deal for 200,000 tonnes of Malaysian palm oil: report
summary: China has agreed to purchase 200,000 tonnes of Malaysian palm oil worth nearly 1 billion yuan (S$200 million) in a barter deal, according to a Malaysian minister. In return, Malaysia will receive construction services, natural resources products, and civilian and defense equipment from China. This deal aims to help Malaysia reduce its palm oil stockpile and stabilize prices, following a record high in December. The agreement follows previous commitments from China to buy more palm oil from Malaysia over the next five years.

images.alt_text: China has agreed to take palm oil worth nearly 1 billion yuan (S$200 million) from Malaysia in a barter deal, media said on Saturday, citing a Malaysian minister.

site_title: US begins collecting higher tariffs on Chinese goods arriving by sea
summary: The US began collecting 25% tariffs on Chinese goods arriving by sea on June 1, 2019, in response to China's retaliatory tariffs on US goods. The US had previously imposed a 10% tariff on these goods, but allowed a grace period that ended on June 1. The tariffs, affecting consumer goods and intermediate components, were imposed in response to China's alleged breach of a trade deal, with no further talks between top negotiators scheduled. China collected its own retaliatory tariffs on US goods, which apply additional 20% or 25% tariffs to over half of the targeted 5,140 US products.

site_title: Alliance Healthcare ends Catalist debut at S$0.205 for a 2.5% premium over IPO price
summary: Alliance Healthcare Group made a successful debut on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board, ending the day at 20.5 Singapore cents for a 2.5% gain over its IPO price of 20 cents. The company received 480 valid applications for its public offer and 31 million shares were subscribed for the placement. Net proceeds of S$4.5 million will be used to expand its network of clinics and medical facilities, as well as invest in technology systems and pharmaceutical services.

site_title: S'pore market cap falls 5.1% in May as investors grow cautious
summary: Singapore's stock market declined 5.1% in May, with the total market capitalization falling to S$903.7 billion, as investors became cautious due to worsening trade tensions between the US and China. Blue-chip stocks, including local banks, were significantly affected, with DBS Group down 14% and UOB losing 15.6%. Despite strong first-quarter results, OCBC and UOB still fell. Analysts predict more downside in June due to weak second-quarter macroeconomic data and ongoing trade tensions, with the upcoming G20 meeting to watch.

site_title: Singapore and Hong Kong to collaborate on personal data protection
summary: Singapore and Hong Kong have strengthened their collaboration on personal data protection through a memorandum of understanding (MOU). The two authorities will share knowledge on data breaches, exchange best practices, and undertake joint research projects to prepare for a digital economy. This follows recent data breaches in both jurisdictions, including the SingHealth data breach in Singapore and a Cathay Pacific data breach in Hong Kong. The MOU aims to promote collaborative initiatives and information exchange in personal data protection.

site_title: China Hongxing Sports gets extension from SGX-ST to meet new-listing rules
summary: China Hongxing Sports has received an extension from the Singapore Exchange Securities Trading (SGX-ST) to meet the requirements for a new listing, including a proposed reverse takeover that could shift its focus to gold mining. The extension was granted to allow the company more time to submit a pre-admission notification, lodge a circular to shareholders, and complete the transaction, all of which are now expected to occur by November 25.

site_title: An outsider to run UOB? 'Why not'? says Wee Ee Cheong
summary: Singapore's United Overseas Bank (UOB) CEO Wee Ee Cheong, 66, says he's open to an outsider taking over the bank, but emphasizes the importance of values. Despite his family's significant ownership stake, Wee Ee Cheong prioritizes succession based on merit. His son, Teng Chuen, is learning from other managers, while his children in other industries are not involved in banking. UOB has delivered a 66% total return to investors since Wee Ee Cheong took the helm, trailing OCBC and DBS Group Holdings. Wee Ee Cheong plans to continue running the bank as long as he's healthy to ensure a strong team with a focus on stewardship.

images.alt_text: With only one of his three children in banking, Mr Wee says he won't force any of them to enter the industry. That differs from his own career, which was more like an "arranged marriage".

site_title: Narrow tax base could hamper M'sian fiscal consolidation: report
summary: Malaysia's efforts to consolidate its finances are commendable, but a narrow tax base may hinder progress. The Asean+3 Macroeconomic Research Office's 2018-19 Annual Consultation Report notes that Malaysia's economy continues to grow, but a decline in the tax-to-GDP ratio since 2015 may limit fiscal space. To reverse this trend, the report recommends streamlining tax incentives, strengthening tax collection, and realigning taxation with economic activities. The government should also aim to reverse the decline in the non-petroleum-related tax-to-GDP ratio to improve revenue mobilization.

site_title: KOP's Q4 net loss of S$418,000 improves on S$9m loss a year ago
summary: KOP Limited, a Singapore-listed property developer, reported a net loss of S$418,000 for its Q4 2019, improving from a S$9 million loss a year ago. Revenue increased 46.6% to S$4.8 million, driven by higher earnings from its Indonesian resorts. Despite a 98% decline in other operating income, gross profit nearly doubled to S$2.4 million. The company's full-year net loss narrowed to S$5.7 million from S$7.8 million in FY2018.

site_title: For Hong Kong property prices, the sky's the limit
summary: Hong Kong's property market reached an all-time high, with home values breaking their previous record set in August 2018. The Centa-City Leading Index reached 189.42, a 8.6% increase since the beginning of the year. High demand, driven by low interest rates and limited supply, has led to prices rising by relentless gains over the past three months. Experts predict the market will remain bullish for another decade, but some warn of a potential bubble and a 5% dip in prices in the second half due to trade war uncertainties.

site_title: UOB chief says 'why not' let an outsider succeed him
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) CEO Wee Ee Cheong, 66, is open to considering an outsider as his successor, saying "if they can do the job, why not." This is a departure from his family's tradition of leading the bank, which was founded by his grandfather over 80 years ago. UOB is the only Singapore bank still run by a family, after OCBC Bank chose an outsider as its CEO. Wee emphasized that he values people with the right skills, regardless of their background.

site_title: Reits
summary: Realty markets are experiencing significant fluctuations. US mortgage rates have climbed after five consecutive weeks of decline, while UK homebuyer demand has rebounded to a six-month high. In Singapore, the Q3 wave of condo launches will test demand for prime projects above S$3,000 psf. Manhattan rents have reached a record high, with expected further increases. Goldman Sachs acquired a large hotel and retail portfolio in Seoul. WeWork secured new tenants and filled more space at a Singapore property post-bankruptcy, demonstrating resilience in the commercial real estate sector. These developments indicate a changing market landscape.

site_title: North Korea's Kim visits factories linked to missile launches
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un visited several factories linked to missile launches, including the Feb 8 General Machine Factory, which has built ballistic missile launchers. The visits, which occurred without publicly disclosing their location or purpose, are believed to be linked to efforts to reduce reliance on imported chassis for missile launching vehicles. Analysts say the sites play a major role in developing North Korea's intercontinental ballistic missile technology. Despite declaring a "complete" nuclear force, Kim called for more operational weapons, and talks with the US remain stalled.

images.alt_text: The factories have innocuous names, but analysts say several ostensibly civilian facilities visited by North Korean leader Kim Jong Un recently, are also used to build ballistic missile launchers and other weapons.

site_title: Capital World further extends bond repayment date
summary: Capital World, a Catalist-listed company, has extended the repayment date of certain bonds to June 30, 2019, after initially agreeing with convertible bondholder Chong Thim Peng to extend it to May 31. The company will pay 10% interest per annum on the S$3 million bonds from June 1 to June 30. Capital World's board believes the terms are in the company's best interests, and it will make relevant updates as needed. The company's shares closed 3.85% higher on Friday.

site_title: Cameroon's Siakam overcame dad's death to live NBA dream
summary: Pascal Siakam, a 25-year-old Cameroonian forward for the Toronto Raptors, achieved his late father's dream of playing in the NBA. Siakam scored a career playoff high 32 points in the team's NBA Finals opener against the Golden State Warriors, dedicating every game to his father's memory after he died in a 2014 auto accident. Siakam credits his father's death with pushing him to work harder and pursue his basketball dreams, and he continues to strive for greatness in his career.

site_title: Is there finally a fix for Boeing?
summary: Boeing has claimed to have a fix for the grounded B737 MAX 8 jet, addressing the MCAS software issue that contributed to two fatal crashes. However, airlines remain skeptical, citing concerns over the software patch's effectiveness and the risks involved. Boeing's chief executive, Dennis Muilenburg, continues to deflect responsibility, focusing on pilot error. The company's optimistic claims have been met with criticism, with some questioning the design flaw of the aircraft itself. The aircraft's recertification process is ongoing, with frequent flyers left wondering about the safety of the plane.

site_title: France tightens rules on Mont Blanc access to combat overcrowding
summary: France has introduced new rules to limit access to Mont Blanc, Europe's highest peak, to combat overcrowding. Climbers must now book a room in one of three shelters on the mountain's flanks for overnight stays, starting June 1. The move comes after 15 climbers died on Mont Blanc last year and a 25-year-old Slovak climber died on Friday. Those caught camping on the route risk two years in prison and a €300,000 fine. The new rules aim to balance safety and mountaineer access to the peak.

site_title: Australian shares finish flat as bluechip gains beat back trade war blues
summary: Australian shares finished flat on Friday, ending 4.80 points higher at 6,396.90, despite US President Donald Trump's aggressive trade diplomacy sparking fears of recession. Investors shifted to blue chips and safe-haven gold stocks, with mining behemoth BHP Group and pharma giant CSL Ltd closing higher. The benchmark marked its fifth straight month of gains but lost over 1% this week. Gold stocks jumped over 2.6%, with Newcrest Mining reaching its best level since 2012.

site_title: Huawei 'too close' to Chinese government to be trusted: US
summary: US Defence Chief Patrick Shanahan says Huawei is "too close" to the Chinese government, making it difficult to trust the company amid escalating trade tensions. The US Commerce Department has placed Huawei on an "entity list" due to national security concerns, citing the firm's integration with the military and alleged espionage. This has led to countries blocking Huawei from working on mobile networks and companies stepping back from the firm. Huawei denies being controlled by the Chinese government, but founder Ren Zhengfei is a former soldier in China's People's Liberation Army.

site_title: Indonesia wins S&P upgrade as Jokowi victory fuels growth bets
summary: Indonesia received a sovereign rating upgrade from S&P Global Ratings to BBB, with a stable outlook, due to strong economic growth prospects and prudent fiscal policy under President Joko Widodo's re-election. The upgrade is seen as a boost to the country's efforts to attract foreign investment, with the rupiah and stocks rallying. The rating is now at the same level as Hungary and Uruguay, but below the Philippines, which also received a rating upgrade recently.

site_title: Trump says Boris Johnson would be 'very good' as next UK prime minister
summary: US President Donald Trump has expressed support for Boris Johnson's campaign to become the UK's next prime minister, calling him "very good" and "excellent". Trump also urged Johnson to boost defense spending, citing its potential to boost US military equipment exports. The two leaders will meet on Tuesday to discuss security risks posed by Iran's nuclear program and Chinese tech company Huawei. Trump's comments come ahead of his state visit to the UK, which begins on Monday.

site_title: GKE Corp to gain stable income stream from limestone mining JV
summary: GKE Corp has formed a joint venture with unrelated parties to mine limestone in China, with a 9.5-year mining contract valued at S$1.01 million. The company's wholly-owned unit, Wuzhou Xing Jian Readymix Co, will hold an 18% stake and receive a stable income stream of 3 yuan per tonne of output produced and sold, with potential increases every three years. The agreement is expected to contribute to GKE's profitability and enhance its competitive edge in ready-mix concrete manufacturing.

site_title: Market Capitalisation
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, exceeding expectations. Meanwhile, US stocks opened lower due to fresh tariffs on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and similar operating loss in H2. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. An Indonesian employee was detained in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its new CEO. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and PBOC agreed to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance, and Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Anti-corruption drive drove up Viet property prices: report
summary: Vietnam's anti-corruption campaign has led to a surge in property prices, particularly in Ho Chi Minh City, due to delays in licensing processes and reduced new supply. The campaign, launched in 2017, has uncovered corruption scandals and targeted projects sourced from state-owned entities. As a result, property prices rose by 15% in 2018, with mid-range apartments also increasing by 13%. However, Vietnamese authorities are expected to take measures to alleviate the impact, with some licensing procedures easing and new projects being allowed to proceed, which may help stabilize the market.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Samurai 2K Aerosol's net profit for FY2019 dropped 10.8% to RM10.4 million due to lower revenue, down 19.3% from RM90 million. The company declared a final dividend of S$0.005 per share. HC Surgical Specialists acquired 25% of Medistar Services for S$480,000 to expand its GP network. Mirach Energy's CEO, Chan Shut Li, will step down, and Liu Kaichun will replace him as executive chairman.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close lower after Trump announces Mexico tariffs
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 1.63% on May 31, 2019, after US President Donald Trump announced a 5% tariff on all goods from Mexico, strengthening the yen against the dollar. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 20,601.19, down 341.34 points, and fell 2.44% for the week.

site_title: Vibrant addresses SGX-ST queries on Sabana disposal
summary: Vibrant Group sold units in Sabana Shari'ah Compliant Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust (Sabana Reit) and its stake in Sabana Investment Partners (SIP) for S$62.2 million. The deal was executed across three agreements, with Vibrant's 51% stake in SIP worth S$20.46 million and units in Sabana Reit valued at S$0.48 per unit. The sale price was deemed "reasonably favourable" and above the median value of past precedent transactions, with excess proceeds exceeding book value by S$22.81 million.

site_title: North Korea 'executed' officials after failed Trump summit: report
summary: North Korea reportedly executed its special envoy, Kim Hyok Chol, and four senior foreign ministry officials after the collapse of the second summit between Kim Jong Un and President Donald Trump in February. The executions were allegedly carried out by firing squad for "betraying the supreme leader." Shin Hye Yong, Kim Jong Un's interpreter, was also sent to a prison camp for failing to translate during the summit. These purges follow a series of short-range missile tests and come amid heightened tensions between North Korea and the US.

site_title: At least 11 dead, six wounded after shooting in Virginia: police
summary: A gunman killed 11 people and wounded six in a shooting at a government building complex in Virginia Beach, Virginia, on Friday. The gunman, a public utilities employee, was also killed after trading fire with responding officers. The shooting occurred in the city's public works and utilities offices building. A police officer was saved by his bulletproof vest. The incident is under investigation by police.

site_title: Leaders whose actions shock markets risk eroding public trust in policy makers
summary: US President Donald Trump's sudden decision to slap tariffs on Mexico has raised concerns among economists and academics about the erosion of public trust in policymakers. The unexpected move can impact monetary policy decisions and diminish the US monetary policy's influence on the global economy. Experts warn that frequent policy changes and disregard for established norms can undermine trust in the US as a reliable policy-making entity. The US dollar's dominance in global trade and finance also carries responsibilities, and abandoning these responsibilities can lead to a loss of trust in the US.

images.alt_text: The US dollar is dominant in global trade and financial transactions. But in the long run, its dominance is likely to fade as the US' share of global GDP shrinks, resulting in the inability to expand the supply of safe dollar assets without exhausting fiscal capacity.

site_title: European stock markets slide at open
summary: European stock markets declined at the open on Friday, with Frankfurt's DAX 30 index dropping 1.3% and the Paris CAC 40 falling 1.0%. The decline followed US President Donald Trump's announcement of tariffs on all Mexican imports, sparking concerns about a new trade war. London's FTSE 100 index also fell 0.7%.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon down 0.6% at 3,123.37
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.6% to 3,123.37 on Friday, marking its fourth consecutive week of declines, with its worst monthly showing in over three years. The decline was initially triggered by US President Donald Trump's tariff threat on Mexico, but markets have since recovered. China's official purchasing managers index (PMI) figures also had an impact, with the non-manufacturing PMI coming in at 49.4, beating expectations.

site_title: Singapore, Hong Kong strengthen cooperation on personal data protection
summary: Singapore and Hong Kong have strengthened their collaboration on personal data protection through a memorandum of understanding (MOU). The agreement enables the sharing of knowledge on data breaches and best practices to prepare for a digital economy. The move comes after instances of data breaches in both countries, including the SingHealth breach in Singapore and Cathay Pacific's data breach in Hong Kong. The collaboration also includes the release of a jointly-developed guide to data protection by design for ICT systems.

site_title: In swipe at China, US defence chief Patrick Shanahan warns of Asia instability
summary: US Acting Defence Secretary Patrick Shanahan warned of Asia instability, specifically targeting China's actions, at the Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore. He suggested China's artificial islands in the South China Sea and other behaviors undermine the international order. Shanahan called on Asian allies to increase security spending, emphasizing the US commitment to the region. This comes amid heightened tensions between the US and China, including a trade war and disputes over Taiwan. Shanahan's comments are seen as a swipe at China, but China's Defence Minister Wei Fenghe is set to criticize the US on Sunday.

site_title: The pleasure and pain of procrastination
summary: Procrastination is a common phenomenon that affects many individuals, particularly in creative industries. It's not simply a matter of laziness or poor time management, but rather a coping mechanism for negative emotions such as boredom, anxiety, and self-doubt. Research suggests that procrastination is a self-sabotaging behavior that compounds in pain as deadlines approach. To break the cycle, experts recommend strategies such as creating an external deadline, finding a distraction-free workspace, and practicing self-compassion to reduce stress and increase motivation. By acknowledging and addressing procrastination, individuals can overcome the vicious cycle and improve their productivity.

site_title: FLT to divest Australia property with planned sale of office, deck car park for A$5.4m
summary: FLT, a real estate investment trust, is selling its Australia mixed-use property for A$5.4 million, including an office and deck car park, to complete the sale of the entire property. This follows a previous A$15 million divestment of a warehouse and parking area. The sale price represents a 20% premium to the book value of the office and deck car park segments. The estimated net proceeds will be used for funding potential acquisitions, debt reduction, or general corporate purposes, with completion expected by the end of 2019.

site_title: Temasek's philanthropy arm sets up Asia-focused private equity fund for impact investing
summary: Temasek Trust, the philanthropic arm of investment company Temasek Holdings, has established ABC World Asia, a private equity fund focused on impact investing in South Asia, South-east Asia, and China. The fund aims to generate positive social or environmental impact alongside a compelling risk-adjusted return, with an initial focus on themes such as financial and digital inclusion, better health and education, and sustainable food and agriculture. The fund is supported by Temasek Trust, Temasek, and Pavilion Capital, with the goal of helping bridge the financing gap for the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals.

site_title: Risk-off appetites bolster safe haven assets
summary: Gold prices reached a two-week high due to diminished risk sentiments amid global growth concerns. US President Donald Trump's vow to impose trade tariffs on Mexican imports weakened risk appetites, while China's contraction in PMI figures bolstered bullion appeal as investors sought safe haven shelter. Economic uncertainties, including a prolonged Sino-US trade dispute and flagging economic growth, will likely draw support for safe haven assets, including gold. Key support levels for gold are at US$1,278.00, while a breakout above US$1,302.00 is needed to extend the bullish trend.

site_title: Industry body boosts Singapore fintech ecosystem with regulatory technology sub-committee
summary: The Singapore FinTech Association (SFA) has launched a regtech sub-committee to promote regulatory technologies and overcome regulatory challenges in Singapore's financial industry. The sub-committee, chaired by Chionh Chye Kit, aims to work with other fintech associations in countries like Hong Kong and Japan. The move is seen as a step to boost Singapore's fintech ecosystem and benefit its stakeholders as the industry expands regionally.

site_title: US: Wall Street skids, jolted by Trump's surprise tariff threat on Mexico
summary: US stocks plummeted on Friday, marking the largest May slump since 2010, as President Trump's surprise threat of tariffs on Mexico fueled fears of a trade war and recession. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 1.41% to 24,815.04, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. The Dow's weekly losing streak reached six, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq closed below their 200-day moving averages for the first time since March. Investors sought safety in government bonds, and yields fell to new multi-month lows.

site_title: Deliveroo riders in Singapore can get paid within 3 working days
summary: Deliveroo has introduced a "Cash Out" feature for its Singapore riders, allowing them to receive their earnings within three working days, instead of the current fortnightly payments. This is the first implementation of this feature in Asia and follows a successful global launch. Since its introduction, 70% of Deliveroo's riders have used the feature, with up to 25% of active riders accessing their pay daily. The company aims to provide riders with more control over their finances and flexibility in accessing their earnings.

site_title: China to create blacklist of 'unreliable' foreign firms
summary: China plans to create a blacklist of "unreliable" foreign firms and individuals, in response to US sanctions on Chinese tech giant Huawei. The list will include entities that harm Chinese companies' legitimate rights and interests, and pose a threat to national security. The move comes as China prepares to increase tariffs on US$60 billion in US goods in retaliation to US President Donald Trump's decision to hike punitive duties on Chinese products. China's entity list will be announced in the near future, and Washington is also reportedly considering adding Chinese video surveillance companies to its own list.

site_title: Everest deaths and overcrowding spark anger over commercialisation
summary: A record 810 climbers reached the summit of Mount Everest in May, with an estimated 11 deaths due to overcrowding and delays. The deaths, which disproportionately affected climbers with new operators, have sparked debate over commercialization and governance. Critics blame the rise of cheap, unqualified operators who prioritize profits over safety. Industry veterans call for new regulations and guidelines to control the number of climbers and ensure quality control. The Nepalese government faces pressure to review management of the mountain, but experts doubt significant change will occur, citing the economic benefits of tourism.

site_title: Over 100 hotels to launch job redesign with government aid
summary: Over 100 Singapore hotels have pledged to embark on job redesign in the year ahead, aiming to equip employees with new skills and cut repetitive tasks to move up the career ladder and earn more. The initiative, backed by the government, provides training programs and assistance schemes under the Lean Enterprise Development Scheme. The goal is to help enterprises manage manpower costs and build capacity, with unions playing a key role in supporting workers during the redesign process.

site_title: Fundamental problem between US and China is 'mutual lack of strategic trust': PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that the fundamental problem between the US and China is a mutual lack of strategic trust, hindering any compromise or peaceful accommodation. This lack of trust is a major obstacle to finding a constructive way forward, despite competing on major global issues.

images.alt_text: PM Lee said that even if there was no outright conflict between the two major powers, a prolonged period of tension and uncertainty will be extremely damaging.

site_title: Disney's Star Wars-themed Galaxy's Edge is out of this world
summary: Disney's Star Wars-themed Galaxy's Edge opened at Disneyland, allowing visitors to pilot the Millennium Falcon and interact with Star Wars characters. The 14-acre area includes two marquee rides, workshops for building lightsabers and functioning droids, and themed food and drinks. The immersive experience features a trading village, stormtroopers, and a cantina, with guests encouraged to stay in character as "Batuu residents." The land's success is crucial for Disney's $20 billion theme park division, as it addresses changing customer expectations and personalization. Despite initial concerns about creative risks, visitors praised the experience, with many considering it a game-changer for the Disney parks.

site_title: CapitaLand, CDL complete S$400m Liang Court mall purchase
summary: CapitaLand and City Developments Ltd (CDL) have completed the S$400 million acquisition of Liang Court mall through their joint venture. The deal was finalized on Friday, marking a significant purchase in the Singaporean property market.

site_title: Jho Low fights to reclaim family mansion in Penang seized in 1MDB case
summary: Fugitive financier Jho Low is fighting to reclaim his mother's Penang mansion, seized as part of a RM680 million civil forfeiture action linked to 1MDB. Low claims the property was purchased and constructed before 1MDB existed, citing a 2000 certificate of occupation. The Malaysian government alleges the funds used to buy the mansion were siphoned from 1MDB. Low's lawyers say the seizure is part of a "personal vendetta" that has risked his family's safety, and he cannot get a fair trial in Malaysia.

site_title: China Gaoxian gives details of financial differences after termination of disposal
summary: China Gaoxian Fibre Fabric Holdings announced details on material differences between its adjusted unaudited and original unaudited financial statements for 2018 after terminating a proposed disposal. The disposal of loss-making subsidiary Huaxiang China Gaoxian International Holdings was shelved due to lack of shareholder approval. The company's loss from discontinued operations widened to 157.1 million yuan, and net loss attributable to shareholders increased to 166.6 million yuan. Assets and liabilities associated with the disposal group also increased. The termination is expected to impact financial results for 2019.

site_title: China's SOE regulator calls for continued overseas expansion despite trade war
summary: China's State-owned Assets Supervision and Administration Commission (SOE regulator) has urged state-owned enterprises to continue their overseas expansion despite the intensifying trade dispute with the US. Deputy director Weng Jieming stated that the regulator would support SOE expansion efforts via the Belt-and-Road initiative, citing 85 central enterprises with 3,000 projects along the route. This move aims to bolster China's economic presence abroad despite trade tensions.

site_title: Saudi king warns attacks could threaten oil supplies
summary: Saudi Arabia's King Salman has warned that "terrorist" attacks in the region could threaten global oil supplies, amid sabotage attacks on Saudi oil tankers and a key pipeline. King Salman has called on Gulf and Arab leaders to confront Iran's "criminal acts" and vowed to resolutely confront aggressive threats. The Organization of Islamic Cooperation (OIC) has condemned the attacks and urged a position on the matter, with Secretary-General Yousef bin Ahmed al-Othaimeen stating that undermining the kingdom's security would undermine the security of the Arab and Islamic world.

site_title: Japanese automaker shares hit as Trump threatens Mexico with tariffs
summary: Japanese automakers' shares sank after US President Donald Trump threatened to impose 5% tariffs on Mexican imports, potentially affecting vehicles made in Mexico and sold in the US. Toyota Motor Corp fell 2%, Nissan Motor and Honda Motor fell 3%, while Mazda Motor plummeted 7%. All four automakers operate vehicle assembly plants in Mexico, producing one-third of the country's vehicles. Trump's tariff threat may impact vehicle sales and production in Mexico.

site_title: STI falls 0.8%, capping a month to forget
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.8% to close at 3,117.76, capping a month of losses, with investors reacting to US President Donald Trump's tariff threat on Mexico and disappointing Chinese manufacturing figures. Regional markets were mixed, with Australia and Malaysia ending higher, while China, Hong Kong, and Japan were lower. The STI lost 9.1% in May, with the telco Singtel outperforming the index, while banking stocks continued to decline.

site_title: First Sponsor's S$147.6m rights issue oversubscribed
summary: First Sponsor Group's S$147.6 million rights issue was oversubscribed, with 117.12% of available convertible securities and warrants accepted. The company plans to use the proceeds to fund its expansion plans. The rights issue was oversubscribed as of May 24, with valid acceptances and excess applications received.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's housing loans shrank for a third month in April, with overall lending flat, according to MAS data. UOB's CEO expressed willingness to consider an outsider for succession, while the Singapore FinTech Association launched a regtech sub-committee. Deliveroo riders in Singapore can now get paid within 3 working days. Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust sold a property in Australia for A$5.4 million. SPH priced its S$150 million perpetual notes at 4.5%. HC Surgical acquired 25% of Medistar for S$480,000. Singapore shares fell 1.6% on the week due to tariff threats and disappointing Chinese manufacturing figures.

site_title: Europe: Stocks stumped as US threatens tariffs on Mexico
summary: European stocks fell 0.8% on Friday, marking the worst monthly loss since January 2016, after US President Donald Trump threatened to impose new tariffs on Mexican imports. Auto-makers and banks exposed to Latin America's second-largest economy were particularly hard hit, with Carmakers shedding 2% and Fiat Chrysler and Volkswagen falling 4.8% and 2.6% respectively. The Stoxx 600 closed out May with a 5.7% slide, with defensive stocks rising and yields on German bonds reaching record lows.

site_title: Gold surges to seven-week high as Trump tariff threat rattles markets
summary: Gold prices surged to a seven-week high on Friday, reaching $1,305.17 an ounce, amid investor fears of a global economic downturn triggered by US President Donald Trump's tariff threat on Mexico. The metal has risen 1.7% this month and 1.6% for the week, with investors seeking a safe-haven investment. US carmakers and manufacturers were among the worst hit by the threat, leading to a sharp decline in Wall Street's main equity indexes.

site_title: Bitcoin's rally masks uncomfortable fact: almost nobody uses it
summary: Bitcoin's recent price surge hides a concerning reality: only 1.3% of economic transactions are made with the cryptocurrency, indicating that merchants are reluctant to accept it due to the volatility of its price. This issue stems from a culture of "hodlers" who prioritize accumulating the digital asset over using it for everyday purchases. Despite major companies like AT&T allowing cryptocurrency payments, speculators are hesitant to use Bitcoin for transactions, making it challenging for the cryptocurrency to gain mass appeal as a viable alternative to traditional money.

site_title: Mexico eyes steps to cut immigrant flows to US border, official says
summary: Mexico plans to sharpen existing measures to reduce the flow of Central American migrants to the US border, according to Deputy Foreign Minister Jesus Seade. The move comes as US President Donald Trump threatens to impose tariffs starting at 5% on June 10 if Mexico doesn't substantially halt illegal immigration. Seade believes traditional mechanisms and better enforcement of existing rules can help reduce the migrant flow, aiming to make progress ahead of planned meetings in Washington.

images.alt_text: "To avoid these flows that go from Central America to the United States in large numbers I think we can make progress with traditional mechanisms and better exercise existing rules," said Jesus Seade, Mexico's deputy foreign minister for North America.

site_title: Vallianz falls into the red with US$128m net loss
summary: Vallianz Holdings, a Singapore-based offshore support vessel provider, reported a net loss of US$128.2 million for the fiscal year ended March 31, compared to a profit of US$16.7 million in 2018. The loss was mainly due to exceptional items of US$133.3 million from impairments of an associated company and US$120.9 million in plant, property, and equipment write-offs. The company attributed the significant decline in earnings to the one-time impairment charges.

site_title: Tesla promotes lower priced China-made Model 3 in sales push
summary: Tesla is pricing its China-made Model 3 vehicles from 328,000 yuan (S$65,500), 13% cheaper than imported versions, to boost sales in the growing Chinese market. The starting prices range from 328,000 to 522,000 yuan, with financing options available. The move aims to make Tesla more accessible and minimize the impact of US-China import tariffs. Production at Tesla's China factory, the first wholly foreign-owned car plant, is expected to start soon, with deliveries forecast to reach 360,000 to 400,000 vehicles in 2019.

site_title: Japan's biggest bank offers redundancy to hundreds of managers in London
summary: Japan's largest bank, Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, is offering voluntary redundancy to hundreds of London-based managers in a bid to cut costs. The program will target 500 directors and managing directors, with applications accepted until the end of July. The move is seen as a response to the severe business environment, including low interest rates. The bank remains committed to London and the European region, with plans to make further contributions to the market.

site_title: SPH sets distribution rate of 4.5% on S$150m perpetual notes
summary: SPH sets a distribution rate of 4.5% on S$150m perpetual notes, yielding 261.2 basis points over the five-year swap offer rate. The securities were sold at par, with a private-bank concession of 25 basis points. The issuer plans to use the net proceeds for general working capital, capital expenditure, and corporate requirements. The deal, part of a S$1 billion multicurrency debt issuance programme, received over S$800 million in orders, with 98% coming from Singapore and 2% from overseas. Payment will be made semi-annually.

site_title: Treating acne scars
summary: Treatments for acne scars have advanced beyond skin-deep therapies, offering effective solutions for various scar types, including ice pick, box car, rolling, and hypertrophic scars. Early therapy of acne can prevent post-acne scarring, while severe scars can lead to psychological distress, including depression, anxiety, and poor self-esteem. Evaluating scar type and severity is crucial to select the most suitable treatment. Research and development in acne scar treatments are now focusing on addressing the psychological impact of these scars, emphasizing the importance of comprehensive therapy for optimal results.

site_title: Streaming services battle Netflix for Arab audiences
summary: Streaming services, including Netflix, Starz Play, and Wavo, are competing for Arab audiences in the Middle East, with a focus on the Ramadan season. Netflix plans to release its first Arabic production in June. Local competitors are offering original content and acquiring international titles to attract viewers. The battle for market share is expected to be fierce, with a potentially lucrative market at stake.

site_title: mm2 Asia posts 7.1% drop in Q4 earnings; DBS upgrades rating to 'buy' as value emerges
summary: mm2 Asia, a film production company, reported a 7.1% drop in Q4 earnings to S$6.2 million, with revenue and gross profit also decreasing 6.5% and 0.7% respectively. Despite this, DBS upgraded its rating to 'buy' as value emerges, citing mm2 Asia's strong track record and growth potential.

site_title: Singapore housing loans shrink again, with overall lending flat in April: MAS data
summary: Singapore's housing loans shrank for a third consecutive month in April, with a net of S$202.76 billion, down from S$203.38 billion in March. Consumer loans fell to S$264.57 billion, and overall bank lending remained flat. The decline was attributed to the cooling measures put in place to stabilize the property cycle, which has been in its 11th month. Business lending growth also slowed, inching up to S$411.69 billion, while total lending rose 1.4% year-on-year.

images.alt_text: Bank lending in Singapore was flat in April from a month ago, bogged by a continued contraction in consumer loans and moderated growth in business lending, preliminary data from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) showed on Friday.

site_title: Australian dollar steady against greenback, weakens versus yen to test support
summary: The Australian dollar remained steady against the US dollar, but weakened against the yen due to concerns over US President Donald Trump's aggressive trade diplomacy, which could lead to recession. Investors dumped shares and sought safer assets, including bonds, amid fears of a US trade war with China. The yen's value tested its support level, while the US dollar remained relatively stable. The US stock market continued to edge towards fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching new highs.

site_title: Trump to formally announce his re-election bid on June 18
summary: US President Donald Trump will formally announce his re-election bid on June 18 at a rally in Orlando, Florida, with his wife Melania, vice-president Mike Pence, and other family members in attendance. The announcement comes as Trump faces mounting Democratic calls for his impeachment, particularly from Democratic frontrunner Joe Biden, who has taken a substantial lead in early polling. Trump's re-election bid is seen as a challenge to Biden's efforts to win back the Midwestern, white, male blue-collar voters who supported Trump in 2016.

site_title: Singapore shares sink 1% at Friday's open after Trump announces Mexico tariffs
summary: Singapore stocks dropped 1% at Friday's open after US President Donald Trump announced plans to impose a 5% tariff on all imported goods from Mexico starting June 10, citing efforts to stop illegal immigration. The Straits Times Index fell 31.51 points to 3,111.49, with losers outnumbering gainers 97 to 35. Key sectors, including banking and automakers with Mexico plants, also saw declines.

site_title: Are you holding too much cash?
summary: Investors may be holding too much cash, as high cash holdings can prevent them from reaching investment return targets. A survey found that cash accounts for a third of individual portfolios, with millennials holding the largest amount in cash. Holding more than 0-11% of cash in an investment portfolio may indicate that the cash is not earning a sufficient risk-adjusted return. Investors can re-evaluate their cash allocation by considering alternative low-risk investment options and building a disciplined strategy for deploying cash as dry powder.

site_title: Jho Low fights to reclaim family mansion seized in 1MDB case
summary: Fugitive financier Jho Low is fighting the seizure of his mother's mansion in Penang, Malaysia, as part of a RM680 million civil forfeiture action related to 1MDB. Low claims his family has lived in the property since 2000, citing a certificate of occupation dated July 2000. The government alleges the assets were bought using siphoned 1MDB funds. Low's lawyers are contesting the seizure, arguing that the property predated 1MDB.

site_title: Singapore shares extend dip on Friday, down 1.6% on the week
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,117.76, down 25.24 points or 0.8% on Friday, marking a 1.6% weekly decline. The decline follows disappointing Chinese manufacturing figures and a US tariff threat on Mexico. Regional markets were mixed, with Australia, Malaysia, and South Korea ending higher, while China, Hong Kong, and Japan were lower. The STI has lost 9.1% in May.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares inch down in early trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks edged down in early trade on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index losing 0.14% to 27,077.30, following US President Donald Trump's announcement of tariffs on all Mexican imports.

site_title: Melco buy-in triggers regulatory review of Crown Resorts' US$1.5b Sydney casino
summary: The New South Wales gambling regulator will review its 2014 approval of Crown Resorts' US$1.5 billion Sydney casino after billionaire James Packer sold nearly half his stake in the company to Hong Kong's Melco Resorts, potentially violating a condition that prohibited business dealings with Stanley Ho, Melco's CEO. The regulator's review raises uncertainty about the project's future, which had been seen as a key growth prospect for Crown. The sale also increases the risk of a full takeover by Wynn Resorts Ltd, which had made an earlier approach to buy the company.

images.alt_text: Crown's billionaire founder James Packer sold nearly half his stake in the company to Hong Kong's Melco Resorts. It is not certain if the New South Wales regulator would let Crown keep building its skyscraper with Melco's involvement.

site_title: Alliance Healthcare debuts on Catalist at 20.5 S cents, 2.5% higher than IPO price
summary: Alliance Healthcare Group made its debut on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board at 20.5 Singapore cents, 2.5% higher than its IPO price of 20 cents. The company received 480 valid applications for its public offer, amounting to S$3.7 million, and all 31 million available shares were subscribed to in the placement tranche, totaling S$6.2 million. The IPO was 1.5 times subscribed. Alliance Healthcare plans to use the net proceeds of S$4.5 million to expand its network of clinics and medical facilities, and invest in technology systems and pharmaceutical services.

site_title: Hong Kong to cull 4,700 pigs after second swine fever case found
summary: Hong Kong is set to cull 4,700 pigs after a second case of African swine fever was detected at a slaughterhouse near the border with China. The animal originated from a farm in Guangdong province, and importation from mainland China has been suspended. This is the second such case in a month, following a previous culling of 6,000 pigs. The government will close the slaughterhouse for cleansing and disinfection, and pork imports from China have been suspended. The move aims to prevent the spread of the virus, which is fatal to pigs but not to humans.

site_title: Asia: Markets fall after Trump announces Mexico tariffs
summary: US President Donald Trump announced tariffs on all Mexican imports, starting June 10, with duties gradually increasing until "illegal migrants" stop coming into the US through Mexico. Asian stocks fell, with Japanese automakers plummeting 3-6% after the announcement. Markets are anxious about the prolonged trade war between the US and China, with investors awaiting the June 28-29 G-20 summit for potential negotiations. Oil prices dropped after a smaller-than-expected US crude supply drop, with US production at an all-time high.

site_title: HC Surgical acquiring 25% of GP clinic operator Medistar for S$480,000
summary: HC Surgical Specialists is acquiring 25% of GP clinic operator Medistar Services for S$480,000. The acquisition will fund the deal through net proceeds from its initial public offering in 2016. The deal is part of HC Surgical's expansion plans to increase its GP network. This marks the first major acquisition by the company since its IPO.

site_title: US inflation picks up; slowing economy likely to curb rise
summary: US inflation rose by 0.3% in April, the largest gain in 15 months, as consumer prices increased, but consumer spending slowed down at a 1.3% annualised rate in the first quarter, the slowest in a year. The Federal Reserve's preferred inflation measure, the core PCE price index, rose 1.6% in the 12 months through April, meeting the central bank's 2% target. The data suggests economic growth is slowing, but the strong labour market and rising wages are supporting consumer spending, with personal income and wages increasing in April.

site_title: Japan's factory output rebounds, but retail sales slow as trade war risks grow
summary: Japan's industrial output rebounded 0.6% in April, driven by increased production of cars, airplane parts, and electronics, but retail sales slowed to 0.5% year-over-year. The data suggests domestic and external demand may come under pressure due to the intensifying Sino-US trade war. Economists warn that Japan's economy may require stimulus if growth prospects deteriorate further, citing weak demand in the semiconductor and electronics sectors.

site_title: Managing misconduct in the financial advisory sector
summary: Effective supervisors in the financial advisory sector must enact policies and procedures to encourage compliance and investigate and punish employee misconduct when it arises. A case involving Samuel, a supervisor at Roundtree Securities Inc., highlights the importance of effective supervision. Despite having an email monitoring system in place and initiating an investigation, Samuel's deference to Wong's seniority led to inadequate action, allowing misconduct to continue. The case emphasizes the need for supervisors to have in-depth knowledge of applicable laws and regulations, and for firms to have clear policies and procedures in place to address misconduct.

site_title: Creative gains 15% after revealing plans to integrate Super X-Fi tech into gaming laptops
summary: Creative Technology shares surged 14.8% after revealing plans to integrate its Super X-Fi technology into Clevo's gaming laptops. The company's shares gained as much as 19.2% during Friday's session. Creative's Super X-Fi technology can be integrated into Clevo's laptop design, which includes the Super X-Fi UltraDSP chip. This move comes after the company's positive response at the CES tech trade show in the US. Orders will depend on uptake from Clevo's customers, with the company focusing on OEM partnerships to take Super X-Fi to market.

site_title: Temasek's philanthropy arm sets up Asia-focused private equity fund for impact investing
summary: Temasek's philanthropic arm, Temasek Trust, has established the ABC World Asia fund, a private equity fund focused on impact investing in South Asia, Southeast Asia, and China. The fund aims to generate a positive social or environmental impact alongside a risk-adjusted return, with initial themes including financial and digital inclusion, education, and sustainable development. The fund complements Temasek's ABC Framework for an Active Economy, and is supported by Temasek Holdings and Pavilion Capital.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.54 points to 1,640.04 at 9am on Friday, with 50.85 million lots traded worth RM21.97 million. The market saw 102 losers beat 87 gainers.

site_title: South Korea's central bank keeps rates on hold as trade pressure builds
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, kept interest rates unchanged at 1.75% for a fourth consecutive meeting amid a slowdown in exports and muted inflation. Policymakers are under pressure to ease policy due to a longer, costlier US-China trade conflict, but concerns about a potential won rout and capital flight risks have held them back. Analysts expect a rate cut between now and 2020, with markets already pricing in a potential policy change, as the economy faces further weakening due to an intensifying tariff dispute with China and the US.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Korea is under pressure to join regional counterparts from New Zealand to India in easing policy to tackle growing headwinds, but has so far held back due to concerns about a potential rout in the won, Asia's worst performing currency this year, and capital flight risks.

site_title: Mirach Energy names new CEO; Chan Shut Li to remain executive chairman
summary: Mirach Energy has named Liu Kaichun as its new CEO, replacing Chan Shut Li, who will remain executive chairman. Liu will focus on "rejuvenating and expanding" the company's business. The change is part of Mirach's succession planning and follows a 15-month extension granted by the Singapore Exchange to cure its watch-list status. The company's shares traded flat at S$0.21 on the news.

site_title: US 30-year mortgage rates drop below 4%
summary: US 30-year mortgage rates dropped below 4% for the first time since January 2018, averaging 3.99% in the week ending May 30. This decline is linked to falling US bond yields amid US-China trade tensions. The 15-year mortgage rate fell to 3.46% and 5-year adjustable mortgage rates averaged 3.6%. The rate drop is seen as a sign of weakening financial sentiment, but Freddie Mac's chief economist believes cheaper borrowing costs will support the housing market.

site_title: India's growth rate drops behind China to lowest in more than four years
summary: India's economy grew at 5.8% in the January-March quarter, the lowest in more than four years, behind China's 6.4% growth rate. The slowdown is attributed to weak consumption demand and private investment. The government is considering fiscal stimulus and a rate cut to boost the economy. Finance Secretary Subhash Chandra Garg expects the economy to grow "relatively slower" this quarter but turn around from the July-September quarter. The government may also cut taxes in its upcoming budget to boost demand.

site_title: Star Wars theme park opens at Disneyland
summary: Star Wars fans gathered outside Disneyland for the opening of Star Wars: Galaxy's Edge, a $1 billion theme park. The park was initially open only to those who reserved tickets, allowing them to experience the attraction for four hours. The land will be open to the public after three weeks, with limited access for the initial period. The highly anticipated theme park marks a major expansion for the California park.

site_title: China's factory outlook worsens as trade war heats up again
summary: China's manufacturing sector outlook worsened in May, with the manufacturing purchasing managers' index dropping to 49.4, below the forecast of 49.9. This indicates a contraction. The non-manufacturing gauge remained steady at 54.3. The escalation of the trade standoff with the US has contributed to the decline. Chinese investors remain optimistic, expecting Beijing to intervene and support the economy. The weak manufacturing data raises pressure on policymakers to address the economic slowdown.

site_title: Housing loans shrink for a third consecutive month
summary: Singapore's housing loans shrank for a third consecutive month in April, with mortgages booked at S$202.76 billion, down from S$203.38 billion in March. Overall consumer loans fell to S$264.57 billion, while overall bank lending remained flat. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has stabilized the property cycle, which was at risk of outpacing fundamentals last year. Moody's Investors Service expects domestic loan growth to remain modest at 5% in 2019, mainly from corporate and SME sectors.

site_title: Mexico says Trump tariff move 'disastrous,' vows to retaliate
summary: US President Donald Trump announced a 5% tariff on all Mexican goods in response to migrant border crossings, prompting Mexico's top diplomat Jesus Seade to call it "disastrous" and vow retaliation. Seade stated that if the tariffs are implemented, Mexico will respond "vigorously." The move is expected to have significant economic implications for both countries and the global market.

site_title: SPH prices S$150m perpetual notes at 4.5%; notes sold at par
summary: SPH priced S$150 million subordinated perpetual notes at a 4.5% distribution rate, yielding 261.2 basis points over the five-year swap offer rate. The notes were sold at par, with a private-bank concession of 25 basis points. The perpetuals may be called after five years, with a distribution rate stepping up by 100 basis points if not redeemed.

site_title: Japan's factory output rebounds, but retail sales slow as trade risks grow
summary: Japan's factory output rebounded in April, but retail sales grew at a slower pace, indicating potential pressure on the economy due to the intensifying Sino-US trade war. Analysts caution that a quick resolution to the trade row is unlikely, and it's too early to be optimistic about Japan's factory output. The US-China trade tensions are expected to impact both domestic and external demand, posing a significant challenge to Japan's economy.

site_title: US preparing antitrust probe of Google: report
summary: The US Department of Justice is preparing an antitrust investigation of Google, citing unnamed sources, amid growing backlash against major tech companies. The investigation will focus on Google's practices related to web search and other businesses. This comes as Alphabet's profit in the first quarter of 2023 fell 29% due to a European antitrust fine, and Google faces pressure worldwide from regulators over alleged abuse of its dominance in internet search, advertising, and mobile systems. Democratic presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren has argued for breaking up big firms like Google, Facebook, and Apple through antitrust enforcement.

site_title: KOP shrinks Q4 loss to S$418,000 on higher revenue from Indonesia luxury hotels
summary: KOP, a Catalist-listed property developer, reported a Q4 net loss of S$418,000, narrowing from S$9.0 million last year. Revenue rose 46.6% to S$4.8 million, driven by higher income from Indonesian luxury resorts. Full-year net loss was S$5.7 million, down from S$7.8 million last year. Gross profit for Q4 almost doubled to S$2.4 million, while operating income fell 98% to S$100,000.

site_title: The bond market is trying to tell us something
summary: The US bond market is sending warning signs that a recession may be imminent, despite the lack of specificity. Falling yields, particularly in the long-term, are a rare occurrence, having preceded every recession over the past 60 years. Inflation expectations are also dropping, with investors' expectations for inflation over the next five years falling to about 1.60 percentage points, a sign that the bond market sees no inflation ahead. The yield curve is inverted, with long-term yields lower than short-term yields, and investors are betting on a rate cut by the Federal Reserve, which could be a sign of economic weakness.

site_title: Trump to impose 5% tariff on all Mexican imports over illegal immigration
summary: US President Donald Trump announced on May 30, 2019, that the United States will impose a 5% tariff on all Mexican imports starting June 10 until illegal immigration is stopped. The tariff will gradually increase until the issue is remedied, with the tariffs to be removed thereafter. The move was met with surprise from Vietnam, which sought a lower rate, and concerns from the Asian garment industry.

site_title: Mary Chia narrows fiscal 2019 loss to S$2.7m
summary: Mary Chia Holdings, a CATALIST-listed company, has reported a narrowed net loss of S$2.7 million for the full year ended March 31, 2019, from S$6.0 million a year ago. The loss per share decreased to 1.64 Singapore cents, despite a 2.5% decline in revenue to S$8.9 million. The company attributed the improvement to a one-time gain from the sale of a property and increased revenue from its direct selling segment. The group plans to conserve cash for expansion and rebranding efforts, with no dividend declared for the quarter.

site_title: Federal Reserve watching potential economic risks: official
summary: The US economy is expected to experience solid growth with strong hiring and low inflation, according to Federal Reserve Vice-Chairman Richard Clarida. Despite predictions of potential interest rate cuts, Clarida remains optimistic and emphasized the Fed's willingness to adjust its course if needed to address any economic risks. Clarida's comments come as the central bank continues to monitor the economy's performance.

site_title: Saudi king calls on Gulf states to tackle Iran's 'criminal' acts
summary: Saudi King Salman urged Gulf Arab states to work together to confront Iran's "criminal" actions, including interference in regional affairs, nuclear and missile programs, and threats to global oil supply. The king's comment came after US National Security Advisor John Bolton accused Iran of sabotaging four ships, including two Saudi oil tankers. Iran strongly rejected the accusation, and Yemeni rebels have stepped up drone attacks on Saudi Arabia. The talks aim to discuss the standoff with Iran and ways to isolate Tehran amid fears of a military confrontation.

images.alt_text: Saudi Arabia's King Salman on Thursday urged Gulf Arab states to work together to confront what he called Iran's "criminal" actions in the region.

site_title: ChildAid searching for potential stars
summary: ChildAid, a 15th edition fundraising concert, is holding auditions for child and youth talents aged 6-19 who can sing, dance, or play an instrument. The concert, to be held at the Esplanade Theatre in November, aims to discover fresh talents to support financially disadvantaged children. The event, organized by The Business Times and The Straits Times, will raise funds for arts training and school support programs, with a focus on fresh talents to build on past performers like Nathan Hartono and Janani Sridhar.

images.alt_text: ChildAid raises funds for The Business Times Budding Artists Fund (BTBAF) and The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund (STSPMF). Over the years, the two funds have raised over S$18 million and assisted more than 175,000 children and youth.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Pacific Star, Vallianz, Samurai 2K, Mary Chia, KOP, Sevak, Addvalue Tech, USP
summary: Singapore stocks saw mixed developments on Friday, with some companies posting significant losses and others seeing flat shares. Pacific Star Development liquidated its aluminium business, while Vallianz Holdings incurred a net loss of US$128.2 million. Samurai 2K Aerosol's net profit decreased 10.8% to RM10.4 million, and Mary Chia Holdings narrowed its net loss to S$2.7 million. KOP posted a S$418,000 net loss in its fourth quarter, while Sevak exited the Singapore Exchange's watch-list. Addvalue Technologies narrowed its net loss to US$3.74 million, and USP Group saw a net loss of S$21.3 million.

site_title: Amazon interested in buying Boost from T-Mobile, Sprint: sources
summary: Amazon is reportedly interested in buying prepaid wireless service Boost Mobile from T-Mobile and Sprint, with the deal potentially fetching up to $3 billion. The acquisition would allow Amazon to use T-Mobile's wireless network for at least six years and gain access to wireless spectrum. The move aims to reduce market share in the prepaid wireless business and gain regulatory approval for the planned $26 billion merger between T-Mobile and Sprint, which could leave the US with only three wireless carriers. The US Justice Department would need to scrutinize the buyer to ensure it stays viable and preserves competition.

images.alt_text: Amazon.com Inc is interested in buying prepaid cellphone wireless service Boost Mobile from US carriers T-Mobile US Inc and Sprint Corp, two sources familiar with the matter said on Thursday.

site_title: James Packer sells Crown Resorts stake to casino mogul Ho
summary: Australian billionaire James Packer sold nearly half his stake in Crown Resorts to Hong Kong casino mogul Lawrence Ho for A$1.8 billion. Packer's stake now stands at 26% after the sale, which saw Ho's Melco Resorts and Entertainment acquire 19.99% of the company. The deal comes as Crown faces revenue decline due to a drop in high-roller spending, particularly from China. Ho's investment is seen as a strategic move to help Crown's success, particularly with the launch of its Sydney casino.

site_title: World must do all 'humanly possible' on climate change: Merkel
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel urged the world to take "everything humanly possible" to combat climate change, emphasizing that humans are the cause of the crisis. She pledged to do her part, including achieving Germany's goal of climate neutrality by 2050. In a commencement address at Harvard University, Merkel also praised European cooperation and criticized attacks on free trade and democracy. Her term as chancellor ends in 2021, leaving open the possibility of a new beginning for her after her time in politics.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open down after Trump announces Mexico tariffs
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 0.79% on May 31, 2019, after US President Donald Trump announced a 5% tariff on all goods from Mexico. Automaker shares dropped sharply. The Nikkei 225 index fell 164.66 points to 20,777.87, while the Topix index fell 11.72 points to 1,520.26.

site_title: Fracking with CO2 instead of water could be more efficient: study
summary: A study led by Chinese scientists found that using carbon dioxide instead of water for hydraulic fracturing (fracking) can be more efficient in extracting oil and natural gas, with oil production increasing by 4-20 fold. This method could reduce environmental impact by trapping CO2 underground, removing it from the atmosphere. However, some experts argue that the overall effect on global greenhouse gas emissions is unclear and may be counter-productive due to the combustion of hydrocarbons released by the process.

site_title: Trump begins North American trade deal ratification process despite objections: top Democrat
summary: President Donald Trump initiated the ratification process of the US-Mexico-Canada Agreement, despite objections from House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, who called it a "lack of knowledge" on the Administration's policy and process. The agreement updates the 25-year-old North American Free Trade Agreement, but Pelosi expressed concerns it would benefit American workers and farmers before the agreement is finalized.

site_title: Trump would be 'in handcuffs' if not president, says Democrat Warren
summary: Democratic presidential hopeful Elizabeth Warren says US President Donald Trump would be "in handcuffs and indicted" if not for his presidential status, claiming he would face obstruction charges. Warren made the statement after special counsel Robert Mueller's report found 10 possible acts of obstruction by Trump, but Mueller was bound by a policy that prevents indicting a sitting president. Despite Warren's call for impeachment proceedings, Democrats are reluctant to begin the process during the 2020 election campaign, citing potential voter backlash and the likely failure in the Republican-led Senate.

site_title: Mexico sends North America free trade deal to lawmakers
summary: Mexico has sent the revised North American free trade deal, the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), to Congress, marking the start of the ratification process. The deal, signed in November, aims to revamp rules on manufacturing, digital commerce, and labor rights. The agreement is crucial for Mexico, a major exporter under the old North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA), with 80% of its exports going to the US. Ratification is expected to pass in Mexico, but faces an uphill battle in the US House of Representatives, controlled by Trump's Democratic opponents.

site_title: Trump admits, briefly, that Russia boosted his election
summary: President Donald Trump acknowledged for the first time that Russia helped him win the 2016 presidential election, but later retracted the statement and launched a fiery attack on Special Counsel Robert Mueller. Trump initially tweeted that Russia's involvement had "disappeared" since he had "nothing to do" with it. This admission came amid a heated exchange between Trump and Mueller over the possibility of impeachment.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump acknowledged for the first time Thursday that Moscow helped him win the White House in 2016 - before retracting himself to launch a fiery attack on Robert Mueller and the Russia probe.

site_title: UK consumer sentiment jumps to 8-month high in May: GfK
summary: British consumers reported a 8-month high in sentiment in May, with the GfK consumer sentiment index rising to -10, beating forecasts. The improvement was attributed to high employment and wage growth, but a bleak assessment of the broader economy. In contrast, business morale sank to +10 in May, down from +14 in April, reflecting concerns over Brexit's impact on trading prospects. The uncertainty surrounding Brexit's departure from the EU remains a concern for the economy.

site_title: R Kelly hit with 11 new sex crime charges
summary: R&B superstar R Kelly has been hit with 11 new sex crime charges in a refiling of counts from an existing case. The charges, filed by Chicago prosecutors, relate to the alleged abuse of a woman identified as JP between 2010 and 2011. The new charges include three counts of child sexual abuse and accusations of using force or threats against JP. Kelly, 52, denies the charges and claims his accusers are lying. He is currently out on bail and will appear in court on June 6.

site_title: Pacific Star appoints RSM to liquidate aluminium business
summary: Pacific Star Development appoints RSM Corporate Advisory to liquidate its aluminium business division, following shareholder and creditor approval. The move is expected to free up resources for the company's property development business, which accounts for the majority of its revenue. The aluminium division, which contributed S$3.9 million of the group's total revenue in 2018, has been facing strong industry competition and is considered relatively insignificant. Joint and several liquidators Chee Yoh Chuang and Lin Yueh Hung will oversee the liquidation process, with Andrew Seet resigning as group general manager and executive vice-president.

site_title: Oil falls to 2-month lows on small US crude stock draw, trade war worries
summary: Oil prices fell to 2-month lows due to a smaller-than-expected decline in US crude inventories and concerns over the US-China trade war. US crude stockpiles fell 300,000 barrels, less than forecast, and Brent futures dropped 3.7% to $66.87 a barrel. The US-China trade war is expected to remain a key driver weighing on oil prices, with global demand growth forecast to slow to 0.7% this year. Oil prices have been supported by output cuts from OPEC and Iran, but are now capped due to weakening demand.

site_title: As unicorns emerge, angels gather for the hunt
summary: Angel investing clubs have emerged in Singapore, catering to affluent individuals seeking to invest in South-east Asian unicorns. These clubs, such as AngelCentral and she1K, source startups, conduct due diligence, and provide members with opportunities to tap into expertise and networks. Members pay a joining fee and gain access to curated deal flows, share investment costs, and attend events. Angel investing is considered a high-risk, high-reward asset class, requiring both financial and non-financial resources. Executives emphasize the importance of diversification and portfolio management to mitigate risks.

site_title: Renault and Fiat Chrysler stuck over merger terms: report
summary: Talks between Fiat Chrysler and Renault have stalled over the proposed 50-50 merger due to disagreements on financial terms. Renault is seeking sweeter terms, citing its share price has fallen since the arrest of former CEO Carlos Ghosn. Fiat Chrysler believes the offer is fair and has been approved by its board, stating it's a take-it-or-leave-it deal. The merged entity would be the world's third-largest automaker, with advantages for both companies in electric vehicles and industrial strength. Renault's board has yet to adopt a position on the proposal.

site_title: PODCAST: Catch up with XM Studios, a winner at Emerging Enterprise Award 2018
summary: XM Studios, a winner of the Emerging Enterprise Award 2018, is featured in a podcast. The award celebrates the bold ambition of young businesses under 10 years old, highlighting their innovation, resilience, and excellence in the Singapore economy.

site_title: Alaskan oil shipped to China for first time in almost a year: data
summary: Alaska is set to ship one million barrels of crude oil to China for the first time in almost a year, according to data from Refinitiv Eikon and Kpler. The shipment, carried by the tanker Sonangol Cabinda, is due to arrive in Qingdao, China on June 6. This marks a significant increase from the 41,600 barrels per day (bpd) of US crude imports China has received in the past six months, down from 377,000 bpd in the first half of 2018. The shipment is a rare boost to China's oil imports.

site_title: Singapore leaps three places to rank second in global cities outlook list
summary: Singapore has jumped to second place on the Global Cities Outlook list for 2019, surpassing cities like San Francisco and Paris. The city's strong performance in economics, innovation, governance, and personal well-being led to its ranking. To reach the top spot, Singapore needs to improve in the cultural experience dimension. The report also highlights rising trends, including uncertainty in Brexit and populism in the West, which have affected the attractiveness of various cities. Cities in China are rising rapidly, with significant gains in governance scores.

site_title: Uber posts US$1b loss in Q1 on growing revenue
summary: Uber reported a US$1 billion loss in Q1 despite a 20% revenue increase to US$3.1 billion, with an average of 17 million trips per day. The loss was in line with Wall Street expectations, and shares rose 2.9% to US$40.97. Despite the disappointing start, CEO Dara Khosrowshahi aims to develop a global brand and transform local transportation. The company plans to invest in 2019 and envisions becoming the "Amazon of transportation" through its platform. Uber's losses since 2011 have been billions, but the company remains focused on achieving profitability.

site_title: BreadTalk, Song Fa take pork rib soup to Taiwan
summary: BreadTalk Group, a Singapore-based food and beverage company, has partnered with Song Fa Holdings to expand into Taiwan. Food Republic Taiwan will operate the Song Fa Bak Kut Teh brand for 10 years, with two outlets set to open in Taipei in the second half of the year. This marks Song Fa's first entry into the Taiwanese market, and BreadTalk aims to reach 18 Song Fa restaurants across Thailand, China, and Taiwan by the end of the year.

site_title: Europe: Stocks gain, propped up by media firms
summary: European stocks rose 0.4% on Thursday, driven by media firms' best day in nearly five months, despite a potential decline in the main regional index. Germany's DAX and the Stoxx 600 gained 0.5% and 0.4% respectively, while media firms like Axel Springer and Daily Mail and General Trust rose 22.2% and 9.6%. However, tariff-sensitive stocks fell 0.3%, and utilities stocks slid 0.9% due to a profit warning from De La Rue Plc. The Stoxx 600 is set for its first monthly decline of 2019, with European and US firms' earnings growth expected to remain anemic for the year.

site_title: Six Capital's ex-boss Patrick Teng sets up virtual currency firm
summary: Singaporean entrepreneur Patrick Teng, former CEO of Six Capital Investments, has set up a new virtual currency firm called Clover Gold. Following the liquidation of Six Capital, which was wound up due to investors' complaints and debts of around $143 million, Teng founded Clover Gold last September. The firm sells virtual currency online with a disclaimer stating it does not accept liability for any losses. Teng has a history of controversies, including a 2005 fine by the Monetary Authority of Singapore for selling unauthorized stored-value cards.

images.alt_text: Patrick Teng Chee Wai's LinkedIn account says he founded Clover Gold last September. He had filed for Six Cap to be wound up.

site_title: Provoking trade rows is 'naked economic terrorism', says China
summary: China's Vice Foreign Minister Zhang Hanhui labeled provoking trade disputes as "naked economic terrorism" amid the ongoing US-China trade war. China opposes the use of tariffs and protectionism, stating that everyone loses in a trade war, which will have a serious negative effect on global economic development. China is intensifying its criticism of the US and has hinted at using its dominant position as an exporter of rare earths as leverage in the trade war. The country is confident in its ability to safeguard its sovereignty and economic interests despite the escalating tensions.

site_title: Time Warp
summary: The House of Hermes is showcasing its new watches in a 'time observatory' at Ngee Ann City from May 30 to June 2. The exhibit features a colorful labyrinth with light, sound, and motion effects, where visitors can interact with timepieces such as Arceau L'heure de la lune and Carre H. The goal is to create an immersive experience where time and playfulness blend, inviting visitors to have fun with Hermes' horological and creative essence.

site_title: Foul smells aplenty at London's 19th-century Palace of Westminster
summary: London's 19th-century Palace of Westminster has seen a surge in complaints of foul smells, attributed to its outdated Victorian plumbing system. With 14,500 politicians and staff, and hundreds of thousands of visitors annually, the strain is evident.
