However, critics argue that algorithms can be untested in crisis situations and lack transparency. The ideal solution may be a hybrid offering that balances human confidence with digital solutions, allowing investors to customize their portfolios while minimizing risk. Ultimately, the suitability of robo-advisers for retail investors depends on individual preferences and investment goals.

site_title: Hungary to build green-powered town from scratch
summary: Hungary plans to build a one-billion-euro, 500-pitch-sized green-powered town on a Danube flood plain, featuring solar and biogas power, 1,000 homes, and 5,000 jobs. The Hegyeshalom-Bezenye project, a collaboration between EON, FAKT, and the Hungarian government, will include a greenhouse, fishery, schools, and shopping facilities. The carbon-neutral town aims to serve as a model for other clean energy conversions across Europe, with sustainable water management and geothermal cooling systems.

site_title: Asia Pulp & Paper products to be back on Singapore shelves
summary: Asia Pulp & Paper (APP) has received the Singapore Environment Council's (SEC) enhanced Green Label certification, allowing its products to return to Singapore shelves after a 4-year ban due to its alleged link to forest fires in Indonesia. The company underwent a 25-point audit and implemented measures to ensure its supply chain is responsibly managed, including a zero-burning policy and comprehensive risk management profiling. APP has invested over $100 million in fire prevention and management systems since 2015, resulting in a marked reduction in forest fires.

site_title: Daily digest
summary: Former CapitaLand CEO Lim Ming Yan is appointed as an independent director to the board of Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) on June 3. Allied Technologies executive director Kenneth Low Si Ren is investigated by commercial crime police. HSBC expands its Singapore insurance business with new products. CapitaLand aims to complete its acquisition of Ascendas-Singbridge by the end of June. US companies face trade war tensions with China.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Nam Cheong secured RM80 million contracts for three offshore support vessels, contributing positively to its financial performance until 2022. SunMoon Food Company reversed into a net loss of S$4.3 million, despite a 62% revenue rise, due to fair value losses on financial liabilities. Accrelist proposed a consolidation of existing shares, while Innopac Holdings' application for more time to satisfy listing requirements was rejected by the Singapore Exchange, leading to a delisting notice. The rejection will prevent Innopac's circular from being cleared to shareholders. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed.

site_title: CIMB posts first quarterly profit drop since 2015
summary: CIMB Group Holdings Bhd reported its first quarterly profit drop since 2015, with a net profit of RM1.19 billion in the first quarter, down from RM1.31 billion in the same period last year. The lender flagged a challenging year ahead due to trade tensions and macro-economic headwinds. CIMB's consumer, corporate segments, and investment banking unit also reported losses. Despite a 3% drop in revenue, the bank's total gross loans grew 7.6% and deposits rose 5.6%.

site_title: Boeing 737 MAX may not return to service until August: Iata
summary: The Boeing 737 MAX is expected to return to service until August, according to IATA's head Alexandre de Juniac. The airline group's director general stated that the final decision rests with regulators, and a summit is planned with airlines, regulators, and Boeing to discuss what's needed for the plane's re-entry. US operators have already removed the planes from their schedules until early to mid August, contradicting the FAA's expected approval for late June.

site_title: Trade spat shifts business away from 'Factory of the World'
summary: The US-China trade war has led to a surge in companies relocating their production from China to South-east Asia and beyond, with Vietnam, Cambodia, India, and Indonesia emerging as new manufacturing hubs. Brands such as Casio, Ricoh, and Steve Madden are shifting production to these countries to avoid US tariffs, taking advantage of low-cost labor, tax incentives, and close proximity to China's supply chains. The shift is expected to continue, potentially redefining global trade patterns and ending China's dominance as the "Factory of the World."

site_title: United Food sees quarterly net loss widen to 27.6m yuan
summary: United Food Holdings reported a widened quarterly net loss of 27.6 million yuan (S$5.5 million) for the three months ended March 31, despite a revenue increase of 3.5 times to 10 million yuan. The loss per share widened to 0.17 yuan, and no dividend was declared. The company attributed the loss to a volatile business landscape due to trade developments between China and the US, as well as exchange rate volatility.

site_title: Hey, mom and pop, tell us again how you price those PE bonds
summary: Singapore's retail investors may be ill-equipped to value private equity-backed collateralized fund obligations, as seen in the 2018 Hyflux debacle. Azalea Asset Management's upcoming public offering of PE bonds may attract strong interest from retail investors who rely on brand recognition and headlines rather than thorough analysis. Regulators and issue managers need to improve transparency and user-friendly explanations of complex structures and risks to help retail investors make informed decisions.

site_title: Hyflux in talks with seven parties; aims to pick suitor by mid-June
summary: Hyflux, a Singapore-based water cleaning firm, is in talks with seven potential investors, aiming to secure a cash infusion by mid-June. The company plans to meet stakeholders, draw up terms of a restructuring scheme, and apply for leave to convene scheme meetings for creditors by July. If all goes according to plan, the restructuring process will be completed in September, with a court-sanctioned extension granted by Justice Aedit Abdullah until August 2.

site_title: STI slips further amid trade woes
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.1% lower at 3,163.28 points, following a decline in Asian markets amid trade woes and growth concerns. US equities fell after a rally in 10-year Treasuries, with historically low yields signaling a possible recession. Local stocks, including Genting Singapore, DBS Group Holdings, and United Overseas Bank, also fell. However, Singtel shares rebounded, and Sheng Siong added 1.9% to its price. The decline in oil prices also impacted smaller oil and gas players.

site_title: UK PM candidate Johnson to face court over Brexit claims
summary: UK Prime Minister candidate Boris Johnson must appear in court over allegations he lied about Brexit by stating Britain would be £350 million better off outside the EU. A judge ruled that Johnson must answer a private summons alleging he committed three offences of misconduct in a public office, despite the allegations not being proven. Johnson's lawyers argue the case is a political stunt, and polls suggest he is well ahead of other candidates in the Conservative Party leadership contest. The case will proceed to the Crown Court for trial.

site_title: Venezuela reports key economic data; GDP plunges 22.5% in Q3 '18
summary: Venezuela's central bank released its first major economic data in over three years, showing a 22.5% GDP plunge in Q3 2018, with inflation soaring to 130,060% in 2018. The data contradicts private economists' estimates, with the IMF projecting a 25% GDP drop for 2019. The report also shows a significant underestimation of inflation, with the bank's figures differing from Bloomberg's Cafe Con Leche Index and the IMF's projections. The publication marks a significant step towards transparency in Venezuela's economy, which has been ravaged by crisis.

site_title: Much ado about audit opinions
summary: A "qualified opinion" on IHH Healthcare Bhd's financial statements by KPMG in April led to a 5% drop in stock price, highlighting the importance of audit opinions for companies and investors. Audit opinions serve to assess the accuracy and reliability of financial statements, with "clean" opinions indicating no material errors. However, investors often misinterpret modified opinions, such as qualified or adverse opinions, as "dirty" or unreliable. Understanding the nuances of audit opinions, including qualified, adverse, and disclaimer of opinion, can help investors react more appropriately to news of companies failing to receive a clean opinion.

site_title: Bespoke fashion startups join forces for European expansion
summary: Bespoke fashion startups Outfittery and Modomoto are merging in an all-share deal to accelerate growth in Europe. The combined company, led by Outfittery's Julia Boesch, aims to become the European leader in personalized fashion shopping. The merged business targets revenue of over 100 million euros in 2020, with Outfittery accounting for two-thirds of joint sales. The deal expands the online menswear business, which has served nearly one million customers and achieved sales of 80 million euros in the past year.

site_title: Four teams to make debut at BT golf league
summary: The Business Times Corporate Golf League will feature 20 teams, including four debutants from OCBC Bank, CarTimes, RHT Management, and a joint team from HG Metals and Samwoh. The 10th anniversary tournament will take place in six legs, starting on July 12 at Sentosa Golf Club. The competition is presented by Audi Singapore, with the first-place team winning a hole-in-one Audi car. The event aims to promote friendly competition among companies and corporates, with networking and camaraderie being key aspects of the tournament.

site_title: US exchanges must face renewed high-frequency trading claims - judge
summary: A Manhattan federal judge has ordered seven US stock exchanges to face proposed class-action claims alleging they defrauded ordinary investors by enabling high-frequency traders to trade faster and at better prices. The exchanges, including BATS Global Markets, Nasdaq, and the New York Stock Exchange, were accused of providing advantages to favored high-frequency trading customers while concealing these services from ordinary investors. The judge's ruling reverses a 2015 dismissal of the claims, which had previously been overturned by a federal appeals court in 2017.

site_title: Court freezes 3 UK homes worth £80m to probe ownership
summary: A UK High Court judge has frozen the ownership of three London residential properties worth £80m linked to a high-profile suspect, while investigators scrutinize the source of funds used to buy the assets. The properties, held by offshore companies, are connected to an official in a foreign country. The move is part of a new law allowing authorities to block assets without proof of illegality, with the aim of preventing money laundering and protecting the UK economy. This is the second time a UWO has been secured, following a similar case in February 2018.

site_title: ECB worries about rising risks to financial stability
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has expressed concerns over rising risks to financial stability in the euro zone, citing a slowing economy, high government debt, and a potential property bubble. The ECB warned that banks may struggle to generate returns, and that a global trade war could exacerbate market volatility. The bank also highlighted the risks of Brexit, particularly a no-deal scenario, which could dent economic growth and lead to sharp market swings. The ECB is considering measures to boost bank capital to mitigate these risks.

site_title: Softbank's Son gives 9.1b yen payday to recruit top talent
summary: SoftBank's billionaire CEO, Masayoshi Son, has paid a total of 9.1 billion yen (S$115.2 million) in compensation to six executives, including former Goldman Sachs executive Katsunori Sago and Nomura Holdings CEO, as part of his US$100 billion Vision Fund. This is one of the highest payouts in Japanese corporate history, with some executives earning billions of yen. The high pay is seen as a strategic move to attract top talent and is comparable to other global companies.

site_title: Braddell View another victim of moribund en bloc market
summary: The Singapore en bloc market has seen a lackluster start to the year, with no residential projects achieving a successful outcome. The mega Braddell View estate, valued at over S$2 billion, has reached its tender close with zero bids. Market watchers attribute this to factors such as the size of the estate and cooling measures implemented last July. In contrast, commercial en bloc sales have fared better, driven by an uptrend in commercial property rents. Experts suggest that developers are cautious about acquiring large sites, but some may be looking to sell their properties at reasonable prices.

images.alt_text: Braddell View's tender closed with no takers despite its prime location. It's seeking private negotiations.

site_title: Boeing 737 MAX may not return to service until August - IATA head
summary: Boeing's 737 MAX is unlikely to return to service before August, according to IATA Director General Alexandre de Juniac. The 737 MAX was grounded globally in March after a fatal crash in Ethiopia, with regulators holding the final say on its re-entry. IATA plans a summit to discuss what's needed for the plane's return, and US operators have removed the planes from their flight schedules until early to mid-August. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is expected to approve the jet's return to service as soon as late June.

site_title: Can businesses do good and prosper?
summary: Businesses can drive both social good and financial success by embracing digital disruption and harnessing the power of ecosystems. A study found that companies committed to sustainable development outperformed competitors by 11% in the stock market. The study highlights the potential of rural redevelopment to unlock $1 trillion of annual output by 2025, and the farm-to-fork and learn-to-earn ecosystems in South-east Asia offer significant opportunities for businesses to generate additional GDP. Digital platforms can connect traditional players with non-traditional industry players, unlocking value and driving growth in rural and semi-urban regions.

site_title: Mueller says he made no finding on whether Trump committed crime
summary: Special Counsel Robert Mueller stated he found insufficient evidence to charge a broader conspiracy involving the Trump campaign, but did not conclude whether President Donald Trump obstructed justice. Mueller announced the end of his Russia probe and won't provide additional information not already in his report, which was released with some redactions. Mueller found numerous links between the Russian government and the Trump campaign but did not establish a conspiracy. He chronicled 10 instances of Trump's attempts to obstruct the investigation, but was unable to reach a judgment on obstruction of justice.

site_title: US: S&P 500 opens at two-month low as trade tensions mount
summary: The S&P 500 opened at a two-month low on May 29, 2019, due to escalating trade tensions between the US and China. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.46% and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.71%. The US-China trade war fears led to a decline in global growth concerns.

site_title: Brick-and-mortar retail pumps up the volume
summary: Brick-and-mortar retail is experiencing a resurgence, with stores like Funan in Singapore and Dubai-based Al-Futtaim embracing innovative concepts to attract customers. Funan features an indoor cycling path, rooftop farm, and "retail pods" to disrupt the retail experience, achieving a 98% occupancy rate before opening. Meanwhile, Al-Futtaim prioritizes physical stores, believing that customers prefer to try products before buying. A startup, INSPIFY, has developed technology for luxury retailers to offer a seamless brick-and-click experience. This trend challenges the notion that e-commerce has made brick-and-mortar stores obsolete.

site_title: How small, open economies can ensure future prosperity
summary: Small, open economies like Singapore and the Netherlands can ensure future prosperity by embracing international trade, investing in infrastructure and human talent, and leveraging regional partnerships. Historically connected through Dutch economist Albert Winsemius, these countries have thrived by adapting to change and working with other cultures. To maintain success, small countries should avoid populistic nationalism, prioritize investment and talent, and actively cooperate with other regions to counteract protectionist practices and promote open trade. This strategy can foster societal adaptability and working with other cultures, ultimately preserving prosperity.

site_title: Braddell View another victim of moribund market
summary: Singapore's moribund market has claimed another victim, the 918-unit Braddell View residential site, which failed to meet the 80% owner consent threshold for collective sale. Other billion-dollar hopefuls like Mandarin Gardens and Dairy Farm also fell short. However, commercial en bloc sales have fared better, with recent deals including Realty Centre and Selegie Centre. Experts attribute the uptrend to rising commercial property rents and incentives like the CBD Incentive Scheme and Strategic Development Initiative. Despite the lacklustre record, some developers are still holding out for collective sales, with reasonable pricing seen as key to success.

site_title: From archaeologists to vets, UK widens list of desired immigrants
summary: The UK's Migration Advisory Committee recommends expanding the list of jobs deemed in short supply, adding over 9% of workers, to include jobs such as archaeologists, architects, and web developers. The move aims to tackle worker shortages, despite a five-year low in immigration. The government will consider the recommendations, which are not binding, amid Brexit preparations and a shift in public opinion, with stricter border controls no longer a top concern.

site_title: Euro zone remains ready in event of no-deal Brexit - ECB's Lane
summary: The European Central Bank's Philip Lane stated that the euro zone is prepared for a no-deal Brexit, which remains a possibility despite being less likely than initially thought. Lane, who is set to join the ECB's executive council, emphasized that the euro zone has been preparing for a no-deal Brexit since March and is ready for its potential consequences. The UK's departure from the euro zone will be considered, but it is just one trading partner among many.

site_title: US banking sector reports US$60.7b in profits for Q1 of 2019
summary: US banking sector reported a profit of US$60.7 billion in Q1 2019, a 8.7% increase from the previous year. Higher net interest income drove the increase. The number of "problem banks" decreased from 60 to 59, the lowest level since 2007.

site_title: Google CEO shunned a large stock award after lavish payouts
summary: Google CEO Sundar Pichai has turned down a large stock award, reportedly worth hundreds of millions of dollars, due to feeling already compensated generously. This decision is unusual among US corporate leaders and may raise questions about Pichai's future at the company. Pichai has not received an equity award in over two years, with most of his previous stock awards vesting by the end of the year, making him an anomaly among top executives.

site_title: Willas-Array posts HK$18.96m full-year net loss amid trade war
summary: Willas-Array Electronics reported a full-year net loss of HK$18.96 million (S$3.34 million) for the year ended March 31, down from a profit of HK$111.96 million the previous year. Revenue fell 19.1% to HK$3.69 billion, and gross profit decreased 17.2% to HK$327.5 million. The company attributed the loss to increasing trade tensions between the US and China, but remains confident in its business sustainability and long-term prospects.

site_title: S-Chips may yet rise from their slumber
summary: China Milk, a Singapore-listed Chinese company (S-Chip), was a leading producer of pedigree bull semen and cow embryos in 2008. It aimed to boost China's milk productivity by importing Canadian bull semen, resulting in tripled sales from 2015 to 2018. However, the company reneged on interest payments in 2009, leading to a collapse in value and wiping out investors. Despite this, many S-Chips, which have been trading at a discount, may offer legitimate businesses with substantial cash reserves, with some companies like China Star Food Group trading at half their net cash.

site_title: Oil retreats below US$59 as US-China trade hostilities escalate
summary: Oil prices retreated below $59 as the US-China trade war escalated, overshadowing forecasted declines in American crude inventories. The worsening trade conflict has weighed on global growth, pushing down oil and riskier assets. US National Security Adviser John Bolton blamed Iran for recent oil tanker attacks. Oil futures fell 1.4% after a 2.1% gain since Thursday, with West Texas Intermediate crude falling to $58.46 a barrel. The Organization for Petroleum Exporting Countries' output cuts expire at the end of June, with a potential meeting in July to set the course for the rest of the year.

site_title: WasteWatch: Prevention is better than cure
summary: Sodexo's WasteWatch programme aims to reduce food waste in Singapore by minimizing the generation of waste. According to Roshith Rajan, the program's goal is to prevent waste from reaching the treatment stage. This initiative is part of a larger effort to reduce waste globally, where one-third of food items are discarded before consumption.

site_title: China Star Food full-year net profit more than doubles to 33.4m yuan
summary: China Star Food Group, a CATALIST-LISTED snack maker, reported a full-year net profit of 33.4 million yuan (S$6.7 million), more than doubling from 12.5 million yuan the previous year. Revenue rose 61.3% to 357 million yuan, driven by increased sales of candies and crisps. The company remains optimistic about the sweet potato snack food industry in China, despite increased competition, and plans to continue product development and expansion.

site_title: Shortage of talent for Malaysia's digital banking push: Hays
summary: Malaysia is facing a talent shortage to support its digital banking push, with recruitment firm Hays citing a high demand for network systems project specialists, infrastructure applications experts, and UI/analytical specialists. The rise of virtual banking and e-wallet adoption has exacerbated the issue, with hiring managers open to recruiting candidates with partial skill sets. Greater regulation has driven hiring of regulatory compliance professionals and financial crime protection roles, but finding suitable candidates remains challenging. The shortage is expected to worsen as licensing guidelines for virtual banking are set to be issued by the end of 2019.

site_title: EU takes Italy to task over high debt
summary: The European Union has warned Italy over its high debt, stating that the country's government is in breach of EU budget rules. The European Commission requested "clarifications" within two days, potentially leading to unprecedented sanctions. Italy's far-right Deputy Prime Minister Matteo Salvini dismissed the warning, calling for a "fiscal shock" to revive the country, which could result in financial sanctions of up to 0.2% of Italian GDP. Italy's public debt stands at 132.2% of GDP, exceeding the 60% threshold set by European rules.

images.alt_text: Italy's far-right Deputy Prime Minister Matteo Salvini on Tuesday dismissed the warning, adding that he expected Brussels to sanction his country for its deteriorating deficit and huge debt by imposing a fine of three billion euros (S$4.6 billion).

site_title: Ley Choon posts Q4 net loss of S$5.84m on higher project costs
summary: Ley Choon Group Holdings, a CATALIST-listed construction firm, reported a net loss of S$5.84 million in Q4 2023, despite a 2.8% increase in revenue to S$27.9 million. The firm attributed the loss to higher project costs, gross loss of S$1.8 million, and a 71.5% decline in full-year gross profit to S$4.7 million. The company expects strong demand from the public sector and secured S$20.5 million in contracts, with an unfulfilled order book of S$128 million.

site_title: Asia Pulp & Paper products to be back on Singapore shelves after passing checks
summary: Asia Pulp & Paper (APP) has received the Singapore Environment Council's (SEC) enhanced Green Label certification, allowing its products to return to Singapore shelves after being temporarily banned in 2015 due to concerns over its link to forest fires in Indonesia. APP suppliers underwent a 25-point audit and implemented measures such as a zero-burning policy, peatland management, and strict fire prevention systems. The company has invested over $100 million in fire management and has seen a marked reduction in forest fires since 2015. APP's products are now certified to meet Singapore's enhanced environmental standards.

site_title: Accrelist proposes 20-to-1 share consolidation
summary: Accrelist, a corporate accretion services provider, proposes a 20-to-1 share consolidation, which would reduce its issued and paid-up share capital from 5.58 billion shares to 279.14 million consolidated shares. The consolidation aims to reduce share price volatility and increase market interest in the company. The proposal is subject to approval from the Singapore Exchange Securities Trading (SGX-ST) and shareholders' approval at an extraordinary general meeting (EGM).

site_title: Braddell View's en bloc tender closes without a bid
summary: Braddell View's en bloc tender, launched at S$2.08 billion, closed without a bid. The collective sale committee has instructed Colliers to enter into private treaty negotiation for the development's sale. The 918-unit HUDC estate, located at Braddell Hill, will be sold if a suitable buyer is found. The development is the largest of 18 HUDC estates in Singapore.

site_title: Wanted Myanmar firebrand abbot summoned by Buddhist council
summary: Myanmar's ultra-nationalist monk, Wirathu, nicknamed the "Buddhist bin Laden," has been summoned by the country's top Buddhist authority for reprimand over his anti-Muslim vitriol. He faces charges of stirring up unrest and has a history of hate speech against Islam and the Rohingya minority. Wirathu was previously banned from speaking in public and had his social media accounts blacklisted. The summoning comes after he made provocative speeches at nationalist rallies, including criticizing Aung San Suu Kyi. Wirathu has a history of imprisonment for extremism and has been called "The Face of Buddhist Terror" by Time magazine.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish lower
summary: Hong Kong shares fell 0.57% on Wednesday, closing at 27,235.71, amid concerns over the US-China trade war's impact on the global economy. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.16%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index remained flat. The decline follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks, which was boosted by positive GDP data and investor sentiment.

site_title: Singapore shares dip 0.1% on continuing trade woes, growth concerns
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.1% lower at 3,163.28 on Wednesday, following a decline in US stocks and trade woes. The local market was affected by lower US treasury yields, which hit a new low since September 2017, and the US yield curve inversion, a historically reliable recession signal. Local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB fell 0.4-0.8%, while Singtel rebounded 1% and Sheng Siong added 1.9%.

site_title: CAD seizes documents from Allied Tech, interviews executive director
summary: The Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) in Singapore seized documents and information from Allied Technologies and its subsidiaries, including Asia Box Office and Activpass Holdings, on May 28. Executive director Kenneth Low Si Ren was asked to attend an interview and surrendered his passport as part of the investigation into missing funds, estimated at S$33 million. Allied Tech will cooperate with the investigation and provide updates to shareholders. The company's board has also announced that Low will recuse himself from decisions and not act as a signatory until further notice.

site_title: Former CapitaLand CEO appointed SPH independent director
summary: Former CapitaLand CEO Lim Ming Yan has been appointed an independent director to the board of Singapore Press Holdings (SPH), effective June 3. He will also join the Nominating and Remuneration Committees. Lim, 56, has a 22-year tenure at CapitaLand, including as president and group CEO from 2013 to 2018. He brings experience in the property sector and embracing digitization to the board, according to SPH chairman Lee Boon Yang. Lim expressed his honor to join the board and contribute to SPH's business strategy and success.

site_title: Thai opposition says "not too late" as pro-junta talks stall after election
summary: Thailand's main opposition Pheu Thai party urged other parties to reject a coalition offer by pro-army Palang Pracharat, seeking to keep ruling junta chief Prayuth Chan-ocha as prime minister. The party seized on the reluctance of presumed allies, Democrat Party and Chart Thai Pattana, to change their minds. Pheu Thai's secretary-general Phumtham Wechayachai said it was not too late for any party to change its mind, while Palang Pracharat's leader Uttama Savanayana expressed confidence in forming a government, but was willing to wait for agreement.

site_title: Mental health app raises US$50m as digital therapy grows
summary: Talkspace, a mental health app, raised $50 million in funding from Revolution Growth, bringing its total to $110 million. The company, which connects users with 5,000 licensed therapists, has forged a deal with Optum, a US health insurer, to reach 2 million customers. The market for digital therapy is growing, with investment in digital health companies reaching $8.1 billion in the US in 2018. Talkspace aims to expand its services, including in China, and is building evidence on the effectiveness of online therapy.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 9.10 points to 1,623.67 on Wednesday, driven by a volume of 2.0 billion lots worth RM1.8 billion. Gainers outpaced losers 442 to 404. The market's momentum was not mentioned in the provided articles, however.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's MAS says its monetary policy framework prioritizes medium-term price stability. Real wages in Singapore saw a growth of 0.4% in 2018, picking up after two consecutive years of slowing down. The country was added to the US currency watchlist due to its large current account surplus and net foreign currency purchases. HSBC launched new insurance plans in Singapore, while a study found Singapore has the highest rate of discrepancies in job applications in the Asia-Pacific region. The STI closed at 3,163.28, down 0.1% due to trade woes and growth concerns.

site_title: Australia: Shares end the day lower
summary: Australian shares fell 0.7% on Wednesday, marking the benchmark's fourth decline in five sessions, as global growth concerns hurt risk appetite. Commodity stocks weakened the most, while rare earths miners gained on the possibility of Beijing halting US exports. The decline was also seen in New Zealand's benchmark index, which fell 0.3%. The downturn was attributed to ongoing tensions between the US and China.

site_title: Artivision Tech narrows Q4 loss, RTO 'in progress'
summary: Artivision Technologies narrowed its total comprehensive loss for Q4 to S$1.22 million, down from a S$2.44 million loss in the same period last year. The company's full-year loss decreased to S$2.76 million from S$7.07 million the previous year. Artivision's controlling shareholder Ching Chiat Kwong provided an undertaking to provide adequate funds for the company to continue operating as a going concern. The company is in the process of a reverse takeover (RTO) deal, with the acquisition and due diligence ongoing.

site_title: Innopac's cure period extension application rejected, may face delisting
summary: Singapore Exchange Securities Trading (SGX-ST) has rejected Innopac's application to extend its cure period, which could lead to delisting. The company had sought more time to meet listing requirements after its shares were suspended in June 2018. The SGX-ST deemed the proposed issuance of placement shares at 0.1 Singapore cent apiece unacceptable, resulting in a delisting notice to be issued on June 2, 2019. Innopac plans to appeal the decision.

site_title: Japan police search home of stabbing attacker
summary: Japanese police searched the home of Ryuichi Iwasaki, a 51-year-old man who carried out a stabbing rampage in Kawasaki, killing two people, including an 11-year-old schoolgirl, and injuring 17 others. Iwasaki died after stabbing himself during the attack, but his motives remain unclear. Police seized unspecified material during the search, and neighbors reported that Iwasaki was a quiet and unassuming person who lived with relatives in their 80s. The government has announced a review of measures to ensure the safety of children traveling to and from school.

site_title: Hyflux in talks with 7 parties, will pick a suitor by mid-June
summary: Hyflux, a Singapore-based water cleaning firm, is in talks with seven potential investors for a cash infusion. The company plans to enter into a binding term sheet with one of them by mid-June and apply for a court-sanctioned restructuring process in July. Hyflux has prioritized discussions with investors willing to keep the company intact, rather than those looking to cherry-pick its assets. The company aims to complete its restructuring process by September, with meetings with creditors and a court hearing scheduled for August and September.

site_title: CapitaLand eyes 100% green certification of enlarged portfolio by 2030
summary: CapitaLand, a global property giant, has set a goal to achieve 100% green certification of its enlarged portfolio by 2030 and 20% of its energy consumption to come from renewable energy by 2025. The company aims to align with the Science-Based Targets Initiative's carbon emission targets, which are in line with the 2015 Paris Agreement's goal to limit global warming by 1.5 degrees Celsius. CapitaLand has made significant strides in sustainability, including reducing single-use plastics and paper consumption, and achieving a 29.8% decrease in carbon emission intensity since 2008.

site_title: UK mortgage approvals climb to highest in more than two years
summary: The UK mortgage approvals rose to a two-year high of 42,989 in May, surpassing the February 2017 figure. This represents a 10% increase from the previous year, suggesting a return of confidence in the market. Credit-card spending also increased by 12% in April, driven by consumers' growing preference for using cards while managing their finances. The UK Finance report covers 60% of total mortgage lending and will be published by the Bank of England on May 31.

images.alt_text: UK mortgage approvals rose to a two-year high last month in a sign confidence may be returning to the market.

site_title: US marine dies in Australia training accident
summary: A US Marine, Lance Corporal Hans Sandoval-Pereyra, has died after being injured in a vehicle accident during a training exercise in Darwin, Australia. The incident occurred on Saturday, and despite airlifting him to hospital, he was unable to be saved. A fellow marine received minor injuries and has been released from hospital. An investigation into the accident is underway. The commanding officer of the US rotation in Darwin expressed condolences to Sandoval-Pereyra's family and praised the Australian partners for their efforts to save his life.

site_title: Washington warns Hong Kong to watch for vessel carrying Iranian oil
summary: The US has warned Hong Kong to be on alert for the vessel Pacific Bravo, carrying Iranian petroleum, which may seek to stop in the Asia financial hub, violating US sanctions. The Pacific Bravo changed course from Indonesia to Sri Lanka and is now heading towards the Strait of Malacca. The vessel is owned by China's Bank of Kunlun, which has been a main channel for money flows between China and Iran. The US will enforce sanctions aggressively, urging Hong Kong to ensure it knows who it's allowing into its waters and services.

site_title: Opportunities abound in Industry 4.0 and SMEs need to seize them
summary: Industry leaders emphasize the need for small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to adapt to Industry 4.0, a new era of the fourth industrial revolution, to avoid being left behind. The era combines machines with digital technologies, creating "smart factories" that drive economic growth. SMEs must learn to harness data and protect customer privacy to thrive. UOB's event aimed to educate SMEs on Industry 4.0 possibilities and implications, and the bank launched an initiative to support businesses in this area, helping 15 companies through the innovation and transformation process.

site_title: Chew's Agriculture signs 10-year S$27m sustainability-linked loan with DBS
summary: Chew's Agriculture, an egg producer, has signed a 10-year, S$27 million sustainability-linked loan with DBS Bank to construct a new farm with larger cage-free facilities. The loan is linked to meeting Humane Farm Animal Care (HFAC) standards, ensuring optimal conditions for hens, lower interest rates, and nutritious eggs. This move aligns with growing consumer demand for responsibly produced and ethically farmed products.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slump at open
summary: European stock markets declined at the start of trading on Wednesday, with Frankfurt's DAX 30 index falling 1.0% and Paris CAC 40 sliding 1.2%. The decline was triggered by the US-China trade war and weakness in Asia and on Wall Street. The London FTSE 100 index dropped 0.7%. The slump in European markets follows similar declines in Asia and on Wall Street, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

images.alt_text: European stock markets slumped at the start of trading on Wednesday after weakness in Asia and on Wall Street triggered by the lingering US-China trade war. European stock markets slumped at the start of trading on Wednesday after weakness in Asia and on Wall Street triggered by the lingering US-China trade war.

site_title: Treasuries at 2% in sight as trade war spurs global bond rally
summary: Global bond yields are on a bull run, with US 10-year yields potentially dropping to 2% for the first time since 2016, driven by escalating US-China trade tensions and slowing global growth. The US 10-year yield has fallen 40 basis points since mid-April, while 10-year yields in Australia and New Zealand have reached records. Central banks are expected to cut rates to revive growth, with some predicting a 2% US 10-year yield if the trade war continues. Investors are seeking fixed income, with bond auctions drawing record bids.

site_title: Airline group to hold summit on Boeing 737 MAX return in 5-7 weeks: Iata head
summary: The International Air Transport Association (IATA) plans to hold a summit with airlines, regulators, and manufacturers in 5-7 weeks to discuss the Boeing 737 MAX's return to service. IATA Director General Alexandre de Juniac stated that regulators should cooperate closely on the decision, and airlines want a unified timeframe. The summit aims to determine what is needed for the plane to safely return to service, following the grounding caused by two fatal crashes in 2018 and 2019.

images.alt_text: At an Iata meeting in Montreal last week, airline members said they wanted regulators to cooperate closely on the decision to un-ground the plane, Iata director general Alexandre de Juniac told reporters.

site_title: Moody's confirms Frasers Centrepoint Trust's Baa1 rating; outlook stable
summary: Moody's has confirmed Frasers Centrepoint Trust's 'Baa1' issuer rating with a stable outlook, following the trust's equity issuance to fund acquisitions. The trust has completed the purchase of a stake in PGIM Real Estate AsiaRetail Fund and will buy a one-third interest in suburban mall Waterway Point. Moody's expects the trust's leverage to increase but still stay within the 7.5-times threshold set for the 'Baa1' rating. The stable outlook reflects the trust's expected strong operating results and financial profile.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower amid trade worries
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index losing 1.21% due to growing trade worries between the US and China. Economists predict a negative impact on the global economy if a trade deal is not reached, with some shares recovering slowly. The yen edged higher against the dollar and euro, weighing on Japanese exporters, and banks also fell due to falls in US bond yields.

site_title: More employees saw pay rise last year as growth in real wages picks up: MOM
summary: Singapore's economy and labor market remained healthy last year, with more employees receiving wage increases, according to the Ministry of Manpower. Real total wages rose 4.2% on average, up from 3.2% in 2017, with higher bonuses and average wage increases. Industries such as financial and insurance services, and professional services saw the highest wage growth. However, low-wage workers were not left out, with about 60% of companies giving wage hikes, but only 45% adopting the recommended quantum.

site_title: Australia sues Sony for refusing refunds on faulty PlayStation games
summary: Australia's consumer watchdog, the ACCC, has sued Sony for allegedly violating Australian consumer law by refusing refunds on faulty PlayStation games. Sony told customers they could not get a refund if the game was downloaded or more than 14 days old, and even then, only with store credits. The ACCC claims Sony gave false and misleading information about consumer guarantees and the process for obtaining refunds. The lawsuit aims to put practical impediments in the way of Australian users seeking refunds for faulty games.

site_title: MAS says it does not manipulate Singapore dollar for export advantage
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has denied manipulating the Singapore dollar to gain an export advantage, in response to a US Treasury report placing Singapore on its watch list for exchange rate and macroeconomic policies. MAS stated its monetary policy framework aims at medium-term price stability, managing the nominal effective exchange rate within a policy band. The central bank also highlighted that Singapore's large current account surplus should be viewed in context, citing its history of running current account deficits in its early years of development.

images.alt_text: MAS said Singapore's monetary policy framework has always been aimed at ensuring medium-term price stability.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks lose 2019 gains as trade war continues
summary: South Korea's Kospi index fell 1.3% to 2,023.32, losing all 2019 gains, due to the US-China trade war. Foreign investors sold 360 billion won of Kospi shares, and earnings for Kospi members fell 36% in the first quarter amid weak economic growth. The selloff was fueled by concerns over shrinking demand for Samsung Electronics and semiconductor exports to China. Analysts predict a radical rebound for the Kospi index unless a trade agreement is reached.

site_title: Singapore has highest rate of discrepancies in job applications in Asia-Pacific: study
summary: A study by First Advantage found that Singapore has the highest rate of discrepancies in job applications in the Asia-Pacific region, with 30% of analyzed applications containing errors. Most discrepancies were in work history and financial records. Financial-related misrepresentations accounted for 22% of the discrepancies. Singapore employers prioritize financial-related checks, with 36% of screenings conducted in 2018. Other economies with high discrepancy rates include Hong Kong, the Philippines, and Malaysia, while South Korea had the lowest rate at 5%.

site_title: Why Singapore, Malaysia, Vietnam were added to US currency watchlist
summary: The US Treasury added Singapore, Malaysia, and Vietnam to its watchlist for currency manipulation due to their large current account surpluses and bilateral trade surpluses with the US. Singapore was cited for its large current account surplus and net foreign currency purchases, while Malaysia was highlighted for its bilateral trade surplus and current account surplus. Vietnam was added due to its large current account and bilateral trade surpluses. The Treasury urged these countries to reform their policies to narrow their external surpluses and ensure their real exchange rates align with economic fundamentals.

site_title: SpaceX satellites pose new headache for astronomers
summary: SpaceX satellites are causing concern among astronomers due to their brightness, potentially threatening views of the cosmos and hindering scientific discovery. With 60 broadband-beaming satellites launched so far, the constellation could grow to 12,000, making it difficult to observe deep space. Astronomers warn that in 20 years, the human eye may see more satellites than stars, and some are calling for measures to reduce the satellites' reflectivity or relocate telescopes to space. SpaceX CEO Elon Musk has offered to look into reducing reflectivity, but critics argue the issue should have been addressed before.

site_title: Pokemon Co developing sleep-based gaming app, plans 2020 launch
summary: The Pokémon Company is developing a sleep-based gaming app called "Pokémon Sleep," which tracks users' sleep and turns it into gameplay. The app is set to launch in 2020. The company aims to turn sleep into entertainment, with CEO Tsunekazu Ishihara stating this goal. This is part of the company's efforts to expand its gaming business beyond traditional video games and augmented reality experiences.

site_title: Toyota may invest about 60b yen in China ride-hailing firm Didi: report
summary: Toyota Motor Corp is considering a 60 billion yen ($757.1 million) investment in Chinese ride-hailing giant Didi Chuxing. The Japanese carmaker also plans to set up a new mobility-services company in China. This investment is part of Toyota's efforts to team up with disruptive tech companies, following large investments in Uber and Grab.

site_title: Law firm Morrison & Foerster names Shirin Tang managing partner of Singapore office
summary: Morrison & Foerster has appointed Shirin Tang as managing partner of its Singapore office, effective June 1, succeeding Eric Piesner and Paul McKenzie. Tang, a partner in the corporate department, specializes in private equity and mergers and acquisitions, and has led transactions with over $29 billion in value. She will continue to serve on the firm's women's strategy committee, which prioritizes the advancement of women in the legal profession.

site_title: HSBC ramps up Singapore insurance business in bid to capture more of Asia's wealth
summary: HSBC is expanding its Singapore insurance business with new products and partnerships, aiming to capture more of Asia's wealth. The bank rebranded its Singapore insurance business to HSBC Life Singapore and launched two new whole-life plans. HSBC aims to grow wealth revenues in Asia by at least $1 billion by 2020, with the global insurance business contributing $400 million. The number of affluent individuals in Asia is expected to swell from 8 million in 2017 to 18 million by 2022, presenting a significant growth opportunity.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon at 3,159.63, down 0.2% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,159.63 on Wednesday, down 0.2% from the previous day. Trade worries and growth concerns continued to impact Asian markets, with the US 10-year treasury yield inversion raising recession concerns. The benchmark index saw 17 of its 30 components trade in the red, with Genting Singapore and local banks down, while Singtel rebounded. Despite regional market declines, Malaysia rose 0.6% and US stocks edged to fresh records.

site_title: Strategists see Wall Street moving higher despite trade war risks: Reuters poll
summary: US stocks are expected to continue their strong gains in 2019 despite growing US-China trade tensions, with the S&P 500 index forecast to finish the year at 2,925, up 4.4% from Tuesday's close. Strategists cite the trade war as the biggest potential negative, but most believe the risk is skewed towards the downside. Despite recent declines, investors remain hopeful of an eventual trade agreement and expect the market to weather turbulence. The S&P 500 is forecast to finish 2019 at 16.7% above its 2018 close.

site_title: Rare earths: The latest weapon in the US-China trade war
summary: The US-China trade war has escalated as rare earth metals, used in various products, become a key battleground. China controls 95% of the world's supply, making them a powerful tool in Beijing's trade war with Washington. The US has been imposing tariffs on Chinese goods, including rare earth metals, which could disrupt global supply chains and give the US an advantage. This development could have significant implications for industries reliant on these metals, including electronics and defense.

site_title: SoftBank's Son gives 9.1b yen payday to recruit top talent
summary: SoftBank Group Corp, led by billionaire Masayoshi Son, paid 9.1 billion yen (S$115.2 million) in compensation to six top executives, including former Goldman Sachs executive Katsunori Sago and SoftBank president Nikesh Arora. The high salaries are part of Son's efforts to recruit top talent for his growing investment empire, including the $100 billion Vision Fund. Despite Son's modest salary, his company's compensation structure allows partners to share in potential profits, making the payments seem less excessive. The Vision Fund's headcount doubled last fiscal year to 297.

site_title: Asia: Stocks sink after losses in US, Europe
summary: Asian stocks sank on Wednesday, following losses in Europe and the US, amid growing concerns over a possible economic slowdown and the US-China trade war. The absence of a trade deal has led to punitive tit-for-tat tariffs, which economists say will have grim implications for consumers. Asian markets, including Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Shanghai, fell 0.4-1.4% as fears of a US-China trade war and a potential European economic slowdown intensified.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand dollars sidelined as bonds steal the show
summary: Australia and New Zealand's currencies, the Aussie and kiwi dollar, remained stable, with the Aussie at US$0.6924 and the kiwi at US$0.6542, as investors sought safety in government bonds amid global growth concerns and the Sino-US trade dispute. The Australian government sold A$3 billion in bonds with a record-low coupon of 1.5%, while the Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to cut interest rates by a quarter point to 1.25% next week, with markets pricing in further rate cuts.

images.alt_text: The Australian and New Zealand dollars were stuck on the sidelines on Wednesday while government bonds took the starring role as mounting concerns about global growth drove yields to all-time lows.

site_title: Australia pilots hit by lasers during South China Sea flights: report
summary: Australian navy pilots were hit by lasers during flights in the South China Sea, with informal Chinese militia vessels believed to be behind the attacks. The incidents occurred during night flights, forcing pilots to temporarily return to their ship for medical check-ups. The attacks are part of China's increasing assertiveness in the region, where Beijing claims sovereignty over virtually all the resource-rich South China Sea. This incident follows a similar incident in Djibouti, where Chinese nationals allegedly shone military-grade lasers at US pilots, causing minor eye injuries.

site_title: Australia: Shares follow global market down as trade worries bite; New Zealand falls
summary: Australian shares fell 0.8% on Wednesday, mirroring global declines due to trade tensions between the US and China. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,435.9. Resource stocks, including Rio Tinto and BHP Group, were particularly affected, with iron ore prices failing to support mining stocks. In contrast, Telstra Corp shares rose as investors looked beyond a writedown and restructuring costs. New Zealand's benchmark index also fell 0.7%, with financial stocks leading the decline.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.05 points to 1,614.62 at 9am. The market saw a volume of 32.83 million lots worth RM14.56 million, with losers beating gainers 103 to 82. This news comes amidst a broader global market trend, with US stocks reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty and the S&P 500, Nasdaq edging past their milestones.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower on Wednesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Wednesday, tracking losses in Europe and the US, as fears of an economic slowdown in the US spooked investors. The Hang Seng Index lost 0.53% to 27,245.47, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also fell. The losses were attributed to concerns over the US economy and ongoing trade talks between the US and EU.

site_title: Flexible work arrangements should be offered at the outset for greater diversity: Hays
summary: Global recruitment firm Hays suggests that offering flexible work arrangements at the point of hire can promote greater diversity in the workplace. Flexible working should be implemented to create "family-friendly" policies, rather than just "female-friendly" ones. This can lead to increased employee engagement, retention, and a wider talent pool. Effective communication of different working practices is also crucial. By embracing flexible working, organizations can tap into a broader talent pool, encourage fresh ideas, and increase employee loyalty and trust.

images.alt_text: Flexible working is a highly effective tool for achieving greater diversity at the workplace, and should be implemented sooner rather than later and offered to all employees, according to global recruitment firm Hays.

site_title: Qualcomm asks US judge to put antitrust ruling on hold while chipmaker appeals
summary: Qualcomm has asked a US judge to put an antitrust ruling on hold while it appeals the decision that the chipmaker illegally squeezed out rivals in the smartphone chips market. The ruling, made by Judge Lucy Koh, directed Qualcomm to renegotiate licensing agreements with customers at fair prices without threatening to cut off supplies. Qualcomm argues that the ruling raises "serious legal questions" and could force it to rework its business in a way that would be impossible to unwind if it wins on appeal.

site_title: Valuetronics FY19 profit down 2.6%, to pay out 20 HK cents per share
summary: Valuetronics Holdings reported a 2.6% decline in FY19 net profit to HK$199.5 million, with earnings per share at 46.2 HK cents. Revenue decreased 0.9% to HK$2.83 billion, while gross profit grew 3.8% to HK$430.3 million. The company proposed a final dividend of 15 HK cents and a special dividend of 5 HK cents per share. Valuetronics aims to expand its production outside of China, with plans to establish a manufacturing site in Vietnam, amid US-China trade tensions.

site_title: Top Global 'still evaluating' options to purchase office-retail units from Allied Tech director
summary: Top Global, a mainboard-listed property group, has been granted options to purchase strata units within Thong Teck Building for S$129.5 million. The non-binding options were granted by entities owned by Kenneth Low Si Ren, executive director of Allied Technologies, which recently sold office and retail space to Top Global. Top Global is "still evaluating the market conditions" before making a decision. The transaction involves 28,360 sq ft office space and 6,440 sq ft of retail space in the building.

site_title: Modi healthcare scheme won hearts, and votes
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi's healthcare scheme, Modicare, has been a key factor in his recent election win, particularly among poorer areas. The program, launched last year, provides hospital costs up to $7,200 for the poorest 40% of Indians, covering around 500 million people. Despite some teething problems, the scheme has made a difference, with over 2 million people benefiting so far. Experts say it has boosted support for Modi's right-wing party, with voting data showing strong support in poorer areas. However, the scheme needs further reforms and increased financial resources to become sustainable.

images.alt_text: While Prime Minister Narendra Modi's nationalist tub-thumping has been widely credited with his recent election win, another factor was one he kept relatively quiet about: Modicare.

site_title: 4 in 5 Singapore firms fell prey to financial crimes over past year: Refinitiv poll
summary: A Refinitiv report found that 82% of Singapore companies fell victim to financial crimes over the past year, with 42% experiencing cases of financial crime by their own employees. The companies plan to spend 46% more to detect and prevent financial crime, with 69% adopting new technologies to combat it. Despite concerns over data privacy regulations, 84% of Singapore companies believe sharing information outweighs the risks, and 85% of Asia-Pacific respondents have existing partnerships or taskforces to combat financial crime.

site_title: SunMoon sinks into the red with full-year loss of S$4.3m
summary: SunMoon Food, a Singapore-based fruit distributor and food ingredients maker, reported a full-year net loss of S$4.3 million, reversing from a net profit of S$1.6 million the previous year. Revenue rose 62% to S$72.6 million, driven by higher sales to Shanghai Yiguo E-Commerce Co. The company has been placed on the Singapore Exchange watchlist due to failing to maintain a minimum trading price and market cap.

site_title: Cyberattack hits New Zealand budget
summary: A "systematic" and "deliberate" cyberattack was behind the leak of secret New Zealand finance documents ahead of the budget, according to Treasury Secretary Gabriel Makhlouf. The attack involved 2,000 attempts to access documents over 48 hours, with hackers obtaining some but not the entire budget. Makhlouf referred the matter to police and dismissed suggestions of accidental release by Treasury staffers. The leaked documents included increased foreign aid and defence spending, as well as the establishment of a Mental Health and Wellbeing Commission. The origin of the attack remains unclear.

site_title: Yoma Q4 profit soars to US$25.7m on fair value gains from investment properties
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings, a Myanmar-focused company, reported a fourth-quarter net profit of US$25.7 million, a significant increase from US$432,000 in the same period last year. The company's earnings per share rose to 1.36 US cents, driven by net fair value gains from investment properties and revenue growth in its development activities and investment properties. Revenue jumped 77.9% to US$31.8 million, while the company's full-year net profit nearly tripled to US$34.1 million.

site_title: Singapore VC-PE group on mission to collate data for S-EA benchmarks
summary: The Singapore Venture Capital and Private Equity Association (SVCA) is partnering with US-based Cambridge Associates to create benchmarks for South-east Asian private investments. The initiative aims to collect performance data from fund managers to support investment decisions by institutional limited partners (LPs). Industry observers believe that successful benchmarking could attract more funds to the region, but challenges in achieving a robust sample size and ensuring data confidentiality remain. The project's timeline and details have not been announced, but experts emphasize the importance of data-driven decision-making in the industry.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower amid trade uncertainty
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, tracking falls on Wall Street amid trade uncertainty. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.93% and the Topix Index dropped 0.91%. The US-China trade dispute remains unresolved, with few signs of progress.

site_title: Boeing tells key MAX buyer that jet will be back in air by July
summary: Boeing has informed SpiceJet Ltd, a major 737 MAX buyer, that the grounded jet is expected to return to service by July, contradicting industry expectations. European regulators will review the entire flight-control system before approval, while US regulators have expressed caution. SpiceJet, which had taken delivery of 13 MAX jets before the grounding, expects to receive 25 more in the current financial year. The company is in talks with Boeing for compensation, with the amount dependent on the plane's on-ground duration. Boeing is "pretty confident" of receiving all approvals by July.

site_title: Singapore added to US watch list for currency practices
summary: Singapore was added to the US watch list for currency practices, joining Ireland, Italy, Malaysia, and Vietnam, after making estimated net foreign exchange purchases of US$17 billion in 2018. The US report calls for Singapore to lower its high saving rate and boost domestic consumption to narrow its large and persistent external surpluses. This is the ninth country on the watch list, up from six in the previous report, and follows a review of countries with significant trade surpluses with the US and other economic indicators.

site_title: BlueChilli offers help to new healthtech ideas
summary: BlueChilli, an Australian innovation group, is launching a healthtech accelerator program to help new startups refine their business ideas, develop products, and grow their businesses. The program aims to enhance the healthtech industry regionally and globally.

images.alt_text: BlueChilli's programme director Seow Hui Hong with the company's chief executive Sebastien Eckersley-Maslin.

site_title: Huawei to ask US court to throw out federal ban
summary: Huawei plans to file a motion for summary judgment in a US court to have the federal ban on its products thrown out. The company claims the US Congress failed to provide evidence to support the restrictions. Huawei faces broader US restrictions, including a ban on its equipment in the US and a blacklist that could cut off critical components. The company is seeking a judge's decision without going to a full trial, hoping to declare the ban unconstitutional and prohibit its enforcement. This move aims to prevent exclusion from the 5G market.

site_title: Nam Cheong unit bags RM80m 3-year chartering contracts for 3 offshore vessels
summary: Nam Cheong's indirect subsidiary, SKOSV SDN BHD, secured RM80 million 3-year chartering contracts for three offshore vessels, including a Platform Supply Vessel and two Anchor Handling Tug Supply vessels, for Malaysian oil majors. The contracts are valued at RM80 million, with an option for extension worth RM50 million, contributing positively to the group's financial performance until 2024. This adds to the group's RM295 million chartering orderbook, with CEO Leong Seng Keat stating the focus is on bolstering chartering operations to capture the recovering market.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Wednesday; STI down 0.5% to 3,149.41
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened down 0.5% to 3,149.41 on Wednesday, following overnight slides in US and European markets. The index saw 55.7 million shares change hands, with losers outnumbering gainers 81 to 36. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding Holdings rose 1.45% while DBS Group Holdings, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank declined. Other index stocks, including Singtel and CapitaMall Trust, traded flat or unchanged. The decline follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Valuetronics, Yoma Strategic, Memories Group, Accordia Golf, Raffles Infrastructure
summary: Valuetronics Holdings reported a 2.6% decline in net profit to HK$199.5 million for FY2019. Yoma Strategic Holdings' fourth-quarter net profit surged to US$25.7 million, driven by investment property gains. Memories Group posted a one-off US$8.07 million gain, resulting in a net profit of US$6.15 million for the fourth quarter. Accordia Golf Trust reported a loss per unit of 20.71 Singapore cents for the fourth quarter. Raffles Infrastructure Holdings was flagged for potential listing on the watchlist due to consecutive pre-tax losses.

site_title: China gears up to weaponise rare earths in trade war
summary: China is preparing to use its dominance of rare earths as a counter in its trade battle with the US, according to reports from state-run media outlets. The country is considering restricting rare earth exports to the US and implementing other countermeasures. China's producers believe rare earths could be a key factor in the trade war, with the nation's producers rallying behind the idea. This move could disrupt global supply chains, particularly for the US, which relies on China for 80% of its rare earths.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip, possible fine on Italy hits bank stocks
summary: European shares fell 0.2% on Tuesday, with bank stocks declining 0.4% due to concerns over a possible 3 billion euro fine on Italy for breaking EU rules. Italy's banking index dropped 1.2%, while Greece's banks rose 2.3% on hopes of a more business-friendly government. Auto-makers and suppliers rose 0.7% as China launched stimulus measures to boost car sales.

site_title: US says North Korea programme violates UN resolutions, after Trump tweet
summary: The US State Department stated that North Korea's overall program of weapons of mass destruction violates UN resolutions, following President Trump's recent warm words for North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. State Department spokeswoman Morgan Ortagus declined to specify whether recent missile launches were of ballistic missiles or WMD, but emphasized that the entire North Korean WMD program is in conflict with UN Security Council resolutions.

site_title: US Treasury again says China is not manipulating currency
summary: The US Treasury announced that China is not manipulating its currency, the renminbi, in a statement released Tuesday. The report notes that the People's Bank of China has limited direct intervention in the last year, but urges China to avoid a persistently weak currency. This is the second time the US Treasury has made this statement, and it comes as China's economy is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: HSBC adding 50 jobs in Singapore as it boosts Asia retail wealth headcount by 300
summary: HSBC Holdings plans to boost its Asia retail wealth management staff by 300 by end of 2019, with a focus on Singapore to add 50 jobs. The bank aims to target both onshore and offshore clients in Singapore, where the high net worth population is expected to grow. HSBC's Asia retail wealth management division serves clients with less than $5 million of investable assets, while those with more than that threshold are taken up by the bank's private banking unit. The bank expects Singapore to be a "growth engine" over the next few years.

images.alt_text: HSBC Holdings plans to boost its Asia retail wealth management staff by about 300 by end of this year, with Europe's biggest lender by assets sharpening its focus on Singapore to add to its presence in core markets of Hong Kong and China.

site_title: US: Wall Street resumes slide on economic, trade fears
summary: US stocks slid on Tuesday, reversing early gains, due to concerns over economic growth and bond rates. The 10-year US Treasury bond rate hit 2.261%, its lowest level since September 2017. This marked the first down month for Wall Street in 2019, with major indices reaching their lowest levels in two months.

site_title: London home sellers offer ever-growing discounts
summary: London home sellers are offering the largest discounts in six years, with the average reduction on a home in 13 inner London boroughs reaching 7.6% in the first quarter, up from 7% a year earlier. The residential real estate market has been impacted by new taxes and Brexit uncertainty. While discounts continue to rise, there are signs that price cuts are starting to ease in some areas, with Kensington and Chelsea seeing little change in the share of discounted properties compared to a year earlier. The downward pressure on prices is moderating, according to Zoopla's research director.

site_title: Trade war's next battle could be China's access to Wall Street
summary: The US-China trade war is expanding to financial markets, with some experts urging the Trump administration to curb China's access to Wall Street due to a lack of transparency about Chinese companies' ultimate owners. Chinese companies have raised billions of dollars through American financial markets, and Alibaba is considering listing its shares in Hong Kong, sparking concerns about the potential for decoupling between the two economies. The US could retaliate by selling Chinese assets, which could have significant consequences for the American stock market.

site_title: Fintechs rethink IPO rush amid weak debuts, healthy funding options
summary: Singapore's fintech scene is reconsidering its initial public offering (IPO) path amid weak debut performances and healthy funding options. Despite this, interest in fintech listings remains, with some companies exploring a listing. Fintech unicorn TransferWise has delayed an IPO, citing the need to become profitable. The Singapore government has introduced a S$75 million grant to attract high-growth firms to the bourse, with dual-class share structures also available. However, concerns remain about investors' interest in high-growth stocks, with some comparing the market to a real estate investment trust (Reit) market.

site_title: Canadian lawmakers fume after Facebook's Zuckerberg snubs invitation
summary: Canadian lawmakers criticized Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg for not attending a hearing on privacy and democracy, as he had previously stated he would attend. This is the second time in six months Zuckerberg and Facebook's COO Sheryl Sandberg have failed to show up, prompting lawmakers to issue a standing summons. The hearing comes ahead of Canada's general election and amid concerns about foreign interference in the national elections. Parliament may hold them in contempt if they don't comply, but it would be a symbolic move.

site_title: Metro's new CEO outlines growth plans
summary: Metro Holdings' new CEO, Yip Hoong Mun, has outlined plans to deepen the company's presence in four key markets: China, Indonesia, Singapore, and the UK. Yip aims to generate recurring income, focusing on property development and investment, and will leverage Metro's strong balance sheet to drive growth. The company will also explore other regional countries, including Indonesia, where it sees good fundamental demand for housing, and China, where it will pursue commercial assets. Metro will stick to its philosophy of partnering local property players and will propose a final dividend of two Singapore cents and a special dividend of 2.5 cents per share.

site_title: EMA, PSA, Shell team up for innovative fixes and help startups
summary: Singapore's Energy Market Authority (EMA) has partnered with PSA Singapore and Shell to develop local energy solutions and nurture startups. The S$12 million partnership includes a joint R&D grant call for innovative solutions in smart grid technologies and energy management for container ports. The collaboration aims to drive innovation and support local energy startups, providing them with the necessary resources and expertise to develop sustainable energy solutions.

site_title: EU leaders agree to pick new 'Mr or Ms Europe' next month
summary: European Union leaders agreed to choose a new 'Mr or Ms Europe' for the European Commission by June 20-21, with a focus on gender balance. Chancellor Angela Merkel expressed concerns over French President Emmanuel Macron's dismissal of her preferred candidate, Manfred Weber, as the Commission head. Macron suggested candidates including Denmark's Margrethe Vestager and Dutch Frans Timmermans, while Merkel emphasized the importance of finding a charismatic and competent leader with a balanced gender representation. The EU faces a five-year leadership transition, with key roles including the head of the European Parliament, the European Central Bank, and the bloc's foreign policy chief.

site_title: Apple unveils first new iPod model in four years
summary: Apple has released its first new iPod model in four years, the iPod touch, starting at $199. The device features a twice-as-fast processor, Group FaceTime, and augmented reality capabilities. The iPod touch is designed for enjoying games, music, and digital content on the go. This new release comes as Apple shifts its focus to digital content and services, with plans for an Apple TV+ streaming service, Apple News+, and Apple Arcade game subscription service launching later this year. The move aims to offset declining iPhone sales and monetize online services.

site_title: Landmark US opioid trial begins in Oklahoma
summary: A landmark US opioid trial began in Oklahoma on May 28, 2019, as the state of Oklahoma sued Johnson & Johnson, alleging the company deceptively marketed opioid painkillers. The case, the first of many to go to trial, seeks to hold the company accountable for the opioid epidemic, which has killed tens of thousands of Americans. Oklahoma Attorney General Mike Hunter accused Johnson & Johnson of a "cynical, deceitful" marketing campaign, while the company denied the charges, citing government approvals and medical professionals' responsibility for prescribing opioids. The trial is expected to last two months.

site_title: US oil prices jump as flooding hits Cushing hub
summary: US crude futures rose 1.4% to $59.43 a barrel after flooding in the Midwest constrained crude flow from the Cushing hub in Oklahoma, hindering distribution and creating a bid on WTI. The flooding, combined with concerns over a potential extension of Opec production cuts, drove prices higher. Brent crude futures remained steady at $70.29 a barrel. The market is also wary of the US-China trade war's impact on fuel consumption, with demand expected to fall.

site_title: Brexit is vaccine against anti-EU propaganda: Tusk
summary: European Council President Donald Tusk stated that Brexit has acted as a "vaccine" against anti-EU propaganda across the continent, as nationalist and eurosceptic parties made gains in the European Parliament election. Tusk believes this shift in sentiment is a sign that people are becoming more pro-European, with some major Eurosceptic parties abandoning anti-EU slogans and rebranding themselves as EU reformers. The EU leaders met in Brussels to discuss the election results, with British Prime Minister Theresa May absent due to her resignation, but Tusk noted that Brexit was not a topic of discussion.

site_title: Where's Joe? Biden taking it slow in early campaign days
summary: Democratic presidential hopeful Joe Biden is taking a slower pace in his 2020 campaign, making fewer than a dozen campaign stops since launching his bid in April. Despite President Donald Trump's criticism, Biden has eased into the race, citing his near-universal name recognition and popularity within Democratic circles. Trump has invoked North Korea's dictator in a tweet criticizing Biden, but the Biden camp has pushed back, calling the president's comments "beneath the dignity of the office." Biden's team says he will soon ramp up his campaigning, promising to "just wait and see" as he works to win voter trust and support.

site_title: Renault-Fiat deal must protect French jobs, says finance minister
summary: France's Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire has set four demands for the Renault-Fiat merger, including guarantees on French jobs, factories, and "zero" site closures. The government wants assurances on the new entity's leadership, ensuring French interests are preserved. Le Maire also seeks to maintain Renault's Franco-Japanese alliance and participate in a European electric vehicle battery project. The deal, if approved, will see Fiat chairman John Elkann remain in his role and Renault's CEO Jean-Dominique Senard take over.

site_title: Growth pause in Asian insurance market, but long term outlook is bright: Allianz Research
summary: The Asian insurance market experienced a growth pause in 2019, with premiums rising 2.3% and accounting for only 16% of global growth. However, Allianz Research forecasts a rebound in the region, with premium growth expected to reach 11% in Asia ex-Japan and 5% globally over the next decade. Despite a sluggish 2019, the long-term outlook for the Asian insurance market remains bright, driven by technological progress and regulatory oversight in countries such as China. Singapore's insurance market, although expected to have a weak year, remains one of the top insurance markets worldwide.

site_title: Ayondo chairman disposed of 1.2m shares on Nov 22 for undisclosed sum
summary: Ayondo chairman Thomas Winkler disposed of 1.2 million shares on Nov 22, 2018, to third-party existing shareholders, reducing his shareholding to 5.66% from 5.9%. The shares were held by Next Generation Finance Management AG, a company chaired by Mr. Winkler. The transactions were announced after a reconciliation of share transaction records, amid trading suspension due to financial viability and compliance issues.

site_title: Govt infocomm-tech tenders worth billions open to SMEs
summary: Singapore's Government Technology Agency (GovTech) has announced that over 80% of the country's ICT contracts worth S$2.5 billion to S$2.7 billion in FY2019 will be open to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The government aims to further develop five key platforms, including the National Digital Identity (NDI) and Smart Nation Sensor Platform, to enhance digital transformation and citizen services. GovTech has also introduced new procurement methods, including dynamic contracting and co-development models, to increase efficiency and meet rapid changes in technology and supply chain.

site_title: JTC launches tender for Senoko Drive site
summary: JTC has launched a tender for the Senoko Drive site, a 1.22-hectare site with a 30-year tenure and a gross plot ratio of 2.5, zoned for Business-2 food use only. The site is part of the 2019 Industrial Government Land Sales (IGLS) programme. The tender will close on July 23. Additionally, a 0.54-hectare site at Tuas Avenue 6 with a 20-year tenure and a gross plot ratio of 1.4 is also available for application.

site_title: UOB, Mastercard launch commercial credit card for SME execs
