summary: UOB and Mastercard have launched a new commercial credit card for small and medium-sized enterprises (SME) executives in Singapore, offering perks such as unlimited airport lounge access, complimentary golf club memberships, and discounts at hotels and restaurants. The card, UOB Regal Business Metal Card, has an annual membership fee of S$680 and is aimed at business executives who travel frequently for work-related activities. The move is part of the two companies' efforts to support SMEs, with UOB seeing a 65% increase in commercial credit card usage by SMEs over the past five years.

site_title: Standard Chartered Singapore Marathon to adopt evening race format
summary: Standard Chartered Singapore Marathon to switch to evening format, starting at 6:00pm, in line with efforts to be inducted into the Abbott World Marathon Majors. The change aims to improve the running experience, draw more Singapore residents, and showcase the city's nightlife. New spectator zones and entertainment points will be introduced, with the marathon, half marathon, and Ekiden distances taking place from November 29 to December 1, 2019. The move is seen as a step forward for the event, but still requires further improvement to meet the WMM's standards.

site_title: China's new Nasdaq taking only profitable firms for now
summary: China's new Nasdaq-style board, designed to support loss-making tech firms, has seen only profitable companies apply so far, with all but one firm posting a profit in 2018. The first batch of applicants to be reviewed includes companies with a three-year track record of profitability, with no clear start date for the new board. Regulators have relaxed listing rules to allow for more leniency, but the review process remains strict, with scrutiny of applicants' financials and research and development spending.

site_title: Trump's bromances with Xi and Abe
summary: US-China trade talks have been suspended for over two weeks with no sign of a revival. Despite initial optimism, the relationship between US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping appears strained. Trump's bromance with Xi began in 2017, with Xi receiving a state visit-plus treatment, but the relationship soured in 2018 when Trump accused China of meddling in US elections. Despite attempts to rekindle the friendship, including a phone call and meeting in Buenos Aires, no final deal has been reached, leaving an accord still elusive.

site_title: Floating parks can help enhance Singapore's garden city environment
summary: Singapore's coastal areas can be transformed into a more livable and tourist-friendly environment by incorporating floating parks. These structures can provide new public spaces, enhance recreational and tourism potential, and improve the urban climate, biodiversity, and public health. While construction costs may be high, hybrid floating structures using prefabricated marine concrete elements and expanded polystyrene can be more affordable and offer a lifespan of 100 years. The concept has been successfully implemented in the Netherlands and is being explored in other countries, offering a novel solution to urban challenges and a potential growth area in the global market.

site_title: New Zealand central bank says risks remain elevated, LVR appropriate for now
summary: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) stated that despite a resilient financial system, risks remain elevated. The current loan-to-value ratio (LVR) is deemed appropriate, with further easing subject to subdued credit and house price growth, as well as prudent lending standards. Governor Adrian Orr emphasized the bank's cautious approach in its half-yearly financial stability review.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokers maintained their stance on Thai Beverage and China Aviation Oil. Thai Beverage was downgraded to "hold" due to moderated expectations for domestic spirit volume growth, but valuations are deemed reasonable. China Aviation Oil was maintained at "buy" due to its ability to deliver mid-single digit jet fuel supply volume growth in 2019, aided by China's growing international passenger traffic and airport capacity expansion.

site_title: HK property back in bubble territory
summary: Hong Kong's property market is showing signs of a bubble, according to economist Carmen Reinhart, who drew parallels to Ireland, Spain, and Iceland before their crises. At the Nomura Investment Forum Asia 2019, Reinhart warned that the city's property market is experiencing similar characteristics, prompting alarm among investors and experts.

site_title: Allied Tech adjourns EGM till special audit completed
summary: Allied Tech, a Singaporean precision engineering company, has adjourned its extraordinary general meeting (EGM) until its special audit is completed. The meeting was originally scheduled for June 4 to approve the acquisition of Activpass Holdings for S$25.2 million. The company is investigating missing S$33 million from an escrow account held by JLC Advisors, and a complaint has been lodged with the Law Society against the law firm's managing partner. Allied Tech has appointed a special auditor and will report solely to the regulator on the scope and findings of the audit.

site_title: Diversifying your portfolio with private equity
summary: Investors can diversify their portfolios by adding private equity investments, which can provide an alternative to traditional stocks and bonds. Private equity funds take stakes in non-publicly traded companies or assets, aiming to increase their value to sell for a higher price. Globally diversifying a portfolio across private equity funds, strategies, and vintages can help reduce risk. This diversification strategy is particularly appealing after a turbulent year in 2018, and can be a key component in managing investment risk.

site_title: Managing liquidity risk in portfolios
summary: Market liquidity, or the ability to buy or sell assets without affecting their price, is a key concern for investors. Volatility in markets can be attributed to liquidity rather than fundamental drivers, with instances of "flash crashes" and extreme market movements. Private markets, such as art collectibles, are relatively illiquid, while cash is the most liquid asset. Financial reforms have reduced the capacity of financial institutions to act as intermediaries, leading to a decline in liquidity. Passive investing has also contributed to this decline, with actively managed funds providing an alternative source of liquidity.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Vallianz Holdings, an offshore support vessel provider, is expected to post a significant net loss for FY2019 due to non-cash impairment expenses. However, the company anticipates operating profits if these expenses are excluded. Vallianz will release its unaudited full-year financial results on May 30.

site_title: Trump-Pelosi temper tantrum: Should we laugh or cry?
summary: US President Donald Trump and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi had a heated meeting over infrastructure plans, which may lead to an impeachment inquiry against Trump. The meeting ended with Trump storming out and later calling Pelosi "crazy" and accusing her of pursuing a "political-legal witch hunt." Pelosi suggested Trump might benefit from a "leave of absence" and implied he needed "an intervention." The meeting's outcome is uncertain, and both sides are becoming increasingly intransigent, making a deal on infrastructure unlikely.

site_title: Hyflux clarifies that recent Utico meeting ended with no binding agreement
summary: Hyflux has clarified that a recent meeting with Utico, a UAE-based investor, did not result in a binding agreement. Utico had proposed a "part cash redemption" and a full redemption plan for Hyflux's debt, but Hyflux stated that no conclusive numbers or percentages were agreed upon. The meeting was exploratory in nature, and Hyflux remains in talks with other potential investors.

site_title: Euro dips on Italian debt worries, trade tensions
summary: The euro dropped 0.1% to US$1.1179, its lowest level in two years, amid concerns over Italian debt and trade tensions. Italian Deputy Prime Minister Matteo Salvini's far-right League's victory in European elections raised concerns about EU debt and deficit rules, while US President Donald Trump's comments on trade with China boosted the US dollar. European leaders meet in Brussels to fill top EU posts, but analysts warn of ongoing pressure on the euro due to rising Italian government bond yields and potential battles between Brussels and Rome.

site_title: N Koreans survive by paying bribes: UN report
summary: A UN report reveals that North Koreans are forced to pay bribes to officials to survive in their isolated country due to widespread corruption and repression. The report, based on 214 interviews with North Korean defectors, found that officials extort money from a population struggling to make ends meet, threatening them with detention and prosecution. The report denounces a "vicious circle of deprivation, corruption and repression" and urges North Korean authorities to stop prosecuting people for engaging in legitimate market activity, allowing them freedom of movement within the country and abroad.

images.alt_text: Four in 10 North Koreans, or 10.1 million people, are chronically short of food and further cuts to already minimal rations are expected after the worst harvest in a decade, a UN assessment said earlier this month.

site_title: Football fans up in arms over price gouging in Madrid
summary: Football fans in Madrid are protesting price gouging by hotels ahead of the UEFA Champions League final between Liverpool and Tottenham Hotspur. Prices for a bunk bed in hostels have skyrocketed to 500 euros (S$771), prompting fans to demand consumer protection laws. The fans' concerns come as the first all-England final in over a decade is set to take place on June 1.

site_title: IndiGo forecasts strong year as Jet collapse boosts its profit
summary: IndiGo, India's largest airline, forecasts a strong year ahead after Jet Airways' collapse boosted its profit by fivefold in the fourth quarter. Optimizing its domestic network and expanding international routes contributed to the growth. Revenue per available seat kilometre increased by 3-4%, while passenger yield rose 12%. The airline expects a 30% rise in available seat kilometres, with half in domestic and half in international markets. Despite this, IndiGo will see the boost ease by June, except in some international markets.

site_title: Euro dips on Italy debt worries and trade tensions
summary: The euro dropped 0.1% to $1.1179 amid concerns over Italy's rising debt and trade tensions between the US and China. Pro-Europe parties won a majority of European parliamentary seats, but investors remain cautious due to ongoing uncertainty. The US dollar rose 0.2% against peers, while the yen remained stable. Investors are also watching the upcoming appointment of EU officials and the potential for a US-China trade deal.

site_title: 'King of Clay' Nadal can make it a Roland Garros treble
summary: Tennis star Rafael Nadal is close to achieving a Roland Garros treble, with the "King of Clay" seeking to join the exclusive club of French Open champions. At 33, Nadal faces stiff competition from fellow "Big Three" members Roger Federer and Novak Djokovic, as well as young talents like Dominic Thiem, who could potentially disrupt the tennis hierarchy. The trio, who have dominated the sport for nearly two decades, have collectively won 52 Grand Slams. Nadal's French Open success could cement his legacy as one of the greatest tennis players of all time.

images.alt_text: Rolex Testimonee Dominic Thiem during the Rolex Monte-Carlo Masters 2019.

site_title: Singapore to step up cooperation with China: DPM
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat announced that Singapore plans to deepen cooperation with China in key areas, including the Belt and Road Initiative and economic zones. Bilateral cooperation is already at a "very high level," and both sides discussed ways to take it forward over the next five to 10 years. Heng met top Chinese leaders, including Premier Li Keqiang and Vice-Premier Han Zheng, and emphasized the mutual benefits of their partnership, citing lessons learned from past collaborations.

site_title: EU leaders fire starting gun for top jobs race
summary: EU leaders, including German Chancellor Angela Merkel and French President Emmanuel Macron, are meeting in Brussels to negotiate the top EU jobs for the next five years. The European Parliament's recent election resulted in a splintered center, with gains by pro-EU liberals and greens, as well as eurosceptic nationalists and the far-right. This shift is expected to influence the distribution of top jobs, with Merkel and Macron likely to engage in a battle for key positions. The outcome will determine the EU's leadership and policy direction for the next five years.

site_title: Aggregate Asset Mgmt seeks to raise S$5.2m via 1exchange listing
summary: Singapore-based Aggregate Asset Management (AAM) plans to raise S$5.2 million via a private listing on 1exchange (1X), a private securities exchange backed by the local bourse. AAM will offer 17,300 shares at a reserve price of S$300 per share, with the option to issue more shares depending on demand. The funds will be used to boost operations, hire staff, and invest in data tools. AAM's valuation is S$158 million, and the S$300 per share price represents a 32% discount. The company may consider an IPO in the future, but this is expected to take 5-7 years.

site_title: Nissan Motor tied to Renault-Fiat faces less independent future
summary: Nissan Motor is expected to have a less independent future after Renault SA and Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV plan to forge closer ties, potentially inviting Nissan and Mitsubishi Motors Corp to join their alliance. The deal, announced Monday, could create the world's third-biggest vehicle maker and aims to combine strengths in different segments of the industry. Nissan has expressed opposition to a merger, but its struggles with slumping US sales, ageing models, and declining profitability may leave it with limited options, making it difficult to resist the proposed alliance.

site_title: Top chocolate producers in Asia struggle to meet rising demand
summary: Top chocolate producers in Asia, such as Indonesia and Malaysia, struggle to meet rising demand due to declining local cocoa bean output. As a result, shipments of cocoa beans from Africa and South America surge, with Indonesia importing a record 240,000 metric tonnes in 2018. To address the issue, Indonesia plans to boost bean production to 600,000 tonnes by 2024, and global players like Olam International invest in the country to meet growing Asian demand.

site_title: The Hour Glass FY2019 profit up 41% at S$70.4m
summary: The Hour Glass, a luxury watch retailer, reported a 41% increase in net profit to S$70.4 million for FY2019, driven by positive consumer sentiment and steady growth across its regional retail network. Revenue rose 4% to S$720.9 million. Gross margins improved to 27%, and earnings per share increased 41% to 9.99 cents. The company expects to be profitable for the next financial year despite current global geopolitics and economics potentially dampening demand. A final dividend of three Singapore cents per share was proposed.

site_title: Hong Kong's second-richest man joins aging tycoons in retirement
summary: Hong Kong's second-richest man, Lee Shau Kee, has stepped down as chairman of Henderson Land Development, handing over the reins to his sons Peter and Martin. The 91-year-old billionaire will remain an executive director, while his sons will oversee mainland and Hong Kong businesses respectively. Lee cited a favorable property market, driven by low interest rates and close ties with mainland China, as a reason for his optimism. His retirement comes as other tycoons, including Li Ka-shing, also step down to make way for the younger generation.

site_title: Completed condo prices edge up 0.2%
summary: Singapore's completed private apartment and condominium prices rose 0.2% in April from the previous month, according to the National University of Singapore's Singapore Residential Price Index (SRPI). The increase was driven by a 1.4% rise in central region apartments, excluding small units. However, prices in non-central regions fell 0.6% and shoebox units dropped 0.4%. Year-to-date, prices are down 0.4%, with larger central region apartments declining 0.5% and non-central region prices rising 0.3%.

site_title: Accrelist narrows FY2019 loss to S$71,000
summary: Accrelist Ltd, a corporate accretion services provider, reported a net loss of S$71,000 for the FY2019, down from S$310,000 in the previous year. The group attributed the improvement to a sustained turnaround and stronger operational performance of its subsidiary, Jubilee Industries Holdings. Earnings per share for FY2019 were zero, compared to a loss of 0.01 Singapore cent previously.

site_title: Google invests 600m euros to expand Finland data centre
summary: Google invests approximately 600 million euros to expand its data centre in Finland, adding to its existing complex and increasing total investment to 1.4 billion euros. The expansion supports Google's push to meet growing demand for faster access to files and media, particularly with its new streaming service Stadia. The Hamina complex will be powered by renewable energy from wind farms.

site_title: It's anybody's game in the women's event
summary: The women's singles event at the French Open is highly unpredictable, with 10 different winners in the last 11 years. Serena Williams has claimed the title twice, but other top players are also contenders. The women's game has evolved, with players adopting fashionable and powerful styles, moving away from traditional court attire. The outcome of the tournament is now uncertain, making it anyone's game.

site_title: FedEx apologises after 'misrouting' Huawei parcels
summary: FedEx has apologized for misrouting some Huawei parcels, with the Chinese telecom giant reviewing its ties with the US package delivery service. The mix-up occurred as Huawei faces US moves to blacklist the company, cutting it off from American-made components. FedEx confirmed no external party requested the transfer and packages are being returned to the sender. Huawei stated it was "reviewing" its relationship with FedEx, adding it had never experienced similar issues in the past.

site_title: At Shangri-la Dialogue, US-China tensions set to steal the spotlight
summary: The Shangri-La Dialogue, a key defence and security summit in the Asia-Pacific region, begins in Singapore, with US-China tensions expected to dominate the agenda. US and Chinese officials, including Defence Minister Wei Fenghe and Acting Defence Secretary Patrick Shanahan, will attend, marking the first time in eight years that Beijing has sent its defence minister. The summit comes amidst a massive trade war between the two nations, with the US imposing tariffs on Chinese exports and Beijing retaliating. Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong is expected to stress the importance of stable and constructive relations between the US and China.

site_title: Practical responses to climate change
summary: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) has rejected mandatory speed restrictions on container ships as a solution to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. However, the organization has agreed to implement regulations to limit speeds, with a focus on setting maximum annual average speeds for container ships and maximum absolute speeds for other ship types. This move aims to reduce emissions from shipping without imposing blanket speed restrictions, which had been proposed by environmental organizations and shipping companies.

site_title: M1: One base plan to replace all mobile plans
summary: M1, Singapore's newly privatised telco, has simplified its mobile offering by introducing one base plan each for SIM-only and handset bundles, replacing its existing 19 plans. The base plan starts at S$25 for unlimited weekend data, and customers can add on more data, voice minutes, SMS, and roaming packs to suit their needs. The move aims to simplify the customer experience, reduce waste, and create a more intuitive decision-making process. M1 CEO Manjot Singh Mann emphasized the importance of data in the business, saying it's "the new oil" and driving decision-making.

site_title: Singapore is 8th most powerful country in Asia-Pacific; China closes in on US for top spot: think-tank
summary: Singapore ranks 8th in terms of power in the Asia-Pacific region, according to the Asia Power Index, with Malaysia taking 9th place. The US remains the top power, but China is rapidly catching up, narrowing its gap to 8.6 points from 10 in 2018. The US faces relative decline due to its focus on trade wars, and China gains the highest power in four measures, but faces structural challenges to establish undisputed primacy.

site_title: MAS issues directive to Pine Capital unit to suspend fund-raising, subscription activities
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has directed Advance Capital Partners Asset Management Private Limited (ACPAM), a unit of Pine Capital, to suspend all fund-raising activities and subscription activities until certain conditions are satisfied. This comes after ACPAM was reprimanded by MAS for failing to discharge its duties and due to concerns over potential conflicts of interest and lapses in internal control. ACPAM has also been involved in legal proceedings with its former CEO, Tan Choon Wee, and has served a notice of termination of its management agreement for one of its funds.

site_title: Falling prices rock coffee growers in Colombia
summary: Colombia's coffee growers are facing a crisis due to falling prices, which have dropped to an all-time low. Growers are selling their coffee at a loss, blaming stock market speculators for the price crash. The industry is struggling, with some growers forced to rip up their crops and others considering selling their farms. Colombia is the third-largest coffee producer in the world, and the crisis has left many families dependent on coffee as their livelihood. The situation is exacerbated by the impact of the 2016-2017 coffee beetle plague, which further reduced quality and prices.

site_title: Rolex makes it four Majors with French Open partnership
summary: Rolex has partnered with the French Open, becoming the official timekeeper of the tournament, marking the brand's fourth Major partnership alongside Wimbledon, the Australian Open, and the US Open. This partnership is a long-term commitment, following Rolex's 40-year association with the tennis world, and will help develop the Roland Garros brand worldwide, benefiting French tennis. The partnership is part of Rolex's rich heritage and ethos of supporting excellence in sports and arts.

images.alt_text: Rolex Testimonee Sloane Stephens at the US Open 2018.

site_title: DBS launches hackathon to find solutions for effortless banking
summary: DBS launched a global hackathon, DBS Paradigm Shift, to find solutions for effortless banking, attracting over 1,000 participants from 25 markets. The hackathon aims to disrupt the banking industry by creating a superior user experience for customers. Teams will be mentored by experts and judged on the novelty and impact of their concepts, with a combined prize pool of US$100,000. The best-performing teams could also land a job at DBS, with Microsoft and Amazon Web Services supporting the initiative.

site_title: Allied Tech executive director in S$129m fast property flip
summary: Singapore's executive director of Allied Technologies, Kenneth Low, sold a parcel of office and retail space in Thong Teck Building to Top Global for S$129.5 million. Low took control of the properties from RSP Architects Planners and Engineers founder Albert Hong early last month. The exact profit from the transaction is unknown. This is Low's second reported fast property flip, with his first sale reportedly occurring last month.

site_title: Is Asian private equity still an attractive play?
summary: Asian private equity investments now account for 26% of the global market, but concerns about the sector's sustainability persist. The intense competition and challenging environment, including high deal prices and diminishing returns, have led some to question whether the boom will fade away. Despite this, investors are not abandoning private equity, and Asia's growing market suggests that the sector remains attractive. The article highlights the need to reassess the situation and consider the impact of factors such as economic growth, trade tensions, and regulatory changes on the private equity landscape.

site_title: Trade tensions won't break Asia's recovery but downside risks have risen
summary: Asia's economic recovery is unlikely to be derailed by trade tensions, but downside risks have risen due to uncertainty. China's policy easing has stabilized its economy, with potential spillover to the rest of the region. The US-China trade tensions, however, pose a credible threat to the global business cycle, particularly for economies in Asia ex-Japan, such as China, South Korea, and Taiwan. A prolonged escalation could lead to a U-shaped recovery, with growth declining to 10-year lows. Policymakers in Asia are likely to respond with fiscal support rather than monetary policy, with central banks having more room to ease monetary conditions.

site_title: Levelling the playing field for women
summary: The Asia Pacific #WeSeeEqual Summit in Singapore highlighted the need for accelerated progress in gender equality and more women in leadership roles. Speakers, including former Australian Prime Minister Julia Gillard, emphasized the importance of challenging assumptions and creating systems that support women's growth. P&G aims to achieve 50-50 gender representation across functions, geographies, and levels, with current senior positions held by 40% women. The summit's goal is to "Fix the System" and include men as inclusive and equality-minded leaders, with a focus on talent development and flexible policies.

site_title: Allfunds eyes market share in Singapore, Asia
summary: Allfunds, a Spanish institutional funds platform, has chosen Singapore as its hub for expansion in Asia, citing a gap in retirement savings and a growing demand for mutual funds. The firm offers a one-stop platform for funds dealing, custody, and portfolio administration, and has seen exponential growth in Singapore, tripling clients since 2018. With a global presence and over 78,000 funds from 1,400 fund houses, Allfunds aims to simplify fund distribution and offer scale to clients through its wealthtech approach, utilizing digital tools such as Telemetrics 2.0 and the Allfunds Connect Marketplace.

site_title: How Asian cities can survive... and even thrive
summary: Asia's cities are expected to double in population by 2030, posing sustainability challenges. To thrive, cities must adopt "smart city" solutions, harnessing Fourth Industrial Revolution tools to optimize productivity and life satisfaction. Six building blocks of smart cities include connectivity, governance, services, automation, health, and mobility. Asia is leading the adoption, with China boasting 500 smart cities and Singapore's "Smart Nation" initiative driving innovation. The smart city market is expected to reach $800 billion by 2025, with opportunities in smart services and governance, fintech, 5G, and healthtech.

site_title: Alibaba eyeing listing in HK to raise US$20b: sources
summary: Alibaba is considering a US$20 billion listing in Hong Kong, its second major IPO after a 2014 record US$25 billion float in New York. The deal would give the e-commerce giant a war chest to invest in technology, prioritizing growth in China amid a trade spat with the US. The move aims to bolster Alibaba's competitiveness and support its expansion plans.

site_title: SoftBank plans second AI venture fund
summary: SoftBank's early-stage venture capital arm, Deepcore Inc., plans to establish a second AI-focused investment fund, valued at over $75.7 million, to nurture promising startups in the field. The new fund will be separate from SoftBank's Vision Fund, which has invested in various industries using AI. Deepcore aims to address Japan's shortage of global AI firms and create a business environment for engineers to start their own companies. The second fund will be launched in two to three years, expanding Deepcore's incubation business and its presence in Tokyo.

site_title: Billionaire Gilbert awake and responsive after Sunday stroke
summary: Billionaire Dan Gilbert, founder of Quicken Loans and owner of the Cleveland Cavaliers, is awake and responsive after suffering a stroke on Sunday. He was taken to the hospital by a family friend and underwent a catheter-based procedure, followed by recovery in the intensive care unit. Gilbert's companies will continue under normal direction, and his personal fortune remains at approximately $8.9 billion.

site_title: Rapper Chris Brown skips Paris hearing over rape accusation
summary: Chris Brown failed to appear at a Paris hearing where he was summoned to meet a 24-year-old Frenchwoman who accused him of rape. The woman, who previously accused Brown of assaulting her in his hotel room, had been seeking a face-to-face meeting with him. Brown's lawyer cited "professional commitments" as the reason for his absence, but Brown's accuser's lawyer, Gloria Allred, called it a "scandal" and questioned Brown's intentions. Brown has denied the allegations and filed a libel countersuit.

site_title: Multiple parties register interest in British Steel
summary: Multiple parties have registered interest in acquiring British Steel, with several given access to the company's financial information before a deadline in early June. The Official Receiver said "good progress" is being made in identifying potential buyers. Expressions of interest are due by early June, and the parties have signed non-disclosure agreements to access detailed information memoranda and virtual data-rooms. The liquidation process is ongoing, with multiple parties vying for control of the British Steel company.

images.alt_text: Multiple parties have been given access to the books of British Steel before a deadline for formal expressions of interest in early June, the office handling the liquidation of the company said on Tuesday.

site_title: Philanthropy in Singapore goes mainstream
summary: Philanthropy in Singapore has become increasingly mainstream as the city-state prospers, with citizens giving back through time and wealth. This shift is attributed to economic growth and rising wealth creation since the turn of the century. The country's philanthropic landscape is expected to continue evolving, with a growing focus on charitable giving and social responsibility. Key figures such as Tan Teck Long, the incoming OCBC CEO, are driving this shift, demonstrating a commitment to using wealth for the greater good. This trend is set to continue as Singapore's economy continues to grow and mature.

site_title: US: Wall Street edges higher at open as trade worries linger
summary: US stocks rose slightly at open on Tuesday, driven by technology stocks, but gains were muted due to ongoing US-China trade tensions. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite opened higher, with the Nasdaq gaining 18.65 points. Despite this, investors remained cautious, and the market's progress was hindered by lingering trade worries.

images.alt_text: US stocks rose slightly at open on Tuesday, led by technology stocks, but gains were muted amid signs that United States and China were far from reaching a trade deal.

site_title: EU's Juncker says EU will not renegotiate Brexit withdrawal deal
summary: European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker stated that the EU will not renegotiate the Brexit withdrawal deal, rejecting the possibility of reopening negotiations. Juncker made the statement before a meeting with Theresa May, who is expected to step down as British prime minister. Several candidates to succeed May have expressed interest in reopening the negotiations, but Juncker was clear that the deal would not be revised.

images.alt_text: European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker said on Tuesday that the European Union was not willing to renegotiate the withdrawal deal struck with the British government, but rejected three times by Britain's parliament.

site_title: 'Boring' is the new black
summary: In a volatile and lower-for-longer interest rate environment, "boring" structured products are emerging as a stable source of income for income investors. With limited investment opportunities in the SGD bond market, investors are turning to structured products that offer diversified portfolios, steady income, and reduced risks. These products, such as DBS Global Income Notes, provide investors with a low-risk complement to existing portfolios and can help navigate market conditions, including recession or boom times. As central banks continue to keep interest rates lower-for-longer, income investors are advised to explore structured products designed to achieve stable income streams.

site_title: Dyna-Mac bags contract from new customer for provision sum of S$4m
summary: DYNA-MAC Holdings has secured a contract worth S$4 million from a new customer for the fabrication of corrosion-resistance alloy pipe spools for an offshore gas field. The project is expected to start in the third quarter of 2019 and be completed by the fourth quarter, with a positive impact on the company's earnings per share and net tangible assets for the current financial year.

site_title: Singapore tops in world competitiveness ranking
summary: Singapore has topped the IMD World Economic Rankings, moving up two spots to claim the top spot, surpassing the US. The city-state's advancements in business efficiency, infrastructure, and technological infrastructure contributed to its success. Rival Hong Kong remains in second place, while Switzerland and the UAE round out the top five. The region, particularly Asia-Pacific, is experiencing positive growth, with Indonesia and Thailand also improving their rankings. Despite global economic uncertainties, Singapore's resilience and business-friendly environment have positioned it well for the future.

site_title: Collective will needed to clear women's path to leadership
summary: A recent survey by Cigna and a study by the Human Capital Leadership Institute (HCLI) found that Singaporean women face significant barriers to career advancement, including "burdened me" and "isolated me" - the struggle to balance work and family responsibilities, and the lack of professional networks. To overcome these challenges, women need to set clear boundaries, initiate conversations with managers about pro-family policies, and expand their networks. Organisations must also do their part by implementing flexible work arrangements, employee support schemes, and mentoring programmes.

site_title: Raffles Infrastructure Holdings flags possible SGX watch-list status
summary: Raffles Infrastructure Holdings may be flagged for Singapore Exchange's watch-list due to consecutive pre-tax losses for three years and a low market capitalization of S$22.9 million over six months. The company's stock closed unchanged at 43.5 Singapore cents. If confirmed, it would be subject to the SGX watch-list, which requires issuers to improve their financial performance within six months.

site_title: Norway has 50 undeveloped gas finds it could use - Gassco CEO
summary: Norway has approximately 50 undeveloped natural gas discoveries that could be tied into its export system, according to Gassco CEO Frode Leversund. The cost of developing offshore oil and gas fields has decreased due to technological advances, potentially making discoveries more profitable. Norway is on track to deliver a similar amount of gas to Europe as in 2018, with volumes expected to remain stable in 2020. By the late 2020s, Norway is projected to export between 100 and 115 billion cubic meters of gas per year, a slight reduction from the 2017 record.

site_title: Bonds are from Mars, stocks from Venus for investors in Gulf
summary: Investors in the Gulf region are increasingly favoring bonds over stocks, with global funds pouring into regional bonds amid declining liquidity in local stock markets. The petrostates of the Gulf, such as Saudi Arabia, Qatar, and the UAE, are issuing large amounts of bonds and Islamic securities, with sales tripling in the first four months of the year. This shift is driven by investors seeking a "little bit of spread" and diversified assets, as well as liquidity. Despite concerns over transparency and market volatility, GCC sovereign debt is viewed as having better credit quality compared to other emerging markets.

site_title: Private banks doing more heavy lifting in challenging markets
summary: Private banks are seeing increased business as clients turn to managed solutions in volatile markets. Key players, including DBS, UBS, and HSBC, report strong growth in assets under management, with some exceeding $400 billion in the Asia-Pacific region. Clients are adopting more cautious approaches, with many opting for discretionary mandates and holistic, diversified solutions to manage risk. Despite a recent halt in global equity returns due to rising trade tensions, private banks remain invested, advocating for measured overweight positions in key markets and a focus on carry and credit quality.

site_title: UOB brings art to Yishun void decks
summary: UOB employees, led by artist Khairulddin Bin Abdul Wahab, painted a magical forest mural on a void deck in Yishun, Singapore, over two days. The community art space was part of UOB's efforts to encourage art appreciation and education. The bank also donated various items, including tables, books, and play materials, to support the Singapore Red Cross Young Hearts Programme. The activity aimed to inspire and bring joy to children aged 4-12, and was praised by Member of Parliament Louis Ng for its positive impact on community bonds.

site_title: Norwegian pension fund ditches alcohol, gambling and pornography
summary: Norway's largest pension fund, KLP, has blacklisted companies profiting from alcohol, gambling, and pornography, and divested shares in 90 companies, including Carlsberg and William Hill. The move aims to reduce harm from addiction and negative societal consequences. The fund, managing $80 billion in assets, sold $320 million worth of shares from affected companies. KLP's CEO Sverre Thornes emphasized responsible consumption and the need to address addiction and societal costs.

site_title: STI dips, bucking regional trend
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 5.45 points lower, or 0.2%, at 3,165.32 on Tuesday, bucking regional trends. Financials weighed on the index, with DBS Group Holdings, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank declining. However, advancers outpaced decliners 188 to 177. The market strategist attributed the decline to a lack of market catalysts and rebalancing of the MSCI Singapore Index.

site_title: Moratorium on proceedings against NK Ingredients extended: Soilbuild Reit
summary: Soilbuild Business Space Reit's manager has granted an eight-week extension for a moratorium on proceedings against NK Ingredients, which owes S$2.28 million due to default on a Feb 15, 2013 lease agreement. The moratorium was initially granted for two months in March, and NK Ingredients paid the required rental and tax payments for April and May 2019. The extension allows NK Ingredients more time to address its debt obligations.

site_title: GP Industries posts Q4 net profit of S$2.33m, reverses year-ago loss
summary: GP Industries reported a Q4 net profit of S$2.33 million, reversing a year-ago loss of S$7 million. Revenue rose 5.5% year-on-year to S$276.9 million, and gross profit increased 17.1% to S$66.2 million. The company declared a final dividend of 2.25 Singapore cents per share. Full-year net profit reached S$29.2 million, up 25.5% from the previous year. GP Industries cited uncertainties in its business outlook due to the US-China trade dispute and Brexit, but plans to expand manufacturing capacity in Malaysia and Vietnam.

site_title: US consumer confidence accelerates in May
summary: US consumer confidence increased 4.9 points to 134.1 in May, surpassing forecasts, as households grew more optimistic about the labor market. The jobs hard to get measure dropped to its lowest level since 2000, while 19.2% of consumers expect more jobs, up from 16.7% in April. This uptick in consumer confidence suggests the economy remains solid despite recent slowing activity. The Atlanta Federal Reserve forecasts a 1.3% annualized GDP growth rate in the second quarter, following a 3.2% pace in the first quarter.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.2% lower on Tuesday, bucking regional trend
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.2% lower on Tuesday, bucking the regional trend of higher markets. The benchmark index closed at 3,165.32 points, weighed down by financials, including DBS Group Holdings, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank. Despite this, Genting Singapore's shares gained 1.1% after the company confirmed its bid for Japan's integrated resort. Trading volume was 73% of the daily average, with 929.37 million securities traded.

site_title: Britain's Hunt says pursuing no-deal Brexit would be 'political suicide'
summary: Britain's Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt has stated that pursuing a no-deal Brexit would be "political suicide." This stance puts him at odds with rival Boris Johnson, who supports a no-deal Brexit by the end of October. With Prime Minister Theresa May set to step down, the Conservative party is gearing up for a leadership contest. Hunt's comments mark a significant shift in the Brexit debate, drawing a battle line between him and other contenders. His remarks may impact his chances of succeeding May as Prime Minister.

images.alt_text: Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt said it would be "political suicide" for Britain to pursue a no-deal Brexit, becoming the most senior figure vying to succeed Prime Minister Theresa May to rule out doing so and drawing a battle line with rivals.

site_title: Challenging environment could present headwinds for SIA amid recovery
summary: SINGAPORE Airlines (SIA) reported a 47.5% drop in net profit for FY19, to S$682.7 million, due to costlier fuel, share of losses from Virgin Australia, and a global slowdown in GDP growth. Revenue rose 3.3% to a record S$16.32 billion. The airline faces headwinds from escalating US-China trade tariffs, weak air freight demand, and increased jet fuel costs. However, SIA has hedged 64% of its fuel needs and has robust demand for premium seats, offsetting some risks. The airline's transformation programme is also yielding positive results, with revenue growth and cost management efforts bearing fruit.

site_title: Indonesian agritech startup TaniGroup raises US$10m in Series A round
summary: Indonesian agritech startup TaniGroup has raised US$10 million in a Series A round led by Openspace Ventures, with participation from other investors. The funding will be used for product development and expansion of TaniGroup's services across Indonesia. TaniGroup operates an agriculture e-commerce marketplace and peer-to-peer lending provider, connecting farmers with businesses and individuals, and providing access to formal financial institutions for farmers. The company aims to strengthen supply chains and deliver fresh produce at best cost to Indonesians.

site_title: Allied Tech adjourns EGM till completion of special audit
summary: Allied Technologies, a precision engineering firm, has postponed its extraordinary general meeting (EGM) until the completion of a special audit. The meeting, initially scheduled for June 4, will now be convened after the audit is finished. The EGM was set to ratify the acquisition of Activpass Holdings by Allied Tech in July 2018.

site_title: Global institutional demand for Asian bonds to rise on attractive yields, index inclusion: State Street
summary: Asian fixed-income markets are expected to see significant inflows from institutional investors and private banking clients in the next 12 months due to attractive yields and maturing marketplaces. A global study by State Street Global Advisors found that over half of respondents invest in Asian bonds and 95% plan to increase or maintain their allocations. Yield was the primary reason for the increase, with 75% of respondents citing it as a key factor. The inclusion of Asian fixed income in global indices and growing market size are also driving the demand.

site_title: This Asian telco will be standing by Huawei - at least for now
summary: Singaporean telco M1 Ltd. will continue to use Huawei Technologies Co. despite US President Donald Trump's campaign to blacklist the Chinese company. M1's CEO Manjot Singh Mann said the company will use Huawei if it makes commercial sense, and will focus on cost-cutting and partnering with other companies, including Keppel Corp. and Singapore Press Holdings Ltd. Mann emphasized that M1's 5G services will be "vendor agnostic" and that alternative providers will be available. The decision reflects Singapore's ties with both the US and China, and its regulator's decision to allow local operators to decide on their own equipment suppliers.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close higher on dovish Trump
summary: Tokyo shares rose on May 28, 2019, as investors expressed relief over the EU elections and US President Donald Trump's softer approach on trade. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.37% and the Topix index added 0.26%. The US and UK markets were closed for holidays, prompting traders to search for fresh incentives.

site_title: Winding-up petition against Innopac Holdings withdrawn
summary: Innopac Holdings' winding-up petition by creditor CBK Holdings has been withdrawn, following a full and final settlement of the claimed amounts. The petition was filed on April 24 with a hearing set for May 17. Trading in Innopac shares has been suspended since June 7, 2018. The withdrawal comes after CBK Holdings served a statutory demand for almost S$214,000 in loan principal and interest.

site_title: Allied Tech lodges complaint with Law Society against Jeffrey Ong
summary: Allied Technologies, a precision engineering firm, has lodged a complaint with the Law Society of Singapore against JLC Advisors managing partner Jeffrey Ong Su Aun over the missing S$33 million escrow fund. The company claims Ong has failed to comply with his professional duties and instructed an unauthorized payout. JLC Advisors denies knowledge of Allied Tech's demands and has appointed a solicitor to respond. The dispute centers on the missing funds, with Allied Tech demanding their release. The Law Society is investigating the matter.

site_title: Meredith sells Sports Illustrated to authentic brands to further digital push
summary: Meredith Corp has agreed to sell Sports Illustrated to Authentic Brands Group LLC for $110 million, aiming to scale its digital media business. The deal includes intellectual property rights to Sports Illustrated, Sports Illustrated Kids, and other brands. Authentic Brands will manage marketing, licensing, and business development for the brand, while Meredith will continue to operate the print magazine and SI.com independently. The sale is part of Meredith's efforts to focus on its core strength in women's magazines.

site_title: GE to cut over 1,000 jobs in French power operations
summary: General Electric (GE) announced plans to cut over 1,000 jobs in its French power operations, mainly in eastern France and the Paris region, as part of a broader effort to stem losses in its power generation business. The 1,044 job cuts are part of a wave of European layoffs, and could become a challenge for French President Emmanuel Macron. The company cited a need to adapt to changing market conditions, but the move is likely to face opposition from unions.

site_title: Memories Group Q4 net profit surges to US$6.15m on one-off gain
summary: Memories Group, a Myanmar-based tourism firm, posted a net profit of US$6.15 million for the fourth quarter, more than 11 times the year-ago figure. The gain was driven by a one-off US$8.07 million bargain purchase. Revenue rose 10% to US$5.41 million, while gross profit fell 12% to US$2.06 million. The company expects improved bookings from Asia in the medium term and will re-strategize its sales and marketing plan for Europe. Full-year net profit turned around from a net loss of US$6.43 million.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close higher after election relief
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose on Tuesday, following European market gains, as investors expressed relief over the European parliament's centrist victory. The Hang Seng Index increased 0.38% to 27,390.81, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose 0.61% and 0.53% respectively. The gains were attributed to investor relief and anticipation of potential US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Accordia Golf Trust Q4 loss per unit widens on impairment losses
summary: Accordia Golf Trust reported a loss per unit of 20.71 Singapore cents for the fourth quarter, widening from a loss of 3.19 cents in the same period last year. The trust saw a net loss of 18,474 million yen (S$232.7 million) due to impairment losses on golf courses and goodwill. Despite this, the trust declared a distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.13 Singapore cents for the six months ended March 31. The trust remains optimistic about the Japanese economy, citing a resilient golf industry, but will adopt a cautious stance in managing operating costs.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks edge higher on institutional buying
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index rose 0.23% to 2,048.83, driven by strong institutional buying. The market has risen 0.38% this year, after a 8.1% decline in the previous 30 trading sessions. The trading volume was 474.63 million shares, with 584 advancing issues out of 896 total. This is the second consecutive day of gains for the KOSPI index.

site_title: France insists any Renault/Fiat deal must protect French jobs -Le Maire
summary: France's Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire stated that any potential merger between Renault and Fiat must protect French jobs. Le Maire confirmed he would seek four guarantees, including preserving industrial jobs and sites in France, and ensuring French representation on the board. The deal, worth over $35 billion, would see Renault's stake in the company decrease to 7.5% from 15%. Le Maire also expressed support for the alliance between Renault and Nissan, despite Nissan's initial reaction to the proposed tie-up being unclear.

site_title: Accrelist and unit Jubilee halt trading pending announcements
summary: Accrelist and its subsidiary Jubilee Industries Holdings have halted trading pending announcements. Accrelist reported a narrowed net loss of S$71,000 for FY2019, while Jubilee recorded a profit of S$3.3 million, more than tripling from the previous year. The trading halts come after both companies posted their fiscal 2019 results earlier in the day.

site_title: Europe: Stocks climb at open
summary: European stock markets rose on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index gaining 0.2% to 7,294.65 points. The eurozone's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 also rose, with gains of 0.2% and 0.1%, respectively. The rally was driven by gains in mining and healthcare shares.

site_title: Freed Sri Lanka Buddhist monk vows to expose Islamist militancy
summary: Sri Lankan Buddhist monk Galagoda Aththe Gnanasara, head of the Bodu Bala Sena, was released from prison after serving nine months for contempt of court. He was pardoned by President Maithripala Sirisena. Gnanasara plans to expose Islamist militancy despite denying allegations that he incited violence against Muslims and Christians. Rights activists say his release sends a message that majority Buddhists can incite hate against minorities, sparking concerns about rising tensions in Sri Lanka.

site_title: Malaysia to ship back hundreds of tonnes of plastic waste
summary: Malaysia will ship back hundreds of tonnes of imported plastic waste, including 450 tonnes from Australia, Bangladesh, Canada, China, Japan, Saudi Arabia, and the US, due to misdeclared contents and lack of environmental standards. The move comes after China stopped accepting waste for recycling last year, prompting Southeast Asian countries to step in. Malaysia's minister of energy, Yeo Bee Yin, vows to crack down on illegal imports and recycling facilities, stating the country will not be a "dumping ground" for the world.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 13.22 points to 1,614.57, with a trading volume of 2.4 billion lots worth RM4.5 billion. Gainers beat losers 427 to 395, closing higher on Tuesday.

site_title: Pine Capital issues update on ACPAM and its former CEO
summary: Pine Capital Group has issued updates on Advance Capital Partners Asset Management Private Limited (ACPAM) and its former CEO, Tan Choon Wee. ACPAM has served a notice of termination of its management agreement with Advance Opportunities Fund I (AOF I) and has been reprimanded by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) for failing to discharge its duties. MAS has directed ACPAM to suspend fundraising and investment activities until certain conditions are met. Pine Capital believes the concerns have been addressed and is working closely with MAS to resolve the issues, with no significant impact on the company's finances.

site_title: Tesla gets ready to reveal prices of Model 3 in China
summary: Tesla is set to reveal prices for its Model 3 in China on May 31, with local manufacturing expected to start this year. The company is considering pricing the vehicle between 300,000 yuan (S$59,220) and 350,000 yuan before subsidies. This move aims to bolster competitiveness in China's crowded electric-vehicle market, where Tesla currently ships vehicles from the US, incurring import tariffs. Local production will allow Tesla to avoid tariffs and speed up deliveries, marking a significant step in the company's expansion in the world's largest car market.

site_title: How processed foods make you fat
summary: A new study published in the journal Cell Metabolism found that consuming ultra-processed foods, such as packaged snacks and sugary drinks, can lead to significant weight gain and increased hunger hormones. Over a four-week period, participants who ate a diet high in ultra-processed foods consumed 500 extra calories per day, resulting in an average weight gain of two pounds. The study suggests that ultra-processed foods, which make up over half of the calories consumed by Americans, can have detrimental health effects and raise questions about the creation of healthier processed foods.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: M1 will replace its 19 mobile plans with one base plan each for SIM-only and handset, starting at S$25 for 30 GB of data and S$30 for 12 GB of data. Hyflux clarified Utico's part cash redemption offer for PNP investors is exploratory. A 25-year-old Cascadale condo in Changi is up for en bloc sale with a S$270m reserve price. Completed condo prices in Singapore edged up 0.2% in April, driven by a 1.4% increase in central region apartments.

site_title: Spain's most aggressive rent controls to soon hit Barcelona
summary: Barcelona is set to introduce Spain's most aggressive rent controls, with landlords required to negotiate leases based on benchmark prices for each neighborhood. The measure aims to curb the 50% surge in housing costs over the past five years. While the new mayor supports the controls, it's unclear if the measures will be implemented, given the need for allies in smaller parties. The rules, written by the Catalonia government, make exceptions for new construction and higher-end apartments, and do not give tenants the right to renegotiate contracts exceeding the new caps.

site_title: SVCA, Cambridge Associates to produce S-E Asian private equity, venture benchmarks
summary: The Singapore Venture Capital and Private Equity Association (SVCA) is partnering with Cambridge Associates to create benchmark data and statistics for the South-east Asian private equity and venture capital industry. The report will provide industry returns compared to market statistics, while protecting individual fund confidentiality. The initiative aims to fill the lack of reliable benchmarking data in the region, with the SVCA chairman calling it "long overdue and truly welcomed". The report will be published quarterly, offering a valuable resource for the industry.

site_title: Shippers raise rates for cargo from US to Venezuela - documents, sources
summary: Shipping lines Hamburg Sud and King Ocean Services have raised rates for transporting goods from the US to Venezuela, with a surcharge of $1,200 per container, due to US sanctions limiting transit. The rates, which previously ranged from $3,000 to $5,000, are expected to affect the delivery of essential goods such as food and medicine to the hyperinflationary nation. The increase is attributed to the risk involved in transporting cargo to Venezuela with sanctions in place.

site_title: Where top chefs eat in Mumbai
summary: Indian chefs reveal their favorite eateries in Mumbai, ranging from affordable seafood spots like Jai Hind Lunch Home and Mahesh Lunch Home to upscale restaurants like Bombay Canteen and O Pedro. Americano, a new restaurant from chef Alex Sanchez, serves eclectic dishes like corn "ribs." Street food stalls like Bademiya and Swati Snacks offer popular dishes like seekh kebabs and pani puri. The Taj Mahal Palace's Sea Lounge is a favorite for afternoon tea, while Shree Thaker Bhojanalay, a hidden vegetarian gem, serves delicious Gujarati dishes.

site_title: Falling prices rock coffee-growers in Colombia
summary: Colombian coffee growers are facing a crisis as falling prices on the New York Stock Exchange force them to sell at a loss. Producers say they are being paid an unfair price of $21 per 12.5-kilogram bag, while the cost of production is equivalent to $22. Many growers are forced to rip up their crops, with some even selling their farms to survive. The industry's livelihoods are at risk, with 540,000 families dependent on coffee production, which is Colombia's top export. The International Coffee Organization predicts a global surplus, exacerbating the crisis, and the government has announced $80 million in aid to support the industry.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rise after gains in Europe
summary: Asian markets rose on Tuesday, following gains in European shares, as investors breathed a sigh of relief over the failure of populist parties to gain control of the European parliament. The gains in Europe prompted a solid open for Tokyo, with US President Trump taking a softer approach in Washington's trade dispute with Japan. Despite ongoing trade uncertainty, Asian markets continued their upward trend, with Singapore stocks notching a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: UOB, Mastercard launch commercial credit card for SME executives
summary: UOB and Mastercard have launched a commercial credit card for SME executives, the UOB Regal Business Metal Card, with an annual membership fee of S$680. The card offers travel privileges, including unlimited access to airport lounges and complimentary access to 60 golf clubs worldwide. It also provides business entertainment benefits, such as dining discounts and champagne at renowned restaurants. The card is designed to cater to the spending habits of SME executives, with 70% of respondents citing travel and entertainment as top business expenses.

site_title: The Hour Glass full-year net profit up 41% to S$70.43m
summary: THE Hour Glass reported a 41% increase in net profit to S$70.43 million for the year ended March 31, driven by a 4% rise in revenue to S$720.93 million. Gross margins expanded to 27%, up from 24.2%. The company attributed the improvement to a stabilization of luxury watch demand in Asia. A final dividend of three Singapore cents per share was proposed, up from two cents the previous year. Despite warning of potential demand dampening from global geopolitics and economics, the company expects to be profitable for the next financial year.

site_title: M1 to replace its 19 mobile plans with one base plan each for SIM-only and handset
summary: M1, Singapore's smallest telco, is replacing its 19 mobile plans with one base plan each for SIM-only and handset bundles, starting at S$25 for 30 GB of data and S$30 for 12 GB of data. The new plans allow customers to build and personalize their own plans, and existing customers can switch to the new plans without additional cost. This move comes as larger rivals Singtel and StarHub have also rolled out similar plans. M1's CEO, Manjot Singh Mann, sees this as the first DIY plan in Singapore, and plans to leverage synergies with parent company Keppel to expand into utilities, smart homes, and smart cities, and explore new growth areas.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon at 3.167.24, down 0.1% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3.167.24, down 0.1% on Tuesday, weighed down by financials. The benchmark index saw 15 of its 30 components trading in the red, with Singtel, StarHub, and financials like DBS Group Holdings, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank experiencing declines. Regional markets, including Australia, Japan, and Malaysia, rose, while Hong Kong and China advanced.

site_title: Scientists zoom in on bug behind Strep throat and scarlet fever
summary: Scientists studying Group A Streptococcus bacteria, known as Strep A, have identified common molecular targets across many strains, offering potential for a vaccine. A study of over 2,000 Strep A samples from 22 countries found several shared genes, which could lead to a global vaccine. This breakthrough aims to prevent hundreds of thousands of infections a year, a leading cause of death from infectious diseases, estimated to cause over half a million deaths annually.

site_title: 25-year-old Cascadale condo in Changi up for en bloc sale with S$270m reserve price
summary: A 25-year-old condominium in Changi, Cascadale, is up for en bloc sale with a reserve price of S$270 million. The 134-unit development sits on a freehold site zoned "residential" and has a land size of 167,528 square feet. Developers expect demand and values for homes in the area to rise 10-20% over the next three to five years, driven by development plans for Changi Airport and surrounding areas. The tender will close on July 10, with a reasonably good chance of securing a buyer due to unique factors and a reasonable reserve price.

site_title: Mobile app users in SEA cost less to acquire: report
summary: A 2019 report by Liftoff found that mobile app users in South-east Asia (SEA) are cheaper to acquire compared to other markets. The region has a high internet penetration rate, with 90% of SEA residents connecting primarily through smartphones. Liftoff's data showed lower acquisition costs and engagement rates in SEA, making it an attractive market for app publishers. The report highlights SEA's potential for app publishers, citing countries such as Thailand, Indonesia, the Philippines, and Malaysia, where users spend four hours or more on mobile internet daily.

site_title: Monkey experiments offer clues on origin of language
summary: Researchers found that green and vervet monkeys share a similar vocabulary when faced with danger, despite diverging 3.5 million years ago. The monkeys use distinct cries to alert others to threats, and their responses are consistent across species. An experiment with drones revealed that the monkeys' alarm calls are highly conserved, suggesting a hard-wired vocabulary that may be similar to infant human sounds, which eventually gave rise to language.

site_title: In Houston, tech and health are cures for the oil 'curse'
summary: Houston, Texas, is shifting its economy away from its dependence on the oil industry, which once dominated the city's economy. The city is investing in healthcare and technology sectors, with the Texas Medical Center becoming a major employer, and startup hubs like Station Houston emerging as symbols of the city's renewal. While the city still faces challenges, experts say it has diversified enough to mitigate the impact of future oil price slumps, and has become a more resilient economy.

site_title: Asia's top chocolate producers can't meet the growing demand
summary: Asia's top chocolate producers, Indonesia and Malaysia, face a shortage of cocoa beans due to local farmers' inability to meet growing demand. Indonesia, the largest producer, imported a record 240,000 metric tons of beans last year, while Malaysia boosted shipments by 10%. The shortage has prompted a surge in shipments from Africa and South America. To address the issue, Indonesia plans to boost bean production to 600,000 tons by 2024 through a national program, while global players invest in the region to meet rising Asian demand.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 2.91 points to 1,604.26. The market saw 80 gainers for every 41 losers, with a total trading volume of 18.15 million lots worth RM4.64 million.

site_title: Hong Kong property back in bubble territory, Reinhart says
summary: Noted economist Carmen Reinhart warns that Hong Kong's property market is showing signs of a bubble, citing similarities with past crises in Ireland, Spain, and Iceland. House prices have reached a record high and are expected to rise for another decade, according to UBS Group AG. Prices have risen for 13 straight weeks, contradicting a temporary blip in prices from August to January. Reinhart's comments come as the market shows no signs of correction, sparking concerns about a potential property market downturn.

site_title: MUFG picks veteran banker Richard Yorke for new senior Singapore-based role
summary: Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group (MUFG) has appointed Richard Yorke, a veteran banker with almost 30 years of experience, as head of global corporate and investment banking, Asia Pacific. Based in Singapore, Yorke will oversee MUFG's GCIB business across South-east Asia, South Asia, East Asia, and Oceania, bringing together the bank's pan-Asian corporate banking coverage and solutions businesses under a single leadership. He will report to Randall Chafetz, Makoto Kobayashi, and Noriaki Goto, and takes over a newly-created role.

site_title: Hyflux says Utico's offer of part cash redemption to PNP investors only 'exploratory in nature'
summary: Hyflux clarified that Utico's proposed part cash redemption offer to retail perpetual and preference shareholders (PNP) is "exploratory in nature" and "currently being contemplated" by Utico. The offer, previously reported by Utico CEO Richard Menezes, includes 50% cash redemption for small investors up to $2,000-$3,000, with a full redemption opportunity. However, Hyflux stated that no conclusive numbers or percentages were discussed, and no binding agreement was reached. The company is in continued talks with potential investors, including Utico, and will make further announcements as necessary.

site_title: Trump bids Japanese emperor farewell, tours US navy base
summary: US President Donald Trump bid farewell to Japan's Emperor Naruhito on Tuesday, wrapping up a state visit that aimed to reaffirm Washington's influence in Asia amid rising Chinese power. The visit, which started on Saturday, included a golf game with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and a sumo tournament. Trump then visited the US naval base in Yokosuka, inspecting the Japanese helicopter carrier Kaga and addressing service members. The trip was seen as a demonstration of the US's military and economic clout in the region.

site_title: Challenger Technologies releases indicative timeline for proposed delisting
summary: Challenger Technologies, a mainboard-listed electronics retailer, plans to dispatch a delisting circular and exit offer letter on June 12, with the last date to lodge proxy forms for an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) set for June 25. If the EGM resolution is passed and approved by the Singapore Exchange (SGX), Challenger will be delisted regardless of the number of acceptances received for the exit offer. The exit offer, led by Digileap Capital, is set to close on July 11.

site_title: Russian space sector plagued by astronomical corruption
summary: Russia's space sector is plagued by astronomical corruption, with millions of dollars missing and officials imprisoned or fleeing. The state space agency Roscosmos has suffered a series of humiliating failures, eclipsing plans to launch new rockets and lunar stations. Corruption scandals have dampened Russia's ambitions to regain its Soviet-era greatness. The embezzlement scheme has led to a significant decline in the sector's performance, highlighting the need for reforms to restore trust and credibility.

site_title: Touch wood: US trade war leaves China importers struggling
summary: US trade war tariffs imposed on Chinese imports have left Chinese businesses struggling, with Xu Xuebing, owner of Shanghai-based Sam Wood, facing significant losses. The tariffs, which have increased by 20% this year, have driven up costs for importers like Xu, who imports US wood products to re-sell to Chinese furniture manufacturers. The tariffs have also reduced Xu's sales, from a target of 50 million yuan in 2018 to just 13 million yuan in 2019. Xu fears that higher tariffs could lead to business closures and price hikes, which could further harm the industry.

site_title: JTC launches tender for Senoko Drive site; Tuas site available for application
summary: JTC has launched a tender for a 1.22-hectare site at Senoko Drive with a 30-year tenure and a gross plot ratio of 2.5. The site is zoned Business-2 for food only use and is the last of five confirmed list sites for the 2019 Industrial Government Land Sales (IGLS) programme. A 0.54-hectare site at Tuas Avenue 6 is also available for application with a 20-year tenure and a gross plot ratio of 1.4. The tender for Senoko Drive site closes on July 23, while the Tuas site is available for application.

site_title: EMA strikes energy solutions partnerships worth S$12m with PSA and Shell
summary: Singapore's Energy Market Authority (EMA) has partnered with PSA Singapore and Shell to develop local energy solutions worth S$12 million. The partnerships aim to reduce energy use and carbon emissions at ports by integrating renewable energy sources with smart control networks and energy storage solutions. EMA and PSA Singapore will launch a joint research and development grant call, while EMA and Shell will set up an enterprise development programme to incubate local startups. The partnerships aim to strengthen the Singapore energy ecosystem and support the country's clean energy ambitions.

site_title: Singapore government to award up to S$2.7b worth of ICT contracts by March 2020
summary: The Singapore government plans to award up to S$2.7 billion worth of ICT contracts by March 2020, with over 80% of contracts open to small and medium enterprises. The majority of the contract value, around 60%, will be allocated to developing five key platforms: the Singapore Government Technology Stack, National Digital Identity, Smart Nation Sensor Platform, Moments of Life, and Adaptive Digital Workplace. An API, SG-Verify, will also be launched to facilitate secure identity verification and data transfer through QR scanning.

site_title: Accrelist narrows FY2019 loss, helped by unit Jubilee Industries' profit more than tripling to S$3.3m
summary: Accrelist Ltd narrowed its net loss to S$71,000 for FY2019, thanks to a turnaround in its subsidiary Jubilee Industries Holdings, which saw its net profit more than triple to S$3.3m. Revenue increased 49% to S$167.1m, driven by Jubilee's acquisition of Honfoong Plastics and Accrelist's acquisition of the Refresh Laser Clinic network. No dividend was declared for FY2019, and net asset value per share decreased to one Singapore cent.

site_title: Completed condo prices edge up 0.2% in April from March: NUS index
summary: Singapore's completed condo prices increased 0.2% in April from March, driven by a 1.4% rise in central region apartments excluding small units. This marks the first price increase in three months. The National University of Singapore's Singapore Residential Price Index (SRPI) released the flash estimates.

site_title: China's first bank seizure in 20 years spooks investors
summary: China's government seized Baoshang Bank Co, its first bank seizure in over 20 years, citing "serious" credit risks. The move led to a drop in Hong Kong-listed Chinese banks and a surge in interbank repurchase rates. The seizure heightens concerns about the quality of lenders' assets and the risks of future seizures. Small banks in China's rust-belt provinces are vulnerable to an economic slowdown due to their aggressive lending practices and inadequate risk management. The incident is likely to pressure shares of small lenders and heighten investor concerns about China's banking sector.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares edge down at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.21% in early trade on Tuesday, despite US President Donald Trump's positive statement on resolving economic differences with Beijing. The Hang Seng Index closed at 27,230.09, while the Shanghai Composite Index opened 0.07% lower at 2,890.27. Investors remained cautious, as the statement did not alleviate concerns about the US-China trade situation.

site_title: China's Nasdaq-style board is only taking profitable startups for now
summary: China's Nasdaq-style Shanghai technology board is initially only accepting profitable startups, with 110 of 111 applicants posting a profit last year. The first batch of listings is on hold, with regulators prioritizing successful and high-quality listings. The strict vetting process is expected to remain in place before regulations are relaxed, according to a fund manager.

site_title: Australian dollar gets a break, eyes iron ore antics
summary: The Australian dollar remained stable at US$0.6924, despite a lack of fresh economic data and global trade news, due to a surge in iron ore prices. Iron ore futures in China jumped 6% to a record high, boosting Australian miners' export earnings and potentially leading to a current account surplus. However, the Aussie's weakness compared to the last price boom in 2010-2014, combined with widening yield spreads favoring the US dollar, has offset its gains, leaving markets expecting a Reserve Bank of Australia rate cut and a Reserve Bank of New Zealand potential rate cut in the near future.

site_title: Bukit Sembawang posts Q4 net loss of S$11.6m
summary: Bukit Sembawang Estates reported a Q4 net loss of S$11.6 million, despite a 72% revenue increase to S$56.5 million. Gross profit was down 19% due to the reversal of costs. The company also saw a significant increase in operating expenses, including an impairment loss and allowance for foreseeable losses. Despite the loss, the company proposed unchanged final and special dividends. Full-year net profit came in at S$101.3 million, double the previous year's figure.

site_title: Hong Kong's Alibaba obsession may finally pay off with mega-deal
summary: Hong Kong's stock exchange is poised to land a record-breaking deal with Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. after the Chinese e-commerce giant considers a second listing in the city, worth US$20 billion. This marks a major victory for Hong Kong, which rewrote its stock-market rules after failing to attract Alibaba in 2014. The city's adoption of dual-class shares has helped lure two of last year's hottest tech IPOs, and a forthcoming new technology board may also attract tech titans. The move could be a deft political move for Alibaba founder Jack Ma amid an increasingly tense relationship between the US and China.

site_title: Newton Lodge makes 2nd attempt at collective sale, again with S$44m minimum price
summary: Newton Lodge, a 16-unit apartment development in Singapore, is making its second attempt at a collective sale with a minimum price of S$44 million for its 21,409 sq ft freehold site. The reserve price translates to S$1,359 psf ppr if an additional 8% bonus gross floor area for balconies and communal areas is factored in. The redevelopment could result in a low-rise apartment project with up to 27 units. The site is located near Novena MRT station and is part of the government's plan to turn the Novena area into Singapore's largest healthcare hub by 2030.

site_title: Australia: Shares up as iron ore rally backs miners, New Zealand lower
summary: Australia's shares rose 0.5% on Tuesday, snapping a three-session losing streak, led by mining major Rio Tinto's 4.8% gain, its highest in over a decade. Iron ore prices surged, and global trade concerns receded, boosting the mining sub-index. Energy stocks also contributed to the rally, while financial stocks gained 0.6%. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.5% due to losses in utilities and healthcare stocks.

site_title: Two dead, 17 hurt after Japan mass stabbing
summary: A Japanese man carrying two knives stabbed a group of children at a bus stop outside Tokyo, killing one 12-year-old schoolgirl and a man, and injuring 17 others, including more children. The suspect died after stabbing himself in the neck. The attack occurred during the morning commute and school run in a quiet neighborhood. Japan has a low rate of violent crime, and mass attacks are rare.

site_title: Hong Kong's second-richest man joins ageing tycoons in retirement
summary: Hong Kong's second-richest man, Lee Shau Kee, has retired as chairman of Henderson Land Development Co at age 91, handing over to his sons as co-chairmen. This move follows other aging tycoons, including Li Ka-shing, who stepped down last year. Lee expressed optimism about the Hong Kong property market, citing low interest rates, housing demand, and close ties with mainland China. He believes house prices will rise for another decade, driven by the Greater Bay Area project.

site_title: PODCAST: The Emerging Enterprise Award 2019
summary: The Emerging Enterprise Award 2019 celebrates 12 years of honoring young businesses in Singapore under 10 years old, focusing on innovation, resilience, and excellence in SMEs. This year's award recognizes bold ambition in the business community. Meanwhile, news includes: NUS researchers developing sustainable marine fuel, OCBC targeting S$5 billion in loans for serial entrepreneurs, and Shatec shutting its Orchard campus and putting it up for sale.

site_title: Microsoft, Facebook to help tame internet ahead of Canada's election, official says
summary: Microsoft and Facebook have agreed to help boost the security of Canada's upcoming October election by removing fake accounts and cracking down on bots.
