This move comes after the Liberal government of Prime Minister Justin Trudeau expressed concerns that major social media companies were not doing enough to combat potential foreign meddling in the vote. The two companies made commitments in a voluntary declaration on electoral integrity, intensifying efforts to combat disinformation and promote cybersecurity safeguards. The declaration is non-binding, but officials say they will hold the platforms accountable, threatening stronger regulatory reforms if necessary.

site_title: Metro Holdings Q4 profit rises to S$51m, promotes Yip Hoong Mun to CEO
summary: Metro Holdings reported a net profit of S$51 million in Q4, up from S$930,000 a year ago, driven by fair value gains on investment properties. Earnings per share fell to 11.5 cents, and the company proposed a final dividend of two cents and special dividend of 2.5 cents per share. Revenue increased 16.6% to S$40 million, driven by property division and joint venture results. Yip Hoong Mun has been appointed CEO, succeeding Lawrence Chiang, who steps down on May 31.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at Tuesday's open; STI down 0.1% to 3,168.4
summary: Singapore shares declined 0.1% to 3,168.4 on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index retreating 2.37 points. The decline was due to a relatively evenly matched gain-to-loss ratio, with 46 gainers and 45 losers. Asian equities saw modest gains, while US markets were closed due to the Memorial Day holiday. The yuan stabilized despite losses earlier in the month, following US President Donald Trump's declaration that the US was "not ready" to reach a trade deal with China.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo shares rose 0.25% on Tuesday, driven by US President Donald Trump's avoidance of a hardline approach on trade in his meeting with Japan's prime minister. The Nikkei 225 index gained 52.97 points to 21,235.55, while the Topix index added 1.86 points to 1,548.86. The rally comes despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions and uncertainty.

site_title: Trax joins Singapore's rarefied unicorn stable
summary: Singapore-based startup Trax is finalizing a deal to raise US$100 million at a pre-money valuation of US$1.1 billion, making it the second most valuable startup in the city-state. The funding round, expected to close by the end of June, is being discussed with private equity firms. CEO Joel Bar-El confirmed the deal in an interview ahead of a conference at the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Iran slams US after Trump's nuclear weapons comment
summary: Iran's Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif criticized the US after President Donald Trump stated he would welcome talks with Tehran, saying the Trump administration was "hurting the Iranian people and causing tension in the region." Zarif denied Iran's pursuit of nuclear weapons, citing a 2003 fatwa issued by Iran's supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei. The US has increased its military presence in the Middle East in response to alleged Iranian threats, prompting Zarif to call the deployment "very dangerous and a threat to international peace and security."

site_title: Greek PM comes unstuck over Macedonia, austerity in European vote
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras faces a crisis after his Syriza party suffered a major defeat in European Parliament elections, with conservative New Democracy party gaining ground. Tsipras called snap elections, citing the need for Syriza to "regroup and fight." Despite a strong showing by Syriza, analysts say Tsipras is not a spent force and may still lead his party to victory in the national vote. The Greek government's austerity policies and U-turns, including a name change agreement with North Macedonia, are blamed for the party's loss.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise, Athens stocks jump on snap election
summary: European shares rose 0.2% on Monday, driven by car-makers Fiat Chrysler and Renault's talks to merge, and strong support for pro-European Union parties in European parliamentary elections. Greek stocks surged 6.1% on hopes of a new government, while Austrian stocks ended flat after Chancellor Sebastian Kurz's government was ejected. Fiat Chrysler's shares rose 8%, and Renault's shares rose 12.1% following the merger talks.

site_title: China Everbright Water bags 1.25b yuan public-private partnership project in China's Zhejiang
summary: China Everbright Water has entered a 1.25 billion yuan (S$249.7 million) public-private partnership project in Zhejiang province, China, to protect drinking water sources. The project will finance, construct, and operate a wetland ecological engineering project, a water pumping station, and a 30km raw water pipeline network for 20 years. China Everbright Water will own 79.9% of the project, with Tongxiang Water Group holding 20% and CCCC Shanghai Dredging 0.1%. The project aims to enhance long-term returns and value for shareholders, marking China Everbright Water's first environmental water project in Zhejiang province.

site_title: Robo-deliveries are now reality in China
summary: China's Neolix startup has begun mass production of self-driving delivery vehicles, making it the first company globally to do so. The vehicles, resembling tiny vans, are expected to be delivered to companies like JD.Com and Huawei within the first year, with plans to deliver 1,000 units. This technology could revolutionize deliveries in China, with billionaire Jack Ma predicting 1 billion deliveries per day by 2030. Neolix's success comes as other companies like Nuro and FedEx also explore autonomous delivery options.

site_title: Farage's Brexit Party wins 31.6% of EU election vote: final tally
summary: Nigel Farage's Brexit Party secured 31.6% of the vote in the European Parliament elections, winning 29 seats. The Liberal Democrats came in second with 20.3%, followed by Labour with 14.1%, the Greens with 12.1%, and the Conservatives with 9.1%. This marked the Conservatives' worst result in a national vote in nearly 200 years.

images.alt_text: Anti-EU populist Nigel Farage's Brexit Party won 31.6 per cent of the vote in the European Parliament elections, final results showed on Monday, giving it 29 seats.

site_title: China Everbright unit bags Phase 2 of industrial waste water project in Jiangsu
summary: China Everbright Water has secured the second phase of an industrial waste water project worth 859.4 million yuan (S$171.3 million) in the Pukou Economic Development Zone of Nanjing City, Jiangsu Province, China. The project, on a build-operate-transfer model, aims to meet the rising need for industrial waste water treatment in the area. Returns on investment will be from waste water treatment service fees paid by Nanjing Tianpu. The project is expected to enhance long-term returns and value for shareholders of China Everbright Water.

site_title: VW to reshuffle 50b euros battery push as Samsung deal at risk: sources
summary: Volkswagen AG is reshuffling its 50 billion euro battery-purchasing plan amid concerns that its supply deal with Samsung SDI Co Ltd may unravel. The deal initially agreed upon was for 20 gigawatt hours of batteries, but disagreements over production volume and schedule led to a reduction in pledged supplies to less than five gigawatt hours. The move comes as carmakers face challenges in accessing batteries to power electric vehicles due to capacity constraints, supply bottlenecks, and limited access to raw materials.

site_title: Vallianz, USP Group warn of fiscal 2019 net losses
summary: Vallianz Holdings and USP Group, two Singapore-listed companies, have warned of expected net losses for the fiscal year ended March 31, 2019. Vallianz is likely to post a significant net loss due to non-cash impairment expenses, while USP expects a net loss based on preliminary unaudited financial results. Both companies advise investors to exercise caution when dealing in their securities. Vallianz will release its unaudited full-year financial results on May 30, and USP will announce its FY2019 results by the same date.

site_title: Japanese man dies mid-flight with stomach full of cocaine
summary: A 42-year-old Japanese man, identified as Udo "N," died mid-flight from Bogota to Tokyo after swallowing 246 packets of cocaine, each measuring 2.5cm in length. He suffered a seizure after traveling from Colombia to Mexico City and boarding a connecting flight. The cause of death was swelling of the brain caused by a drug overdose. The Aeromexico plane made an emergency landing in Hermosillo, Sonora, and resumed its flight after the body was removed. The incident is believed to be a smuggling tactic by drug cartels.

site_title: Alibaba eyeing second listing in Hong Kong to raise US$20b
summary: Alibaba is considering a second listing in Hong Kong to raise US$20 billion, aiming to diversify funding channels and boost liquidity. The e-commerce giant is working with financial advisers and plans to file a confidential listing application in the second half of 2019. This move comes as Chinese companies face increased hostility from the US government, with several Chinese tech companies postponing IPOs due to market jitters over the trade war. Alibaba's New York-traded shares have slid 22% in the past year, but the company has a market capitalization of US$400 billion.

site_title: Oil rises to US$69 as Middle East tension and supply cuts offset trade concerns
summary: Oil prices rose to about US$69 a barrel on Monday, driven by Middle East tensions and Opec-led supply cuts, despite concerns over the US-China trade dispute and global economy. Supply cuts, including those resulting from US sanctions, have contributed to a 29% year-to-date increase in Brent crude. However, the global economy's outlook remains a concern, with money managers cutting their bets on rising prices. Tensions between the US and Iran also support the market, but its impact may be limited.

site_title: Ayondo chairman disposed of 1.2m shares on Nov 22 for undisclosed sum
summary: AYondo chairman Thomas Winkler transferred 1.2 million shares on Nov 22, 2018, to existing shareholders for an undisclosed price. This reduced his shareholding to 5.66% from 5.9%. The transfer occurred after a six-month moratorium expired on Sept 26, 2018. Winkler also moved another 1.2 million shares to a custodian account on May 2, 2019. The transactions were only announced on Tuesday, following a reconciliation of share transaction records, amid trading suspension due to financial viability and compliance questions.

site_title: Plunge in migration deepens New Zealand labour shortage, chokes businesses
summary: New Zealand's labour shortage deepens due to a plunge in net immigration, exacerbating an already strained economy. Businesses, particularly in sectors such as agriculture, hospitality, and construction, struggle to find workers with the necessary skills. The central bank has cut interest rates for the first time since 2016, citing the labour shortage as a major concern. The government has introduced measures to improve vocational training and tighten work visa restrictions, but some businesses claim the process is becoming increasingly difficult and uncertain. The country's unemployment rate remains at decade lows, but the labour shortage is expected to worsen.

site_title: Money, money, money: behind the scenes at a euro note printing press
summary: The European Central Bank's Banknote Printing Department has begun producing new 100 and 200 euro banknotes, featuring enhanced security features. The Europa series notes, named after the mythological princess, include large value numerals, watermarks, and a portrait of Europa, making them more difficult to counterfeit. The ECB prints about 2.3 billion 100 euro notes annually, with some notes being kept in vaults and sent to commercial banks as needed. The new notes aim to stay ahead of counterfeiters and offer better protection against forgery.

images.alt_text: In secretive vaults in Rome, crisp 100 and 200 euro banknotes are rolling off the printing press.

site_title: Revenue growth strengthens UnUsUaL's FY19 bottom line
summary: UnUsUaL, a Singapore media company, reported a 31.7% year-over-year increase in net profit to S$13.19 million, driven by 22.6% revenue growth to S$56.93 million in FY2019. The revenue boost came from higher contributions from promotion and other revenue segments.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Coffee with Claressa: DinoQuest is for the whole family
summary: World-renowned palaeontologist Patricia Vickers-Rich joins Money FM podcast "Coffee with Claressa" to discuss the Singapore Science Centre's new exhibition "DinoQuest" opening on June 1. Vickers-Rich shares her expertise on dinosaurs and the family-friendly exhibition, which aims to educate visitors of all ages about prehistoric creatures.

site_title: Brazil ex-billionaire fined US$134 million for insider trading
summary: Brazilian ex-billionaire Eike Batista was fined $134 million for insider trading and banned from running a publicly traded company for seven years. Batista, who was once the richest man in Brazil, was accused of selling shares in his oil company OGX in 2013 after knowing it would fail to explore blocks acquired at an auction in 2007. This is the second time he has been fined for insider trading, following a 30-year prison sentence for corruption and money laundering in 2018.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler puts merger offer to Renault board
summary: Fiat Chrysler has made a merger proposal to Renault, aiming to create a world No.3 global car manufacturer. The deal, valued at 5 billion euros, would combine the two companies' brands, selling 8.7 million vehicles annually, and generate annual savings. The merger, discussed at Renault's board meeting, could alter the competitive landscape and have significant repercussions for Renault's alliance with Nissan. The deal faces political and workforce hurdles, including potential factory closures, but the French government and Italian government have expressed support in principle.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Bukit Sembawang, China Everbright Water, UnUsUaL, Vividthree, Ossia, Vallianz, USP Group
summary: Singapore stocks saw new developments on Tuesday, with several companies reporting financial results. Bukit Sembawang Estates posted a loss of S$11.6 million for the fourth quarter, despite revenue rising 72%. China Everbright Water secured a public-private partnership for a 1.25 billion yuan project. UnUsUaL reported a 31.7% jump in year-on-year net profit to S$13.19 million. Vividthree Holdings posted a net profit of S$1.5 million for the fourth quarter, more than 20 times the figure for the year-ago period. Ossia International reported a net profit of S$3.92 million, down 7.8% from the previous year. Vallianz Holdings and USP Group are expected to post significant net losses for the year ended March 31.

site_title: Austrian chancellor loses no-confidence showdown
summary: Austrian Chancellor Sebastian Kurz lost a no-confidence vote after a corruption scandal, known as "Ibiza-gate," brought down his coalition with the far-right Freedom Party. Kurz was accused of an "uncurbed and shameless power grab" and was voted out by more than half of MPs. He will remain in office as a caretaker government is expected to be appointed by President Alexander Van der Bellen. Kurz won a European election for his conservative People's Party, but the FPOe suffered a setback in the same election, falling from 19.7% to 17.2% of the vote.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: AA Group Holdings has called off a potential data centre deal with OneAsia Network due to disagreements on mutually acceptable terms. Boustead Singapore reported a 2% increase in net profit to S$7.9 million for the fourth quarter, driven by a 27% rise in revenue. Vividthree Holdings posted a significant net profit increase, more than 20 times the figure for the previous year, due to doubling of revenue. No dividend was declared by Vividthree due to cash conservation.

site_title: Huawei founder defiant in face of existential threat
summary: Huawei founder Ren Zhengfei expressed defiance in the face of US sanctions, stating the company will either develop its own chips or find alternatives to maintain its edge in smartphones and 5G. The Trump administration's export curbs will cut into Huawei's two-year lead over rivals, but the company is determined to overcome the challenge. Zhengfei's comments came after the US imposed curbs on Huawei's access to US technology, threatening the company's survival.

site_title: Euro struggles to cling on to gains
summary: The euro struggled to maintain gains after European parliamentary elections, where centre-right and centre-left blocs lost their majority but parties committed to strengthening the union held on to two-thirds of seats. The euro initially rose to a two-year high but later fell 0.1% to US$1.1197 due to market holidays. Despite the mixed results, the euro held on to gains against the Swiss franc and is still awaiting the US Federal Reserve's potential interest rate cut later this year, which could impact the currency market.

site_title: Australia home prices' long decline pauses on rate cut prospects
summary: Australian home prices in capital cities rose 0.1% last week, marking a pause in declines, driven by expectations of lower mortgage rates and continued tax breaks for property investing. This stability is seen as a welcome relief for the economy, as sliding prices have eroded consumer spending power. A pause in price declines could boost confidence and stimulate economic growth.

site_title: Singapore must stay out of the 5G war between US and China
summary: Singapore should avoid taking sides in the US-China 5G trade war, balancing vendor choice with security concerns. The US has blocked Huawei from participating in 5G trials due to security fears, but China's technological prowess poses a challenge to Western dominance. Countries like Singapore need to ensure networks are secure and competitively priced, without being locked into a single vendor. Vigilance is warranted, but taking sides is not necessary, as the responsibility lies with telecommunications operators to maintain high-quality networks.

site_title: DPM Heng tours Singapore-China knowledge city in Guangzhou
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat toured the Sino-Singapore Guangzhou Knowledge City (SSGKC) in Guangzhou, China, during an eight-day working visit to China. The SSGKC, launched in 2010, is a private-sector project aiming to build an innovation and knowledge hub in the Greater Bay Area, attracting research institutes and talent. Heng met with Guangzhou party secretary Zhang Shuofu, affirming the project's progress, and later visited Tencent's headquarters, where he was briefed on the company's technology and products.

site_title: Three floors at The Octagon for sale at indicative total price of S$43m
summary: Three floors at The Octagon, a 25-storey freehold office building in Singapore's CBD, are up for sale through a bulk tender with an indicative price of S$43 million. The prime ground floor retail unit and two office floors have a total strata area of around 15,995 sq ft. Strong interest is seen for freehold strata retail and office floors in the CBD, with the recent CBD incentive scheme encouraging owners to relook their options. The tender closes on July 3.

site_title: IHH Healthcare chief executive to retire at year-end
summary: IHH Healthcare's managing director and CEO Tan See Leng will retire at year-end, replaced by Kelvin Loh, former Mount Elizabeth Hospital CEO. The move comes after Japan's Mitsui & Co acquired a 32.9% stake in the group. Tan, 54, will step down after 15 years, while Loh, 45, will lead the transition process from July 1 and take over as CEO-designate on January 1, 2020.

site_title: Pro-EU parties have firm hold on parliament
summary: Pro-EU parties maintained control of the EU parliament, with liberals and greens matching eurosceptic gains. The parties won 507 of 751 seats, with liberals and greens forming a pro-EU coalition. The EU's social and democratic groups aim to build a "social Europe" and protect workers' rights, free speech, and democracy. Investor sentiment was bolstered by the smaller-than-expected gains by populist parties, but a shift in the balance of power could complicate policymaking and require broader cross-party agreements.

site_title: Will China dump US dollars?
summary: China holds over $1 trillion in US Treasury securities, sparking concerns that it could dump the dollars to harm the US economy, potentially triggering a recession. However, experts doubt China's willingness to do so, citing the risks of reducing the value of its remaining Treasury holdings and exacerbating a global recession. The US Treasury market's "safe asset" status and the global appetite for US debt securities also suggest that China is unlikely to deliberately undermine the market. Instead, China's economy is struggling with unsustainable debt levels, leading many to predict a decline in growth.

site_title: Fallout from US$2b ruling against Monsanto
summary: Bayer, a German multinational pharmaceutical and life sciences company, is facing significant financial and reputational damage after being ordered to pay over $2 billion in damages to a couple whose cancer was allegedly caused by using Roundup, a weed killer manufactured by its subsidiary Monsanto. The company has been criticized for its "circling the wagons" strategy to discredit scientists warning of Roundup's safety risks, despite internal documents revealing questionable tactics. Bayer's US$63 billion purchase of Monsanto has also led to a 40% decline in its shares, with estimated damages potentially reaching up to $14.6 billion.

site_title: Nasdaq pulls out of Oslo Bors battle with Euronext
summary: Nasdaq has withdrawn its bid to acquire Oslo Bors, allowing Euronext to pursue the acquisition. Euronext secured approval from Norway's Ministry of Finance to buy over 50% of Oslo Bors for 158 Norwegian crowns per share, effectively blocking Nasdaq's bid. The acquisition is expected to diversify Euronext's revenue and block Nasdaq's ambition to complete a sweep of the Nordic-Baltic region. Both exchanges aim to expand their portfolios, but opportunities are scarce due to market consolidation.

site_title: Expanding overseas still not an easy task for SMEs
summary: Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) face challenges in expanding overseas due to limited resources, unfamiliar regulatory environments, and building a strong local foundation. Despite the government's push to support SMEs in internationalization, many remain reluctant to take the leap. Industry leaders cited these factors as major hurdles, highlighting the need for targeted support and strategies to overcome these obstacles.

site_title: China April imports of US coking coal up 5-fold on trade deal bets
summary: China's imports of US coking coal rose 5-fold in April to 308,789 tonnes, driven by traders' bets that trade tensions were easing. This was a significant increase from 60,585 tonnes in March and 133,315 tonnes in April last year. The imports reflect US vessels departing in February and early March, before new tariffs were imposed. Chinese buyers are hesitant to buy US coal due to high sulphur content and uncertainty in the trade situation, with Australian coking coal imports increasing instead.

site_title: Air New Zealand orders eight Boeing 787 jets for long-haul flights
summary: Air New Zealand has ordered eight Boeing 787-10 Dreamliner jets worth $2.7 billion, to be powered by General Electric engines, as part of a drive towards increased efficiency. The order confirms Boeing beat out Airbus and will replace eight older 777-200ERs, leaving the carrier with an all-Boeing wide-body fleet. The 787s will enter the fleet between 2022 and 2027, offering 15% more space for customers and cargo than the 787-9. The airline cited the 787's 25% fuel efficiency as a key factor in the decision.

site_title: New York's vanishing diners
summary: New York City's iconic diners are facing a decline due to increasing rents, enticing offers, and changing tastes. Many are closing, with 39 closing in the past three years, as owners struggle to make ends meet. The classic diner's heyday was in the 1920s, but only about 80 remain, with 16 sold since 2014. Owners like Louis Gritsipis, who refuses to sell his Hell's Kitchen diner, are fighting to preserve their businesses, while others are adapting by offering delivery services or exploring alternative uses for their properties.

site_title: Remaining competitive in the Fourth Industrial Revolution
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) must adapt to the Fourth Industrial Revolution by re-skilling their workforce and shifting to knowledge-based businesses. Low-skilled jobs are at risk of being replaced by AI and robotics, but future generations can succeed with the right skillsets. To remain competitive, businesses should focus on innovation, digitalization, and upskilling their employees. This will enable them to thrive in the new era.

site_title: Assisted living: Trendy lifestyle for all ages
summary: Luxury developers in Manhattan are shifting their focus from hotel-like amenities to community-building activities catering to idealistic millennials. Companies like LIVunltd, which oversees over 100 buildings, are hosting events such as beekeeping talks, dance classes, and art workshops to foster a sense of community among residents. These activities are often free or low-cost, and are designed to create a unique experience for residents. With the rise of luxury condos, these events have become an essential part of the building's story, offering residents a sense of belonging and connection.

site_title: Emaar Properties hires advisers for sale of district cooling unit
summary: Emaar Properties, a Dubai-based developer, has hired advisers, including Standard Chartered, to sell its district cooling business as part of its plan to offload non-core activities. The move follows a statement by Emaar chairman Mohammed Alabbar last year that the group aims to sell assets beyond its main businesses. The company has not commented on the sale, despite reports suggesting it is worth billions. Emaar's core businesses focus on property development, retail, and hospitality, with a 7.2% increase in first-quarter profit reported earlier this month.

site_title: Singapore caught in the crossfire of powerful clans
summary: A bond offering by Eldorado Brasil Celulose, a pulp maker owned by the Widjaja family and the Batista brothers, has been blocked by a Singapore court due to allegations of material inaccuracies. The court ordered Eldorado to clarify information on its offer document. The dispute is part of a larger corruption scandal in Brazil involving the Batista brothers and has also led to a arbitration process between the two families. The outcome of the bond sale remains unclear, with Eldorado's financial information disputed by a shareholder.

site_title: New S$40m plant converts NTU's waste into power and building materials
summary: A new S$40 million incineration facility in Singapore's Tuas South has been launched to convert NTU's waste into electricity and building materials. The facility can process 11 tonnes of rubbish daily through gasification, producing synthetic gas, electricity, and recyclable metal alloys. The high-temperature furnace can kill harmful pathogens and convert waste into liquid fuel. The plant aims to minimize landfill waste and recover value from treated waste, with the goal of producing valuable resources from previously discarded materials.

site_title: Celebrating Lennon-Ono's 'bed-in' for peace, 50 years later
summary: John Lennon and Yoko Ono spent 7 days in 1969 at The Queen Elizabeth hotel in Montreal, wearing pajamas and holding a "bed-in" for peace during the Vietnam War. Fifty years later, the hotel is celebrating this event with guided tours of their room, where they recorded "Give Peace a Chance."

site_title: Road to the Fiat Chrysler, Renault merger talks
summary: Fiat Chrysler and Renault announced a proposal to merge in May 2019, with each company's shareholders controlling 50% of the new entity. The potential deal, announced after years of consolidation talks, comes as the car industry faces tightening emissions regulations and global competition. Sergio Marchionne's leadership at Fiat and Carlos Ghosn's departure from Renault laid groundwork for the talks. However, the proposal's future remains uncertain, with Fiat Chrysler stating it is open to pursuing alliances and merger opportunities.

site_title: Bitcoin rises to year-high amid cryptocurrency comeback
summary: Bitcoin surged to a year-high, reaching $8,847, after more than doubling since March. Rival coins like Litecoin and Ether also rose. The price increase is attributed to mainstream firms' growing interest in the cryptocurrency space, including Fidelity's plans to buy and sell Bitcoin and AT&T's permit for crypto payments. Analysts see the rally as a sign of adoption, but some warn of a potential pullback due to lingering concerns and caution in crypto transactions.

site_title: Increasing trading within region will help Asean build resilience against global trade tensions
summary: The ongoing US-China trade tensions have sparked concerns for the Asean region, but it also presents an opportunity for the region to strengthen its resilience. Trade diversion is occurring as companies shift imports from the US and China to other countries, with six Asean countries (Malaysia, Thailand, Philippines, and others) benefiting from this "import substitution effect". Asean countries can also increase trade within the region, with a goal of reaching 50% of intra-regional trade, and attract foreign direct investment by implementing policies to liberalize ownership restrictions and improve the business climate.

site_title: A holistic security strategy can cut risks of ransomware attacks
summary: Ransomware attacks are expected to continue posing a significant threat to businesses in 2019 and beyond. According to Verizon's Data Breach Investigations Report 2018, ransomware comprised 39% of all malware attacks, and a Singapore-based public/private initiative warned that a major ransomware attack could cost $193 billion and affect over 600,000 businesses globally. SMEs in Singapore are particularly vulnerable due to inadequate planning and resources. To counter this threat, organizations must adopt a holistic security strategy that includes time-sensitive measures, such as implementing and maintaining common-sense protection measures, and investing in enhanced behavioral protection for mission-critical systems.

site_title: China to sell strategic Anbang stake under revamp plan
summary: China is selling a strategic stake in Anbang Insurance Group Co, the acquisitive insurer it took over in 2018 amid a fraud investigation. Most of Anbang's businesses will be moved into a new company called Dajia Baoxian, with some policies sold by Anbang's property insurance unit not being transferred. To make the business more palatable to investors, regulators are stripping out investment-type policies. China aims to reduce its ownership by February next year, and Anbang plans to rely on professional insurance agencies to sell its life policies.

site_title: Will Vegas glitz play in Boston? Wynn Resorts will soon find out
summary: Wynn Resorts has decided to keep its $2.6 billion Massachusetts project, Encore Boston Harbor, after previously considering a sale to MGM Resorts International. The casino, set to open next month, will feature Vegas-inspired glitz with high-end dining, modern art, and a nightclub. Analysts expect the property to be successful, citing the Boston market's sports-crazy atmosphere and the potential for international clientele. Encore will also offer unique local cuisine options, including lobster rolls with truffles and caviar. The company still needs to address state gaming commission demands for an independent monitor.

site_title: Ascendas-Singbridge to launch urban solutions co-innovation lab
summary: Ascendas-Singbridge, being acquired by CapitaLand, is launching a Smart Urban Co-Innovation Lab in Singapore Science Park, supported by IMDA and ESG. The lab will focus on smart urban solutions, including intelligent estates, smart mobility, and agritech, and will provide a platform for companies to collaborate and commercialize new technologies. The lab will also offer access to ASB's portfolio developments and help participants develop a business case and connect with investors. The initiative aims to promote the development of smart urban solutions in Singapore and overseas.

images.alt_text: S Iswaran (fifth from left), Minister for Communications and Information, with key executives from Ascendas-Singbridge, IMDA and ESG.

site_title: Plan B Media looking to up its stakes in Singapore to expand in region
summary: Plan B Media, a Thailand-based out-of-home media company, is expanding its operations in Singapore as part of its efforts to grow in the region. The company, which has partners in multiple ASEAN countries, aims to leverage Singapore's advertising space despite competition from streaming platforms and social media. Plan B's CEO, Palin Lojanagosin, believes out-of-home media can still be effective, citing its ability to provide a unique experience and leverage online platforms. The company has also ventured into sports marketing and social media engagement, with success in promoting Thai idol group BNK48.

images.alt_text: "We saw a very strong opportunity for brands to get better conversion for products BNK48 endorsed," says Mr Luechaikajohnpan (left). "Singapore has always been something we want to put into our portfolio," says Mr Lojanagosin (right).

site_title: Huawei supplier surges in Hong Kong after cancelling NYSE listing
summary: Shanghai-based chipmaker SMIC surged in Hong Kong after cancelling its NYSE listing, attracting more volume to its main listing. The stock rose 10% on Monday, making it the top gainer on the MSCI China Index. SMIC's biggest customer is Huawei Technologies Co, whose parent company is subject to a US ban. This move is seen as a strategic decision to focus on its main listing in Hong Kong, potentially increasing trading volume and liquidity.

site_title: Eagle Hospitality slides further despite action by stabilising agent
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) saw its stapled securities decline 4.1% to US$0.70, amid a selloff by investors and stabilisation efforts by DBS Bank. The trust's IPO was met with a poor take-up, with only 0.4 times subscribed to the public offer tranche. In contrast, ARA US Hospitality Trust's IPO was 1.1 times subscribed, and its listing portfolio performance was better. Market watchers attribute EHT's poor performance to bad timing, given the worsening US-China trade spat.

site_title: HSBC Singapore creates new role to drive financial institution clients coverage in S-EA
summary: HSBC Singapore has appointed Kanakanjan Ray as head of financial institutions group (FIG), South-east Asia, a newly created role. Ray will lead the lender's activities across the region, focusing on financial institution clients in Singapore, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Thailand, and Vietnam. The appointment is part of HSBC Singapore's three-year country strategic plan to build its Asean credentials and regional coverage. Ray brings over 15 years of experience, including his previous role as country head of FIG in Singapore.

site_title: Singapore equity prices look appetising but investors not biting
summary: Singapore equity prices appear attractive, trading at 12.9 times price-to-earnings, making it one of the cheapest in Asia. However, investors are hesitant to buy, preferring to wait for the US-China trade tensions to resolve. Experts predict a further downside of less than 10% for the Singapore market, with recent escalations largely priced in. Despite this, the market's high dividend yield and stable earnings growth make it an attractive option, with some analysts predicting a potential trade diversion benefit for Singapore if the US-China trade war escalates.

site_title: Craft brewers lighten up and take aim at the 'sweaty consumer'
summary: Craft breweries are shifting their focus from high-calorie, high-hop beers to lighter, lower-calorie options catering to consumers concerned with maintaining active lifestyles. Dogfish Head and other breweries are producing beers with fewer calories than traditional light beers, while some craft brands are acquiring smaller labels to expand their lighter beer offerings. The trend is driven by changing consumer preferences, with 52% of beer drinkers wanting to reduce their alcohol consumption. Breweries are marketing their beers as components of active lifestyles, emphasizing ingredients and flavors that support health and wellness.

images.alt_text: Sierra Nevada Brewing (above) in California is among the breweries responding to consumers more concerned with healthy lifestyles than with hops or high alcohol content.
Caitlyn Landesberg (above), founder of Sufferfest Beer Co, which markets its beers to runners.

site_title: Flat trading session on lack of catalysts
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) settled at 3,170.77, down 0.88 point, after a flat trading session with 188 decliners outpacing advancers 159. Regional indices were mixed, with China's Shanghai Composite Index posting the strongest gains. Investors remained cautious due to US-China trade tensions, with market strategist Pan Jingyi noting that other key events, such as US consumer confidence data, will influence market sentiment.

site_title: Japan to limit foreign ownership of firms in high-tech sectors
summary: Japan's government plans to limit foreign ownership of firms in 20 high-tech sectors, effective August 1, amid concerns over cyber-security risks and technological transfers involving China. This new rule aims to restrict foreign ownership of Japanese firms in information and communications industries. The move follows pressure from the US, and it is expected to impact businesses operating in these sectors, potentially limiting their access to foreign investment and partnerships.

site_title: Trump presses Japan on trade gap, wants trade barriers removed
summary: US President Donald Trump pressed Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe to narrow the trade gap between the two countries, aiming to remove trade barriers to level the playing field for US exports. Trump expressed optimism about North Korea's nuclear program, but said he was in no rush for a peace deal. The two leaders agreed to expand cooperation in human space exploration. Trump also hinted at further announcements on trade soon.

site_title: Status quo powers fall away in EU elections earthquake
summary: In the European Parliament (EP) elections, anti-integration parties, centrist liberals, and greens gained power in a referendum on the EU's six-decade integration project. The results, seen as a mixed message from voters, led to a more fragmented political landscape. Anti-integration parties made gains in some countries, including Italy and Hungary, while centrist parties, including Emmanuel Macron's En Marche!, also won seats. The outcome will shape the EU's agenda into the 2020s and has implications for the world's economy, as the EU remains a significant economic power.

site_title: After EU poll disaster, Britain's main parties gird for no-deal Brexit battle
summary: Britain's main parties, the Conservatives and Labour, are set for a battle over a no-deal Brexit after European elections, where the Brexit Party led by Nigel Farage captured the most votes. The outcome has led contenders for the Conservative leadership to pledge to deliver Brexit, while Labour says a public vote or new national election is needed to reunite the country. The two parties face pressure to commit to either side of the debate, with Farage seeking to be included in any new negotiations.

site_title: IoT startup Brazn clinches US$3.65m from Tin Men in seed round
summary: IoT startup Brazn has secured a US$3.65 million seed investment from Tin Men Capital, its first and sole venture investor. The funds will be used to enhance Brazn's existing products, including Buildos, Retailr, and Agrios. This investment aims to further develop the company's IoT solutions.

site_title: Ossia posts 7.8% drop in full-year net profit to S$3.92m
summary: Ossia International reported a 7.8% drop in full-year net profit to S$3.92 million, down from S$4.16 million in the previous year, due to a decline in sales by 18.4% to S$23.95 million. The decline was attributed to the disposal of business and end of operations in Malaysia. Ossia has proposed a final dividend of 0.17 Singapore cent per share and will focus on its core business by closing non-performing outlets and brands.

site_title: Adjudicator says any security defence of US auto tariffs at WTO "very difficult"
summary: The US will find it "very difficult" to defend President Donald Trump's proposed 25% car tariff against any challenge at the World Trade Organisation, according to a veteran trade adjudicator. The tariff, which applies to vehicles and components from everywhere else in the world, is justified under a WTO exception for national security. However, trade experts doubt the national security argument would withstand a legal challenge, citing a high bar set by a previous ruling that national security claims need to be based on an emergency in international relations.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT) has been upgraded to a "buy" with a target price of S$2.65 due to its prime beneficiary status in Singapore's Jurong Lake District. The Reit's Funan mall, set to open in June, is expected to contribute S$16.5 million in rental income in the third quarter. In contrast, Valuetronics Holdings has been downgraded to "neutral" with a target price of S$0.67 due to the ongoing trade war and tariffs affecting its manufacturing business.

site_title: CapitaLand's new exco to include several C-suite Ascendas-Singbridge execs
summary: CapitaLand is setting up a new executive committee to oversee its post-Ascendas-Singbridge acquisition. The committee, led by CEO Lee Chee Koon, includes several C-suite executives from Ascendas-Singbridge, focusing on strategic planning, organisational alignment, and implementation. The acquisition is on track for completion by end-June, propelling CapitaLand into one of Asia's largest diversified real estate groups with over S$123 billion of assets under management. The new committee will also establish a group centre of excellence to enhance capabilities, innovation, and standards across various business sectors.

site_title: Cybersecurity as a strategic investment for businesses
summary: Cybersecurity is a crucial investment for businesses in the age of Industry 4.0, where smart and autonomous systems, data analytics, and AI are increasingly adopted. A cyber-attack can disrupt business operations, as seen in Norsk Hydro's ransomware attack that cost the company up to US$52 million. The Singapore government has established the Cyber Security Agency to oversee national cybersecurity functions, and organizations must prioritize cybersecurity as a core component of their business. Effective cybersecurity requires a "defence-in-depth" approach, balancing technology, processes, and people, and involves developing a positive cybersecurity culture within the organization.

site_title: New blockchain platform for wine verifies authenticity, tokenises bottles
summary: EY has developed an e-commerce blockchain platform for Blockchain Wine's TATTOO Wine Platform, allowing wine producers to track authenticity, quality, and origin. The platform tokenizes bottles, enables real-time shipment tracking, and arranges insurance coverage. A smart-contract capability ensures transparency and saves time by providing a decentralized system for agreements between producers, logistics operators, and insurance providers. This blockchain-based solution aims to improve the wine industry's supply chain management and authentication process.

site_title: Germany to order banks to boost recession buffers
summary: Germany's Financial Stability Commission has ordered banks to boost recession buffers for the first time, citing financial stability risks due to low interest rates and potential undervalued risks. The move aims to prevent a credit crunch in case of a recession. The commission warned that if risks materialize, banks may excessively limit credit to the real economy, exacerbating the situation.

images.alt_text: German banks will for the first time be required to bolster capital buffers designed to prevent a credit crunch in case of recession, authorities said Monday.

site_title: World's rivers loaded with antibiotics waste: study
summary: Rivers worldwide are heavily polluted with antibiotics, exceeding safety thresholds by up to 300 times, according to a study of 711 river samples from 72 countries. One-third of samples contained common antibiotics, with Ciprofloxacin surpassing safety levels at 51 sites and metronidazole concentrations reaching 300 times the limit in Bangladesh. The widespread presence of antibiotics contributes to antimicrobial resistance and impacts wildlife, with the World Health Organization warning of a global shortage of effective antibiotics.

site_title: EU draws red line for Trump on cars, calling quotas a no-go
summary: The European Union has rejected US President Donald Trump's proposal to fix quotas on European automotive exports to the US, citing World Trade Organization rules that prohibit voluntarily restricting exports. EU trade chiefs dismissed Trump's claim that European car shipments pose a threat to national security. The EU has warned of greater transatlantic trade tensions if the US pursues such measures. The US Trade Representative, Robert Lighthizer, is set to address the matter in talks with the EU and Japan, but the EU remains resolute in its opposition.

site_title: Shenton Way, Tanjong Pagar offices most popular among tech tenants in Asia
summary: Singapore's Shenton Way/Tanjong Pagar district is the most popular location among tech tenants in Asia, according to a Colliers report. The district's "excellent accessibility" makes it attractive to TMT firms and flexible workspace operators. City Hall and the Raffles Place/New Downtown area are also considered good locations, offering ample office stock. Other top tech locations in Asia include Hong Kong, Bangalore, Shenzhen, and Tokyo, with specific recommended areas such as Outer Ring Road in Bangalore and Causeway Bay in Hong Kong.

site_title: WHO recognises 'burn-out' as medical condition
summary: The World Health Organisation (WHO) has officially recognized "burn-out" as a medical condition, with the International Classification of Diseases (ICD) defining it as a syndrome resulting from chronic workplace stress. The condition is characterized by three dimensions: energy depletion, mental distance, and reduced professional efficacy. This decision marks the first time burn-out has been included in the ICD, which will take effect in January 2022. The update also recognizes video gaming as an addiction and removes transgenderism from its list of mental disorders.

site_title: US measles outbreak grows with 60 new measles cases across 26 states
summary: The US recorded 60 new measles cases last week, bringing the total to 940 confirmed cases, the worst outbreak since 1994. The outbreak, which has reached 26 states, shows a 6.8% increase in cases from the previous week. Experts warn the outbreak is not over, as the number of cases edges closer to the 1994 total of 958. This marks the highest number of measles cases since 1992, when the CDC recorded 2,126 cases.

site_title: Trump presses Japan over trade gap
summary: US President Donald Trump pressed Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe to narrow the country's trade imbalance, citing an "unbelievably large" trade gap favoring Japan. Trump expressed optimism about a potential trade deal, stating he would have more to announce soon, while Abe agreed to speed up two-way trade talks but dodged a question about timing. Trump is on a four-day state visit to Japan, which aims to showcase the alliance between the two countries, and has hinted that significant trade moves may come after Japan's upper house election in July.

site_title: Indonesia, Inpex agree on Masela gas block framework
summary: Indonesia's oil and gas regulator SKK Migas has agreed with Japanese energy explorer Inpex Corp on a revised $20 billion development plan for the Masela gas block. The government expects to have at least a 50% share in production. The project, delayed since 2016 due to changes in the development scheme, is expected to benefit the local economy. The agreement marks a significant step forward for the Masela project, which could potentially unlock Indonesia's natural gas resources and meet the country's energy needs.

site_title: Aladdin takes flight with US$105m box office haul
summary: Disney's live-action Aladdin has taken flight with a US$105 million box office haul in North America during the Memorial Day holiday weekend, becoming the sixth-highest total ever. The film dominated internationally, earning US$121 million in 56 markets. With a 67% recommendation rate, Aladdin outperformed Disney's pre-opening domestic projections, exceeding US$75 million to US$85 million. The film's success marks a strong Memorial Day weekend, with Aladdin set to finish fifth in the domestic box office.

site_title: Gold hits one-week high on simmering US-China trade spat
summary: Gold prices reached a one-week high on May 27, 2019, due to fears of a prolonged US-China trade war, which hurt risk sentiment. The metal edged 0.1% higher to $1,286.21 per ounce, boosted by weak US economic data and US Federal Reserve rate cut bets. Analysts attributed the surge to the simmering trade spat and ongoing uncertainty, including the UK's Brexit uncertainty and US President Donald Trump's tariff threats.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed, a significant success. Meanwhile, US stocks opened lower due to a fresh tariff salvo from the US on Canada. Companies like Creative Technology warned of lower-than-target H2 revenue and operating losses. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10b upgrade. In other news, an Indonesian court detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case, and Singapore's MAS and PBOC are expanding green finance cooperation. Singapore stocks continued their 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Thailand on red alert in bid to stop 'pig ebola' crossing border
summary: Thailand is on high alert to prevent the spread of African swine fever, a lethal pig virus that has been spreading across Asia, causing widespread deaths and a global protein shortage. The disease has been detected in several countries, including Vietnam, Cambodia, and China, and Thailand has tightened inspections, cracked down on illegal slaughterhouses, and imposed stricter reporting requirements. With no vaccine available, the Thai government estimates a potential outbreak could cost the economy over $1 billion, and experts warn that no country is safe from the virus.

site_title: Swee Kee and Ka Soh start next chapter
summary: Swee Kee Eating House, a Singaporean family restaurant, marks its 80th anniversary with the third-generation owner, Cedric Tang, taking over. The restaurant, known for its commitment to using high-quality ingredients and traditional Cantonese-style dishes, has expanded to a new food court stall at Changi Airport's Jewel. To attract a younger generation, the family has also launched a new branch, Faai Di by Ka Soh, with a different menu and brand name. Tang hopes to expand the business in Singapore and overseas, aiming to preserve Asian food culture.

images.alt_text: Cedric Tang, owner and director of Ka Soh and Swee Kee Restaurant, says candidly that he and his siblings could each have pursued other careers, but they share a passion for the family business and that it would be a 'waste' if the restaurant has to close down.

site_title: Deal signed with authorities for China Jinjiang waste-to-energy project
summary: A public-private partnership agreement has been signed for a waste-to-energy project in Yan'an, China's Shaanxi province, with China Jinjiang Environment Holding investing 49% and local government partner Yan'an Guojin Environmental Protection Energy Co. The $64.8 million project, expected to be completed by 2020, will have a 1,300-tonne waste treatment capacity and 100-tonne sludge treatment capacity. The 30-year concession period includes a 2-year construction phase and 28-year operation phase, with the investment funded through bank borrowings and internal resources.

site_title: Thailand's pro-army party seeks allies to cement power
summary: Thailand's pro-army party, Palang Pracharat, has invited two parties, the Democrat and Bhumjaithai parties, to join its coalition government, potentially securing a slim majority in the House of Representatives. The move aims to counter the opposition Democratic Front coalition's bid to limit junta members' influence. A deal is expected to give the pro-army coalition a majority, with Palang Pracharat leader Uttama Savanayana expressing confidence in forming a government soon.

site_title: European trade policy seen going greener after EU parliament vote
summary: The European Union is shifting towards a more climate-oriented trade policy following the EU parliament vote, with liberal and Green blocs gaining seats. The Greens, led by Greta Thunberg's "Greta effect," and French President Emmanuel Macron's party are likely to push for environmental protection and sustainable development in trade agreements. The EU may form a pro-European coalition with the Greens, who have vowed to block free trade agreements with countries that don't adhere to the Paris climate accord, including China. This change in policy is seen as a response to the EU's loss of traditional conservative and socialist parties in the election.

site_title: Nationalists surge in EU Parliament, but pro-EU parties remain dominant
summary: Pro-European parties maintained a strong grip on the EU Parliament, securing 507 of 751 seats, despite a surge in nationalist and eurosceptic parties. The far-right and nationalists in Italy, Britain, France, and Poland gained control of a quarter of seats, but failed to dramatically alter the EU's pro-European balance. Investors were bolstered by the smaller-than-expected gains by populist parties, but the decline in support for main centre-right and centre-left blocs may complicate policymaking. Pro-EU groups now seek to form a majority and secure top EU jobs to shield the EU from anti-establishment forces.

site_title: Office marketplace GorillaSpace bags seed funding led by Japan's Mitsubishi Estate
summary: GorillaSpace, an office marketplace, has secured undisclosed seed funding led by Japan's Mitsubishi Estate Co. The investment, alongside Singapore-based Silversea Media Group, will be used to bolster the team and expand listings and geographic reach. The startup aims to triple its listings, focusing on partnerships with local brokers and operators. This marks Mitsubishi Estate's first proptech investment outside Japan and its first seed-round investment. GorillaSpace has seen significant growth, with 21.5% month-on-month growth in website traffic and over 30% growth in listings since 2018.

site_title: Lenovo profit tops estimates as focus on higher margins pays off
summary: Lenovo reported a net income of $118 million in the March quarter, surpassing the highest analyst estimate. Revenue and gross margin also exceeded projections, driven by a focus on higher-margin products. Despite a 4.6% drop in global PC shipments, Lenovo outgrew competitors HP and Dell, aided by local cloud computing relationships. The company's mobile division revenue climbed 15%, while its data center division saw a 2.3% increase in sales. Rising US-China tensions may impact Lenovo's performance in the North American market.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.03 points to 1,601.35 on Monday, driven by gains in the stock market. The index saw a volume of 1.6 billion lots worth RM1.3 billion, with 464 losers beating 348 gainers.

site_title: Coworking, market entry startup Greenhouse raises S$3.8m in bridge financing
summary: Indonesian startup Greenhouse has raised S$3.8 million in bridge financing to expand its capabilities in helping companies enter and scale up in South-east Asia. The funding round was led by 14 angel investors, including Dilip and Deepak Chugani of KNS Group. The funds will be used to expand its coworking brand, launch new spaces, and complete a Series A fundraising in 2020. Greenhouse provides fully-serviced coworking spaces and business support networks, simplifying the process for companies to enter and grow in the region.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler and Renault pursue US$35b merger to tackle car sector challenges
summary: Fiat Chrysler proposed a US$35 billion merger with Renault to create the world's third-largest automaker, addressing sector challenges. The tie-up, if successful, would impact rivals such as General Motors and PSA Group. Renault expressed interest in the proposal, considering it friendly. The deal could spur further mergers and alter the automotive landscape.

site_title: Singapore shares end flat on Monday on lack of market cues
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended flat on Monday with no market catalysts, despite a strong performance from the Shanghai Composite Index, which rose 1.4%. Trading volume was 73% of the daily average, with decliners outpacing advancers 188 to 159. Banking stocks were mixed, while ISR Capital and Penguin International saw gains. The lack of fresh impetus from the US-China trade situation or data updates left regional markets in a mixed state.

site_title: Quebec provincial leader aims to boost use of hydroelectric power
summary: Quebec provincial leader François Legault plans to electrify public transport and heating systems by the end of 2019 or early 2020. The plan includes expanding subway and light-rail lines, new tramways, and electrifying bus lines in Montreal and Quebec City areas. This move aims to boost the use of hydroelectric power, a key energy source in Quebec.

site_title: S Korea: Stocks extend declines for third session
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index declined for a third consecutive session, closing 0.05% lower at 2,044.21 points. The decline was attributed to the lack of market-moving news and concerns about the China-US trade spat potentially escalating into a technology cold war. The KOSPI has lost 8.1% in the previous 30 trading sessions, but has risen 0.16% so far this year.

site_title: PODCAST: Financial adulting 101 and controlling monthly credit card debt (Money Hacks, Ep 44)
summary: In a recent podcast episode, "Financial Adulting 101 and Controlling Monthly Credit Card Debt," experts share actionable tips for managing debt and achieving financial stability. The episode is part of a weekly series by The Business Times and The Straits Times. Key takeaways include prioritizing debt repayment, creating a budget, and avoiding impulse purchases. The episode aims to empower listeners with practical advice for taking control of their finances and achieving long-term financial goals.

site_title: Bukit Sembawang posts Q4 net loss of S$11.6m
summary: Bukit Sembawang Estates reported a Q4 net loss of S$11.6 million, despite a 72% revenue increase to S$56.5 million. The loss was attributed to a 19% decrease in gross profit and higher operating expenses. The company proposed unchanged final and special dividends, and reported full-year net profit of S$101.3 million, doubling the previous year's figure. The developer also noted a decline in private residential property prices in the first three months of the year, with plans to launch new phases of its Luxus Hills project.

site_title: Brazil's Magazine Luiza raises offer to buy Netshoes to $93.18 million
summary: Brazilian retailer Magazine Luiza SA has raised its offer to buy online shoe retailer Netshoes Ltd to $3 per share, valuing the company at approximately $93.18 million. This comes after a rival bid of $2.80 per share from Grupo SBF SA. Netshoes' board has approved the amendment and recommended shareholders favor the deal, which will be voted on on May 30.

site_title: IHH CEO to step down at end of the year, replaced by former executive
summary: IHH Healthcare's CEO, Tan See Leng, will step down on December 31, 2019, and be replaced by Kelvin Loh, a former IHH executive. Loh will take over as CEO-designate and executive director on July 1, 2019, with Tan's tenure ending on January 1, 2020. Loh previously left IHH in 2017 to become CEO of Columbia Asia Group, and his return comes after Malaysia's Khazanah Nasional divested a 16% stake in IHH to Japan's Mitsui & Co in November.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed lower on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index falling 0.24% to 27,288.09, amid ongoing investor jitters over the US-China trade war. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 1.38% and the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 2.51%, contrasting the Hong Kong market's decline. The US-China trade tensions continue to affect investor sentiment, with stocks globally showing mixed results.

site_title: Australia: Shares end flat
summary: Australian shares ended flat on Monday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index closing 4.1 points lower at 6,451.9, despite gains in mining stocks. Rio Tinto rose 1.8% to its best level in over a decade, while BHP Group added 1.3%. The decline was partly offset by weakness in banks. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.7% due to healthcare stocks.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's business receipts rose in Q1 2019, with services industries increasing takings, but at a slower pace. The Smart Urban Co-Innovation Lab will launch, focusing on urban solutions. Trax, a Singapore-based startup, raised $100m, valuing the company at $1.1b. The Shenton Way/Tanjong Pagar district is top for tech, media, and telco tenants in Asia. HSBC Singapore appointed a head of financial institutions group for S-E Asia. The STI ended flat on Monday due to lack of market cues, settling at 3,170.77.

images.alt_text: The Smart Urban Co-Innovation Lab will focus on the key areas of intelligent estates, smart mobility, digital wellness, and agritech.

site_title: Europe: Markets surge higher after EU election results
summary: European stock markets surged higher on Monday after EU Parliament election results presented few surprises. The Frankfurt DAX 30 index jumped 0.8% and the Paris CAC 40 gained 0.7%. US President Donald Trump's positive statement on US-China trade talks also boosted investor optimism. Marine Le Pen's far-right National Rally topped in France, while pro-EU President Emmanuel Macron's centrist alliance was close behind. The results did not provide major surprises, and analysts attributed the market's rally to a continuation of existing political trends.

site_title: Citi, JPMorgan, UBS face Australia forex cartel class action
summary: Citi, JPMorgan, and UBS are among five banks named in a class action lawsuit in Australia for allegedly colluding on foreign-exchange trading strategies. The banks, along with Royal Bank of Scotland and Barclays, are accused of manipulating FX benchmark rates, controlling spreads, and triggering client stop-loss orders. The lawsuit claims Australian businesses and investors were harmed by the distortion of currency markets, with damages sought for trades over A$500,000 between 2008 and 2013. The banks have previously paid EU fines for similar collusion.

site_title: Australia's gas industry faces climate test despite election win
summary: Australia's gas industry is facing a climate test despite the re-election of its center-right government, which may reduce pressure to cut emissions. Industry leaders will debate domestic gas prices and supply glut, but tackling climate change is the most urgent topic. Investors are scrutinizing the sector's contribution to climate change, with industry executives agreeing that companies must position for a net-zero emissions global economy. The industry must work to engage with climate groups and address concerns, as activists and executives agree that technology solutions are needed to mitigate pollution.

site_title: China restructures Anbang in step to sell firm after takeover
summary: China is restructuring Anbang Insurance Group Co, a strategic insurer it took over in 2018, as part of efforts to sell a stake in the company. The Chinese government wants to reduce its ownership by February next year. Anbang's businesses will be moved into a new company called Dajia Baoxian, with some policies sold by its property insurance unit not being transferred. The company is stripping out investment-type policies, which were a key hurdle in discussions with potential investors. Anbang plans to rely on professional insurance agencies and brokers to sell its life policies, aiming to spur long-term policy sales and reduce its dependence on investment products.

site_title: Poland's ruling right-wing PiS party tops in EU polls
summary: Poland's ruling right-wing Law and Justice party (PiS) won European elections, securing 45.56% of the vote and 27 seats in the European Parliament. The party's leader Jaroslaw Kaczynski urged a wider victory in the autumn general election. The PiS campaigned on a platform of generous social spending, but faced criticism for its stance on gay rights and Holocaust claims. The party's victory has raised concerns about a "Polexit" threat, with the EU warning of a clash over judicial independence and democracy.

site_title: Kimberly-Clark pumps in additional S$25m to double Tuas factory exports
summary: Kimberly-Clark is investing S$25 million in its Tuas factory to double export volume and value of its Huggies brand products by end 2022. The funds will be used to expand production capacity for diapers, pull-up pants, and improve value addition to baby wipes. The investment also incorporates Industry 4.0-related productivity enhancements. This is the third investment by Kimberly-Clark in the past four years, showcasing the success of the Tuas manufacturing facility, which has been a globally leading export facility since 1981.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher
summary: Tokyo shares rose on Monday, driven by relief over US President Donald Trump's softer stance towards Japan amid a trade dispute. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.31% and the Topix index rose 0.38%. Investors expressed optimism, despite ongoing tariff uncertainty. The gains followed a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a record close in the US S&P 500.

site_title: UnUsUaL posts 31.7% rise in FY19 net profit to S$13.19m
summary: UnUsUaL, a media company, reported a 31.7% year-over-year increase in FY19 net profit to S$13.19 million, driven by 22.6% revenue growth to S$56.93 million. Earnings per share rose to 1.28 cents from 0.98 cents. The company warned that the live entertainment industry remains competitive and challenging, but plans to promote globally appealing shows to drive performance. The counter closed at 31.5 Singapore cents, down half a cent, before the financial results were released.

site_title: Australia home prices' long decline pauses on rate cut prospects
summary: Australia's housing market showed a hint of stability as home prices rose 0.1% in capital cities last week, breaking months of declines. Sydney saw a 0.3% increase, while Melbourne firmed 0.1%. The rise was attributed to expectations of lower mortgage rates and tax breaks for property investing. The Reserve Bank of Australia is set to consider a rate cut at its next meeting on June 4, with a 84% probability of a cut. Economists have scaled back estimates for price drops, with property brokers seeing a surge in customer inquiries.

site_title: Three floors at The Octagon up for sale with total S$43m indicative price
summary: Three floors at The Octagon, a 25-storey office building in Singapore's central business district, have been launched for bulk sale by tender with a total indicative price of S$43 million. The floors, located on the first, second, and fourth floors, have a strata area of around 15,995 square feet and are fully occupied by a fitness centre and two childcare centres. The sale is seen as a response to the Urban Redevelopment Authority's CBD incentive scheme, which encourages the conversion of existing office developments to hotel and residential uses.

site_title: Australian telco Vocus entertains US$2.3b offer from Sweden's EQT
summary: Australian telecoms junior Vocus Group Ltd received a non-binding buyout offer of A$3.3 billion (S$3.16 billion) from Swedish private-equity firm EQT Infrastructure. The offer is a 35% premium to Friday's closing price and surpasses previous bids from US firms KKR & Co Inc and Affinity Equity Partners. Vocus shares jumped 26% after the announcement, with the board allowing EQT to conduct non-exclusive due diligence. The offer is seen as a strategic move to capitalize on Vocus's fibre-focused turnaround plan, which has gained traction despite the struggling telco's retail businesses.

site_title: Renault-Fiat to eventually invite Nissan, Mitsubishi to join forces: sources
summary: Renault and Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV have announced a merger, creating the world's third-largest carmaker. The plan includes eventually inviting Nissan and Mitsubishi Motors Corp to join forces, despite Nissan's initial reluctance. The merger aims to achieve cost savings of over $7.7 million and create a combined 8.7 million cars per year. Nissan's struggling sales, profitability, and recent arrest of Carlos Ghosn have led to pressure to merge with Renault. Analysts believe a loose partnership could be beneficial for Nissan, providing it is not overly restrictive.

site_title: In Hong Kong, foreign maids are racing to reclaim their voices
summary: In Hong Kong, foreign maids are finding a sense of empowerment through trail running, a sport that allows them to challenge themselves and be treated as equals in a society that often discriminates against them. Despite long workdays and limited time off, maids like Jaybie Pagarigan and Fredelyn Alberto are training for ultramarathons and mountain running events, blurring the lines between employers and maids. Trail running has become an unlikely equalizer, giving domestic workers a sense of agency and self-expression in a city where they are often expected to be subservient.

site_title: Singapore-based startup Trax raising US$100m to value company at US$1.1b, second only to Grab
summary: Singapore-based startup Trax is finalizing a deal to raise US$100 million, valuing the company at US$1.1 billion, making it the second most valuable startup in Singapore, behind ride-hailing giant Grab. The funding round is expected to close by the end of June, led by private equity firms. Trax previously raised US$125 million last year, with GIC and Boyu Capital among its investors.

site_title: Catalist-listed Vividthree posts Q4 net profit of S$1.5m
summary: Vividthree Holdings, a Catalist-listed company, reported a net profit of S$1.5 million for its fourth quarter ended March 31, more than 20 times its year-ago profit of S$60,000. Revenue doubled to S$4 million from S$1.8 million in the same period last year. The company's full-year net profit reached S$3.3 million, a 20% increase from the previous year. This is Vividthree's first full-year results since listing on Catalist in September 2018.

site_title: Singapore's business receipts continue to rise in Q1, but pace is slowing down
summary: Singapore's services industries saw a 3.6% increase in business receipts in Q1 2019, easing from the 4.1% in the previous quarter. Growth was led by the information & communications services industry, with a 7.2% increase, while the financial & insurance services and transport & storage services industries also reported increases. However, the transport & storage services industry's decline of 5.6% contributed to the overall slowdown.

images.alt_text: Singapore's services industries saw an increase in takings in the first quarter of 2019, even as the pace slowed down from before, according to data from the Department of Statistics on Monday.

site_title: Tee International calls for trading halt pending announcement
summary: MAINBOARD-LISTED Tee International has requested a trading halt pending an announcement. The engineering group's shares were trading flat at 6.2 Singapore cents as of 12:31pm on Monday. The company did not provide further details about the announcement.

site_title: BOJ's Kuroda sounds alarm on global economy ahead of G-20
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda expressed concerns over the global economy, citing uncertainty and downside risks due to trade friction, China's slowing economy, and Britain's Brexit negotiations. Kuroda stated that Group of 20 meetings this year will discuss current account balances, and bilateral trade measures will not resolve such imbalances. He warned of a high degree of uncertainty and large downside risks, emphasizing the need for policymakers to be prepared for potential economic challenges.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda said on Monday the global economic outlook is highly uncertain, and there are downside risks due to trade friction, China's slowing economy and Britain's negotiations to leave the European Union.

site_title: Asia: Lukewarm morning for stocks
summary: Asian markets experienced a lukewarm recovery on Monday as investors sought to overcome anxiety over the US-China trade war. Tokyo rose 0.3% and Jakarta gained 0.7%, while Hong Kong lost 0.5% and Shanghai edged down 0.3%. The cautious recovery came ahead of US President Donald Trump's visit to Japan, where he is expected to hold formal talks with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe. Investors remain cautious due to the ongoing trade tensions and uncertainty surrounding the Brexit.

site_title: Broker's take: UOB Kay Hian upgrades CapitaLand Mall Trust to 'buy' with S$2.65 target price
summary: UOB Kay Hian has upgraded its rating on CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT) to 'buy' with a target price of S$2.65, citing positive factors such as rental contributions from the revamped Funan mall and the development of the Jurong Lake District. The trust's revised distribution per unit forecast is increased by 12% to factor in Funan's contributions. CMT's malls in the Jurong Gateway area are expected to benefit from future growth in the area, which is being developed as Singapore's second central business district.

site_title: China Everbright Water unit bags 2nd phase of industrial waste water project in Jiangsu
summary: China Everbright Water's unit secured the second phase of an industrial waste water project worth 859.4 million yuan in Jiangsu Province, China. The project, to be funded through internal resources and external financing, will be operated on a Build-Operate-Transfer model. The Phase II project aims to meet the rising need for industrial waste water treatment in the Pukou Economic Development Zone. The company expects to enhance long-term returns and value for shareholders with the project.

site_title: Supply chains may be shifting to Vietnam: reports
summary: Vietnam may be shifting its supply chains away from China due to US-China trade tensions, with record foreign direct investment (FDI) from China and Hong Kong in the first four months of the year. This shift is mainly taking the form of expanding existing facilities and adding capacity, rather than greenfield investment or acquisitions. US companies are also showing interest in outsourcing to Vietnam, particularly in sectors like apparel and furniture. However, economists caution that the impact of these supply chain shifts may not be enough to offset the negative effects of the trade war.

site_title: Superstar cities lose their pull
summary: US superstar cities, such as Seattle and San Francisco, are experiencing a decline in population due to rising housing costs and limited job opportunities for workers without a college degree. This trend is becoming widespread, with eight of the 10 largest metropolitan areas losing people to other parts of the country in 2018. The shift underscores how uneven the distribution of opportunity has become, with high-paying jobs concentrated in areas that are unaffordable for many workers.

images.alt_text: Eight of the 10 largest metropolitan areas in the country, including those around New York, San Francisco, Los Angeles and Miami, lost people to other places in 2018.

site_title: Vietnam culls 1.7m pigs as virus spreads to new areas
summary: Vietnam has culled over 1.7 million pigs due to the spread of African swine fever, with 5% of the nation's pig population affected. The disease has spread to 42 provinces and cities, and officials warn it may penetrate larger commercial farms. The rainy season has exacerbated the spread, and the government advises that outbreaks may recur even in areas with no new cases for 30 days. The epidemic is expected to continue expanding, posing a significant threat to the country's pig industry.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday afternoon at 3,158.78, down 0.35% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Monday, down 0.35% or 11.11 points to 3,158.78, with decliners outnumbering advancers 177 to 110. ISR Capital rose 50%, while AA Group Holdings slipped 30%. Eagle Hospitality Trust, which debuted on Friday, continued to fall 2.06% from its IPO price. The decline was attributed to about 376.5 million shares worth S$263.4 million changing hands.

site_title: Solomons first trip for re-elected Australia PM Morrison amid China tensions
summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison's first foreign trip after re-election will be to the Solomon Islands, a move to strengthen Canberra's strategic presence in the Pacific amid growing Chinese influence. Morrison's visit aims to cement the region's importance and follows the elevation of the Pacific to a full ministerial role. The trip is seen as a reinforcement of Australia's "Pacific step-up," with Foreign Minister Marise Payne praising the decision. The visit is expected to focus on strengthening bilateral ties and promoting regional stability.

site_title: Ascendas-Singbridge to launch co-innovation lab for urban solutions, supported by IMDA and ESG
summary: Ascendas-Singbridge, set to be acquired by CapitaLand, is launching a co-innovation lab for urban solutions in Singapore Science Park. Supported by IMDA and ESG, the lab will focus on smart estates, mobility, digital wellness, and agritech, providing a platform for companies to co-develop and trial new solutions. The lab aims to develop technology capabilities and produce innovative proof-of-concepts, with various programmes including call for proposals, pilot tests, and workshops.
