Revenue rose 50% to S$69.3 million, driven by a 60% surge in design-and-build revenue. The company proposed a final dividend of 1.5 cents and special dividend of 0.5 cent per share. Full-year earnings increased 5% to S$30.6 million, driven by a gain from the sale of Changi North Rise and higher revenue conversion. The firm's order book remains resilient at S$660 million.

site_title: Lights out for five Singapore power retailers amid fierce competition
summary: Five licensed electricity retailers in Singapore's retail electricity market for big businesses have exited the market amid fierce competition triggered by the liberalisation of the sector. Market observers expect further consolidation as the number of electricity retailers has climbed sharply in recent years. Big-business consumers account for 90,000 accounts, or 80% of Singapore's total electricity demand, and consumers are spoilt for choice on retailers, leading to concerns about the sustainability of the current model.

images.alt_text: Five players have called it a day in Singapore's retail electricity market for big businesses amid fierce competition triggered by a phased liberalisation of the sector - a process completed only this month, with all residential households in the fold as well.

site_title: Panasonic steps away from Huawei after US ban
summary: Panasonic and Toshiba are halting shipments to Huawei due to US security concerns. The move follows a US ban on US companies selling technology to Huawei, and comes as major Japanese and British mobile carriers delay releasing new Huawei handsets. Panasonic has stopped supplying electronic parts to Huawei, while Toshiba temporarily halted shipments to check if they include US-made parts. The US ban aims to address concerns over Huawei's ties to the Chinese military.

images.alt_text: Panasonic stopped all business transactions with Huawei and its 68 group companies.

site_title: Plein Styling
summary: German designer Philipp Plein has opened his first flagship store in The Shoppes at Marina Bay Sands, featuring a 4,000 sq ft duplex space showcasing his Spring/Summer collection inspired by Michael Jackson's style. The store also includes selected styles from his Autumn/Winter collection, blending street and formal wear. Plein's designs are known for their edgy, extravagant, and pop culture-inspired aesthetic, reflecting his career as a law student turned fashion designer.

site_title: China stocks at the mercy of foreigners like never before
summary: Foreign investors are significantly influencing China's stock market, with their trades accounting for a record 10% of daily volume. This increased influence is due to expanded quotas and index inclusions, which allow overseas traders to manage risk more easily. Foreign investors own 3.1% of China's $6.5 trillion stock market, comparable to the country's mutual funds. Recent outflows of foreign capital have affected sentiment onshore, with stocks like Kweichow Moutai Co experiencing high turnover rates, and MSCI's expansion of China-listed shares in benchmark indexes predicted to attract more overseas capital.

site_title: Freeing up Singapore's power market bittersweet for businesses
summary: Singapore's liberalization of the electricity sector has saved businesses 25-30% in power bills, but the plethora of choices and complex contract terms have left many overwhelmed. Businesses are struggling to navigate the numerous electricity retailers and their packages, with potential penalties for non-compliance. To address this, an online portal called PowerSelect was launched, offering procurement options and data from wholesale markets, potentially saving businesses an additional 5-15%. Despite the challenges, the liberalization has been a boon for businesses, with many reporting significant savings.

site_title: US FAA chief says no 737 MAX fix yet ahead of global summit
summary: The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has not yet approved a software fix for the Boeing 737 MAX 8, which was grounded following two fatal crashes in 2018 and 2019. The FAA's interim chief, Dan Elwell, said the agency is waiting for Boeing to formally submit the software for approval, and officials from the European Union and Canada have expressed skepticism about clearing the plane for takeoff until their questions are answered. The FAA is expected to provide clues about its decision at a global aviation summit, with 57 agencies from 33 countries attending.

site_title: DPM Heng, China's Premier Li meet, discuss ways to deepen cooperation
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat met with Chinese Premier Li Keqiang to discuss ways to deepen bilateral cooperation, including the Belt and Road Initiative and government-to-government projects. The two leaders welcomed progress in existing collaborations, such as the China-Singapore Connectivity Initiative. This meeting aimed to strengthen economic ties between Singapore and China.

site_title: Daphne Hedley
summary: Daphne Hedley, CEO of Mekhala, a Singapore-Thai organic food brand, has led the company from its rustic roots in Chiang Mai to broader recognition in the organic food world. After a decade of growth, Mekhala was stocked by Whole Foods in the US, with its curry pastes now available in over 400 outlets. The company started with a commitment to quality and a focus on Asian condiments, eventually achieving certified organic status in 2016. Hedley, 40, co-founded the company with her sister Diane Wong after a career change from banking and finance.

site_title: Abe-Trump talks topped by trade and Korea
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to visit Japan, where he will meet with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe to discuss trade, North Korea, and security issues. The visit aims to deepen the US-Japan alliance and address concerns about China's growing influence in the Asia-Pacific region. Abe is seeking to push for Japan's military modernization, including the abolition of Article Nine, which limits the country's military capabilities. The visit comes ahead of the G-20 summit next month and follows a recent meeting between Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un.

site_title: Rihanna's Fenty fashion label debuts in Paris
summary: Rihanna debuted her first Fenty fashion collection in Paris, unveiling a mix of high and low pieces with menswear inspirations and a feminine twist. The 31-year-old pop star aimed to bring a unique approach to the fashion industry as the first woman to start a new brand from scratch at LVMH, France's largest company by market value. Rihanna wore a statement outfit featuring a white canvas blazer dress paired with gold leather heels, setting the tone for her boss lady and party girl persona.

site_title: Why Iran raises the Iraq Syndrome spectre
summary: The Trump administration's policy of containing Iran has raised concerns about the risk of escalating tensions, mirroring the "Iraq Syndrome" that dominated US foreign policy after the Vietnam War. The US has traditionally avoided entangling itself in long-term military interventions, but the current containment strategy, which includes strengthening ties with Saudi Arabia and Israel, has sparked fears of miscalculations and war. President Trump's mixed messages and failure to articulate a clear strategy have made it difficult to ensure that things won't get out of hand, leaving the American people, still recovering from past military interventions, to wonder if they will have to endure another Iraq.

site_title: Cry Of The Wild
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

At Singita's luxury lodges in Kruger National Park, guests can experience a unique wildlife conservation experience. The lodges generate revenue to fund conservation efforts, including anti-poaching operations and community engagement programs. Guided by experienced rangers and conservationists, guests can get up close to endangered species like rhinos, lions, and leopards while learning about the importance of conservation. Despite poaching threats, conservation efforts are showing progress, with Singita's efforts in Tanzania, Zimbabwe, and Mozambique helping to reintroduce black rhinos and protect wildlife habitats. The company's community outreach programs also support local communities in protecting the environment.

site_title: Big Tech giants' omnipresence in digital life must be dealt with
summary: Big Tech giants, such as Facebook and Google, have become omnipresent in digital life, but few moves have been made to address their dominance. Facebook co-founder Chris Hughes has proposed breaking up the company by spinning off its acquisitions of Instagram and WhatsApp, citing concerns over monopolistic control and fake news spread. This move could dilute the company's hold on digital communication and improve data privacy, but critics argue that anti-trust regulation alone may not be enough to solve the issue.

site_title: Amazon investors reject proposals on climate change, facial recognition
summary: Amazon shareholders rejected proposals to reconsider the company's societal impact in two key areas: facial recognition and climate change. The proposals, which asked Amazon to develop a more comprehensive approach to reducing its carbon footprint and put the brakes on selling surveillance technologies to governments, were voted down. The rejection suggests that investors are not prioritizing the company's environmental and social responsibilities.

site_title: All eyes on EU polls amid fears of far-right appeal
summary: The European elections have sparked concerns about the rise of far-right parties, which could hinder economic growth and unity in the European Union. Polls indicate that these parties could win at least a third of the European Parliament seats, potentially disrupting legislation and unity. Many voters believe the EU will fall apart in the next 10-20 years, and some even think this week's elections will be the last. The far-right parties' anti-immigration and protectionist policies could lead to economic instability and discourage foreign investment.

site_title: US opens antitrust probe of real estate brokerage industry
summary: US antitrust officials are investigating the residential real estate brokerage industry for potentially anti-competitive practices, focusing on broker compensation and access to listings. A civil investigative demand was issued to CoreLogic, which provides real estate data to government agencies and lenders. The probe follows a lawsuit claiming brokerages conspired to restrict commission negotiations. The Justice Department seeks information on listing services and data distribution practices. The investigation may lead to changes in the industry, with online brokerages like REX welcoming the potential for reduced fees and increased transparency.

site_title: Dance Diva
summary: Singer Jasmine Sokko has released her music video for hit single "Tired", a cinematic tour de force shot in Bangkok and Singapore. The video, directed by Choann, marks her third collaboration and draws references from Singapore's colonised history to tell a story of a reimagined world. The video's release comes after Sokko's appearance in Tencent Video's Rave Now show in China, where she was exposed to new experiences and cultural differences. The song and video are now available on Apple Music, YouTube, and Jasmine Sokko's website.

site_title: Body Politic
summary: Korper, a contemporary dance work by Sasha Waltz, explores the human body's inner and outer workings. The performance, described as "dramatic" and "architectural", will be held in Singapore as part of the Singapore International Festival of Arts 2019, from May 31 to June 1 at the Esplanade Theatre. This is Korper's first performance in Singapore, and tickets are available through Sistic. Waltz's unique style, which has been praised globally, showcases the beauty and complexity of the human body in a visually striking and thought-provoking way.

site_title: Japanese firms among biggest victims of US ban on Huawei
summary: Japanese electronics component makers, such as Taiyo Yuden Co and TDK Corp, are severely impacted by the US ban on Huawei, with their stocks plummeting 26% and 23% respectively. These companies are estimated to receive around 10% of their sales from Huawei, with Taiyo Yuden's stock experiencing its steepest monthly drop since 2016. The ban is a result of the US-China trade war, which has affected numerous Japanese firms.

site_title: More Than Meets The Eye
summary: A Singaporean home designed by Linghao Architects is a surprise to the untrained eye, despite its simple exterior. The 3,641 sq ft, three-storey home was built on a 2,070 sq ft plot and features curved surfaces, metal mesh, and open layouts to promote natural air flow and human interaction. The house has various surprises, including a standalone toilet and a room that can be used as a study or guest room. The design aims to create a sense of space and flow, with different levels and materials used to achieve a unique and elemental atmosphere.

site_title: Thai court blocks junta nemesis from entering parliament
summary: Thailand's constitutional court suspended Future Forward Party leader Thanathorn Juangroongruangkit from parliament a day before the party's scheduled convening, citing allegations of violating election rules by holding shares in a media company. The decision comes after Thanathorn's party secured over six million votes in March's elections, posing a challenge to the military establishment. The court agreed to hear the case, which could put an end to Thanathorn's political career.

site_title: New BMW 3 Series review: Bumpy progress
summary: The BMW 3 Series 330i M Sport is a fine driver's car with a sporty feel, but its ride quality is marred by a bumpy and unforgiving suspension. Despite its impressive handling and 258 horsepower engine, the M Sport setup comes at the cost of a poor ride quality, making it less desirable. In contrast, the Luxury trim offers a softer suspension and more comfortable seating. The new digital cabin also falls short, with cluttered and hard-to-use virtual instruments and a poorly designed infotainment touchscreen.

site_title: A (Political) Star Is Born
summary: Netflix's documentary "Knock Down The House" provides an inside look at Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez's rise to fame. Filmmaker Rachel Lears initially set out to document four female grassroots political aspirants, but the film focuses on Ocasio-Cortez due to her remarkable charisma and ability to connect with people. The documentary showcases her journey from working as a bartender to becoming the youngest woman in US Congress. Despite comparisons to charismatic politicians like Barack Obama, Ocasio-Cortez's authenticity and people skills have made her a compelling figure, and the film highlights her exceptional qualities.

site_title: HK's longest-serving CEO of listed company stepping down as sons take over
summary: Hong Kong's longest-serving CEO, David Li, is stepping down from Bank of East Asia Ltd after 38 years, handing over the reins to his sons Adrian and Brian. Li's tenure spans a tumultuous period in Hong Kong's history, marked by economic crises and challenges from activist investors. His sons will assume the roles of co-CEOs, while Li becomes executive chairman. This marks a changing of the guard in Hong Kong's business elite, with many titans passing the torch to the next generation.

site_title: Midas Land unveils maiden project Jervois Privé
summary: Midas Land unveiled its maiden project, Jervois Privé, a 45-unit freehold residential development in District 10, Singapore. The 27,109 sq ft site, acquired for S$52.9 million, will be completed by mid-2022 and ready for occupancy in early 2023. Prices start from S$1.62 million for 1-bedroom apartments and S$3.18 million for 3-bedroom apartments, with early bird prices starting from S$2,816 per square foot. The development is near the Redhill MRT station and major shopping belts, with PropNex and SRI as appointed marketing agencies.

site_title: Modi promises inclusive India after stunning election win
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi has won a stunning election, with his Hindu-nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) expected to increase its majority and pursue business-friendly policies. Modi promised to unite the country, but his campaign was often divisive, prompting concerns about his government's stance on minority communities. The BJP's predicted margin of victory, 348 seats to 85 for the opposition, has boosted financial markets and put pressure on Modi to address employment, agricultural income, and banking sector issues.

images.alt_text: Official data shows Mr Modi's Hindu-nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party ahead in more than 300 of the 542 seats available, up from the 282 that it won in 2014 and more than the 272 seats needed for a majority in the Lower House of Parliament.

site_title: Calm returns to streets of Jakarta after second night of unrest
summary: Calm has returned to Jakarta after two nights of unrest following Indonesia's presidential election, in which Joko Widodo won a second term. Financial markets have rebounded, with the rupiah up 0.5% and the main stock index up 1.6%. The violence, which included clashes between security forces and protesters, resulted in six deaths and 737 injuries. Analysts say the election outcome may deprive the opposition of a strong case to claim rigging, but may still be able to count on agitation from Islamist supporters.

images.alt_text: Roads were abuzz with traffic again on Thursday. City workers cleaning up following two nights of clashes between security forces and protesters.

site_title: Facebook, Twitter, Google seek to assuage lawmakers about 2020 US elections
summary: Facebook, Twitter, and Google executives testified before US lawmakers on concerns about foreign influence campaigns in the 2020 elections. The tech giants aim to reassure lawmakers that they take the threat seriously and are taking steps to prevent disinformation, including setting up operation centers and collaborating with the government. Officials from the Department of Homeland Security and the Election Assistance Commission also participated, acknowledging a significant technology deficit in state and local election systems. The companies are warning of US adversaries developing new ways of meddling and emphasizing the need for continued investment to secure election systems.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower on fears of broader trade spat with China
summary: US stocks opened lower on Thursday, May 23, 2019, due to concerns over a potential technology cold war between the US and China amid unresolved trade tensions. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.46%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.69%, and the Nasdaq Composite declined 1.16%. Investors fear the trade spat could spiral into a broader conflict, despite no signs of a resolution in sight.

site_title: JLC lawyer told repeatedly to return S$33m before going incommunicado
summary: A Singaporean law firm, JLC Advisors, is at the center of a controversy over missing funds. The firm's senior lawyer, Jeffrey Ong, had repeatedly assured Allied Technologies that the $33 million in escrowed funds would be returned, but failed to do so. Allied Technologies issued a letter of demand, and a purported letter from JLC claiming the funds had been paid out. The company is now seeking repayment and has lodged a report with the police and the Law Society. JLC Advisors has reported the matter to the authorities and is cooperating with the investigation, while also denying any wrongdoing.

site_title: China pork imports jump 24% in April
summary: China imported 136,517 tonnes of pork in April, a 24% increase from the same month last year, amid concerns of a looming shortage due to the African swine fever virus. This is the largest monthly volume since September 2016. China has imported 470,776 tonnes of pork in the first four months of 2019, up 8.4% compared to last year. Importers have sourced meat from the US, despite steep duties, but some orders have been cancelled. Domestic pork production is expected to be down by at least 30% in 2019.

site_title: Pre-trial hearings in Ghosn case likely to last for months
summary: Pre-trial hearings in the Ghosn case began at Tokyo District Court's 17th Criminal Court Division on May 23, 2019, marking a new phase in the saga that started when Ghosn was arrested in November. Ghosn, former Nissan chairman and CEO, is facing charges related to his alleged misconduct. The hearings are expected to last for months, with no clear timeline for a verdict. Ghosn's defense team has not commented on the proceedings, and the court has not released any details about the case's progress. The outcome remains uncertain.

site_title: CSC Holdings Q4 losses deepen to S$6.9m on cost overruns
summary: CSC Holdings, a geotechnical engineering firm, reported a 20.6% increase in fourth-quarter losses to S$6.9 million due to cost overruns on a project and reduced revenue. The company's full-year losses widened 34% to S$18 million, largely attributed to delays in new projects and increased debt. Despite this, CSC is cautiously optimistic about a potential turnaround in the local construction sector and will maintain a prudent approach to tenders.

site_title: Here and N.O.W.
summary: TheatreWorks, a Singapore-based performance company, has launched "N.O.W." (Not Ordinary Work), its first all-women mini arts festival. The three-week festival, running from July 10 to 28, features a diverse range of events, including stand-up comedy, performances, exhibitions, and films, all helmed by women. Headed by veteran actress and producer Noorlinah Mohamed, the festival celebrates women's strength and wisdom in various fields, including botanical healing arts and magic-making. The festival aims to highlight and celebrate women's talents and contributions to the arts.

site_title: Pine Capital unit sues former CEO, directors and managers
summary: Pine Capital's unit, ACPAM, is suing its former CEO, Tan Choon Wee, and several former directors and managers for alleged breaches of fiduciary duties. This comes after the company was served with a writ of summons by Tan for alleged discrimination. ACPAM is also suing former directors and managers, including compliance manager Michelle Chee and client services manager Charlene Tan. The lawsuits were filed in the High Court, and the outcome is yet to be determined.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Sunpower Group secured a 43.6 million yuan (S$8.7 million) contract to provide high-efficiency heat exchangers to Zhejiang Petrochemical Co, expected to positively impact its 2019 and 2020 results. Yorkshine Holdings will be delisted from the Singapore Exchange due to its failure to comply with bourse criteria. Pine Capital's parent company, Pine Capital, is suing former CEO Tan Choon Wee and others for alleged breaches of fiduciary duties.

site_title: Israeli tech's Singapore connection
summary: Singapore is providing a connection for Israeli tech startups seeking Asian capital, while giving Singapore businesses access to leading-edge technologies in cybersecurity and data science. The country's bridge to capital is facilitating traffic both ways, with Singapore banks, SMEs, and Israeli deep-tech AI startups benefiting from the connection. This is part of a broader trend of Singapore supporting its businesses in accessing global markets and technologies.

site_title: Chefs' Specials
summary: In Singapore, restaurants are catering to demanding diners by sourcing unique and high-quality ingredients. Chefs are collaborating with farmers, fishermen, and suppliers to develop customized ingredients. Examples include wagyu beef from Japan, Italian olive oil, Japanese sudachi limes, and locally grown hybrid corn. Restaurants such as Michelin-starred Béni, Buona Terra, Hashida Sushi, and Odette are showcasing their commitment to using the best ingredients, while others like Shangri-La Hotel and Sushi Kimura are working with local suppliers to create unique dishes.

site_title: Alpine A110 review: The best sports car you've never heard of
summary: The Alpine A110 is a sports car that offers a unique driving experience, focusing on handling and agility rather than pure speed. It features a 1.8-liter turbocharged engine producing 252 horsepower. The A110's lightweight design and rear-wheel drive layout provide exceptional balance and responsiveness. With a starting price around $50,000, it's an affordable option for those seeking a sporty driving experience, rather than solely focusing on raw speed. The Alpine A110 is an underrated contender in the sports car market.

site_title: Jason Marine full-year earnings soar to S$191,000 on forex movements
summary: Jason Marine Group reported FY2019 revenue of S$29 million, a 8.4% dip from the previous year, due to weak demand in the marine and oil and gas industries. The company's full-year earnings quadrupled to S$191,000, boosted by foreign exchange movements. Despite a 26.2% decline in net profit excluding forex, the company saw an improvement in gross profit margin to 35.1%. Jason Marine declared a 0.5 cent per share dividend and warned that US-China trade tensions and industry uncertainties will continue to affect its business.

site_title: Sunpower bags 43.6m yuan contract from Chinese petrochemical firm
summary: Sunpower Group has secured a 43.6 million yuan contract from Chinese petrochemical firm Zhejiang Petrochemical Co. to provide high-efficiency heat exchangers for a refinery and chemical integration project. The contract is expected to have a positive impact on Sunpower's results for 2019 and 2020. This is the second project Sunpower has worked on with Zhejiang Petrochemical, following a similar contract in 2017. The deal highlights Sunpower's ability to supply high-quality equipment and solutions for large-scale installations.

site_title: No plea deal seen this week for ex Goldman banker Ng on US charges in 1MDB case
summary: Former Goldman Sachs banker Roger Ng is unlikely to receive a plea deal this week on US charges related to the 1MDB scandal, with prosecutors and Ng's lawyer planning to discuss scheduling for case proceedings instead. Ng, who faces up to 30 years in prison, was extradited to New York from Malaysia and pleaded not guilty to three charges of laundering money and bribing officials. Negotiations to reach a plea deal have been deemed unlikely, with prosecutors hoping to avoid a trial.

images.alt_text: Ex-Goldman Sachs banker Roger Ng and his lawyer Marc Agnifilo leave the federal court in New York, U.S., May 6, 2019.

site_title: IMF warns US-China trade war will 'jeopardize' 2019 global growth
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) warned that the escalating US-China trade war will "jeopardize" 2019 global growth, citing a potential loss of 0.33% of global GDP. IMF chief economist Gita Gopinath stated that US consumers are the primary losers from trade tensions, contradicting US President Donald Trump's claim that tariffs benefit the US treasury. The warning comes as the US is set to impose tariffs on all Chinese goods, which could exacerbate economic damage.

site_title: India's Gandhi concedes personal defeat in family bastion
summary: Rahul Gandhi, leader of India's Congress party, conceded defeat in his family's long-held home constituency of Amethi, where BJP candidate Smriti Irani won. Gandhi congratulated Irani and acknowledged the people of Amethi had given their mandate. At the national level, Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party secured a landslide victory, leading to a significant loss for the Congress party.

site_title: Britain launches investigation into failed investment firm LCF
summary: Britain's finance ministry has launched an investigation into the collapse of investment firm London Capital & Finance (LCF), led by former judge Elizabeth Gloster, following losses of up to £237 million from mini-bond investments. The investigation aims to determine the circumstances around the collapse and whether further regulatory changes are needed. A wider policy review of mini-bond regulation is also underway. The investigation's findings will be reported within 12 months, amid concerns from investors and politicians about the 12-month deadline.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.87 points to 1,601.87. The market saw 2.4 billion lots traded worth RM2.1 billion, with losers beating gainers 718 to 188. This marks a reversal from the previous day's gains.

site_title: Rush awarded A$2.9m dollars in defamation case, a record for Australia
summary: Australian actor Geoffrey Rush was awarded A$2.9 million in his defamation case against Nationwide News, a record payout in Australia's history. Rush initially won A$850,000 in damages and was awarded an additional A$1.98 million for economic losses and A$42,000 in interest. The case involved two front-page articles alleging unseemly conduct by Rush toward a female co-star, Eryn Jean Norvill. Nationwide News is appealing the verdict, which could potentially nullify the damages.

site_title: Singapore shares hit 4-month low on Thursday as slump continues
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) hit a four-month low on Thursday, closing 0.7% down at 3,160.72 points, amid ongoing US-China trade tensions. Investors are concerned about the technology sector's implications on global tech supply chains. Despite local tech counters experiencing steep sell-offs, some real estate investment trusts, such as Frasers Centrepoint Trust, gained ground. The benchmark index is still up 3% in 2019.

site_title: Malaysian officials go undercover to spy on fasting Muslims
summary: Malaysian officials are disguising themselves as cooks and waiters to catch Muslims who don't fast during Ramadan. Thirty-two enforcement officers from a local council are going undercover at 185 food outlets in Segamat district, monitoring for Muslims breaking the fast. Critics, including a rights group, have blasted the "disgraceful act of spying" as conservative attitudes gain ground in Malaysia. Muslims who break the fast can face punishment, including jail time or fines. The scheme has been criticized for its invasive nature and potential to give the wrong impression of Islam.

site_title: Goodyear's Eagle F1 Supersport tyre is so racy, it's almost illegal
summary: Goodyear has unveiled its new Eagle F1 Supersport tyres, designed for high-performance cars, which promise faster lap times and improved grip without compromising road safety. The tyres, set to launch in the third quarter of 2019, will be available in three versions: the basic Eagle F1 Supersport, the Supersport R for driving enthusiasts, and the Supersport RS, an extreme performer with a rubber compound similar to racing products. The tyres are expected to cost over S$400 each, targeting drivers of high-performance cars such as Ferraris and Porsches.

site_title: Mercedes EQC review: The Tesla-fighter from Benz is headed for Singapore
summary: The Mercedes-Benz EQC, the first full-production electric vehicle from Mercedes-Benz, is set to enter the Singapore market in early 2021, competing with the Jaguar I-Pace and Audi E-Tron. The luxury SUV boasts a 408-hp twin electric motor, 760Nm of torque, and a 458km electric range. With a price tag expected to be around S$400,000, Mercedes-Benz is confident that its appeal lies in combining the allure of the three-pointed star with the benefits of electric drive. The EQC features a unique design, advanced technology, and exceptional refinement, making it a promising contender in the EV market.

images.alt_text: Mercedes paid extra attention to insulating the cabin from noise, vibration, and harshness, and the result is that the car ghosts along with even less fuss than an S-Class.
Mercedes paid extra attention to insulating the cabin from noise, vibration, and harshness, and the result is that the car ghosts along with even less fuss than an S-Class.

site_title: US manufacturing activity growth near 10-year low - Markit
summary: US manufacturing activity growth reached a nearly 10-year low in May, according to data from IHS Markit, with the Purchasing Managers Index declining to 50.6 from 52.6 in April. This is the lowest level since September 2009. The services sector also showed weakness, with a reading of 50.9, mirroring the decline in manufacturing. Economists attribute the slowdown to trade war worries and increased uncertainty, citing a sharp decline in order book growth and business confidence.

site_title: ECB minutes show declining confidence in growth recovery
summary: European Central Bank policymakers expressed concern over weaker-than-expected economic growth in the euro zone, eroding confidence in a recovery in the second half of 2019. The ECB may provide more support with ultra-cheap loans to ensure credit continues to flow to the economy. Policymakers considered pricing these loans as a backstop or a tool to adjust monetary policy, with the terms to be decided in June. The ECB's concerns are largely driven by global trade slowdowns and uncertainty, with the bloc's troubles being largely outside its sphere of influence.

site_title: US new home sales fall more than expected in April
summary: US new home sales dropped 6.9% in April to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 673,000 units, falling short of expectations. Despite the decline, sales remain underpinned by declining mortgage rates and a strengthening labor market. The median new house price increased 8.8% from a year ago to $342,200, the highest level since December 2017. Economists attribute the recent strength to declining mortgage rates, with the 30-year fixed mortgage rate dropping to 4.07%. The overall housing market has contracted for five straight quarters.

site_title: US EU, Japan seek to complete text on subsidies to rein in China
summary: The US, EU, and Japan are working to finalize a trilateral text on reforming global rules on industrial subsidies, aimed at limiting China's distortive trade practices. The proposal includes increased transparency, identifying harmful subsidies, and benchmarks. The three countries aim to present the rules to the World Trade Organization and negotiate their adoption. China has agreed to end forced technology transfer, but a consensus among all 164 WTO members is needed for the reforms to be adopted. The effort is part of efforts to address growing frustration among industrialized countries over China's trade practices.

site_title: WHO unveils plan to tackle global snakebite 'emergency'
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has unveiled a plan to cut deaths and injuries from snakebites, warning of a potential public health emergency due to a lack of antivenoms. Each year, nearly three million people are bitten, with 81,000-138,000 deaths and 400,000 survivors suffering permanent disabilities. WHO aims to cut snakebite-related deaths and disabilities in half by 2030 by boosting antivenom production, integrating treatment into national health plans, and educating communities. The strategy also calls for a global antivenom stockpile and better training of health personnel.

site_title: Yorkshine Holdings to appeal delisting notice from SGX
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) to delist Yorkshine Holdings due to failure to comply with criteria to exit the watchlist. Yorkshine Holdings will appeal the decision. The company had sought to extend a deadline to submit a resumption of trading proposal but was rejected. Under SGX rules, a reasonable exit offer must be provided to shareholders, a condition Yorkshine failed to meet. The company's largest shareholder, Zhu Jun, holds a 66.6% stake in the company.

site_title: Indonesian troops flood Jakarta streets after post-election riots
summary: Tens of thousands of Indonesian military and police troops flooded Jakarta's streets on May 23, 2019, as rioting broke out after a presidential challenger, Prabowo Subianto, claimed widespread cheating in the April 17 election. At least seven people, including a 17-year-old high school student, were killed in clashes with protesters opposed to President Joko Widodo's re-election. Indonesian officials have dismissed Subianto's claims, and the government has deployed nearly 60,000 security personnel to maintain order, with some blocking social media to curb fake news.

images.alt_text: Indonesian workers and firemen clean the road after a riot outside Indonesia's Election Supervisory Agency (Bawaslu) building in Jakarta, Indonesia, 23 May 2019.

site_title: Asean needs to improve capabilities, integration to benefit from supply chain diversion: HSBC
summary: HSBC says Southeast Asia's supply chain potential won't be realized unless the region improves its technology, capacity, and regional integration. Despite widespread sentiment that supply chains are shifting to the region, there's little evidence of this happening. To attract businesses, Asean must build credibility and visibility, including improving regulatory frameworks, tax incentives, and free trade zones. If successful, Asean could see a 9.3% GDP increase and 12.1% export growth.

site_title: Malaysian police raid Deloitte office for 1MDB-related documents - sources
summary: Malaysian police raided Deloitte's Kuala Lumpur office on May 23, 2019, to search for documents related to 1MDB, a multibillion-dollar scandal. The raid follows investigations in at least six countries, with US prosecutors alleging $4.5 billion was misappropriated from 1MDB. Deloitte audited 1MDB's financial statements in 2013 and 2014 before resigning as auditor in 2016.

images.alt_text: Malaysian police raided the Kuala Lumpur office of audit firm Deloitte on Thursday to search for documents and records related to a multibillion-dollar scandal at state fund 1MDB, two police sources told Reuters.

site_title: China says US needs to fix 'wrong actions' as Huawei ban rattles supply chains
summary: China has urged the US to correct its "wrong actions" after the US blacklisted Huawei, a move that has disrupted global supply chains and hurt technology shares. Several companies, including Panasonic, have stopped shipments to Huawei due to the US supply blockade, potentially crippling the Chinese firm's ability to make new smartphone processors. The US blacklist affects Huawei's ability to design and manufacture its own processors, a critical component in its smartphones.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims underscore labour market strength
summary: US weekly jobless claims unexpectedly fell to 211,000 for the week ended May 18, indicating sustained labor market strength despite the economy slowing down. This marks the third consecutive week of decline in claims. The decline suggests that the labor market remains resilient despite the fading effects of last year's stimulus from the Trump administration's tax cuts and spending increases.

site_title: Allied Tech's missing S$33m: Law firm says partner Jeffrey Ong may have ordered withdrawal
summary: Allied Tech claims S$33m in missing funds were withdrawn from an escrow account managed by JLC Advisors, possibly at the instruction of managing partner Jeffrey Ong. Ong is uncontactable, and JLC has stated that the funds may have been paid out on his instructions, but no evidence of unauthorized payouts to his account exists. Allied Tech is seeking repayment and has instructed its lawyers to lodge a police report and commence legal proceedings. The Law Society of Singapore has taken over the running of the account due to suspicions of dishonesty.

site_title: Europe: Stocks sink at open as EU voting begins
summary: Europe's major stock markets fell in initial trading Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 down 0.5%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 down 0.9%, and Paris' CAC 40 down 0.8%, amid concerns over the China-US trade war. The European Parliament elections kicked off, with populist forces hoping to gain significant ground, threatening EU integration. Asian equities also tumbled due to the trade war, with risks to the downside building and equity markets needing to reprice to reflect heightened risks.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close down as trade fears hit high-tech
summary: Tokyo shares declined on Thursday due to heightened trade fears and US-China tech disputes. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.62%, and the Topix index slipped 0.36%. The decline was attributed to concerns over US-China trade tensions and their impact on high-tech shares.

site_title: First Sponsor extends payment deadline for 465m yuan Chengdu project disposal
summary: First Sponsor Group has extended the payment deadline for the sale of 465 million yuan worth of its Chengdu Cityspring project to Minyoun Industrial Group. The payment will now be made in monthly instalments of at least 10 million yuan, with liquidated damages of 1% per month if payments are missed. The deal, which was initially set to close by May 27, has been amended multiple times since its announcement in May last year.

site_title: COE for smaller cars dives as buying stalls
summary: COE prices in Singapore decreased across the board at the May 23 tender, with smaller cars experiencing the largest drop. COE for cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp fell to $27,000, down from $36,704 two weeks ago. The prices are attributed to a halt in new car sales following recent price increases, but industry players expect the latest prices to re-ignite buying interest.

images.alt_text: Certificates of entitlement (COE) prices ended lower across the board at the tender on Thursday (May 23), with the premium for smaller cars taking the biggest tumble.

site_title: Atlantic Navigation extends contract with Middle Eastern oil firm to 2020
summary: Atlantic Navigation Holdings has extended its contract with a Middle Eastern National Oil Company for its lift-boat service by one year to May 2020. The contract, initially set to expire in June, was awarded in 2017 and includes a daily charter rate that remains unchanged. The company's shares were suspended due to falling below the minimum free float requirement in December. The secured contracts are expected to contribute positively to Atlantic Navigation's earnings for the financial year 2019.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish with steep losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index falling 1.58% to 27,267.13, and the Shanghai Composite Index dropping 1.35% to 2,852.52. Tensions between China and the US contributed to the decline, affecting tech and energy firms. The losses were also influenced by the US-China trade situation and the split views on the Federal Reserve's future actions.

site_title: Britain's B&M plans 50 more stores as profit rises
summary: Britain's B&M European Value Retail reported an 8.7% rise in 2018-19 profit, reaching £249.4 million. The company plans to open 50 new stores in its new financial year, despite rising costs and internet sales shifts. B&M has seen 17.1% revenue growth and a net 44 new store openings in the year. The company's shares rose 35% this year, valuing the business at £3.82 billion.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary:

ComfortDelGro will test a driverless shuttle at NUS starting Saturday. The Straits Times Index fell 0.7% to 3,160.72, its lowest point in four months, amid global economic concerns, including US tariffs on Vietnam and the UK economy shrinking for the second month.

site_title: Boustead Projects Q4 earnings slip 2% to S$5.7m on weaker margins
summary: Boustead Projects reported a 2% year-on-year decline in Q4 earnings to S$5.7 million, driven by weaker gross margins in its core design-and-build segment. Revenue rose 50% to S$69.3 million, primarily due to a significant project under a deferred payment arrangement. The company proposed a final ordinary dividend of 1.5 cents and special dividend of 0.5 cent. For the full year, earnings rose 5% to S$30.6 million, despite a 26% decline in gross margin due to lower cost savings from completed projects.

site_title: Cushman & Wakefield hires Singapore-based international project marketing head to lead new team
summary: Cushman & Wakefield has appointed John Koh as its head of international project marketing in Singapore, leading a new team specializing in selling new-build London and UK residential developments. Koh, based in Singapore, previously worked at PropNex, Colliers, and Knight Frank, marketing high-profile projects for prominent developers. This appointment aims to strengthen the firm's presence in the UK residential market.

site_title: Great Eastern offers critical illness plan insuring three generations in market first
summary: Great Eastern, an insurance arm of OCBC Bank, has introduced the first critical illness plan in Singapore that protects three generations of a family under a single policy. The Great Family Care plan provides coverage for parents and children without medical underwriting, offering up to S$100,000 coverage for parents and S$100,000 for each child until age 18. The plan aims to ease the financial burden on the "sandwich generation," who care for aging parents and children. The plan is available for a limited period without medical underwriting for existing policyholders.

site_title: Theresa May in peril over Brexit on EU election day
summary: Theresa May faces intense pressure to name a departure date after her final Brexit gambit fails, overshadowing the European election. The Brexit deadlock has led to a potential orderly exit, no-deal exit, election, or second referendum. Following a revolt by some Brexit-supporting ministers, including Andrea Leadsom's resignation, May is now under pressure to step down. The 1922 Committee chairman suggests she will name a departure date on Friday, and the European election results are expected on Sunday, with the Brexit Party likely to win and the Conservatives expected to do poorly.

site_title: Clear lead for Modi's BJP in Indian election, early trends show
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) is on track for a major victory in the election, with early trends showing a lead in 277 out of 542 constituencies. This surpasses the 272 seats required for a majority without allies, indicating a strong possibility of a majority government. The BJP's lead suggests a clear direction for Modi's rule, with the outcome of the election expected to be announced soon.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Narendra Modi looked on course Thursday for a major victory in India's election, with early trends from the election commission showing a clear lead for his party.

site_title: Singapore's headline inflation edges up in April, core inflation eases
summary: Singapore's headline inflation rose to 0.8% in April, matching economists' expectations, driven by higher private road transport costs. Core inflation, which excludes housing and transport costs, eased to 1.3% year-on-year, its third consecutive month of easing. Economists expect the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) to keep policy settings unchanged at its October meeting. They forecast core inflation to average 1-2% and headline inflation to average 0.5-1.5% for 2019, with some expecting a slight increase in headline inflation due to oil-related items.

site_title: Low risk that Vietnam will be labelled as "currency manipulator": Maybank Kim Eng
summary: Vietnam is considered to be at a low risk of being labeled a "currency manipulator" by the US Treasury in the upcoming semi-annual report, according to Maybank Kim Eng Securities. Vietnam meets all three criteria, including a significant bilateral goods trade surplus with the US ($39.5 billion in 2018), a current account surplus of 5.4% of GDP, and total net purchases of foreign currency at 2.6% of GDP. The US may instead use the opportunity to push Vietnam for trade concessions or changes to its currency policy, rather than imposing additional tariffs.

site_title: Lenovo Group Q4 profit surges more than three-fold
summary: Lenovo Group reported a more than three-fold increase in its quarterly profit to US$118 million, beating estimates. Revenue rose 10% to US$11.71 billion, matching forecasts. For the full year, Lenovo swung to a profit of US$597 million, up from a loss of US$189 million. This marks a significant turnaround from the previous year. The company's strong computer sales contributed to the surge in profit.

images.alt_text: Lenovo Group reported a more than three-fold increase in its quarterly profit thanks to strong computer sales.

site_title: Australia shares snap 6 days of gains on trade war fears; NZ at new peak
summary: Australian shares fell 0.3% on Thursday, ending six consecutive gains, due to concerns over US-China trade frictions affecting the technology sector. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,491.80. Global stocks declined, and analysts attributed the drop to "headline flashes on trade." This marks a departure from the previous day's 0.2% gain.

site_title: Surprise consequence of trade war is likely fewer defaulters in China
summary: China's trade tensions with the US may have a surprise consequence: fewer defaulters in the country's US$13 trillion bond market. Despite a surge in defaults this year, the number of first-time defaulters has dropped to three in the current quarter, down from 12 in January-March and 16 in 2018. This decrease could reduce the number of problem companies investors need to avoid, bolstering the broader corporate debt market and providing breathing space for Chinese policymakers. Economists predict a drawn-out trade war with more stimulus needed.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks slip on widening Sino-US tension
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index fell 5.27 points, or 0.26%, to 2,059.59 on growing anxiety over Sino-US conflicts involving Huawei Technologies. This marks a decline in the index's performance over the past 30 trading sessions, which has lost 6.6%. The KOSPI has risen 0.91% so far this year.

images.alt_text: South Korea's KOSPI stock index fell on Thursday on growing anxiety over the Sino-US conflicts involving Huawei Technologies, with the spillover impact dragging on a South Korean telecom operator.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon at 3,168.99, down 0.4% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) resumed trading at 3,168.99, down 0.44% or 14.15 points, due to a decline in 21 out of 30 constituents. Tech stocks, including YZJ Shipbuilding, Thomson Medical, and AEM Holdings, fell 1.4%, 4.8%, and 3.2%, respectively. The decline was also influenced by escalating US-Sino tensions, which affected regional markets, including Japan's Topix, Hong Kong's Hang Seng, and Shanghai's Composite Index.

site_title: ComfortDelGro to test driverless shuttle in NUS from Saturday
summary: ComfortDelGro, a Singapore-based transport giant, will begin testing an autonomous shuttle bus in and around National University of Singapore's Kent Ridge campus starting May 25. The one-year trial, funded by Inchcape Singapore, will use an EZ10 shuttle supplied by EasyMile and travel at speeds of 5-16km/h to collect mapping data. A passenger service trial is expected to start in the third quarter. This trial is part of ComfortDelGro's efforts to assess the commercial viability of driverless services, with similar trials already underway in Sentosa and Jurong Island.

site_title: New fund to help Singapore's marginalised groups land jobs
summary: The Community Foundation of Singapore (CFS) has launched a new fund, Lift, to support marginalized groups in Singapore's workforce. The fund aims to provide vocational training and job placement for 90 participants, including those with disabilities, mental illnesses, and disadvantaged women, with a focus on the food and beverage industry. The program, which includes technical training, social support, and job coaching, aims to help participants overcome barriers to securing employment and improve their socio-economic status.

site_title: Hong Kong's longest-serving CEO steps down, hands over to sons
summary: Hong Kong's longest-serving CEO, David Li, is stepping down from Bank of East Asia after a 38-year tenure, handing over to his sons Adrian and Brian Li. Li, 80, will become executive chairman, while his sons will assume co-CEO roles. His departure follows criticism from Elliott Management Corp, which has alleged improper stock issuance and poor performance. The bank's shares have fallen 25% over the past year, leading to a consensus rating of 1.91 out of 5 from analysts, the lowest among Bloomberg Asia Pacific Banks Index members.

site_title: Universal Music eyeing industry bidder as buyout firms baulk: sources
summary: Vivendi SA is targeting strategic buyers to acquire a stake in Universal Music Group as private equity investors are deterred by the high price and slow deal pace. Despite floating the idea of a partial sale or IPO for 50% of the company, Vivendi has yet to hire advisers and several investors have lost interest. Talks with Tencent Holdings Ltd have been held, but a sale to the Chinese company could raise US trade tensions. The move aims to expand Universal Music internationally, including in China.

site_title: Citic Telecom CPC names Derek Ung as new sales head for Singapore
summary: Citic Telecom CPC has appointed Derek Ung as the new general manager of enterprise sales for Singapore. Ung replaces Simon Lim and will focus on expanding the company's sales and marketing efforts in South-east Asia. With over 20 years of experience selling high-value solutions, Ung will help establish new partnerships and drive go-to-market strategies for ICT solutions in emerging markets. His expertise will foster increased support for channel partners and customers in the region, aiming to expand market share and channel partner portfolio.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower after Wall Street drops
summary: Tokyo shares opened lower on May 23, 2019, following a drop on Wall Street amid US-China trade and tech disputes. The Nikkei 225 index lost 0.47% and the Topix index slipped 0.39%. The declines were attributed to ongoing tensions between the US and China.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Thursday, down 6.02 points to 1,597.72. Losers beat gainers 102-53, with a total trading volume of 49.86 million lots worth RM35 million.

site_title: Cross-border QR payments between Singapore, Hong Kong possible with Liquid Group, JETCO partnership
summary: Liquid Group and Joint Electronic Teller Services (JETCO) have partnered to enable cross-border QR payments between Singapore and Hong Kong. The collaboration aims to encourage QR payment adoption in both cities, with a focus on the travel segment. Customers of participating banks can use their QR payment apps to make purchases in both cities, and merchants can launch marketing campaigns without additional training. The partnership will expand to provide additional value-added services and facilitate large-scale QR payment adoption across the region.

site_title: Singapore firms are global leaders in adopting office technology, workspace trends: Condeco poll
summary: Singapore firms are leading the adoption of office technology, with 72% having smart building measures, compared to 55% globally. The city-state's Smart Nation programme has contributed to this progress, with 17% increase in mobile app usage for booking meeting rooms and higher expectations for cloud computing, IoT, and Big Data. Digital transformation is the biggest challenge globally, with 37% of business leaders citing it. Singapore also tops the flexi-time rankings, with 66% of firms offering flexible work arrangements.

site_title: Taiwan's TSMC says chip shipments to Huawei not affected by US ban
summary: TSMC, the world's largest contract chipmaker, stated that its shipments to Huawei are not affected by the US ban on American technology. The company had previously maintained supplies to Huawei and was assessing the impact of the decision. This comes after the US took action to curb Huawei's access to American technology, with the goal of limiting the telecom equipment maker's ability to source components.

site_title: Ascendant Farage bids to harness Britons' Brexit anger
summary: Nigel Farage, the 55-year-old former UKIP leader, is aiming to secure his third political victory in five years in Thursday's European parliament polls with his Brexit Party. Farage, a driving force behind the 2016 vote to quit the EU, is threatening to smash the two main parties' historic hold on power. Despite criticism of being a hypocrite and a showman, Farage has increasingly mainstream appeal in modern Britain, with a charismatic and communicative persona.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open sharply lower on Thursday
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.37% on Thursday, following a sell-off on Wall Street due to China-US trade anxiety. The Hang Seng Index dropped 379.76 points to 27,326.18, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined 0.38% and 0.40% respectively. The decline was attributed to investors' concerns over the ongoing trade tensions between the US and China, which has sparked anxiety globally.

site_title: Even with trade war, Asia bond investors sleep better at night
summary: Asian bond investors are maintaining their confidence in the region despite a US-China trade war, with local-currency debt offering a return of 1.0% since May 3. Central banks in Asia have more flexibility to cut interest rates, and reforms in countries like China and Papua New Guinea are attracting foreign investors. Investors are seeking the region's relative safety, with demand for local debt issued in currencies like India and the Philippines. Asian policymakers are expected to respond to the trade tensions with stimulus measures if the dispute takes a toll on Chinese growth.

site_title: BHP says outlook for coal 'challenged' as 'no appetite for growth'
summary: BHP, the world's largest miner, has stated that the outlook for coal is "challenged" and there's "no appetite for growth." The company expects thermal coal to plateau and decline due to increasing demand for electric transport and renewable energy. In contrast, BHP sees opportunities in nickel, copper, and oil, which it aims to expand through exploration. The company also views potash as a valuable growth option, contributing to sustainable land use and food security.

site_title: Australia: Shares slip on rising Sino-US trade tensions, New Zealand up
summary: Australian shares slipped 0.3% on Thursday due to rising Sino-US trade tensions, with the mining and financial sectors leading declines. The US administration is reportedly considering sanctions on Chinese technology firm Hikvision, fueling worries of a technology cold war. In contrast, New Zealand's shares rose 0.2% as investors remained positive despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Ikea plans to open first Mexico store in 2020
summary: Ikea plans to open its first store in Mexico in eastern Mexico City in the fall of 2020, marking the company's expansion into Latin America. The medium-sized store will offer 7,500 products and a restaurant seating over 650 people. Ikea aims to target other cities across the country, following a similar compact format to its recent developments. The move is part of the company's strategy to counter growing competition in its core US and European markets.

site_title: US lawmakers want to help rural telecoms replace Huawei, ZTE equipment
summary: US lawmakers introduced a bipartisan bill to provide $700 million in grants to help rural telecoms replace Huawei equipment in their networks. The bill also aims to block the use of Huawei and ZTE equipment in 5G networks, citing concerns over national security. The move is a step further than previous actions by the Trump administration, which has already barred the US government from using Huawei and ZTE equipment. The bill's introduction comes as small rural carriers, which rely heavily on Huawei and ZTE equipment, estimate the cost of replacement to be $800 million to $1 billion.

site_title: PUB fines 2 building contractors for discharging silty water into public drains
summary: The Public Utilities Board (PUB) fined two building contractors, Chye Joo Construction and The Builders (Hup Huat), S$30,300 and S$14,400 respectively for violating earth control measures (ECM) regulations. Both contractors were charged for discharging silty water into public drains, failing to implement ECM plans, and not covering bare areas with erosion control blankets. The fines were imposed after PUB inspections in 2018 uncovered ECM-related offences at various construction sites. The PUB emphasized the importance of ECM to prevent silt buildup in waterways.

site_title: Ankara stopped buying Iran oil out of respect for US sanctions: official
summary: Turkey stopped importing Iranian oil in May out of respect for US sanctions, despite disagreeing with them, according to a Turkish official. The decision came after the US ended exemptions for Turkey and other countries from the sanctions, which prohibited the export of Iranian oil. The move was made as part of a broader effort to address tensions between the US and Turkey, including the purchase of Russian S-400 missile defense systems and US support for Syrian Kurdish forces.

site_title: CAAS sets up panel to review regulations on drone use
summary: The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) has established an Unmanned Aircraft Systems Advisory Panel (UASAP) to review and enhance the country's drone regulatory framework. The panel, chaired by Timothy De Souza, will gather feedback from stakeholders and make recommendations by early 2020. The review comes after technological advancements in drones made them increasingly popular, with proposed changes including compulsory online training, pilot licensing, and certification for heavier drones. Existing regulations prohibit flying drones within 5km of airports or at altitudes above 200 feet without a permit.

site_title: Asia: Equities, pound and oil sink on trade and Brexit woes
summary: Asian equities plummeted on Thursday as China-US trade tensions and Brexit worries weighed on markets. The pound hit a four-month low due to concerns over Prime Minister Theresa May's leadership. Energy firms were also hit by falling oil prices, which tanked after a surprise increase in US inventories. Despite some optimism over a potential China-US trade deal, many observers expect volatility to persist until clarity emerges on the trade front.

site_title: Pacific Star Development to liquidate aluminium business
summary: Pacific Star Development is liquidating its aluminium business division, a creditors' voluntary liquidation of its subsidiaries Durabeau Industries and LH Aluminium Industries, due to strong industry competition and challenges in achieving profitability. The move allows the group to free up resources and focus on property development. The announcement follows a failed disposal attempt earlier this month and shares of Pacific Star Development closed up 11% on the news. The aluminium division accounts for a "small and insignificant" proportion of the group's overall revenue.

site_title: In the land of stout and spirits, Ireland's first 'dry pub'
summary: Ireland's first "dry pub," The Virgin Mary, has opened in Dublin, offering a menu of non-alcoholic beverages. The pub's popularity is seen as a sign that hard-drinking Ireland may be changing its ways, with customers opting for beers and zero-per cent wine instead of stout and spirits. The owners view this as a positive trend, suggesting that the country may be shifting towards a more health-conscious lifestyle.

site_title: Uber to open third Latin America support centre in Bogota
summary: Uber plans to open its third support centre in Latin America in Bogota, Colombia, with a $40 million investment over five years, creating 600 jobs. The centre will provide specialized support to users, drivers, and deliverers for Uber and Uber Eats in the region. The move comes amid regulatory challenges in the country, where the government has deemed ride-hailing apps illegal. Uber hopes to engage in dialogue with the government to establish regulation for the industry.

images.alt_text: Ride-hailing app Uber will spend US$40 million over five years to open its third support centre in Latin America in September in the Colombian capital Bogota, the company said on Wednesday.

site_title: South Korea central bank official says no reason for won to track China's yuan
summary: A South Korea central bank official stated that the won is not necessarily influenced by China's yuan, despite the yuan's recent weakening. The official cited differences in markets and economies as the reason for the won's movement. This comes after officials warned of possible action to curb the won's rapid decline. The official's comments contradict previous warnings from Bank of Korea and finance ministry officials.

site_title: Annica says acting non-executive chairman resigns by email with immediate effect
summary: Annica Holdings' acting non-executive chairman Jeffrey Ong Su Aun resigned by email on May 20, citing "personal reasons." Despite his departure, the company's operations will not be affected. Adnan Bin Mansor will take over as acting non-executive chairman. Annica's shares closed flat at S$0.001, and the full details of Ong's resignation will be disclosed in a separate announcement.

site_title: Europe: Stocks edge down on Brexit, trade war fears
summary: European shares declined 0.08% on May 22, 2019, due to concerns over the US-China trade war and Britain's uncertain departure from the EU. Investors shifted to safe-haven euro zone bonds, causing banks and Brexit-sensitive stocks to fall. The FTSE 100 closed 0.07% higher, while the DAX rose 0.2%, despite a weak pound and losses in homebuilders and retailers. A report on potential curbs on Chinese video surveillance firm Hikvision added to investor unease.

site_title: BOJ to heed market impact when adjusting interest rates: deputy govenor
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) will consider the impact of its interest rate adjustments on domestic and overseas financial markets when exiting monetary stimulus, according to Deputy BOJ Governor Masayoshi Amamiya. The central bank will maintain its current easing policy until inflation reaches its 2% target. This stance reflects the time it takes to accelerate inflation, as the BOJ prioritizes economic growth over immediate inflationary pressures.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Japan would adjust interest rates by paying heed to its impact on domestic and overseas financial markets when it comes to exiting from monetary stimulus, Deputy BOJ Governor Masayoshi Amamiya said on Thursday.

site_title: Panasonic halting business with Huawei after US ban: spokesman
summary: Panasonic has suspended business with Huawei, a Chinese telecoms giant, following a US ban over security fears. The halt affects 68 group companies of Huawei, with Panasonic supplying electronic parts. The move is a blow to Huawei, which is already facing significant challenges due to the US ban. This decision comes after an internal instruction to fully enforce the US government ban was issued by Panasonic.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at Thursday's open; STI down 0.51% to 3,166.98
summary: Singapore stocks declined 0.51% on Thursday, falling to 3,166.98, amid US-China trade frictions and a weaker open in the US markets. Losers outnumbered gainers 69 to 29, with stocks like Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, Golden Agri-Resources, and Sembcorp Marine falling 1.4%, 1.8%, and 2.0% respectively. The decline follows a 5-day rally, and investors are awaiting GDP data on Friday.

site_title: Court says banks must give Congress Trump records
summary: A US federal judge has ruled that banks must comply with Congressional subpoenas for records related to President Donald Trump's businesses. The subpoenas were sent to Deutsche Bank and Capital One as part of a probe into election meddling by Russia. Trump and his children had attempted to block the release of documents, but the judge upheld the subpoenas, paving the way for the documents to be sent to Congress. The decision follows a report that Deutsche Bank failed to report suspicious transactions involving Trump and his son-in-law Jared Kushner in 2016 and 2017.

site_title: Rich Capital partner demands issuance of performance bond by June 1 for Batam project
summary: Rich Capital, a 80% owner of Oxley Batam, received a second letter from its joint-venture partner PT Karya Indo Batam (KIB) demanding the issuance of a performance bond by June 1 for the Batam project. This contradicts a previous agreement reached on May 17. Rich Capital will confirm the bond provision in the letter.

site_title: US urges South Korea to reject Huawei products, citing security risks: Chosun Ilbo
summary: The US government is urging South Korea to reject Huawei products due to security concerns, citing the potential for espionage or cyberattacks. A US State Department official suggested that LG Uplus Corp, a South Korean telco using Huawei equipment, should not serve in sensitive areas. This comes amid a broader push by Washington to get its allies to reject Huawei goods. South Korea, a US ally, has significant trade ties with China, its largest export market, adding to the complexity of the issue. The US has banned Huawei equipment in US telecom networks and imposed limits on its purchases of US technology.

site_title: Huawei executive accused of starting a spy mission against rival
summary: Huawei executive Xu Zhijun, a deputy chairman, allegedly orchestrated a spy mission against US chip startup CNEX Labs in 2016. He asked the lead architect to study and analyze CNEX's technology, claiming Huawei was interested in becoming a client. However, CNEX claims Xu pretended to be interested in purchasing the technology. Huawei denies the allegations, stating it is a victim of stolen trade secrets. CNEX is now seeking permission to compel Huawei to produce relevant emails, which could potentially link Xu to the alleged spy mission.

site_title: China stocks at mercy of foreigners like never before
summary: Foreign investors have never had such a significant influence on China's stock market, with their daily turnover accounting for a record 10% of the onshore market. They own 3.1% of the $6.5 trillion stock market, rivaling the country's mutual funds. Recent outflows of foreign capital are affecting sentiment onshore, with MSCI set to expand China-listed shares in its benchmarks, potentially attracting billions of dollars in overseas capital. Foreign investors tend to favor megacaps, driving significant buying power for top stocks like Kweichow Moutai and Midea Group.

site_title: Allied Tech's S$130m RTO of dorm operator called off amid news of missing S$33m at law firm
summary: Allied Technologies, a Catalist-listed precision engineering firm, has cancelled its proposed S$130 million acquisition of dorm operator Aik Chuan Construction (ACC) due to a missing S$33 million from law firm JLC Advisors, which is believed to belong to Allied Tech. The acquisition was subject to the execution of definitive documents, but no such documents were entered into. The cancellation comes amid an investigation into the missing funds, which has left Allied Tech's auditors flagging the issue.

site_title: Honda recalls 118,000 US SUVs for sudden air bag deployments
summary: Honda Motor Co's US unit is recalling 118,000 new US SUVs, including the 2019 Honda CR-V, due to three reported cases of sudden air bag deployments without a crash. The issue is caused by metal burrs on the steering wheel, which may lead to a short circuit and overheating. There are no related crash reports. This recall is separate from previous Takata air bag inflator recalls affecting over 21 million vehicles. The affected vehicles will receive steering wheel wire harnesses and supplemental restraint system cable reels replacements.

site_title: US aviation regulator says Boeing hasn't submitted 737 Max fix
summary: The US aviation regulator, the FAA, has not received Boeing's proposed fix for its 737 Max aircraft, which has been grounded globally following two deadly crashes. Boeing said it had finished making changes requested by the FAA, but the agency's interim chief, Dan Elwell, stated that the agency is still waiting for the software for approval. The FAA is working to re-establish trust with aviation regulators from 33 countries and has set a goal to lift the prohibition on the 737 Max jets as soon as possible. The fix is expected to be completed by August.

images.alt_text: The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) on Monday said it has lifted the restrictions on Boeing 737 MAX aircraft operations into and out of Singapore, two years after it grounded the plane due to two fatal accidents involving the aircraft model.

site_title: Qatar World Cup to be played with 32 teams: Fifa
summary: Fifa announced that the 2022 World Cup in Qatar will be played with 32 teams, scrapping a proposed expansion to 48 sides. The decision was made after a consultation process with stakeholders, and no proposal will be submitted at the next FIFA Congress. The tournament will remain as originally planned with 32 teams, following a thorough evaluation of the circumstances.

site_title: Russia forges on with Europe gas project despite US sanctions threat
summary: Russia is moving forward with the Nord Stream 2 natural gas pipeline project, despite US threats of sanctions. The 1,230km pipeline, which will supply gas from the Bovanenkovo field to Germany, aims to secure Europe's gas needs at lower prices. The US, along with Ukraine, has criticized the project, saying it increases Europe's reliance on Russian gas and isolates Ukraine. Russia's Gazprom and its European partners, including Germany and Shell, insist that Ukraine will remain a transit country. The project's launch has been delayed due to Denmark's refusal to issue a permit, and the US has warned of "onerous restrictions" if the project is completed.

site_title: Philippines' Duterte orders garbage shipped back to Canada
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has ordered the shipment of garbage sent by Canada to the Philippines in 2013 and 2014 to be returned to Canada. The order comes after Manila recalled its ambassador from Ottawa due to Canada's missed deadline to repatriate the trash. If Canada refuses, the garbage will be dumped in Canadian territorial waters. Canada has since awarded a contract to Bollore Logistics to safely bring the waste back to Canada, with removal and disposal planned by the end of June and summer.

images.alt_text: President Rodrigo Duterte has ordered tonnes of garbage dumped in the Philippines years ago to be shipped back to Canada, his spokesman said on Wednesday, but Ottawa announced arrangements to take back the offending cargo which led to a diplomatic row.

site_title: Federal Reserve says economic risks have receded
summary: The US Federal Reserve stated that economic risks, including trade uncertainty and Brexit, have receded but remain present. The central bank's April meeting decision to keep interest rates unchanged was influenced by optimism over a potential US-China trade deal. However, President Trump's subsequent tariff increase on Chinese goods has raised concerns. The Fed can afford to be patient before making further rate moves due to muted inflation pressures.

site_title: May stares at defeat in final Brexit gambit
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit deal is facing its final rejection as parliament overwhelmingly condemned her plan, forcing Britain to miss its original departure date. With her career seemingly on the line, May is considering stepping down despite promising to do so regardless of the outcome. The European Parliament elections, which favor the anti-EU Brexit Party, further erode her support, and pressure is building for her to resign. A new leader, including former foreign secretary Boris Johnson, is likely to take over and attempt to rescue the Brexit process.

site_title: Investors stick with safe-haven bonds on trade, Brexit concerns
summary: Investors are favoring safe-haven bonds due to ongoing trade tensions between the US and China, as well as renewed uncertainty surrounding the UK's Brexit exit. The 10-year German bund yield dropped to -0.07% on Wednesday, while French and Dutch bond yields also fell marginally. Portugal is set to issue a 2 billion yuan Chinese yuan-denominated Panda bond, and Italian yields fell after recent opinion polls suggested deputy prime minister Matteo Salvini's far-right party may not perform well in European parliamentary elections.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SingHaiyi, Yongnam, Neo Group, Pacific Star Development
summary: SingHaiyi reported a 47.6% year-over-year increase in Q4 FY19 net profit to S$9.74 million, while revenue declined 67.6% to S$9.84 million. Yongnam Holdings raised up to S$15 million through redeemable convertible bonds, with an estimated net proceeds of S$14.5 million. Neo Group posted a 43% increase in Q4 net profit to S$3.92 million, driven by higher revenue. Pacific Star Development announced the liquidation of its aluminium business division, while proposing a final cash dividend of 0.5 Singapore cent for FY19.

site_title: HDB launches more than 6,700 flats, including units in Tengah, Kallang Whampoa
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) launched 6,753 new flats in Singapore, including 1,193 units in Tengah and 987 units in Garden District. Prices start from S$86,000 for a two-room flexi flat to S$562,000 for a four-room flat. The launch includes 3,485 Build-To-Order (BTO) flats and 3,268 balance flats, with 28% already completed. HDB will also announce upcoming BTO projects six months in advance to help buyers plan.

site_title: Marks & Spencer challenges supermarkets with big food stores
summary: Marks & Spencer plans to open more large food stores, shifting away from smaller convenience outlets, as part of an alliance with Ocado Group Plc. The move comes as the retailer faces declining profit and shares fell 5.4% due to a £601 million shareholder rights issue to finance the deal. Marks & Spencer aims to increase its presence in Britain's full-range grocery sector and revamp its ageing large stores with a modernisation programme, but faces challenges from e-commerce and Brexit's impact on consumer sentiment.

site_title: US: Wall Street slides as trade anxiety resumes
summary: US stocks declined, falling 0.4% on Wednesday, as trade anxiety resurfaced. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 both fell, while the Nasdaq dropped 0.5%. Qualcomm's 10.9% drop was attributed to a federal judge's ruling on antitrust laws. Investors reacted to reports of President Trump considering blacklisting Hikvision, a Chinese video surveillance firm. Despite the Dow staying flat for the week, shares in Target jumped 7.8% after better-than-expected earnings, while Walmart warned of potential price hikes due to new tariffs.

site_title: Mobile phone resellers shun Huawei handsets for now
summary: Mobile phone resellers in Singapore have temporarily halted purchasing Huawei handsets due to concerns over reselling and potential security risks.
