The rally, which ended peacefully, turned violent when protesters refused to leave and hurled objects at police. Police had deployed riot gear and tear gas, and no injuries were reported. The official election results confirmed Joko's victory, with Prabowo Subianto threatening to challenge the results in court. Tensions remain high in the country, with over 30,000 troops deployed across the capital.

site_title: Jamie Oliver: TV star and man on a mission
summary: British chef Jamie Oliver's restaurant chain, comprising 25 outlets across Britain, collapsed on Tuesday, resulting in the loss of 1,000 jobs. The 43-year-old, a multi-millionaire, had struggled with the financial viability of his business, despite his popularity and success in the culinary world, including his TV shows and books. Oliver had invested in creating a London restaurant staffed with disadvantaged youngsters and campaigned for healthier eating options, but controversy surrounding his business practices and ties with big supermarkets ultimately contributed to its downfall.

site_title: Austrian F1 great Niki Lauda dies at 70
summary: Niki Lauda, the Austrian Formula One legend, has died at the age of 70. Lauda's life was marked by his near-fatal 1976 accident, which he miraculously recovered from to win two more world championships. After retiring from racing, he went on to found Lauda Air, which he sold to Austrian Airlines, and later created the low-cost carrier Niki. He also held various business and racing roles, including team principal at Jaguar and non-executive chairman of Mercedes. Lauda's determination and expertise earned him respect, but his uncompromising behavior also ruffled feathers.

site_title: Trump meets Pacific islands leaders to boost US ties
summary: US President Donald Trump met with the leaders of Palau, the Federated States of Micronesia, and the Republic of the Marshall Islands at the White House, showcasing US support in the Pacific region amid growing Chinese influence. The leaders issued a joint statement reaffirming their interest in a free and open Indo-Pacific region, highlighting the importance of maritime trade. This meeting demonstrates Trump's focus on the Pacific Islands, recognizing the US's strategic, economic, cultural, and people-to-people links in the region.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: A buyout offer for Kingboard Copper Foil has closed, with the offeror group owning 98.5% of shares issued. The offer, valued at S$0.60 per share, was deemed "not fair but reasonable" by an independent financial adviser. The company's shares were suspended from trading after the free float fell below 10%.

site_title: US business group says retaliation rising in China amid trade war
summary: A top US business lobby in China reported that nearly half of its members are experiencing non-tariff barrier retaliation in China due to the ongoing trade war. 40.7% of respondents considered relocating manufacturing facilities outside China, and 75% said tariffs are hurting their competitiveness. Companies are coping by focusing on domestic sales and delaying investments, citing increased obstacles such as government inspections and slower customs clearance. The US business community in China has advocated a harder line on discriminatory Chinese trade policies, which may hinder future trade negotiations.

images.alt_text: A top US business lobby in China said on Wednesday that nearly half of its members are seeing non-tariff barrier retaliation in China as a result of the increasingly bitter trade war between Beijing and Washington.

site_title: Amazon finally gets rights to .amazon domain name
summary: Amazon has been granted the rights to the ".amazon" domain name by the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN). After years of dispute with South American countries, including Brazil, ICANN sided with the US-based e-commerce giant. The Brazilian Ministry of Foreign Affairs had argued that the domain should not be monopolized by a company due to its relation to the Amazon forest. A public comment period will follow the decision, and Amazon will now be able to establish its own online neighborhood.

site_title: US trade chief to talk with EU, Japan amid concerns over Chinese subsidies
summary: US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer is set to meet with EU and Japanese officials in Paris to address non-market oriented policies, focusing on Chinese subsidies. The meeting, during the OECD ministerial meeting, aims to strengthen joint efforts against unfair trade practices. Lighthizer will also hold bilateral meetings and attend the World Trade Organization's informal ministerial meeting. This move comes amid concerns over Chinese subsidies and its impact on global trade.

images.alt_text: US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer will meet with officials from the European Union and Japan in Paris on Thursday regarding joint efforts to address the non market-oriented policies and practices of other countries, his office said.

site_title: Adidas, Nike, PUMA say new tariffs on China would be 'catastrophic'
summary: US President Donald Trump faces opposition from major shoe manufacturers Adidas, Nike, and PUMA over new tariffs on China, which they claim would be "catastrophic" for the industry. The companies, along with over 170 American shoe manufacturers and retailers, urge Trump to exempt footwear from a new round of tariffs on $300 billion in Chinese goods. They argue that additional tariffs would increase costs and prices, and US consumers would ultimately bear the burden.

site_title: US McDonald's hit with sexual harassment complaints
summary: US McDonald's workers have filed dozens of new sexual harassment complaints against the fast food giant, with allegations including groping, indecent exposure, and retaliation. The complaints, filed with the US agency, come as workers protest for unionization and stronger worker protections, tying their efforts to the #MeToo movement. McDonald's CEO Steve Easterbrook claims the company has improved its policies and training, but workers' advocates say little has changed since previous complaints were filed. Workers demand the right to craft sexual harassment policies and control personnel decisions of franchisees, as part of their "Fight for $15" unionization effort.

images.alt_text: McDonald's workers filed dozens of new sexual harassment charges against the fast food giant, advocates said on Tuesday, escalating a years-long battle for unionisation in the US and stronger worker protections.

site_title: Airbus prepares counter-punch to new Boeing mid-sized jet
summary: Airbus is preparing to counter a potential new Boeing mid-sized jet, which could compete with its A330neo and A321neo models. Airbus aims to defend the market with its existing aircraft, promising a "left hook, right hook" approach. The company is also considering a long-range version of the A321, called A321XLR, to pre-empt the Boeing jet. Airbus and Boeing are playing reverse roles in the market, with Boeing's 777X facing competition from the newer A350-1000.

site_title: Kirchner corruption trial opens in Argentina
summary: Former Argentine President Cristina Kirchner's corruption trial began on May 21, 2019, with charges accusing her of favoring a businessman friend for lucrative road construction contracts in Santa Cruz province. The trial, which is expected to last a year, marks a significant challenge for Kirchner ahead of the October presidential election. Despite strong support among the poor, Kirchner's parliamentary immunity as a senator spared her from pre-trial detention, and she dismissed the trial as a "smokescreen" to distract voters from economic problems.

images.alt_text: Former Argentine president Cristina Kirchner listened to the charges against her on Tuesday in the first hearing of a corruption trial that will unfold as the country heads towards general elections in October.

site_title: Temasek-linked Astrea PE bonds get Fitch upgrades, affirmations
summary: Fitch Ratings upgraded and affirmed ratings for Astrea III and Astrea IV private-equity bonds, citing diversified portfolios, over-collateralisation, and ability to pass loan-to-value tests. Astrea III's US$170 million Class A-2 notes were upgraded to "A+(sf)" and its US$100 million Class B notes were affirmed at "BBB+(sf)". Astrea IV's S$242 million Class A-1 notes were upgraded to "A+(sf)", while its US$210 million Class A-2 and US$110 million Class B notes were affirmed at "A(sf)" and "BBB(sf)" respectively. The upgrades reflect the performance and reserves accounts balances of both transactions.

site_title: ST Telemedia JV building 7b baht Bangkok data centre
summary: ST Telemedia Global Data Centres (STT GDC) and Frasers Property (Thailand) Public Company (FPT) are investing 7 billion baht (S$302 million) in a data centre development in Bangkok's Ramkhamhaeng area. The 60,000 sq m facility will be the largest in Thailand, with two data centre buildings, and is expected to be completed by 2021. The project aims to cater to strong demand from banking and financial institutions, e-commerce players, and global cloud operators. The digital economy in Thailand is expected to grow, driven by IT-related spending estimated at US$72 billion from 2019 to 2022.

site_title: Singapore bucks weak commercial property market in Q1
summary: Singapore's commercial real estate market defied the downtrend in other major Asia-Pacific markets, with investments jumping 72% year-on-year to US$1.9 billion in Q1. This marked a departure from the trend seen in other markets, with diverse transactions in retail, office, and industrial sectors contributing to the growth. According to RCA, this increase was driven by a more diverse range of transactions in the first quarter of 2019.

site_title: Getting serious about zero CO2 emissions
summary: The International Maritime Organization's (IMO) Marine Environment Protection Committee (MEPC 74) concluded its session with mixed reactions, with some expressing concern over the lack of ambition in addressing climate change. Environmental groups criticized the IMO for wasting time on procedural issues, while the International Chamber of Shipping (ICS) expressed confidence in meeting the 2030 CO2 reduction target. The ICS called for the introduction of commercially viable zero- or near-zero CO2 emitting propulsion systems to achieve the target of a 50% total cut of GHG emissions by 2050.

site_title: Renault's JV in Russia hands control of dashboard to search engine
summary: Renault's joint venture in Russia has partnered with Yandex to integrate its search engine into the dashboards of locally made cars. This partnership allows for real-time navigation, voice assistance, and music services, and may provide access to valuable customer data. The move is part of Russia's efforts to develop connected vehicles, and marks a significant shift towards local solutions in the country's car-making industry. The partnership may also give Yandex a competitive edge in the Russian market.

site_title: A stronger Jokowi must face economic headwinds
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo, known as Jokowi, has won a second term with a 55.5% share of votes, defeating Prabowo Subianto. Jokowi must now deliver on a reform agenda, including record spending on infrastructure, attracting foreign investment, and navigating a worsening global trade environment. The economy has been weighed down by weaker global demand and US-China trade tensions, with inflation expected to accelerate. Jokowi's administration plans to spend over $400 billion on infrastructure, and he aims to boost investment and exports to stimulate the economy.

site_title: Asian market fixed income ETFs see 'solid returns' over past 12 months: SGX
summary: Asian fixed-income ETFs have seen "solid returns" over the past 12 months, with some tracking bond markets in Asia and Singapore. According to the Singapore Exchange, these ETFs have a total fund size of S$1.4 billion, with notable performers including the iShares JPMorgan USD Asia Credit Bond, which returned 8.5% and 10.4% in USD and SGD respectively. The strong performance is attributed to investors seeking opportunities outside the US, amid a pause in the Fed's interest rate hike, and the inclusion of China bonds into global bond indices.

site_title: US: Tech rally leads stocks higher
summary: US stocks rose on Tuesday, led by technology shares, after the US delayed imposing a ban on dealings with Huawei, boosting tech-rich indices. The Nasdaq Composite Index gained 1.1% to 7,785.72, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 rose 0.8% and 0.9% respectively. The delay lifted investor sentiment and pushed the Nasdaq to a fresh record, despite ongoing trade uncertainty and tariff concerns.

site_title: Oil climbs as Opec and allies agree to 'stay the course'
summary: Oil prices rose 0.5% in New York futures, extending gains from the previous day, as Opec and its allies are likely to extend production cuts beyond June 2019. Saudi Energy Minister Khalid Al-Falih urged the coalition to "stay the course" on output limits after a meeting in Jeddah. The move aims to stabilize oil prices amid a deteriorating US-China trade relationship.

site_title: Uber's IPO flop a wake-up call for investors that the bottomline matters
summary: Uber's initial public offering (IPO) on the New York Stock Exchange was a major flop, with investors losing $655 million on the first day of trading and a combined $2.27 billion over the next two years. The company's valuation has dropped from $120 billion to $40 billion, highlighting a disconnect between private and public valuations. Uber remains unprofitable, with high burn rates and slowing growth, and its CEO has warned that it may never make money. The IPO's failure serves as a warning to investors and ride-hailing companies, including Grab and Go-Jek, to focus on profitability.

site_title: Extreme CEO pay: America's economic 'miracle'
summary: US CEOs have seen their pay rise 1,000% between 1978 and 2017, while median worker wages increased only 11.2%. The shift to equity-based pay, where CEOs are tied to stock performance, has contributed to this disparity. The average American worker's wages have remained flat in real terms since 2000, while the S&P 500 index has tripled. Critics argue that CEO pay is excessive, especially when tied to company performance that benefits shareholders, not employees. The issue is exacerbated by corporate tax cuts, which have led to increased stock buybacks, further widening the pay gap.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rise, Huawei reprieve boosts tech shares
summary: European shares rose on Tuesday, driven by tech stocks recovering from losses following a temporary easing of US restrictions on China's Huawei. The Stoxx 600 gained 0.5%, with chipmakers and telecoms firms making gains. The tech sector rose 1.6%, while oil and gas stocks added 1%. Despite a positive day, investors remain cautious due to ongoing US-China trade tensions, with analysts warning of potential downside in equity markets if the situation escalates.

site_title: Fullerton starts multi-asset funds for savers in various age groups
summary: Fullerton Fund Management has launched a series of multi-asset funds targeting savers of various ages, including young savers and retirees. The SGD Heritage Funds comprise three Singapore-centric solutions with varying asset allocation and income payouts, aiming to generate regular income and potential long-term capital appreciation. The funds are distributed by Standard Chartered Bank and have annual management fees ranging from 0.8% to 0.98%. The funds are tailored to different segments, including younger savers, those in their 40s and 50s, and retirees, with target distributions ranging from 2% to 8.8% per year.

site_title: JCG to buy 51% stake in Malaysian medical aesthetics group
summary: JCG Investment has announced its proposed acquisition of a 51% stake in Malaysian medical aesthetics group, Beverly Wilshire Medical Centre, for up to RM15.3 million (S$5.1 million). The acquisition is part of JCG's overall strategic plan to build its health business, with plans to expand into wealth management. The deal is expected to strengthen and expand JCG's business into Malaysia, with demand for high-end medical services and aesthetics expected to grow.

site_title: Spaces opens new locations in Somerset, Clarke Quay
summary: Spaces, a flexible workspace provider, has opened two new locations in Singapore, bringing the total to four. The new locations are at TripleOne Somerset and Clarke Quay, with plans for two more by year-end. The Somerset branch spans 35,000 sq ft with luxury brands and 135 co-working desks, while the Clarke Quay branch covers 16,684 sq ft. IWG plans to expand further in Singapore, targeting the mobile workforce and decentralised offices, with a total coverage of 250,000 sq ft across six locations in the country.

site_title: Asia's woes push US$ to 2½ week high as investors seek safety
summary: The US dollar surged to a 2½ week high against a basket of six major currencies, rising 0.2% to 98.11, as investors sought safety amid concerns over a trade conflict between the US and China affecting Asian economies. Data showed Singapore's economic growth hit a nearly decade-low in the first quarter, while Thailand's was at its lowest in four years. Higher US Treasury yields also contributed to the dollar's strength, with the 10-year yield rising to a one-week high of 2.428%.

site_title: Morgan Stanley slashes worst-case price for Tesla to US$10
summary: Morgan Stanley analysts have lowered their worst-case price estimate for Tesla to US$10 per share, citing concerns over market saturation and strain on fundamentals. The electric car leader faces challenges, including flagging deliveries and growing competition in China, where Tesla must expand aggressively to boost demand. Analysts recommend Tesla expand into the Chinese market, offer lower-priced vehicles, and supply mobility fleets to tap into the world's largest EV market. Despite this, they maintain a price target of US$230.

site_title: Growth, trade woes weigh on STI
summary: Singapore stocks closed 0.7% lower on Tuesday, down 22.20 points to 3,183.26, due to a missed GDP growth expectation and a lowered growth outlook. The China-US trade relationship also weighed on investors' minds. The Straits Times Index declined, with decliners outnumbering advancers 281 to 121. Key stocks, such as Yangzijiang Shipbuilding and AEM Holdings, fell, while defensive counters like telcos and food and beverage players gained. Market watchers advise investors to remain cautious due to volatile equity markets and uncertainty in China's response to the US.

site_title: Be future-ready with a diverse, gender-balanced workforce
summary: A diverse and gender-balanced workforce is crucial for driving innovation and growth in the financial sector, particularly in the face of technological advancements. According to an EY study, companies with forward-looking diversity and inclusion practices deliver a 42% higher return on sales. New technologies, such as teleconferencing and cloud communications, have made remote working possible, allowing more women to succeed in their careers. To achieve a future-ready workforce, organizations must adopt flexible work arrangements, upskill employees, and foster a growth mindset among female students to pursue STEM disciplines.

site_title: Indonesia may ground 737 Max until 2020
summary: Indonesia may ground Boeing's 737 Max until 2020 due to safety concerns after two fatal crashes. The country's Director General of Civil Aviation, Polana Pramesti, stated that pilots will undergo more stringent training before flying the jet, and Indonesia will make its own decision after the US Federal Aviation Administration clears the plane. Even if cleared, Indonesia's decision may delay the plane's return to service globally, with other countries such as China, Canada, and the European Union also planning independent reviews.

site_title: TrickleStar, maker of energy-saving products, seeks Catalist listing
summary: TrickleStar, a Singapore-based energy-saving products company, has lodged a preliminary prospectus for an initial public offering (IPO) on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board. The company plans to pay out at least 50% of its consolidated net profit in dividends following the IPO. TrickleStar posted revenue of $12.8 million and net profit of $2 million for fiscal 2018. The IPO aims to raise funds for product development, expansion into new markets, and general working capital purposes.

site_title: Westpac Singapore pulls rug from under 300 mortgage customers
summary: Westpac Singapore has announced it will exit the mortgage business, affecting 300 borrowers, including foreigners and Singaporeans, with six months to refinance or repay outstanding loans. The bank cited commercial and strategic factors for the decision, and has offered alternative refinance options through local banks and its parent bank in Australia and New Zealand. The move has raised concerns about the impact on customers and the competitive market in Singapore.

site_title: Samsung shares rise as Huawei struggles amid blacklist woes
summary: Samsung shares rose 2.7% on Tuesday amid Huawei's mounting problems, including a decision by Google to sever ties with the Chinese mobile phone maker. The US ban on Huawei could benefit Samsung, the world's largest smartphone maker, by damaging Huawei's ability to sell phones outside China. Analysts predict a potential decline in demand for semiconductors, which could hurt Samsung's business.

site_title: Maybank Kim Eng eyes technology, IP to seize Asean growth opportunities
summary: Maybank Kim Eng, the investment arm of Malaysian banking giant Maybank, aims to harness technology and intellectual property to drive growth in the Asean region. The bank's CEO, Ami Moris, emphasizes the need to stay relevant with clients seeking sophisticated, individualized solutions. Maybank Kim Eng has developed proprietary applications, such as KE Trade Mobile, to cater to clients' needs and has successfully rolled out the app in several countries. The bank plans to continue leveraging its Asean presence to capitalize on the region's growth, which is expected to reach over 5% annually in the next five years.

images.alt_text: "The mission statement of the bank is humanising financial services and we want to be part of the agenda to drive and leverage responsible growth, by taking on an environmental, social and governance-focused approach to investment," Ami Moris, CEO of Maybank Kim Eng, said

site_title: Nigeria's business prospects, investment opportunities to grow in government's 2nd term
summary: Nigeria's President Muhammadu Buhari secured a second term with 56% of the vote, winning 19 out of 37 administrative divisions. The ruling APC secured a majority in the Senate and House of Representatives, giving the president a strong mandate to deliver on his promises. Buhari's second term is expected to focus on rooting out corruption, infrastructure spending, and fuel stability. The Central Bank of Nigeria governor, Godwin Emefiele, has had his term extended, suggesting a continuation of multiple exchange rates to ensure naira stability. Fiscal and monetary policy are expected to remain consistent, with growth constrained by the lack of meaningful reforms.

site_title: Trade war hurts, what else?
summary: The US-China trade war continues to pose significant risks to global markets, with the IMF estimating a 0.6% annual cut in US GDP growth and 1.5% in China's growth. However, a full-scale trade war is unlikely, with a 50% probability of continued negotiation. China's strategy is to play it cool with targeted retaliation, while the US may back down if market sentiment worsens. Despite the risks, China's growth is expected to remain stable at 6.2%, with the renminbi likely to stay above 6.65 per USD. Easing in China and a patient US Fed may support global growth and risk assets, particularly in Asia.

site_title: 'Mother of Satan' bombs show foreign involvement in Sri Lanka bombings
summary: Sri Lankan investigators have found that the bombers who killed 258 people in Easter Sunday bombings used "Mother of Satan" explosives favored by the Islamic State group. The unstable TATP mixture was manufactured by local jihadists with Islamic State expertise, indicating foreign involvement. Sri Lankan detectives believe the National Thowheeth Jama'ath, local militants blamed for the attacks, must have had foreign help to assemble the bombs. At least two suspects have been arrested in Qatar and Saudi Arabia, underscoring the international link.

site_title: Ex-Credit Suisse banker pleads guilty in US$2 billion Mozambique scam
summary: A former Credit Suisse banker, Detelina Subeva, pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy to launder funds in a US$2 billion scam related to loans to Mozambique. The scam involved bribes and kickbacks for maritime projects, with at least US$200 million plundered. Subeva admitted to laundering proceeds of secret payments made by a company, Privinvest Group, and agreed to cooperate. She faces up to 20 years in prison but was allowed to remain free on a US$2 million bond. The case centers on deals made in 2013 to finance maritime projects and coastline protection in Mozambique.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. Meanwhile, US stocks opened lower amid a fresh tariff salvo by Trump on Canada. Creative Technology warned of possible below-target H2 revenue and operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for its £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, is set to become OCBC's incoming CEO. MAS and PBOC are deepening cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks had a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: May to ask lawmakers to vote on a second Brexit referendum
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May has announced that her government will include a requirement for lawmakers to vote on a second Brexit referendum in the Withdrawal Agreement Bill. This move aims to address the strong public demand for a second referendum. May stated that MPs who want a second referendum must first have a deal and the Withdrawal Agreement Bill to make it happen.

site_title: Trade war, weak yuan keep foreign money away from China's markets
summary: Foreign investors are pulling out of China's capital markets due to a weaker yuan and trade tensions, with overseas investors selling mainland-listed stocks at a record pace. The offshore yuan has declined 2.9% against the dollar, making yuan-denominated assets less attractive, and foreign investors are instead opting for dollar-denominated Chinese and emerging-market debt. The Shanghai Composite Index has lost about half of its gains for the year, and policymakers are under pressure to open the country's financial sector to the world.

site_title: Cirque du Soleil looks to break into Hollywood with film deal
summary: Cirque du Soleil has partnered with Rideback to produce feature-length films based on its characters, following the success of "The Lego Movie" and "Aladdin." The deal aims to expand the company's revenue streams beyond its stage shows, with more specific plans and release dates to be worked out. This move is part of Cirque du Soleil's efforts to diversify and capitalize on the growing demand for intellectual property in the entertainment industry. The partnership will help Cirque du Soleil "be present on multiplatforms," according to CEO Daniel Lamarre.

site_title: Singapore growth downgraded as trade war threatens economy, business
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to experience a sharp slowdown due to the US-China trade war and its impact on the global tech electronics cycle. The Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) has downgraded its full-year growth forecast to 1.5-2.5% from 1.5-3.5%, citing a challenging external environment. The first quarter growth rate of 1.2% is the lowest in almost a decade, with manufacturing contracting by 0.5% due to the electronics and precision engineering segments. Despite some bright spots, economists predict a slim chance of a trade recovery this year.

site_title: Discovery of cancer remedy raises issues of when, how to proceed
summary: Researchers have discovered a compound called indole-3-carbinol (i3c) that blocks an enzyme inhibiting the Pten gene, potentially offering a cancer remedy. The compound, found in cruciferous vegetables like Brussels sprouts, can counteract a rare mutation in the Pten gene, which increases cancer risk. While the study was conducted in mice and human cancer cells, experts are debating whether to proceed with a clinical trial using a pharmaceutical-grade version of i3c. A clinical trial is recommended to determine the efficacy and safety of i3c as a cancer treatment.

site_title: Singapore, Malaysia to defer Johor Baru-Woodlands Link till Sept 30
summary: Singapore and Malaysia have signed an agreement to defer construction of the Johor Baru-Woodlands Link, a cross-border MRT link, until September 30. The six-month suspension will result in Malaysia reimbursing Singapore more than S$600,000 in abortive costs. This decision comes after the two countries failed to reach a consensus on the project's terms. The agreement is seen as a temporary reprieve for both countries, allowing them to revisit the project's feasibility and negotiate a revised deal.

site_title: Tech adoption linked to better performance in firms
summary: A study by the Singapore Ministry of Trade and Industry found that the adoption of digital technologies by firms, including small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), is linked to better performance in terms of value-added and productivity. About 1,150 firms were analyzed from 2014 to 2016, and results showed that basic digital tools were widely adopted, but adoption rates for digital platform tools and advanced digital tools are lower. SMEs were responsible for the low adoption rate of more advanced digital technologies, with a significant increase in value-added and productivity seen when firms adopted digital platform tools or advanced digital tools.

site_title: Home design startup Livspace snags investment from Ikea group
summary: Livspace, a home design and renovation startup, has secured a strategic investment from Ingka Group, the parent company of Ikea, in a minority stake. Ingka's investment aims to leverage Ikea's retail expertise and synergies with Livspace's omnichannel approach. The deal allows Livspace to integrate Ikea's catalogue and explore online-to-offline innovations. The startup plans to expand beyond India, targeting geographies in South-east Asia, and will continue to be headquartered in Singapore.

site_title: India watchdog probing allegations of anti-competitive conduct by Maruti: sources
summary: India's Competition Commission is investigating Maruti Suzuki, the country's largest car maker, for allegedly controlling discounts at its dealerships, stifling competition and harming consumers. Maruti, majority-owned by Japan's Suzuki Motor Corp, is accused of forcing dealers to limit discounts, contrary to Indian law. A similar case against Hyundai Motor Co was fined $12.5 million in 2017, and if the CCI finds merit in the allegations against Maruti, it could lead to a stronger case. Maruti's market power and dominance in the Indian car market make it a significant player in the investigation.

site_title: Acromec unit to build, operate waste-to-energy plant for Chew's Agriculture poultry farm
summary: Acromec's 80% owned unit will build, own, and operate a waste-to-energy power plant at Chew's Agriculture's new poultry farm in Neo Tiew Road, Singapore. The 15-year agreement aims to boost recurring income and diversify into renewable energy. Chew's will supply poultry waste to convert into biogas, generating electricity at a discounted rate. The facility will process waste from 600,000 egg-laying chickens and supply 0.5 megawatt per hour of electricity. Construction is expected to be completed by March 31, 2020, with the option to purchase the facility after 15 years.

site_title: Wilmar tops Singapore companies for human rights disclosure, second in Asean: study
summary: Wilmar International, a Singapore-based agribusiness giant, topped Singapore companies for human rights disclosure, ranking second in the Asean region. The ranking, conducted by a joint study of the Asean CSR Network, Article 30, and Mahidol University, evaluated 50 publicly listed companies in Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore, the Philippines, and Thailand against the United Nations Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights. Wilmar scored 90% in human rights disclosure, with eight of the top three companies being palm-related consumer staple companies, indicating progress in the industry's transformation towards sustainability.

site_title: Bristol an urban canvas for Banksy
summary: Banksy's street art has made Bristol, his hometown, a popular tourist destination, with many of his works being photographed and admired daily. The city has become a hub for street art, with over 150 artists working there, thanks to Banksy's influence. Despite his anonymity, Banksy has a special connection with the city, and locals have helped preserve his secret identity. His works, such as "The Girl with a Pierced Eardrum" and "Love is in the Bin," have become iconic and continue to attract visitors.

site_title: ESG cuts exports forecast range to 0 to -2% contraction following 6.4% Q1 drop
summary: Singapore's Enterprise Singapore (ESG) has cut its non-oil domestic export growth forecast to 0 to -2% contraction in 2019, following a 6.4% drop in the first quarter. This is worse than the 1.1% dip in the fourth quarter of 2018. The downgrade comes amid weak global trade expansion and a sharp decline in shipments to top markets, with only the US and Thailand seeing growth. The projection for total merchandise trade growth remains at 0.0 to 2.0% for 2019.

images.alt_text: The official non-oil domestic export growth forecast for this year has been trimmed - following a sharper drop in the NODX in the first three months of the year.

site_title: Diversification not working for Jardine Matheson
summary: Jardine Matheson Holdings Ltd, a 187-year-old conglomerate, has seen two of its owned companies, Dairy Farm International Holdings Ltd and Jardine Cycle & Carriage Ltd, experience significant declines in 2019, with the former dropping 15% and the latter 6%. This is unusual given the diversified portfolio, with more than two-thirds of the Straits Times Index's shares rising. Analysts attribute the decline to operational issues, restructuring charges, and a slowing car market in Indonesia.

site_title: Job cuts at Ford to reach 7,000 by the end of August
summary: Ford Motor plans to cut 7,000 salaried jobs, or 10%, by the end of August, with 500 US jobs cut this week and an unspecified number over the next several weeks. The reductions aim to reduce bureaucracy and result in annual savings of $600 million. This is part of Ford's broader cost-cutting efforts, following slower sales in Europe, South America, and Asia. The company has already cut 800 US jobs this year, with 1,500 eliminated last year through buyouts.

site_title: Jamie Oliver's UK restaurant chain collapses
summary: Celebrity chef Jamie Oliver's restaurant group has collapsed, employing 1,300 staff, amid fierce competition and a rough trading environment on Britain's high streets. The group, which includes Jamie's Italian, Barbecoa, and Jamie's Diner, has officially fallen into administration. Oliver expressed sadness and gratitude to staff and suppliers, citing difficulty in the move. This marks the latest victim of the struggling casual-dining business, following closures of other prominent chains in 2018.

site_title: US eases curbs on Huawei; founder says clampdown underestimates Chinese firm
summary: The US temporarily eased trade restrictions on Huawei, granting the Chinese telecoms equipment maker a license to buy US goods until August 19 to maintain existing networks and provide software updates. Huawei founder Ren Zhengfei said the reprieve underestimated the company's capabilities and that it had been preparing for such a scenario. The move is seen as a compromise to minimize disruption to customers, but analysts warn that changes to Huawei's supply chain may have far-reaching and unintended consequences.

site_title: New Australia PM struggles to meet tax relief election pledge
summary: Australia's re-elected coalition government faces a challenge in delivering tax breaks promised to tens of millions of voters by July 1, as parliament may not convene in time due to vote counting and result verification. Treasurer Josh Frydenberg said the legislation may not be passed before the end of June, and the central bank has called for stimulus to boost an economy hit by a slowdown in household consumption. The delay could pile pressure on the government, which had promised tax rebates worth up to A$1,080 to middle- and low-income earners.

site_title: Australian regulator to ease mortgage rules in reprieve for banks
summary: The Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA) has proposed easing mortgage rules, allowing banks to set their own minimum interest rate floors in loan assessments. The current 7% floor is expected to be reduced to 2.5% with a 0.5% buffer, potentially boosting borrowing. This change comes amid a slowing economy and record-low interest rates, with banks' shares surging in response. The regulator's move aims to alleviate the gap between the current interest rate and actual rates paid, with APRA chairman Wayne Byres stating that the current floor may be "unnecessarily high" in some cases.

site_title: Spain's richest man bets billions on prime US real estate
summary: Spanish billionaire Amancio Ortega has invested over $3 billion in US real estate in the past six years, increasing his global property empire's value to $13 billion. Ortega's investment vehicle, Arteixo, has completed several major deals, including a $72.5 million purchase of a Chicago hotel and a $1.1 billion acquisition of two Seattle offices leased by Amazon. The economic stability of the US has made it a popular destination for foreign real estate investors, with cross-border acquisitions totaling $94.9 billion last year.

site_title: Three key residential division execs to leave Knight Frank
summary: Three senior executives from Knight Frank's residential business, including Tan Tee Khoon, Alice Tan, and Edison Ong, will leave the firm in June. Tan Tee Khoon, KEO of KF Property Network, will be replaced when his appointment is announced. The exits follow a decline in KF Property Network's agent numbers to 632 from 933 in 2014. The challenge of retaining clients and providing strong manpower is highlighted, with increasing competition from brokerages such as ERA and PropNex in the residential project marketing market. Wendy Tang will oversee the department in the interim.

site_title: Tech stocks take a beating amid Washington's ban against Huawei
summary: Singapore-listed semiconductor firms faced a sell-off amid Washington's ban on Huawei, with AEM Holdings and Hi-P International experiencing significant declines. The ban, despite a temporary US-China truce, has investors concerned about further escalation, potentially leading to higher tariffs. Experts warn that Singapore-listed firms, which have factories and manufacturing facilities in China, could be affected. While some analysts see limited near-term impact, others predict volatility and opportunities to buy on dips, emphasizing the need for further clarity.

site_title: India set to plant more land with soya bean crops as prices rally
summary: India is set to increase soya bean production on more land in the 2019 crop year due to rising prices, which have pushed farmers to switch from cotton and pulses. Higher prices are expected to help trim costly purchases from Brazil and boost Indian exports of soya meal to countries such as Bangladesh and Japan. The shift is expected to benefit farmers, especially in states like Maharashtra and Madhya Pradesh, which could receive lower-than-normal rainfall in 2019.

site_title: Oxley expecting sale completion of Chevron House by first quarter of 2020
summary: OXLEY Holdings expects the completion of the sale of Chevron House by the first quarter of 2020. The 32-storey Raffles Place commercial building will be sold to AEW's investment vehicle Golden Compass for up to S$1.025 billion. The sale includes the assumption of existing bank loans, with Golden Compass paying S$210 million upon the first completion. Oxley will divest retail and banking units "as soon as practicable" before the final completion, with the majority of costs funded by bank loans.

site_title: Business China forum to promote sustainable development
summary: Singapore's 10th FutureChina Global Forum (FCGF) and 9th Business China Awards (BCA) will promote sustainable development and strengthen ties between Singapore and China. The forum, held on June 7, 2019, will feature keynote speakers and discussions on sustainable growth, economic, environmental, and technological challenges amid global geopolitical complexities. The BCA awards will honor individuals and organizations contributing to Singapore-China relations and bilingualism. The event aims to identify growth areas for Singapore businesses and provide a platform for networking and collaboration.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: SATS reported a 5% decline in core net profit to S$248.4 million for Q4 FY2019, down from expectations, due to a 63% decline in associate earnings. The company lowered its FY2020 and FY2021 net profit estimates. Singapore Airlines (SIA) reported a 47.6% year-on-year fall in net profit to S$682.7 million for FY2019, within expectations, but its share price has fallen 9% post Boeing 737 Max 8 grounding. Both companies' results reflect global economic slowdown concerns and weaker air cargo volumes.

site_title: Singdollar to hit 1.40 to USD later this year as trade tensions worsen: analysts
summary: The Singapore dollar is expected to fall to 1.40 per US dollar later this year due to worsening trade tensions between the US and China. The Ministry of Trade and Industry downgraded Singapore's 2019 growth forecast to 1.5-2.5%, citing uncertainties and downside risks. Analysts at Bank of Singapore and DBS predict the SGD/USD pair will weaken, with DBS forecasting a target of 1.40 by 3Q19. A weaker Singapore economy may also lead to a less likely tightening of monetary policy in October, according to analysts.

site_title: Beware trade wars becoming cold wars
summary: The US is on the cusp of a new Cold War with China, with officials, lawmakers, and pundits warning of a global confrontation. This echoes the 1950s Cold War with the Soviet Union, with a focus on containment and competition in economic and military arenas. The Trump administration's China strategy has taken on Cold War attributes, including restrictions on Chinese investment and cooperation, labeling Huawei as a national security threat, and increasing tariffs. The long-term implications of this approach could lead to decoupling of the world's two largest economies, with significant costs for both the US and China, and playing into nationalist sentiments on both sides.

site_title: US temporarily eases trade restrictions on China's Huawei
summary: The US temporarily eased trade restrictions on China's Huawei, granting the company a 90-day licence to buy US goods until August 19 to maintain existing telecoms networks and provide software updates. This move aims to minimize disruption for Huawei's customers, but the company's founder, Ren Zhengfei, said it had little meaning as the company was already prepared for US action. Huawei is still prohibited from buying American-made hardware and software to make new products without further licences. The company is working on its own operating system for mobile handsets and considering alternatives to Google's Android.

site_title: Al Gore's generation raises US$1b for latest private equity fund
summary: Al Gore's investment firm, Generation Investment Management, has raised $1 billion for its third private equity fund, Generation IM Sustainable Solutions Fund III. The fund will invest in companies promoting sustainability, financial inclusion, and healthy living. Founded by Al Gore in 2004, Generation IM manages $22 billion in assets and focuses on sustainable investments. The firm's latest fund aims to capitalize on growing demand for sustainable investments, particularly in Europe.

site_title: Merck to buy Peloton for up to US$2.2b, one day before IPO
summary: Merck & Co agreed to acquire Peloton Therapeutics Inc for up to $2.2 billion in cash and additional payments, just one day before the company's planned initial public offering. Merck will pay $1.05 billion in cash and $1.15 billion in future payments based on the development of Peloton's experimental cancer therapies. The deal offers an immediate payout for Peloton's investors and aims to diversify Merck's cancer treatment offerings.

site_title: Belgian monks resurrect brewery after two century break
summary: Belgian monks at the Grimbergen abbey are reviving a centuries-old tradition of brewing beer after a 200-year hiatus. The abbey's brewery was destroyed by French troops in 1795, but plans have been made to build a new one. The new brewery will revive a tradition dating back to the 13th century, with the phoenix emblem, "Ardet nec consumitur" ("Burned but not destroyed"), serving as a symbol of the revival. The monks aim to recreate the original beer recipes, marking a significant milestone in the abbey's history.

site_title: US: Stocks open higher on Huawei reprieve
summary: US stocks rose on Tuesday, with the Dow gaining 102.44 points, or 0.40%, to 25,782.34, following Washington's temporary easing of trade restrictions on China's Huawei. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, with the Nasdaq gaining 63.19 points, or 0.82%, to 7,765.57. The rebound in technology stocks came after Huawei's restrictions were lifted, lifting investor confidence.

site_title: Chevron House sale to be completed by Q1 of 2020: Oxley
summary: Oxley Holdings expects to complete the sale of Chevron House to AEW's investment vehicle Golden Compass by the first quarter of 2020. The sale includes the 32-storey Raffles Place commercial building and the retail and banking units. The buyer will assume Oxley's existing bank loans totaling up to S$1.025 billion. The developer will fund the majority of the asset enhancement initiative (AEI) costs through bank loans, which will be discharged upon final completion.

site_title: BOJ seeks more accurate measure of Japan's economic growth
summary: The Bank of Japan is considering its own calculation of economic growth to provide a more accurate and timely gauge of the economy's health. This move comes amid concerns over the reliability of Japanese economic statistics, particularly consumption data, which may influence Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's decision on a sales tax increase. The BOJ aims to use supply-side data in its calculation, which could result in higher growth readings and less justification for supporting the economy with limited policy tools.

site_title: Growth fears, trade worries send Singapore shares down 0.7% on Tuesday
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.7% on Tuesday, closing at 3,183.26, due to a missed GDP growth forecast and a lowered growth outlook. The Straits Times Index also weighed on investors' minds amid the ongoing China-US trade war. The market had previously seen a 5-day rally ahead of the GDP data, but the latest news sent prices lower.

site_title: RBI to create specialised supervisory, regulatory cadre
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has decided to create a specialized supervisory and regulatory cadre to strengthen supervision and regulation of commercial banks, urban cooperative banks, and non-banking financial companies. The move comes after reviewing the current supervisory structure and addressing issues in currency management and banker-to-government functions. The decision aims to address the ongoing liquidity crunch in the banking system and the impact of large-scale defaults by IL&FS last year.

images.alt_text: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) said on Tuesday its central board had decided to create a separate supervisory and regulatory cadre within the bank after reviewing the current supervisory structure.

site_title: DBS, AU Optronics sign Taiwan's first sustainability-linked loan
summary: DBS Bank and Taiwanese display manufacturer AU Optronics have signed a three-year, NT$2 billion (S$88 million) sustainability-linked loan, marking the first such loan in Taiwan. The loan is pegged to sustainability performance targets, with the interest rate reduced when AU Optronics meets or exceeds pre-determined ESG criteria. This is the first sustainability-linked loan for a tech company in the Asia-Pacific and follows DBS's trend of offering such loans to corporates, with AU Optronics having an "excellent" performance track record in corporate governance and sustainability.

site_title: Healthtech startup Biofourmis raises US$35m in Series B funding
summary: Healthtech startup Biofourmis has secured US$35 million in Series B funding led by Sequoia India and MassMutual Ventures SEA. The fresh capital will be used to expand operations and enhance products, aiming to increase employee headcount to over 100 in the US and Singapore. Biofourmis utilizes AI-powered platforms and wearable biosensors to manage chronic health conditions, with plans to form partnerships with pharmaceutical companies for distribution and reimbursement. The startup, already working with top US health systems, aims to commercialize its digital therapeutics products akin to prescription medications.

site_title: Nokia CEO admits to delays in rolling out 5G
summary: Nokia CEO Rajeev Suri admitted to delays in rolling out 5G technology, citing the integration of acquired Alcatel-Lucent plans as a reason. The company reported a surprise quarterly loss due to failed 5G equipment supply. Suri stated Nokia is "late in 5G by a few weeks to a couple of months" but remains confident in reaching its annual financial guidance.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish with fresh losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed in negative territory on Tuesday, extending losses fueled by concerns over the Huawei row and its impact on China-US trade talks. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.47% to 27,657.24, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 1.23%. The Shenzhen Composite Index also increased 1.77%. The losses come as investors weigh the implications of the trade tensions and their potential impact on global markets.

site_title: The Taj Mahal becomes first Indian monument with breastfeeding room
summary: The Taj Mahal in India is set to introduce a breastfeeding room, a first for the country due to conservative attitudes towards public breastfeeding. The move aims to support "millions of mothers who visit with their babies." The room is expected to be ready by July and was inspired by a recent observation of a mother struggling to breastfeed under a staircase. This initiative promotes inclusivity and acceptance, challenging traditional norms surrounding public breastfeeding.

site_title: Driving fleets through Singapore's digital revolution
summary: Singapore's fleet landscape is undergoing a digital revolution, driven by the growth of e-commerce and evolving consumer habits. The sector is expected to reach US$5.4 billion by 2025, with asset-sharing services and emerging technologies playing a key role in addressing challenges such as load and route optimisation, accurate delivery scheduling, and last-mile delivery. To remain competitive, fleet companies must adopt more efficient fleet management systems, leveraging technologies like big data and machine learning to optimize demand volatility and supply chain bottlenecks. Collaboration between public, private, and government players is essential for addressing today's fleet challenges and creating a refreshed and efficient approach to fleet management.

site_title: Fullerton Fund Management launches series of multi-asset funds
summary: Fullerton Fund Management has launched a series of multi-asset funds to cater to Singaporeans across various age groups, offering a combination of growth and income. The Fullerton SGD Heritage Funds comprise three funds with varying asset allocations and income payouts. The funds aim to help investors cope with challenges like longevity and rising costs of living and healthcare. With a total of S$48.9 billion in assets under management, the funds have an annual management fee of 0.88-0.98%.

site_title: US existing home sales unexpectedly fall in April
summary: US existing home sales unexpectedly fell 0.4% in April to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.19 million units, missing economists' forecasts. Sales of homes priced under $100,000 dropped 10% from a year ago due to a shortage of available properties. Demand is fueled by lower mortgage rates, while housing supply remains tight, especially at the lower end. Existing home sales have declined for 14 consecutive years, with the median house price increasing 3.6% to $267,300 in April.

site_title: Taste for Western diet reshapes trade in Myanmar
summary: Myanmar has entered the global grain trade with the arrival of a large cargo of American wheat at its newly opened port. The 22,000-tonne shipment from the US was offloaded at the International Bulk Terminal Thilawa near Yangon, marking a significant step for the country's demand for Western food. This purchase may be the first time Myanmar has imported grains in such large amounts at once, with the port planned to handle 1 million tonnes a year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.62 points to 1,603.74. The index saw 1.8 billion lots traded worth RM1.5 billion, with losers beating gainers 603 to 216.

site_title: DuPont plans US$2b share buyback after spin off
summary: DuPont plans a US$2 billion share repurchase program after separating from DowDuPont on June 1, following the spin-offs of Dow Inc. and Corteva Agriscience. As a standalone entity, DuPont aims to grow full-year organic revenue by 2-3% and adjusted operating core earnings by 3-5%. The company plans to focus on its core businesses, including chemicals used in semiconductors, brake fluids, and lubricants.

site_title: Jamie Oliver's UK restaurant chains are headed for insolvency
summary: Jamie Oliver's UK restaurant chains are facing insolvency, with 1,300 jobs at risk. The celebrity chef's company filed for administration in the High Court, affecting 25 Jamie's Italian, Barbecoa, and Fifteen eateries. Oliver's efforts to revive the business, including a company voluntary arrangement last year, were unsuccessful due to a tough consumer market and rising costs. The international division of the business remains unaffected.

site_title: PayPal is backing a German startup to help you save, not spend
summary: German fintech firm Raisin GmbH, backed by PayPal, plans to expand its internet platform for bank-savings products to the US within 12 months. The company, which has brokered over 13 billion euros in customer deposits, aims to increase this to 20 billion euros by the end of 2019 and double it next year. Raisin, founded in 2012, has raised almost $200 million in funding and plans to use the latest round of $100 million to reach profitability within two to three years.

site_title: 'Mother of Satan' bombs show foreign hand in Sri Lanka bombings: investigators
summary: Sri Lankan investigators have found evidence of foreign involvement in the April 21 bombings that killed over 250 people, using "Mother of Satan" explosives favored by the Islamic State group. Local jihadists with Islamic State expertise manufactured the bombs, and international links have been confirmed, with suspects arrested in Qatar and Saudi Arabia. The investigation is ongoing, with authorities checking travel records and bomb-making lessons, and eight countries are providing assistance. The government has admitted to ignoring Indian warnings of the looming attacks.

site_title: Powerstrip producer TrickleStar seeks Catalist listing
summary: TrickleStar Limited, a Malaysian-based energy-saving products producer, has lodged a preliminary prospectus for an initial public offering (IPO) on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board. The company, which posted a revenue of US$12.8 million and net profit of US$2.0 million in 2018, plans to use IPO proceeds to expand its presence in markets, establish new sales channels, and develop new products. The IPO is expected to increase the company's issued and paid-up share capital, with CircleBright Limited and executive chairman Bernard Emby expected to hold significant stakes.

site_title: Pacific Radiance JV gets US$2.78m in HK arbitration for failed vessel delivery
summary: A joint-venture of Pacific Radiance has been awarded approximately US$2.78 million in a Hong Kong arbitration for failing to deliver two platform supply vessels as part of 2013 contracts with Shanghai Waigaoqiao Shipbuilding & Offshore and China Shipbuilding Trading (Shanghai). The award includes a pre-delivery instalment refund and contractual interest. Arbitration for the second vessel is ongoing.

site_title: Kingboard Copper offer closes, company to be delisted
summary: Kingboard Copper Foil's buyout offer has closed with the offeror group owning 98.5% of shares. The offer received valid acceptances of 10.5% of issued shares, following a suspension of trading due to a free float below 10%. The company will be delisted as a result.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks close higher on foreign buying
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index closed higher on Tuesday, with foreigners snapping eight sessions of net selling. The main KOSPI index rose 5.54 points, or 0.27%, to 2,061.25 points, driven by gains in Samsung Electronics. The KOSPI has climbed 0.99% this year and fallen 6.8% in the previous 30 trading sessions. The won was quoted at 1,194.0 per dollar, 0.02% higher than its previous close.

site_title: Activists demand end of Shell, fossil fuel at shareholder meeting
summary: Environmental activists from Code Red disrupted Royal Dutch Shell's shareholder meeting, calling for the company's business model to end due to its role in global warming. The activists, dressed in red, held up banners and jeered at shareholders, while a spokeswoman claimed Shell's business cannot be reconciled with climate change. CEO Ben van Beurden stated the energy industry cannot work alone to combat climate change, and that collaboration with customers, regulators, and policymakers is needed. Shell has set industry-leading targets to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, but the activists argue the company invests too heavily in fossil fuels.

images.alt_text: Environmental activists demonstrate outside the Royal Dutch Shell's annual general shareholder meeting, calling for the end of the use of fossil fuel, in Scheveningen, Netherlands May 21, 2019.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's economy saw a 1.2% growth rate in Q1 2019, its lowest in almost 10 years. The country's 2019 economic growth forecast was downgraded to 1.5-2.5% due to a weak outlook. Non-oil exports are expected to decline 2-0% in 2019, with electronic exports falling 17.2% and non-electronic exports 2.6%. The Singdollar is forecast to hit 1.40 to USD by 3Q19.

images.alt_text: THIS comes as the economy saw growth of 1.2 per cent in the first quarter of 2019 - the lowest growth rate in almost 10 years.

site_title: Singapore, Malaysia to defer Johor Baru-Woodlands RTS Link till Sept 30
summary: Singapore and Malaysia have agreed to defer the construction of the Johor Baru-Woodlands RTS Link until September 30. The six-month suspension will result in Malaysia reimbursing Singapore over S$600,000 in abortive costs. The project's original deadline was December 31, 2024, but it may be revised. The two countries will discuss affordable and sustainable solutions to address traffic congestion at the border, including new technology for enhanced security and checkpoint efficiency.

site_title: Stop it! Japan anti-groper app becomes smash hit
summary: A Tokyo police smartphone app designed to scare off molesters has become a hit in Japan, with over 237,000 downloads. The app, called Digi Police, blasts out a voice shouting "stop it" or produces a full-screen SOS message to alert other passengers. The app's popularity has led to an increase in reported groping cases, with nearly 900 incidents reported in 2017. Experts say the app can help "silent" victims and may contribute to a shift in Japan's traditional bias against reporting such incidents, with some women exchanging tips online to avoid unwanted attention.

images.alt_text: A Tokyo police smartphone app to scare off molesters has become a smash hit in Japan, where women have long run the gauntlet of groping on packed rush-hour trains.

site_title: US's Huawei ban amplifies downside risk on Asian semiconductor cycle
summary: The US's Huawei ban has amplified downside risk on the Asian semiconductor cycle, particularly affecting countries like Malaysia, which relies heavily on China's import demand. Key players such as Google, Intel, and Qualcomm have stopped shipments to Huawei, a major buyer of Asian semiconductor products. This ban could directly hurt ASEAN's semiconductor exports, given China's significant market share. The move highlights the growing tensions between the US and China, which could have far-reaching implications for the global semiconductor industry.

site_title: Australia PM struggles to meet tax relief election pledge
summary: Australia's re-elected coalition is struggling to meet its election pledge of tax relief for tens of millions of voters by July 1, as the central bank calls for stimulus to aid a slowing economy. The Treasury has said parliament may not convene in time to pass the tax legislation, and the Reserve Bank of Australia has urged tax relief to boost household incomes. The government had promised tax rebates worth up to A$1,080 per person to about 10 million middle- and low-income earners, but now plans to deliver the rebates before July 1, 2020.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon at 3,192.65, down 0.4% on day
summary: Singapore stocks declined 0.4% to 3,192.65 as trading resumed, following a weak morning driven by tech stocks' drop on Wall Street amid the US-China trade war. The Straits Times Index dropped 12.81 points, with 212 losers outnumbering 100 gainers.

site_title: Chemicals in consumer goods escaping safety checks, study says
summary: A German environmental lobby, BUND, has found that European consumer goods manufacturers are not properly enforcing safety checks on chemicals in products like clothes and cosmetics. The study, published in 2019, identified hazardous chemicals like dibutyl phthalate and methyl acetate in household goods without proper vetting by the European watchdog. The chemicals can cause hormonal cancers, brain disorders, and other severe impacts, according to BUND. The European Chemicals Agency plans to increase compliance checks, while industry groups acknowledge shortfalls in some studies, and manufacturers are working to address issues.

site_title: Hundreds protest as Indonesia confirms president's re-election
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo has been confirmed to have won re-election with 55.5% of the vote, surpassing his opponent Prabowo Subianto's 44.5%. Widodo won over 85 million votes in the April 17 election, but Prabowo claimed widespread cheating occurred. Approximately 1,000 supporters gathered in a peaceful protest in the capital, Jakarta, amid the controversy.

site_title: Malaysia, flooded with plastic waste, to send back some scrap to source
summary: Malaysia, overwhelmed with non-recyclable plastic waste, will send back contaminated scrap to its source countries, including the US, Britain, and Japan. The move follows a ban on Chinese imports of plastic waste and comes amid concerns over environmental damage and unfair dumping of waste on developing countries. The country has already returned five containers of smuggled waste to Spain and plans to send more next week. The decision aims to hold developed countries responsible for the waste they send out, as part of the Basel Convention, a UN treaty on plastic waste management.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rebound at open
summary: European stock markets rebounded at the start of trading on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.4% and eurozone indices gaining 0.3-0.6%. The rebound comes after markets slumped on Monday due to US concerns over Huawei amid the trade war.

site_title: Panama's worst drought hints at the future of its canal
summary: Panama's worst drought has resulted in lower water levels in the Panama Canal, forcing shippers to limit cargo to safely navigate the waterway. The drought, linked to an El Niño, has led to restrictions on ships using the canal, with the maximum allowable draft reduced five times since February. The restrictions, which will continue through the summer, may become more frequent as climate change is expected to lead to more extreme storms and dry periods. The canal authority is planning to build more reservoirs to mitigate the effects of climate change, but the cost and feasibility of this project are unclear.

site_title: Typical expat pay in Singapore for middle managers rose nearly 6% in 2018: ECA
summary: The average annual pay package for expatriate middle managers in Singapore rose 5.9% in 2018 to US$236,258, driven by a US$5,000 increase in yearly salaries and a US$6,400 rise in benefits. Singapore ranked 19th globally and 9th in Asia for mid-level expats, with low tax-related costs contributing to the high cash salary and benefits. This makes it a favorable location for companies relocating staff, with the UK taking the top spot globally due to a 25% jump in benefits.

site_title: The global diamond glut worsens
summary: De Beers' recent diamond sales fell to the lowest since 2017, with $415 million in gems sold in its fourth sale of the year, down 25% from the previous year. The Anglo American Plc unit's struggles are part of a global diamond glut, affecting miners, especially those producing cheaper gems. Macroeconomic uncertainty, a weak Indian rupee, and stagnant end demand are contributing factors. De Beers has held prices relatively stable but customers are declining to take up stones due to difficulty making a profit.

site_title: Asian market fixed income ETFs saw 'solid returns' over past 12 months: SGX
summary: Asian market fixed income ETFs have produced "solid returns" over the past 12 months, with five listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) tracking major bond market indices across Asia and Singapore markets. Total fund size across these ETFs reached S$1.4 billion in April 2019, with some recording significant returns, including iShares JPMorgan USD Asia Credit Bond at 8.5% and iShares Barclays USD Asia High Yield Bond at 7.1%. The strong performance is partly driven by investors looking beyond the US for opportunities amid a pause in the Fed's interest rate hike.

site_title: For many wealthy Brazilians, Portugal is becoming the new Miami
summary: Wealthy Brazilians are flocking to Portugal, with many choosing the country over Miami as their new hub for business and lifestyle. A booming real estate market and tax breaks are major draws, with a flat income-tax rate of 20% and potential tax-free pension. Brazilian entrepreneur Ricardo Bellino, a multimillionaire, made the move from Miami to Lisbon, citing the opportunity to live in a "tax haven that isn't an island in the Caribbean." This trend is expected to continue as Portugal experiences a revival, making it an attractive destination for wealthy individuals.

site_title: DBS, AU Optronics sign Taiwan's first sustainability-linked loan
summary: DBS Bank Taipei Branch signed a 2 billion New Taiwan dollar (S$88 million) sustainability-linked loan with Taiwanese display manufacturer AU Optronics. This is the first such loan in Taiwan and the first for a tech company in Asia Pacific. The loan pegs the interest rate to sustainability performance targets, demonstrating DBS's commitment to environmental responsibility.

site_title: Nike, Adidas call tariffs on China-made shoes 'catastrophic' in open letter to Trump
summary: US footwear giants Nike, Adidas, and 173 other companies signed an open letter to President Donald Trump, urging him to reconsider tariffs on shoes made in China, calling it "catastrophic" for consumers and the American economy. The proposed tariffs, worth up to $300 billion, would increase the cost of importing shoes to US customers by $7 billion annually, disproportionately affecting working-class individuals. The companies claim they cannot absorb the increased costs and will pass them on to consumers.

site_title: ST Telemedia arm and Frasers Property Thailand to develop 7b baht data centre in Bangkok
summary: ST Telemedia Global Data Centres (STT GDC) and Frasers Property (Thailand) Public Company (FPT) are investing 7 billion baht to build a 60,000 sqm data centre in Ramkhamhaeng, Bangkok. The new centre will be the largest in Thailand, with a gross floor area of 60,000 sqm. The joint venture builds on their partnership announced in April last year.

images.alt_text: ST Telemedia Global Data Centres (STT GDC) and Frasers Property (Thailand) Public Company (FPT) is investing seven billion baht (S$302 million) to build a data centre development in Bangkok.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close down as trade worries resurface
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Tuesday, tracking global market losses due to the China-US trade war, particularly the US decision to sever ties with Chinese tech giant Huawei. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.14% and the Topix index dropped 0.30%. Tech firms were hit hard, with Rohm and Tokyo Electron down 1.16% and 1.87% respectively. Meanwhile, SoftBank Group rallied 3.52% after the US communications regulator announced support for its proposed merger with Sprint and T-Mobile.

site_title: Smart wearables startup KaHa raises US$6.2m in Series B round to accelerate Asia-Pac growth
summary: KaHa, a Singapore-based smart wearables startup, raised US$6.2 million in its Series B funding round led by ICT Fund and an existing European strategic investor. The funds will boost research and development and expand operations in the Asia-Pacific region, particularly in Singapore. KaHa will enhance its IoT platform, Cove, to support health, wellness, sports, safety, and digital payments needs. The startup aims to discover breakthrough products and increase the platform's international availability, accessibility, and affordability.

site_title: Singdollar to hit 1.40 to USD later this year as economy slows: DBS
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to slow, leading to a depreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD) to 1.40 per US dollar by 3Q19, according to DBS Bank FX strategist Philip Wee. The Ministry of Trade and Industry downgraded its growth forecast to 1.5-2.5% in 2019, the lowest in nearly 10 years. This is despite the SGD having only fallen 1.1% year-to-date versus the USD. Wee's forecast has been consistent since January, but is still seen as a possibility due to the economic slowdown.

site_title: Walmart, Target, Bed Bath must face lawsuit over fake 'Egyptian' cotton - NY judge
summary: A US federal judge has ruled that Walmart, Target, and Bed Bath & Beyond must face a lawsuit over selling linens falsely labeled as "100 per cent Egyptian Cotton." The linens, produced by Welspun India Ltd, were sold by the retailers despite being mislabeled. The decision allows New York and California consumers to pursue breach of warranty and negligent misrepresentation claims against the retailers. The lawsuit claims consumers overpaid for the mislabeled cotton, which is often sold at a premium due to its prestige and durability.

site_title: Spaces opens new co-working locations in Somerset and Clarke Quay
summary: SPACES, a co-working provider, has opened two new locations in Singapore: one at TripleOne Somerset with 35,000 sq ft and 135 co-working desks, and another at Clarke Quay with 16,684 sq ft. This brings the total number of locations to four, with plans for two more openings by year-end. The Somerset branch features a blue-chip tenant list and luxury brands, while the Clarke Quay branch offers modern commercial space.

site_title: Vietnam central bank says ready to sell dollars to support dong
summary: Vietnam's central bank, the State Bank of Vietnam, is prepared to sell US dollars to stabilize the dong currency, which has weakened 0.9% this year due to the US-China trade war. The dong has fallen 2.8% from last year, with the recent devaluation of China's yuan putting pressure on the dollar-dong exchange rate. The bank has built up its foreign exchange reserves, and its head of monetary policy said it will closely monitor market conditions and use monetary tools to stabilize the foreign exchange market.

site_title: US airline group sees record summer travel, despite 737 Max grounding
summary: US airline group Airlines for America expects a record 257.4 million passengers between June 1 and Aug 31, a 3.4% increase from last summer's record. Despite the grounding of Boeing's 737 Max aircraft following two fatal crashes, airlines are adding 111,000 seats daily to accommodate the extra passengers. This will be the 10th consecutive summer of increases in US airline passengers, with 93,000 extra passengers expected per day.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on eased home loans, central bank comments
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% on Tuesday, reaching a 12-year high, as mortgage rules were eased to spur borrowing and interest rate cuts were considered. RBA Governor Philip Lowe said the central bank would consider a rate cut in June to support employment growth and meet inflation targets. Financial stocks surged, with the "Big Four" banks gaining 1.5-2.7%, as lenders expected the easing would boost borrowing and combat low house prices. A rate cut is expected in June, according to ANZ.

images.alt_text: Australian shares advanced on Tuesday, boosted by financials after mortgage rules were eased in a bid to spur borrowing and the chance of a June interest rate cut increased.

site_title: Samsung shares surge as Huawei struggles
summary: Samsung shares surged 4.3% on Tuesday after US internet giant Google severed ties with Huawei due to a US executive order. The move could harm Huawei's ability to sell phones outside China, potentially benefiting Samsung, the world's largest smartphone maker. Analysts say the ban will damage Huawei's global market share, allowing Samsung to consolidate its position. Samsung accounted for 23.1% of global smartphone sales in the first quarter, while Huawei had 19.0%. The US ban could also impact Huawei smartphone users, who will no longer have access to Google's proprietary services.

site_title: WH Smith chief Clarke steps down, shares fall
summary: WH Smith Plc announced the departure of CEO Stephen Clarke, effective immediately, as the company reported a 10.2% rise in sales in the third quarter. Managing Director Carl Cowling will replace Clarke as part of a succession plan. Shares fell over 4% in early trading.

site_title: In inland Chinese province, property bubble haunts dreams of prosperity
summary: In Zhengzhou, China, a property bubble has burst, leaving many like Song Jingyi, a 25-year-old paralegal, unable to afford homes due to high prices and downpayment requirements. The market, which boomed in 2016, has slowed down due to government efforts to curb speculation and clean up the financial system. As a result, property prices have dropped, and developers are struggling to sell their inventory. The slowdown has affected not only Zhengzhou but also nearby cities, with many residents passing on buying new developments due to the cooling market.

site_title: Singapore commercial property investment jumps 72% to US$1.9b in Q1; bucks regional downtrend: RCA
summary: Singapore's commercial property investment surged 72% year-over-year to US$1.9 billion in Q1, bucking the regional downtrend. The growth was driven by a diverse range of transactions in retail, office, and industrial sectors. Occupier demand and higher rents allowed investors to lock in higher returns. In contrast, the Asia-Pacific market saw a 36% decline in investment volume to US$30.5 billion, with China and Japan suffering from economic concerns. Despite this, Singapore's commercial property market remains strong, with a record level of capital expected to be deployed in the region this year.

site_title: British Steel on brink of collapse with thousands of jobs at risk -source
summary: British Steel, the UK's second-largest steel producer, is on the brink of collapse due to a £30 million loan shortfall. The company, owned by Greybull Capital, employs around 5,000 people and has tens of thousands more in its supply chain. A loan of £30 million is needed to prevent administrators from being appointed, with a decision expected by Tuesday afternoon. British Steel had previously secured a £120 million government loan, but this was to comply with EU Emissions Trading System rules, not to prevent collapse.

site_title: 2019 growth forecast for Singapore non-oil exports cut to -2 to 0%; fell 6.4% in Q1
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) declined 6.4% in Q1, surpassing the 1.1% drop in Q4 2018. The decline led Enterprise Singapore to revise down its full-year NODX forecast from 0-2% growth to -2.0-0.0%. The agency attributed the growth in total trade to a 4.5% increase in non-oil trade, while oil trade slipped 6.9%. This follows a global trade slowdown forecast by the World Trade Organisation, which expects 2.6% global trade growth for 2019, down from 3.0% in 2018.

site_title: SMU, Citi Ventures to offer fintech experiential learning in Singapore
summary: SMU and Citi Ventures have partnered to offer experiential learning in fintech to SMU undergraduates starting in January 2020. The Cupid programme, launched in the US in 2018, will enable students to apply classroom knowledge to real-world challenges, working on projects leveraging blockchain, machine learning, and AI. This makes SMU the first partner university in Asia for the programme, and aims to develop diverse talent for the fintech sector.

site_title: Asia: Shares off 4-month lows, but Huawei row casts shadow
summary: Asian shares rose 0.35% on Tuesday, but remain near a four-month low, as the US temporarily eased trade restrictions on China's Huawei. The move did little to ease concerns about a tech war, with investors fearing further escalation in tensions. The US S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite fell, while Japanese shares dropped 0.4%.
