Huawei suppliers took a hit, with Qualcomm and Micron Technology falling 6% and 4% respectively. Tensions between the US and China continue to weigh on markets, with investors awaiting corporate earnings guidance that may be impacted by the Huawei ban.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Tuesday, rising 2.56 points to 1,607.92. Volume was 61.1 million lots worth RM25.17 million, with losers beating gainers 90-89.

site_title: Jaguar counts on China recovery to bolster return to profit
summary: Jaguar Land Rover Automotive Plc reported its first profit in four quarters, driven by a turnaround in China. The luxury manufacturer posted a net income of £119 million in the first quarter of 2019, after a record £3.1 billion loss in 2018. Despite the improvement, sales in China fell 46% in April due to a market pullback. Tata Group, the parent company, is exploring strategic options for Jaguar, including a potential stake sale, amid concerns over the brand's long-term viability.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks began trading on Tuesday with losses, following a sell-off on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.42%, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.17%. Investors are concerned about the impact of the Huawei row on tech firms and the ongoing US-China trade talks.

site_title: Wilmar tops Singapore companies for human rights disclosure, second in Asean: study
summary: Wilmar International has taken the top spot among Singapore-listed companies and second place in the overall ASEAN category for human rights disclosure, according to a joint study by the Asean CSR Network, Article 30, and the Institute of Human Rights and Peace Studies of Mahidol University. Sime Darby from Malaysia ranked first with 95% disclosure, while Wilmar scored 90%. The study measured the top 50 publicly listed companies in Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore, the Philippines, and Thailand against the United Nations Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights.

site_title: SGInnovate, RB Capital back AI startup Prowler.io's US$24m funding round
summary: British AI firm Prowler.io has raised US$24 million in a Series B funding round led by SGInnovate and RB Capital, valuing the startup at US$100 million. The funding will support product expansion and growth into various industry verticals, including finance, logistics, and education. Prowler.io's AI platform, VUKU, combines mathematics and economic theory to help organizations make better decisions and process dynamic data. Strategic partners include Tencent, Pearson, and Amadeus Capital Partners, with plans to expand into new markets and implement VUKU in industries such as real estate and ride-sharing.

site_title: Singapore's worst stocks clobber a 187-year-old conglomerate
summary: Singapore's 187-year-old conglomerate Jardine Matheson Holdings Ltd has seen its stock value plummet in 2019, with its two subsidiaries, Dairy Farm International Holdings Ltd and Jardine Cycle & Carriage Ltd, being among the biggest losers in the Straits Times Index. Dairy Farm's profit dropped 77% in 2018, while Cycle & Carriage's profit fell by more than half. The conglomerate's diversified portfolio is not providing enough protection against downswings, with all three companies experiencing similar declines, according to analysts.

site_title: Dressbarn clothing chain is being shuttered after attempted sale
summary: Ascena Retail Group Inc. will shut down its 650-store Dressbarn clothing chain after an attempted sale. The decision comes amid significant losses, over $1 billion in the past four years, due to shifting consumer tastes. The company will wind down the chain, keeping stores open until the process begins, with no timeline given. This marks the end of another retail chain born in the New York area, following the demise of Toys "R" Us in 2018.

site_title: InterDigital expects to be able to license 5G tech to Huawei, despite US ban
summary: InterDigital expects to license its 5G technology to Huawei despite a US ban, as export control laws don't cover patents. The company can continue efforts to strike a deal due to patent records being public and not confidential. Qualcomm, another major patent holder, may also be able to do so, according to trade attorneys. Both companies generate revenue from patent licenses, with Huawei being a major customer, accounting for 14% of InterDigital's revenue in 2017.

site_title: Olam prices US$120m of notes in private placement
summary: Olam International has successfully priced a US$120 million issuance of five-year fixed rate notes via a private placement. The notes were placed to nine investors at a fixed coupon of 3.89% for five years. The proceeds will be used for debt repayment and general corporate purposes. Rabobank acted as the sole placement agent for the transaction.

site_title: BP staff work from home as Greenpeace blockades London HQ
summary: BP staff work from home as Greenpeace blockades London HQ, citing the need for radical action to stop a climate breakdown. The environmental group, Greenpeace, blocked the entrances to BP's London headquarters, forcing employees to work remotely. The protest, which began at 3 a.m., demands that BP end its investment in oil and gas and become a renewable-energy company. Greenpeace will stop protesting if BP meets its demands or chooses to go out of business. BP has supported one of two shareholder resolutions related to climate change at its annual general meeting in Scotland.

site_title: Australia's Lynas lays out A$500m rare earths expansion plan, shares jump
summary: Lynas Corp, a rare earths producer, has unveiled a plan to invest A$500 million to boost production and set up a processing facility in Western Australia by 2025. The company aims to increase production of Neodymium and Praseodymium to 10,500 tonnes a year, driven by demand from electric vehicles. Lynas shares surged 12% to a 5-1/2 month high, citing geopolitics as a key factor, as concerns over Sino-US trade tensions impact global rare earths supply.

site_title: Fears as Chinese investment in Australia falls
summary: Chinese investment in Australia has fallen to its lowest level in five years, with A$4.8 billion invested in the country last year, down 50% from A$9.6 billion in 2017. This decline has sparked concerns about the impact on Australia's economy and its relationship with China. Researchers say the decrease is in line with China's global investment trends, but the Australian government is urged to improve its ties with Beijing to boost investment. The decline marks a significant shift in the country's economic relationship with China.

site_title: Vertex-backed Validus Capital makes key hires
summary: Validus Capital, a peer-to-peer lending platform for SMEs, has appointed Sonal Jain as chief data officer and Arvind Rao as chief technology officer to drive technological innovation and expansion in South-east Asia. The firm has also appointed Vincentius Ivan as head of technology and innovation at Batumbu, its Indonesian arm. With over 15 years of analytics experience and 25 years of global experience in consumer banking, the new hires are expected to play a strategic role in Validus' growth in the region.

images.alt_text: Validus Capital, a peer-to-peer lending platform for small and medium-sized enterprises, has made several key hires as it prepares for further expansion in South-east Asia.

site_title: '.amazon' gives e-commerce giant its own internet domain
summary: Amazon has secured the ".amazon" internet domain after the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) sided with the US e-commerce giant over its long-standing application. The decision comes after years of disagreement with Brazil and other South American countries, who opposed the domain due to its association with the Amazon forest. ICANN has allowed Amazon to proceed with the application, with a public comment period to follow. The move is seen as a major victory for Amazon, allowing it to establish its own online neighborhood.

site_title: Gardens of the future spring up at Chelsea Flower Show
summary: The Chelsea Flower Show in London unveiled innovative gardens of the future to combat climate change. Designer Tom Dixon teamed up with IKEA to create a "Gardening Will Save The World" exhibit, showcasing functional and decorative gardens using hydroponics and aeroponics. The exhibit aims to promote the importance of plants beyond decoration, highlighting their uses in food, ecology, medicine, and therapy. The show features edible plants, a walkable oasis, and a laboratory demonstrating sustainable growing techniques, encouraging visitors to get involved in gardening with minimal know-how and materials.

images.alt_text: Britain's Princess Beatrice of York speaks with garden designer Tom Dixon in his 'Gardening Will Save The World' garden at the Chelsea Flower Show in London, Britain

site_title: Huawei says discussing with Google how to deal with US ban
summary: Huawei founder Ren Zhengfei said the company is discussing with Google how to deal with a US ban on selling or transferring US technology. The ban comes after Google began cutting ties with Huawei due to the ban. Ren described Google as a "highly responsible company" and stated that the two sides are working on a response plan. This move aims to mitigate the impact of the ban on Huawei's Android-powered smartphones.

site_title: Former F1 champion Niki Lauda dies at 70
summary: Former F1 champion Niki Lauda has died at 70, according to his family. Lauda's death comes eight months after he underwent a lung transplant. The statement released by his family said he passed away peacefully with his family on Monday. Lauda was a legendary Formula One driver and the only driver to win the championship three times.

site_title: US judge backs Democrats' request for Trump financial records
summary: US District Judge Amit Mehta denied President Donald Trump's request to quash a subpoena from Democratic lawmakers for years of financial documents, allowing the House Oversight and Reform Committee to proceed with their investigation into Trump's tax returns, finances, and Russian election interference. The judge ruled that the subpoena was valid as it was related to a subject matter on which legislation could be had, citing Article I of the Constitution. Trump's legal team plans to appeal the ruling.

site_title: First Sponsor unit completes acquisition of 60% stake in Guangdong land
summary: First Sponsor's wholly-owned subsidiary, Wenjiang (BVI), has completed its acquisition of 60% of shares in Concord Focus Development, a Singapore-based property developer, for a preliminary price of 404 million yuan (S$81.6 million). The acquisition includes a mixed-use development site in China's Guangdong province. First Sponsor intends to jointly develop the property for residential and commercial use. The remaining 40% of Concord shares was acquired by Masaoka Realty Investment, an unrelated third party.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at Tuesday's open; STI down 0.2% to 3,199.84
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.2% to 3,199.84 at Tuesday's open, following a decline in tech stocks worldwide. The move was triggered by Google's severing ties with Chinese telecom giant Huawei amid the US-China trade war. The Ministry of Trade and Industry downgraded its growth forecast for the year to 1.5-2.5% due to a weak global trade outlook. Banking stocks also slipped, with OCBC, UOB, and DBS losing between 0.3-0.5%.

site_title: Australian regulator to ease mortgage rules in reprieve for banks
summary: Australia's prudential regulator proposed easing mortgage rules, allowing banks to set their own minimum interest rate floors for assessing loan serviceability. The change would remove the current 7% minimum and instead require a 2.5% buffer above the average loan rate. The move is seen as a reprieve for banks, with shares surging in early trade. The easing comes amid a slowing economy and low interest rates, with the regulator citing a "wide gap" between the 7% floor and actual rates paid. A consultation period for the proposed change closes on June 18.

site_title: Interest in granny flats at 'fever pitch' amid US housing crisis
summary: US cities are seeing a surge in interest for accessory dwelling units (ADUs), also known as "granny flats," as a low-cost housing solution amid the country's housing crisis. Washington D.C. has made the process easier, allowing homeowners to build ADUs as a matter of right, and other cities are following suit. The trend is gaining momentum nationwide, with some states considering legislation to further promote ADU construction. Experts see ADUs as a way to address gentrification and provide affordable housing, particularly for low-income communities and families.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower as trade worries resurface
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on May 21, 2019, as investors fretted over the latest China-US trade war flare-up, causing losses in global markets. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 0.42%, while the Topix index fell 0.44%. This decline follows a recent 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and follows US stocks reaching fresh records despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Mike Ashley's Sports Direct divests stake in MySale fashion site
summary: Mike Ashley's Sports Direct International Plc sold its 4.8% stake in MySale Group Plc, an Australian fashion website, after MySale withdrew from the UK market. The sale price was undisclosed, but shares began selling at 7 pence after being valued at 229 pence in 2014. This is another loss for Ashley, following his failed investment in Debenhams UK department store chain, which was taken over by lenders earlier this year.

site_title: Temasek-linked Astrea PE bonds get upgrade, affirmations by Fitch
summary: Fitch Ratings has upgraded and affirmed its ratings for Temasek-linked private equity bonds offered by Astrea III and Astrea IV, citing the strong performance and reserves accounts balances of both transactions. The upgrades reflect the diversified PE portfolios, sufficient over-collateralisation, and close alignment of interests between the sponsors and bondholders. Astrea III's ratings have been upgraded to "A+(sf)" for its US$170 million Class A-2 notes and affirmed at "A+(sf)" for its S$228 million Class A-1 notes. Astrea IV's ratings have been upgraded to "A+(sf)" for its S$242 million Class A-1 notes.

site_title: Huawei founder says US underestimates company, 'can't be isolated'
summary: Huawei founder Ren Zhengfei said the US underestimates the company's strength, despite President Donald Trump's efforts to block Huawei's global ambitions. The US has issued orders to thwart Huawei's business in the US, but Ren stated that Huawei's 5G technology will not be affected and others will struggle to catch up in two or three years. Ren also dismissed the US Commerce Department's 90-day reprieve on the ban on transferring US technology to Huawei, saying the company can make its own chips and "can't be isolated" from the world.

site_title: JCG to acquire 51% of Malaysian medical aesthetics group for up to RM15.3m
summary: JCG Investment Holdings is proposing to acquire 51% of Beverly Wilshire Medical Centre, a Malaysia-based medical aesthetics group, for a minimum of RM13.77 million and up to RM15.3 million by issuing new shares and warrants. Ng Tian Sang, chairman of Beverly Wilshire, will become non-executive chairman of JCG, while his son Howard Ng How Er will be appointed executive director. The acquisition aims to expand JCG's medical aesthetics business into the Malaysian market and provide new revenue streams, as part of its strategic plan to rebuild its health business.

site_title: Oil touches multi-week highs as Opec signals it may extend cuts
summary: Oil prices rose to multi-week highs on Monday, driven by Opec's indication of maintaining production cuts and escalating Middle East tensions. US West Texas Intermediate crude futures reached $63.81, the highest price since May 1, while Brent crude futures touched $73.40, their highest since April 26. Opec+ agreed to cut output by 1.2 million barrels per day for six months to prevent inventory increases. The market remains fragile, with Opec set to meet again on June 25-26 or July 3-4.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Tianjin Zhongxin, Moya Holdings Asia, Mercurius Capital Investment, JCG
summary: Tianjin Zhongxin Pharmaceutical Group received a drug GMP certification for its pharmaceutical products, while Moya Holdings Asia entered into a credit agreement with a lender for up to $25.2 million. Mercurius Capital Investment is in advanced negotiations for a joint venture and business investment, but faces uncertainty regarding its listing status. JCG Investment Holdings proposed acquiring 51% of Beverly Wilshire Medical Centre for a minimum of $4.59 million, with the chairman committing to subscribe for a private placement into JCG.

site_title: Whitney Houston estate working on hologram tour, new album
summary: The Whitney Houston estate has partnered with Primary Wave Music Publishing to revive the late singer's brand. The deal includes a 50% stake in the estate's assets and allows for the development of a hologram tour featuring Houston's likeness, as well as a potential new album of unreleased music. The partnership aims to restore Houston's legacy and reputation, following years of negative publicity surrounding her personal struggles. The hologram tour is seen as the first priority, with branding deals and a potential Broadway musical also in the works.

images.alt_text: The estate of Whitney Houston has struck a deal aiming to revive the late superstar's brand, potentially launching a touring hologram and album of unreleased music.

site_title: EU firms 'caught in crossfire' of US-China trade war
summary: European firms are facing uncertainty due to the US-China trade war, with 23% citing it as a top concern. The trade tensions are seen as a significant obstacle to business, with 45% of firms experiencing a Chinese economic slowdown and 27% citing a global economic slowdown as a concern. Many European companies manufacture products in China, and some have already relocated or plan to do so to circumvent US penalties. The EU Chamber of Commerce in China reports that state firms and their subsidies are the main bone of contention, with 62% of firms saying they have better access to public contracts.

site_title: Eiffel Tower climber grabbed after sparking evacuation
summary: A climber sparked an evacuation of the Eiffel Tower on Monday, clinging to the landmark for over six hours. Emergency teams deployed to the tower and managed to "talk the individual down" after a rappelled fireman made contact. The man, not immediately identified, was grabbed by emergency teams. The tower reopened to visitors early Tuesday, with the incident frustrating tourists who had been planning to visit. The Eiffel Tower is a frequent target for rogue freeclimbers, with previous incidents including a British man who plunged to his death in 2012.

site_title: Ford to cut 7,000 jobs, 10% of global salaried staff
summary: Ford plans to cut 7,000 jobs, or 10% of its global salaried workforce, as part of a reorganization to revamp its vehicle offerings. The downsizing will involve 800 layoffs in North America, with 500 expected this week. The move is part of a shift towards more pickup trucks and SUVs, following a trend in US consumers. The layoffs are expected to be complete by the end of August.

site_title: US: Huawei ban fallout hits Nasdaq as stocks fall
summary: US stocks fell on Monday as the Nasdaq Composite Index dropped 1.5% to 7,702.38, with chip companies hit hard by Google's severing ties with Huawei amid the US-China trade war. The Dow Jones and S&P 500 also declined, with Alphabet shedding 2% and chip companies like Micron Technology and Qualcomm falling. The losses added to a poor stretch for semiconductors, which have lagged the S&P 500 due to the worsening trade war.

site_title: MTI downgrades Singapore's 2019 economic growth forecast to 1.5-2.5 per cent on weak outlook
summary: The Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) downgraded Singapore's 2019 economic growth forecast to 1.5-2.5% due to a weak outlook, following a 1.2% growth rate in the first quarter. This is the lowest growth rate in nearly a decade. The manufacturing sector is expected to slow, while services and construction sectors are expected to remain resilient. The MTI cited global growth uncertainties, including a slower Chinese economy and escalating trade tensions, as contributing factors to the downgrade.

images.alt_text: In a clear signal that Singapore's economic growth is likely to be muted for the rest of 2019, the Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) narrowed its forecast range downwards to 1.5 to 2.5 per cent on Monday morning, from an earlier 1.5 to 3.5 per cent.

site_title: Trump tells ex-White House lawyer to ignore subpoena
summary: US President Donald Trump has instructed his former White House lawyer Don McGhan to ignore a subpoena from the House Judiciary Committee to testify about alleged obstruction of justice. The White House claims a Mueller investigation has cleared Trump of wrongdoing, and the Department of Justice has issued a legal opinion stating McGhan cannot be forced to testify. The move is seen as an attempt to undermine the Democratic-led investigation.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump has told his former White House lawyer Don McGhan to ignore a subpoena from Congress to testify about the president's alleged obstruction of justice, Trump spokeswoman Sarah Sanders said on Monday.

site_title: Google suspends some business with Huawei after Trump blacklist
summary: Google has suspended business with Huawei that requires the transfer of hardware, software, and technical services, except those publicly available via open source licensing. This move follows the US government's efforts to blacklist Huawei globally. However, users of current Huawei smartphones with Google apps will continue to use and download app updates provided by Google.

images.alt_text: Huawei will continue to have access to the version of the Android operating system available through the open source licence but Google will stop providing Huawei with access, technical support and collaboration involving its proprietary apps and services going forward.

site_title: UN concerned about rising US-Iran rhetoric
summary: The United Nations expressed concern over rising rhetoric between the US and Iran, urging both sides to dial down their remarks. Following President Donald Trump's warning of a devastating US response to any Iranian attack, UN spokesman Stephane Dujarric called for a decrease in rhetoric and actions. The US-Iran tensions escalated after the US withdrew from a 2015 nuclear deal and imposed sanctions, with Iran responding to Trump's tweet as "genocidal taunts." UN officials are in contact with both countries to calm the situation.

site_title: Europe: Stocks fall on worries about Huawei fallout
summary: European stocks fell on Monday, with the Euro STOXX 600 down 1.1% and 3.5% for the month, as concerns over a US crackdown on China's Huawei Technologies and worsening global trade ties weighed on tech and auto stocks. The decline was also attributed to a report on Deutsche Bank's alleged ties to US President Donald Trump and his son-in-law. Telecom stocks were the only sector to gain, with Vodafone Group rising 1.7%. The market's volatility gauge jumped, with banks and auto-makers also experiencing losses.

site_title: US tech firms to take hit from Huawei sanctions
summary: US tech firms may face a significant hit from sanctions imposed on Huawei by President Donald Trump, which could affect companies that make components for the Chinese tech giant. American firms sold an estimated $11 billion worth of components to Huawei in 2018, and a ban could effectively ban US hardware and software from being sold to Huawei. Companies like Intel, Qualcomm, and Microsoft could be impacted, while Huawei may accelerate its efforts to develop its own microprocessors and components, potentially driving a shift away from American suppliers.

site_title: US eases some restrictions on China's Huawei to keep mobile networks operating
summary: The US government has eased restrictions on China's Huawei, allowing the company to purchase American-made goods to maintain existing networks and provide software updates to existing Huawei handsets for 90 days. Huawei is still prohibited from buying new American parts and components without license approvals, which are likely to be denied. The move aims to prevent network blackouts and limit unintended impacts on third parties using Huawei equipment.

site_title: Reasons for caution with Japan's unexpected GDP growth
summary: Japan's economy unexpectedly grew 2.1% in the first quarter, but its engine is far from robust. The growth was driven by declining imports and rising inventories, rather than strong exports, capital spending, or private consumption. The economy's pillars of growth declined during the quarter, with exports tumbling 2.4% and household spending falling 0.1%. The government's plan to raise the sales tax in October is being questioned, with some economists warning that it could derail the economy at a time of weakness.

site_title: Oil jumps as Opec signals continued cuts
summary: Oil prices surged as Opec members signaled continued supply cuts, with futures rising 1.7% in New York. Saudi Arabia's energy minister urged members to "stay the course" on output cuts, amid US tensions with Iran and rising sanctions pressure. Oil has rallied 40% this year, driven by supply cuts outweighing demand concerns. Crude prices are expected to remain high due to backwardation, with Brent rising to $73.18 a barrel and WTI reaching $63.81.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand: Shares slip on growing worries over trade war escalation
summary: Australian shares fell 0.3% on Tuesday, following a global slump after the US added Chinese telecom giant Huawei to a trade blacklist. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 16.6 points, as investors worried about a potential escalation in the Sino-US trade war. Mining stocks fell 1.2% to 3.7%, despite record high iron ore prices, while technology stocks plummeted 3.2%. The Reserve Bank of Australia Governor's speech later in the day will be closely watched for clues on an expected interest rate cut.

site_title: Sprint, T-Mobile mega-merger gets nod from key US official
summary: US FCC Chairman Ajit Pai announced support for the proposed $26 billion Sprint-T-Mobile merger, which could lead to final approval from federal authorities. The companies promised to offer a 5G network to 99% of Americans within six years of completion and expand mobile broadband access. The deal still requires review by the US Department of Justice and faces potential anti-trust concerns.

site_title: UK warns over online trading scams
summary: The UK has seen a significant surge in cryptocurrency and foreign exchange-based "get rich quick" scams, with over 1,800 reported cases in 2018/2019, resulting in £27 million in losses. The Financial Conduct Authority and Action Fraud UK have joined forces to raise awareness about the scams, which often promote fake online trading platforms on social media. Authorities warn people to carry out necessary checks to ensure investments are legitimate, after victims lost an average of £14,600 each.

site_title: Thailand on red alert in bid to stop 'lethal pig virus' crossing border
summary: Thailand intensifies efforts to prevent the spread of African swine fever, a lethal pig virus causing widespread outbreaks across Asia. The disease, which kills nearly all infected pigs, has spread from China and Mongolia to Vietnam and Cambodia, resulting in millions of pig culls and global protein shortages. Thailand has tightened inspections, cracked down on illegal slaughterhouses, and imposed stricter reporting requirements, but the risk of introduction remains high due to porous borders and the virus's ability to survive in uncooked meat.

site_title: Nissan's credit rating takes further hit with S&P's negative outlook revision
summary: Nissan's credit rating took a hit with a negative outlook revision by S&P Global Ratings, citing a weaker profit outlook and increased pressure due to the arrest of former chairman Carlos Ghosn. The rating agency lowered Nissan's long-term issuer credit rating to A- from A and placed the company on negative watch. A further decline in profitability is possible, with a one-in-three chance of a delay in profit recovery. Nissan's full-year earnings forecast was reduced, and the company reported its lowest annual profit in a decade.

site_title: France trims graft charges against former Malaysian PM Najib's associate
summary: France has dropped some charges against Abdul Razak Baginda, an associate of former Malaysian PM Najib Razak, in a corruption case related to a submarine deal. Baginda was charged with "active and passive complicity in corruption" and "misappropriation of corporate assets" in 2017. The Paris appeal court dropped the "passive corruption" charge, but retained the other charges. Baginda's lawyer plans to appeal. This development comes as Najib is embroiled in a massive corruption scandal involving the state economic development fund 1MDB in Malaysia.

site_title: Neuberger Berman shrugs off fears regarding junk bond market
summary: Neuberger Berman, a large employee-owned money manager, is dismissing concerns about a potential slowdown in the junk bond market due to global economic fears and trade tensions. Despite US-China trade tensions weakening high-yield debt, the firm's senior portfolio manager, Vivek Bommi, believes the fundamentals of corporate credit remain strong. The market has shown resilience, with global junk bonds returning 6.7% this year, and Neuberger Berman is finding value in bonds from telecom companies with stable earnings.

site_title: India shares hit record high over Modi election victory forecasts
summary: India's shares hit a record high on May 20, 2019, after exit polls indicated a new term for Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Hindu nationalist government. The Bombay Stock Exchange Sensex index gained 3.75% to close at a record 39,352 points, while the Indian rupee strengthened to 69.63 to the US dollar. Most polls predicted the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) would form a government despite losing some seats, with the opposition Congress party expected to double its seats. The election marked a significant end to political uncertainty, with traders citing stability as a vital sign for India's fast-growing economy.

site_title: Google Glass finds a new home at the factory
summary: Google Glass, the computerized eyewear that was initially met with criticism and flopped six years ago, has found a new home at a factory. The product was deemed too awkward and pretentious, leading to its retirement by Alphabet Inc. However, it seems that the timing and market conditions were not right for its debut. The exact details of the new home and its purpose are not specified in the article.

site_title: Huawei ban a salvo in widening US-China standoff
summary: The US has effectively banned Huawei, a move seen as a salvo in the widening US-China standoff. The ban restricts Huawei's US sales and makes it difficult for the company to buy critical US components. The US accuses Huawei of posing a national security and personal privacy risk due to its close ties to China's authoritarian government. This move comes amid tense trade negotiations between the US and China, with President Trump raising tariffs on $200 billion of Chinese goods. The US sees China as a fundamental, long-term threat, rivaling Russia in a global competition.

site_title: Deutsche Bank staff said to flag Trump, Kushner transactions for watchdog: report
summary: Deutsche Bank staff advised US President Donald Trump and his son-in-law Jared Kushner to report suspicious transactions to a federal watchdog in 2016 and 2017, but the reports were never filed. The transactions, involving entities controlled by Trump and Kushner, set off alerts in a computer system designed to detect illicit activity. However, bank executives rejected the advice and the reports were never filed, citing a lax approach to money laundering laws and a desire to protect relationships with lucrative clients. Deutsche Bank has denied the report, stating that investigators were not prevented from escalating suspicious activity.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Bank denied the newspaper report, saying: 'At no time was an investigator prevented from escalating activity identified as potentially suspicious.'

site_title: Jaguar posts first profit in four quarters amid China woes
summary: Jaguar Land Rover (JLR) posted its first profit in four quarters, with a net income of £119 million in the first quarter of 2019, exceeding its previous record loss of £3.1 billion in 2018. Despite struggles in China, where sales tumbled 46% in April, JLR has managed to stabilize its operations. Tata Motors, JLR's Indian parent, is exploring strategic options, including a potential stake sale, but has ruled out selling the luxury brand. The company's shares rose 10% and its bonds gained traction following the positive results.

site_title: US dollar holds firm as market awaits Fed minutes
summary: The US dollar remained firm against a basket of rivals on Monday as investors awaited the release of Federal Reserve minutes, which may provide insight into the Fed's stance on interest rates. The minutes, due on Wednesday, are expected to confirm the Fed's decision to keep rates steady in May. Despite escalating trade tensions, the dollar has found strength as a safe-haven currency, but positioning data suggests this may be temporary. The Australian dollar surged after an unexpected election win by Prime Minister Scott Morrison's conservative coalition.

site_title: Singaporeans must learn to work alongside robots
summary: Singapore must adapt its workforce to work alongside robots as automation replaces tasks rather than jobs. A recent report found that one-third of finance industry jobs will be merged or changed due to automation in the next 3-5 years. To prepare for this shift, Singaporeans need to learn how to work effectively with robots, focusing on value-added work. The government and educational institutions must incorporate skills training into curricula, starting from tertiary education and earlier, to prepare students for the evolving workforce. This will enable Singapore to harness the benefits of automation and create a workforce optimized for human-machine interactions.

site_title: May weighs up plans to keep Brexit deal alive
summary: Theresa May is considering a plan to win support for her Brexit deal from opposition Labour politicians by proposing a tighter customs relationship with the EU. Officials are drafting a new law for a customs-union style arrangement to guarantee no border checks, aiming to appeal to Labour's demands. The move could trigger Cabinet resignations, including from pro-Brexit ministers, and may not be pursued if Labour's Jeremy Corbyn does not abide by the results. May plans to put the Withdrawal Agreement Bill to a vote in Parliament in early June.

site_title: SGX firms report insipid Q1 earnings; nearly one in three posts losses
summary: Singapore-listed companies reported mixed Q1 earnings, with nearly one in three firms posting losses. The combined net profit of 306 companies stood at S$8.45 billion, up 4% from the same period last year. The three major banks boosted earnings, but analysts warn that the April-June quarter could be worse due to the escalating US-China trade war. Experts predict lower loan growth and increased net interest margins, affecting mortgage repricing.

site_title: Luxury goods may go the way of iPhone in China
summary: Luxury goods sales in China may decline due to the escalating US-China trade war. Despite initial resilience, Chinese demand for luxury goods, fueled by pent-up demand in 2015-2016, is expected to slow down. The fragile Chinese economy, industrial output slowdown, and rising house prices have already dampened consumer confidence. As the trade war intensifies, luxury goods, including Gucci and Cartier products, may follow the iPhone's decline in China, with second-order effects potentially damaging growth and consumer confidence.

site_title: Busting myths that discourage SMEs from securing themselves
summary: A recent survey by Chubb and YouGov found that 56% of Singapore SMEs have experienced a cyber attack or error in the past 12 months, despite SMEs being encouraged to take up digitalisation efforts. The Infocomm Media Development Authority's SMEs Go Digital initiative aims to assist SMEs in adopting digital solutions. This trend is particularly concerning given SMEs' significant contribution to Singapore's GDP.

site_title: US business debt a 'moderate' economic risk: Federal Reserve's Powell
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell stated that US private sector debts pose a "moderate" risk to the economy. Corporate debts are at historic highs relative to the economy, with varying opinions on the threat they pose. Powell said the truth lies "somewhere in the middle," indicating a cautious assessment of the economic risk.

images.alt_text: The American private sector's mounting debts pose a "moderate" risk to the world's largest economy, Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell said on Monday.

site_title: CNPC breaks into fuel retailing in Myanmar with Singapore brand
summary: China National Petroleum Corp (CNPC) is entering Myanmar's fuel retail market with its Singapore-based brand SPC, marking the first major foreign investor in the Southeast Asian fuel market. The investment, potentially reaching tens of millions of dollars, follows a similar strategy in Brazil and aims to tap overseas retail margins. CNPC plans to open dozens of petrol stations in Yangon, Mandalay, and Naypyidaw, with a longer-term goal of setting up hundreds of outlets.

images.alt_text: A fuel station in Yangon diplays the bright red logo of SPC, the first venture for the brand outside Singapore.

site_title: China's former top securities regulator under investigation
summary: Former China's top securities regulator, Liu Shiyu, is under investigation for suspected law violations and has turned himself in. Liu, a senior Communist Party official, is cooperating with the probe and was chairman of the China Securities Regulatory Commission for three years before being replaced. He had vowed to crack down on market manipulation and enforcement during his tenure, but two high-profile projects failed to materialise. Liu's cooperation and the probe's findings are part of a broader crackdown on corruption in China's financial regulators under President Xi Jinping's administration.

site_title: UK firms likely to scrap planned investment on a no-deal Brexit: BoE's Broadbent
summary: British companies are likely to cancel projects on hold due to Brexit uncertainty, with uncertainty on the terms of a no-deal Brexit viewed as the most negative outcome. According to Bank of England Deputy Governor Ben Broadbent, Brexit uncertainty has led to a decline in business investment, with companies growing only slightly in early 2019. The UK's Brexit deadline has been delayed to October 31, but Broadbent warns that repeated cliff-edges may be more damaging for investment than a prolonged process. This could lead to further cancellation of investment projects.

images.alt_text: British companies are likely to cancel projects that they have put on hold because of Brexit uncertainty if the country leaves the European Union without a deal to smooth the shock, Bank of England Deputy Governor Ben Broadbent said on Monday.

site_title: Did China break the world economic order?
summary: The US-China trade war has escalated into a full-blown conflict, with the US accusing China of unfair practices, including technology transfer and intellectual property theft. However, experts argue that bilateral trade deficits are a symptom of broader economic issues in the US. China's rapid growth has led to concerns about its impact on the international economic order, with some questioning whether it has broken the rules set up after World War II. The US has imposed tariffs on Chinese goods, but China has made progress in protecting intellectual property rights. The issue is complex, with some arguing that China's growth requires adapting existing norms and regulatory mechanisms.

site_title: A floating life away from the maddening crowd
summary: A growing number of people in the US are turning to houseboats as an affordable alternative to traditional city living. The couple Aislyn Greene and Jeannie Cruz, who bought a $645,000 houseboat in Sausalito, California, found that living on the water reduced their monthly housing costs and provided stunning views and a vibrant social community. While there are challenges to living on a houseboat, including septic tank maintenance and limited living space, many owners, such as Chris Mitchell and Kevin Wright, find the lifestyle to be a great perk, with benefits like being close to nature and having a sense of community.

site_title: Reits to continue providing high returns: Panel
summary: A panel of experts at a symposium agreed that real estate investment trusts (Reits) will continue to provide high returns, but cautioned that Reit managers need to make good, sizeable investments to be accretive to existing portfolios. The challenge lies in balancing risk and returns, as investors should be wary of assets and acquisitions made by Reit managers. Despite this, the panel unanimously agreed that Reits remain a viable investment option in the long run.

site_title: Carrefour considers sale of stake in China business, say sources
summary: Carrefour, Europe's largest retailer, is considering the sale of a minority stake in its loss-making China business, valued at around $1 billion. The company is working with BNP Paribas on the deal and is waiting to assess the level of interest following an auction for Metro's China operations. Carrefour has struggled to fix its China business, which saw a 5.9% decline in sales in 2018, amid fierce competition and a buoyant online market. The company has been expanding into e-commerce and convenience stores in China, but has yet to finalize its partnership with Tencent.

site_title: London office building at post-Brexit referendum high
summary: London's office market is at a three-year high, with 13.2 million square feet of space under construction, a 12% increase from six months ago, according to Deloitte's London Office Crane Survey. The survey found that 55% of office space under construction was already let, with the financial services sector pre-letting 2.1 million sq ft. International Trade Secretary Liam Fox attributed the growth to the city's global pre-eminence as an investment destination, despite Brexit uncertainty.

site_title: Q1 results ended March 2019
summary: SGX firms reported lackluster Q1 earnings, with nearly one-third posting losses. Meanwhile, NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss in H2. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. In other news, Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case, and MAS and PBOC are set to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Air New Zealand picks Boeing for wide-body jet order: sources
summary: Air New Zealand has decided to purchase wide-body planes from Boeing Co, ending an 18-month battle with Airbus SE. The airline is considering replacing eight Boeing 777-200ER aircraft in a deal worth over $2 billion. Air New Zealand's chief financial officer, Jeff McDowall, said the airline is evaluating the Boeing 787 and Airbus A350, with a decision expected within the next month. The airline already operates 13 787-9 jets and has one more on order, and the purchase will likely use discounts from list prices.

site_title: Coal losing power to attract major lenders in last bastion of SE Asia, says Thai tycoon
summary: Thai billionaire Sarath Ratanavadi, founder of Gulf Energy Development Pcl, believes Southeast Asia will no longer support coal power due to environmental concerns. Ratanavadi plans to expand his company's reach into the region using natural gas and renewables, citing the increasing willingness of governments and the public to pay higher electricity costs from cleaner sources. At least 100 major lenders have restricted financing for coal mines and power plants, and some banks are shifting focus to renewable projects. Experts predict the world must abandon coal power by 2050 to avoid catastrophic climate change damage.

site_title: China's mortgage rates slide for first time since 2016
summary: China's mortgage interest rate dropped to 5.68% in March, the first decline since 2016, as the central bank aims to stimulate the housing market. The rate decrease is part of the government's efforts to provide easier credit to certain sectors of the economy. This move is expected to boost demand for home appliances and other products, contributing to a relatively heavy reliance on property and infrastructure investment.

site_title: Wiselink focuses on the future
summary: Wiselink Technology, a Singapore-based electronic components distributor, has implemented an automated data processing system to improve its productivity. The system analyzes data on available stock and customer buying patterns to provide purchasing recommendations. This has reduced paperwork for staff and enabled the company to manage its production schedule effectively. Wiselink has also received recognition as the Top Distributor in Asia by Riedon Inc and has been awarded the Enterprise 50 and five-year awards. The company believes its focus on relationships and precision in high-demand fields such as aerospace and medicine sets it apart from larger competitors.

images.alt_text: Ms Lim says that distribution is like a relationship business, where distributors often serve as the link between customers and manufacturers. Hence, Wiselink believes in having a good relationship with its customers.

site_title: US warship sails in disputed South China Sea amid trade tensions
summary: The US destroyer Preble sailed near the disputed Scarborough Shoal in the South China Sea on May 19, 2019, challenging China's excessive maritime claims and preserving access to international waters. This move, part of a growing series of US operations in the region, is likely to anger Beijing amid tense trade relations between the US and China. The US military asserts its operations are separate from political considerations and aim to counter China's efforts to limit freedom of navigation in the strategic waters.

site_title: Clean floating is out, dirty is in for emerging markets
summary: The Bank for International Settlements (BIS) is reevaluating the traditional orthodoxy of exchange-rate management for emerging economies. Current practice of letting currencies float freely has proven ineffective due to the negative impact of currency depreciations on domestic financial conditions. Research by the BIS shows that a depreciating exchange rate leads to widening sovereign interest-rate spreads and can cause financial instability. In response, central banks are considering modifying their monetary policies to include exchange-rate considerations and implementing sterilized exchange-market intervention to stabilize currencies.

site_title: John Wick 3 knocks Avengers off the box office perch
summary: John Wick 3: Chapter 3 - Parabellum opened with a global start of $92 million, surpassing Avengers: Endgame's three-week box office reign. The action franchise's third installment debuted with $57 million from North American locations and $35 million from international markets. John Wick 3 opened above its predecessors and hit a franchise record overseas, while Avengers: Endgame slid to second place with $29.4 million. The film's success marks a much-needed win for Lionsgate, which suffered a string of disappointments with its recent releases.

site_title: Goldman Sachs in talks to buy B&B Hotels for 2b euros
summary: Goldman Sachs is in exclusive talks to buy the B&B Hotels chain from European buyout firm PAI Partners for approximately 2 billion euros. The deal, expected to close in the second half of 2019, marks a significant expansion for Goldman's merchant banking division. B&B Hotels has over 486 hotels in Europe, Brazil, and Morocco, with 580 million euros in revenue last year. The deal follows PAI's purchase of B&B in 2016 for 790 million euros. Financial details are not disclosed at this time.

site_title: Schumer asks US govt to probe rail tech from China
summary: US Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer is requesting an investigation into whether a Chinese state-owned firm's plan for new subway cars in New York City poses a threat to national security. The company, CRRC Corp Ltd, won a design contest for the project and plans to install new technology in the New York subway system. Schumer is concerned about potential security risks, citing recent cyberattacks on transportation hubs. The investigation comes amid increased tensions between the US and China, with the Trump administration adding Huawei Technologies Co Ltd to a trade blacklist.

images.alt_text: The Department of Commerce must "thoroughly check any proposals or work China's CRRC does on behalf of the New York subway system, including our signals, Wi-Fi and more", says Mr Schumer.

site_title: Gold hits 2-week low as dollar eclipses metal's safe-haven appeal
summary: Gold prices fell to a two-week low on Monday, trading at $1,274.39 per ounce, as the US dollar gained safe-haven appeal amid strong economic data and rekindled trade tensions. The dollar index rose to its highest level since early March, while US consumer sentiment reached a 15-year high. Analysts attribute the dollar's surge to its safe-haven status, which is taking away from gold's appeal.

site_title: Money FM symposium to discuss challenges to jobs
summary: MONEY FM 89.3 is organizing a symposium, "Spotlight: Career Disputed," on June 1 to discuss challenges to jobs in Singapore. Speakers will include National Trades Union Congress assistant secretary-general Patrick Tay, Zainal Abidin Ahmad, and headhunter Jaime Lim, who will discuss the future of work, workplace literacy skills, and developing future-ready skills to boost employability. The event aims to make sense of career disruption caused by technological advancements, the gig economy, and Industry 4.0, with the goal of helping workers adapt to changing workplace demands.

site_title: Morrison has job cut out managing Australian economy
summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison's narrow victory over the Labor Party should serve as a reminder of the unpredictability of opinion polls. Morrison will face major economic challenges, including a potentially deflationary spiral and stagnant wages. House prices are falling, particularly in Sydney and Melbourne, and wages have stagnated. The jobless rate is estimated to be higher than 5%, with a significant under-employment problem. Morrison's government may need to cut taxes, spend more on infrastructure, and provide higher pensions, but conservatives are hesitant to borrow and maintain a balanced budget.

site_title: Ryanair profit hits 4-year low; CEO warns of further pain
summary: Ryanair reported its weakest annual profit in four years, with after-tax profits falling to 1.02 billion euros from 1.45 billion euros the previous year. The airline's CEO, Michael O'Leary, warned of further pain due to "attritional fare wars" in Europe. Shares fell 6% after the profit forecast was missed, following two previous profit warnings. This marks a significant decline from the previous year's profit.

site_title: Uber and Lyft: Lessons from lacklustre IPOs
summary: Uber and Lyft, two ride-hailing giants, recently went public with impressive valuations but underwhelming stock performances. Uber's IPO saw its stock plummet 17% in value, while Lyft's stock dropped 34%. Despite posting significant revenue and user growth, both companies have struggled to turn a profit, relying on private funding to stay afloat. The lesson for investors and budding tech unicorns is that profitability matters, and a unique proposition is crucial for long-term success, as seen in the case of Beyond Meat, a loss-making company that has rallied since its IPO.

site_title: Indonesian unicorn teams up with Singapore logistics startup
summary: Indonesian e-commerce unicorn Bukalapak has partnered with Singapore startup Janio for cross-border logistics, allowing consumers from Singapore and other countries to buy products from Indonesian merchants. This move is part of Bukalapak's plan to go global. The company is also in talks with Singapore's Economic Development Board to potentially open an office in the country.

images.alt_text: Mr Rasyid says BukaGlobal is also designed to address regional logistics challenges faced by Indonesian businesses. This includes the high costs of delivery and effort spent on dealing with customs.

site_title: Mercurius Capital Investment 'in advanced talks' for possible investment
summary: Mercurius Capital Investment is in advanced talks for a joint venture and business investment, with a possible investment deal. The company has applied to the Singapore Exchange for an extension of the deadline to demonstrate a viable business, and its shares will resume trading on Tuesday. There is no certainty yet that the Exchange will approve its application, and the company has called for its trading halt to be lifted. The company will update shareholders when there are material developments.

site_title: Lippo Karawaci CEO wants LMIRT to own more non-Lippo assets
summary: Lippo Karawaci CEO John Riady expressed his desire for the two real estate investment trusts (Reits) his company sponsors, LMIRT and First Reit, to own more non-Lippo assets. He believes that acquiring sponsor assets should be a secondary purpose, with the primary goal of maximizing the value of the Reits themselves. Riady hopes to see LMIRT acquire a quarter of its portfolio comprising non-Lippo Indonesian malls, and notes that the Reits' ability to grow through third-party acquisitions will lead to a higher quality portfolio, resulting in higher prices and lower yields.

site_title: Burning cash is strategy of choice for China's Starbucks rival
summary: Luckin Coffee, China's Starbucks rival, successfully raised US$561 million in its IPO, exceeding expectations. The company's aggressive expansion plan, which includes burning cash to quickly grab market share, has impressed American investors. Luckin aims to overtake Starbucks in the US$5.8 billion Chinese coffee market, which is still in its initial stage. However, some investors question the company's sustainability, citing negative restaurant margins and a lack of prestige compared to Starbucks. Luckin's strategy, which includes offering free coffee and discounts, is similar to its previous car rental venture.

site_title: Search for yield sparks surge in emerging market bonds
summary: Global investors have poured money into emerging market bonds, with $3.8 trillion issued between 2010 and 2019. Asia-Pacific borrowers accounted for over half of these issues, with China, Russia, and Brazil being the top borrowers. Moody's rates 1,660 issuers from 71 EM countries, with 59% of non-financial corporate issuers classified as high yield. Despite growing economies, Moody's warns of uneven global economic stress through 2020, citing risks such as slower growth, variable market sentiment, and geopolitical risks.

site_title: Trade uncertainty darkens US small caps outlook
summary: US small-cap stocks have fallen 5.4% since President Trump's May 5 tweets about raising tariffs on Chinese goods, with the Russell 2000 small cap index declining 4.9% compared to the S&P 500's 2.9% drop. Analysts expect a first-quarter earnings recession for the S&P 600 index of small cap stocks, with a 9% second-quarter decline predicted. A prolonged US-China trade dispute could worsen the outlook, with traders betting on weaker US economic growth and traders making bets that imply a decline in consumer spending and capital spending.

site_title: Moya gives unit corporate guarantee for 265b rupiah banking facility
summary: Moya Holdings Asia's subsidiary, Air Semarang Barat, has secured a 265 billion rupiah (S$25.2 million) banking facility through a credit agreement, backed by a corporate guarantee from Moya. The loan covenant requires Air Semarang Barat to immediately prepay any outstanding amounts in the event of a change of ownership of Moya. This is part of a broader risk management strategy, with Tamaris Infrastructure, the majority owner of Moya, having previously entered into a share pledge arrangement to secure another banking facility from OCBC Bank.

site_title: Indian: Stocks, rupee rally as Modi vote win predicted
summary: Indian stocks and the rupee surged on Monday as exit polls predicted a second term for Prime Minister Narendra Modi, with the Bombay Stock Exchange Sensex index surging over 2% and the rupee trading at 69.49 per dollar. The official vote count is set to begin on Thursday. This follows Modi's business-friendly platform in 2014, despite criticism of his economic record since. The predicted win is seen as a positive sign for the Indian market.

site_title: Top US tech firms begin to cut off supply of critical components to Huawei
summary: Top US tech firms, including Intel, Qualcomm, Xilinx, and Broadcom, have cut off supply of critical components to Huawei, a move that is disrupting the global supply chain and impacting the world's largest provider of networking gear. Google has also suspended some business with Huawei. The Trump administration's blacklisting of Huawei has led to a ripple effect across the global semiconductor industry, potentially delaying the rollout of 5G wireless networks worldwide. Huawei has stockpiled enough components to keep its business running for at least three months, but its executives believe it has become a bargaining chip in US-China trade negotiations.

site_title: Sony's deal with Microsoft blindsided its own PlayStation team
summary: Sony's cloud gaming pact with Microsoft has blindsided its own PlayStation team, who have spent years fighting the US software giant in the $38 billion video game console market. The companies announced a strategic partnership to co-develop game streaming technology and host some of PlayStation's online services on Microsoft's Azure cloud platform. This comes after PlayStation developed its own cloud gaming offering with limited success. The move may indicate a shift in Sony's strategy, but the reasons behind the partnership remain unclear. The deal is seen as a surprise to the industry, leaving employees of Sony's PlayStation division reeling.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher after GDP beats expectations
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday after Japan's economy grew 0.5% in the first quarter, beating expectations. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.74% and the Topix index rose 0.52% amid concerns over the US-China trade row and US auto tariffs. Analysts consider these issues neutral for now, with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe potentially calling a snap general election to boost economic growth.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start with small gain
summary: Hong Kong stocks started with a small gain on Monday, edging up 0.05% to 27,959.23, following gains across Asia. Energy firms were among the big winners due to a jump in oil prices. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index declined 0.26% and 0.21% respectively.

site_title: Ex-YuuZoo staff file claims for unpaid salaries
summary: Former employees of YuuZooNow! Pte Ltd in Singapore have filed claims against the company for unpaid salaries, with about 10 people seeking mediation through the Tripartite Alliance for Dispute Management. A former general counsel and head of legal is claiming S$37,090 for unpaid salary from January 1, 2019 to April 2, 2019. The company, which was founded in 2008, has been under investigation by the Singapore Police Force's Commercial Affairs Department and has its shares suspended due to financial issues, including a 12-month net loss of S$101 million.

site_title: South Korea automakers' shares rise on hope of US tariff exemption
summary: South Korean automakers' shares rose on Monday due to optimism over potential exemption from US import tariffs on vehicles deemed a threat to national security. Hyundai and Kia shares increased by nearly 3% after US President Donald Trump mentioned a revised trade deal could address concerns. Toyota shares were nearly flat, while Nissan shares fell 1.6%. The US president's delay in imposing tariffs for up to six months has given South Korean automakers hope, with Seoul's finance minister vowing to continue efforts to persuade the US not to impose tariffs.

site_title: A US$19b test is coming straight for China's battered yuan
summary: A US$19 billion test is coming for China's battered yuan, with offshore-listed Chinese firms selling yuan to buy foreign currencies and fund their US$18.8 billion dividend bill due from June to August. The yuan is at its weakest this year, with speculation mounting that it will fall to 7 per dollar, a key psychological level. The US trade dispute has put the yuan under pressure, and China's central bank may weaken the currency to offset the blow from tariffs. The offshore yuan has dropped 2.9% in May, and pressure on the yuan may build before July's peak dividend payouts.

site_title: New Lippo Karawaci CEO to improve management, governance
summary: Lippo Karawaci's newly appointed CEO, John Riady, aims to improve management and governance after an alleged bribery investigation linked to the Meikarta development project. Riady cited this incident as a driving factor in his efforts to overhaul the company. He also mentioned that he will take steps to address governance issues. The move comes after the company denied involvement in the bribery allegations. Riady's goal is to "clean house" and improve the firm's management and governance.

site_title: Tokyo's Olympic Village condos to become apartments
summary: Tokyo's Olympic Village condominiums, built for athletes during the 2020 Tokyo Olympics, will be converted into apartments after the Games. Applications for ownership will be accepted in late July, with sales prices ranging from 50 million to over 100 million yen (S$625,663) per unit. The units, designed with larger spaces and higher ceilings, will be sold by major real estate companies in phases, potentially affecting prices of other condominium units in the market. The conversion aims to create a town complex called Harumi Flag with 24 buildings and 5,632 units.

site_title: Indonesian e-commerce unicorn kickstarts global expansion
summary: Indonesian e-commerce unicorn Bukalapak has launched BukaGlobal, allowing consumers from Singapore, Malaysia, Brunei, Hong Kong, and Taiwan to purchase products from Indonesian merchants through the Bukalapak platform. This marks the company's international expansion, with backing from Singapore's GIC and Indonesian telecoms conglomerate Emtek. The move aims to capture the growing middle-class consumer population in South-east Asia, capitalizing on the region's growing e-commerce market.

site_title: Japan's economy grew 0.5% in first quarter
summary: Japan's economy expanded 0.5% in the first quarter, beating analyst expectations. The growth was driven by net exports, but consumption and corporate investment remained weak. The result defies gloomy forecasts and may lead to a postponement of a planned sales tax hike. However, the data also suggests the economy may have entered a recession, with the key economic indicator showing the Japanese economy was "worsening" for the first time in over six years.

site_title: Australia: Shares rally on surprise conservative election win
summary: Australian stocks surged on Monday, reaching an 11-year high, after conservative coalition parties won the election. The benchmark S&P/ASX 200 index rose 1.7%, driven by gains in banks, property, and health-related stocks. Shares of Commonwealth Bank, Westpac, and Medibank Private jumped 6-10%. The Australian dollar also rose, while markets expect the Reserve Bank of Australia to cut interest rates in the next few months. Prime Minister Scott Morrison's coalition won 75 seats, one short of a majority, with investors relieved that uncertainty has been removed.

site_title: Tianjin Zhongxin gets GMP certification for herbal medicinal slices
summary: Tianjin Zhongxin Pharmaceutical Group announced that its wholly-owned subsidiary, Tianjin Darentang (Bozhou) Chinese Herbal Medicinal Slices, has received a certificate of good manufacturing practices (GMP) from the Anhui Medical Products Administration. The GMP certification allows the company to manufacture 500 different products, meeting market demand. This certification is expected to expand the company's market share in China's traditional Chinese medicine herbal slices market.

site_title: SGX Bull Charge Golf event raises record S$770,000 for charity
summary: SGX's Bull Charge Golf event raised a record S$770,000 for charity, surpassing last year's S$600,000. The event, now in its seventh year, brought together 140 social golfers and attracted 200 attendees at an eight-course dinner. Corporate sponsors, including Sasseur Reit, donated S$300,000, the largest single donation to SGX's charity initiative in recent years. The funds will be distributed among five charities, benefiting underprivileged children, families, persons with disabilities, and the elderly.

site_title: Asia: Most markets up but trade row rumbles on
summary: Most Asian markets rose on Monday, with Sydney leading gains, as investors cautiously welcomed signs of conciliation in the US-China trade war. Despite Trump's recent actions, including a six-month delay on tariffs, markets are still on edge. The pound fell to four-month lows due to growing fears of a no-deal Brexit. Global markets have been volatile for two weeks, with some markets ending in positive territory, while others, such as Hong Kong and Shanghai, fell.

site_title: Brexit Party rises as Tory and Labour lose ground
summary: Nigel Farage's Brexit Party is on track to win the European Parliament elections in the UK, potentially becoming the second non-Conservative or Labour party to win a nationwide UK ballot in over a century. Polls indicate that both major parties, the Conservatives and Labour, will lose seats compared to the 2014 elections. This shift could reverse the results of the 2017 General Election, where the two parties combined for over 80% of the vote. The Brexit Party's success would put pressure on Prime Minister Theresa May.

site_title: PODCAST: Saving for key life goals in your early 20s (Money Hacks, Ep 43)
summary: In the podcast "Saving for key life goals in your early 20s" (Money Hacks, Ep 43), hosted by Chris Lim, 19-year-old Lim Li Shian and Vasu Menon, OCBC Bank's senior investment strategist, discuss saving for life goals. A survey found that 75% of young adults prioritize travel, life experiences, and maintaining relevant skills. Chris Lim uses Frank by OCBC's Savings Goals calculator to show how to set aside money each month for immediate goals, and advises against borrowing for short-term goals. The conversation also touches on medium-term goals like owning a car.

site_title: Bomb blast hits tourist bus near Egypt pyramids
summary: A bomb blast hit a tourist bus near Egypt's Giza pyramids on Sunday, injuring 17 people, including South Africans, in a roadside explosion. The incident occurred as the bus was being driven through the area, also injuring Egyptians in a nearby car. No deaths were reported. The attack is the latest blow to Egypt's tourism industry, which has faced security concerns in recent years.

site_title: Saudi Arabia says it seeks to avert war, ball in Iran's court
summary: Saudi Arabia seeks to avoid war in the region, but stands ready to respond with "all strength" following attacks on its oil assets and vessels in the UAE. Iran denies involvement in the operations, while the US Navy increases security patrols in the Arabian Gulf. Saudi Arabia's King Salman invites Gulf and Arab leaders to emergency summits to discuss the attacks, with the US and Iran engaging in heightened tensions over sanctions and military presence. The ball is in Iran's court, according to Saudi Arabia's Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, Adel al-Jubeir.

site_title: Google suspends some business with Huawei after Trump blacklist: Reuters
summary: Google has suspended business with Huawei, excluding open-source licensing, due to the US government's blacklist of the Chinese tech giant. This move affects Huawei's smartphone business outside China, as it will lose access to updates to Google's Android operating system and popular services like the Google Play Store and Gmail. Huawei will only use the public version of Android, without proprietary apps and services from Google.

site_title: DBS, OCBC lead buybacks with new mandates
summary: DBS and OCBC led buybacks with a total consideration of S$24.9 million over five trading sessions, more than double the previous period. The STI declined 1.2% during the period, with the Nikkei 225 Index, Hang Seng Index, and S&P/ASX 200 Index also experiencing a 0.3% decline. This brings the STI's 2019 total return to 7%.

site_title: US to hold economic conference in June to seek boost for Palestinians
summary: The US will hold an international economic "workshop" in Bahrain in late June to encourage investment in the Palestinian areas as part of President Trump's Middle East peace plan. The conference aims to jump-start the economic portion of the plan, which also includes proposals for resolving the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. However, Palestinian officials have rejected the US effort, citing bias in favor of Israel. The workshop is expected to bring together government and business leaders to promote economic development in the region.

images.alt_text: Mr Trump's Middle East team, led by his son-in-law Jared Kushner (pictured) and regional envoy Jason Greenblatt, appears intent on focusing initially on the potential economic benefits, despite deep skepticism among experts that they can succeed where decades of US-backed efforts have failed.

site_title: China's CNPC breaks into Myanmar fuel retailing with Singapore brand
summary: China National Petroleum Corp (CNPC) plans to open dozens of petrol stations in Myanmar, marking the first major foreign investor in the country's fuel market. The investment, potentially reaching tens of millions of dollars, follows a strategy to tap overseas retail margins as China's domestic fuel market becomes saturated. CNPC sees Myanmar as a prime frontier market for fuel retailing, where demand is growing at 10% annually. The company's first station in Myanmar bears the Singapore brand, Singapore Petroleum Company (SPC), due to its strong presence in the region.

images.alt_text: China National Petroleum Corp is planning to open dozens of petrol stations in Myanmar, the first major foreign investor to enter the fast-growing South-east Asian fuel market, as the state giant expands its retail oil business, company officials said.

site_title: Australian dollar gains after election surprise, yen slips
summary: The Australian dollar gained against the greenback following a surprise election victory by the country's conservative government, with the Aussie rising 0.5% to A$0.6904. The yen slipped 0.1% to 110.195 due to improved risk appetite among investors, despite Japan's economy showing stronger-than-expected growth in the last quarter. The dollar index was steady at 97.970, while the euro recovered slightly to $1.1161 after a drop last week.

site_title: Australia's shock election shows killing coal mining is no sure thing: Russell
summary: Australia's opposition Labor Party lost the election, but the anti-coal environmental lobby suffered a significant setback. The Liberal Party-led coalition, led by Prime Minister Scott Morrison, secured a third term despite not securing an outright majority. Labor leader Bill Shorten's party was predicted to win, but results indicated they would have no chance of victory. This outcome will force the anti-coal lobby to reassess their strategy to end coal mining in Australia.

images.alt_text: The conservative Liberal Party-led coalition is likely to have pulled off one of the great political escapes by returning to office for a third term, confounding polls and pundits who thought Labor was a near certainty to win the May 18 election.

site_title: Startup making paper from rock seeks more pre-IPO funding
summary: TBM Co, a Japanese startup, is seeking additional funding to expand overseas before its planned initial public offering (IPO) in 2021. The company, known for its limestone-based paper product Limex, has already secured investments from Goldman Sachs and Toppan Printing Co. TBM aims to establish partnerships and hire more staff to achieve revenue growth of at least fivefold in the coming year. The company's valuation has increased to 56.3 billion yen, and it plans to produce 30,000 tons of Limex products per year starting in 2020.

site_title: Opec shows intention to keep oil supply constrained all year
summary: Saudi Arabia and other Opec members pledged to keep oil supplies constrained for the rest of the year, preventing genuine shortages. However, Russian Energy Minister Alexander Novak expressed openness to relaxing production cuts if demand grows. The decision is uncertain, with the production cuts set to expire in June and the Opec+ coalition focusing on managing inventories and keeping supply and demand in balance.

images.alt_text: Saudi Arabia and other key producers in Opec signalled their intention to keep oil supplies constrained for the rest of the year, while pledging to prevent any genuine shortages.

site_title: Shape your business around customer desires: sgsme.sg seminar panellists
summary: Panellists from Razer and Luxasia emphasized the importance of putting customers at the heart of businesses and being laser-focused on core products. Companies must pivot when needed, communicating compelling reasons for changes to executive staff to ensure a smooth transition. The key to sustaining growth is the courage to take forward-thinking steps, while avoiding distractions from trends.

site_title: 'Our watch is ended': It's a wrap for Game of Thrones
summary: Game of Thrones concludes after eight years with its final episode airing Sunday, bringing an end to the highly anticipated series. The finale, directed by Dan Weiss and David Benioff, has been met with both excitement and controversy, with critics and fans divided over the show's portrayal of violence, sex, and female characters. Despite criticism, the series has achieved numerous records, including 47 Emmy Awards and a budget of $15 million per episode. The fate of the Iron Throne remains a mystery, leaving fans eagerly awaiting the conclusion of George R.R. Martin's novels.

site_title: Digital is the key to success in ASEAN banking
summary: ASEAN's digital economy is a rapidly growing force, with a projected $240 billion internet economy by 2025, fueled by a digitally-savvy population and wealth creation. Digital banking is key to success, with banks needing to adapt to changing customer behaviors and preferences. Citi's transformation journey in the region includes digitizing processes, developing digital solutions, and distributing products through digital channels. Digital partnerships are also crucial, with Citi partnering with global and local digital players to offer a superior digital banking experience. The region's fintech sector is also enabling accessibility to financial services, promoting financial inclusion.

site_title: Trade spat continues to dictate market sentiment
summary: US-China trade tensions continue to drive market sentiment, with recent tariff measures and executive orders from President Trump affecting regional and local markets. The US Commerce Department added Huawei to a trade blacklist, while US companies are barred from using the telecommunications equipment. Markets are also impacted by corporate earnings reports, including NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer being oversubscribed 9.8 times. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks experience a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Oil producers meet to discuss output amid Iran tension
summary: Major crude producers met in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, to discuss stabilizing a volatile oil market amid rising US-Iran tensions in the Gulf. The meeting, attended by Opec+ members and Russia, focused on Iran's reduced crude exports due to US sanctions and sabotage attacks on tankers and a pipeline. The group assessed compliance with production cuts and discussed potential increases, but exporters fear a rush could trigger a new supply glut. Saudi Arabia emphasized its readiness to defend its interests without seeking war with Iran.

site_title: Treat Facebook the same way as vices like tobacco
summary: Facebook's addictive nature, similar to vices like tobacco and gambling, warrants regulation akin to those industries. The social media giant's influence over society has sparked calls for government intervention, with co-founder Chris Hughes and Senator Elizabeth Warren advocating for its break-up. Regulating Facebook like tobacco companies, which disclose their products and undergo public scrutiny, could curb its harm. This approach would protect youth, reduce dependence on the platform, and increase transparency, ultimately reducing the industry's negative impact on society.

site_title: Consumer survey finds Thais and Indonesians in upbeat mood
summary: A consumer survey by Credit Suisse Research Institute found Thai consumers to be in an upbeat mood, despite economic indicators being muted. 17% of respondents expect an improvement in personal finances, and 63% think it's a good time to make a major purchase. In Indonesia, a higher percentage of consumers plan property and car purchases, with a focus on personal appearance and spending on fashion, cosmetics, and skincare. The survey also showed positive consumer sentiment in Latin America, with Brazil and Mexico recording the highest levels of confidence in personal financial outlook.

site_title: Global dividends hit record in first quarter as companies shake off macro worries
summary: Global dividends reached a record $263.3 billion in the first quarter, up 7.8% from the same period last year, according to a report. This growth matches last year's and pushes the Janus Henderson global dividend index to an all-time high. The increase is seen as a sign of companies' growing optimism despite global economic and earnings growth concerns, and equities' continued appeal amidst trade tensions and economic slowdown worries.
