US officials plan to continue talks, but China seems unwilling to engage.

site_title: IMDA seeks feedback on spectrum allocation for enterprise and public mobile use
summary: The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) is seeking public feedback on spectrum allocation for enterprise and public mobile use in Singapore. Key areas include allocating dedicated spectrum in the 800 MHz and 1900 MHz bands to enterprise users and assigning the 2100 MHz spectrum for both 3G and 4G services. The goal is to optimally allocate scarce spectrum resources to deliver maximum benefits to Singapore and consumers. This move follows a previous public consultation on the nationwide 5G network roll-out planned for 2020.

site_title: US junk bond funds suffer biggest outflow since December
summary: US junk bond funds experienced their largest outflow since December, with $2.57 billion withdrawn from retail funds in the week ending May 15, according to Refinitiv's Lipper. Despite this, year-to-date net inflows stand at $14 billion, and high-yield remains the top performer in fixed income. Other measures of the junk bond market, such as supply and spreads, remain healthy. The outflow is attributed to investors becoming defensive and taking gains, with liquidity improving compared to year-end.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.54% at the start of trade on Friday, driven by a positive start to the week. The Hang Seng Index added 152.93 points to 28,428.00, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw minor gains. Investors remain cautious ahead of developments in the China-US tariffs standoff.

site_title: Grab to expand anti-fraud team to 200 by end-2019 as scammers get smarter
summary: Grab is expanding its regional anti-fraud team to 200 employees by end-2019 to combat increasingly sophisticated scammers. The team will focus on "end-to-end" fraudulent activity, including incentive abuse, GPS spoofing, and fake apps. The move comes as Grab detects rising cases of fraud, including 13 driver accounts with over 2,000 transactions and a total loss of S$41,800. The company aims to maintain a fraud rate under 1% of gross merchandise value across all markets, and notes that fraudsters are increasingly targeting the ride-hailing and food delivery segments.

site_title: Credit Suisse sets up family office services unit for Greater China's rich
summary: Credit Suisse has established a unit focused on family office services in Greater China, driven by growing demand from rich Asians seeking private investment vehicles and business succession planning. Tan Mae Shen, senior specialist for family office services in Asia Pacific, will lead the unit, providing coverage for clients in Hong Kong and mainland China. This move aims to capitalize on the increasing need for wealth planning and private investment solutions in the region.

site_title: Australia shares surge to 11-year high as miners soar; New Zealand hits record
summary: Australia's benchmark share index surged to an 11-year high on Friday, driven by rising iron ore and oil prices, a weaker local dollar, and growing expectations of a potential interest rate cut. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.8% to 6,376.30, with miners and energy stocks leading the gains. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index hit a record high for a third straight session, driven by a strong performance from dairy and healthcare stocks.

site_title: China plans to cut jet fuel prices to aid airlines, consumers
summary: China plans to cut jet fuel prices starting July, aiming to reduce business costs in a slowing economy. The price cuts could amount to over $199.3 million annually for airlines, with wholesale fuel prices and rates charged by China National Aviation Fuel Group (CNAF) affected. The move is part of the government's response to help smaller businesses and consumers. China's air passenger traffic rose 4.6% in April, recovering slightly from a 4.0% growth in March, which marked the slowest gain in three years.

site_title: Singapore Airlines says its order for 31 Boeing 737 Max jets "intact"
summary: Singapore Airlines CEO Goh Choon Phong confirmed that the airline's order for 31 Boeing 737 Max jets remains intact despite deadly crashes involving the aircraft. The airline's regional arm, SilkAir, operated six 737 Max jets before they were grounded in March. Singapore Airlines reported its highest-ever annual revenue, but profits nearly halved due to higher fuel costs.

site_title: Hong Kong: Q1 GDP growth slows to 0.6%
summary: Hong Kong's economy grew 0.6% in Q1, slower than 1.2% in the previous quarter, due to a slowdown in exports and investment amid US-China trade frictions. This compares to a revised 0.5% contraction in Q4 2018. The quarterly growth was 1.3%, after a 0.5% contraction in the previous quarter. The slower growth is attributed to the ongoing trade tensions between the US and China.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong's economy grew a slower 0.6 per cent in the first quarter from a year earlier, the government said on Friday, hit by a slowdown in exports and investment amid US-China trade frictions.

site_title: Ex-vice justice minister arrested for bribery in South Korea
summary: A former South Korean vice justice minister, Kim Hak Ui, has been arrested on bribery allegations, including accepting prostitutes from a construction contractor. He is accused of accepting bribes worth 130 million won (S$151,000) and was previously cleared of similar allegations in 2013. Kim was stopped at Incheon airport in March as he attempted to flee, and has denied the allegations. The arrest comes as part of a new investigation into Kim's activities, which have raised concerns about corruption in South Korea.

images.alt_text: Kim Hak Ui is a former prosecutor who briefly served as the number two at the justice ministry in 2013, during the administration of ousted former president Park Geun Hye.

site_title: StanChart hires JPMorgan's top mining banker in Asia, to be based in Singapore
summary: Standard Chartered hired Michael Willoughby, head of Asia Pacific metals and mining investment banking at JPMorgan Chase, to be based in Singapore. Willoughby, who spent over 20 years at JPMorgan, will be co-head of metals and mining for the region. This move is key for Standard Chartered as it builds its business advising mining companies on transactions, particularly with gold deals driving activity in the sector. Willoughby will report to global head of metals and mining Richard Horrocks-Taylor.

site_title: Vegan burgers have kickstarted a dangerous stock frenzy in China
summary: A meat-substitute inspired rally in Chinese stocks has sparked a speculative frenzy, with companies like Hefei Fengle Seed and YanTai Shuangta Food soaring over 70% despite having no vegan burgers to sell. The trend is attributed to escalating trade tensions and rising pork prices, with investors betting on increasing agricultural prices. However, analysts claim the market is "artificial" and "speculative," with no real market for substitute meat in China, and warn that the trend may be unsustainable.

site_title: Australian politicians woo voters on Chinese social media app WeChat
summary: Australian politician Kevin Andrews is campaigning on the Chinese social media app WeChat to fight off a challenge from a Chinese-speaking rival in the upcoming election. Despite tense relations with China, Andrews' campaign has employed Chinese speakers to run channels in areas with large Mandarin and Cantonese-speaking populations. The Labor party, which is predicted to win the election, has also used WeChat to engage with the Chinese community. WeChat has become a major campaign tool in Australia, allowing politicians to demonstrate a commitment to multiculturalism and win votes.

site_title: SpaceX postpones Starlink satellite launch again, for 'about a week'
summary: SpaceX has postponed its Starlink satellite launch for about a week due to inclement weather, initially set for Wednesday night. The mission, aiming to carry 60 satellites into low-earth orbit, was rescheduled for Thursday night but was delayed again after excessive winds over the launch site. The company cited the need to update satellite software and triple-check everything before the launch, with the next opportunity set for about a week.

site_title: US trade war will only make us stronger, China's top paper says
summary: China's top paper, the People's Daily, asserts that the US trade war will only strengthen the country, citing its long history of perseverance and resilience. The Communist Party's official newspaper describes China's determination to protect its national interests as "firm as a boulder" and notes that the country has weathered past disasters such as the Opium War and SARS. China's Commerce Ministry has vowed to take steps to protect its companies, further straining ties with the US.

site_title: Virgin Australia expects annual loss on softening demand; shares drop to 4-month low
summary: Virgin Australia expects to incur an annual loss due to softening domestic demand and rising fuel prices, sending its shares to a 4-month low. The airline, which posted its best half-year profit in a decade in February, now expects underlying earnings for 2019 to be at least A$100 million lower than the previous year. Virgin has cut flights and is reviewing its network to address the challenging conditions, with shares falling 8% in early trade. The forecast earnings drop includes annual fuel and foreign exchange headwinds exceeding A$160 million.

site_title: China issues second batch of fuel export quotas for 2019, up 30% on first batch: traders
summary: China has issued a second batch of fuel export quotas for 2019, totaling 23.79 million tonnes, a 30% increase from the first batch. The quotas include 9.09 million tonnes of gasoline, 9.175 million tonnes of diesel, and 5.525 million tonnes of jet fuel, all allocated to state oil companies. This brings the total issued for 2019 to 42.15 million tonnes, amid a growing fuel surplus due to increased refinery production and upcoming plant expansions.

site_title: These are the worst-case scenarios for China in the trade war
summary: China's economic growth could plummet to below 6% as a deepening trade war escalates, according to economists at Bank of America, Morgan Stanley, and UBS. This would be the first time in almost three decades that China's expansion slows below 6%. Tariffs are driving manufacturers overseas, and a spiraling debt of 300% of output threatens the country's role as a global supply hub. The US market curbs on Huawei Technologies also underscore the economic containment threat China faces, putting pressure on policymakers to act.

site_title: Singapore is 3rd most innovative city globally; innovation key to property investment: JLL report
summary: Singapore is ranked as the third most innovative city globally, according to a report by JLL. The city's innovative status, driven by significant foreign investments and a rapidly growing startup scene, is now a key consideration for real estate investment strategies. Innovation-centric cities tend to be more resilient to economic shocks, as seen in cities like Seoul, Berlin, and Chicago, which experienced slower declines and quicker recoveries in real estate capital values.

site_title: ASTI, Dragon Group and Advanced Systems seek extension to hold fiscal 2018 AGMs by June 29
summary: ASTI Holdings, Dragon Group International, and Advanced Systems Automation have requested an extension to hold their fiscal 2018 annual general meetings (AGMs) by June 29, citing "certain outstanding matters" that require additional time to clear and ensure accurate financial reporting. The companies, which are associated with each other, need more time to finalize their accounts for fiscal 2018, with ASTI's shares closing 2.86% lower at 3.4 Singapore cents. The Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority had previously granted an extension until July 30.

site_title: Huawei ban could affect Japanese firms, says Japan finance minister
summary: Japan's Finance Minister Taro Aso warned that a US bid to block Huawei from buying vital American technology could affect Japanese companies and weigh on economic growth. Aso stated that Japanese companies supply parts to Huawei, with complex supply chains that could have direct and indirect effects on the country. The Trump administration's decision to add Huawei to a trade blacklist will make it difficult for the telecom giant to do business with US companies, potentially impacting Japanese firms.

images.alt_text: A US bid to block China's Huawei Technologies from buying vital American technology could affect Japanese companies and weigh on economic growth, Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso said on Friday.

site_title: China says economic impact of US trade tensions "controllable"
summary: China's state planner stated that the economic impact of US trade tensions is "controllable" and that countermeasures will be taken when necessary to maintain economic stability. China reported weaker-than-expected retail sales and industrial output in April, putting pressure on Beijing to implement stimulus measures. The US-China trade war continues to escalate, with its effects on China's economy expected to slow. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising concerns for policymakers.

site_title: Keyboard predators: South-east Asia kids targeted by online paedophiles
summary: A surge of paedophile activity is targeting children in South-east Asia, with online predators using live-streaming sites and webcams to orchestrate and watch abuse, often paying with near-untraceable cryptocurrency. Thailand, Cambodia, Vietnam, Laos, and the Philippines have long been seen as vulnerable to foreign and local paedophiles, but technology has shifted the patterns of abuse. Online giants are giving evidence to an independent inquiry into child sexual abuse, and experts warn that the cyber-abuse phenomenon is reaching Cambodia and Vietnam, with harsher penalties recently introduced in Vietnam.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, SATS, China Everbright Water, Wing Tai, FLT, Banyan Tree
summary: Singapore Airlines' fourth-quarter net profit fell 28% to S$202.6 million, while SATS' net profit dropped 23.7% to S$49.9 million. China Everbright Water's shares fell 6.33% after its unit closed a mandatory cash offer for Ying Li International Real Estate. Wing Tai Holdings plans to issue S$150 million perpetual securities, while Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust sold a warehouse for A$15 million. Banyan Tree Holdings posted a 74% drop in net profit to S$5.2 million for the first quarter.

site_title: Riot Games keeps forced arbitration clause despite employee protest
summary: Riot Games, the maker of League of Legends, has decided to maintain its forced arbitration clause despite employee protests, despite a town hall meeting with workers. The company, a division of Tencent Holdings, has been under fire for its "bro" culture and handling of sexual harassment complaints. Riot has pledged to create a new council on diversity and inclusion, but employees are still demanding changes. The decision has been met with criticism, with some comparing it to Google's decision to eliminate forced arbitration after a similar walkout.

site_title: Nissan's Saikawa to stay on as president, Renault chief to join board: sources
summary: Nissan has decided to retain Hiroto Saikawa as president and will appoint Renault's Thierry Bollore as a board member. Nissan's chairman, Jean-Dominique Senard, will also remain on the board. The appointments, expected to be announced on Friday, come after the company reported a 28% drop in annual profit and slashed its dividend. Former chairman Sadayuki Sakakibara, seen as a potential board candidate, will not be appointed, according to sources.

images.alt_text: Japan's Nissan Motor will keep Hiroto Saikawa on as president and will bring in the chief executive officer of alliance partner Renault, Thierry Bollore, as a board member, two sources briefed on the matter said on Friday.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at Friday's open, STI down 0.1% to 3,227.99
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.07% to 3,227.99 at the open on Friday, despite US stocks gaining for the third straight session. Gainers outnumbered losers 52 to 38 on the Singapore bourse, with Singtel trading flat and Genting Singapore down 0.6%. The decline comes after Singapore Airlines posted a 28% fall in fourth-quarter net profit due to lower operating profit and higher costs. US stocks rose after better-than-expected housing construction and a dip in jobless claims.

site_title: China to step up efforts to tackle hidden debt: China Daily
summary: China will implement new measures to tackle "hidden debt" among local governments, with Finance Minister Liu Kun stating the country will use new financial instruments to reduce the debt. The debt, capped at 3.08 trillion yuan, is expected to dwindle due to expiring bonds and dwindling land sales income. China aims to address the issue as its economy slows and a trade war with the US intensifies. The new measures may include selling off or restructuring state-owned assets and reorganizing projects.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher encouraged by US rallies
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, driven by US rallies that alleviated concerns over the US-China trade war. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.67% to 21,203.70, while the Topix index gained 0.54% to 1,545.82.

site_title: In China's heartland, once-flush shoppers turn cautious
summary: In China's Henan province, consumers are cutting back on spending due to the economic slowdown, which has hit real estate agent Zhao Na's business and income. With China's US$5 trillion-plus retail market slowing, consumers are becoming more cautious, with many shelving shopping trips and reducing debt. The slowdown could have serious repercussions for China's economic growth and global retailers, who have pinned hopes on growth in inland cities like Zhengzhou. As the economy continues to slow, consumer confidence in provincial cities is falling, with retailers reporting a decline in spending and a shift towards more cautious spending habits.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Friday, rising 0.13 points to 1,599.32. Volume was 25.62 million lots worth RM8.93 million, with gainers beating losers 110 to 52. This follows a positive trend in the region, with Singapore's STI up 0.4% on Thursday and the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq also reaching fresh records despite ongoing US-EU trade uncertainty.

site_title: Eggless egg-maker Just Inc considers IPO after Beyond Meat success
summary: Just Inc, a plant-based protein producer, is considering an initial public offering (IPO) after Beyond Meat's successful IPO. CEO Josh Tetrick says the company will enter the public markets "at some point," with no set timeline. Just Inc, valued at $1 billion, has seen growing consumer demand for plant-based proteins, which has led to increased sales and interest in its products, including a liquid egg substitute and plant-based mayonnaise. The company aims to expand globally, with China, India, and Europe as key markets.

site_title: Trump's business earnings decline as revenue at Mar-a Lago falls
summary: US President Donald Trump's business earnings declined to at least $421.3 million in 2018, down from $452.6 million the previous year, according to his financial disclosure. Licensing royalties and rents fell at properties like Mar-a-Lago, while revenue rose at his Washington hotel and golf courses in Scotland and Ireland. Trump's debt increased to $315 million, and his financial performance was affected by the Trump Organization's abandoned hotel expansion plan and government investigations.

site_title: A Cornell crypto professor is launching his own coin
summary: Cornell crypto professor Emin Gun Sirer is launching his own cryptocurrency coin, Ava, with funding from top venture capitalists. The Ava network aims to offer high throughput, fast confirmation times, and support various applications, including supply-chain tracking and securities management. The network is expected to process transactions per second comparable to Visa and have 1.35-second confirmation latency. Ava Labs, the startup behind the project, raised $6 million in February and is debuting a test version of its network. The coin's issuance is planned for a public launch in the coming months.

site_title: Your cup of coffee is about to get cheaper
summary: Indonesia is expected to become the world's largest coffee producer in 2019, with an estimated 11.5 million bags or 690,000 tonnes of robusta beans, a 5% increase from last year. This surge in production is due to favorable weather conditions, particularly modest rainfall, which allowed crops to produce good quality beans. Rising supplies have led to a 5% reduction in prices of export-grade robusta to US$1,540 a tonne, further reducing costs for caffeine addicts and boosting global supplies.

site_title: FCT oversubscribed placement raises S$369.6m at top end of price range
summary: FRASERS Centrepoint Trust (FCT) announced a 2.3 times oversubscription of its private placement, raising S$369.6 million at the top end of its issue price range of S$2.30 to S$2.382. The exercise issued 155.2 million new units and was oversubscribed by new and existing institutional and accredited investors. The trust's manager stated that the upsize option was fully taken, with demand coming from various investors.

site_title: China formally arrests two Canadians on state secrets charges
summary: China has formally arrested two Canadians, Michael Kovrig and Michael Spavor, on state secrets charges, amid increasing tension between Ottawa and Beijing. The arrests follow the detention of Huawei executive Meng Wanzhou in December, and China has demanded her release. Canada has condemned the move, calling it an "arbitrary arrest." Kovrig, a former diplomat, and Spavor, a businessman, could face trial, with experts suggesting China is using their cases to pressure Canada.

site_title: Singapore non-oil exports extend double-digit drop for 2nd straight month in April; confounding expectations
summary: Singapore's non-oil exports declined by 10% in April, extending a double-digit drop for the second straight month, according to Enterprise Singapore. This surpassed economists' expectations of a 4.6% drop. The decline follows a revised 11.8% plunge in March. The unexpected drop is attributed to a high base from the previous year.

site_title: Walmart reports jump in profit, warns on tariffs
summary: Walmart reported a 80% increase in first-quarter earnings to $3.8 billion, driven by strong US store sales and e-commerce growth. However, the company warned that higher US tariffs could lead to increased prices for customers. Walmart's international sales declined due to a strong US dollar and political headwinds in Latin American markets. Despite the warning, Walmart's shares rose 1.4% following the earnings report.

site_title: Trump says having gay presidential candidate is 'great'
summary: US President Donald Trump expressed support for gay presidential candidate Pete Buttigieg, calling his candidacy "great." Trump stated he has no problem with Buttigieg's homosexuality, despite being a Republican who has historically been opposed to gay marriage. Buttigieg, a married gay man, could become the first openly gay president if he wins the White House, with his husband potentially becoming the first gentleman. Trump's comments mark a departure from his previous mixed stance on gay rights.

site_title: SATS Q4 profit falls 23.7% to S$49.9m on absence of one-off gains
summary: SATS Q4 net profit fell 23.7% to S$49.9 million due to the absence of one-off gains. Revenue grew 11.3% to S$471.5 million, driven by higher contributions from its food solutions and gateway services businesses. The company has recommended a final dividend of 19 cents per share, up from 18 cents last year. SATS has secured a long-term contract with Singapore Airlines and plans to invest in new opportunities in Asia-Pacific. The company also announced the purchase of a 50% stake in a Chinese food company, Nanjing Weizhou Airline Food Company, for S$31.2 million.

site_title: US$575m Qatar World Cup stadium opens to fanfare
summary: Qatar's US$575 million Al-Wakrah stadium, designed by late architect Zaha Hadid, officially opened with a domestic cup final, attracting a full crowd and praising its futuristic design and world-class amenities. The 40,000-capacity stadium features a retractable roof and was the site of a 1-1 stalemate between Al-Sadd and Al-Duhail. The venue's unique architecture and high-tech features were met with praise from spectators, with some hailing it as "one of the loudest stadiums" in the world.

site_title: Amazon is close to buying Sizmek's ad-serving technology
summary: Amazon is close to acquiring Sizmek's ad-serving technology, a deal that could give the e-commerce giant a competitive edge against Google's dominant online advertising business. Sizmek's Ad Server helps advertisers place spots and measure effectiveness, directly competing with Google's Marketing Platform. The purchase, which could be announced soon, hasn't been finalized, but would mark Amazon's entry into the ad-serving market. The deal would bolster Amazon's advertising capabilities, potentially challenging Google's dominance in the industry.

images.alt_text: Amazon.com is close to an agreement to buy the ad-serving technology of bankrupt company Sizmek in a deal that would give the e-commerce giant another weapon against Google's dominant online advertising business.

site_title: Court orders Wellness Group to be wound up
summary: The High Court in Singapore has ordered the winding-up of The Wellness Group due to the mismanagement of its funds by directors Manoj and Kanchan Murjani, who treated the company's funds as their personal piggy bank. The company's only known asset is its 30% stake in luxury tea brand TWG Tea. The court found that the directors had failed to obtain prior written consent for personal remuneration and had caused the company to borrow millions for legal costs. The company's financial affairs are in disarray, and there is no exit mechanism for shareholders to exit the company at fair value.

site_title: Yorkshine sinks into the red for Q3 with US$989,000 loss
summary: Yorkshine reported a third-quarter net loss of US$989,000, down from a net profit of US$8.2 million a year ago. The loss per share was 0.52 US cents, compared to 4.26 US cents in the same period last year. The company attributed the loss to its tinplate manufacturing business being at its early resumed stage. No dividend was declared for the third quarter, unchanged from a year ago.

site_title: SpaceX set to launch first satellites of its internet network
summary: SpaceX is set to launch 60 satellites into low-Earth orbit on Thursday night, marking the first of potentially thousands of satellites in its Starlink project. The launch, led by Elon Musk, aims to provide broadband internet globally, with the potential to earn $30 billion annually. The satellites will be replaced regularly due to their shorter lifespan, but SpaceX has obtained approval for up to 12,000 satellites in various orbits. The company plans to team up with telecoms operators and has not yet begun finding clients, with the goal of becoming a major player in the future space internet market.

site_title: Mexico journalist murdered, fifth this year
summary: A Mexican journalist, Francisco Romero, was found dead outside a nightclub in Playa del Carmen, Mexico, after receiving death threats, making him the fifth reporter slain in the country this year. Romero, who was enrolled in a government protection program, had filed a complaint about the threats in April. Reporters Without Borders reported that the killing officially made Mexico the deadliest country in the world for journalists this year.

site_title: Taiwan parliament to vote on Asia's first gay marriage bill
summary: Taiwan's parliament is set to vote on Asia's first gay marriage bill on Friday, with a court ruling ordering same-sex marital equality and a two-year deadline for the government to make necessary changes. Three bills have been tabled, with the most progressive government bill offering limited adoption rights, but conservative lawmakers are launching a last-ditch attempt to scupper the bill. The outcome will determine Taiwan's stance on marriage equality, with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party holding the majority in parliament.

site_title: Online shopping in China goes luxury, with men in black delivering Hermes
summary: China's online luxury shopping market is rapidly growing, with Chinese consumers accounting for one-third of global spending on luxury items in 2018. The market is expected to nearly double to $1.2 trillion by 2025. To cater to this market, luxury brands are teaming up with internet companies to offer exclusive services, such as white-gloved delivery and social media promotions. This shift challenges traditional luxury retail strategies and forces brands to rethink their approach to the Chinese market.

site_title: US-based equity funds post US$12 billion outflows amid US-China trade tensions
summary: US-based equity funds experienced their fourth consecutive week of outflows, totaling US$12.27 billion, amid US-China trade tensions. Investors shifted to safer assets, such as money market and Treasury funds, following the S&P 500's steepest drop since early January. Equity exchange-traded funds (ETFs) saw net outflows of around US$10 billion, with the SPDR S&P 500 ETF accounting for over half of the total weekly outflows. The outflows are attributed to uncertainty driven by US-China trade tensions.

site_title: Iraqi Airways to resume flights to Syria after 8-year break
summary: Iraqi Airways will resume flights to Damascus, Syria after an 8-year break, starting a weekly service from Baghdad. The resumption is seen as important for bilateral trade, tourism, and the size of the Iraqi community in Syria. The last flight occurred in December 2011, before the conflict escalated. The move comes as the conflict has wound down in recent years, with Damascus largely spared the violence. Analysts say the resumption will help Syria inch its way back into trade with the wider region.

site_title: Tariffs are driving up prices on canned fruits and vegetables, says Del Monte CEO
summary: US canned fruit and vegetable prices have increased due to tariffs, according to Del Monte CEO Greg Longstreet. The 25% tariff on steel imports and 10% tariff on aluminum imports in 2018 led to a 25% price hike for Del Monte's products. Transportation costs and a tight labor market are also contributing to the price rise. Del Monte is shifting to non-canned products to offset the increase, with new uncanned lines set to generate 40% of the company's revenue. This could lead to higher inflation, with economists projecting a 0.1-0.3 percentage point gain.

site_title: Rapper to address 1MDB-linked charges on new 'Elon Musk' EP
summary: Former Fugees rapper Prakazrel 'Pras' Michel has declared his innocence in the US campaign finance charges related to 1MDB-linked charges, stating he will address the issues on his upcoming 9-track EP titled "Elon Musk", set to release in June. Michel pleaded not guilty to conspiracy, making false statements, and making false entries. His defence lawyer plans to review 60,000 pages of records and may seek a dismissal due to prosecutors' delay in bringing the case.

images.alt_text: Former Fugees rap star Prakazrel 'Pras' Michel declared he is "totally innocent" of the illegal US campaign finance charges levelled against him last week - and he will have a distinctive way of broadcasting that.

site_title: Starbucks' China challenger Luckin Coffee raises US$561m in US IPO
summary: Luckin Coffee, a Chinese challenger to Starbucks, raised $561 million in its US IPO, selling 33 million American depository shares at $17 each. The company, valued at $4.2 billion, plans to use the funds for store expansion, customer acquisition, and marketing. Luckin aims to displace Starbucks as China's largest coffee chain, with 2,370 stores and plans to open 2,500 more this year. The IPO comes amid Chinese-US trade tensions, with Chinese firms raising $619 million in US IPOs this year.

site_title: Trump proposes immigration overhaul to favour skilled, English speakers
summary: US President Donald Trump proposed a radical immigration reform plan, favoring skilled, English-speaking workers and shutting the door on frivolous asylum claimants. The reforms would fundamentally pivot away from the US tradition of welcoming immigrants. However, the proposal faces little chance of passing in Congress, where immigration is seen as a politically toxic subject ahead of 2020 elections.

site_title: Pinterest forecasts 2019 revenue in line with estimates, shares fall
summary: Pinterest forecasts full-year revenue between $1.055 billion and $1.08 billion, slightly above analysts' estimate of $1.06 billion. The company added 291 million monthly active users globally in the quarter, exceeding estimates. Total revenue rose 54% to $201.9 million, beating estimates. Despite the positive forecast, shares fell 19% in extended trading, following a 62% rise since the company's initial public offering last month. Net loss narrowed to $41.4 million in the first quarter.

site_title: Iran says no talks with the US as Gulf tensions soar
summary: Iran has rejected US talks amid rising tensions in the Gulf, with the US deploying an aircraft carrier strike group and B-52 bombers to the region. Iranian Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif called the US escalation "unacceptable" and said there was "no possibility" of negotiations. The US claims Iran has loaded missiles onto small boats in the Gulf, prompting a US official to describe the situation as a "concern." The deployment of US forces and heightened rhetoric has put pressure on the White House and Pentagon to justify their actions.

site_title: Wikipedia 'doing very well financially': co-founder
summary: Wikipedia co-founder Jimmy Wales stated that the free online encyclopedia is financially stable, with annual revenue exceeding expenses. Despite potential impact from increasing mobile phone use on future donations, Wales expressed confidence in the organization's financial health.

site_title: US publishes Huawei export blacklist order
summary: The US Commerce Department has placed Huawei Technologies and 68 affiliates in over two dozen countries on its "Entity List", banning them from buying US parts and components without approval. The move, effective immediately, was made due to alleged national security and foreign policy concerns, including a pending US sanctions case against Huawei. This ban is expected to significantly hinder Huawei's ability to sell products, affecting not only the company but also US suppliers, with a trade expert stating the likelihood of Commerce granting licenses is "negligible".

site_title: Amazon close to buying a stake in UK's Deliveroo: Sky News
summary: Amazon is reportedly in talks to invest hundreds of millions of pounds in UK food delivery app Deliveroo as part of a $575 million fundraising. If a deal is confirmed, Amazon is expected to invest a significant portion of the funds in the gig economy. Deliveroo operates in over 100 UK towns and cities, working with 8,000 restaurants. The company's algorithm uses predictive technology to optimize order distribution. Amazon declined to comment on the report, while Deliveroo has not confirmed the deal.

site_title: Video game rivals Microsoft and Sony team up on streaming games, chips and AI
summary: Microsoft and Sony have formed a strategic partnership to stream games and media through Microsoft's cloud, with the two companies also working together to develop image sensors and offer game makers new development tools. The deal aims to bolster Microsoft's Azure cloud computing business and counter Amazon's Amazon Web Services. Sony shares jumped 11% as Asian markets opened, while Microsoft's stock rose 2%. The partnership will also explore the use of Microsoft's artificial intelligence (AI) technology in Sony's consumer products.

images.alt_text: Longtime video game console rivals Microsoft and Sony on Thursday announced an alliance to improve their platforms for streaming entertainment from the internet cloud.

site_title: Oil prices rise more than 1% as Middle East conflict persists
summary: Oil prices rose more than 1% on Thursday as tensions in the Middle East persisted, with a Saudi-led coalition launching air strikes in response to recent attacks on its crude infrastructure. Brent crude futures settled at $72.62 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures at $62.87 a barrel, their highest levels in three and two weeks respectively. The escalation of tensions has raised fears of supply disruptions, prompting international oil companies to operate as normal in Iraq and Asian shippers to put ships on alert.

images.alt_text: Oil futures were up more than 1 per cent on Thursday as tensions in the Middle East grew, with a Saudi-led coalition launching air strikes in retaliation for recent attacks on its crude infrastructure.

site_title: US cancels US$929m in California high speed rail funds after appeal rejected
summary: The US government has cancelled $929 million in previously awarded funding for California's high-speed rail program after rejecting an appeal by the state. The Federal Railroad Administration cited the state's failure to comply with the project and make reasonable progress. California Governor Gavin Newsom vowed to go to court to protect the state's funds, calling the action "illegal and a direct assault on California." The decision is the latest in a long-standing battle between the Trump administration and California over issues including immigration and vehicle emissions standards.

images.alt_text: The Trump administration said on Thursday it was formally cancelling $929 million in previously awarded funding for California's high-speed rail programme after rejecting an appeal by the state.

site_title: Baidu Q1 revenue forecast falls short of estimates, sending shares down
summary: Baidu reported lower-than-expected first-quarter earnings and forecast quarterly revenue below estimates, sending its shares down 8% in extended trading. Revenue from its online marketing services business rose 3% to $2.57 billion, missing estimates of $2.66 billion. Despite government policies to improve market conditions for small and medium-sized enterprises, Baidu's chief financial officer expects online marketing to face a challenging environment in the near term.

site_title: Boeing completes 737 Max software update, working on pilot training plan
summary: Boeing has completed a software update for its 737 Max jets, which were grounded worldwide after two fatal crashes in 2018 and 2019. The planemaker is working on a pilot training plan and submitting it to the US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) for certification. The FAA plans to review the software fix and pilot training on May 23. The update aims to address concerns raised by the crashes and restore the 737 Max to service. Boeing is expected to conduct a certification test flight once the FAA certifies the updated aircraft.

site_title: Yale investing chief David Swensen tops university pay at US$4.7m
summary: Yale University's investing chief, David Swensen, received $4.7 million in compensation in 2017, making him the highest-paid executive at the Ivy League school. His pay included a base salary of $843,954 and a performance bonus of $2.9 million. Swensen's compensation was nearly unchanged from the previous year, despite Yale's endowment growing to $29.4 billion. This is lower than Harvard's head of endowment, Narv Narvekar, who received $9.3 million in 2017, and reflects Swensen's relatively lower pay compared to peers in the industry.

site_title: I.M. Pei, a pillar of modern architecture, dies at 102
summary: I.M. Pei, a renowned US architect, has died at 102. He was known for his modern designs, such as the Louvre pyramid and Bank of China tower, while balancing history and grandeur. Born in China in 1917, Pei studied architecture in the US and became a naturalized citizen in 1954. He received numerous awards, including the Medal of Freedom and Chevalier in the Legion d'Honneur. Pei's work continues to be celebrated, with his legacy as a master of modern architecture cemented.

site_title: Saudi reopens key oil pipeline after drone attack: Aramco
summary: Saudi Arabia has reopened the East West Pipeline, a key oil pipeline, after it was shut down by drone attacks claimed by Yemen's Huthi rebels. The attacks, which occurred amid escalating tensions between the US and Iran, were blamed on Iran by Saudi Arabia's deputy defence minister. The pipeline, which can pump 5 million barrels of crude per day, provides a strategic alternative route for Saudi exports. The Huthis said the attacks were in revenge for Saudi actions in Yemen, which has led to a four-year conflict and a humanitarian crisis affecting over 24 million people.

site_title: Huawei ban clouds US-China trade talks, tech sector
summary: The US has banned China's Huawei Technologies from buying vital American technology without special approval, drawing a sharp rebuke from Beijing. This move could hurt trade talks and affect tens of thousands of American jobs. Huawei's US suppliers saw their shares fall, and the company said it will seek remedies to find a resolution. The US-China trade war continues, with both sides imposing tariffs and threatening further measures. The ban is the latest shot fired in the trade war, which has rattled financial markets and threatened to derail a slowing global economy.

images.alt_text: A US bid to block China's Huawei Technologies from buying vital American technology threw into question prospects for sales at some of the largest tech companies and drew a sharp rebuke from Beijing, which said the move could hurt trade talks.

site_title: Singapore to spend 'billions' on upgrading air traffic control hardware and training, says Khaw
summary: Singapore plans to spend billions of dollars over the next few decades to upgrade its air traffic control system and introduce enhancements to ensure high safety and efficiency. Transport Minister Khaw Boon Wan said the current system, which cost over S$300 million, is being upgraded to avoid obsolescence. The country invests heavily in air traffic management capabilities, including training and upskilling air traffic controllers, and aims to integrate airspace with harmonized procedures to optimize use and benefit all.

site_title: Third fatal Tesla Autopilot crash renews questions about system
summary: A fatal Tesla Autopilot crash in Delray Beach, Florida, on March 1, 2019, has raised questions about the system's ability to detect hazards. The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) found that Autopilot was engaged and the system failed to detect the driver's hands on the wheel for 8 seconds before the crash. Tesla's Autopilot system has been linked to at least three fatal US crashes, prompting concerns about its safety. The NTSB and National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) are investigating, with some experts calling for restrictions on Autopilot's use and a more effective system.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: ISR Capital reported a net loss of S$387,426 for its first quarter to March 31, with a loss per share of 0.01 Singapore cent, similar to the previous year.

site_title: Eyes Wide Shut
summary: Singapore film Demons, helmed by 32-year-old writer-director Daniel Hui, premieres at the Singapore International Festival of Arts (SIFA) film section. The experimental horror film follows a theatre director's unconventional methods to mold his actors, exploring themes of power and abuse. With a twisty narrative and non-diegetic cinematography, Demons rewards attentive viewers with a dream logic conclusion. Hui's first foray into genre filmmaking, Demons is a hypnotic and surreal work that ties together loose threads via a dream-like structure.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Mind Your Business - How SMEs can change the game
summary: The "Mind Your Business" podcast on Money FM discusses how Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs) can change the game in the market. According to a 2019 report, startups raised US$10.5 billion in venture capital deals, outpacing IPOs on the SGX. Expert Jacky Tai shares strategies for SMEs to succeed, but also warns of potential landmines to avoid. Meanwhile, recent news includes Royal Healthcare's plans to open a specialist centre in Tokyo or Osaka, and NUS researchers' startup aiming to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel.

site_title: BMW CEO talks up model offensive as downturn crimps profits
summary: BMW CEO Harald Krueger defended the company's cautious approach to electric cars, citing uncertainty about the technology's future and the need for diversified strategies. Despite a tough start to the year, BMW plans 21 new models and expects business to improve in the second half of the year. The company reported its first loss in a decade in the automotive division, but Krueger remains confident in the company's ability to retake the premium car sales crown by 2020. BMW aims to launch 12 electric cars by 2025, but is prioritizing plug-in hybrid vehicles and fuel-cell cars alongside battery-only models.

site_title: A Simple House
summary: Aesthetic doctor Gabriel Wong commissioned designer Roystern Goh to redesign his two-and-a-half storey terrace house in Upper Thomson, Singapore. The redesign aimed to create a more spacious and brighter home. Pillars were removed, and unnecessary spaces were optimized. Light wood and black colors were used to enhance the home's appearance. The second floor was brightened with full-height windows, and a see-through bathroom was incorporated. The result is a minimalist, fuss-free home that suits Wong's bachelor lifestyle, with plants adding a touch of serenity to the space.

site_title: UK banks brace for grilling over 'alarming' gender pay gap
summary: The UK's biggest banks face scrutiny over their handling of the gender pay gap, with a parliamentary hearing set to grill them on the issue. The second year of UK gender pay gap reporting revealed little change, with women earning less than men at most organisations. Advocates push for expansion of mandatory pay gap reporting to cover racial and ethnic pay gaps. Barclays, a sponsor of the Women's Super League, is seen as a positive example of progress in the industry, while experts suggest women could lead the European Central Bank in the future.

site_title: DBS partners LittleLives to digitise payments
summary: DBS has partnered with Singapore-based edutech firm LittleLives to digitize payments for one in three pre-schools in Singapore. The enhanced LittleLives app will allow parents to make payments via PayNow and DBS PayLah, enabling them to purchase school uniforms, pay for field trips, and sign up for classes. The partnership aims to take the hassle out of payments, allowing pre-school operators to better manage their cash flow.

site_title: US: Shares gain for third straight session
summary: US stocks rose for a third consecutive session, driven by solid economic data and positive earnings reports from Dow members Cisco and Walmart. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.8% to 25,862.68, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 0.9% and 1% respectively. The gains followed benign US statements on trade and positive investor sentiment. Key stocks including Boeing, Goldman Sachs, and Cisco Systems surged, while Tesla Motors fell 1.6% after a National Transportation Safety Board report.

site_title: Citi to roll out consumer e-payments business in Asia and other markets by Q1 2020
summary: Citi plans to launch its consumer e-payments business in Asia and other markets by Q1 2020, aiming to capture last-mile C2B flows. The move follows the growth of digital ecosystems in the region and the bank's existing presence in the market. Citi targets to be live in 20 markets across Asia and elsewhere by 2020, with plans to expand to 40 markets over the next three years. The digital payments space is transforming rapidly, driven by consumer demand for speed and convenience.

site_title: Shanghai surprise
summary: Yan's Dining Fine Shanghai Cuisine, a small Chinese restaurant in Singapore, offers high-quality food despite its compact size. The restaurant's communal eating concept and large portions cater to high volume and turnover, making it ideal for groups. Despite limited English spoken by staff, the cooking is authentic and elegant, with a rustic home-style feel. The menu features a variety of dishes, including the signature Noodles Served with Scallion Oil, which showcases the restaurant's substance and potential for growth. The reviewer gives Yan's Dining a rating of 7, praising its good food and atmosphere.

site_title: US is prima facie losing the trade war
summary: The US is losing the trade war with China, according to a trade expert. The Trump administration's strategy aims to reduce the US$419 billion goods trade deficit with China, but experts believe this goal is muddled. The deficit may decline temporarily through increased US purchases, but the effect is likely to fade over time. The US is suffering significant losses, while China is holding its ground, indicating a flawed approach to the trade war.

site_title: New home prices in China grow at solid pace
summary: China's new home prices rose 0.6% in April, marking the 48th consecutive month of price increases, according to data from the National Bureau of Statistics. This growth is driven by pent-up demand, easier credit conditions, and relaxed purchase restrictions in some cities. Despite this, Beijing has urged local governments to control the market, citing concerns of a potential bubble. Annual home prices rose 10.7% in April, and most cities reported monthly price increases, with the top-tier cities of Beijing, Shanghai, Shenzhen, and Guangzhou driving the growth.

site_title: Europe: Stocks climb as deal talk outweighs trade fears
summary: European stocks rose 1.3% to a 10-day closing peak, driven by deal-making news in Germany, including Thyssenkrupp's 9.4% gain after reports of a potential bid for its elevator division. The STOXX 600 index also rose, with Paris-traded stocks gaining 1.4% and London-listed equities firming by 0.8%. The gains were overshadowed by US-China trade tensions, but market economists say fears have already been priced in, focusing on Europe-US trade talks.

site_title: Nanyang Memories
summary: The musical "Memoirs Of Nanyang" tells a cross-generational tale of an immigrant's journey from China to Singapore, blending nanyin music, Malay songs, and Mandarin pop. Commissioned by the Singapore Chinese Cultural Centre, the production features collaborations with three Cultural Medallion recipients and showcases a diverse and distinct Singaporean identity. The musical premieres on May 25 at the Singapore Chinese Cultural Centre.

site_title: Shanghai aluminium futures hit 7-month high amid supply shortage in China
summary: Shanghai aluminium futures reached a 7-month high due to a supply shortage in China, following the shutdown of a major refinery in Shanxi. The refinery, operated by Xinfa Group, closed production lines amid an environmental dispute, causing alumina prices to spike. The Shanghai Futures Exchange saw a 0.4% gain, marking the fifth straight session of gains. Analysts predict alumina prices will remain high, supporting aluminium prices, with mid-term demand to be closely monitored.

site_title: Debt bubbles could burst as economies slow, threatening stability, bankers warn
summary: Debt bubbles are forming globally due to heavy reliance on debt financing and slow economic growth, posing a threat to financial stability. Economists warn that a major shock could trigger a credit crunch, with liquidity drying up in certain asset classes. The build-up of debt, worth 230% of global economic output, is unsustainable and could lead to a major bankruptcy wave if interest rates rise. Low liquidity, exacerbated by reduced bank holdings of bonds, could further destabilize the system, highlighting the need for investors and issuers to recognize the risks and be prepared for a potential credit crunch.

site_title: Affordable Luxury
summary: Tissot, a Swiss watch brand under Swatch, defies the luxury industry's pricing rule by offering high-quality, affordable timepieces. Founded in 1853, Tissot prioritizes craftsmanship and innovation, creating products for everyone, not just high-end clients. The brand's president, Francois Thiebaud, attributes this approach to its history and mission. Tissot's recent release of the Ballade Powermatic 80 watch, featuring a silicon hairspring, showcases its commitment to quality and affordability, with a price tag under $1000.

site_title: Expect car permit costs to escalate if cab firms rejoin bidding for COEs
summary: Singapore's Land Transport Authority (LTA) is reviewing regulations to allow taxi operators to rejoin the Certificate of Entitlement (COE) bidding process, potentially leading to increased car permit costs for motorists. The move aims to level the playing field between traditional cab operators and ride-hailing firms, which have expanded their fleets and competed for COEs. If reversed, the ban could lead to a surge in taxi fleet growth, with cab operators seeking to secure COEs to supplement their fleets, further increasing costs for car buyers.

site_title: City Planning
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority and Singapore Land Authority launched "Power Up Pasir Panjang," a competition to transform the Power District in Pasir Panjang into a waterfront lifestyle destination. The district, built in the 1950s and 1960s, houses the Pasir Panjang Terminal and power generation facilities, and its unique industrial heritage will be reflected in the redesign. Winners will receive cash prizes and see their ideas come to life, with entries closing on June 25. The project aims to kick-start the rejuvenation of the Greater Southern Waterfront.

site_title: Asian family offices, Insignia bless YouTrip with US$25.5m pre-Series A funding
summary: YouTrip, a Singapore-based mobile wallet operator, has received US$25.5 million in pre-Series A funding from Asian family offices and venture firm Insignia Ventures Partners. The funding is seen as "patient capital" to support the fintech startup's South-east Asian expansion. YouTrip aims to capitalize on the growing demand for digital payments in the region. The funding is a significant boost to the company's plans to expand its services across Southeast Asia.

images.alt_text: Asian family offices are the long-term patient capital, according to Ms Chu

site_title: Pawan Gandhi
summary: Pawan Gandhi, founder and CEO of KaHa, a Singapore-based start-up, has revolutionized the wearable technology industry with his company's innovative smart watches and fitness trackers. With multiple patents pending, KaHa's Cove brand has gained significant traction, with the global smart wearable market expected to double to $27 billion by 2022. Gandhi's mission to create wearable devices for vulnerable women, such as panic buttons and safety features, was sparked by a personal experience in India. As the industry continues to evolve, Gandhi predicts that smart wearables will replace traditional watches, with the top 10 watch companies shifting to smart portfolios.

site_title: China LNG buyers seek to swap US cargo after new tariffs
summary: Chinese liquefied natural gas buyers are seeking to swap US cargo for shipments from non-tariff nations due to Beijing's plans to raise tariffs amid a trade dispute. Some buyers have approached suppliers to trade US cargo for cargo from countries such as Australia or Qatar, in an effort to mitigate potential price increases. The move is part of a broader effort to diversify LNG supplies and reduce dependence on US imports.

site_title: Wrap It Up
summary: The Dragon Boat Festival is approaching, with hotels and restaurants in Singapore offering a variety of rice dumplings. Classics include pork belly and salted fish at Pan Pacific Singapore's Hai Tien Lo, while Crystal Jade features Taiwanese roast pork belly and black beans. Marina Mandarin offers local rendang kurobuta and Japanese purple sweet potato dumplings, and Shangri-La Hotel's Chef Mok offers unique variations with ingredients like foie gras and wolfberries. These restaurants offer a range of options, from traditional to innovative, to cater to different tastes and preferences.

site_title: China blasts US blacklisting of Huawei as trade tensions rise
summary: China strongly opposed the US decision to blacklist Huawei, calling it a "trade protectionism" move that will damage Sino-US relations. The US Commerce Department added Huawei to its "Entity List", banning it from acquiring US components and technology without prior government approval. Huawei denies posing a security threat, while US officials have previously labeled it a "threat" to national security. The move may delay China's 5G rollout and harm US interests in the long run, with analysts warning of global tech supply chain ramifications.

site_title: Application to wind up Midas will be heard on May 24
summary: Midas Holdings, a Singapore-based aluminium train components supplier, will have its court hearing date for a winding up application on May 24, 2019. The company does not intend to contest the application, filed by executive director Xu Wei Dong, following a statutory demand for unpaid salaries. As of March 31, Midas had net liabilities of S$81.2 million and cash of S$122,000. The company is also owed S$2.79 million by CRRC Nanjing Puzhen Rail Transport Co, and is contesting a claim by CRRC at the Hong Kong International Arbitration Center.

site_title: Artificial intelligence is not a silver bullet
summary: Businesses must approach artificial intelligence (AI) with caution, recognizing that it's not a silver bullet. AI encompasses various technologies with differing levels of maturity and risk. To avoid failed AI projects, businesses should thoroughly assess individual systems and their potential value. They should review AI sub-segments, consider tried-and-tested applications, and integrate AI with existing operations. A test bed approach and careful consideration of datasets are also crucial. Ultimately, informed investments in the right types of AI will pay off in the long run, but businesses must be prepared to play a long game, accepting a 60-70% accuracy rate post-implementation.

site_title: Smart Shopper
summary: A list of seven value-for-money workwear labels, including Klarra, OM, COS, Everlane, Ying the Label, Karen Millen, and J.Crew, are recommended for a professional wardrobe. These brands cater to various styles and preferences, offering affordable options with a focus on quality and practicality. Available at various shopping centers, including Raffles City and ION Orchard, these labels can help individuals update their workwear wardrobe.

site_title: ST Index finding support at 3,200
summary: The Singapore Stock Exchange (SGX) closed 11.49 points or 0.4% higher at 3,230.26 on Thursday, following the US ban on foreign telecoms equipment, which spooked tech counters. Most tech firms declined, but Netlink NBN Trust rose 0.6% due to its defensive position in the market. The STI found support at 3,200, but market analysts warn that trade tensions persist and may impact the market further.

site_title: SIA's Q4 earnings down 28%, full-year gain slumps 47%; airline sees fuel costs headwinds
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) reported a 28% drop in Q4 earnings to S$202.6 million, and a 47.5% decline in full-year net profit to S$683 million. Higher fuel costs and non-fuel costs related to SilkAir's refleeting and restructuring contributed to the decline. Despite a record revenue of S$16.3 billion, operating profit and dividends were down. The airline expects passenger capacity to grow 6% in the year ahead, but faces uncertainty due to trade disputes and slowing economic growth in key markets.

site_title: Pilot decisions contributed to Boeing 737 MAX crashes: FAA chief
summary: The outgoing FAA Administrator, Daniel Elwell, stated that pilot decisions contributed to the Boeing 737 MAX crashes in Indonesia and Ethiopia, killing 346 people. The automated anti-stall feature, MCAS, was activated when it wasn't supposed to, causing the planes to nosedive repeatedly. Elwell said pilots failed to respond properly, turning off motors but not controlling the plane's speed. The FAA has faced criticism for its certification process and the agency is working on a software fix for the MCAS system, which will use data from two external sensors rather than one.

site_title: Indonesia has a US$564b plan to rebuild country
summary: Indonesia has drafted a $564 billion plan to rebuild the country, with 60% of the spending going towards transportation infrastructure, including airports and ports. The plan aims to boost economic growth and spread wealth beyond Java, where the capital is located. The government plans to fund 40% of the project directly, 25% through state-owned enterprises, and the rest through the private sector. The plan is part of President Joko Widodo's strategy to increase connectivity and stimulate economic growth, although financing challenges and infrastructure gaps have been a concern in recent years.

site_title: A*Star: Nothing came out of MOU signed with Marvelstone Group last year
summary: A*Star's commercialization arm, A*ccelerate, signed a memoranda of understanding with Marvelstone Group in 2018, but no collaboration has been made. Marvelstone's founder, Joe Cho Seunghyun, is involved in legal disputes with investors and Singapore property group Hong Leong Holdings, who claim he failed to pay contractually promised returns. Marvelstone Group is not a member of the Singapore Fintech Association and its CEO, Gina Heng, is no longer on the board. Despite claims of being a fintech hub, Marvelstone's activities appear to be minimal, with its fund company reporting no assets under management.

site_title: China Everbright unit owns 72.04% of Ying Li, together with concert parties
summary: China Everbright unit, State Alpha, has closed its mandatory unconditional cash offer for Ying Li International Real Estate, resulting in a 72.04% shareholding. The offer was triggered after State Alpha acquired 767.1 million shares from Newest Luck Holdings, increasing its combined stake with concert parties to 72.04%. DBS served as the financial adviser to the offeror.

site_title: Peranakan Pride
summary: A new Peranakan Gallery on Orchard Road in Singapore offers insights into the 500-year-old history of the Straits Chinese population in Southeast Asia. The gallery, designed to resemble a Peranakan home, features exhibits on the art of embroidering and wearing traditional clothing, as well as a grand spread of dishes called Tok Panjang, highlighting the importance of culinary heritage in Peranakan culture. The gallery is open daily from 11am to 10pm and admission is waived for visitors with hotel key cards or receipts from Claymore Connect outlets.

site_title: Hyflux saga: Judicial management not the panacea for company's restructuring
summary: Hyflux, a Singapore-based water treatment firm, is seeking a moratorium to restructure its finances. After the initial investor, SM Investments, withdrew, new potential investors Utico and Oyster Bay Fund have emerged with offers of S$400 million and S$500 million respectively. Sias, a group representing Hyflux's creditors, believes that judicial management would be premature and potentially detrimental to the company's restructuring process, citing concerns over the impact on ongoing projects and strategic investors. Instead, an extended moratorium with heightened conditions for disclosure and engagement with creditors is seen as the most sensible route ahead.

site_title: Oil climbs on falling US gasoline stockpiles and Gulf tension
summary: Oil prices rose for a third consecutive day, driven by falling US gasoline stockpiles and heightened tensions in the Middle East. US gasoline inventories dropped 1.12 million barrels, while Saudi Arabia restarted its main oil pipeline after a drone attack. The ongoing US-Iran tensions and a looming OPEC meeting will be closely watched for potential output cuts. Crude prices rose 0.9% in New York, with West Texas Intermediate crude reaching its highest close in over two weeks.

images.alt_text: A drilling rig in Texas, US. Futures rose as much as 0.9% after adding 1.6% over the previous two sessions; while American gasoline inventories dropped by 1.12 million barrels last week.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Wilmar International's second quarter results are expected to be upbeat, driven by a positive soybean crush utilisation rate and lower input costs due to cheap soybean meal prices. Consolidation in the crushing industry and improving demand are also contributing factors. The company's target price is set at S$3.94.

site_title: When ignorance is not bliss
summary: The Dunning-Kruger effect, a cognitive bias where individuals fail to recognize their own ignorance or incompetence, can lead to poor decision-making in the workplace. This phenomenon can manifest in arrogant behavior, bluster, and loudness, which can be both amusing and annoying. However, it can also result in bad decisions and poor outcomes. Experts discuss strategies to deal with DKE-prone staff and how to create a system that rewards humility and wisdom over arrogance and loudness.

site_title: Rise In Time
summary: Liverpool and Tottenham Hotspur face off in the UEFA Champions League Final, marking an all-English showdown. Tottenham manager Mauricio Pochettino celebrated the team's shock result, wearing an IWC Pilot's Watch Timezoner Chronograph. The timepiece allows for easy time zone adjustments, as Pochettino will need to set it for the current time zone in Madrid for the upcoming final against Liverpool.

site_title: Hyflux suitor Utico seeks delay over water unit; PUB says 'no'
summary: Utico, an Emirati utilities group, is seeking a delay in taking over Hyflux's water unit, citing a need to secure funds for Hyflux's junior creditors, including preference share holders who invested S$900 million. Utico has proposed a potential S$400 million cash injection into Hyflux, but PUB, the national water agency, has refused to delay its seizure of the Tuaspring desalination plant. Utico has invited Hyflux's junior creditors to a town hall meeting to discuss a potential win-win deal.

site_title: Bonds climb, stocks slip as trade tensions fester
summary: Global bond markets rose amid trade tensions, while stocks fell in Europe and Asia. US equity futures declined after President Trump restricted Huawei's access to the American market. Treasuries edged higher, sending 10-year note yields to their lowest level since 2017. Investors increased bets on the Federal Reserve cutting borrowing costs later this year due to fragile business confidence.

site_title: Authentic Flavours Of Barcelona
summary: In Barcelona, authentic Catalan cuisine shines through in various restaurants. Disfrutar, with two Michelin stars, offers a playful yet real culinary experience rooted in Catalan heritage, featuring dishes like spherified pea pearls and a Salvador Dali-inspired 'painting'. Sergi de Meià's restaurant stays strictly Catalan, using regionally sourced ingredients, while Informal, run by Marc Gascons, presents traditional Catalan cooking with modern twists. These restaurants showcase the unique flavors and traditions of Catalan cuisine, which sets it apart from the rest of Spain.

site_title: Sakae posts S$6.1m Q3 loss on S$3.2m goodwill charge for Chilean unit
summary: Sakae Holdings reported a S$6.1 million net loss for its third quarter, reversing from a profit in the same period last year, due to a S$3.2 million goodwill impairment charge for its Chilean seafood trader. Revenue decreased 0.8% and operating expenses nearly tripled, with the group expecting challenging operating conditions in the next 12 months. The company will continue to take reasonable steps to ensure growth and effective cost management, despite negative operating cash flow of about S$100,000.

site_title: Euro edges higher on hopes of auto tariffs delay
summary: The euro edged higher against the dollar and sterling on Thursday as US officials announced a possible delay in implementing tariffs on autos, adding 0.1-0.2% to the single currency. However, concerns about domestic politics and the European parliamentary elections limited the euro's gain. The Japanese yen also rose, supported by falling bond yields, while the Australian dollar dropped to a five-month low due to domestic economic data.

site_title: Alliance is done with capital raising for now
summary: Alliance Mineral Assets, an Australia-based miner listed on the Singapore Stock Exchange, has completed its A$32.5 million equity fundraising. Galaxy Resources emerged as the largest shareholder with an 11.83% stake, while Weier Antriebe und Energietechnik increased its stake to 9.08%. This marks the end of Alliance's capital raising efforts for now.

site_title: Eagle Hospitality Trust prices IPO at US$0.78, below indications
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) has priced its initial public offering (IPO) at US$0.78 per stapled security, below the indicated range of US$0.80 to US$0.81. The trust, backed by Urban Commons, will raise US$565.8 million to pay for the purchase price of its initial portfolio and working capital. EHT has projected an annualized yield of 8.2% for the forecast period from May 1, 2019 to Dec 31, 2019, with an expected increase of 2.4% for 2020.

site_title: New British Cuisine
summary: British cuisine is gaining recognition, with chefs like Clare Smyth and Nuno Mendes showcasing the country's produce in their restaurants. CORE by Clare Smyth, a two-Michelin-starred fine dining restaurant, celebrates British heritage through its menu, which features ingredients like Jerusalem artichoke and smoked eel. Mãos, a 16-seater dining experience in Shoreditch, also incorporates local produce, including wasabi grown in Dorchester and red shiso leaves from Cornwall. These restaurants are part of a new wave of chefs who are redefining British cuisine, inspired by their own cultural backgrounds and a desire to promote local produce.

site_title: Music Smorgasbord
summary: Vivid Sydney kicks off in a week, featuring over 163 performances, including Dirty Three, Jonsi, Herbie Hancock, Underworld, and The Cure. The Cure's five-gig lineup has sold out, but their last show will be live-streamed on Facebook and YouTube. The festival runs from May 24 to June 15, with the full line-up available at vividsydney.com.

site_title: FCT to buy a third of Waterway Point from Frasers Property for S$440.6m
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) is set to acquire a one-third interest in Waterway Point, a suburban mall in Punggol, Singapore, for S$440.6 million. The acquisition will be partly financed through an equity fund-raising exercise, where FCT will raise S$421.7 million in gross proceeds, with S$245.3 million going towards the Waterway Point acquisition and S$176.4 million towards paying down bridging loans. The acquisition is expected to be "DPU-accretive" and will increase FCT's gearing to 33.2%.

site_title: China blocks all language editions of Wikipedia
summary: China has blocked all language editions of Wikipedia, a move that comes ahead of its most politically explosive anniversary. The block, reported by the Open Observatory of Network Interference, affects millions of readers and volunteer editors, writers, academics, and researchers in China. China's online censorship apparatus, known as the "Great Firewall," blocks foreign sites, including Google and Facebook, and has previously blocked Wikipedia's Chinese language version in 2015. The move is seen as a symbol of the Chinese authorities' fear of the truth and their control over information.

site_title: Wealthy Geneva at risk of losing its allure
summary: Geneva, a hub for wealthy individuals and multinational corporations, faces a decline in its allure as companies increasingly set up elsewhere. The city's economy, which relies heavily on these corporations, is at risk. MNCs account for 76,000 jobs and over 40% of the city's GDP, but are moving to other locations. This shift is exemplified by a vacant six-storey building once home to a private bank, a reminder of the city's past as a destination for clandestine wealth storage. The decline poses a threat to Geneva's luxury reputation and economic stability.

site_title: Perfect Step
summary: Dumb Type, a Japanese avant-garde dance company, returns to the Singapore International Festival of Arts after 17 years with "ST/LL", a performance-installation performed on a sheet of water. The show features stunning dancers and an ambient score by Ryuichi Sakamoto, exploring the dynamics of silence, stillness, and photographs. "ST/LL" will be performed from May 24 to 25 at the Esplanade Theatre, with tickets available through Sistic. This unique production is a must-see for fans of contemporary dance and theatre.

site_title: Temasek's Vertex raises US$230m for fourth South-east Asia fund
summary: Temasek's Vertex Venture Holdings has raised US$230 million for its fourth South-east Asian fund, backing tech startups across the region and India. The fund, which is expected to be finalized in the next few months, has attracted most of its investors from its third fund. Vertex, which has a net internal rate of return of 45.2%, plans to continue investing in early-stage technology for financial services, enterprises, and consumers in the region. This new fund comes amid a flurry of fundraising activities in the region.

site_title: Blockchain startup Terra gets undisclosed investment from LuneX Ventures
summary: Blockchain startup Terra has secured an undisclosed investment from LuneX Ventures, a blockchain and crypto-focused arm of Singapore's Golden Gate Ventures. The funds will be used to expand Terra's payment system across South-east Asia, establish a Singapore office, and launch its payment product in the region by 2019. Terra has also recently recruited new team members from leading financial companies, including Goldman Sachs, to drive its South-east Asia expansion plan. The company aims to prioritize Singapore as a key market for its blockchain operations.

site_title: It's a buyer's market in Bangkok as glut worsens
summary: A buyer's market has emerged in Bangkok, Thailand, due to a glut of condominiums, with 65,000 new apartments added last year, an 11% increase. Tepid demand and stricter mortgage-lending rules have led to a 6% decrease in average asking prices. Experts predict the market will enter an equilibrium stage, with prices adjusted to a more realistic level, as Thailand's economy wavers and China's economic slowdown affects foreign property buyers.

site_title: Former Australian PM Bob Hawke, 89, dies
summary: Former Australian Prime Minister Bob Hawke, 89, has died. Hawke, a charismatic left-wing lawmaker, served as prime minister from 1983 to 1991 and implemented economic reforms that led to a wave of economic growth. He introduced universal healthcare, strengthened social security, and enacted stronger environmental legislation. Hawke's legacy was praised by his successors, including Prime Minister Scott Morrison and Labor Party leader Bill Shorten, who described him as a great Australian who loved and served the country with passion and courage.

images.alt_text: Mr Hawke served as Australian prime minister from 1983 to 1991.

site_title: Boeing crashes leave US$450m bill for European insurers
summary: Europe's largest insurers, including Munich Re, Swiss Re, and Hannover Re, face potential losses of up to US$450 million from Boeing 737 Max plane crashes in Ethiopia and Indonesia. The insurers' losses are on paper only, with payouts expected to take months or years to materialize. Investigators are examining the cause of the crashes, which may impact payouts. Boeing's insurance policies, including a manufacturer's liability policy capped at US$500 million, will also be scrutinized.

site_title: Jeff Koons sculpture smashes record at auction for work by a living artist
summary: Jeff Koons' 1986 stainless steel sculpture "Rabbit" sold for a record-breaking $91.1 million at Christie's auction, surpassing the previous record held by David Hockney's 1972 painting "Portrait of an Artist (Pool With Two Figures)". The sculpture, inspired by a child's inflatable toy, was made in an edition of three and was the last example left in private hands. The sale confirms Koons' metal sculptures as the ultimate "billionaire trophies" of the contemporary art boom of the 1980s and 1990s.

site_title: The value of Burgundy, regardless of the price
summary: Burgundy wine has become the most coveted wine globally due to its limited production capacity and high prices. Despite being a small region, Burgundy produces a relatively small amount of wine, and recent frosts and hailstorms have further reduced output. The prices of Burgundy wines have increased significantly over the past 20 years, making them unaffordable for most people. To understand Burgundy, wine enthusiasts must spend more than they are comfortable with, as the region's influence on wine producers worldwide is unparalleled, shaping the way vineyards are managed and wines are made.

site_title: IMF says Sri Lanka budget, current account deficits could widen after bombings
summary: Sri Lanka's budget and current account deficits may widen due to the Easter Sunday bombings, which killed over 250 people. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) predicts the economy will recover in the medium-term, with 5% annual growth, but may slide to 2.5% this year. The bombings have hurt business confidence and tourism, exacerbating existing economic challenges. The IMF expects fiscal and external current account deficits to be wider than initially projected, but notes that normalcy has largely returned to the island.

site_title: White House asks people to report 'political bias' by social media
summary: The White House is launching a form for reporting alleged social media bias, encouraging all Americans to share their experiences with potential censorship of political views. The form aims to collect data on instances where users were suspended, banned, or unfairly reported for violating user policies. The collected information will not be shared with the president's re-election campaign, but its purpose and distribution beyond the White House are unclear. The move follows increasing pressure on social media companies like Facebook and Twitter over alleged political bias.

site_title: Vietnam eyes US avocado market after Trump spat with Mexico
