The offshore yuan has slumped 2.4% this month, reaching its weakest since December, amid intensified trade tensions. This could lead to a significant reduction in China's $15.9 trillion US Treasury holdings, which would have far-reaching implications for global financial markets. Beijing has already increased levies on American goods in retaliation for US tariff hikes.

site_title: Rumours fuelling crypto rally get debunked, leaving enthusiasts deflated
summary: Cryptocurrency enthusiasts were disappointed after rumors of mainstream acceptance and new company entries into the crypto space were debunked. Speculation about companies like eBay and TD Ameritrade Holding joining the crypto market fueled the recent rally in token prices. However, the Consensus conference in New York failed to deliver on these promises, leaving investors deflated. The news may have a negative impact on the crypto market, which has been experiencing a surge in prices.

site_title: Amid rising trade tensions, UOB to double down on Asean-China flows: CEO
summary: UOB plans to double down on Asean-China flows, capturing greater connectivity revenue in the region. The bank expects rising global trade tensions to drive more businesses to diversify supply chains into Asean, benefiting local suppliers. Currently, 40% of UOB's group operating profit comes from outside Singapore, with 80% from Asean and Greater China operations. The bank aims to strengthen regional connectivity, ecosystem partnerships, and balance sheet quality earnings, with Asean expected to have its GDP more than double by 2030.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at Wednesday's open; STI down 0.1% to 3,219.37
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.13% to 3,219.37. Despite US stocks rebounding from Monday's sell-off, the Singapore market declined due to a lack of significant earnings announcements. Singtel posted a 0.4% rise in fourth-quarter net profit, while Mapletree Logistics Trust advanced 2.1%. The decline was attributed to evenly matched gainers and losers, with 56 securities up and 55 down. The market will continue to watch US-China trade developments and GDP data.

site_title: Saudi Arabia's 200b riyal non-oil stimulus may last beyond 2021
summary: Saudi Arabia's 200 billion riyal non-oil stimulus package may last beyond 2021, with a possible extension into 2022, according to Naif Al-Rasheed, managing director of the Private Sector Stimulus Office. The program aims to boost private-sector growth, promote exports, and invest in new technologies, with 36 billion riyals allocated for this year and 40 billion riyals already spent. The office plans to spend 22 billion riyals next year and 25 billion in 2021, with the goal of creating over 86,000 jobs and contributing 150 billion riyals to the economy.

site_title: ST Engineering Q1 profit up 11% to S$131.1m
summary: ST Engineering's first-quarter net profit increased 11% to S$131.1 million, driven by improved US shipbuilding performance and increased profits in aerospace and electronics. Revenue rose 5% to S$1.73 billion, but net profit for land systems declined due to unfavorable sales mix and higher operating expenses. The company's shares closed down 0.5% and no dividend was recommended for the quarter. ST Engineering's order book stands at S$14.1 billion, with S$4.2 billion expected to be delivered in the remaining months of 2019.

site_title: South Korea jobless rate rises to 3-month high in April
summary: South Korea's unemployment rate rose to 4.1% in April, the highest in three months, due to job losses in the manufacturing and construction sectors. This marks a nine-year high, with 171,000 jobs added in April, down from 250,000 in the previous month. The healthcare and social service sector saw a gain of 127,000 jobs. The country's job market remains under pressure, prompting President Moon Jae-in to consider additional measures to boost employment.

site_title: Walmart mulls stock market listing for UK arm Asda
summary: Walmart is considering a stock market listing for its UK arm Asda, citing a path to an initial public offering (IPO) to strengthen the supermarket's long-term success. Asda's attempt to combine with Sainsbury's was blocked by the UK regulator last month. The decision to pursue an IPO would take years, according to Walmart International CEO Judith McKenna. The move aims to provide Asda with increased financial flexibility and support for its growth strategy.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, ST Engineering, CDL, Sembcorp Industries, Memtech
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several Singaporean companies released their Q1 earnings reports, with notable increases in net profit for Singtel (0.4% rise), ST Engineering (11% rise), City Developments Limited (more than doubled), and Sembcorp Industries (21% rise). Memtech International is set to be delisted after a voluntary conditional offer to buy the company at S$1.35 per share. Meanwhile, Yanlord Land posted a net loss, Straits Trading Company saw a 78.1% increase in net profit, and Isetan Singapore reported a 29.65% increase in net profit. The Singapore stock market closed up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Trump Jr agrees to testify in Senate in Russia probe: US media
summary: US President Donald Trump's son Donald Jr has agreed to testify before the Senate Intelligence Committee investigating Russian election meddling. The agreement resolves a fight between the Congress and the White House after Donald Jr was subpoenaed by the Republican-led committee. He will testify behind closed doors with limits on time and questions. This move comes as the Senate panel seeks clarification on his knowledge of contacts between the 2016 Trump presidential campaign and Russians.

site_title: Huawei chairman says ready to sign 'no-spy' deal with UK
summary: Huawei chairman Liang Hua said the company is willing to sign a "no-spy" agreement with the UK government to commit to meeting security standards. The move comes as the UK weighs the risks of allowing Huawei to develop its 5G infrastructure. Meanwhile, US President Donald Trump is expected to sign an executive order banning US companies from using equipment made by firms posing a national security risk, potentially paving the way for a ban on doing business with Huawei.

site_title: Angry taxi drivers block airport as Cannes festival opens
summary: French taxi drivers blocked Nice airport on May 14, 2019, over a dispute with online ride-hailing services, disrupting traffic for hours. The drivers, who were demanding restrictions on ride-sharing rivals, suspended the protest mid-afternoon but vowed to resume the strike on Friday. A woman taxi driver was knocked down and filed a complaint with police, while authorities reported a 15% increase in airport traffic due to the Cannes film festival. The protest was part of an anti-fraud drive, which the taxi drivers claim private hire drivers have evaded.

site_title: A flood of toxic loans in China is a bonanza for debt buyers
summary: Chinese banks are rushing to offload soured loans, giving debt buyers more bargaining power. As of March, China's outstanding bad loans reached a record 2.16 trillion yuan. The government's encouragement of banks to classify corporate loans overdue for more than 60 days as nonperforming has led to a surge in the sale of bad debt. Investors are embracing cheaper and bigger supply of bad loans, with prices expected to drop 30-40% of book value this year. This is a boon for debt buyers, with many firms planning to evaluate more portfolios.

site_title: WhatsApp security breach may have targeted human rights groups
summary: WhatsApp has disclosed a security breach that may have targeted human rights groups, with signs suggesting a government or private company using surveillance technology developed by NSO Group, an Israeli cyber surveillance company. WhatsApp notified the US Department of Justice and encouraged users to update the app, but did not disclose how many users were affected. The breach allowed attackers to inject spyware on phones via WhatsApp's voice-calling function, with a human rights lawyer in the UK reportedly targeted. WhatsApp and NSO Group declined to comment, but the company said it would investigate any "credible allegations of misuse" of its technology.

images.alt_text: WhatsApp said on Tuesday that a security breach on its messaging app had signs of coming from a government using surveillance technology developed by a private company, and it may have targeted human rights groups.

site_title: US lawmakers want to tighten visas for Chinese students, researchers
summary: US lawmakers, led by Republican Senators, introduced legislation to prohibit Chinese military-affiliated individuals from receiving US student or research visas. The bill would create a list of institutions affiliated with the Chinese People's Liberation Army and restrict visas for those employed or sponsored by them. The move comes amid escalating trade tensions and concerns over intellectual property theft or espionage by Chinese nationals at US universities. The bill was sponsored by five Republican Senators and a companion bill was introduced in the House of Representatives.

site_title: Britain's May to launch new push on her Brexit deal in June
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May will launch a new push to secure approval for her Brexit deal by June, setting a new deadline for ratification before the summer break. The Withdrawal Agreement Bill, which implements the terms of Britain's departure from the EU, is expected to be brought forward in the week beginning June 3. However, Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn has raised doubts over the bill's credibility, and May is under pressure from her own party to set a date for her departure.

site_title: Saudi cabinet approves special residency scheme for foreign expats
summary: Saudi Arabia's cabinet has approved a special residency scheme for foreign expats, similar to green card systems in other countries. The plan aims to attract wealthy and high-skilled individuals, offering defined and renewable residency or permanent stay in exchange for a one-off fee. Expats would enjoy free movement, property ownership, and business opportunities in the kingdom. The move is seen as a shift away from the current sponsorship system, which requires expats to be sponsored by a Saudi employer and obtain an exit/re-entry visa.

site_title: US warns EU over 'poison pill' defence plans
summary: The US has warned the European Union that its plans to boost defence cooperation within the bloc could harm decades of transatlantic cooperation and damage NATO. The US sent a letter to EU diplomatic and security chief Federica Mogherini, warning that "poison pills" embedded in proposed rules could shut out third-country allies like the US. The US demands a rapid response and threatens reciprocal sanctions, while the EU insists it remains open to American defence manufacturers. The US concerns focus on the European Defence Fund and PESCO, which could lead to a "dramatic reversal" of integration.

site_title: Victory awaits in China trade war, Trump tells farmers
summary: US President Donald Trump has reassured farmers that they will benefit from the ongoing trade war with China, despite the tariffs biting into their industry. China has raised tariffs on $60 billion in US agricultural and manufactured goods in retaliation for Trump's decision to raise tariffs on $200 billion in Chinese merchandise. US farmers, who are major exporters of pork and soy, have seen exports to China decline by 75% and are concerned about the impact of the trade war on their incomes and livelihoods. Trump claims that the government will make up the difference by buying crops to prop up prices, and he predicts a "little squabble" will ultimately lead to US victory.

site_title: BRC Asia's Q2 profit soars to S$5.4m
summary: BRC Asia's second-quarter net profit soared to S$5.4 million, eight times its profit for the same period last year, driven by higher revenue from sales orders and better buying power. Revenue more than doubled to S$231.1 million, with construction demand expected to grow due to mega projects in the transport sector. The company adopted new dividend policies, targeting a minimum annual dividend of 30% of net profit for fiscal 2019 and 2020.

site_title: Reports of suspected slavery rise by 36% in Britain
summary: Reports of suspected modern slavery in Britain increased by 36% in 2018, with 6,993 cases referred to the National Referral Mechanism, according to the National Crime Agency. Campaigners say the true scale of the problem is likely much larger, with estimates suggesting at least 136,000 modern slaves in the UK. Authorities have launched initiatives to enlist public help, but some argue that victims are being deported to countries where they risk further exploitation. The government has pledged to support victims and prevent deportation to countries of origin if they are at risk of persecution.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Chasing Cars: Cool commercial pick-ups
summary: SGCarmart's Julian Kho and Claressa Monteiro discuss the coolest commercial pick-ups on the market. They share their favorites, including the MG ZS Hybrid+, BMW's adrenaline tourism, and the Jaecoo J7. The conversation focuses on the unique features and capabilities of these vehicles, highlighting the latest trends in the automotive industry. No clear winners were mentioned, but the discussion emphasizes the variety of options available for car buyers.

site_title: China still most attractive renewables market despite subsidy cuts: EY
summary: China remains the most attractive renewable energy market, ranking first for the fourth consecutive year, according to a report by Ernst & Young. Despite subsidy cuts, China's renewable energy growth is expected to continue due to declining technology costs and international interest. The US takes second place, and France moves to third, with India dropping to fourth. The report highlights the growing use of power purchase agreements (PPAs) as a key driver of renewable energy investment, with 13.4 GW of clean energy generation supported by PPAs in 2018.

site_title: US growth would have contracted without trillions in government, consumer debt: DoubleLine CEO
summary: US growth appears to be based "exclusively" on government, corporate, and mortgage debt, according to DoubleLine Capital CEO Jeffrey Gundlach. Without trillions in debt, US growth would have contracted, with nominal GDP rising by 4.3% over the past five years, but total public debt rising by 4.7%. Gundlach warns that the US economy is heading into a volatile environment, citing a declining Citi Economic Data Change Index, and is "comfortably" long gold, predicting prices to reach $1,300 an ounce.

site_title: Walmart speeds up delivery in race with Amazon
summary: Walmart has started offering free next-day deliveries on online purchases, aiming to compete with Amazon. The service is initially available in Phoenix and Las Vegas, with plans to expand to 75% of the US this year. Eligible items, including 200,000 frequently purchased products, will be shipped free on orders of $35 or more. Unlike Amazon, Walmart won't require a membership fee, citing lower delivery costs due to consolidation at single fulfillment centers. The move aims to boost shopping and membership for Walmart, which expects to reduce costs and compete with Amazon's Prime subscription benefits.

site_title: Putin says he senses Trump genuinely wants to repair US-Russia ties
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin stated that US President Donald Trump genuinely wants to repair relations between Russia and the US. Putin also denied Russia's interference in US elections and expressed interest in discussing global energy market stability. This comes after US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo warned Russia against interfering in the 2020 US presidential election. The two leaders are set to discuss these topics during their talks.

site_title: Nissan earnings slide fuels Renault deal pressure
summary: Renault is pushing for a change in Nissan leadership as the Japanese carmaker warned of a 45% earnings slide due to the Carlos Ghosn scandal. Renault chairman Jean-Dominique Senard sees Nissan boss Hiroto Saikawa as an obstacle to progress and is seeking a tie-up between the two companies, which Saikawa has refused to discuss. A preliminary meeting of Nissan directors is set for Wednesday, and Renault is expected to continue pushing for talks, citing performance as the impetus.

site_title: Mexico creates database of clandestine graves
summary: Mexico has created a database of hundreds of clandestine graves discovered across the country, with over 40,000 missing persons and 250,000 murders since 2006 linked to drug trafficking. President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador blames his predecessors for the "militarized war on drugs," which has led to widespread violence. The database, covering 20 years, is expected to shed light on the thousands of bodies found in the graves, with some estimates suggesting there may be far more than initially reported. Lopez Obrador has vowed a change in strategy, declaring the drug war over.

site_title: The future of sustainable energy in Singapore
summary: Experts say Singapore's future of sustainable energy is bright, with initiatives like the SolarNova programme and research on renewable energy. A recent forum on clean energy brought together leading experts, including Geneco and SEAS, to discuss how businesses can transition to a low-carbon model. The event highlighted the potential of renewable energy and energy efficiency projects, as well as the importance of carbon credits and offsets. Geneco, one of Singapore's leading electricity retailers, emphasized its commitment to making sustainable energy more accessible and has implemented innovative solutions, such as digital customer journeys and solar energy purchasing options.

site_title: More Roundup trials, appeals in store for Bayer after US$2b verdict
summary: A California jury awarded over $2 billion in damages to a couple alleging Bayer's glyphosate-based weed killer Roundup caused their cancers, the third successive loss by Bayer in US courts. Bayer denies the allegations, citing decades of studies and regulatory approvals showing glyphosate and Roundup to be safe for human use. The verdict highlights the legal risks and mounting cost to the company of the burgeoning litigation over its widely-used herbicide.

site_title: US Treasury chief to plan for trade meeting in China soon
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin plans for a trade meeting in China at some point soon, according to a Treasury spokesman. This comes as US President Donald Trump has stated that dialogue with Beijing will continue. Mnuchin's meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping is planned for late June at the Group of 20 leaders summit in Japan. The timing of the visit has not been disclosed.

images.alt_text: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin will plan for another trade meeting in China at some point soon, a Treasury spokesman said on Tuesday, adding to US President Donald Trump's earlier statements that US dialogue with Beijing was continuing.

site_title: Google to push new ads on its apps to snare shoppers
summary: Google is expanding its advertising on its apps to boost revenue from mobile shoppers. The company will feature ads on the homepage of its smartphone app worldwide, show more ads in Maps, and place ads with image galleries in search results. This move comes as Google faces choppy revenue growth and competition from Amazon and Facebook. The changes aim to make it easier for users to discover and buy new products, particularly while shopping in spurts.

site_title: US: Stocks bounce back as trade rhetoric cools
summary: US stocks rebounded on Tuesday, regaining some lost ground from the previous day's steep sell-off. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq rose, led by technology stocks, as investors were reassured by a toned-down US-China trade rhetoric. President Trump referred to the trade war as "a little squabble" and stated that the US and China have agreed to continue discussions. This shift in rhetoric helped to calm investors' nerves, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 0.82%.

site_title: Oil prices jump on drone attack on Saudi Aramco facilities
summary: Oil prices rose nearly 2% on Tuesday after a drone attack on Saudi Aramco facilities by a Yemeni-armed movement aligned to Iran. Brent futures increased 1.6% to $71.36 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 1.4% to $61.89 a barrel. Saudi Energy Minister Khalid al-Falih stated that Aramco production and exports were not disrupted, despite halting East-West pipeline pumping for evaluation.

site_title: Nissan mulls buying 25% stake in Chinese electric-car startup
summary: Nissan is considering investing up to 25% in a Chinese electric-car startup, aiming to bolster its presence in the world's largest EV market. The Japanese company is evaluating three potential targets, including WM Motor Technology Co, Zhejiang Hozon New Energy Automobile Co, and CHJ Automotive Co. The move is part of Nissan's efforts to expand its EV ambitions, despite facing a slowdown in US sales and an aging model lineup. The investment is seen as a strategic move to counter rivals such as Volkswagen and Tesla, which are strengthening their presence in China.

site_title: Trump expected to sign order paving way for US telecoms ban on Huawei
summary: US President Donald Trump is expected to sign an executive order this week barring US companies from using telecommunications equipment made by firms posing a national security risk, paving the way for a ban on Huawei. The order would invoke the International Emergency Economic Powers Act and direct the Commerce Department to draw up a plan for enforcement. The move comes as the US and China escalate tensions over trade and security concerns, with the US accusing Huawei of being used by the Chinese state to spy.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump is expected to sign an executive order this week barring US companies from using telecommunications equipment made by firms posing a national security risk, paving the way for a ban on doing business with China's Huawei, three US officials familiar with the plan told Reuters.

site_title: Uber drivers are contractors, not employees, US labour agency says
summary: The US labour agency's general counsel has concluded that Uber drivers are independent contractors, not employees, in an advisory memo. The recommendation, made on April 16, is likely to impact a pending case against the company and prevent drivers from joining a union. The general counsel cited that drivers set their own hours, own their cars, and can work for competitors, meeting the criteria for independent contractors under federal labour law. This decision may have significant implications for the company and its drivers.

images.alt_text: Drivers for ride-hailing company Uber Technologies are independent contractors and not employees, the general counsel of a US labor agency has concluded, in an advisory memo that is likely to carry significant weight in a pending case against the company and could prevent drivers from joining a union.

site_title: Amazon rolls out machines that pack orders and replace jobs
summary: Amazon is rolling out machines to automate packing orders in its warehouses, replacing jobs held by thousands of workers. The company is considering installing machines at dozens of warehouses, which would remove at least 24 roles at each facility. This move aims to reduce labor costs and boost profits, with the goal of recovering costs in under two years. Amazon plans to use the efficiency savings to create new jobs in other areas of the business, but critics warn that the company is prioritizing profits over public goodwill and employee welfare.

site_title: Wealth advisers flee big banks for smaller firms
summary: Wealth advisers are increasingly leaving large banks for smaller firms, seeking greater control and a larger share of revenue. Four UBS bankers, managing $530 million in client assets, have formed a new firm called Great Diamond Partners, while five Bank of America advisers and a $6 billion Morgan Stanley team have also made the move. Technology ventures like Dynasty Financial Partners are facilitating this trend, providing record-keeping and product offerings. Most breakaway teams retain around 87% of their client assets, and experts predict that independent and hybrid investment advisers will make up 28% of the market by 2020.

site_title: Investors shed European safe-haven bonds on trade talk hopes
summary: Investors have shifted their focus from European safe-haven bonds to trade talks, causing yields to rise away from six-week lows. China's conciliatory tone in trade talks with the US has boosted market sentiment, with European bond yields increasing. Italy faces a test of investor appetite for its debt with a bond auction this week, amid rising yields and concerns about the country's public finances. Despite the positive tone, analysts expect public discord to grow in Rome ahead of European elections.

site_title: 'Dark year' for France as LGBT+ assaults hit record in 2018
summary: Physical attacks on LGBT+ individuals in France reached a record high in 2018, with 321 cases reported, a 66% increase from 2017. This year marked a "dark year" for the community, with complaints of harassment and discrimination rising 15% to 1,905 cases. The majority of incidents occurred in public spaces, at work, or in school. A new plan to combat LGBT+ discrimination is expected to be presented by the government in the coming weeks. Despite a 34% increase in reported victims of homophobic acts, only two out of 10 actions from the government's November plan were taken.

site_title: Marriott planning major makeover for 'beige' Sheratons
summary: Marriott International is revamping the Sheraton brand with a major makeover, starting with the $255 million purchase of the Sheraton Grand Phoenix. The 1,000-room hotel is undergoing an extensive renovation, featuring lighter-colored guest-room furniture and a more streamlined design. This project marks a significant step towards transforming the Sheraton brand into its new face.

site_title: OCBC beneficiaries' preview visit to Bicentennial Experience
summary: OCBC Bank's group CEO Samuel Tsien attended a preview of "From Singapore to Singaporean: The Bicentennial Experience" with 55 vulnerable seniors and youths. The event featured a multi-sensory depiction of Singapore's 200-year history, including an interactive exhibit at Pathfinder. Guests praised the highlight of the show, Act 5, which commemorated ordinary Singaporeans' contributions. CEO Tsien said the experience aims to recognize the past contributions of ordinary Singaporeans and inspire them to continue giving their best to society. The event was seen as a meaningful reminder of Singapore's progress.

site_title: Europe: Stocks regain ground, hoping for smoother US-China trade
summary: European stocks regained ground on Tuesday, recovering most of the previous day's losses due to optimistic comments from US and Chinese leaders about trade talks. The pan-European STOXX 600 index rose 1%, with trade-sensitive stocks such as autos and tech gaining 2.2% and 1.2% respectively. Despite the gains, the STOXX 600 remains down 3.8% for the month, its biggest monthly loss since December.

site_title: Cézanne chromatic still life sells for US$59.3m at auction
summary: A Paul Cézanne painting, "Bouilloire et Fruits" (Pitcher and Fruit), sold for $59.3 million at Christie's auction in New York, part of a week-long series of marquee auctions expected to raise $1.6 billion. The painting, one of 11 from the estate of billionaire magazine publisher S I Newhouse Jr, was sold above its estimated $40 million price tag. The sale, which also included works by Jeff Koons and Amedeo Modigliani, saw five Newhouse entries bring in $101 million, with some art experts noting that tastes have changed and Impressionist and modern works may struggle to hold value.

site_title: Foxconn's Terry Gou to sell stake in trustee-manager of Asian Pay TV Trust
summary: Foxconn founder Terry Gou plans to sell his 20% stake in the trustee-manager of Singapore-listed Asian Pay Television Trust (APTT), which will be transferred to senior executive Lu Fang-Ming. The move is part of Gou's preparations to run for Taiwan president next year. APTT posted a net profit of S$7.4 million for the first quarter, with revenue falling 4.9% year-over-year. The trust plans to pay an undetermined portion of its management fee in units from July onwards.

site_title: Chuang family offers S$1.35 a share to delist Memtech
summary: The Chuang family, led by executive chairman Chuang Wen Fu, has made a voluntary conditional offer to delist Memtech International, a Singapore-listed electronics components manufacturer, with a cash offer of S$1.35 per share. The offer values the company at S$189 million, representing a 23.9% premium over its last traded price. Keytech, a family-owned investment firm, and Universal Global Technology (UGT) are involved in the deal, with UGT investing in Memtech to diversify its capabilities. The offer will become unconditional if 90% of shares are accepted, with the offeror reserving the right to reduce the acceptance condition to 50%.

site_title: Singapore condo resale prices up 0.9% in April: SRX
summary: Singapore condo resale prices rose 0.9% in April, marking the third consecutive month-on-month increase, according to SRX Property. Non-landed resale prices were up 2% for the first four months of the year, while year-on-year prices increased 3.6%. Despite a 48.4% drop in resale units sold in April, the number of units resold was 3.4% higher than March. The resale market is likely influenced by new and upcoming property launches, with some buyers attracted to resale homes despite price increases.

site_title: Facebook raising pay for contract workers
summary: Facebook announced pay raises for its 15,000 contract moderators, citing rising living costs and the emotionally demanding nature of their work. The company also provided additional support services, including higher wages and benefits. The move comes after criticism of the tech giant's treatment of its contractors, who are responsible for reviewing graphic content on the platform.

site_title: S$20m funding sought for honestbee; no update on strategy tweak
summary: honestbee, a Singapore-based grocery delivery startup, is seeking at least S$20 million in funding following its leadership change. Before the change, the company was in talks to expand its brick-and-mortar supermarket concept, Habitat, to Japan and Thailand. However, its financial situation remains unclear, with limited visibility on its finances and a three-year backlog of financials. The startup's new CEO, Brian Koo, needs to provide more updates on its strategy to win back investor confidence.

site_title: Potential hike in Ningbo bank stake behind OCBC's conservative dividends?
summary: OCBC Bank is considering a potential hike in its stake in Bank of Ningbo, a Chinese bank, amid growing interest in China's Greater Bay Area. The bank's conservative dividend payout has raised questions among shareholders, with some speculating that the extra capital buffer is being used to build its presence in China. Analysts estimate that a 20% incremental stake in Bank of Ningbo could cost OCBC around $4 billion. The bank's strategy aims to tap into investment and capital flows between China and Southeast Asia, with a focus on organic growth and inorganic opportunities.

site_title: Risk-off stance persists as sell-off continues
summary: Asian markets continued their sell-off on Tuesday, with Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closing 0.3% lower at 3,223.71, down 10.57 points or 0.3% from Monday. The index has fallen 5% since May 3 due to US President Donald Trump's tweet about raising tariffs. China's tariff hike on US goods sparked concerns, but eased tensions after Trump expressed optimism about resolving trade issues. Defensive sectors like telcos and healthcare outperformed the market, while tech-related counters registered gains.

site_title: Policy goals are one thing. Fulfilling them is another
summary: US President Donald Trump's foreign policy goals have been hindered by a legacy system he inherited from his predecessors. Trump's internationalist approach, which emphasized regime changes and nation-building, has been opposed by many in the American foreign policy establishment. Despite Trump's efforts to adopt a more national-interest-based strategy, he has faced resistance from officials like Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and National Security Adviser John Bolton, who advocate for regime change in North Korea and Iran. This has led to increased tensions with these countries, potentially drawing the US into costly military interventions.

site_title: Temasek, UOB commit a further US$200m to venture debt firm InnoVen
summary: Singapore-based venture debt firm InnoVen Capital has secured US$200 million in additional capital from investors Temasek and United Overseas Bank (UOB). The funds will allow InnoVen to support more startups in the region, with over 200 companies already backed by the firm. InnoVen aims to disburse over US$50 million this year, providing debt to high-growth companies to help entrepreneurs accelerate growth without equity dilution. The firm has a presence in India and China, and its portfolio includes notable startups such as Pomelo Fashion and InstaReM.

site_title: Ayondo says it's 'committed to complying' with SGX's order on sale of its AML unit
summary: Ayondo, a European social trading broker, stated that its board is working closely with the Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX Regco) to comply with a Notice of Compliance (NOC) issued on April 16. The NOC was issued due to concerns over Ayondo's sale of its AML unit to BUX Holding BV, which was deemed non-binding and subject to shareholder approval. Ayondo has confirmed that there is no disregard of the SGX order, and the company is committed to meeting the conditions set by the regulator.

site_title: Tesla car catches fire in Hong Kong parking lot
summary: A Tesla Model S electric car caught fire in a Hong Kong shopping mall parking lot on Sunday, with no injuries reported. The blaze occurred 30 minutes after the vehicle was parked, and firefighters took 45 minutes to extinguish the flames. The cause of the fire was not immediately known.

site_title: London insurance market facing huge skills shortage
summary: The London insurance market is facing a significant skills shortage, with a report by KPMG and the London Market Group warning that the industry is lagging behind in adopting new technology and adopting Brexit may exacerbate hiring difficulties. The report highlights the need for underwriters and brokers to develop skills in data and analytics, and for the industry to poach staff from other sectors to improve creativity. The skills shortage is at a "tipping point" and London cannot wait for the next generation to fill the gap, with Brexit also creating a threat of an outflow of talent from the UK.

site_title: New chapter in US diplomacy playbook - alienate both China and Russia
summary: The Trump administration is pursuing a foreign policy strategy of alienating both China and Russia, reversing a decades-old approach that had stabilized the international system by improving ties with both nations. This move is seen as counterproductive, as Beijing and Moscow pose significant challenges to US interests, and may encourage them to cooperate against the US. Experts warn that this approach could lead to a destabilization of the global system, and undermine US global power.

site_title: Businesses need to prepare themselves for US-China trade war fallout: Minister Chan
summary: Singapore's Minister of Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing warned businesses to prepare for the fallout from the US-China trade war, citing increased global downside risks. He emphasized the need for diversification, upgrading business capabilities, and worker skills to stay competitive. The government will provide support to help businesses and industries stay competitive and create jobs for Singaporeans. The US-China trade war has raised tariffs on billions of dollars in goods, affecting global trade flows and business sentiment.

site_title: HSBC, Barclays said to be advising Dubai banks on Noor purchase
summary: HSBC and Barclays are advising Dubai Islamic Bank on a possible acquisition of Noor Bank, a smaller rival. The acquisition would create a lender with 278 billion dirhams in assets. The discussions are private, and the deal has not been finalized. This move could impact the banking landscape in Dubai and create a more substantial player in the market.

site_title: Singapore's JustCo secures three new co-working centres in Taipei
summary: Singapore-based co-working company JustCo has expanded to Taipei, securing three new co-working centers in the Taiwanese city. The centers, located in Xinyi, Songshan, and Zhongshan financial districts, bring the company's portfolio to 32 centers across eight cities. The flagship center in Taiwan will open in the second half of 2019, offering 65,000 square feet of office space. JustCo's expansion follows its recent announcements in South Korea and Australia, and is part of its $177 million investment in a co-working space platform across Asia.

site_title: Current state of tariff battle is already causing real harm
summary: The US and China have escalated their trade tensions, with China announcing retaliatory tariffs on $60 billion of US goods, including aircraft, computers, and liquefied natural gas, after the US increased tariffs on $200 billion of Chinese goods to 25%. The move has wiped $1 trillion from global share prices and has raised concerns about the potential for a full-blown trade war. The US has threatened to retaliate, and investors are questioning whether President Trump's approach is reckless and whether China will back down.

site_title: Edtech startup Cialfo raises US$3m in Series A funds for US expansion
summary: Cialfo, a Singapore-based college admissions platform, has raised US$3 million in Series A funds to expand its US operations. The funding, led by DLF Venture and supported by Enterprise Singapore, brings Cialfo's total funding to over US$5 million. The startup aims to grow its global presence, targeting a US$2 billion addressable market, and plans to raise Series B funds by late 2020. With 400 institutions in over 40 countries using its platform, Cialfo has seen revenue triple year on year and expects to reach 500,000 users by the end of the year.

site_title: Credit Suisse and Rothschild advising Olam on restructuring
summary: Olam International, a Singapore-based agri-food company, has hired Credit Suisse and Rothschild & Co as joint financial advisors to restructure its business. The company aims to eliminate hidden value and create a more coherent business through a possible reorganization. Olam has already exited four businesses and plans to invest $3.5 billion in 12 priority areas. The company expects a majority of divestments to unfold in the first three years of its six-year strategic plan, which also includes committing to three large investments.

site_title: Singtel stumbles towards lowest profit in 16 years, faces cost pressure
summary: Singtel, South-east Asia's largest telecom firm, is set to post its lowest annual profit in 16 years, due to slowing demand at home and intense competition in its key overseas markets. The company faces pressure to cut costs and find new sources of revenue as rivals seek to boost margins through measures such as job cuts and mergers. Singtel's net income is expected to be S$3.08 billion, marking its lowest headline profit since 2003.

site_title: Thailand unveils Senate made up of military government's allies
summary: Thailand has unveiled a Senate comprising 250 members, including military and police officials, to select the next prime minister. The Senate will vote jointly with the elected lower house on the next premier, with analysts predicting Prayuth Chan-Ocha, leader of the pro-military Palang Pracharath party, to return as premier. The move has raised concerns about the military's grip on power, with critics arguing the junta-appointed Senate can stifle the lower house. The new government will face economic challenges, including a slowing economy and a spreading drought.

site_title: Strategists betting on safe-haven assets amid market swings
summary: US-CHINA trade tensions have brought market volatility back, prompting investors to bet on safe-haven assets. Strategists expect volatility to continue, driven by trade optimism being a key market driver this year. Meanwhile, Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. In other news, the US stock market opened lower after President Trump's fresh tariff salvo on Canada, and Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall. The Singapore market notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, while MAS and PBOC announced deeper cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Trump seeks further US$1.6b to return to Moon by 2024
summary: The Trump administration has requested a $1.6 billion increase in NASA's funding for the 2020 fiscal year to accelerate the goal of returning Americans to the Moon's surface by 2024. This proposal would bring NASA's total spending to $22.6 billion. The additional funding will support the development of a human lunar landing system, with the aim of establishing a presence on the Moon by 2024, four years ahead of the previously planned timeline.

site_title: Final Basel III proposals 'credit positive' for local banks: Moody's
summary: Moody's Investors Service has deemed the proposed final Basel III rules as "credit positive" for Singapore banks, maintaining their "very strong capital ratios". The rules, set to be implemented from 2022 to 2027, will introduce risk-weighted assets output floors to reduce variability and enhance comparability. Singapore banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB are expected to see a small increase in mortgage risk-weighted assets, but overall RWAs will remain stable. No significant deterioration in capital ratios is anticipated among the three banks.

site_title: Foreland Fabrictech's newly appointed independent director quits after SGX queries
summary: Foreland Fabrictech Holdings announced the resignation of independent non-executive director Soh Yong Soon, effective May 13, following queries by the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on his suitability. Soh was appointed just five days prior to his resignation, taking on roles including chairman of the audit, nominating, and remuneration committees. The reason for his resignation remains unclear.

site_title: FamilyMart's China business threatened by partners' feud
summary: FamilyMart, a Japanese convenience-store chain, is embroiled in a royalty payments dispute with its Chinese joint-venture partner Ting Hsin International Group. FamilyMart is suing Ting Hsin to end the partnership, alleging the company hasn't fairly shared profits and withholding royalty payments. The dispute could impact FamilyMart's Chinese operations, which are set to grow to $27 billion in the next five years. The company's stock has dropped 2.2% following the news, amid a larger trend of foreign brands seeking to alter local partnerships in China's rapidly growing convenience-store market.

site_title: WhatsApp urges update after 'serious' security breach
summary: WhatsApp has urged users to update the app after a 'serious' security breach that allowed sophisticated attackers to insert spyware into phones. The vulnerability, fixed in the latest update, allowed hackers to insert malicious software on phones by calling the target using the app, which is used by 1.5 billion people worldwide. The breach is attributed to the NSO Group, an Israel-based firm accused of helping governments spy on activists and journalists, and WhatsApp has reported the matter to US authorities and the Data Protection Commission in Ireland.

site_title: Boeing slumps after editor's tweet raises prospect of lost China sales
summary: Boeing shares plummeted to a four-month low after editor Hu Xijin of the Global Times warned that China may stop purchasing US agricultural and energy products, cut Boeing orders, and restrict trade in American services, potentially impacting the company's sales. The tweet heightened US-China trade tensions and raised concerns about Boeing's largest market, China, which has carefully split its aircraft orders between Boeing and Airbus. Analysts expect a lengthy review of the 737 Max by Chinese regulators, further exacerbating Boeing's challenges.

images.alt_text: China is the largest global market for the 737, Boeing's main source of profit.

site_title: Utico has so far submitted draft term sheet, not binding offer: Hyflux
summary: Hyflux clarified that Utico's submission of a "draft term sheet" is not a binding offer, contrary to a Reuters report. The term sheet was sent to Hyflux on May 6 and is to be regarded as binding, but Hyflux has not accepted or entered into any binding agreement. Hyflux is currently engaged in discussions with Utico's advisors to finalize the proposed terms, while also engaging with Oyster Bay Fund as another potential investor.

site_title: SoCash turns shops into cheaper ATMs for banks
summary: SoCash, a Singapore startup backed by Vertex, aims to reduce banks' expenses by converting shops into cheaper ATMs. The company estimates banks spend around $200 million annually on ATM maintenance and other expenses. SoCash is seeking a $8 million Series B funding round by end-June to further its mission.

site_title: Slow progress on recycling
summary: Hong Kong's Hong Kong International Convention for the Safe and Environmentally Sound Recycling of Ships, adopted in 2009, remains unenforced 10 years later. The EU has implemented its own recycling rules, addressing environmental concerns and working conditions in ship demolition sites. The convention aims to ensure safe and environmentally sound recycling without compromising ship safety and efficiency. Despite its adoption, the convention's implementation lags behind, with no significant progress in 10 years.

site_title: EU and Singapore: accelerating digital transformation and delivering value
summary: The European Union and Singapore are accelerating digital transformation and delivering value through their collaboration. Singapore, a trailblazer in digital government, has launched its national e-authentication and digital signature scheme, while the EU has created the eIDAS Regulation to facilitate the recognition of electronic identification schemes across borders. The EU aims to set up the Digital Single Market, enabling the free movement of goods, capital, services, and labor in the digital domain. A key aspect of this is interoperable public services, which the EU has achieved through its European Interoperability Framework. The EU and Singapore are also working together to improve cybersecurity, recognizing the importance of the human factor in combating cyber threats.

site_title: China, US agree on continuing talks
summary: China and the US have agreed to continue talks on their trade dispute, despite ramping up tariffs against each other. US President Donald Trump said recent discussions in Beijing were successful, while Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Geng Shuang expressed optimism about the talks. China will not be bullied and will defend its interests, while the US plans to hold a public hearing on imposing duties of up to 25% on $300 billion worth of imports. The global economy is at risk due to the ongoing trade tensions.

site_title: Many Americans will need long-term care. Most won't be able to afford it
summary: A growing number of Americans, particularly those in the middle-income class, are facing financial insecurity in their pursuit of long-term care. By 2029, an estimated 14.4 million middle-income seniors will need assistance with daily living activities, with 80% having less than $60,000 in income and assets. The industry's focus on serving the affluent has left middle-income seniors with limited options, with many considering selling their homes to finance long-term care. Policymakers are exploring incremental changes, including expanding Medicaid coverage and tax credits for low-income senior housing.

images.alt_text: Retired attorney Gretchen Harris has assorted health problems and will need assisted living. Her pension and Social Security provide her with US$4,600 a month. A one-bedroom assisted living unit already charges US$3,425, a figure projected to rise.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: SIIC Environment Holdings received government approval to operate a wastewater treatment plant in China. Impossible Foods secured $300 million in funding, bringing total equity funding to over $750 million. Alliance Minerals requested a trading halt due to a capital raise announcement. NTT DC Reit's public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed, while Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade, and Indonesia detained an employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case.

site_title: Opec sees more 2019 demand for its oil as it keeps cutting output
summary: OPEC forecasts higher 2019 oil demand due to slower supply growth from non-OPEC producers, particularly US shale. Despite cutting output, OPEC's April output fell by 3,000 bpd, and the group's share of the agreed supply cut is 800,000 bpd. This suggests a potential 2019 supply deficit of over 500,000 bpd if OPEC maintains current production levels. The Opec+ group will meet next month to review whether to maintain the production-limiting deal beyond June.

site_title: Nexon's parent delays bidding for its stake
summary: Nexon's parent company has delayed bidding for its controlling stake in the company, which was scheduled for this week, citing uncertainty. The postponement has sent Nexon's shares sharply lower. The deal, valued at potentially $16 billion, would be one of South Korea's biggest and the largest gaming deal worldwide. The delay raises concerns for the future of the deal, which had been expected to be finalized next week.

site_title: Straits Trading first-quarter earnings up 78% at S$17m
summary: Straits Trading Company reported a 78.1% increase in first-quarter earnings to S$17.3 million, driven by a 78% rise in real estate profits to S$12.4 million. The company's property portfolio saw significant growth, with revenue more than doubling to S$9.5 million. Despite challenges in the tin mining and smelting segment, Straits Trading remains optimistic, citing opportunities to unlock the development potential of a freehold land and a new smelter expected to be operational by 2020.

site_title: Has the BJP lost its mojo in the core Hindi heartland?
summary: The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) is expected to lose massively in the northern Hindi heartland in the upcoming general election due to widespread voter discontent over the government's failure to address farmers' debt, demonetization, and Goods and Services Tax, as well as rising youth unemployment. A study by two Indian professors suggests the BJP's fortunes in the election rest largely on its performance in the Hindi heartland. The BJP's refusal to help distressed farmers and acknowledge the jobless crisis has fanned voter discontent, potentially leading to a loss in the election.

site_title: Allianz's managed assets reach record after clients add 18b euros
summary: Allianz's managed assets have reached a record high of 1.55 trillion euros, driven by 18 billion euros added by clients in the first quarter. This growth reverses outflows from last year and brings the total managed assets under Allianz's insurance and investment businesses to 2.1 trillion euros. The company's investment businesses, including Pacific Investment Management Co and Allianz Global Investors, are among the largest globally.

site_title: Asia's spot oil prices rise to multi-year highs on tight supply
summary: Asia's spot oil prices have surged to multi-year highs due to tightened global supplies. US sanctions on Iran and Venezuela, disruptions in Russian oil flows, and maintenance at oilfields in the Atlantic Basin have limited global supply. As a result, Asian buyers are snapping up cargoes, leading to premiums for Middle East and Russian spot crude grades. Key grades, such as Murban and Sokol, have seen significant price increases, with premiums reaching as high as $1 and $6 per barrel, respectively.

site_title: Yuan, Aussie dollar strengthen on trade talk hopes
summary: The Chinese yuan and Australian dollar strengthened on Tuesday after US President Donald Trump suggested trade talks with Beijing could be successful. The yuan rose 0.25% to a six-day high, breaking a losing streak, while the Australian dollar firmed 0.1% to a 10-day high. Analysts expect China to intervene to prevent a yuan plunge below 7 to the dollar and potentially sell US Treasuries as a negotiating tactic. The move is seen as a positive for conventional safe havens like the Swiss franc and Japanese yen.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: GSS Energy's Q1 2019 revenue was maintained, but margins narrowed to 16.1% due to price competition and cost pressures. The oil and gas business is expected to continue dragging on earnings until regulatory approvals are obtained. UMS Holdings will acquire JEP Holdings, a precision machining and engineering services provider, in a mandatory conditional cash offer. The acquisition aligns with UMS' diversification strategy and maintains its call due to weak near-term outlook for the semiconductor industry.

site_title: Privacy should not be a luxury good
summary: Google's CEO Sundar Pichai emphasizes the importance of privacy, stating it should not be a luxury good reserved for premium users, but rather equally available to everyone. Google aims to provide clear choices around data use, while minimizing data collection and using anonymous data to improve services for all users. The company has introduced new privacy features, including one-click access to settings and auto-delete controls, and is exploring data minimization through "federated learning." Google also supports legislation that requires businesses to accept responsibility for data processing and is committed to leading the way in making privacy a reality for everyone.

site_title: Why China millionaires are keen to emigrate
summary: China has seen a significant number of its millionaires and billionaires emigrating, with 658 billionaires and 1.47 million families worth $1.5 million or more, controlling trillions of dollars. A 2014 study found 47% of Chinese millionaires planned to emigrate within five years, citing better educational and employment opportunities, economic security, and a desirable climate. However, a recent report found that only 37% of high net worth individuals are considering emigration, with 90% planning to retire in China. The government's crackdown on corruption and efforts to improve the quality of life may be deterring some from leaving, with new investment visa options emerging in Europe and island nations offering passports for cash.

site_title: Sri Lanka imposes curfew again as anti-Muslim riots escalate
summary: Sri Lanka has imposed a nationwide curfew for the second night due to escalating anti-Muslim riots that have left one man dead and dozens of shops, homes, and mosques damaged. The riots, which began three weeks after Islamist extremist bombings killed 258 people, have seen rampaging mobs carrying out arson attacks and vandalizing properties. 23 people have been arrested, including a man from Sri Lanka's majority Buddhist community on bail for his role in similar riots last year. The government has issued a text message to citizens announcing the curfew, which will continue until further notice.

site_title: GIC, BC Partners to sell majority stake in Acuris to Ion in £1.35b deal
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC and private equity firm BC Partners are selling their majority stake in financial intelligence firm Acuris to Irish software firm Ion for £1.35 billion. Acuris, which has 1,500 employees globally, provides proprietary insights and analytics across six financial areas. BC Partners will retain a 25% minority stake, while GIC sells its entire interest. The deal marks Acuris' next stage of growth, with Ion citing complementary capabilities and technologies. UBS Investment Bank acted as exclusive financial adviser to Ion, and JP Morgan and Goldman Sachs advised Acuris.

site_title: India's embattled Jet Airways CEO quits
summary: India's Jet Airways CEO Vinay Dube has resigned due to "personal reasons" amidst the airline's financial struggles. Jet Airways, heavily indebted with over $1 billion in debt, has suspended operations and defaulted on loans. The airline's main lender, State Bank of India, has invited offers for a stake in the airline, with two unsolicited bids received. A collapse of Jet Airways would deal a significant blow to Prime Minister Narendra Modi's pro-business reputation, potentially affecting over 20,000 jobs.

site_title: Two Singaporean teen golfers earn US trip
summary: Two Singaporean teen golfers, Sean Lee and Inez Ng, have qualified for a US trip after participating in the SGA's Asia-Pacific initiative golf event. They will play against a Southern California junior team at the Riviera Country Club in Los Angeles in August. The event, which was held at Laguna National Golf and Country Club, also featured golfers from Malaysia and Thailand, with Malaysia's Zubair Mohd Firdaus winning the boys' division and South Korea's Joo Ri Jeong winning the girls' category.

site_title: Thailand unveils Senate featuring military government allies
summary: Thailand has unveiled an appointed Senate with 250 members, including military and police officials, to select the next prime minister. The Senate, approved by King Maha Vajiralongkorn, features former Cabinet members and top military brass. Analysts expect the upper house to back Prayuth Chan-Ocha, leader of the pro-military Palang Pracharath party, to return as premier. The move is seen as a way for the military establishment to maintain power, despite the elected lower house having 500 members.

site_title: Japan takes India to WTO over mobile phone import duties
summary: Japan has filed a complaint with the World Trade Organization (WTO) over India's duties on mobile phone imports, citing excessive tariffs that hinder global trade. The complaint, the first step in a legal dispute, targets India's "Make in India" campaign, which aims to foster domestic production by adjusting various taxes, including customs duties. Some tariffs are "clearly in excess" of WTO rates, Japan claims, and the country seeks a resolution to protect its interests in the global mobile phone market.

site_title: Home prices in the US climb at slower pace as inventory rises
summary: US home prices rose 3.9% in the first quarter to a median of $254,800, according to the National Association of Realtors. This slower rate of growth is attributed to an increase in inventory, with 1.68 million existing homes available for sale, up 2.4% from last year. Thirteen regions experienced price increases of 10% or more, down from 14 in the fourth quarter. Despite this, some markets remain expensive, with San Jose, California, having the highest median price of $1.22 million.

site_title: Santander plans to cut more than 3,700 jobs in Spain
summary: Santander plans to close 1,150 branches in Spain and cut over 3,700 jobs, approximately 11% of its workforce, as part of its cost-cutting strategy to focus on Latin America and digital services. The measures aim to achieve incremental annual cost savings of 1.2 billion euros, with 1 billion euros coming from Europe. The bank's commercial network and intermediate support structures will be mainly affected.

site_title: 'Saturated' Paris tells e-scooter fleets to clean up
summary: Paris authorities have warned electric scooter operators to keep their fleets off pavements or face a temporary ban amid rising complaints from pedestrians. The city has signed a "code of good conduct" with 10 scooter operators, which includes measures to distribute devices in designated parking areas, use renewable energy for charging, and ensure recycling of damaged devices. Fines for riding scooters on pavements and obstructing sidewalks will be introduced, and operators will have to pay annual licence fees. The city aims to build 2,500 scooter parking areas and monitor traffic trends to optimize parking spaces.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.90 points to 1,599.19. Volume was 2.8 billion lots worth RM2.5 billion, with losers beating gainers 488 to 386.

site_title: Ministers agree UK must get Brexit law through by summer - PM's spokesman
summary: British ministers agreed to continue talks with the opposition Labour Party to reach a Brexit deal, with a focus on passing the Withdrawal Agreement Bill before the summer parliamentary recess. The UK government aims to ratify the bill and get it signed into law as soon as possible, with Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman emphasizing the need for urgency.

site_title: US: Stocks open higher, rebounding from Monday rout
summary: US stocks rose early Tuesday, rebounding from Monday's sell-off due to US-China trade war fears. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.5%, the S&P 500 rose 0.6%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 0.7%. These gains followed a 10% decline on Monday, bringing the Dow to 25,441.48 and the S&P 500 to 2,827.43.

site_title: Global energy investment steadies at US$1.85t in 2018
summary: Global energy investment remained steady at nearly US$1.85 trillion in 2018, with oil and gas spending increasing by 4% and coal supply investment rising by 2%. However, renewables spending edged down by 1% to US$300 billion, and low-carbon energy investment growth stagnated since a 3% rise in 2016. The International Energy Agency (IEA) warns that the world needs to see a significant reallocation of capital towards low-carbon energy to meet global warming goals, with the share of low-carbon energy in total energy investment needing to reach 65% by 2030.

site_title: Bank of England fires warning shot to insurers over capital, Libor
summary: The Bank of England is closely monitoring insurers' capital levels, particularly those using their own models for calculating capital requirements. Executive director David Rule warned insurers that ending the use of Libor, a tainted interest rate benchmark, is a top priority. Insurers must reference the Sterling Overnight Index Average (SONIA) in contracts and balance sheet assessments by the end of 2021. The Bank of England and Financial Conduct Authority have written to insurers and banks, urging them to prepare for the transition. Unacceptable reductions in capital will be addressed through a review of model "drift" or misuse.

images.alt_text: The Bank of England said it was carefully monitoring falling capital levels at insurers that use their own computer models for calculating capital requirements.

site_title: Thai regulator sets initial price for three 700-MHz licences at US$555m each
summary: Thailand's telecom regulator has set an initial price of US$555 million each for three 700-MHz licences, ahead of a June 19 auction. The licences will be valid for 15 years and are seen as essential for the rollout of 5G services, expected to be completed by late 2020. The regulator has set the price as a condition for the country's main operators to receive a payment extension for their 900-MHz licences.

site_title: US tariffs on China goods may cut Thai exports as much as US$6.7b: ministry
summary: Thailand's exports could fall by $5.6-$6.7 billion due to US tariffs on Chinese goods, covering 46% of Thai exports, according to the Thai commerce ministry. Shipments of electronics and automobiles are expected to decline sharply. The US and China remain Thailand's two biggest export markets.

site_title: Saudi Arabia says oil facilities outside Riyadh attacked
summary: Saudi Arabia reported that armed drones attacked two oil pumping stations outside Riyadh, causing a fire and minor damage. The attack, which occurred two days after oil tankers were sabotaged off the coast of the UAE, did not disrupt oil production or exports. Oil prices rose by 1.20% following the news, trading at $71.07 a barrel. The incident was described as a "cowardly" act of terrorism by the Saudi energy minister.

site_title: WhatsApp urges users to upgrade app after report of spyware attack
summary: WhatsApp has urged users to upgrade to the latest version of its app following a report of a spyware attack that could install malicious spyware on phones without users' knowledge. The app, used by 1.5 billion monthly users, has touted its high security and privacy features. WhatsApp advises users to upgrade to the latest version and keep their mobile operating system up to date to protect against potential exploits.

site_title: Isetan Q1 net profit rises 30% to S$1.5m on accounting change
summary: Isetan Singapore reported a net profit of S$1.5 million in Q1 2019, a 29.65% increase from the same period last year due to an accounting policy change. The adoption of a new standard lowered the group's reported rental expense to S$1.4 million, down from S$8.2 million. Group revenue fell 6.83% to S$29.2 million, while earnings per share rose to 3.72 Singapore cents.

site_title: WhatsApp urges users to upgrade app after security breach
summary: WhatsApp has urged users to upgrade to the latest version of its app after reporting a potential security breach that could allow malicious spyware to be installed on phones without users' knowledge. The popular messaging app, used by 1.5 billion people monthly, has emphasized the importance of keeping mobile operating systems up to date to protect against targeted exploits. WhatsApp's high level of security and encryption has been highlighted, but the company is taking proactive steps to inform users of potential vulnerabilities and ensure their safety.

site_title: Singapore shares claw back early drop to close 0.3% lower on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.3% lower on Tuesday, despite early losses, as risk-off sentiments persisted in the market. The benchmark index fell 10.57 points, or 0.3%, after a 1% drop at the start of the session. Market watchers attributed the decline to US-China trade tensions, with China increasing tariffs on US goods and the US considering tariffs on Chinese exports. However, tensions eased after US President Trump expressed optimism about resolving trade issues, and Chinese officials stated that a mutually beneficial trade deal was possible.

site_title: Sri Lanka govt orders nationwide curfew for second night
summary: Sri Lanka's government has ordered a nationwide curfew for the second consecutive night due to anti-Muslim riots that killed one person and damaged dozens of shops, homes, and mosques. The riots followed Easter bombings by Islamist militants that killed over 250 people. Police arrested 23 people for inciting violence against Muslims, and soldiers are patrolling affected areas. The curfew will run from 9 pm to 4 am, with the North Western Province under a longer shutdown. The situation remains under control, but the government aims to maintain order.

site_title: Diabetes crisis draws challengers for global US$22b insulin market
summary: The global US$22 billion insulin market is facing pressure due to high prices, with millions of Americans with diabetes forced to skimp on dosages. Lawmakers and the FDA are pushing for regulatory reform to create more competition among the three dominant companies: Eli Lilly, Novo Nordisk, and Sanofi. New entrants from China and India, such as Lannett and Gan & Lee Pharmaceuticals, are developing biosimilars that could cut prices in half. The FDA is simplifying the approval process for biosimilar drugs, and generic manufacturers like Mylan and Sandoz are also launching affordable versions of insulin.

site_title: German investor confidence worsens as global trade woes mount
summary: German investor confidence in growth outlook weakened in May for the first time since October, dropping to minus 2.1. This decline comes as global trade tensions worsen, particularly the US-China trade dispute, which risks spilling over to German companies. The DAX Index slid almost 3% last week, and economists expect restrained economic growth in Germany for the next six months. The country's first-quarter GDP figures are set to be released, with analysts predicting a 0.4% expansion, but Bundesbank President Jens Weidmann warns that this may not reflect a comprehensive improvement.

site_title: More mainland Chinese want to buy Hong Kong property: UBS poll
summary: Mainland Chinese respondents in a UBS survey said they intend to purchase a Hong Kong property in the next two years, up from 7% in September, with 12% of respondents planning to buy in the next two years. Despite US-China trade tensions and concerns over a controversial extradition law, UBS forecasts an uptrend in Hong Kong's housing market over the next decade. Experts attribute this to mainland Chinese seeking to park their money in Hong Kong property to ward off capital depreciation.

site_title: Memtech gets cash offer of S$1.35 per share from exec chairman
summary: Memtech International, a Singapore-listed electronics components manufacturer, has received a cash offer of S$1.35 per share from its executive chairman, Chuang Wen Fu, and his family, valued at S$189 million. The offer represents a 23.9% premium over the company's last transacted price and a 31.5% premium over the company's one-month volume-weighted average price. The offeror, a special purpose vehicle, aims to delist the company and has received 57.77% of Memtech's shares. The offer will become unconditional if it receives 90% valid acceptances, with Universal Global Technology (UGT) investing in Memtech to diversify its capabilities.

site_title: Indonesian supply chain solutions startup Advotics raises US$2.7m in seed funding
summary: Indonesian startup Advotics has secured US$2.7 million in seed funding led by East Ventures. The funds will be used to improve technology and grow its customer base. Advotics helps supply chain stakeholders digitalize their processes, providing insights for decision-making and digitizing physical assets through QR codes. With over 50 corporate clients, including ExxonMobil and Danone, Advotics aims to cater to both large and small enterprises with its product portfolio, including an in-store productivity app and offline-to-online marketing features.

site_title: Straits Trading Q1 net profit up 78% to S$17.3m
summary: Straits Trading Company reported a net profit of S$17.3 million in Q1 2019, a 78.1% increase from the same period last year. The real estate business saw a significant boost, with net profit rising to S$12.4 million, driven by increased rental income from overseas portfolio additions. The company's property portfolio, comprising Straits Real Estate, Suntec Reit, and ARA Asset Management, contributed to the growth. Despite challenges in the tin mining and hospitality segments, the company remains cautious about investment opportunities in 2019.

site_title: Retail closures hit Land Securities' portfolio, loss widens
summary: Land Securities Group reported a wider loss of £123 million for the year due to a decline in the value of its assets, largely attributed to the collapse of British retailers and higher vacancies. The company's CEO expects no near-term improvement in retail market conditions and predicts further decline in rental values for shopping centers and retail parks. However, revenue profit rose 8.9% to £442 million, driven by income from completed developments, high occupancy, and refinancing of bonds.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks sink as China hikes tariffs
summary: Hong Kong's stocks plummeted 1.50% on Tuesday, mirroring a sell-off across Asia and the US market. China's retaliation against US tariff hikes fueled fears of an all-out trade war. The Hang Seng Index fell to 28,122.02, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.69% to 2,883.61. The move follows a hammering on Wall Street, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty. The sell-off is a result of China's 25% tariff hike on US goods, sparking concerns of a global trade war.

site_title: Russia, Belarus, transport companies to hold talks on contaminated oil
summary: Russia, Belarus, and several transport companies will hold talks in Bratislava to discuss restarting oil flows via the Druzhba pipeline, which was disrupted by contamination issues. The talks come after Russia began shipping clean oil via the Baltic and Hungary resumed imports via the Druzhba pipeline as a test. The contamination problem, caused by high levels of organic chloride, had disrupted Russian exports for three weeks. Industry officials, including those from Transneft and the Russian energy ministry, are expected to attend the meeting.

site_title: Yanlord Land Q1 net profit falls 59% to 323m yuan
summary: China-based property developer Yanlord Land reported a net profit of 323 million yuan (S$64.3 million) in the first quarter, down 59% from the same period last year. Revenue fell 50% to 3.6 billion yuan due to a decrease in delivered gross floor area. The average selling price per square meter was lower than last year, primarily due to the delivery of higher-priced projects in the first quarter of last year.

site_title: South Korea gaming firm Nexon's parent delays bidding for stake sale: sources
summary: Nexon's parent company, NXC Corp, has delayed the bidding process for its controlling stake in gaming firm Nexon Co Ltd, initially scheduled for this week. The delay raises concerns about the future of the potentially $16 billion deal, one of South Korea's largest. Nexon shares plummeted 5% after the news, and affiliates tumbled 19%. The bidding was postponed by one week, with billionaire Jungju Kim selling his 98.64% stake in NXC. Tencent, a Chinese gaming giant, is seen as a key player in the deal due to its exclusive China licence for Nexon's Dungeon Fighter game.

site_title: Wear heels. But don't take selfies.
summary: The Cannes Film Festival, known for its strict rules and regulations, has implemented a no-selfie policy to maintain its high standards. Festival director Thierry Frémaux believes this rule is essential to the festival's reputation. The rules, which also include wearing heels, aim to keep the event classy and upscale. By adhering to these rules, the festival ensures a unique and memorable experience for attendees and maintains its position as the world's most famous film festival.

site_title: Australia, NZ shares end lower as Sino-US trade war intensifies
summary: Australia's shares closed at a one-month low on Tuesday due to escalating Sino-US trade tensions, as investors shifted to safe-haven assets. China announced tariff increases on $60 billion of US goods in retaliation for US tariffs on $200 billion of Chinese imports. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.92% to 6,239.90, while US shares reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: A feud threatens to tear apart convenience store chain
summary: FamilyMart, a Japanese convenience-store chain in China, is involved in a royalty payments dispute with its Taiwanese joint-venture partner Ting Hsin International Group. FamilyMart UNY Holdings Co. is suing Ting Hsin, alleging it hasn't fairly shared profits from the chain's rapid expansion. The partnership, which operates over 2,500 FamilyMart stores in China, is at risk of being terminated. The dispute could impact the business model and profitability of both parties.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon at 3,207.84, down 0.8% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened at 3,207.84, down 0.8% on Tuesday, amid global market selloffs following China's tariff hike on US goods. US President Donald Trump later expressed optimism about resolving the US-China trade dispute, easing tensions. The STI traded at 3,207.84, with local banks like DBS, OCBC, and UOB down, while defensive counters like Singtel and ComfortDelGro bucked the trend.

site_title: Hyflux clarifies it has not received binding offer from Utico
summary: Hyflux has clarified that it has not received a binding offer from Utico to invest in the company, contrary to a Reuters report. Utico's chief executive Richard Menezes stated that a binding term sheet was submitted, but Hyflux received only a "draft term sheet" from Utico's advisers. Hyflux's advisers are engaged in discussions with Utico and another potential investor, Oyster Bay Fund, to finalize the proposed terms.

site_title: Foreland Fabrictech's newly-appointed independent director quits after SGX queries
summary: Foreland Fabrictech's newly-appointed independent director Soh Yong Soon has resigned just days after his appointment, following queries by the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on his suitability. The SGX questioned Soh's ability to fulfill his role as independent director due to his past working relationship with Foreland's executive chairman Huang Min and his previous role as CFO of China Environment, where Huang was superior. Soh cited his time commitment to other business opportunities as the reason for his resignation.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rebound on revived trade optimism; won dips
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rebounded 2.83 points, or 0.14%, to 2,081.84 points, driven by optimistic comments from US and Chinese officials on trade negotiations. The won dropped 0.16% to 1,189.4 per dollar, while the benchmark bond yields also fell. Foreigners were net sellers of 285.2 billion won worth of shares, and South Korea's finance minister said policy efforts focus on monitoring and containing risks from increased FX volatility and US-China trade dispute.

site_title: Philippines gives thumbs up to Duterte as loyalists dominate mid-term vote
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte's allies dominated a mid-term Senate election, with nine of 12 seats set to go to pro-Duterte candidates. The opposition failed to make the cut, and the election is seen as a referendum on the president's rule. Duterte's popularity, despite controversies, is unprecedented, with a Senate majority expected to consolidate his power and ease opposition. The opposition vows to continue fighting for justice and a more progressive future, but Duterte's control of the lower house is also expected to remain unchanged.

site_title: Singapore's JustCo expands to Taiwan with opening of 3 new co-working centres
summary: Singapore-based co-working company JustCo has expanded to Taiwan with the opening of three new co-working centres in Taipei.
