site_title: Telkomsel, partners create US$40m fund for startups
summary: Telkomsel, a subsidiary of Singtel, has created a US$40 million fund for startups in collaboration with MDI Ventures and Singtel's Innov8. The fund will be managed by Telkomsel Mitra Inovasi, a new corporate venture arm that will invest in promising young companies and help accelerate their growth. The move aims to accelerate digital transformation, improve customer experience, and optimize business processes. Telkomsel president director Ri-riek Adriansyah said the partnership will provide startups with access to Telkomsel's ecosystem, assets, and expertise, while Singtel Innov8 CEO Edgar Hardless noted that Telkomsel is well-positioned to help startups expand into Indonesia.

site_title: En garde! France embraces lightsaber as a sport
summary: The French Fencing Federation has officially recognized lightsaber as a sport, creating a new discipline with four different categories. The sport combines moves from fencing and other combat sports, with a focus on immersive experience inspired by Star Wars. Since its introduction in 2019, the number of participants has quadrupled, with over 1,200 people training in 92 clubs across France. The federation has established safety guidelines and created its own academy to structure training and competitions.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Thai Beverage's Q2 net profit declined 12% year-on-year to 5.8 billion baht (S$249.9 million), mainly driven by softer domestic consumption in the spirits segment. However, core net profit for the half year improved 11% year-on-year to 13.2 billion baht. The decline was in line with the broker's initial full-year forecast.

site_title: Lab-grown meat that's simply Shiok
summary: Shiok Meats, a Singapore-based foodtech startup, has successfully grown lab-grown shrimp dumplings, with the company's first product tasting like the real thing. The company, founded by Dr. Sandhya Sriram and Dr. Ka Yi Ling, uses stem cells from animals to create "clean meats" with a goal of reducing animal cruelty and food sustainability issues. With a US$10,000 initial investment, the company has grown to a team of six and aims to commercialize its product by 2020, with plans to be available in supermarkets in five to seven years.

site_title: Europe's economy not yet on solid ground as business sweats
summary: Europe's economy is showing signs of recovery, with the euro-area GDP growth topping expectations at 0.4% in the first quarter. However, uncertainty over global trade, ongoing weakness in German manufacturing, and Brexit continue to cast doubt on the outlook. The US-China trade war and escalating tensions in the Middle East add to the volatility, making it challenging for European businesses to invest and demand. Economists forecast 1.1% growth for Europe in 2019, less than half the pace projected for the US.

site_title: EU ready to retaliate as Trump vehicle tariff deadline nears
summary: The European Union is preparing to impose retaliatory tariffs on US goods worth 20 billion euros (S$31 billion) if the US imposes a 25% levy on European cars. The EU will target a larger amount of US exports to Europe, as EU automotive exports to the US are about 10 times greater than its steel and aluminium exports combined. EU trade chief Cecilia Malmstrom hopes for a negotiated settlement, saying dialogue is preferred over tit-for-tat measures, but is prepared for counter-measures if necessary.

site_title: Mind economists' ignorance gap
summary: Economists' predictions have proven inaccurate in recent times, as shown by a Bureau of Labour Statistics report that 263,000 payroll jobs were created in April, exceeding economists' predicted 190,000. This discrepancy highlights an "ignorance gap" among economists, with the causes and duration of the strong job growth remaining unknown. The unexpected job growth continues to be a mystery, and economists' inability to accurately forecast this trend raises questions about their knowledge and abilities.

site_title: Trading platform delists KAYA tokens issued by Marvelstone unit
summary: A Singapore fintech group, Marvelstone Group, has had its KAYA tokens issued by its unit, Lattice80, delisted from cryptocurrency trading platform COSS.io due to "community feedback" and "negative press". The delisting follows reports that Marvelstone Group's CEO, Joe Cho Seunghyun, is being sued in South Korea for allegedly failing to pay investors. Marvelstone Group has also ceased being a regulated entity and reported no assets under management from investors. The KAYA token's initial coin offering (ICO) was unsuccessful, with thin trading and broken weblinks suggesting the project did not take off.

site_title: Oil prices fall with Wall Street on trade war, give back early gains
summary: Oil prices fell on Monday as the US-China trade war intensified, with Brent crude futures dropping 39 US cents to settle at US$70.23 a barrel and WTI crude futures falling 62 cents to settle at US$61.04 a barrel. The decline was attributed to investors moving into safe-havens like Treasury bonds amid concerns about the escalating trade war. Despite reports of sabotage attacks on tankers in the Middle East, oil prices were pressured by a slump in stocks and risk assets.

site_title: Australia is really doing better than the numbers show
summary: Australia's economy is experiencing a boom due to rising resource prices, with export earnings reaching a record A$438 billion in 2018. However, a statistical quirk means that tens of billions of dollars are being removed from main measures of growth, making the economy seem weaker than it actually is. Despite this, the country's miners are seeing significant profits, dividends, and share price increases, and the government has the flexibility to cut income tax and boost spending to support the household sector.

images.alt_text: Australia's export earnings are surging because commodity prices are up. Mining companies are booming. A statistical quirk results in the stripping out of "inflationary costs" to get "real growth" data.

site_title: Amazon offers employees US$10,000 to quit, launch delivery business
summary: Amazon is offering US$10,000 to employees who want to quit their jobs and start their own delivery businesses, with three months of wages also provided. The company aims to reduce its dependence on external services like the US Postal Service and FedEx. Since launching the "delivery service partner" program in 2018, 200 people have started their own delivery startups, and Amazon expects hundreds more to join with the added incentives, available in the US, Britain, and Spain.

site_title: Pintec Technology launches global expansion from new HQ in Singapore
summary: Pintec Technology, a Chinese fintech solutions provider, has established its international headquarters in Singapore to expand its global business. The company, which debuted on Nasdaq in 2018, plans to leverage its cloud computing, Big Data, and artificial intelligence technologies to provide overseas markets with financing solutions. Pintec expects the international HQ to contribute significantly to revenue in three to five years and aims to employ 20-40 staff in Singapore. The company also plans to set up a research and development centre and an independent data centre in Singapore to develop cutting-edge technologies for international markets.

site_title: Don't fear the Euroskeptic parties as elections loom
summary: Euroskeptic parties are expected to perform well in the upcoming European Parliament elections, but their success represents a backlash against recent European integration rather than opposition to the EU itself. This trend is not new, as Euroskeptic parties had a strong presence in the first European Parliament in 1979. Their opposition to European integration in the past was largely driven by concerns about market forces and worker protection, which seem premature given the EU's economic progress. The current rise of Euroskeptic parties reflects a backlash against the recent pace of European integration, rather than dissatisfaction with the EU's current state.

site_title: NetLink NBN Trust to raise FY2019 DPU
summary: NetLink NBN Trust has announced a distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.44 Singapore cents for the fourth quarter, up from 3.24 Singapore cents for the previous year. The trust reported a 30.9% year-on-year increase in net profit to S$20 million, with revenue rising 8.9% to S$87.9 million. Residential connections increased by 11.3% to 1.33 million, while non-residential connections rose 5.4% to 1.19 million. The trust expects to benefit from the rollout of fifth-generation (5G) mobile technology in Singapore.

site_title: Allow virtual banks, but maintain fair play and manage new risks
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is considering issuing virtual banking licenses to non-traditional banks, with the goal of promoting innovation and fair competition. Virtual banks can add unique risks to the system, but regulations should be implemented to manage these risks and ensure a level playing field. The MAS should extend existing rules to virtual banks, maintaining capital requirements, anti-money laundering principles, and limiting non-banking activities. This would allow innovative players to harness technology to improve efficiency and access, benefiting consumers.

site_title: China vehicle sales fall for 10th month in April
summary: China's auto sales declined 14.6% in April, marking the 10th consecutive month of decline, with 1.98 million vehicles sold. This follows a 5.2% decline in March and a 14% decline in February. The China Association of Automobile Manufacturers attributed the decline to the ongoing impact of the US-China trade tensions and global economic slowdown.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Singapore companies reported mixed Q1 earnings. APAC Realty's net profit dropped 70% to S$1.78 million due to lower transaction volume, while Thomson Medical posted a loss of S$1.01 million due to higher finance costs. However, SBS Transit's earnings rose 23.3% to S$20.7 million driven by better margins from bus contracts and higher ridership. The companies expect to remain profitable in 2019, with SBS Transit anticipating growth in transit revenue and operating margins.

site_title: China strikes back with higher tariffs on US$60b of US goods
summary: China has announced plans to impose higher tariffs on US$60 billion of US goods, targeting 5,140 products with import tariffs ranging from 5% to 25%, effective June 1. The move comes after US President Donald Trump warned China not to retaliate against the recent tariff hike. The US market plummeted, with the Dow falling 500 points, as investors fear escalating tensions could trigger a global recession. China's retaliation is seen as a tit-for-tat response, with the country vowing to defend its interests and dignity.

images.alt_text: State television said in a separate commentary that the effect on the Chinese economy from the US tariffs was "totally controllable".

site_title: Europe: Stocks drop as China ups stakes in trade war with US
summary: European stocks plummeted, with the STOXX 600 index falling 1.2% and Germany's DAX dropping 1.5%, amid escalating US-China trade tensions. China imposed higher tariffs on most US imports, sparking a risk-off sentiment and prompting investors to shift into safer sectors. Utilities stocks rose 0.2%, while auto-makers and suppliers fell 2.7%. The decline marked the sector index's underperformance of the broader benchmark for the first time this year.

site_title: Two Saudi oil tankers attacked on way to Persian Gulf
summary: Two Saudi oil tankers were attacked while sailing towards the Persian Gulf, adding to regional tensions as the US increases pressure on Iran. The incident occurred off the United Arab Emirates coast and damaged the tankers, which were approaching the Strait of Hormuz, a critical waterway for oil shipments. The US has deployed troops to the region amid worsening friction with Iran, and global crude prices rose following the incident. No one has claimed responsibility for the attack, which has raised concerns about the security of oil supplies to consumers worldwide.

site_title: Pemex signs US$8b syndicated loan with banks
summary: Pemex, Mexico's state-owned oil company, has signed a $8 billion syndicated loan with leading banks, marking the largest in its history. The loan aims to regain investor confidence and address the company's debt burden. The agreement includes tax breaks, refinancing of existing debt, and replacement of credit lines. The move is seen as a win for the government, which has been criticized by investors over a proposed refinery project. The loan's interest rate is Libor plus 235 basis points, and further terms will be announced this week.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue and operating loss shortfalls in the second half of the year. London's Heathrow Airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, a former DBS veteran. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) will deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Australia's CBA profit hit by fee cuts, refunds
summary: Australia's Commonwealth Bank (CBA) reported a 28% drop in cash profit in the third quarter, primarily due to falling fee income and rising refunds for wronged customers. The bank's cash earnings from continuing operations fell to A$1.70 billion. This is the latest weak result among Australia's "Big Four" banks, which are facing millions of dollars in provisioned payments to reimburse customers for overcharged or wrongly billed services. The result follows a public inquiry.

site_title: Take more risks, if you want to get ahead
summary: Singapore, ranked among the world's top 10 most forward-thinking nations, prioritizes investing in human capital to sustain growth. The city-state's continued growth will come from cultivating world-class talent, making the most of every worker, and encouraging disruptive thinking in hires. As the world faces increasing uncertainty and rapid change, organizations must prioritize promoting meritocracies, championing cultures of learning and growth, and empowering their workforce to make change happen. Taking calculated risks and investing in ongoing learning experiments will be key to success in a fast-changing environment.

site_title: Ayondo's disregard of SGX order: What now?
summary: Ayondo, a Singapore-listed fintech company, has disregarded a Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) order to meet conditions before selling its subsidiary to a Netherlands-registered company for £5.7 million. Despite this, Ayondo has proceeded with the sale, prompting the regulator to issue a warning and a review of the company's compliance. The sale is part of Ayondo's efforts to focus on growing its social trading platforms, citing tighter regulations in Europe and unfavorable market conditions. The incident raises concerns about Ayondo's disregard for regulator orders and its impact on investor confidence.

site_title: Funds flock to king dollar on wagers trade angst set to deepen
summary: The US dollar is expected to rise as a result of the escalating US-China tariff dispute, with fund managers anticipating a prolonged trade war. This will lead to a hunt for haven assets and a shorting of risk-sensitive emerging market currencies. The article cites various financial and economic indicators, including China's slowing GDP growth and the need for a stimulus package, to support this prediction.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Meanwhile, US stocks opened lower due to President Trump's fresh tariff salvo on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue below target and similar operating loss for H2. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case worth 285 trillion rupiah. OCBC's incoming CEO is Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran. MAS and PBOC are set to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: US: Dow ends down 2.4% as new China tariffs batter Wall Street
summary: US stocks plummeted 2.4% on Monday as China announced new tariff measures on the US, sparking fears of a deteriorating trade conflict. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 615 points to 25,324.99, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also declined. Key companies such as Boeing, Apple, and Caterpillar suffered significant losses, with Boeing down 4.9%. Analysts predict the trade conflict may still reach an agreement, but investors are bailing out due to uncertainty.

site_title: Opioid maker Insys plunges on warning of possible bankruptcy
summary: Insys Therapeutics Inc. plummeted 70% on May 13, 2019, after warning it may seek bankruptcy protection due to tens of millions of dollars in legal settlements and defending former executives convicted of bribing doctors to prescribe its opioid painkiller Subsys. The company has $87.6 million in cash and $240.3 million in liabilities, raising substantial doubt about its ability to continue as a going concern. Insys founder John Kapoor and four ex-executives face up to 20 years in prison for racketeering conspiracy charges related to the company's aggressive marketing tactics.

site_title: New CDS nearly halves Deutsche Bank default protection costs
summary: Deutsche Bank's default protection costs nearly halved after introducing new derivatives contracts for insuring against German bank debt defaults. The new contracts, linked to safer senior preferred debt, traded at 99bp, compared to 180bp before. Analysts note volatility, but executives see it as a significant development for the bank, reducing costs for clients and making it more cost-effective to trade with Deutsche. The move aims to level the playing field with other European banks, with German banks' CDS still trading at higher levels due to perceived risk.

images.alt_text: The cost of default protection on Deutsche Bank nearly halved on Monday following the introduction of new derivatives contracts used to insure against German bank debt defaults.

site_title: P&G partners NTUC FairPrice to pay tribute to mothers of Special Olympics athletes
summary: Procter & Gamble partnered with NTUC FairPrice to honor mothers of Special Olympics athletes on Mother's Day, celebrating their role as their children's first enabler. The event, part of P&G's global "Thank You, Mom" campaign, recognized the sacrifices and challenges mothers face, especially those of Special Olympics athletes. The company presented a S$20,000 cheque to Special Olympics Singapore, showcasing its commitment to the community.

site_title: Apple loses at US Supreme Court on iPhone app antitrust suit
summary: The US Supreme Court ruled 5-4 in favor of consumers, allowing them to proceed with a lawsuit against Apple for allegedly using its market dominance to artificially inflate prices at the App Store. The ruling could pressure Apple to cut its 30% commission on app sales, with lawyers seeking hundreds of millions of dollars on behalf of overpaying consumers.

site_title: Consumer insolvencies in Canada climb to highest in 8 years
summary: Canadian consumers filed the highest number of insolvencies in eight years, with 11,963 filings in March, a 5.7% increase from the same period last year. This marks the highest volume of filings since March 2011. With record household debt levels at $2.17 trillion, experts are concerned that unsustainable debt levels may be contributing to the rise in insolvencies. Regional increases were highest in Manitoba, with a 29% jump in consumer insolvencies.

site_title: Number of S'pore billionaires falls by 5 in 2018, combined wealth drops 8.8%
summary: Singapore's billionaire population declined 11.4% in 2018 to 39, with a 8.8% drop in combined wealth to US$84 billion. This decline is attributed to negative equity market performance, and Singapore remains the 15th country with the most billionaires. The global billionaire population decreased by 5.4% to 2,604 individuals, with combined wealth falling 7% to US$8.6 trillion. The decline is attributed to market volatility, global trade tensions, and a slowdown in economic growth.

site_title: GSH Corp Q1 net profit dives 70.3% on higher cost of sales, finance expenses
summary: GSH Corp reported a 70.3% decline in Q1 net profit to S$329,000 due to higher cost of sales (17.6% year-on-year) and finance expenses (28.2% year-on-year). Revenue rose 7.6% to S$26.2 million, while earnings per share dropped to 0.017 Singapore cent. The company's shares closed unchanged at S$0.285.

site_title: French fashion group Kering sets guidelines on animal welfare
summary: French fashion group Kering has set internal guidelines for animal welfare, covering issues such as animal treatment and intensive farming. The company backs prohibiting sub-therapeutic antibiotic treatments. This follows other brands like Burberry and Gucci abandoning fur, and Los Angeles outlawing its sale and manufacture within city limits. Kering's move aims to tighten ethical standards in the fashion industry.

site_title: 'No laughing matter': India's Modi mocked for tech gaffes
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi faced ridicule for claiming that radars are affected by clouds and boasting about sending an email attachment years before the technology existed. Modi stated that he ordered air strikes on Pakistan due to cloud cover, which would stop radar detection of Indian fighter jets. Experts and opposition politicians dismissed his claims, with many mocking his supposed "shock and awe" disclosure and questioning his national security judgment. Modi's comments were widely criticized on social media, with many labeling it a "no laughing matter" issue.

site_title: Thomson Medical posts Q1 net loss of S$1.01m on higher finance costs
summary: Thomson Medical reported a Q1 net loss of S$1.01 million, down from a net profit of S$89,000 last year, due to higher finance costs. Revenue grew 4% to S$54.52 million, driven by increased inpatient volumes and higher average bill sizes at Singapore and Malaysian hospitals and clinics. Loss per share was 0.0039 Singapore cent, compared to earnings per share of 0.0003 cent last year.

site_title: UMS makes general offer for JEP at S$0.15 per share
summary: UMS Holdings, a precision engineering firm, has made a general offer for JEP Holdings at S$0.15 per share, acquiring 10.9% of JEP's shares. This deal raises UMS' stake in JEP to 38.8%. The offer is mandatory, but will only become unconditional if UMS controls more than 50% of JEP by the end of the offer period.

site_title: Buyout firm Onex to acquire Canada's WestJet for US$2.6b in cash
summary: Canada's second-largest airline, WestJet, accepted a US$2.63 billion cash buyout offer from private equity firm Onex Corp, ending a two-month strategic review. The deal will be led by Onex Partners and is expected to close in the latter part of this year or early next year. WestJet's shares soared 62% following the announcement, while Onex shares inched lower. The acquisition is seen as unlikely to dramatically alter the competitive landscape, with analysts predicting a private equity owner to remain rational with respect to yields and profitability.

site_title: Philippine insurtech platform Maria Health raises US$1m in seed round
summary: Maria Health, a Philippine insurtech platform, raised US$1 million in a seed round led by Gobi Ventures. The funding will be used to expand the company in its home market, where health insurance spending has grown at 12% compound annual growth rate over the last 10 years. Maria's platform aggregates health insurance products from top providers, providing education and comparison shopping, aiming to simplify the cumbersome process of group health insurance coverage for Filipino SMEs.

site_title: ThaiBev shares tumble 7.3% following 12% fall in Q2 earnings
summary: ThaiBev shares plummeted 7.3% after the company's Q2 earnings fell 12% to 5.79 billion baht (S$249.9 million). OCBC Investment Research downgraded its recommendation to "hold" due to lower profits and the stock's rally this year. Despite this, other research houses maintained their calls, citing positive outlooks and synergies from the Sabeco acquisition. Analysts attribute the earnings dip to the spirits business and cost-saving initiatives, but expect sustained growth and a repaying of borrowings.

site_title: NetLink NBN Trust raises FY2019 DPU to 4.88 Singapore cents
summary: NetLink NBN Trust has raised its FY2019 distribution per unit (DPU) to 4.88 Singapore cents, a 48% increase from the previous year's 3.24 cents. The trust reported a 30.9% year-on-year increase in net profit to S$20 million, driven by growth in residential fibre connections and diversion services. Revenue rose 8.9% to S$87.9 million, with analysts attributing the growth to Starhub's fibre expansion and the impending rollout of 5G technology in Singapore.

site_title: Hollywood star Doris Day, singer of 'Que Sera, Sera,' dead at 97
summary: Doris Day, a Hollywood star known for her wholesome image and hit songs like "Que Sera, Sera," died on May 13, 2019, at 97. Born Doris von Kappelhoff, she began her career as a dancer but shifted to singing and eventually became a renowned actress, starring in films like "Pillow Talk" and "The Man Who Knew Too Much." Despite her sunny image, Day's life was marred by personal struggles, including four marriages and financial troubles.

site_title: Sasseur Reit posts Q1 DPU of 1.656 Singapore cents, beating forecast
summary: Sasseur Reit reported a Q1 DPU of 1.656 Singapore cents, beating the forecast of 1.515 cents. The company's distributable income was S$19.7 million, 9.3% higher than expected, and net property income was S$30.9 million, 2.4% above forecast. This marks a 9.3% increase in DPU and distributable income from the same period last year.

site_title: EU fines AB InBev for overcharging Belgians for beer
summary: The European Union has fined AB InBev, the world's largest brewer, 200 million euros for overcharging Belgians for beer by restricting cross-border sales of its popular Jupiler beer from the Netherlands. The EU found that AB InBev used tactics to prevent Belgian supermarkets from importing cheaper beer, resulting in higher prices for consumers. The fine is a result of the EU's antitrust rules, which aim to promote fair competition and prevent dominant companies from carving up the single market to maintain high prices.

site_title: EU is ready to retaliate as Trump auto-tariff deadline nears
summary: The European Union is preparing to retaliate against the US with tariffs on $30.7 billion of American goods if President Donald Trump imposes levies on car imports by May 18. The EU has finalized a list of possible items to target, which could include 20 billion euros of US goods. The move would mark a significant escalation of transatlantic tensions and target a larger amount of US exports to Europe. The EU hopes for a limited trade agreement focusing on industrial goods to avoid new tariffs.

images.alt_text: The European Union is finalising a list of American goods to target with retaliatory tariffs in the event that US President Donald Trump, who is expected to make a decision by May 18, imposes levies on car imports.

site_title: Take two bike rides and call me in the morning: cycling as doctor's orders
summary: A new program in Wales allows family doctors to prescribe bicycles to patients as an alternative to medication for better health. The six-month bike-rental service, launched at two medical centers in Cardiff, aims to encourage physical activity and improve health outcomes. The program reflects a global trend of medical professionals promoting exercise as a treatment option, supported by research showing its efficiency in treating conditions like high blood pressure and obesity.

site_title: Oxley posts Q3 net profit of S$66.1m on fair-value gains
summary: Oxley, a property developer, reported a net profit of S$66.1 million in Q3 2019, up 118% from the same period last year, driven by fair-value gains and the sale of 30 Raffles Place for S$1.025 billion. Revenue fell 75% due to lower contributions from UK projects. The company expects improved cash flow and gearing with the sale of properties. Earnings per share rose to 1.64 Singapore cents from 0.78 cents last year, and its gearing ratio decreased to 2.49 times.

site_title: Sri Lankan towns rocked by Christian-Muslim riots
summary: Sri Lanka experienced violent Christian-Muslim riots in several towns, including the North-Western Province, following Easter suicide bombings. Police fired warning shots and tear gas to disperse mobs attacking mosques and Muslim-owned businesses. At least six towns were affected, with hundreds of Christian-led rioters being fought off by police and troops. A curfew was imposed in response to the violence, with several shops being attacked. The riots are part of a broader backlash against the Easter bombings, which killed over 250 people.

site_title: Fragrance Group posts Q1 net loss of S$3.7m after City Gate's completion
summary: Fragrance Group reported a net loss of S$3.7 million in its first quarter due to the completion of City Gate, a major Singapore project, which led to a 78% decline in revenue to S$14.5 million. The company expects negative results in some quarters this fiscal year due to redevelopment plans for Tower 15 and the impact of City Gate on its revenue. Despite an improvement in occupancy, Fragrance's gross profit fell 54.8% to S$10.6 million, with finance costs increasing 86.2% due to additional loans and debt issuance.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks hit 4-month closing low as trade woes deepen
summary: South Korea's KOSPI index ended at its lowest since January 15, 2019, as trade tensions between the US and China deepened. The won dropped to its lowest since 2017, and foreigners sold 137.9 billion won worth of shares. The US and China appeared at a deadlock over trade negotiations, with Washington demanding concrete changes to Chinese law and Beijing refusing to swallow "bitter fruit." The KOSPI fell 1.38% and the junior Kosdaq market lost nearly 2%.

site_title: Singapore shares slump 1.2% as US-China trade tensions mount
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.2% on Monday, marking its fourth consecutive decline, amid heightened US-China trade tensions. Investors are concerned about potential countermeasures China may take against the US following last Friday's tariff hike. The decline was led by the local banking sector, with DBS, OCBC, and UOB experiencing losses. Despite this, some analysts remain optimistic about the sector, with UOB Kay Hian maintaining "buy" calls on DBS and OCBC.

site_title: APAC Realty Q1 net profit slides 70% to S$1.78m on lower transaction volume
summary: APAC Realty's Q1 net profit fell 70% to S$1.78 million due to lower transaction volume following Singapore's property cooling measures. Revenue dropped 26.4% to S$77.41 million, mainly from lower brokerage income. The company expects a challenging market environment, but sees growth opportunities in Indonesia and Thailand.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 9.18 points to 1,601.09. Losers outnumbered gainers 815 to 140, with 2.5 billion lots traded worth RM1.6 billion. This is the latest update from Bursa Malaysia, marking a decrease in the market.

site_title: Small parties back Thai junta chief after rule change gave them seats
summary: Eleven small Thai parties that gained parliamentary seats through a disputed electoral rule change will back the main pro-army party, Palang Pracharat, led by junta chief Prayuth Chan-ocha. The parties will give Prayuth enough votes to stay in power, despite opposition from the Democratic Front, which accused the Election Commission of rigging the system. The move is seen as a significant boost to Prayuth's position, as his party needs 126 votes in the combined House-Senate vote to approve the prime minister. A new government is expected to be formed in weeks, with Prayuth likely to remain prime minister.

site_title: Thailand's richest man, 12 others to build US$6.8b high-speed rail
summary: Thai conglomerate Charoen Pokphand Group and 12 other companies will build a US$6.8 billion high-speed train project linking three major airports in Thailand, with the project expected to be completed in five years and operational for 45 years. The government has chosen a joint investor with the lowest government investment, with the project's proposal set to be sent for cabinet approval on May 28. The high-speed train project is part of Thailand's Eastern Economic Corridor Policy, aimed at boosting investments in hi-tech industries.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Key news events include Best World confirming its CEO's brother-in-law owns a main customer in China, while the company's board did not provide clarity on the matter. Fintech firm Marvelstone Group holds a 0.9% stake in media startup Tech in Asia. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) signed a pact to promote fintech collaboration between Singapore and China. Meanwhile, Swissco completed the disposal of its bulk offshore support vessels business, and Singtel Indonesia's associate Telkomsel created a $40 million fund for startups. Singapore shares fell 1.2% due to US-China trade tensions.

site_title: SGX orders Best World's major customer to hand over documents
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has ordered Best World International, a skincare products firm, to hand over documents related to its largest customer, Changsha Best, amid allegations of CEO Dora Hoan's brother-in-law owning the company. The move follows claims that the CEO's brother-in-law was the owner of Changsha Best, which was Best World's primary import agent in China until it switched to a franchise model last year. SGX is investigating the veracity of Best World's China sales and requires the company to provide financial information and accounting records.

site_title: US: Wall St tumbles at open after China plans tariff retaliation
summary: US stocks plummeted at the open on Monday after China announced plans to retaliate with tariffs on US goods, raising recession fears. The Dow Jones fell 374.31 points, or 1.44%, to 25,568.06, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. The move follows US President Trump's threats to extend tariffs on Chinese goods, sparking concerns about another round of tit-for-tat measures.

site_title: Freehold mixed development Parc Komo opens for preview
summary: Parc Komo, a freehold mixed development in Changi, Singapore, has opened for preview. The development, by CEL Development, features 276 residential units and 28 commercial spaces, with prices starting from S$663,000 for a one-bedroom unit. Located in District 17, Parc Komo is part of a region earmarked for development and rejuvenation. The development is expected to be accessible via the upcoming Loyang MRT Station and offers proximity to Changi Business Park and recreational amenities. The indicative pricing averages S$1,450 per square foot, with units ranging from 452 sq ft to 1,905 sq ft.

site_title: Australia shares end lower hurt by financials; NZ gains
summary: Australian shares ended lower, down 0.2%, as disappointing earnings from Commonwealth Bank of Australia weighed on financials, while healthcare and gold stocks rose. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,297.60. Disappointing earnings from top banks, including CBA, NAB, and Westpac, led to a near four-week low. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.3% as investors sought safe-haven assets.

site_title: DBS chief information officer David Gledhill to depart bank
summary: DBS' Chief Information Officer David Gledhill, 57, is retiring from the bank after 29 years in Asia and 11 years at DBS, to return to the UK. His retirement, effective August 1, will be followed by Jimmy Ng, who has been deputy group head of technology and operations. Gledhill will stay connected with DBS in a part-time advisory role and return to Singapore with SIA every three months. He played a key role in transforming DBS' technology and culture during his tenure.

site_title: Swissco completes disposal of bulk of offshore support vessels business
summary: Swissco Holdings has completed the disposal of its offshore support vessels business, involving six subsidiaries and 12 vessels. The disposal was made to reduce liabilities, including shares and assets, and was overseen by judicial managers. The High Court has ordered their release and discharge from their appointment. Swissco shares are suspended from trading following the completion of the disposal. The move aims to help the group's financial restructuring and is seen as a step towards reducing its liabilities.

site_title: Japan Display says bailout from Chinese group to be delayed
summary: Japan Display Inc. announced that a planned $997.65 million bailout from a Chinese-Taiwanese group will be delayed due to the investor group's decision to reassess the company's business prospects. The rescue deal, which was initially set to be finalized by mid-June, will now be made after re-examining the company's business performance. Japan Display is facing financial difficulties, including its fifth straight year of net losses, due to slowing iPhone sales and delayed adoption of OLED screens. The company's cash-strapped situation has raised concerns about its future.

site_title: SBS Transit posts 23.3% rise in Q1 net profit to S$20.7m
summary: SBS Transit posted a 23.3% rise in net profit to S$20.7m for Q1 2019, driven by higher operated mileage for bus services and higher rail ridership. Revenue increased 6.9% to S$350.8m. Average daily ridership for the Downtown Line grew 10.4% to 476,000 passenger trips, while the North-East Line saw a 3.2% increase. Bus service revenue is expected to climb with the full-year contribution from the Seletar and Bukit Merah Bus Packages, while rail service revenue will benefit from higher ridership and a 4.3% fare adjustment.

site_title: Saudi oil tankers attacked on way to Persian Gulf
summary: Two Saudi oil tankers were attacked off the UAE coast, with the vessels suffering damage while en route to the Persian Gulf. The incident, described as a sabotage attack, aims to undermine maritime navigation security and oil supply. Saudi Energy Minister Khalid Al-Falih called on the international community to ensure oil tanker security, warning of adverse consequences on energy markets and the global economy. The attacks come amid heightened regional tensions, as the US increases pressure on Iran.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close lower as trade fears linger
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Monday due to lingering trade fears, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.72% to 21,191.28. US President Donald Trump defended his tariff policy, stating China will pay billions in duties to the US. Investors remain wary of renewed trade tensions between the US and China after talks failed to achieve a deal. The broader Topix index also fell 0.53%.

site_title: MAS inks pact to promote fintech collaboration between Singapore and China
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) signed a cooperation agreement with the Asia-Pacific Future Financial Research Institute (AFF) to promote fintech collaboration between Singapore and China. The pact aims to enhance academic exchanges, information sharing, and research cooperation, as well as facilitate greater cooperation among financial institutions to benefit consumers. MAS Chief Fintech Officer Sopnendu Mohanty and AFF Executive President Du Yan emphasized the need for international communication and cooperation to promote innovation in financial services and enhance financial inclusion globally.

site_title: Fintech firm Marvelstone Group holds 'less than 1%' of media startup Tech in Asia
summary: Fintech firm Marvelstone Group holds less than 1% stake in media startup Tech in Asia, according to CEO and founder Willis Wee. Marvelstone Group invested S$135,050 in Tech in Asia at end-2017, its single-largest investment. Wee stated that Marvelstone Group has minimal interactions with Tech in Asia, as investors trust the business to run well.

site_title: Malaysia bubble tea chain plans RM300m IPO next year: sources
summary: Malaysia's bubble tea chain, Tealive, is planning a potential initial public offering (IPO) valued up to RM1 billion (S$98 million) with a target listing in the first half of 2024. The Kuala Lumpur-based company, Loob Holding Sdn, has hired corporate advisers and aims to raise RM300 million from the IPO. This move comes as Malaysia's IPO market is expected to boost with a recent US$250 million offering by Leong Hup International Bhd. and existing shareholders.

site_title: Singtel Indonesia associate Telkomsel, partners create US$40m fund for startups
summary: Telkomsel, a subsidiary of Singtel Indonesia, has created a US$40 million fund for startups through its new corporate venture arm, Telkomsel Mitra Inovasi (TMI). The fund will invest in promising young companies and help accelerate their growth by providing access to Telkomsel's ecosystem, assets, and expertise. TMI aims to drive digital transformation, improve customer experience, and business process optimization, with a focus on forging partnerships with startups to develop new services and enhance the user experience.

site_title: Euronext gets green light to take over Oslo Bors by end June
summary: Euronext NV has received permission from the Norwegian government to acquire Oslo Bors by the end of June, winning a five-month takeover battle over Nasdaq Inc. Euronext aims to complete a 53% controlling stake purchase and consolidate Oslo Bors into its financial accounts. The deal price is estimated at US$775 million, with Euronext shareholders set to vote on the bid on May 16.

images.alt_text: Euronext NV won the permission of the Norwegian government to buy the Oslo stock exchange without imposing an ownership threshold on the Franco-Dutch company.

site_title: UK PM May's party slumps to fifth place as pressure mounts for her to go
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative Party has slumped to fifth place in an opinion poll ahead of the May 23 European parliamentary election, with the Brexit Party led by Nigel Farage in the lead. May's party has 10% support, down from 22% in 2017. Pressure mounts for her to set a date for her own departure, with senior Conservatives urging her to step down. The UK's Brexit deadline is October 31, but the country remains uncertain about its future in the EU.

images.alt_text: British Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservatives have fallen to fifth place in an opinion poll ahead of the May 23 European parliamentary election as pressure grows for her to set a date for her own departure.

site_title: Foxconn's chip boss tipped to be Taiwanese group's next chairman: sources
summary: Foxconn, the world's largest contract manufacturer, is set to nominate Liu Young, 63, as its next chairman, following Terry Gou's plan to run in Taiwan's presidential election. Liu, who has been head of Foxconn's chip business since 2017, is considered a surprise choice due to his relatively junior rank among top executives. Gou has expressed a desire for younger talent to lead the company, and Liu has gained Gou's trust. The nomination is subject to shareholder approval at a June meeting.

site_title: In Jerusalem's Old City, lantern maker lights up Ramadan
summary: In Jerusalem's Old City, Palestinian lantern maker Issam Zughair crafts traditional lanterns for Ramadan, battling competition from cheap Chinese imports. The 67-year-old imports materials from Egypt and Turkey and adds Koranic verses or names of God to the lanterns, selling them for between 10 and 1,000 shekels. However, Zughair faces a 70% decline in customers since the 2000 Palestinian uprising, and cheap Chinese knock-offs pose another threat to his business. Lanterns play a significant role in Ramadan, symbolizing Islamic culture and heritage, and Zughair aims to protect his family's heritage by continuing the traditional craft.

site_title: UOB scales up offerings for small businesses across region
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has expanded its offerings for small businesses across the region, including machinery financing solutions and e-commerce website development through its partnership with Shopmatic. The bank has also renewed its Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with Guangxi LiuGong Machinery to provide asset financing and other financial solutions. This move aims to address the digital knowledge gap of small businesses, with 70% of those planning to invest in IT saying they lack the necessary expertise. The partnership aims to help businesses build customised e-commerce websites in a fraction of the time required.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday afternoon at 3,235.64, down 1.2% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.2% to 3,235.64 on Monday, weighed down by local banks, which account for 40% of the STI's total weighting. DBS Group Holdings and OCBC Bank declined 1.7% and 1.6% respectively, while United Overseas Bank dropped 1.1%. ThaiBev's 12% drop in second-quarter earnings was the only positive contributor. The market is down across Asia, with the Hong Kong market closed and resuming trading on Tuesday.

site_title: Japan PM Abe gets imperial bump as support surges ahead of vote
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's support surged ahead of a July upper house election following the country's first imperial abdication and accession in two centuries, boosting his standing. Polls showed 55% of respondents supported Abe's Cabinet, up 7 percentage points, with 57.4% supporting him in a separate poll. However, his signature policies, including a planned sales tax hike, received weak support. Abe is set to become Japan's longest-serving premier in November and may call a lower house election to coincide with the upper house election, potentially securing a fourth consecutive term.

site_title: US agriculture secretary urges Japan to reach trade deal
summary: US Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue urged Japan to swiftly reach a trade deal on farm products and other goods, treating the US fairly as its "premier customer." President Trump is reportedly looking forward to a deal, which would be welcomed by Perdue. The meeting between Trump and Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is scheduled later this month, potentially paving the way for a trade agreement.

site_title: European stocks rise at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the start of trading on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.1% to 7,212.68 points. The eurozone's Frankfurt DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 also saw gains, rising 0.1% and 0.3% respectively. The rally was driven by mining and healthcare stocks, while US-EU trade talks were in focus.

site_title: Nissan said to push back Renault's renewed efforts to merge
summary: Nissan is opposing Renault's renewed efforts to merge under a holding company structure. The proposal was made by Renault Chairman Jean-Dominique Senard to Nissan CEO Hiroto Saikawa in April. Nissan has previously rebuffed the idea and continues to oppose it. The move comes as Nissan faces its lowest annual operating profit in a decade, affected by US sales slumps, aging models, and a product cycle out of sync. The proposal follows the tumultuous few months in the companies' 20-year partnership, which was shaken by the arrest of former chairman Carlos Ghosn.

site_title: World's biggest palm oil planter is running out of space at home
summary: Sime Darby Plantation Bhd, the world's largest palm oil planter, is seeking to expand its global refining capacity by acquiring refineries in Latin America due to poor margins and mounting costs at home. The company has set aside RM400 million to invest in refineries and may consider debt financing or listing its units' shares. Latin America's proximity to Europe and shorter sailing days for palm oil imports make it an attractive location, despite European Union restrictions on palm oil use in biodiesel. The company aims to mitigate the weakness in its upstream plantation business with stronger downstream earnings.

site_title: Cannes makes a killing on the film festival
summary: Cannes' film festival generates a significant revenue for local businesses, with hotels reporting nearly a sixth of their annual turnover due to the festival. The 2017 festival was worth 197 million euros to the town, and hoteliers expect the 2019 festival to be just as lucrative, with some hotels charging up to 260 euros per night for rooms. However, locals are also cashing in by renting out homes and apartments, leading to concerns about the market's sustainability and the impact of Netflix's possible defection on demand.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit DPU rises 6.3% to 1.02 euro cents for Q1
summary: Cromwell E-Reit's distribution per unit (DPU) for Q1 rose 6.3% to 1.02 euro cents, beating its forecast by 5.2%. Net property income and gross revenue also increased, driven by acquisitions of 23 new properties. The Reit's portfolio occupancy stood at 90.2% as of March 31, with a weighted average lease expiry of 4.7 years. CEO Simon Garing is confident in the Reit's ability to deliver "attractive risk-adjusted returns" through proactive leasing activities and asset divestments.

site_title: NZ's Fonterra sells Tip Top ice cream to Froneri for US$250m
summary: New Zealand's Fonterra has sold its Tip Top ice cream business to Froneri for NZ$380 million, a gain of about NZ$100 million above book value. The sale is part of Fonterra's efforts to reduce debt by the year-end. Froneri, a UK-based ice cream maker, will maintain the Tip Top name and operations, including a factory site in Auckland. The deal is expected to have a positive impact on Fonterra's earnings, with a 6 cents-per-share benefit. Fonterra aims to trim its portfolio and reduce debt through strategic sales and divestments.

site_title: 'I am the original': India PM Modi lookalike hits campaign trail
summary: A lookalike of Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, Abhinandan Pathak, is running as an independent candidate against Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party in the country's marathon election. Pathak, 58, claims to be the original Modi due to his resemblance, but was once a supporter who felt ignored by the party. He is gaining support from angry voters who feel Modi has failed to deliver on promises. This is not an isolated incident, as other Modi lookalikes have run for office, including Vikas Mahante, who was even offered a film role.

site_title: Memtech, Tritech call for trading halts on Monday morning
summary: Memtech International and Tritech Group separately requested trading halts on Monday morning. Memtech shares rose 7.92% to S$1.09, while Tritech Group shares increased 2.56% to S$0.04. The trading halt request was likely due to the companies' recent significant price movements.

site_title: China: Stocks open lower on trade talk fears
summary: Chinese stocks opened lower on Monday due to fears over a lack of a US-China trade deal, weakening the yuan. The Shanghai Composite Index dropped 1.16% and the Shenzhen Composite Index lost 1.14%. Hong Kong markets were closed for a public holiday. The decline was attributed to concerns over the ongoing trade tensions and its impact on the global economy.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks hit 4-month low on trade talk anxiety; won down
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index fell 17.24 points, or 0.82%, to 2,090.80, marking its lowest level since January 15, due to growing uncertainties over the Sino-US trade deal. The Korean won also weakened near its lowest level since January 2017, while the benchmark bond yield fell. The decline was attributed to anxiety over trade talks, causing investors to sell stocks and seek safer assets.

site_title: Foreigners can soon own more China stocks. But no one wants them
summary: Foreigners are rapidly selling Chinese stocks at a record pace, despite MSCI's plan to increase their weighting in its benchmark indices. Since May 1, 17.4 billion yuan (S$3.46 billion) of A shares have been sold, wiping US$1 trillion from China's equity markets in three weeks due to trade tensions with the US. MSCI will expand the inclusion factor of large-cap A shares to 10% and add stocks from the ChiNext board on May 29, potentially drawing foreign inflows from index-tracking funds.

site_title: Indonesia: accelerating urban transportation development with public-private partnership
summary: Indonesia is accelerating urban transportation development through public-private partnerships (PPPs) to address the country's rapid urbanization and infrastructure challenges. With 68% of the population expected to live in cities by 2025, the government aims to develop a well-developed urban transportation system. The first MRT system was launched in March 2019, and the government plans to prioritize mass rapid transit and transportation demand management. However, challenges such as a lack of financial resources, complex regulatory frameworks, and bureaucratic inefficiencies hinder the development process. The government is seeking to increase private sector participation and adopt best practices from mature PPP markets to overcome these issues and drive urban transportation development.

site_title: Hot stock: ThaiBev shares tumble 11% in early trading after posting Q2 earnings
summary: Thai Beverage Public Company Limited (ThaiBev) shares plummeted 11% in early trading after posting Q2 earnings, with a net profit of 5.79 billion baht (S$249.9 million), a 12% drop. The company attributed the decline to poor performance in its spirits and food businesses. Analysts from OCBC Investment Research, CGS-CIMB, and RHB Research Institute maintained their "buy" calls, citing positive synergies from the Sabeco acquisition and expected economic stimulus measures in Thailand.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, Keppel Corp, Sarine Technologies, Swee Hong, Memtech, Tritech
summary: DBS shares fell 0.19% on Monday after Citi Investment Research downgraded its rating to 'neutral' due to exposure to China amid US-China trade uncertainties. Keppel Corp's shares dropped 0.31% after securing a contract worth over S$150 million to build offshore wind farm substations for Orsted in Taiwan.

site_title: Gold firms as US-China trade impasse fuels safe-haven demand
summary: US-China trade talks stalled, fueling safe-haven demand for gold. Gold prices rose 0.1% to $1,286.59 per ounce, driven by concerns over the trade impasse and potential tariffs on Chinese imports. The US had already imposed tariffs on $200 billion worth of Chinese exports, and Washington demanded concrete changes to Chinese law. Safe-haven assets, including the Japanese yen and sovereign bonds, also gained as risk appetite decreased. Gold demand jumped in India due to retail purchases for key festivals, while premiums in China eased as buying slowed.

site_title: Australia shares slip on financials as CBA, ANZ weigh; NZ up
summary: Australian shares slipped 0.3% on Monday, weighed down by financial stocks, particularly Commonwealth Bank of Australia, which reported disappointing third-quarter results and announced additional provisions to compensate customers. The country's top banks, including National Australia Bank and Westpac Banking Corp, also fell. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.3% as dairy firm a2 Milk Company and Fonterra Shareholders' Fund gained. Market uncertainty was fueled by the US-China trade deadlock.

site_title: Pakistan secures US$6b IMF bailout to ease economic crisis
summary: Pakistan secured a $6 billion IMF bailout to ease its economic crisis, its 13th IMF bailout since the late 1980s. The 39-month loan requires timely implementation of prior actions and confirmation of international financial commitments. The agreement comes after Prime Minister Imran Khan overhauled his economic team, including the installation of Reza Baqir as central bank governor. The IMF mission chief noted that decisive policies and reforms are necessary to reduce vulnerabilities and increase confidence in the economy.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Monday; STI down 0.42% to 3,259.66
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.42% to 3,259.66 on Monday, amid growing anxiety over a potential US-China trade deal. The Straits Times Index declined 13.84 points, with losers outnumbering gainers 91 to 33. The decline came as other Asian markets also dropped, following Washington's sharp hike in tariffs on Friday.

site_title: Hot stock: DBS shares tumble 2% following Citi downgrade; UOB, OCBC also slide more than 1%
summary: DBS shares dropped 2% after Citi Investment Research downgraded its rating to "neutral" from "buy" due to exposure to China amid US-China trade uncertainties. Citi lowered its target price to S$27 from S$31.10. The downgrade follows the US increasing tariffs on Chinese imports from 10 to 25%. Other Singapore banks, UOB and OCBC, also fell more than 1%.

site_title: China, Singapore renew bilateral currency swap agreement
summary: China and Singapore have renewed a bilateral currency swap agreement worth 300 billion yuan (S$59.80 billion) for three years, supporting trade and investment financing needs, including Belt and Road Initiative projects. The agreement, first established in 2010, can be extended again, with the original arrangement having been renewed in 2013 and 2016. The People's Bank of China and Monetary Authority of Singapore can access foreign currency liquidity to stabilize financial markets.

images.alt_text: China and Singapore have renewed a bilateral currency swap agreement worth 300 billion yuan (S$59.80 billion) for three years, the central banks of the two countries said on Monday.

site_title: Yen gains but yuan, Aussie dip as US-China trade war escalates
summary: The US-China trade war escalated, with the US imposing tariffs on $200 billion worth of Chinese goods, prompting a decline in the Chinese yuan and Australian dollar. The Japanese yen rose as a safe-haven currency. Despite the escalation, hopes for an eventual settlement remain, with US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping set to meet at the G20 summit in June. The US dollar index fell 0.05% to 97.283, while the euro remained little changed at $1.1234.

site_title: Oil prices fall amid US-China trade impasse
summary: Oil prices fell amid a US-China trade impasse, with Brent crude futures down 12 cents to $70.49 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures down 27 cents to $61.31 a barrel. The US and China remained at a deadlock over trade negotiations, with Washington demanding concrete changes to Chinese law and Beijing refusing to compromise. The US-China trade conflict, accounting for 34% of global oil consumption, has led to bearish market sentiment, contributing to the decline in oil prices.

site_title: Philippines votes in polls expected to strengthen Duterte
summary: Philippines votes in midterm polls expected to strengthen President Rodrigo Duterte's grip on power, with over 18,000 seats at stake, including half of the Senate seats. Duterte's tough-on-crime platform and pledge to rewrite the constitution are key to his expected victory. Winning a Senate majority would give him legislative backing for his anti-crime proposals and allow him to expand his contentious anti-drug crackdown. The opposition warns that this could lead to Duterte's re-election despite his repeated statements that he would stand down.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open slightly higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 0.46 point, or 0.03%, to 1,610.55 on Monday, driven by slight gains. Volume was 49.6 million lots worth RM15.6 million. Losers outperformed gainers 84 to 61.

site_title: New Zealand begins inquiry into Christchurch's mosques massacre
summary: New Zealand has begun an inquiry into the Christchurch mosque massacre, where 51 people were killed in March 2019. The Royal Commission will examine the gunman's activities, social media use, and international connections. Australian Brenton Tarrant, a suspected white supremacist, has been charged with multiple counts of murder. New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern is co-hosting a meeting in France to promote the "Christchurch Call", a pledge to eliminate terrorist content online, with tech companies and world leaders expected to sign. The inquiry will report its findings on December 10.

images.alt_text: An inquiry into Christchurch's mosques shooting massacre began hearing evidence on Monday, as New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern prepared to co-host a meeting in France that seeks global support to tackle online violence.

site_title: Back on the menu: Chinese steel mills regain taste for high-grade iron ore
summary: Chinese steelmakers are regaining their appetite for high-grade iron ore, driven by recovering profit margins and stricter environmental regulations. Following record-high ore prices, steel firms have switched to low-quality ore, but as China's economic growth revved up, executives are now seeking higher-quality ore to improve efficiency and reduce pollution. The industry's shift is fueled by China's anti-smog drive, which aims for ultra-low emission levels, and a supply gap left by the Vale dam disaster in Brazil, resulting in a shortage of high-grade iron ore products.

site_title: China tried to link 737 MAX approval to support for its own jets
summary: China attempted to link the approval of Boeing's 737 MAX to favorable treatment of its own aircraft in 2017, but the US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) refused. Despite this, China certified the MAX for flight. The move was seen as an attempt to gain leverage in trade talks, which were ongoing at the time. China's willingness to permit the jet to fly again after crashes in Ethiopia and Indonesia will be closely watched, potentially affecting US-China relations.

site_title: Best World confirms CEO's brother-in-law owns main customer in China, discloses other connections
summary: Best World, a Singapore-based company, has confirmed that its CEO's brother-in-law, Koh Kim Chuan, is the owner and legal representative of its primary import agent in China, Changsha Best Commodity Trading Co. Despite this, the company's board maintains that Changsha Best is an independent party, citing a lack of involvement in management and business operations. The company has also disclosed other connections between Koh and Changsha Best, including a US$100,000 seed funding investment and a distribution agreement that was terminated in 2018.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower as trade fears linger
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on May 13, 2019, due to lingering trade fears amid US-China talks failing to achieve a deal. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 0.85% to 21,163.81, while the Topix index fell 0.67% to 1,539.09. Investors remain cautious despite US stocks reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: SoftBank's market value slides US$9b as Uber IPO flops
summary: SoftBank's market value slid US$9 billion after Uber's initial public offering (IPO) failed to meet expectations, with shares dropping 4.9% on the first day of trading. Despite reporting a US$3.8 billion gain from its stake in Uber, SoftBank's stock fell 5.4% and 4.9% in the two trading days following the IPO. SoftBank's profit more than tripled, thanks to the valuation gain from its stake in Uber, but the company's market value took a hit.

site_title: Southwest, pilot unions get subpoenas for 737 Max documents
summary: Southwest Airlines and pilot unions from Southwest, United, and American Airlines have received federal grand jury subpoenas for documents related to Boeing's grounded 737 Max. Southwest is cooperating fully, with 34 Max planes and additional orders. The subpoenas follow investigations into the plane's development and approval process, including a new software system that repeatedly pushed the nose down in two fatal crashes. The unions have until May 24 to comply, with the Southwest pilots' union seeking an extension due to the time needed to search through documents.

site_title: Money FM podcast: The Hot Seat: Fighting financial crime and misconduct
summary: Nathan Lynch, Thomson Reuters Asia-Pacific bureau chief, discusses the Hayne Commission Inquiry in Australia, which exposed financial industry wrongdoing, including fees charged to dead people, cash bribes, and interest rate rigging. This raises questions about how other countries, such as Singapore, can learn from Australia's experience in fighting financial crime and misconduct.

site_title: Asian stocks drop, yuan slides as trade war escalates
summary: Asian stocks plummeted on Monday as trade talks between the US and China ended without a resolution, with China saying the US must remove all extra tariffs. The yen and Treasuries rose, while the yuan slid. US equity futures fell 1.1% and the S&P 500 Index declined 0.4% on Friday. China's state funds helped ease the turmoil, but shares in Shanghai fell 3% last week after the US increased levies on Chinese goods. The breakdown in negotiations has investors favoring safer-haven assets, with more volatility expected.

site_title: Myanmar pilot safely lands plane on its nose after landing gear failure
summary: A Myanmar National Airlines pilot safely landed a passenger jet without its front wheels after the landing gear failed during a flight from Yangon to Mandalay. The Embraer 190 aircraft touched down on its rear wheels and traveled a distance on its nose before coming to a halt. No one was injured in the incident, which is being investigated. The pilot followed emergency procedures and evacuated the crew after fuel was burned to reduce landing weight. This is the second aviation incident in Myanmar this week, following a Biman Bangladesh Airlines plane skidding off the runway in Yangon.

site_title: London housing is taking the hardest Brexit hit: report
summary: London's housing market continues to be severely impacted by Brexit uncertainty, with house prices falling 1.1% in April from the previous year, and sales down 14% since 2017. Sellers in the capital are lowering prices to secure early sales. In contrast, other regions in the UK, such as Wales, the Midlands, and the north of England, are experiencing price gains. The report from Acadata attributes the London slowdown to the ongoing Brexit uncertainty, scheduled for the end of October.

site_title: British PM Theresa May aims to reopen EU Brexit talks to win Corbyn's support
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May aims to reopen EU Brexit talks to win support from Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn. May's office announced plans to explore rewriting the outline political agreement on the UK's future partnership with the EU. The goal is to strike a deal that includes a customs deal and environmental protections, with Labour demanding a confirmatory referendum. The move comes as May faces mounting pressure over her failure to complete the UK's Brexit divorce from the EU, with her Conservative Party leaders believing she has failed and must resign.

site_title: HSBC opens a Jade in Jewel
summary: HSBC has opened its second Jade Centre at Jewel Changi Airport in Singapore, marking the bank's affluent proposition for high net worth customers. The Jade Centre is designed to engage relationship managers with complex wealth needs. HSBC is also the naming rights partner for the 40-metre high HSBC Rain Vortex, the tallest indoor waterfall in the world. The bank's second Jade Centre in Singapore adds to its flagship branch at Claymore Road, catering to customers with at least S$1.2 million in cash and/or investments.

site_title: US stock futures slide as trade war escalates
summary: US stock futures slid 1.1% after trade talks between the US and China ended without a resolution, with China demanding the US remove all extra tariffs. The yen climbed and the Australian dollar slipped in early trading. The heightened tensions threaten to unwind gains in risk assets, following a week of optimism over progress between the two sides.

site_title: Earnings week sees fewer director filings
summary: Earnings week saw fewer director filings amid declining markets. The STI declined 3% from May 3-9, while the Hang Seng Index and S&P/ASX 200 Index declined 5.4% and 0.8%, respectively. The STI's 2019 total return is 8.4%.

site_title: Keppel snags S$150m offshore wind contract
summary: Keppel Corp has secured a contract worth over S$150 million to build two offshore wind farm substations for Orsted in Taiwan. Keppel FELS, a subsidiary of Keppel Offshore & Marine, will complete the work by 2021. The contract strengthens Keppel O&M's presence in the renewable energy sector and follows a major deal in the North Sea for TenneT Offshore. The deal supports the growing demand for offshore wind energy and aligns with Taiwan's goal of achieving 5.5GW of installed capacity by 2025.

site_title: South Korea's latest big export: Jobless college graduates
summary: South Korea is turning to job opportunities abroad for its jobless college graduates, with the government's K-move program placing graduates in 70 countries. In 2018, only 97,000 jobs were created, leading to nearly a quarter of young Koreans being unemployed. The country's unique business model, dominated by family-run conglomerates, has resulted in a low labor force participation rate. To address this, the government is bringing in foreign workers, particularly in blue-collar jobs, but some graduates have reported taking menial work abroad, with many losing touch with the government once overseas.

images.alt_text: Facing an unprecedented job crunch at home, many young South Koreans are now signing up for government-sponsored programmes designed to find overseas positions for a growing number of jobless college graduates in Asia's fourth largest economy.

site_title: Avengers: Endgame stays No 1; Detective Pikachu debuts with US$58m at North American box office
summary: Avengers: Endgame maintained its lead at the North American box office, collecting $65 million in its third weekend. It surpassed Avengers: Infinity War and Black Panther to become the third-highest grossing film domestically with $724 million. The movie remains the second-highest globally with $2.48 billion. Detective Pikachu, a live-action Pokémon adaptation, debuted with $58 million in 4,202 venues.

site_title: WeWork's starry valuation dazzles landlords, leaves critics unconvinced
summary: WeWork, a flexible office space startup, is set to go public with a planned IPO valued at $47 billion, making it the largest IPO of 2019. The company's valuation has dazzled landlords but raised concerns among critics, who question its ability to sustain profitability. WeWork's business model, which relies on short-term leases, has disrupted the traditional office leasing market, but its persistent losses and reliance on tenants' contracts have raised doubts about its long-term viability.

site_title: Bitcoin jumps to nine-month high
summary: Bitcoin surged to a nine-month high of $7,445, up 6.9% from Friday's close, as cryptocurrencies rebounded from a slump amid the New York attorney-general's investigation into Tether and Bitfinex. The price has more than doubled since its December trough and is rising for a sixth-straight day. This rebound follows a 11% decline in the Bloomberg Galaxy Crypto gauge last month, which was the biggest one-week slide this year.

site_title: Shortselling of oil jumps as sputtering trade talks darken outlook
summary: US oil prices fell for the third consecutive week amid pessimistic market sentiment due to sputtering trade talks and rising US production. Hedge funds increased bearish bets on West Texas Intermediate crude by 39%, the largest short-selling surge in over eight months. The US Commodity Futures Trading Commission reported a 10% decline in the net-long WTI position to 271,912 contracts. In contrast, Brent crude prices rose for the ninth straight week, as investors are less concerned about US production.

site_title: China's top security regulator seeks to ease volatility fears
summary: China's top security regulator, Yi Huiman, sought to ease concerns about stock-market volatility, attributing recent price swings to "external factors" rather than internal elements. Despite a 4.5% decline in the Shanghai Composite, Yi emphasized that economic fundamentals and company quality will drive long-term share prices. The commission is considering delisting "zombie" and "empty-shell" companies to improve market health, as China's major stock market remains the world's best-performing this year.

site_title: Butchers have their knives out for synthetic meats
summary: Butchers in Frankfurt express concerns over the growing popularity of synthetic meat products, which they believe threaten the essence of their profession and sales. Despite some young butchers acknowledging the trend and its potential to shift consumer attitudes, many remain skeptical about the taste, color, smell, and texture of plant-based alternatives. As big conglomerates like Nestle and Unilever enter the market, some butchers predict a limit to the industry's changes, with traditional products remaining a staple in their displays.

site_title: China defiant toward US on trade, Kudlow urges strong enforcement steps
summary: The US and China remain at a deadlock over trade negotiations, with the US demanding concrete changes to Chinese law and Beijing refusing to yield on key issues. The US has imposed tariffs on $200 billion worth of Chinese goods, and the US economy adviser Larry Kudlow urged "very strong" enforcement provisions for a potential deal. China has rejected the US demands, saying it will not "swallow bitter fruit" that harms its core interests. The situation has raised concerns about a potential retaliatory tariff hike and its impact on US farmers.

site_title: Bitcoin climbs above US$7,000 as cryptocurrency rally extends
summary: Bitcoin surged to a 9-month high, briefly surpassing US$7,000, as a rally in cryptocurrencies continued. The cryptocurrency advanced 11% to US$6,981.45, with the Bloomberg Galaxy Crypto Index up 7.6%. Despite reaching a 2017 peak of US$19,000, Bitcoin remains a long way off its previous high. The rally comes amidst concerns over regulators and a recent hack on a large exchange, with new threats to the digital currency space.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin climbed to the highest since September, briefly surpassing US$7,000, as a rally in cryptocurrencies gathered pace in trading over the weekend.

site_title: Man behind fintech hub Lattice80 locked in legal disputes in Seoul, Singapore
summary: A South Korean investor, Joe Cho Seunghyun, is being sued in Seoul and Singapore for allegedly failing to pay contractually promised returns to investors. Cho, the chairman and founder of Marvelstone Group, a Singapore-based fintech hub, is also being sued by Hong Leong Holdings for breaching a licence agreement. The lawsuits claim that Cho and the group failed to deposit revenue receipts into designated bank accounts, resulting in missed payments. Cho has denied the claims, stating they are "untrue" and that the disputes are being handled by solicitors.

site_title: Facebook takes down fake Italian accounts ahead of EU election
summary: Facebook has removed numerous Italian accounts on its platform ahead of the EU election, citing violations of its authenticity policy. The European Commission had urged tech companies to tackle fake news before the May 23-26 poll. Facebook also removed several pages due to name-changing violations. The move comes amid warnings of foreign interference in the election campaign.

site_title: Report picks out divergence in US housing wealth
summary: A report by ATTOM Data Solutions found that over 11% of mortgaged properties in the US are "seriously underwater," with over 5.2 million properties having loan balances at least 25% higher than their estimated market value. This represents an increase of nearly 600,000 from the post-recession low in 2017.

site_title: Investors optimistic about Vale's prospects
summary: Vale SA, the world's largest iron ore miner, posted a net loss of $1.6 billion in its worst-ever quarter due to a fatal dam disaster. Despite this, investors remain optimistic about the company's prospects, with shares gaining 2.6% in Brazil trading. Analysts believe that once Vale settles with authorities on compensation, investor focus will shift to fundamentals, potentially triggering a re-rating. The company has set aside $4.5 billion to cover potential costs and aims to meet its record 400 million-tonne production target in two to three years.

site_title: China's smaller developers getting cold shoulder from lenders
summary: China's smaller developers are struggling to secure offshore loans, despite offering attractive pricing, due to sector limits and concerns over a property slowdown. Smaller borrowers, such as Shanghai-based Zhenro Properties Group and Guangzhou-based China Aoyuan Group, have faced tepid responses from lenders, with loan deals taking months to complete. In contrast, high-yield bond sales from China's property sector have reached a record, with $27.7 billion raised so far in 2019, as investors become more risk-tolerant and developers tap into the bond market to refinance debt.

site_title: Disclosures on 1MDB probes were timely, relevant, and adequate
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) has defended its disclosures on 1MDB probes, stating they were timely, relevant, and adequate. This comes after Tan Chong Huat and Chan Yuet Ann suggested MAS should disclose more during ongoing investigations. MAS disagrees, citing its efforts to balance transparency with the need to protect ongoing investigations. The MAS has made public its regulatory findings and actions, but with some limitations.

site_title: This week will decide whether Goldilocks rally has run its course
summary: The US-China trade deal is at risk of unraveling, threatening the "Goldilocks" stock rally, which has driven major indexes to new record highs. The unexpected increase in US tariffs on Chinese imports by President Trump has led to a sell-off in US stocks, with the S&P 500 experiencing its biggest weekly loss this year. The trade deal's collapse could lead to slower US economic growth, higher inflation, and a return to the Federal Reserve's rate-hiking plans. This week's industrial-production and retail sales data will be closely watched to determine if the economy remains in a favorable state for the stock market.

site_title: The winner from Trump's Iran sanctions? Saudi Arabia
summary: President Donald Trump's Iran sanctions have led to Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf Arab countries benefiting from increased oil sales.
