SoftBank's Vision Fund, which holds stakes in all major ride-hailing companies, has delivered a 45% rate of return to limited partners, exceeding expectations.

site_title: Adtech startup Pencil aims for Series A in 12-18 months after S$1.5m seed round
summary: Singapore-based adtech startup Pencil has raised S$1.5 million in a seed round led by Wavemaker Partners, SGInnovate, and Entrepreneur First. The funds will be used to double its headcount, expand engineering and customer teams, and extend its patent-pending technology. Pencil aims to return to the market for further funding in 12-18 months, with plans to expand into English-speaking geographies such as the Philippines, Australia, and India. The company's first enterprise product, Studio, uses AI to generate personalized advertising content at scale, and it expects to achieve S$1 million in recurring revenue by its next fundraising attempt.

site_title: A vast, unwieldy, exhilarating spectacle
summary: The Venice Biennale, a prestigious art exhibition, kicked off with a grand spectacle, featuring over 20 national pavilions and numerous collateral events. The International Art Exhibition, curated by Ralph Rugoff, explores the state of art globally, with works by artists such as Martin Puryear, Teresa Margolles, and Sun Yuan and Peng Yu. The exhibition's theme, "May You Live in Interesting Times," aims to highlight the role of art in breaking barriers and challenging identity. With over 20 events and exhibitions, the biennale showcases a vast and unwieldy spectacle that attracts an elite audience.

site_title: Augmenting creativity with AI can take us much further
summary: The "Fourth Industrial Revolution" is transforming business in Singapore and South-east Asia with exponential technologies like AI and robotics, creating new business models and disrupting jobs. According to the World Economic Forum, creativity will become the third most important job skill by 2020, surpassing negotiation and emotional intelligence. However, most people do not consider themselves creative, with 60% of the population not seeing themselves as creative. To address this, businesses and workers must learn to harness and augment human creativity with AI, adopting a "SuperCreativity" mindset and toolkit. This concept, exemplified by the "Centaur Mindset" of human-machine collaboration, is already being applied in various industries.

site_title: China commercial properties woo more foreign investment in Q1
summary: China's commercial property sector saw a 14.6% rise in foreign investment in Q1 2019, accounting for 35% of total inflows, according to Cushman & Wakefield. Total investment reached $12 billion, with office space and retail being the most favored asset classes. However, leasing activity decreased to a 5-year low due to reduced occupancy costs, with net absorption at 474,000 square meters. The report noted an increasing preference for stabilized cash-flow generating assets over those with higher lease-up risk.

site_title: Betting On Cantonese Cuisine In Macau
summary: Macau has emerged as a culinary hub, rivalling Hong Kong and Guangzhou in preserving Cantonese cuisine. Two Michelin-starred restaurants, The Eight and Wing Lei Palace, offer exceptional fine dining experiences, with The Eight holding three Michelin stars. Chef Joseph Tse, executive chef of The Eight, emphasizes the importance of precision in stir-fry techniques, while Chef Tam Kwok Fung of Wing Lei Palace adapts traditional Cantonese cuisine to incorporate modern trends and ingredients. Meanwhile, Jade Dragon, another Michelin-starred restaurant, is led by young executive chef Kelvin Au Yeung, who is determined to maintain its reputation.

site_title: Mum's The Word
summary: This article highlights unique and personalized jewelry gift options for Mother's Day, including engraved pieces, custom-made jewelry, and special collections celebrating motherhood. Brands such as Gifts Less Ordinary, Jennifer Fisher, and Studio Emoi offer one-of-a-kind designs, while local jewellers like Annielka and Poh Heng provide simple yet meaningful options. Luxury brands like Tiffany & Co and Swarovski also feature heart-shaped pendants and star sign-inspired designs, perfect for celebrating mother figures.

images.alt_text: (Left) Swarovski Mother's Day Collection. (Right) Studio Emoi wired bracelet.
(Left) Jennifer Fisher 14K yellow gold Skinny Tag necklace with diamonds. (Center) Tiffany & Co. Keys collection. (Right) Celine Alphabet B necklace in brass with gold finish.
APM Monaco's Collection Kaleidoscope "Love Silver Bracelet" (Amour).

site_title: GM unveils US$700m Ohio investment, plans to sell shuttered plant
summary: GM announces a $700 million investment in Ohio, creating 450 jobs, to expand diesel engine production for heavy-duty trucks and other parts. The investment is part of the company's efforts to grow manufacturing jobs in the US, following a previous commitment to create 700 new jobs with a $1.8 billion investment. The move comes after GM sold its shuttered Lordstown plant to Workhorse, a company that produces electric delivery vehicles, drawing praise from President Trump.

site_title: Why Singapore spends more on foreign exchange fees than tuition
summary: Singapore spends an average of S$2,000 per household on foreign exchange fees, totaling S$2.8 billion annually, exceeding the country's S$1 billion spent on after-school tuition. This is largely due to hidden fees in exchange rate mark-ups, where banks and remittance providers charge individuals 15 times more than companies for each dollar sent. The practice harms consumers by impairing their judgment and is estimated to cost individuals an additional S$2 billion per year in hidden fees.

site_title: Curtain Raiser
summary: The Singapore International Festival of Arts (SIFA) opens on May 16 with a lineup of collaborative works, including Beware Of Pity, directed by Simon McBurney, and Dionysus, directed by Tadashi Suzuki. The festival features a mix of theatre, music, and dance, with other notable shows including 100 Keyboards and The Mysterious Lai Teck. The event promises to showcase cutting-edge performances, striking costumes, and music, with tickets available from Sistic.

site_title: Music & Memory
summary: Cats, the iconic musical by Andrew Lloyd Webber, continues to thrive 38 years after its debut. A movie adaptation starring Taylor Swift, Jennifer Hudson, and Judi Dench is set for release this Christmas. The musical, based on T.S. Elliot's Old Possum's Book of Practical Cats, will also return to the stage in Singapore, with a limited season at Marina Bay Sands from Dec 17, starting at S$50 tickets. The show has been translated into 15 languages and has been viewed by over 81 million people worldwide.

site_title: Kenny Pang
summary: Singaporeans are among the most sleep-deprived people in the world, with studies showing they sleep significantly less than their foreign counterparts. Sleep doctor Kenny Pang says those who claim to need only four hours of sleep are likely not getting enough "dream sleep," which is crucial for feeling refreshed. High-achievers may be able to function on less sleep due to their high metabolism, but those who sleep less than five hours have a higher risk of mortality. Sleep apnea is also prevalent, with one in three Singaporeans suffering from moderate to severe cases, and most going undiagnosed. Pang advises putting away devices before bedtime and using a wrist-worn device to accurately assess sleep quality.

site_title: Redefining Motherhood
summary: Four women entrepreneurs, Nichol Ng, Jessica Cheam, Hazleen Panayiotou, and Emily Perkin, share their experiences of balancing career and motherhood on their own terms. Despite the challenges, they have found ways to achieve fulfillment in both aspects. Ng, founder of FoodXervices, credits her ability to multitask and prioritize her tasks, while Cheam, founder of Eco-Business.com, emphasizes the importance of finding a supportive partner and environment. Panayiotou, founder of Amazing Trekkers Club, has found empowerment through her trekking expeditions, while Perkin, founder of Just Cause, has leveraged her experience in non-profit organizations to create a successful impact consulting firm. All four women acknowledge the benefits of having a supportive spouse and the flexibility of Singapore's work culture, which allows them to balance their careers and family responsibilities.

site_title: 'We can't live life based on what Trump tweets'
summary: US President Donald Trump has threatened to increase tariffs on billions of dollars in Chinese goods, casting doubt on the outcome of trade talks. However, companies in the Asean region, including Singapore, have already hedged their bets, with Singapore's Economic Development Board (EDB) noting that the country can't prepare for Trump's tweets. The EDB expects Singapore to benefit from a slowdown in trade, with companies investing in manufacturing capacity in South-east Asia. Experts believe Singapore will remain a hub for supply chains, particularly for companies operating in the region.

images.alt_text: At the dialogue were (from left) SCMO president Nicolas de Loisy, EDB executive director Lee Eng Keat and moderator Sophie Kamaruddin.

site_title: ARA US Hospitality Trust debuts a shade off but ends day at IPO price of US$0.88
summary: ARA US Hospitality Trust debuted on the Singapore Exchange's mainboard at US$0.875 per stapled security, slightly below its IPO price of US$0.88. The trust raised US$498 million, with 565.9 million stapled securities issued to 6 cornerstone investors. The IPO was 0.6% or half a US cent below the offer price, amid a weaker market. The trust will focus on organic growth opportunities through active asset management and accretive investments.

site_title: China developer Agile Group expands into new energy vehicles with We Solutions
summary: China-based property developer Agile Group has partnered with electric vehicle technology provider We Solutions to develop new energy vehicles and build towns for NEVs. Agile acquired a 5.89% stake in We Solutions for HK$203 million, with most funds used for projects. This move follows China Evergrande Group's investment in the NEV industry, aiming to be a big player in the market. Agile joins its peer in betting on growth in the NEV market, with plans to research, develop, and produce NEV-related technology in China.

site_title: HDB resale volume up 16.5% in April, resale prices slip 0.4%: SRX
summary: The volume of Housing and Development Board (HDB) resale flats in Singapore increased by 16.5% in April compared to the previous month, while resale prices slipped 0.4% from March. This trend is seen as within expectation, with many flats reaching their five-year minimum occupation period, making them eligible for resale. Prices for mature estates decreased by 1.4% year-over-year, while prices for non-mature estates remained stagnant. The median transaction over X-Value (TOX) was negative $1,000, indicating that buyers may be overpaying for some flats.

images.alt_text: A market watcher says owners of units in mature estates may have accepted lower price offers because of competition from newer units hitting the five-year mark, making them eligible for sale.

site_title: New CPF rules to expand pool of buyers for older homes
summary: Singapore has introduced new CPF rules to expand the pool of buyers for older homes, allowing buyers to use their CPF savings to purchase properties with remaining leases of at least 20 years. The changes aim to stabilize prices and increase demand for such properties, particularly among older buyers. The revised rules will also provide greater flexibility for HDB flat buyers, enabling them to tap into their CPF savings for up to 90% of the property's valuation. Analysts expect prices to stabilize and potentially rise, and the changes may boost the liquidity of older flats and apartments in the market.

site_title: Oxley responds to SGX queries on Chevron House sale
summary: Oxley Holdings has sold its 32-storey commercial development, Chevron House, to Golden Compass for up to S$1.025 billion. The property was valued at S$787 million as of June 2018. Oxley will assume S$520 million in bank loans and receive S$295 million upon final completion. The deal includes a retention sum and the sale of retail and banking units, with the proceeds to be used to pay off loans and share costs between Oxley and Golden Compass. The sale is expected to have a positive impact on Oxley's earnings per share and net asset value.

site_title: Yen hits three-month high on US-China trade conflict
summary: The Japanese yen surged to a three-month high against the US dollar, driven by investor concerns over the escalating US-China trade conflict. The yen rose 0.3% to 109.6 yen, its highest level since February, as traders sought a safe-haven currency amid growing tensions. The Australian dollar and US dollar fell, while the Chinese yuan hit a four-month low. Speculators increased their net long dollar bets against the yen, citing the yuan's role as a global anchor of stability. The move reflects investor fears of further escalation in the trade conflict.

site_title: The most powerful car Mercedes makes is almost here
summary: The Mercedes-AMG GT 4-Door Coupe, a powerful and luxurious car, made its regional debut in Malaysia on May 3. The GT 63 S version, with 639 horsepower, is expected to arrive in Singapore in July, potentially retailing for up to S$900,000. The car offers a balance of comfort and performance, with all-wheel drive and a 0-100km/h time of just 3.2 seconds. While the GT 63 S is not expected to be a volume seller, its entry-level variant, the GT 53, is expected to be more affordable.

site_title: Technology's a boon and a bane; deploy and use with circumspection
summary: Technology has both positive and negative impacts on modern life, with AI and automation making many tasks easier and more convenient, but also raising concerns about over-dependence, cybersecurity, and job displacement. While technology has improved lives and saved lives, it is essential to adopt it where it has a real capacity to improve the human condition, not just for the sake of innovation. Common sense and circumspection are needed in its application and use to avoid negative consequences.

site_title: 'Non-existent trade receivables' enabled China Environment to understate loss by 340m yuan
summary: Independent auditors of China Environment found a 339.9 million yuan discrepancy in the company's 2015 net loss, attributed to "non-existent trade receivables" from 2013-2015. The auditors' report states the net loss should have been 450.8 million yuan instead of the announced 110.9 million yuan. This discrepancy was underreported by 340 million yuan, indicating potential financial mismanagement.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Frencken Group is expected to post robust year-on-year growth due to industrial automation orders and growth in its analytical and medical units. The company is undervalued and is expected to rerate upwards as earnings growth continues. Hongkong Land's office leasing demand has softened, but the company's Central office portfolio vacancy is expected to fall as tenants take up committed space. Despite softer demand, the company's valuation is attractive, trading at a 47% discount to its appraised current net asset value.

site_title: Qantas flags record annual revenue as leisure travel grows
summary: Qantas reported a 2.3% increase in quarterly revenue to A$4.4 billion, driven by growing leisure travel. The airline forecasts record annual revenue, with analysts expecting A$18.03 billion, up 5.6% from last year. Qantas shares rose 4% after the announcement, with CEO Alan Joyce citing long-term fleet and network changes as key drivers of revenue growth. The airline also settled a terminal sale and secured future access for A$355 million.

site_title: Story Time
summary: De Relaxette, a free program at the Singapore International Festival of Arts, allows participants to relax in revolving hammocks while listening to a master storyteller. The event, which began in 2019, provides a unique and immersive experience. Guests are given noise-cancelling headphones and a short story to choose from, then settle into the hammocks for a transportive experience. This program has been a part of the festival since its inception, offering a tranquil escape for those attending.

site_title: Powell highlights problem of stagnant US middle class incomes
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell highlighted the US middle class's stagnant income growth, widening inequality, and declining economic prospects. Middle-class Americans believe having a secure job and ability to save define being middle class, but income growth has lagged in recent decades. Factors beyond effort and talent, including family background, neighborhood, and education, also play a significant role. Powell emphasized the need to address these issues to ensure lower-income families reach the middle class and maintain economic security for middle-class status.

site_title: China says it's all set to defend its interests in trade war with US
summary: China is prepared to defend its interests in the ongoing trade war with the US, but hopes for a resolution through dialogue. Vice-Premier Liu He's delegation is meeting with US officials to salvage a deal, but US President Trump has threatened to hike tariffs on $200 billion of Chinese goods to 25% on Friday. China has made preparations to respond to possible outcomes and has accused the US of backtracking on earlier commitments. China is willing to continue talks, but is determined to defend its interests, with a growing trade deficit and intellectual property concerns driving US demands.

site_title: US March wholesale inventories revised down
summary: US wholesale inventories were revised down to a 0.1% decline in March, contrary to initial reports of no change. This is the first decline since October 2017, following a 0.4% increase in February. Sales at wholesalers rose 2.3% in March, the largest increase since May 2018, and it would take wholesalers 1.32 months to clear shelves at the current sales pace. The revised inventory data is expected to restrain economic growth, particularly in the third quarter, as businesses place fewer orders and dispose of unwanted goods.

images.alt_text: The inventory overhang is mostly visible in the automobile industry, despite recent decreases.

site_title: Jaguar XF review: Old school delights
summary: The updated Jaguar XF prioritizes luxury over advanced technology, offering a traditional driving experience. The vehicle's focus on physical isolation from the outside world is reminiscent of pre-digital era luxury cars. The new model features a 2.0-liter engine and a more refined interior, providing a sense of comfort and refinement. While it may not be a groundbreaking car, the Jaguar XF delivers a luxurious driving experience that appeals to those seeking a more traditional approach to luxury vehicles.

images.alt_text: Driving the XF is immensely pleasurable, with nary a peep from the engine while cruising.

site_title: Ant Financial, Tencent, join HK virtual banking race
summary: Tencent, Ant Financial, and Industrial & Commercial Bank of China Ltd have won licenses to create virtual lenders in Hong Kong, entering the city's traditional banking sector. Tencent partnered with ICBC's local unit and Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Ltd. Ant and Xiaomi also received permits through local entities, marking a significant shift in the city's banking landscape. This move is expected to shake up the traditional banking sector and bring major players into the virtual banking market.

site_title: Silicon Valley is coming for your house
summary: Silicon Valley tech companies are entering the real estate market through "instant buying" or "iBuying," where they buy homes, perform light maintenance, and resell them quickly. Companies like Zillow, Opendoor, and Offerpad aim to use algorithms to predict home values and offer efficiency and convenience to the process. However, critics worry that this model could bring volatility and risk to the industry and may not work in all markets. The trend is growing, with established companies and traditional brokerage firms announcing plans to get into the game, and companies like Zillow expect to buy 5,000 homes per month in three to five years.

site_title: After disputed polls, Thais expected to keep Prayut as PM
summary: Thailand's pro-military Palang Pracharat party is expected to form a government with a slim majority in the House of Representatives, keeping military junta leader Prayut Chan-o-cha as prime minister. The party will likely join forces with the Democrat and Bhumjaithai parties, securing the 126 votes needed under the new electoral system. The Democratic Front of seven parties, led by the Pheu Thai party loyal to exiled former prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra, has cried foul over the electoral system and threatened legal action. The new government is expected to be unstable, with the military regime maintaining control.

site_title: For connoisseurs and Joe Sixpack: Swig on canned wines
summary: A California couple, Gina Schober and Jake Stover, founded Sans Wine Co in 2016 to produce fine, organic wines in convenient, lightweight cans. The company's single-vineyard, varietal wines cater to those who love wine but don't want the hassle of heavy bottles. Canned wines have gained popularity, with sales reaching $70 million in the US in 2019, and are now being sold in restaurants and online. The cans' advantages include portability, environmental friendliness, and cost-effectiveness, making them a great value for consumers.

site_title: German tax revenues to rise more slowly as economy cools
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel's government predicted that tax revenues will rise more slowly than expected due to slowing global economic growth, primarily caused by trade wars. The expected shortfall of 124 billion euros over the next four years will impact government spending and investments, with some parties calling for spending reductions and others urging corporate tax cuts. Despite this, the government vows to stick to its "black zero" policy, avoiding fresh debt. The economic slowdown is attributed to "man-made" causes, with the US and China's trade wars impacting Germany's export power.

site_title: Deutsche Bank bosses set to face angry shareholders
summary: Deutsche Bank executives face opposition from shareholders at the annual general meeting on May 23. Major investor advisory firms Glass Lewis and ISS have urged shareholders not to endorse the executive team's performance in 2018, citing the bank's inability to cover its costs and self-inflicted reputation damage. The bank's former co-chiefs Anshu Jain and Juergen Fitschen resigned in 2015 after a confrontational AGM. The votes have no binding consequences, but signal to executives that they face growing discontent among investors.

site_title: Meat matters at The Feather Blade
summary: The Feather Blade is a no-frills eatery offering a single signature off-cut steak for S$21, with no appetizers, main courses, or desserts. Despite the simplicity, the steak is cooked to perfection via sous vide and served with a bearnaise sauce. The restaurant also offers four sides and a burger, with prices ranging from S$7 to S$21. While The Feather Blade is praised for its affordability and promotion of off-cuts, it has been criticized for its limited options and association with budget meals. Overall, the restaurant scores 6.5 out of 10, making it a good option for those looking for a cheap and friendly steak-eating experience.

images.alt_text: The Feather Blade is a steak house. Not "steakhouse". It serves just one kind of steak - the titular feather blade or flat iron (above), with the occasional sides such as smashed potatoes and corn and onsen tamago.

The Feather Blade is a steak house. Not "steakhouse". It serves just one kind of steak - the titular feather blade or flat iron, with the occasional sides such as smashed potatoes and corn (above) and onsen tamago.

The Feather Blade is a steak house. Not "steakhouse". It serves just one kind of steak - the titular feather blade or flat iron, with the occasional sides such as smashed potatoes and corn and onsen tamago (above).

site_title: Nissan Leaf review: A current affair
summary: The Nissan Leaf is a highly-regarded electric car with over 400,000 units sold worldwide, making it the best-selling electric car in history. Its e-Pedal system allows for smooth, one-pedal driving, recovering energy and slowing the car to a halt. The Leaf is also a practical and efficient vehicle, with a spacious interior and a range of up to 300km on a single charge. Despite its success, the Leaf is often overlooked due to its unassuming design, but it remains a top choice for those looking to make the switch to electric power, with a proven track record and low battery failure rates.

site_title: RBA takes 'responsibilty' for currency note typo
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has acknowledged a typo on the country's most widely circulated currency note, the A$50 bill, which contains the word "responsibility" misspelled as "responsibilty" three times. The error was discovered on a magnified photo sent to a radio station and was present on the note since its introduction in October 2018. The RBA has confirmed the error and stated that the notes are still legal tender, but will correct the spelling during the next print run.

images.alt_text: The goof first became known on Thursday, when a listener to radio broadcaster Triple M sent it a magnified photo of the Reserve Bank of Australia's (RBA) new A$50 note highlighting the word "responsibility" misspelt as "responsibilty" three times.

site_title: Out Of This World
summary: China's sci-fi blockbuster "The Wandering Earth" has grossed over $700 million worldwide, making it the country's second-highest-grossing film and second-highest-grossing non-English film of all time. Directed by Frant Gwo, the film was made on a budget of $50 million and has been praised for its stunning CGI landscapes and action-packed plot. Despite some cheesy lines and a lack of originality, the film has proven that China can compete with Hollywood in the sci-fi genre, laying the groundwork for future Chinese productions.

site_title: Huawei CFO to seek extradition stay, citing Trump comments
summary: Huawei CFO Meng Wanzhou, who is fighting extradition on US charges, is seeking a stay of proceedings citing US President Donald Trump's comments about the case. Meng's lawyers argue that Trump's statements disqualify the US from pursuing the matter in Canada, and that her arrest was unlawful and based on political considerations. Meng claims she was detained, searched, and interrogated at Vancouver's airport, and that there is no evidence she misrepresented to a bank about Huawei's relationship with a company operating in Iran.

images.alt_text: Meng's case has attracted global attention and sparked a diplomatic crisis between Beijing and Ottawa.

site_title: Officials warn of lead pollution risks after Notre-Dame blaze
summary: Paris officials warn of lead pollution risks after the Notre-Dame cathedral fire, which released lead particles in areas surrounding the church. Analysis detected high levels of lead dust, 10-20 grammes per kilogramme, in soil samples, compared to normal background levels of 0.3 g/kg. The areas remain off limits to the public due to the hazardous conditions.

site_title: Facebook's Zuckerberg in Paris to talk elections, online hate
summary: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg met with French President Emmanuel Macron in Paris to discuss future internet regulation and online hate speech. The meeting follows last year's co-regulation pilot, which aims to curb hate speech on the platform. France plans to upgrade its hate speech laws next year, and the meeting is part of Macron's "Tech for Good" initiative. Zuckerberg also plans to co-chair a global meeting on May 15 with New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern to curb violent extremism online.

site_title: CPF, HDB housing loan rules for buying older properties updated
summary: Singapore has updated its CPF and HDB housing loan rules, allowing homeowners to use their CPF for older properties as long as the remaining lease can cover them until 95 years old. The new rules, effective May 10, increase flexibility for buyers of both HDB flats and private properties. For HDB flats, the minimum lease requirement for CPF usage is reduced to 20 years from 30 years. This change aims to provide greater flexibility for Singaporeans to buy a home for life.

site_title: MAS bans 2 former brokerage employees, insurance agent for dishonest conduct
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has banned three individuals for dishonest conduct. Jeremy Lee Seow Poh, former managing director at Jefferies Singapore, was banned for four years for failing to disclose bond trades from 2011 to 2012. Additionally, a former insurance agent at Legacy and another individual were also prohibited from working in the industry. The MAS imposed the bans after finding that the individuals had engaged in dishonest conduct, affecting the integrity of the financial markets.

site_title: US securities regulator proposes to change accelerated filer definitions
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has proposed changes to "accelerated filer" definitions for public companies. The proposed changes would exclude smaller-reporting companies with annual revenues under $100 million from an outside auditor review of internal controls. Industry advocates praise the move as an incentive to boost the number of smaller companies raising capital in the public markets, potentially increasing access to capital for these firms. The proposal is subject to a 60-day public comment period.

site_title: US: Stocks close lower again amid trade war jitters
summary: US stocks fell 0.5% on Thursday, closing at 25,828.36, amid trade war jitters ahead of key US-China negotiations. Investors weighed the latest developments, which saw the Dow Jones Industrial Average finish lower. Despite this, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records. The Singapore Stock Index rose 0.4% on Thursday, while the STI also gained 0.4%. Despite tariff uncertainty, investors remained positive.

site_title: Europe: Shares tumble amid trade tensions
summary: European shares dropped 0.7% on Thursday, hitting a four-week low, amid trade tensions between the US and China. US President Trump said China "broke the deal" in trade talks, threatening new tariffs on $200 billion of Chinese goods. Heavyweight bank stocks, including Italy's Banco BPM and UniCredit, declined, while semiconductor stocks fell 1.6%. Investors sought safety in defensive stocks, with telecom, utilities, and real estate seeing the smallest losses.

site_title: Lion Global chief gets lifetime achievement award
summary: Lion Global Investors (LGI) CEO Gerard Lee has been awarded a lifetime achievement award by Asia Asset Management for his leadership and strategic foresight. The award caps a career spanning over three decades, with LGI's assets under management growing from S$29 billion in 2010 to US$41 billion. Lee is known for championing retail investors and reducing costs, launching low-cost funds such as the Lion Global All Seasons Fund. He believes it's essential to find fulfillment beyond financial success, and the industry must tackle high costs and intermediation to benefit retail investors.

site_title: Chevron drops US$33b bid for Anadarko, ceding key oil asset to Occidental
summary: Chevron has dropped its US$33 billion bid for Anadarko Petroleum, ending a 15-year takeover battle and allowing Occidental Petroleum to acquire Anadarko for US$38 billion. Occidental's deal includes a US$10 billion investment from Berkshire Hathaway, positioning it to become a dominant force in the US oil industry, particularly in the Permian Basin and Gulf of Mexico. Chevron cited cost and capital discipline as reasons for its decision, while Occidental's CEO likely views the acquisition as a strategic move to expand its presence in the US oil market.

site_title: Pope changes Church law to make reporting sex abuse obligatory
summary: Pope Francis has passed a landmark measure to oblige those aware of sex abuse in the Catholic Church to report it to their superiors, with every diocese worldwide required to have a reporting system by June 2020. The law, which comes into effect on June 1, applies retroactively, allowing reports of old cases. However, it does not require reporting to civil authorities, and secrets revealed in confession are protected. The move aims to bring new cases to light and empower the Church to bring predators to justice, but critics say it does not go far enough in addressing the issue.

site_title: China Gaoxian reveals 3 undisclosed interested person transactions in 2016
summary: China Gaoxian Fibre Fabric Holdings revealed three undisclosed interested person transactions (IPTs) from its 2016 financial year, including a 4.4 million yuan loan to a trading company and a 30.3 million yuan loan to another company. The transactions were deemed normal commercial terms and not prejudicial to the company's interests. The audit committee found the non-disclosure was "unintentional and due to inadvertent oversight" and determined no further action was necessary, as the loans have been repaid and the transactions were in the ordinary course.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 15.02 points lower at 1,618.53 on Thursday, with a volume of 2.1 billion lots worth RM2 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 610 to 246.

site_title: Opec in the dark on oil supply as Russia, Iran cut exports
summary: Opec is uncertain about the oil supply outlook for the second half of 2019 due to Russian and Iranian export cuts. A pipeline outage in Russia and US sanctions on Iran are expected to further reduce oil supplies. Saudi Arabia is reluctant to increase production, fearing a price crash. Analysts predict a potential 400,000 bpd reduction in Russian exports, which could tighten the market. Opec and its allies will discuss the market at a meeting in June, but conflicting views on the significance of the Russian outage complicate the decision-making process.

images.alt_text: Opec is in the dark on the oil supply outlook for the second half of this year, with Iranian and Russian outages looking increasingly significant but Saudi Arabia reluctant to pump more due to fears of a price crash, sources in the organisation said.

site_title: Powell: "Crucial" US restore health of middle class, pathways to it
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell emphasized the need for the US to address issues affecting the middle class, citing slow income growth, widening inequality, and declining prospects for the poor to move up the economic ladder. Research shows that factors such as family background, neighborhood, and education quality play a significant role in determining middle-class status. Powell stated that fostering conditions for lower-income families to reach the middle class and ensuring middle-class status provides economic security are two-fold challenges for the country.

site_title: Maxi-Cash Q1 net profit soars 55.2% to S$2.8m
summary: Maxi-Cash Financial Services' first-quarter net profit rose 55.2% to S$2.8 million, driven by a decrease in operating expenses such as foreign exchange losses. Revenue fell 13.5% to S$46.6 million, primarily due to lower sales in the retail and trading business. Despite increased finance and staff costs, the company reported a decrease in other operating expenses and a higher earnings per share of 0.27 Singapore cents.

site_title: EU unveils 10-point blueprint for post-Brexit future
summary: European leaders unveiled a 10-point blueprint, known as the Sibiu Declaration, to guide the EU's post-Brexit future. The declaration emphasizes unity, fairness, and protecting democracy and the rule of law. It also pledges to safeguard the future for future generations and protect citizens. The 10 points include defending one Europe, staying united, and delivering where it matters most. The declaration sets a five-year agenda, with European Parliamentary elections and a new EU leadership team to be named before the end of the year. Britain's departure from the EU is expected to trigger a new era for the bloc.

images.alt_text: Poland's Prime Minister Mateusz Morawiecki arrives for the Informal Summit of Heads of State or Government of the European Union. European leaders revealed a broad-brush statement of principles to guide them into the post-Brexit future on Thursday, promising a "new Union at 27 ready to embrace its future as one."

site_title: PSA and SATS join hands to improve sea and air connectivity
summary: PSA International and SATS, a ground handler and in-flight caterer, have partnered to improve supply chain efficiency and sea and air connectivity for cargo owners and logistics service providers. The partnership aims to enhance data transparency, ease of shipment movement, and regulatory compliance through initiatives such as yard-to-port data linkages, network extensions, and integrated systems. The goal is to make Singapore a stronger global transshipment hub for air and sea cargo, enabling innovative multimodal solutions, lower costs, and faster delivery.

site_title: Genting Singapore Q1 net profit falls 5% on lower gaming revenue
summary: Genting Singapore reported a 5% decline in first-quarter net profit to S$205.5 million, primarily due to lower gaming revenue. The company's gaming revenue fell 8% to S$430.2 million, while non-gaming revenue rose 1% to S$209.3 million. Genting plans to invest S$4.5 billion in Resorts World Sentosa expansion. Despite this, investment bank Nomura lowered its earnings forecasts and target price, citing expected volatility. Genting Singapore's shares closed unchanged at S$0.95.

site_title: US goods trade deficit with China drops to five-year low
summary: The US goods trade deficit with China decreased 16.2% to a five-year low of $20.7 billion in March, driven by a surge in soybean exports. The overall trade deficit increased 1.5% to $50.0 billion, while imports from China fell 6.1%. Exports to China jumped 23.6% in March, and the trade data has been volatile amid US-China trade tensions. The decline in the trade deficit is seen as a positive sign for the US economy, but economists still expect a trimmed initial GDP growth estimate.

site_title: Prince Harry given baby romper at first workday as father
summary: Prince Harry marked a year until the 2020 Invictus Games, a sporting event he founded for wounded military personnel, with his first public outing since the birth of his son Archie. At the event, he received a baby romper with the Invictus Games logo and a soft toy, and he also wore a customized jacket with the words "Invictus Family" and "Daddy." The games will be held in The Hague next year, and Prince Harry emphasized the importance of the event for veterans, saying it was a "reason" he chose to participate.

site_title: Indonesia should probe deaths of election staff - parliament deputy
summary: Indonesia's parliament deputy is calling for an investigation into the deaths of over 500 election staff, most linked to fatigue-related illnesses, during the April 17 presidential vote. The vote, which combined presidential, national, and regional parliamentary ballots, saw 7 million officials work in challenging conditions, with 456 staff dying and 4,310 falling ill. The government has agreed to pay compensation, but critics say more needs to be done to address the risks faced by election officials, including long hours, stress, and poor working conditions.

site_title: Ascendas Hospitality Trust posts 2.9% rise in Q4 DPS
summary: Ascendas Hospitality Trust posted a 2.9% year-on-year rise in distribution per stapled security (DPS) to 1.77 Singapore cents for the fourth quarter, driven by contributions from acquired hotels and lower net finance costs. Income available for distribution was up 3.5% to S$20.1 million. The trust's full-year DPS rose 2.9% to 6.03 Singapore cents, and portfolio valuation increased 11.5% to S$1.8 billion. Despite challenging conditions, the trust's CEO believes the acquisitions have improved the portfolio's resilience and stability.

site_title: US: Wall Street falls at open as crucial trade talks resume
summary: US stocks fell at the open on Thursday as high-stakes trade talks between the US and China resumed, despite looming tariffs on Chinese goods. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.34%, the S&P 500 fell 0.68%, and the Nasdaq Composite declined 1.13%. The uncertainty surrounding the trade talks weighed on investor sentiment, leading to a decline in market values. The US-China trade deal's fate remains uncertain, with additional tariffs on Chinese goods still in effect.

images.alt_text: US stocks dropped at the open on Thursday, with focus on a high-stakes meeting between the United States and China that could decide the fate of a long-awaited trade deal, even as additional tariffs on Chinese goods loomed.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares suffer more losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 2.39% on Thursday, following a sell-off fueled by China-US trade tensions. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 28,311.07, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also fell 1.48% and 1.28%, respectively. Investors await the resumption of China-US trade talks later in the day, which may impact markets.

site_title: Shell to shut Malaysia oilfield in July for maintenance; Kimanis exports to drop
summary: Royal Dutch Shell plans to shut its Gumusut-Kakap oilfield in eastern Malaysia in July for 27 days, reducing Kimanis crude exports from eight to three cargoes in July to early August. This will tighten Asian crude supplies. The shutdown is expected to impact the global energy market.

site_title: Oxley discloses more conditions for S$1.025b Chevron House sale
summary: Oxley Holdings has disclosed more conditions for the sale of its S$1.025 billion Chevron House property. The sale, to US-based real estate fund AEW, is subject to adjustments based on the completion of Alteration, Enhancement, Improvement (AEI) works and divestment of retail and banking units. The company will receive an initial S$210 million and S$295 million upon final completion, with the remaining S$520 million of bank loans to be discharged by the buyer. Oxley also has retention sums tied to the sale, including up to 10% of the office tower and banking hall values.

site_title: OUE C-Reit Q1 DPU rises 47.5% to 0.9 Singapore cent
summary: OUE Commercial Reit (OUE C-Reit) reported a 47.5% increase in its distribution per unit (DPU) to 0.90 Singapore cent for the first quarter ended March 31, driven by a full quarter's contribution from office components of OUE Downtown and one-off income from other Singapore properties. Gross revenue rose 25.5% and net property income climbed 23.5%. The trust manager expects positive operational performance in 2019, citing narrowed gaps between market rents and expiring rents in Singapore's Grade A CBD core office market.

site_title: Europe rejects Iran 'ultimatum' but stands by nuke deal
summary: European powers rejected Iran's "ultimatums" and vowed to fight to save the Iran nuclear deal, amid rising tensions with the US. Iran threatened to defy some restrictions under the 2015 accord and go further if Europe fails to deliver sanctions relief within 60 days. European leaders, including French President Emmanuel Macron, appealed for calm and urged Iran to stick to the deal. The EU statement emphasized the International Atomic Energy Agency's role in monitoring Iran's compliance, but no concrete action is likely until the inspectors' next report.

site_title: Britain's answer to 'King Tut's tomb' found on roadside
summary: Archaeologists in the UK have discovered a 1,400-year-old Anglo-Saxon burial chamber, believed to be the oldest example of a Christian royal burial in Britain. The site, found on a roadside near a pub and supermarket, contains gold coins, glass and wooden drinking vessels, and fragments of a lyre, making it comparable to King Tut's tomb. The tomb is thought to belong to a prince, possibly Seaxa, brother of King Saebert, who died between 575 and 605. The discovery, made by a team of 40 researchers, is being hailed as a significant find in British archaeology.

site_title: Financial services, healthcare among sectors to see strongest job growth in 2019: report
summary: Singapore's job market is expected to see strong growth in 2019, with key sectors including financial services, healthcare, and engineering. According to Kelly Services' 2019 Singapore Salary Guide, financial services will create 2,000 new jobs by 2020, while the healthcare sector needs to almost double its long-term care workers to support the ageing population. The manufacturing sector remains the largest contributor to the economy, but faces a shortage of local engineers. To address these challenges, the government has committed S$72 million to workforce training and development until 2020.

site_title: Singapore shares continue losing streak, drop 0.4% on Thursday
summary: Singapore's benchmark index dropped 0.4% on Thursday, extending its losses to 14.14 points, as US President's tweets on increased tariffs on Chinese imports weighed on the market. Despite this, the local market fared better than regional peers. The MSCI Asia-Pacific Index slipped 1.1% between Wednesday and Thursday.

site_title: Sheeran doubles fortune but Lloyd Webber is richest UK musician
summary: Andrew Lloyd Webber has become Britain's wealthiest musician with an estimated fortune of £820 million, surpassing Paul McCartney. Lloyd Webber, 71, wrote the scores for successful musicals like "Cats" and "The Phantom of the Opera." McCartney's fortune has dropped to £750 million, while U2 ranks third with a joint worth of £583 million. The ranking reflects a change in fortunes, with McCartney and U2 previously holding top spots.

site_title: Indonesia outperforms for geothermal energy: Fitch Solutions
summary: Indonesia outperforms in geothermal energy, with Fitch Solutions predicting a 9.2% year-on-year growth in geothermal generation from 2019 to 2022, surpassing the US as the country with the largest geothermal capacity. The country's geothermal power potential remains largely untapped, despite supportive regulations. However, risks include artificially low government-regulated electricity tariffs, local content requirements, and the attractiveness of thermal energy due to Indonesia's vast hydrocarbon reserves.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall more than 3% on escalating trade tensions
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index fell 3.04% to 2,102.01 points, its fourth consecutive decline, amid escalating US-China trade tensions. Foreign investors sold 186.2 billion won worth of shares, and the won weakened against the US dollar. US President Trump reiterated his threat to impose additional tariffs on Chinese goods, further spooking investors. The won dropped 0.88% against the dollar, and the benchmark bond yield fell, with investors seeking safe-haven assets.

site_title: ARA US Hospitality Trust debuts on SGX mainboard at US$0.875, just off IPO price
summary: ARA US Hospitality Trust made its trading debut on the Singapore Exchange's mainboard at US$0.875 per stapled security, 0.6% below its IPO price of US$0.88. The trust raised US$498 million through the issuance of 565.9 million stapled securities. Its initial portfolio is valued at US$719.5 million, comprising 38 upscale select-service hotels with 4,950 rooms. The trust aims to focus on organic growth and accretive investments through active asset management, with support from institutional and retail investors.

site_title: Frencken Q1 net profit up 27.2% to S$8.6m on industrial automation sales
summary: Frencken Group, a technology solutions provider, reported a 27.2% increase in first-quarter net profit to S$8.6 million, driven by a surge in industrial automation sales. Revenue rose 14.7% to S$159.1 million, with the core mechatronics division boosted by storage drive production equipment orders from a key Asian customer. The company attributed the growth to the industrial automation segment, which offset a slump in semiconductor-related revenues.

site_title: North Korea fires unidentified projectile: South's military
summary: North Korea fired an unidentified projectile from its northwest location towards the east, according to South Korea's military chiefs. The incident comes less than a week after the country's leader Kim Jong Un oversaw the test-firing of multiple rockets and a missile. This is the latest escalation of tensions on the Korean peninsula, following a previous launch of a short-range missile from the east coast. The projectile's origin and destination are unclear, but the launch site is believed to be a medium-range Rodong missile base.

site_title: US producer prices rise moderately in April
summary: US producer prices rose 0.2% in April, matching March's increase, and 2.2% year-over-year. This was slightly higher than economists' expectations. The core PPI, excluding food, energy, and trade services, rose 0.4% in April, its largest increase since January 2018. Despite a strong economy and labor market, inflation pressures remain moderate, with the Federal Reserve's preferred inflation measure, the core PCE price index, increasing 1.6% year-over-year. The Fed kept interest rates unchanged, citing "somewhat weaker" inflation.

site_title: British govt to spend £200m fixing cladding on 170 high-rise buildings
summary: The British government will spend £200m to replace combustible cladding on 170 high-rise buildings after private developers refused to pay for the work. The move comes two years after the Grenfell Tower fire, which killed 71 people, and amid concerns that many developers are passing on the cost to residents. Prime Minister Theresa May stated that it is "paramount importance" that residents feel safe in their homes, and the government will fully fund the replacement of cladding.

site_title: Drone sighting briefly grounds flights at Frankfurt airport
summary: Frankfurt airport was briefly grounded for nearly an hour on May 9, 2019, due to a drone sighting in the southern part of the airport area. The incident occurred just weeks after a similar incident in March, which caused 60 flight cancellations. German air traffic controllers reported 158 drone-related disruptions to scheduled flights in 2018, an 80% increase from the previous year. This is not an isolated incident, as London's Gatwick airport was also shut down for three days last December due to drone sightings.

images.alt_text: Frankfurt airport was shut down for nearly an hour on Thursday morning as operators halted flights over a drone sighting, in the latest such incident affecting a busy European hub.

site_title: New catalytic system helps firms turn CO2 emissions into fuel
summary: A new catalytic system, developed by IHI Corporation and the Institute of Chemical and Engineering Sciences, can efficiently convert carbon dioxide into methane, a potential fuel source. The system, powered by a specially-developed catalyst, can cut emissions by converting CO2 and hydrogen into methane, a main component of liquefied natural gas. A small demonstration unit is being launched on May 10, with the technology expected to hit the market as soon as next year, potentially reducing emissions for firms.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Best World has initiated defamation proceedings against Bonitas Research and its founder in the Singapore High Court. The company, founded by Dora Hoan and Doreen Tan, claims Bonitas Research made false statements about them. Meanwhile, Vietnam expressed surprise over the US's decision to impose tariffs, seeking a lower rate. The Asian garment industry is bracing for the impact of higher US tariffs.

site_title: Philippines cuts interest rates after sharp growth slowdown
summary: The Philippines central bank lowered its benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points to 4.5% amid a sharp slowdown in inflation and economic growth. The decision, made by Governor Benjamin Diokno, reverses 175 basis points of rate hikes from last year. Inflation has eased to within the 2-4% target, while economic growth contracted to a four-year low of 5.6% in the first quarter. The central bank also lowered its inflation forecast for this year to 2.9% and raised its 2020 projection to 3.1%.

site_title: World food prices climb in April, cereal output seen rising
summary: World food prices rose 1.5% in April, driven by a 5.2% increase in dairy prices and a 3.0% rise in meat prices, according to the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO). Despite a 2.8% decline in the cereal index, the FAO forecasted a record 2.722 billion tonnes of global cereal production for 2019, up 2.7% from last year. Global food consumption of cereals is expected to rise by at least 1.1% this year, leading to a 0.7% decrease in world cereal stocks.

site_title: AirHelp ranking of airlines and airports of 2019; Singapore's Changi in 7th spot
summary: AirHelp's 2019 rankings of airlines and airports ranked Changi Airport in Singapore as the 7th best airport globally, while Newark Liberty Airport in the US ranked 116th as the worst. The rankings are based on on-time performance, service quality, and food and shopping options. Congestion remains a major issue at airports worldwide, with the flight industry experiencing a rapid increase in global tourism. Qatar Airways topped the rankings for the second year in a row, followed by American Airlines, Aeromexico, and SAS Scandinavian Airlines.

site_title: LifeBrandz settles with former executive director over unpaid salary
summary: LifeBrandz has settled with former executive director Kayoko Francis over unpaid salary for January and February 2019 and an annual wage supplement. The terms of the settlement are confidential, and the company denies any admission of liability. Francis resigned on February 28, 2019, due to managerial differences with the CEO. The settlement is expected to have no material impact on LifeBrandz's financial year-end results. Francis had been the executive director since July 2018.

site_title: Singapore life insurance sector sees 1% rise in new business premiums for Q1 to S$937.2m: LIA
summary: Singapore's life insurance sector experienced a 1% rise in new business premiums to S$937.2 million for Q1 2019, according to the Life Insurance Association Singapore. Annual premium policies increased by 11% to S$712.5 million, while single premium policies fell 20% due to subdued economic growth. The industry also saw an 84% increase in retirement policies purchased, with S$109 million coming from these policies.

site_title: Australia: Shares gain on Telstra, Qantas; New Zealand at record high
summary: Australian stocks rose 0.4% on Thursday, driven by a boost to Telstra after the antitrust regulator blocked a merger between TPG Telecom and Vodafone's Australian joint venture. Qantas Airways also rose after forecasting record annual revenue. New Zealand shares reached a record high, with the benchmark index up 0.4% to 10,104.35. Meanwhile, broader Asian shares fell to an eight-week low due to concerns over fresh Chinese and US trade talks.

site_title: Tariffs will cut China growth by one point, Citi says
summary: Citigroup economist Cesar Rojas predicts that a 25% tariff on $200 billion of Chinese goods would cut China's growth by 0.5 percentage points over one to two years. The impact could double if duties are slapped on all Chinese shipments to the US, primarily borne by China. Global growth would also be affected, with a 0.2 percentage point cut if only $200 billion is targeted. The US would experience a 0.3 percentage point increase in core inflation, while countries like Mexico and Vietnam could benefit from diverted US trade.

site_title: Edgewell to buy shaving startup Harry's for US$1.37b: NYT
summary: Edgewell Personal Care plans to buy US-based shaving startup Harry's for US$1.37 billion in a cash-and-stock deal. Founded by Andy Katz-Mayfield and Jeff Raider, Harry's is a growing male grooming products company. The deal would be Edgewell's second billion-dollar acquisition, following Unilever's buy of Dollar Shave Club in 2016. Edgewell CEO Rod Little will continue to lead the combined business, and Harry's founders will oversee US operations.

site_title: Gloom spreads across steel as car woes and trade tensions bite
summary: The world's biggest steelmakers, including ArcelorMittal, are bracing for a tough year due to weakening automotive demand and cheap imports. The European steel market is expected to contract by 1% this year, with domestic demand stagnating and cheaper imports flooding in. ArcelorMittal also lowered its forecast for demand outside of China, reversing an earlier projection of growth. Despite this, China is expected to see an increase in demand this year. The industry faces two major challenges: stagnant domestic demand and the failure to pass on higher iron ore prices to consumers.

site_title: China fully ready to defend interests, has 'kept promises' on US trade deal: commerce ministry
summary: China's commerce ministry stated that it has kept its promises in trade talks with the US, despite US accusations of backtracking. China is prepared to defend its interests, but hopes the US can resolve problems through dialogue. US tariffs on $200 billion of Chinese goods will increase to 25% on Friday, amid a deep rift over the language of a proposed accord. China is willing to continue talks with the US, but has made preparations to respond to possible outcomes.

site_title: Foreigners are dumping Chinese stocks before tariff deadline
summary: Foreign investors are rapidly selling Chinese stocks before a looming tariff deadline, netting 3.8 billion yuan (S$762 million) per day. This trend began in April, with a record 18 billion yuan sold. The selling extends the trend, which may be influenced by uncertainty over trade talks and the potential impact of tariffs on Chinese equities. The heavy selling through Hong Kong's Shenzhen connect is the heaviest since its opening in 2016.

site_title: BlackRock pulls out of rescue bid for Italian bank Carige
summary: US asset manager BlackRock has pulled out of a proposed rescue bid for Italian bank Carige, raising concerns of a costly state bailout. The move leaves the government with a €1 billion bailout plan and the European Central Bank's mid-May deadline for investors to submit binding bids. Carige's capital shortfall is attributed to years of mismanagement and excessive exposure to the depressed economy of the Liguria region. The bank may now seek government financial aid or consider other market solutions.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close down for fourth straight session
summary: Tokyo stocks fell for the fourth straight session, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.93% and the Topix index down 1.38%. The decline was attributed to the yen's relative strength against the dollar and ongoing US-China trade tensions. Investors closely watched the US-China trade talks, awaiting potential tariff hikes on Chinese-made imports.

site_title: SoftBank Vision Fund 2 to be announced soon: CEO
summary: SoftBank Group CEO Masayoshi Son plans to announce a second Vision Fund, similar in size to the original US$100 billion Saudi-backed fund, which has already invested in around 80 tech companies with a loss of roughly US$80 billion. Many international investors have expressed interest in participating, with SoftBank likely to be the only initial investor.

site_title: The answer to Uber's profit challenge? It may lie in its trove of data
summary: Uber's growth rate slowed to 2.3% in the fourth quarter, leading to a $3 billion annual loss. Despite efforts to find new customers, analysts believe the core ride-hailing business is not profitable. Instead, the company's vast data trove may hold the key to generating revenue. Uber's data collection and machine learning capabilities could enable the company to extract value from its data, improving efficiency and driving up margins. The company is also exploring partnerships and acquisitions to drive growth, but its long-term profitability remains uncertain.

site_title: Fashion retalier Superdry issues profit warning after founder's return, blaming weak sales
summary: UK clothing retailer Superdry issued a profit warning, blaming weak e-commerce and wholesale sales, with full-year underlying pretax profit expected to be below market expectations. Founder Julian Dunkerton returned as interim CEO after a campaign criticizing previous management, focusing on stabilizing the business. Superdry's performance has declined in the past year and a half, with a 75% drop in share price since 2018, and Dunkerton has identified opportunities to improve efficiency and performance.

site_title: Cracks appear in emerging-market currencies as sell-off endures
summary: Emerging-market currencies experienced significant declines, with the MSCI Emerging Market Currency Index set to have its largest drop in over two weeks. The won, rupiah, and yuan depreciated, and commodity-sensitive currencies such as the ruble, Chilean peso, and South African rand were particularly vulnerable. Despite low currency volatility, emerging-market stocks continued to decline, with the MSCI index extending its losses. A rate cut in the Philippines and potential rate hikes in other countries may provide some relief, but the outlook remains uncertain amid trade tensions.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon at 3,270.45, down 0.41% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading Thursday afternoon at 3,270.45, down 0.41% from the previous day, with 669.8 million securities worth S$638.8 million changing hands. Losers outnumbered gainers 208 to 119. Notable movers included Best World International, down 2.5%, and Mapletree Logistics Trust, down 2.0%. Despite the decline, the Straits Times Index has had a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: After disputed election, Thailand expected to keep junta leader as PM
summary: Thailand's pro-army Palang Pracharat party is expected to form a government, keeping military junta leader Prayuth Chan-ocha as Prime Minister, following disputed elections. The party is likely to join forces with the Democrat and Bhumjaithai parties, securing a slim majority in the House of Representatives. The opposition Democratic Front, led by Pheu Thai, has cried foul over the electoral system and election commission, but its chances of forming a government are seen as slim. The government's stability is expected to be low, with the military regime maintaining control.

site_title: SoftBank unveils stock split, rakes in higher profit on tech bets
summary: SoftBank Group, a Japanese conglomerate, announced a stock split at a two-for-one ratio on June 27, doubling its shareholder payout. The company reported an 80.5% increase in operating profit to 2.4 trillion yen (S$29.8 billion) for the year ended March, driven by higher valuations of its tech investments. The results come ahead of potential IPOs of Uber Technologies and the Saudi-backed Vision Fund, which has invested $80 billion in 80 tech firms. SoftBank's shares rose 7% on the news.

site_title: 340m yuan difference in China Environment's audited FY2015 loss due to 'non-existent trade receivables'
summary: Independent auditors RT LLP found a 339.9 million yuan discrepancy in China Environment's audited FY2015 loss, attributed to "non-existent trade receivables" from 2013-2015. The auditors reported a net loss of 450.8 million yuan instead of 110.9 million yuan announced, and revenue of 36.7 million yuan instead of 316.7 million yuan. The company's new board noted severe non-compliance and restated its financial statements. Trading in the company's stock remains suspended.

site_title: Australia's jobs miracle proves to be all government work
summary: Australia's jobs growth in the public sector has outpaced the private sector, with 292,900 new jobs created in the public sector from February last year, while private sector jobs shrank by 8,300. This shift could pose a challenge for the Reserve Bank of Australia, which has relied on continued job growth to offset sluggish wages and falling home prices. The data casts a new light on Prime Minister Scott Morrison's claim of record jobs growth, which was largely driven by public sector jobs, including professional positions and community service workers.

site_title: Chinese AI start-up Megvii raises US$750m ahead of planned Hong Kong IPO
summary: Chinese AI start-up Megvii Technology has raised $750 million in its latest funding round, valuing the company at over $4 billion ahead of a planned Hong Kong IPO later this year. The funding was led by Bank of China Group Investment and joined by Macquarie Group, ICBC Asset Management, and Abu Dhabi Investment Authority. Existing investors Alibaba Group and Foxconn Technology also participated. The funds will be used to strengthen technology capabilities, accelerate AI solutions, and finance global expansion, amid Beijing's plans to build a ubiquitous surveillance network and become an international AI leader.

site_title: World's largest steelmaker ArcelorMittal cuts demand forecast for key markets
summary: ArcelorMittal, the world's largest steelmaker, reduced its demand forecast for key markets due to lower steel prices and high imports in Europe. The company reported a 34% decline in first-quarter core profit to US$1.65 billion, below consensus. This move is attributed to the twin challenges of lower steel prices and high imports into Europe.

site_title: Crypto traders ponder blacklist to keep scammers, thieves at bay
summary: Crypto traders are discussing the creation of a blacklist to identify and prevent scammers and thieves from engaging in nefarious activities in the cryptocurrency market. Companies like Binance, DRW Holdings, and Galaxy Digital Holdings are considering a blacklist of counterparties that have reneged on trades or demonstrated malicious behavior. Alternatively, an accreditation system could be established to recognize firms in good standing, as proposed by the Crypto OTC Roundtable Asia. The goal is to increase transparency and trust in the market.

site_title: Million-car electric dream spurs smoggy Poland to grasp at Elon Musk
summary: Poland aims to have 1 million electric vehicles by 2025, but industry experts say the goal is ambitious due to infrastructure shortfalls, financial constraints, and regulatory hurdles. The country currently has fewer than 5,000 electric vehicles and 646 chargers, with a goal to expand to 1,500 by 2022. The government is considering subsidies and incentives, including an 8,000 euro subsidy, to boost demand, but the future of incentives is uncertain due to a stretched budget. Local companies, such as ElectroMobility Poland, are also developing electric vehicles, which could help meet the target.

site_title: Viva extends Hong Kong biotech fever in city's hottest IPO this year
summary: Viva Biotech Holdings raised US$194 million through its Hong Kong IPO, becoming the city's hottest offering this year. The company's shares rose 2.3% on their debut, outperforming the Hang Seng Index. The IPO saw retail investors order shares 107 times the initial amount available, and the institutional tranche was "significantly oversubscribed". This success follows another biotech firm, CanSino Biologics, which attracted orders 91 times its initial retail tranche in March and surged 58% on its debut.

site_title: Australia's central bank takes 'responsibilty' for banknote error
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia acknowledged an error on its A$50 banknotes, where the word "responsibility" is misspelled as "responsibilty" three times. The typo was discovered on a new series of banknotes that entered circulation in October 2018. The bank has confirmed the error and stated that it will be corrected at the next print run, but it is unclear how many of the affected banknotes are in circulation. The A$50 note features a portrait of Edith Cowan, the first woman elected to an Australian legislature.

site_title: Europe: Stocks drop at open before China-US talks
summary: European stocks dropped at the open on Thursday ahead of high-stakes trade talks between China and the US. London's FTSE 100 index fell 0.6%, while the Paris CAC 40 and Frankfurt's DAX 30 also declined 1.1% and 0.7%, respectively. Investors are concerned about the impact of US-China trade tensions on global markets.

site_title: Suu Kyi tries to save face with Myanmar reporters' release
summary: Aung San Suu Kyi released two Reuters journalists, Wa Lone and Kyaw Soe Oo, who were imprisoned for over 500 days for reporting on a Rohingya massacre, in a surprise move amid international pressure. The pardon, seen as a political decision to save face for the country, was made just before Myanmar is set to go to the polls next year. The move is expected to ease global criticism of Suu Kyi's government, but analysts warn that it may not lead to greater press freedom in the country.

site_title: Weakest US bond auction in decade validates Dimon's warning
summary: The US Treasury saw its weakest demand for 10-year notes in a decade, with bids exceeding the offering by 2.17 times. This drop in demand underscores a shift in Treasuries' dynamics, potentially leaving them vulnerable to spikes in volatility. Foreign investors, led by China and Japan, have decreased their share of American government debt, and the Federal Reserve is trimming its holdings. The low yield of 2.46% has been described as "extraordinarily low" by Jamie Dimon, highlighting concerns about the long-term implications for Treasuries.

site_title: Indonesian president aims for slimmer government in second term
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo aims to reduce the size of his government in his second term to boost efficiency and accelerate growth. He announced plans to close government agencies not contributing to growth, and urged regional governments to reduce bureaucracy. The official result of his re-election is due by May 22. This move is expected to streamline the government and improve development, allowing President Widodo to focus on his goals without being held back by election concerns.

site_title: China to begin final anti-dumping review of some steel tubes imports from US, EU
summary: China is set to complete a final review of anti-dumping measures on US and EU steel tube imports by May 9, 2020, following a complaint from a Chinese company that removal of tariffs will harm domestic producers. China imposed 13-14.1% tariffs on US and EU companies in 2014, which are currently set to expire on Friday. The review aims to determine whether the tariffs are still necessary to protect China's steel industry.

site_title: Singapore ride-hailing app TADA debuts in Cambodia
summary: Singapore's ride-hailing app TADA has debuted in Cambodia, partnering with digital wallet Pi Pay and Alipay for seamless cashless transactions. MVL Foundation, the app's developer, has also partnered with local tuk-tuk manufacturer TVS Motor Company to enable drivers to register with TADA. The app, which uses blockchain technology, is now available in Singapore, Vietnam, and Cambodia, with over 30,000 drivers and 230,000 users. This expansion aims to increase cashless payments in Cambodia, driven by the growth of ride-hailing services.

site_title: Vietnam posts US$500m trade deficit in April; coffee exports down 13%
summary: Vietnam recorded a trade deficit of $550 million in April, lower than the government's forecast of $700 million. Exports rose 10.3% to $20.44 billion, while imports decreased 0.8% to $20.99 billion. The main export earners were smartphones, garments, and electronic home appliances, while key imports included electronics, machinery, and fabrics. The smaller-than-expected deficit was a surprise, considering the recent US trade tensions and tariffs.

site_title: Toyota, Panasonic to set up firm to connect cars, homes: Kyodo
summary: Toyota and Panasonic plan to establish a joint company to connect cars and homes, focusing on technology for urban planning. The new company will utilize technology developed by Toyota, including a network of connected cars that can share vehicle usage and diagnostics information. This technology could be used for on-demand ride-sharing, insurance, and maintenance. The firms will hold a joint news conference to announce the creation of the new company.

site_title: Enhancing the competitiveness of the Indonesian export service
summary: Indonesia has introduced a new regulation (Minister of Finance Regulation No. 32/PMK.010/2019) to enhance the competitiveness of its export services. The regulation, effective March 29, 2019, expands the types of exported services subject to a 0% value-added tax (VAT) rate. The new rules cover toll manufacturing, repair and maintenance services, freight forwarding, construction consultation services, and other services that utilize goods or facilities outside Indonesia. The aim is to improve Indonesia's economic condition by increasing the export of services, making it more competitive with other jurisdictions.

site_title: Fund manager who called China stock rally sees end to good times
summary: Deutsche Bank Wealth Management is changing its view on Chinese stocks, shifting from a bullish stance to a more cautious one, citing profit-taking due to the US-China trade negotiations. The firm expects a short-term equity pullback of around 5-10% and recommends taking profits, but still sees value in Chinese stocks for the next 12 months. The change in view comes despite the MSCI China Index having gained 15% since October, and the firm believes the upside from a potential trade agreement has already been priced in.

site_title: China, Hong Kong: Stocks extend fall on renewed US tariff threat
summary: China's stocks fell 1.9% to 3,597.59, with the Shanghai Composite Index losing 1.4%, on renewed US tariff threats. US President Donald Trump vowed not to back down on imposing new tariffs on Chinese imports, citing China's failure to meet trade deal terms. China's CSI300 financial sector sub-index fell 1.85%, and the yuan weakened 0.36% against the US dollar. The US Trade Representative's office announced tariffs on $200 billion worth of Chinese goods would increase to 25% on Friday.

site_title: US drug firms will have to show prices in TV ads
summary: The US government will require pharmaceutical companies to disclose the price of their drugs during television commercials, starting in 60 days. The measure aims to fight high prescription drug prices, which often exceed those in neighboring countries. The price will be displayed at the end of ads, similar to side effects. The rule applies to drugs priced at least $35 per month. The move follows President Trump's call for "historic transparency" and his vow to make healthcare more affordable.

site_title: Oil falls as trade row fears outweigh drop in US crude stocks
summary: Oil prices dropped 1% on Thursday amid escalating US-China trade tensions, despite a surprise 4 million barrel drop in US crude inventories. Brent crude oil futures fell to $69.72 per barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures dropped to $61.52 per barrel. Analysts say the trade war's impact on oil prices outweighs the inventory numbers, with higher tariffs set to take effect on Friday. Oil prices have had support from production cuts by Opec and its allies, and robust Asia demand.

site_title: China arrests five Fuxing private fund executives in fraud case
summary: Chinese authorities arrested five senior executives of Shanghai Fuxing Group, an embattled conglomerate, on charges of alleged fraud and illicitly taking public deposits. The executives were accused of manipulating the price of Dalian Insulator Group and a "funding black hole" of over 20 billion yuan (S$4 billion) was uncovered. This follows the chairman, Zhu Yidong, who fled the country last year and was later arrested and escorted back to China on charges of manipulating stocks and economic crimes. The arrests mark a significant development in one of China's most high-profile financial investigations.

site_title: HDB resale volume up 16.5% in April as resale prices slip 0.4%: SRX
summary: The volume of HDB resale flats sold in April rose 16.5% from the previous month, with 1,931 transactions, while resale prices eased 0.4% from March. This marks a 4.3% increase from April last year. Prices for 4-room flats rose 0.2%, while those for 3-room, 5-room, and executive flats fell by 1.6%, 0.2%, and 1.6% respectively. The median transaction over X-Value (TOX) was negative S$1,000, indicating buyers may be underpaying.

site_title: Asia: Markets stuck in the red as traders await crunch talks
summary: Asian markets fell on Thursday as investors awaited high-stakes trade talks between China and the US, with stocks sinking in Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Tokyo. The two-day meeting in Washington follows President Trump's threat to ramp up tariffs on Chinese goods, sparking fears of a brutal trade war. Despite reassurances from Trump, markets remain volatile, with the Australian dollar and Indonesian rupiah down against the greenback. Both China and the US are seen as "hungry" to reach a deal, but uncertainty weighs on currency and oil markets.

site_title: HNA's Hong Kong spat is a sign of worse to come
summary: HNA Group, a Chinese conglomerate, is at the center of a dispute with Hong Kong Airlines, a company it previously invested in. HNA allegedly siphoned money from Hong Kong Airlines, leading to a leadership squabble and raising concerns among bondholders and government creditors. The airline reported a significant loss in 2018 and needs to raise funds to retain its operating license. The dispute may worsen HNA's asset selloff, raising anxiety among investors and creditors. HNA has denied the allegations.

site_title: Bitcoin rises above US$6,000 level for first time since November
summary: Bitcoin has broken above the US$6,000 level for the first time since November 2018, rising 2.5% to US$6,048.52. Technical strategist Rob Sluymer from Fundstrat Global Advisors LLC believes this marks the beginning of a new up cycle, as bitcoin rebounds from its 200-week moving average support. This move follows a wild ride that saw bitcoin reach US$19,000 in December 2017 and as low as US$3,136.04 in December last year.

site_title: As trade truce collapses, US, China scramble to revive a deal
summary: The US and China are set to resume trade talks on Thursday, amid a truce on the brink of collapse. The US is due to increase tariffs on hundreds of billions of dollars' worth of Chinese exports, sparking concerns about a potential escalation of the trade war. Chinese trade envoy Liu He returns to the bargaining table, hours before the US tariffs are set to take effect, following a sudden rupture in negotiations.
