The collapse of the truce has roiled global markets and raised anxieties among exporters and industries.

site_title: Singapore's fake news law may hurt innovation, says Google
summary: Singapore's Parliament has passed a law to combat fake news, which critics say could stifle innovation and freedom of speech. The Protection from Online Falsehoods and Manipulation Bill requires online media platforms to correct or remove false content, with penalties of up to 10 years in prison or S$1 million. Google and Facebook have expressed concerns, with Google stating the law could hurt innovation, while Facebook's Asia-Pacific vice-president hopes for a "proportionate and measured approach" in practice. The law's implementation has sparked fears of censorship and a chilling effect on internet freedom in South-east Asia.

site_title: It's everyday Americans who pay Trump's tariffs
summary: President Donald Trump plans to increase US tariffs on $200 billion worth of Chinese goods to 25% on Friday, despite research showing Americans bear the brunt of the impact. The tariffs, initially expected to bring in $100 billion a year, will raise annual expenses for a family of four by $767 and threaten nearly one million jobs. Industry leaders and retailers worry that the tariffs will disrupt businesses and consumers, while consumers will ultimately pay more for everyday goods. The US-China trade negotiations are set to take place under the threat of new tariffs.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall as Trump stresses China will face additional tariffs
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index fell 1.08% to 2,144.49, marking its fourth consecutive session decline, amid escalating China-US trade tensions. US President Donald Trump reiterated his threat to impose additional tariffs on Chinese goods, causing investor uncertainty. Meanwhile, Hanjin Kal shares rose amid expectations of a leadership change. Despite the decline, Singapore's STI index rose 0.4% on Thursday, with investors remaining positive despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Policy easing on the cards as Philippine Q1 economic growth disappoints
summary: The Philippine economy grew at its weakest pace in four years in Q1, expanding 5.6% due to delays in passing the budget and government spending slowdown. The slowdown is attributed to weak farm output, exports, and the US-China trade dispute. Expectations are that the central bank will cut interest rates to support growth, with a 25 basis point rate cut predicted by economists. The government's growth target for the year has been revised downward to 6-7% from 7-8%, and economic managers are pinning hopes on the mid-term election to boost growth.

site_title: Adtech startup Pencil aims for Series A in 12-18 months after $1.5m seed round
summary: Singapore-based adtech startup Pencil has raised S$1.5 million in a seed round led by Wavemaker Partners, aiming to double its headcount and expand into new markets within 12-18 months. The company plans to use the funds to grow its engineering and customer teams, expand proprietary datasets, and extend its patent-pending technology. Pencil's goal is to achieve S$1 million in recurring revenue by its next fundraising attempt, with the company currently generating content for clients such as Sephora SEA and POND'S.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars remain hostage to Trump tariff threats
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars remained under pressure on May 9, 2019, as US President Donald Trump continued to escalate trade tensions with China. Trump threatened to impose additional tariffs on Chinese goods, while Beijing announced it would retaliate if tariffs rise. The comments jolted markets, despite some calming overnight. The Australian and New Zealand dollars were seen as "hostage" to Trump's tariff threats, with investors seeking safe-haven assets. The situation raised concerns about the impact on regional economies.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks dip in opening trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell in the opening minutes of Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index easing 0.56% to 28,839.35, amid concerns over high-stakes trade talks between China and the US. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined, with the latter losing 0.91%. Investors are cautious ahead of the trade talks, which could impact global markets.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at Thursday's open; STI down 0.6% to 3,264.52
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.6% to 3,264.52 at Thursday's open, with the Straits Times Index down 19.32 points. The decline comes after US President Donald Trump said China "broke the deal" on trade, leading to a drop in US stock-index futures and Asian shares hitting six-week lows. Investors are also awaiting crucial US-China trade talks.

site_title: Denver first US city to decriminalise 'magic mushrooms'
summary: Denver has become the first US city to decriminalize psychedelic mushrooms, with voters approving a ballot initiative by a narrow margin. The new ordinance allows people over 21 to possess and use psilocybin mushrooms, but prohibits buying, selling, or possessing them. Police officers are instructed to treat users as a low priority. The measure, which passed with 50.6% of the vote, is seen as a step forward in the US's growing trend of drug legalization, following Colorado's legalization of marijuana in 2012.

site_title: China's Kangde Xin says auditor cannot verify 12b yuan of deposits
summary: China's Kangde Xin Composite Material Group reported that its auditor couldn't verify the authenticity of 12.2 billion yuan (S$2.45 billion) of deposits, as the bank's records showed the balance was zero. The discrepancy occurred in response to regulators' queries, amid China's increased scrutiny of listed companies' disclosures. This is the second instance of a listed company reporting discrepancies in its cash positions, following Kangmei Pharmaceutical's 2017 overstatement of 29.9 billion yuan.

site_title: China's consumer inflation up 2.5% on food price gains; factory-gate inflation hits 4-month high
summary: China's consumer inflation rose 2.5% in April, driven by surging food prices, while producer prices increased 0.9% year-over-year, their fastest pace in four months. The surge in food prices was largely due to supply issues from a growing swine fever epidemic. While the data suggests a recovery in the economy, analysts remain cautious, with concerns about underlying demand and the impact of trade tensions on China's growth.

site_title: A US$5.9b market in China is finally getting some attention
summary: Global investor participation in US-dollar bonds of China's local government financing vehicles (LGFVs) has increased, driven by growing familiarity with the asset class. This has led to a rise in issuance of high-yielding securities, making them an attractive option for investors seeking to beat regional bond benchmarks. According to Standard Chartered, international investor interest in LGFVs is on the rise, with experts noting that ignoring these bonds would be unwise for investors seeking to participate in the Chinese market.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Thursday, down 4.55 points to 1,629.00 at 9am. The market saw 40.5 million lots traded worth RM35.41 million, with gainers beating losers 67 to 62.

site_title: Australia: Shares climb as telecom firms gain; New Zealand flat
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.4% to 6,291.10, driven by gains in telecom stocks, including TPG Telecom and Telstra. However, the rally was tempered by concerns over escalating US-China trade tensions. Energy stocks also rose, while material stocks fell. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index remained flat. Investors await the outcome of US-China trade talks, with US President Trump indicating he would keep tariffs on Chinese imports if a deal is not reached.

site_title: China banks temper April lending as debt worries rise, but all eyes on trade threat
summary: China's banks reduced new lending in April, extending 1.02 trillion yuan (S$204.6 billion), below analysts' expectations. This follows a record first quarter and concerns over bad loans. The central bank is expected to maintain policy support amid escalating US-China trade tensions. Despite a moderate credit growth, outstanding yuan loans grew 13.5% and total social financing slowed to 10.4%. The Chinese economy remains uncertain, with policymakers cautious not to open the credit floodgates amid debt concerns.

site_title: Boeing struggling with public relations challenge
summary: Boeing is struggling to repair its reputation following two deadly plane crashes, with the company's CEO, Dennis Muilenburg, facing criticism for downplaying the company's responsibility. Despite acknowledging "we own it," Muilenburg has walked back his statement, blaming a "chain of events" for the crashes. The 737 MAX aircraft has been grounded worldwide since March, and Boeing is working on a software update to address issues with the Maneuvering Characteristics Augmentation System. Regulators are set to clear the planes to fly again, but public confidence remains a concern, with nearly half of surveyed fliers saying they would wait a year to fly the plane.

site_title: IBM brings blockbuster bond deal as market defies trade drag
summary: IBM is selling up to $20 billion in senior unsecured bonds to fund its $33 billion acquisition of Red Hat, the longest portion of which may yield 1.55 percentage points more than Treasuries. This deal is part of a rare buying frenzy in the corporate-bond market, with US investment-grade corporate bond sales reaching record highs. The market's response to trade tensions has spurred companies to borrow, with issuance expected to top $40 billion this week, the highest since September.

images.alt_text: International Business Machines (IBM) kicked off a debt sale that's likely to make this the corporate-bond market's busiest week in at least eight months, a rare buying frenzy amid turbulent markets globally.

site_title: Indonesia will intervene in bond market to defend rupiah: central bank
summary: Indonesia's central bank will intervene in sovereign bond markets to defend the rupiah amid rising US-China trade tensions. The rupiah opened at 14,295 per US dollar, slipping slightly from the previous closing. The bank's head of monetary management, Nanang Hendarsah, stated that Bank Indonesia will intervene in the bond market for a "sizeable amount" to maintain rupiah stability. This move aims to counter the weakening currency.

site_title: Price stability is key to market trust in yen: Bank of Japan Governor
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that price stability is the key to maintaining market trust in the yen. Investors' confidence in the central bank's ability to achieve price stability is a significant factor behind market trust. This confidence is not solely determined by exchange-rate fluctuations, but rather by the central bank's commitment to its policy. Kuroda emphasized the importance of confidence in the central bank's policy in maintaining market trust in the yen.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Haw Par, Best World, Halcyon Agri, Roxy-Pacific, PACC Offshore Services
summary: Haw Par Corporation reported a 14.1% increase in net profit to S$22.07 million for the first quarter, driven by increased demand for healthcare products. Best World International initiated defamation proceedings against Bonitas Research, alleging false and defamatory allegations against the company.

site_title: Asian Healthcare Specialists H1 profit down 4.2% on higher staff costs
summary: Asian Healthcare Specialists (AHS) reported a 4.2% decline in net profit for its fiscal half-year, to S$1.38 million, due to higher staff costs. This resulted in earnings per share of 0.44 Singapore cents, down from 0.49 cents previously. The decline was attributed to a rise in staff costs outpacing revenue growth.

site_title: Damaged by Brexit, EU heads meet in Romania to chart bloc's next steps
summary: European Union leaders, excluding Britain, met in Romania to discuss the bloc's future steps after the Brexit setback. The 27 leaders gathered on Europe Day to chart a way forward, despite internal divisions over issues like migration and democratic standards. They will discuss strategic agenda points, including deepening euro zone cooperation and promoting environmentally friendly policies. The leaders will also consider appointing new names for the bloc's top roles, including the European Commission job, with candidates including Manfred Weber and Frans Timmermans.

site_title: Eerie calm in FX leaves market vulnerable in more volatile world
summary: Foreign-exchange options traders have experienced a relatively calm market despite US-China trade tensions, with only marginal increases in currency volatility measures. This contrasts with sharp jumps in equity and interest-rate volatility. Experts attribute the calm to structural changes in the market, including liquidity gaps and positioning dynamics, rather than cyclical issues. However, if trade negotiations break down, volatility could rise, and experts warn of potential risks to the global economic outlook.

site_title: China sets yuan mid-point at weakest level in 3 months
summary: China's central bank set the yuan midpoint at 6.7665 per US dollar, its weakest level in nearly three months, amid escalating Sino-US trade tensions. The move, 69 pips or 0.1% weaker, was made ahead of two-day trade talks in Washington. The weakened yuan may impact Chinese exports and fuel concerns about a trade deal.

site_title: Amazon hit by extensive fraud with hackers siphoning merchant funds
summary: Amazon was hit by an extensive fraud in 2018, with hackers siphoning funds from approximately 100 seller accounts over six months. The attackers broke into accounts on the Seller Central platform, changing details to funnel cash into their own bank accounts. Amazon is still investigating and has asked a London judge to approve searches of account statements to identify the perpetrators and recover stolen funds. The exact amount stolen is unclear, but the company issued over $1 billion in loans to merchants in 2018.

site_title: Bank workers who survive robot uprising stand to make more money
summary: A McKinsey report suggests that bank workers who survive a potential robot uprising may see higher pay, despite a potential 20% drop in compensation costs, resulting in annual savings of $600 million. The report predicts 40% of existing jobs at financial firms could be automated, with trading and customer-facing roles evolving to require technical and sales capabilities. Successful employees will be those who can combine technical and traditional sales skills, as banks invest heavily in technology, with JPMorgan Chase allocating over $10 billion annually.

site_title: In shrinking Singapore stock market, award-winning analyst sees gems
summary: Award-winning analyst Jarick Seet has identified 20 promising smaller firms in Singapore's shrinking market, despite delistings outnumbering listings and trading volumes slumping. Seet, head of small and mid-cap research at RHB Securities, selected stocks with undervalued gems, including seafood eatery Jumbo Group and visual effects producer Vividthree Holdings Ltd. He believes investors who put in the research and effort can still achieve good returns, citing past successes such as Singapore Medical Group Ltd and precision-mold maker Fu Yu Corp.

site_title: First patents surface for Dyson electric car planned for 2021
summary: Dyson Ltd has filed patents for its electric car, set to be introduced by 2021. The patents reveal a design with a long wheelbase, reclining seats, and aerodynamic features, as well as a potential larger wheel size for improved efficiency. The company is also exploring a low centre of gravity to enhance handling. Dyson's founder, James Dyson, has stated that the patents do not reveal the final design or specifics of the vehicle. The company has already invested £2 billion in the project and has over 500 people working on it.

site_title: Disney profit up as Fox joins the fold
summary: Disney reported a 85% increase in net income to $5.4 billion in the first quarter, driven by a 3% rise in revenue. The entertainment giant's profit boost comes from the acquisition of 21st Century Fox assets, which includes Marvel's "Avengers: Endgame," a record-breaking film that has earned $2.19 billion worldwide in less than two weeks. The acquisition also led to increased revenue from Hulu and amusement parks, but came with $662 million in charges related to the Fox merger.

site_title: Best World takes Bonitas to Court for defamation
summary: Best World International Limited has taken Bonitas Research to court in Singapore, accusing the firm of defamation over a 28-page report questioning the authenticity and legality of the company's profits. The company claims the report contains false and defamatory allegations intended to undermine its reputation and inflict financial harm. Best World has also launched a separate investigation into the report's findings, citing a need to address concerns about the company's China business.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on trade war fears
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Thursday due to US-China trade tensions, with the Nikkei 225 index slipping 0.44% and the Topix index down 0.59%. Investors were watching the US-China trade talks and the potential hike in tariffs on Chinese-made imports. Automakers such as Toyota, Nissan, and Honda also saw losses, with Toyota's results disappointing investors. The yen remained relatively high against the dollar, contributing to the market's decline.

site_title: Lyft plunges to low as loss overshadows revenue growth
summary: Lyft's shares plummeted 11% to a record low of $52.91 after the ride-sharing company reported a steep quarterly loss despite better-than-expected revenue growth. The stock has lost 27% since its debut. Analysts were mixed, with some citing positive signs for Lyft's long-term prospects, while others expressed concerns about the company's current unprofitable state. Despite this, at least three firms raised their price targets, citing the growth in revenue and active riders as positive signs.

site_title: Qantas Airways forecasts record annual revenue
summary: Qantas Airways forecasts a record annual revenue of A$4.4 billion, a 2.3% increase from the previous year's revenue. The airline expects to fully offset the impact of higher fuel costs. Qantas also announced a deal to sell its Melbourne Airport terminal for A$355 million. Despite the forecast, the article does not provide further details on the airline's financial performance or operational outlook.

site_title: Hong Kong extradition law may hurt overseas investment: ICC
summary: Hong Kong's planned extradition law may deter overseas investment, according to the International Chamber of Commerce (ICC). The law's potential impact on the rule of law and protection for foreign businesses has raised concerns. The ICC urges the legislative process to halt pending a thorough public consultation. Opponents of the law, including the American Chamber of Commerce, argue it will reduce Hong Kong's appeal as a business center. The law's passage could lead to a loss of international investment and harm Hong Kong's status as a major business hub.

site_title: Australia's Macquarie downsizes in the Gulf: sources
summary: Macquarie Group, an Australian bank, is downsizing its operations in the United Arab Emirates, specifically in Abu Dhabi. The bank's investment banking unit, Macquarie Capital, has relinquished its operating licence in Saudi Arabia and is also scaling back in the UAE. Several staff members are leaving or have already left the company, with some being offered positions in other Macquarie offices. The downsizing is attributed to a tough business environment in investment banking and banking, with few deals coming the bank's way, as part of its strategy to remodelling its business.

site_title: Swiss drugmaker Novartis buys Takeda's dry eye drug for US$3.4b
summary: Swiss drugmaker Novartis AG agreed to acquire Takeda Pharmaceutical Company's dry eye drug Xiidra for US$3.4 billion, expanding its portfolio of eye care medicines. The deal includes potential milestone payments of up to US$1.9 billion and is expected to close in the second half of 2019.

images.alt_text: Swiss drugmaker Novartis AG said on Wednesday it agreed to acquire Japan-headquartered Takeda Pharmaceutical Company's dry eye drug Xiidra for an upfront payment of US$3.4 billion to expand its portfolio of eye care medicines.

site_title: 'New economics' - the way to save the planet?
summary: A group of economists, business leaders, and politicians are proposing a new economic system that prioritizes environmental sustainability and social equity over traditional measures of growth like GDP. The "new economics" approach aims to create a more holistic notion of progress, involving the state, local communities, and nature. This could involve initiatives such as locally-run clean energy projects, worker-owned cooperatives, and regenerative agriculture. The movement is gaining traction, with some major investors recognizing the need for change, but it faces opposition from orthodox economists and critics who argue that the existing system simply needs tweaks rather than a fundamental transformation.

site_title: US storms kill one, disrupt flights
summary: Heavy rains in the central US caused flooding, killing one person and disrupting flights. The flooding, stretching over 1,600km, affected communities from Texas to Wisconsin, with evacuations reported in Kansas and Texas. The National Weather Service warned of more rain and flooding through the weekend. Hundreds of flights were canceled, and motorists were stranded in areas like Houston, where rising waters battered the city. The Midwest, including Nebraska and Iowa, were also severely affected by earlier floods.

site_title: Shadow banks feel sting as Indian mutual funds cut debt exposure
summary: India's largest investors in shadow bank debt are reducing their exposure, with mutual fund investments in commercial paper and bonds falling to 3.24 trillion rupees (S$63.3 billion) at end-March. This is the lowest in six quarters, amid concerns over defaults by IL&FS Group last year and rating cuts on debt instruments. India's non-bank lenders are selling stakes or raising funds as the central bank steps in to provide liquidity to squeezed credit markets. This move is expected to make it more difficult and costly for weaker companies to access funding.

site_title: North Korea says recent rocket drill was 'regular and self-defensive'
summary: North Korea's leader Kim Jong Un oversaw a recent rocket drill, which the country's foreign ministry described as a "regular and self-defensive" military training exercise. The drill included the launch of rockets and at least one short-range ballistic missile, according to the US Pentagon. The foreign ministry claimed the drill had neither targeted anyone nor escalated tensions in the region. The incident comes amid heightened tensions between North Korea and the US, with the acting US Defense Secretary detailing the launch for the first time.

site_title: One year in, Mahathir gets mixed result on Malaysian economy
summary: Malaysia's economy has received mixed results one year after Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad's shock election win. The government has struggled to boost revenue and identify new growth drivers, scoring negative or mediocre grades in six out of 10 categories across the economy. Investor sentiments have shifted from euphoria to frustration, with the ringgit sliding against the US dollar and equities underperforming in Asia. The government points to its solid credit ratings, but analysts warn of fragile debt funding and weak debt affordability. A majority of voters now sees the country headed in the wrong direction.

site_title: Saudis said to be willing to meet all orders from ex-Iran oil buyers
summary: Saudi Arabia plans to meet all requests for oil purchases in June, including from countries that previously bought Iranian crude due to US sanctions. The kingdom will export less than 7 million barrels a day, below its Opec quota, and Opec+ will increase supply if a shortage occurs. This cautious response aims to prevent a spike in crude prices amid US pressure on Saudi Arabia to offset losses from Iranian exports. Saudi Arabia is navigating a fine line between pleasing the US and maintaining Opec+ unity.

images.alt_text: Saudi oil production for June is expected to remain below the kingdom's ceiling under an agreement between the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) and its allies limiting output until the end of next month, the person said.

site_title: Global power and utility deals drop to lowest quarterly level since 2012: EY
summary: Global power and utility deals reached their lowest quarterly level since 2012, totaling US$20.6 billion in the first quarter of 2019, according to Ernst & Young. The decline is attributed to the risk of an economic slowdown, with most transactions focusing on renewable energy. The Americas was the largest region, accounting for US$9.1 billion in deals, while Chinese deals fell 45% and European deals fell 27% compared to the previous quarter. The report also highlights the growing influence of governments in investing in renewable energy and reducing fossil fuel reliance.

site_title: Britain will be 3% poorer if it retains post-Brexit customs union: NIESR
summary: Britain's economy would be around 3% poorer over the long term if it leaves the EU and retains a customs union, according to a report by the National Institute of Economic and Social Research (NIESR). This would result in a £800 per person per year loss, equivalent to a 2.3% reduction in GDP. The report suggests that a customs union would not guarantee frictionless trade and would limit Britain's capacity to strike its own free trade deals, ultimately discouraging investment and reducing productivity.

site_title: MAS' S$45b transfer to GIC could give government revenues a boost
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will transfer S$45 billion from its official foreign reserves to GIC, the city-state's sovereign wealth fund, in May to manage investments in a low inflation and interest rate environment. This move could translate to an annual contribution of over S$900 million to the Singapore Budget, with economists welcoming the government's efforts to boost public spending. The transfer aims to ensure adequate sustainable returns on investments, as the returns from reserve management have become a significant component of the government budget.

site_title: Colombia unicorn startup Rappi worth US$3.5b after SoftBank bet
summary: SoftBank Group has invested $500 million in Colombian delivery app Rappi, valuing the company at $3.5 billion. This deal makes Rappi one of the most valuable tech startups in Latin America, joining Brazil's Nubank. SoftBank's $1 billion bet on Rappi is its largest investment in the region. The investment, part of the Innovation Fund's $5 billion spending in Latin America, will see Jeffrey Housenbold join Rappi's board of directors, who believes Rappi has the potential to expand and become a major technology company in the region.

site_title: Hooters operator's shares soar as it joins the Beyond Meat universe
summary: Hooters operator Chanticleer Holdings has partnered with Beyond Meat to offer unique burgers at 50-plus individual store locations. This collaboration is expected to lead to wider adoption of alternative proteins in the market. As a result, Chanticleer's shares soared 94% on Wednesday, its largest intraday gain since 2018. Beyond Meat's shares have seen volatility since its initial public offering, with a total return of 222% compared to the S&P 500's 1.5% losses. The partnership may indicate a growing trend towards alternative proteins in the food industry.

site_title: Huawei CFO vows to fight extradition to US in Canada court
summary: Huawei CFO Meng Wanzhou, 47, vowed to fight extradition to the US in a Canadian court, stating that the charges against her are "simply untrue" and alleging "political factors" behind her arrest. Meng faces US charges related to Iran sanctions violations and is currently on bail in Vancouver. The case has sparked a diplomatic row between Ottawa and Beijing, with China detaining two Canadian citizens in retaliation. The extradition hearing is set to begin in January, with a potential outcome that could have significant implications for US-China relations and global trade.

site_title: UK housing market shows scant sign of recovery in April: RICS
summary: The UK housing market showed little sign of recovery in April, with properties put up for sale falling at the fastest rate since 2016, according to the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors. The RICS gauge of house prices remained at -23, the weakest in almost eight years. Despite official data showing rising prices nationwide, London prices fell due to unaffordable prices, tax changes, and Brexit uncertainty.

site_title: What Uber's IPO tells us about SoftBank's big ride-hailing bet
summary: SoftBank CEO Masayoshi Son has invested $18 billion in ride-hailing companies, including Uber, Didi Chuxing, Grab, and Ola. According to analyst Chris Lane, Son has already made nearly $9 billion in paper gains, with potential returns of $22-26 billion if his portfolio companies achieve their vision for robot taxis and AI. Lane projects a 24-30% annualized return over the next 12 years if ride-hailing companies adopt autonomous vehicles, reducing operating expenses and increasing revenue. SoftBank's stake in Uber could be worth nearly double its initial investment of $7.7 billion if the company prices its IPO at the top end of the targeted range.

site_title: EU watchdog head warns bloc over lapses in standards
summary: The European Union's ombudsman, Emily O'Reilly, expressed frustration over the bloc's institutions' recent high-profile lapses in standards, providing ammunition for eurosceptics to attack the EU. O'Reilly stated that the EU's generally high standards are undermined by external and internal criticism, allowing populists to exploit these issues.

site_title: US: Stocks end mostly lower amid trade uncertainty
summary: US stocks ended mostly lower on Wednesday amid uncertainty over US-China trade tensions, despite a positive statement from the White House. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 dipped, while the Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.3% and 0.2%, respectively. Investors welcomed the news that Chinese trade officials are set to visit Washington for talks, but China's Commerce Ministry warned of unspecified retaliation. The market remains cautious ahead of steep tariffs set to take effect on Friday.

site_title: Wells Fargo creates new unit focused on regulatory compliance
summary: Wells Fargo is creating a new unit focused on regulatory compliance, according to an internal memo. Derek Flowers, a 20-year veteran, will head the unit, tasked with satisfying US regulatory requirements. As chief credit and market risk officer, Flowers had frequent contact with regulators, making him well-suited for the role. The new unit aims to address regulatory priorities, following recent regulatory challenges faced by the bank.

site_title: Gold miner Barrick expects to raise US$1.5b through asset sales
summary: Barrick Gold plans to sell $1.5 billion worth of assets by the end of next year, according to CEO Mark Bristow. The move comes after the company's $5.4 billion acquisition of Randgold Resources earlier this year. The gold sector has seen a wave of asset sales, with Barrick's acquisition sparking interest in unloved mines. The sale of these assets will be done once they are optimised enough to create value for shareholders.

site_title: UK annual house price growth hits 2-year high
summary: UK annual house price growth reached a 2-year high of 5% in the three months to April, exceeding forecasts of a 4.5% increase. This growth is attributed to unusually weak prices in April 2018 and more sales of expensive newly built homes, particularly in London. However, other housing market indicators suggest a muted market, contradicting the surge in house prices.

site_title: Europe: Shares buoyed by improved US-China trade hopes
summary: European shares rose 0.2% on Wednesday, overcoming a one-month closing low, due to easing US-China trade fears and strong earnings from Siemens and Wirecard. China's Vice Premier Liu He will meet with US officials on Thursday for trade talks, and US tariffs on $200 billion of Chinese imports are set to rise to 25% on Friday. Industrial stocks gained 0.7% and German stocks rose 0.7%, while travel and leisure stocks fell 1.3%.

site_title: Trump administration to ask Supreme Court to prevent nationwide injunctions
summary: The Trump administration plans to ask the US Supreme Court to prevent nationwide injunctions against the President's policies, following a speech by Vice-President Mike Pence. Pence criticized federal district courts for issuing more nationwide injunctions against President Trump than the first 40 presidents combined. The administration has previously sought to curb nationwide injunctions, but the Supreme Court did not address the issue in previous cases. The move is seen as a response to the court's handling of issues such as the travel ban and transgender military service policies.

images.alt_text: US Vice-President Mike Pence said the Trump administration will ask the US Supreme Court to prevent lower courts from imposing nationwide injunctions against the President's policies.

site_title: Rideshare firms worsened congestion in San Francisco: study
summary: A study published in Science Advances found that ride-hailing firms in San Francisco increased congestion by 40% and travel times by 62% between 2010 and 2016, contrary to their promise to reduce traffic. The study, which accounted for changes in population and road network, found that two-thirds of new cars added to the road were from ride-hailing services. The companies disputed the findings, citing factors like increased freight and tourism, but experts praised the study's methodology. The study's authors suggest that cities should implement congestion pricing and curbside regulation to manage the positive benefits of ride-hailing while mitigating the negative externalities.

site_title: Buffett's 'ridiculously cheap' call echoes in loopy US stocks
summary: Warren Buffett calls the US stock market "ridiculously cheap" citing low inflation and low borrowing costs. Since his statement, the market has become slightly cheaper. The Berkshire Hathaway CEO's logic is based on the Fed model, comparing corporate earnings to Treasury rates. The spread between the S&P 500's earnings yield and the 10-year Treasury yield is at 2.9 percentage points, its highest since 2016, suggesting valuations may not be "nuts." Experts note that interest rates and inflation influence stock valuations, but there's no single right price and multiple factors come into play.

images.alt_text: In the 48 hours since Warren Buffett called the US stock market "ridiculously cheap," it has gotten somewhat cheaper. Bulls looking to console themselves after their roughest stretch in five months might want to consider his logic.

site_title: Brazil central bank holds interest rates at 6.5%
summary: Brazil's central bank kept interest rates at 6.5% in a unanimous decision, unchanged since March 2018. The bank expects the rate to remain at this level for the rest of the year, but may rise to 7.5% in 2020. This decision comes despite concerns over President Jair Bolsonaro's pension reform and Brazil's sluggish economic growth, expected to expand by 1.49% this year. The government's pension overhaul is seen as crucial to the president's economic plans.

site_title: General Motors unveils US$700m Ohio investment, plans to sell shuttered plant
summary: General Motors (GM) announced a $700 million investment in Ohio, creating 450 jobs, as part of its efforts to expand diesel engine production for heavy-duty trucks and other parts. The investment is part of GM's broader US$1.8 billion commitment to create 700 new jobs, following a $300 million investment in Michigan to produce electric vehicles. The move is seen as a positive outcome for GM and Ohio, with US President Donald Trump praising the deal. The investment will also help solidify Workhorse's role in the electric vehicle market by purchasing the shuttered Lordstown plant.

site_title: China, India boosting global booze binge: study
summary: A study found that global alcohol consumption per adult increased by 10% between 1990 and 2017, largely due to increased drinking in China and India. Projections suggest that global consumption will rise another 17% by 2030, with half of all adults drinking alcohol and a quarter binge drinking monthly. The World Health Organization aims to reduce "harmful alcohol use" by 10% by 2025, but the study's authors call for more aggressive counter-measures, such as higher taxes and advertising bans.

site_title: European Union nations are living far beyond the Earth's means: report
summary: The European Union's 28 countries consume Earth's resources at a rate twice that of the planet's renewal, with none having sustainable consumption policies, according to a report by the World Wide Fund and Global Footprint Network. The EU uses 20% of the Earth's bio-capacity, equivalent to 2.8 planets, and its smallest country, Luxembourg, consumes resources at the fastest rate. The report highlights the need for climate protection and sustainable development, with EU leaders meeting to discuss priorities for the next five years. The EU aims to become climate neutral by 2050.

images.alt_text: The European Union's (EU) 28 countries consume the Earth's resources much faster than they can be renewed, and none of them has sustainable consumption policies, a report released on Thursday said, as EU leaders meet to discuss priorities for the next five years.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Read with Michelle Martin: Vikram Khanna
summary: Vikram Khanna, associate editor of The Straits Times, discusses why populist policies often lead to hyper-inflation and failed economies. He shares insights from his book "Headwinds and Hazards: Economic Snapshots in an Age of Populism". Khanna also comments on Singapore's participation in the Belt-and-Road initiative potentially influencing China's lending practices.

site_title: Blaming government 'failure', Britain's Labour launches European vote campaign
summary: British Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn is launching a European election campaign, blaming the Conservative government's "complete failure" to steer the country out of the EU. Corbyn will urge voters to support his party, which sees a second referendum as an option to stop a "bad deal" or leaving the EU without an agreement. The European Parliament election is scheduled for May 23, after the UK failed to meet its original Brexit deadline.

site_title: Uber, Lyft drivers strike to press demands on rideshare firms
summary: Thousands of Uber and Lyft drivers in the US, including an estimated 10,000 in New York, went on strike to protest pay and working conditions. The drivers, who are classified as independent contractors, claim the companies' flawed business model forces them to absorb costs, leaving them in poverty. The strike comes weeks after Lyft's Wall Street debut and days ahead of Uber's massive share offering, estimated at $90 billion. The drivers are seeking fair pay and benefits, but companies maintain that their model allows for flexibility and profit.

site_title: Free Old Chang Kee Unicorn'O puffs for SPH direct subscribers
summary: Old Chang Kee Coffee House @ Rex is hosting a giveaway for DIRECT subscribers of The Business Times and other SPH newspapers. The first 300 subscribers who show their e-card in the SPH Rewards app from 2pm to 5pm on Saturday will receive a free Unicorn'O curry puff. The event is part of Old Chang Kee's first-year anniversary celebrations of its flagship store. Customers can also enjoy promotional prices on popular items, participate in a design competition, and win goodie bags and merchandise.

site_title: Trump moves to strangle Iran economy as nuclear deal withers
summary: US President Donald Trump tightened sanctions on Iran's mining industry, further straining the country's economy, amid heightened tensions after the US deployed an aircraft carrier strike group and nuclear-capable bombers to the region. Iran suspended some nuclear deal promises, threatening to abandon more if European allies fail to deliver sanctions relief within 60 days. Trump denounced European countries for seeing the US as the "sheriff" and said he was willing to negotiate face-to-face with Iran's leaders, but observers believe such a meeting is highly unlikely.

site_title: Quality, trustworthy news will always be at core of media business, say industry leaders
summary: Industry leaders, including Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) CEO Ng Yat Chung, emphasize the importance of quality, trustworthy news in a fragmented social media landscape. To secure its future, SPH is investing in digital capabilities, data-driven approaches, and exploring new advertising models. Despite challenges, leaders acknowledge the need for original content and professional news production processes. They believe high-quality news will always have a place in society and that technology will not replace human journalists, but rather, change the way they work.

site_title: China's trade surplus narrows sharply in April as exports dip
summary: China's trade surplus narrowed to $13.84 billion in April, down from $35 billion in March, as exports fell 2.7% and imports rose 4%. The decline in exports was attributed to US tariff threats, while imports were boosted by higher commodity prices. Despite a potential trade deal between China and the US, economists expect subdued export growth, with potential tariffs affecting growth by 2-3 percentage points. The data suggests a negative outlook for smart devices and automobile sales globally.

site_title: Airbnb-style short-term home sharing still illegal: URA
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) in Singapore has decided to maintain the status quo on short-term home sharing, keeping it illegal in private homes for periods under three consecutive months. The move is seen as a relief by hospitality players, who may benefit from the shift to mid-market hotels and economy options. The URA will continue to monitor the situation and is open to reviewing its position in the future if platform operators adhere to regulatory frameworks.

site_title: Thai junta-backed party is just 11 votes shy of a majority after election count
summary: Thailand's army-backed Palang Pracharat party needs 11 votes to secure a majority in the lower house after the election, with 115 seats and the support of 250 military-appointed senators. The party, led by coup leader Prayut Chan-O-Cha, is at risk of losing power if coalition partners, including the Democrat Party and Bhumjaitai, do not join forces. The election results, released after a month's delay, have sparked challenges and negotiations, with the Shinawatra-linked Pheu Thai party threatening to take legal action over the counting process.

site_title: Nestle, rivals vie for baby milk prize in China's smaller cities
summary: Nestle plans to launch a new line of baby formula in China, targeting smaller cities where imported brands are unaffordable due to shipping distances and lower incomes. The new line, under an existing brand, will focus on quality and sophistication while being marketed differently to appeal to local consumers. This move aims to lengthen Nestle's lead in China's $25 billion baby formula market, where local brands are gaining traction and premium Western brands face intense competition.

site_title: 5G is coming soon - but not so soon
summary: Singapore's 5G mobile network rollout is expected to be delayed, with a wide-scale deployment not anticipated until 2023 or 2024. The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) attributes the delay to the availability of the 3.5GHz spectrum band, which is still being used by regional neighbors and for satellite television reception. This slower roll-out is expected to be more gradual than 4G, with analysts noting that the lack of decent revenue opportunities in the consumer space may contribute to the delay.

site_title: FAA sets up board to review Boeing 737 Max software fix
summary: The FAA has established a Technical Advisory Board to review Boeing's proposed software fix for the grounded 737 MAX. The board, composed of experts from the FAA, US Air Force, Nasa, and Volpe National Transportation Systems Center, will assess the Maneuvering Characteristics Augmentation System (MCAS) and provide recommendations to inform the FAA's decision on the plane's safe return to service. The review comes after two 737 MAX crashes killed 346 people, and Boeing has yet to submit its software fix for approval. Other reviews are ongoing, including a blue-ribbon committee and a joint review by 10 governmental air regulators.

site_title: 'Never been sexually harassed': Hollywood legend Keaton says
summary: Hollywood legend Diane Keaton claims to have never experienced sexual harassment in her nearly 50-year career, attributing her good fortune to her confidence and being "not harassment material." Despite being friends and former lovers with Woody Allen, Keaton has continued to support him following the sexual harassment scandals. She is set to release her latest film, Poms, about ageing women, and remains active in her career, saying she has no intention of stopping work.

site_title: Shopee, Lazada lead in battle for S-E Asia's e-commerce crown: iPrice
summary: Shopee and Lazada have split the lead for South-east Asia's e-commerce crown in the first quarter of 2019, according to product comparison website iPrice. Shopee's web platform recorded 184.4 million monthly visits, surpassing Lazada's 179.7 million. However, Lazada led in mobile apps, particularly in the Philippines, Malaysia, Thailand, and Singapore, while Shopee's app ranked first in Vietnam. The regional battle between the two e-commerce giants is intensifying, with Shopee's growth driven by increased visits in Indonesia and Thailand.

site_title: Haw Par Q1 net profit rises 14% to S$22m
summary: Haw Par Corporation's first-quarter net profit rose 14.1% to S$22.07 million, driven by higher revenue from its healthcare products. Group revenue increased 22.3% to S$73.38 million, while earnings per share rose to 10 Singapore cents. Distribution and marketing expenses rose 24.3%, but finance expenses declined 40.7%. The company cited global uncertainties and potential price increases for raw materials as potential risks to its future outlook.

site_title: Oil rises from 5-week low; supply risks trump trade-talk failure
summary: Oil prices rebounded from a five-week low as Russia's contamination crisis and a drop in US gasoline inventories took precedence over concerns about US-China trade talks. Futures rose 0.9% in New York after dropping 1.4% on Tuesday. Analysts expect Russian supply issues to be short-term, but the situation remains "fraught with risks." US crude stockpiles climbed, while gasoline inventories fell, providing a bullish sign for demand. Oil prices rose 0.8% to $61.86 a barrel, while Brent crude climbed 0.5% to $70.22 a barrel.

images.alt_text: The Ust-Luga terminal about 110 km from St Petersburg. Organic chlorides were found in Russian crude last month, tainting the oil. Ships loaded with the product have mostly suspended their journeys.

site_title: As Uber guns for US IPO, drivers in India suffer as incentives are slashed
summary: Uber is set to debut on Wall Street, but drivers in India are struggling due to slashed incentives. In 2016, drivers like Rajesh Raut earned up to $1,280 a month, but after a 30% cut in 2017, their earnings dropped to around $540 a month. Many drivers are now defaulting on loan payments and quitting the service, citing the reduced income as unsustainable. The company acknowledges the risk of driver dissatisfaction, but plans to pay $300 million to over 1.1 million drivers as part of its IPO.

site_title: Hackers steal US$41m in bitcoins from cryptocurrency exchange
summary: Hackers stole approximately US$41 million in bitcoins from Binance, one of the world's largest cryptocurrency exchanges, using techniques such as phishing and viruses. The incident is the latest in a string of thefts from cryptocurrency exchanges, with US$950 million stolen last year. Binance's CEO, Zhao Changpeng, stated that user funds would not be affected and that the company would use its secure asset fund to cover the loss. Deposits and withdrawals from the exchange remain suspended while a thorough security review is conducted, estimated to take about a week.

site_title: Dollar slips as trade tensions raise rate cut expectations
summary: The US dollar weakened 0.1% to 97.50 against a basket of rivals as investors raised expectations of a rate cut due to escalating trade tensions between the US and China. Market strategists expect a rate cut if trade tensions escalate further, citing data showing China's trade surplus with the US expanded to $21.01 billion in April. The yuan edged 0.1% lower, and the yen gained 0.2% against the dollar. The New Zealand dollar fell after the central bank cut benchmark cash rates, while the euro remained steady.

site_title: Rich Capital to pay S$33.7m instead of S$44m for acquisition of 2 building firms
summary: Rich Capital, a Catalist-listed Singapore company, will acquire two construction firms, Rich-Link Construction and Rich-Link Builders, for S$33.7 million instead of the initially agreed price of S$44 million. The revised price takes into account a revised valuation report from independent valuer BDO Advisory, as well as outstanding orders secured and prevailing business risks. The acquisition aims to expand Rich Capital into the construction business. The deal involves issuing new shares to the firms' owners, with the first tranche worth S$27 million and the second tranche worth S$6.7 million.

site_title: Halcyon Agri posts Q1 loss of US$5.7m on higher financing cost, lower sales volumes
summary: Halcyon Agri Corp, a rubber supplier, reported a Q1 loss of US$5.7 million due to higher financing costs and lower sales volumes. Revenue fell 16% to US$399.7 million, with sales volume dropping 9% and revenue per metric tonne falling 8%. The company attributed the decline to a deliberate strategy change to focus on higher margins. Despite this, gross profit improved 11.3% to US$32 million, and operations in Ivory Coast returned to profitability.

site_title: Allied Tech suspends trading, appointing special auditor to probe 'concerns'
summary: Allied Tech, a Catalist-listed company, has suspended trading and appointed a special auditor to investigate concerns raised by its auditors, Ernst & Young LLP. The auditors questioned business rationale for investments and transactions, including an interest-free loan facility and a revolving loan agreement. The company also faced concerns over the use of funds held in trust and/or escrow by a law firm. Allied Tech has been granted extensions to hold its annual general meeting and release Q1 FY2019 results, and will require additional time to complete its audit for FY2018.

site_title: Commerzbank faces same old problems after merger talks end
summary: Commerzbank, a Frankfurt-based bank, is facing the same old problems after merger talks with Deutsche Bank ended. Despite adding 123,000 new retail customers and 800 business clients in the first quarter, the bank's profit slumped by more than half due to negative interest rates and competition. The bank's growth strategy relies on heavy marketing, but this is expensive and takes time to translate into business. Commerzbank's CEO Martin Zielke has set a goal to grow revenue by 3% a year, but analysts warn that the environment for banks in Europe will remain difficult for the next two years.

site_title: Labour shortage chips away at Japan's back-breaking work culture
summary: Japan's traditional back-breaking work culture is shifting as younger employees increasingly demand better work-life balance and autonomy. Companies like Cybozu Inc. are now giving employees more freedom to set their own goals, work from home, and take vacations, leading to improved productivity and reduced turnover. The government has introduced reforms to limit work hours and make it easier for staff to take time off, with penalties for non-compliance. As a result, average work hours have fallen, and productivity has increased, with some companies experiencing double-digit annual growth rates in sales.

site_title: Siemens carves out energy unit, cuts 10,000 jobs in massive overhaul
summary: Siemens, a German conglomerate, has announced a massive overhaul, carving out its struggling power and gas division and cutting over 10,000 jobs. The move is part of CEO Joe Kaeser's strategy to dismantle the company's cumbersome structure and position it for the future. The company posted strong Q2 profit, with adjusted earnings rising 7% to 2.41 billion euros. The power and gas division will be listed next year, and Siemens will retain around 50% of the new entity. The restructuring aims to save 2.2 billion euros by 2023.

site_title: COEs end mixed in latest bidding exercise
summary: Singapore's latest COE (Certificates of Entitlement) bidding exercise ended with mixed results, with most COE prices rising. Car COE prices increased for vehicles up to 1,600cc and 130bhp, while commercial vehicle and motorcycle COE prices decreased. The open COE for bigger cars rose to $52,502, and motorcycle premium decreased to $3,352. The May-July quota saw a slight decrease overall, with the largest decline in the car COE quota.

site_title: Toyota annual net profit falls 25% to 1.88t yen
summary: Toyota's annual net profit fell 25% to 1.88 trillion yen due to investment losses, but the company forecasts a 19.5% rise in earnings to 2.25 trillion yen for the upcoming year. Despite record sales of 30.23 trillion yen, Toyota attributes the loss to the deterioration of the stock market and a comparison to the previous year's 250-billion-yen boost from US tax reform. The company expects operating profit to increase 3.3% to 2.55 trillion yen and sales to sag 0.7% to 30 trillion yen.

site_title: Perps as equity: Hyflux saga shows rethink needed
summary: Hyflux's accounting treatment for its perpetual securities, or perps, has sparked debate over whether they should be classified as 'equity' or 'liability' in the balance sheet. Current accounting practices classify perps as equity, but critics argue that the coupon step-up feature may negate the "if and only if there is no contractual obligation to repay" condition for equity classification. Additionally, the cost of equity financing is not accounted for in financial statements, leading to potential misinterpretation of financial performance. A rethinking of accounting issues is suggested to provide a more accurate representation of financial instruments.

site_title: How pay packages of top brass at GIC, Temasek are determined
summary: Singapore's Second Finance Minister Lawrence Wong stated that the pay packages of top brass at sovereign wealth fund GIC and state investment firm Temasek Holdings are determined by performance and industry benchmarks. The government maintains an arms-length relationship with the companies, allowing them to set their own remuneration for staff. This approach aims to attract and retain capable people, as well as support a prudent risk-taking culture. The government evaluates GIC and Temasek's performance based on long-term returns, with figures published in their annual reports.

site_title: Property slowdown beckons as next risk for emerging markets
summary: Emerging markets face a slowdown in property markets due to weakening domestic growth, with some countries experiencing double-digit declines in real estate sales. China's real estate market shows signs of recovery, while others, such as Thailand, Indonesia, and Turkey, face challenges due to rising interest rates, currency volatility, and economic uncertainty. Developed countries like Australia, the UK, and Switzerland also face property market woes. Experts warn that decelerating economic growth momentum is a headwind for all markets, making the property sector a critical element to monitor for further signs of gloom.

site_title: Adopt 996? Singapore has things in better perspective
summary: Singapore's working hours show a trend opposite to China's 996 work culture, with the number of paid weekly hours per employee falling steadily over the decade, averaging 44.8 hours last year. This contrasts with China, where tech moguls have endorsed the 996 work culture. Singapore's Ministry of Manpower attributes the trend to part-time work, short-term stints, and the use of technology, but notes that long hours are still common in certain sectors. The country is instead focusing on workplace health, including mental health risks, and exploring a four-day work week.

site_title: Asia markets slide on trade concerns
summary: Asia markets declined on Wednesday, following a Wall Street sell-off triggered by hawkish US officials supporting increased levies on Chinese imports. The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.9% to 3,283.84, with 23 of its 30 components ending in the red. China's mixed April trade figures and a stronger yen also weighed on the market. However, some stocks bucked the trend, including Wilmar International, which rose 1.7%, and Isetan Singapore, which gained 0.6%. Investors are cautious ahead of US-China trade talks starting on Thursday, with some advising to pare back risk exposure.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings reported a 31% decrease in net profit to S$5.3 million for the first quarter, despite a 91% increase in revenue to S$88.5 million. The company attributed the decline to lower revenue from hotel ownership and property investment segments.

site_title: IPO fever yet to boost Frisco's real estate market
summary: Frisco's real estate market has not been boosted by this year's tech IPOs, despite expectations of increased demand from newly minted millionaires. The housing market's peak prices last year remain unchanged, indicating little impact from the IPOs. Meanwhile, other markets are experiencing fluctuations, including rising US mortgage rates, record Manhattan rents, and a rebound in UK homebuyer demand. Additionally, WeWork has secured new tenants at its Singapore property after emerging from bankruptcy, while New World is selling its China property assets after a loan deal. Demand for Singapore prime projects remains uncertain.

site_title: Ayondo goes ahead with controversial move to sell UK unit
summary: Ayondo, a CATALIST-listed Singaporean investment firm, has sealed a deal to sell its UK-based investment firm, Ayondo Markets Limited (AML), for £5.7 million (S$10.2 million) to reduce liabilities. Despite concerns from the Singapore Exchange's regulation unit (SGX RegCo) over the deal, Ayondo has proceeded with the sale, citing a working capital deficiency from continued losses. The disposal aims to focus on enhancing its social trading platform and achieving profitability.

site_title: The ups and downs in motherhood journey
summary: On Mother's Day weekend, a spotlight was shone on four successful entrepreneurs who balance career goals with motherhood. The article also discussed the challenges of motherhood, including sleep deprivation, and highlighted Macau as a food destination with multiple Michelin-starred Cantonese restaurants. Additionally, it covered various lifestyle topics, including jewelry gift ideas, home styling, and upcoming film festivals. The article aimed to redefine the ideal of motherhood and showcase women who have found fulfillment in their roles.

site_title: Aussie housing downturn the top risk for money managers: Fitch
summary: Fitch Ratings surveyed over 3/4 of Australia's real money market, totaling A$500 billion, and found that the top risk for local credit markets is an Aussie housing market downturn. This is a significant shift in sentiment from last year, when the jobs sector was seen as the top risk. The survey results highlight the potential impact of a housing market downturn on the country's fixed income assets.

site_title: Best World Q1 net profit up 79% to S$10.3m
summary: Best World International posted a 79% jump in Q1 net profit to S$10.3 million, driven by strong sales growth across most markets, particularly in China. Revenue more than doubled to S$53.4 million. The company attributed the outperformance to its DR's Secret skincare line and full adoption of its new franchise model. However, net profit margin fell to 19.4% due to increased distribution costs and a decrease in other operating income. The group is cautiously optimistic about 2019 growth, with contributions from both direct selling and franchise segments.

site_title: The 100 trillion dollar question
summary: The US economy's vast wealth gap has reached $114 trillion, according to a Federal Reserve study, with the top 1% holding nearly 40% of the total wealth. This skewed distribution poses significant economic and political implications, including the potential for increased inequality and a shift in the 2020 election's focus to economic issues. The study's findings also highlight the need for policymakers to address the root causes of wealth inequality and balance the need for tax increases with the risk of discouraging risk-taking and investment.

site_title: Telcos' dilemma: How to scale up to 5G without breaking the bank
summary: Singapore's mobile network operators face a dilemma in scaling up to 5G technology without breaking the bank. To alleviate the sharp capital expenditure (capex) pinch, telcos may consider sharing infrastructure and rolling out services gradually. The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) is weighing the benefits of shared infrastructure against potential drawbacks, including lower service differentiation. Experts predict that telcos must share the 5G network to justify the costs, with 5G capex potentially being two to three times as much as 4G.

images.alt_text: Singtel has said that it is "committed to maintaining our investment-grade credit ratings", while StarHub chief executive Peter Kaliaropoulos last week called StarHub's debt level - 1.5 times its earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation, as at March 31 - "fairly respectable".

site_title: Human-centred AI that works with humans
summary: A new approach to artificial intelligence, known as human-centred AI, is gaining traction, shifting the focus from emulating human intelligence to augmenting the process using computer technology to work with humans. This approach recognizes the limitations of traditional AI in coping with unexpected scenarios and seeks to empower humans by facilitating their abilities. By studying human intelligence and developing AI systems that work together with humans, human-centred AI aims to increase productivity, improve standards of living, and provide tangible societal benefits. This approach prioritizes trust, tempering AI behavior, and addressing user pain points to create an environment where humans and AI can co-exist.

site_title: Lyft posts US$1.1b Q1 loss; sees losses peaking this year
summary: Lyft Inc reported a US$1.1 billion quarterly loss, despite gaining more revenue per customer and controlling expenses. The company expects losses to peak this year but sees a path to profitability in ride-sharing. CEO Brian Roberts expressed confidence in the core business, sparking a short-lived gain in shares.

images.alt_text: Ride services company Lyft said investments in areas such as self-driving, scooters and bikes were masking improvements in its core business.

site_title: Fake news bill passed into law after marathon debate
summary: Singapore's Protection from Online Falsehoods and Manipulation Bill was passed with 72 MPs voting "yes" after a marathon 2-day debate. The bill, which gives ministers the power to decide on online falsehoods, was opposed by the Workers' Party, with all 9 MPs voting "no". Three Nominated MPs abstained. The bill's passage has raised concerns about ministerial power and the potential for abuse.

site_title: Moutai's new chief to overhaul strategy, scrap brands
summary: Moutai, China's most valuable alcohol distiller, is overhauling its strategy under new chairman Li Baofang. The company is shutting down subsidiaries that produce non-premium brands, halting a customization business, and establishing its own sales office to sell directly to customers. This shift aims to refocus on its cash cow, ultra-premium baijiu lines, and protect the brand's reputation from suspected kickbacks between distributors and subsidiaries. The changes have created concerns among investors, with Moutai's stock losing 12% this week amid worries about the shift in power and sales.

site_title: China Gaoxian fails to obtain shareholder approval for proposed divestment
summary: China Gaoxian Fibre Fabric Holdings has shelved plans to dispose of its loss-making subsidiary Huaxiang China Gaoxian International Holdings due to inability to obtain shareholder approval. The proposed divestment agreement has lapsed, affecting the group's consolidated financial statements for the previous and current financial years. The company's shares have been suspended from trading since April 3, and it will make a separate announcement regarding material differences in its financial statements.

site_title: Captains of Iron Ore
summary: SGX plays a crucial role in managing the impact of fluctuations in iron ore cargo prices. A supply-side shockwave in January 2019, triggered by a Vale SA mine collapse, pushed prices 10% higher and volatility surged to 40%. To mitigate risks, SGX offers freight derivatives indexed to global benchmarks, clearing over 1.3 billion tonnes of iron ore derivatives in 2018. The company's launch of high-grade iron ore derivatives has made risk management more effective for producers and traders. Looking ahead, market analysts predict more volatility due to Chinese economic growth, trade tensions, and environmental pressures, making better risk management essential for surviving market challenges.

site_title: Court confiscates S$2.6m in ill-gotten gains from convicted football match-fixer
summary: The Singapore High Court has issued a confiscation order for S$3.4 million in concealed income from a match-fixer, Eric Ding, who was convicted of bribing Lebanese football officials. The order, made on May 3, 2019, is part of a rare move by the authorities to strip ill-gotten gains from convicted offenders. The confiscation is based on the Corruption, Drug Trafficking and other Serious Crimes (Confiscation of Benefits) Act, and aims to ensure that Ding does not enjoy the illicit proceeds upon his release from jail.

site_title: OnRobot opens Asia-Pac HQ in Singapore, eyes booming regional market
summary: Denmark-based robotics company OnRobot has opened its Asia-Pacific headquarters in Singapore, aiming to develop products for the region's growing demand for robotic arms. The company plans to create 40-50 new products, advancing collaborative applications between humans and machines in South-east Asia and beyond. OnRobot CEO Enrico Krog Iversen emphasizes the importance of ease of business and bridging cultural differences, with a focus on the Singapore, Thailand, and Malaysia markets. The company aims to make Singaporean companies more competitive and provide complete collaborative robot solutions to improve productivity and reduce costs.

site_title: Qantas captain flies into risky tenure territory
summary: Qantas CEO Alan Joyce has agreed to lead the airline for another three years, despite concerns about the risks of long-term leadership. Under Joyce's tenure, Qantas has generated a 10% annual return for shareholders and implemented ambitious projects, but he faces the challenge of succession and potential blind spots as he approaches 13 years at the helm. Front-runners for the position include Gareth Evans and Tino La Spina, and the airline may need to prepare a new leader to navigate future challenges.

site_title: Regulator blocks Vodafone's US$7.7b merger with TPG
summary: Australia's competition watchdog blocked a $7.7 billion merger between Vodafone's struggling Australian business and TPG Telecom, citing it would substantially lessen competition in the mobile services market. The decision blocks a proposal to create a new Australian tech giant and will force TPG to challenge the regulator in court. Vodafone and TPG had argued the merger would bring benefits to consumers, but the ACCC said it would give Telstra and Optus more power, potentially harming competition.

site_title: Iran rolling back nuclear curbs under pact now abandoned by Washington
summary: Iran announced it is scaling back nuclear curbs under the 2015 nuclear deal with world powers, amid escalating tensions with the US. President Hassan Rouhani unveiled measures to halt the sale of excess enriched uranium and heavy water to other countries, but threatened to enrich uranium beyond permitted levels if sanctions are not lifted. The move is seen as a warning to the five remaining parties to the deal to protect Iran's oil and banking industries. The US has imposed sanctions and blacklisted Iran's Revolutionary Guards force, prompting Iran to threaten to close the Strait of Hormuz.

site_title: EU elections: A new era for European politics?
summary: The EU elections, taking place from May 23-26, will mark a significant shift in European politics, potentially ending traditional party dominance and favoring populist radical right parties. The fragmented parliament may lead to a slower and more complex policymaking process, with a strong representation of nationalist and Eurosceptic views. Moderate forces are urged to act as agents of progress and unity to counter populist narratives. The outcome will have far-reaching implications, including potential delays in trade policy decisions and the EU's external trade agenda.

site_title: Deutsche Bank execs set to face angry shareholders after adviser reports
summary: Deutsche Bank executives may face angry shareholders at its annual general meeting on May 23, as ISS and Glass Lewis recommend voting against backing the bank's management and supervisory board. The firms cited the bank's 40% share price loss over the past year and ongoing legal and business challenges. Other shareholders have expressed frustration with the leadership and chairman Paul Achleitner, with some even tabling motions to oust him. The recommendation is a rare sign of shareholder discontent and could impact the bank's leadership.

site_title: CapitaLand's revamped Funan secures 98% pre-leasing commitment for twin office blocks
summary: CapitaLand's revamped Funan integrated development in Singapore has secured a 98% pre-leasing commitment for its twin office blocks, covering 210,000 square feet of total office net lettable area. The office tenants, including public agencies, multinational corporations, and startups, are set to move in from the second quarter of 2019. The project, valued at S$560 million, features a retail component, office blocks, and a co-living serviced residence, and will have smart building technologies and cycling facilities. The pre-leasing commitment is expected to contribute earnings to CapitaLand Mall Trust from Q3 2019.

site_title: Souped up Google Assistants offer privacy trade-offs
summary: Google unveiled new privacy features for its Google Assistant at its I/O event, but also introduced features that increase the trade-off between convenience and privacy. The new features include improved voice recognition and personalized recommendations, which require users to share more personal data. This move increases tension between convenience and privacy, highlighting the ongoing debate about the balance between these two aspects.

site_title: It's still all about the economy in US presidential race
summary: US presidential candidates' economic platforms vary, with potential outcomes including a Trump victory, a non-Trump Republican win, a centrist Democrat, or a populist Democrat. A strong economy could favor a Trump or non-Trump Republican win, while a weaker economy could lead to a Democrat victory. A centrist Democrat would likely focus on growth and low inflation, while a populist Democrat would promise significant fiscal expansion and increased regulatory oversight. The economy's performance between now and the 2020 election will be a key factor in determining the next president.

site_title: China is losing its grip on companies because of Trump's trade war
summary: Taiwan-based electronics supplier Delta Electronics Inc. is shifting production away from China amid US-China trade tensions and security concerns. The company is moving production to Taiwan, Thailand, and India, including building three to four plants in India, in response to Prime Minister Narendra Modi's "Make in India" program. Delta aims to reduce its reliance on China to 60% of its products from 70-73% currently, and its CEO says diversification is inevitable due to rising labor costs, security concerns, and the prospect of higher tariffs.

site_title: Trade dispute a 'big headwind' but US manufacturing sees solid growth: report
summary: US manufacturing expects solid growth despite a "big headwind" from ongoing trade disputes with China. The sector's revenue is projected to increase by 4% this year, according to an industry survey. Companies are passing on price increases to customers due to existing tariffs, but are preparing for a larger hit from planned tariffs on $200 billion in Chinese goods. US and Chinese officials are set to meet to discuss trade talks, with President Trump stating they aim to "make a deal."

site_title: Chinese oil imports surge to record
summary: China's crude oil imports surged to a record 43.73 million tons in April, or 10.68 million barrels a day, according to data from the General Administration of Customs in Beijing. This is the highest figure since 2010, driven by large volumes of Iranian oil imports before US sanctions exemptions expired on May 2. The record purchases were partly offset by maintenance shutdowns of local refiners, which took 1.7 million barrels a day offline in April.

site_title: US House approves pro-Taiwan Bills amid China tensions
summary: The US House of Representatives unanimously approved legislation supporting Taiwan, amid China's military and diplomatic pressure. The measures include a non-binding resolution reaffirming US commitment to Taiwan and the "Taiwan Assurance Act of 2019," which urges Taiwan to increase defense spending and supports its participation in international organizations. China expressed anger, urging the US to block the bills and warning of harm to China-US cooperation. Taiwan's foreign ministry welcomed the move, expressing gratitude.

site_title: Ex-Vogue Paris style siren releases her signature scent
summary: Former Vogue Paris editor-in-chief Carine Roitfeld has launched her signature scent line, Carine Roitfeld Parfums, with seven unisex fragrances available on Net-a-Porter and her website. The collection, inspired by her great loves and favorite cities, was created with a team of perfumers and took eight years to develop. Roitfeld retained creative control and footed the bill herself, opting for a niche approach to differentiate her line from mass market fragrances. The collection's unique scents, including Vladimir and George, are now available for purchase, with prices starting at $285 for a 90ml bottle.

images.alt_text: "We are French, as you know, and French people never talk about money." - Carine Roitfeld (above) when pressed on how much she personally invested in her own line of scents.

site_title: Thai King Power to compete with Korea's Lotte, others in duty free auction
summary: Thai King Power Duty Free will compete against major players like Korea's Lotte and Thai mall-operator Central Group in an auction for a lucrative duty free concession from Airports of Thailand (AOT). The concession, set to expire in 2020, will be awarded on May 31 and begin on September 28, 2020. The winner will generate $526.2 million in concession revenue for AOT, with the concession expiring on March 31, 2031.

site_title: Petrobras profit misses forecasts, higher oil output expected in Q2
summary: Brazilian state-run oil firm Petrobras posted a quarterly profit of 4.03 billion reais, 42% lower than the same period last year, due to judicial contingencies and one-off items. Quarterly oil production fell 4% to 2.61 million barrels per day, but management expects a production boost in the second quarter as new platforms ramp up output. The company reported adjusted EBITDA of 27.5 billion reais, missing Refinitiv estimates. Net debt increased 38% in the quarter, but would have fallen marginally without accounting adjustments.

site_title: Sri Lanka President vows to destroy jihadists
summary: Sri Lanka's President Maithripala Sirisena vowed to crush Islamic extremist groups responsible for the Easter Sunday bombings that killed 258 people. He toured a village where a gun battle with troops left 16 dead and set off three suicide explosions. Sirisena stated that the offensive against Islamic extremists is "successfully moving forward."

site_title: Trump asserts executive privilege over full Mueller report
summary: President Donald Trump asserted executive privilege over the Mueller report and underlying evidence, shielding hidden portions from Congress. The assertion comes as the House Judiciary Committee is set to vote on holding Attorney General William Barr in contempt for defying a subpoena. This is Trump's first use of executive privilege as president. The move is expected to further escalate tensions between the executive and legislative branches over the report's contents.

site_title: Prince Harry and Meghan name baby son Archie
summary: Prince Harry and Meghan have named their baby son Archie Harrison Mountbatten-Windsor, according to their Instagram account. The couple introduced their baby to Queen Elizabeth II at Windsor Castle, with other family members also present. Meghan expressed happiness and relief about motherhood, describing her son as calm and having a sweet temperament. The baby is the seventh-in-line to the British throne.

site_title: Singapore shares slide 0.9% on Wednesday after sell-off on Wall Street
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.9% on Wednesday, following a Tuesday sell-off on Wall Street due to US threats to hike tariffs on Chinese goods. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,283.84, down 28.68 points, as investors remained jittery over trade tensions.
