Far East Orchard saw a 55.4% drop in first-quarter net profit to S$3.42 million. AEM Holdings posted a 19.7% drop in first-quarter earnings to S$6.6 million.

site_title: Pandora to cut 1,200 jobs as Q1 profit, sales fall
summary: Pandora, the jewellery maker, is cutting 1,200 jobs in Thailand and speeding up marketing spending under its new CEO, Alexander Lacik. The move follows a 700-layoff announcement in February and aims to turn around the struggling brand. Like-for-like sales fell 10% in Q1 due to declining shopper numbers at stores in key markets. The company will double marketing investments in Italy, the UK, and China, and bring in celebrities and digital media influencers to boost sales. Earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortisation (Ebitda) fell 12% to 1.5 billion Danish kroner.

site_title: As Wall Street IPO looms, Uber clings to hard-knuckled tactics in pursuit of growth
summary: Uber is set to debut on Wall Street with its largest US public stock offering since 2014, but the company's sharp-elbowed tactics and failure to address regulatory issues may impact its growth and profitability. Uber's aggressive business methods, including lobbying against local regulations and using the courts to block restrictions, have led to a stalemate with cities worldwide. The company's CEO, Dara Khosrowshahi, has made efforts to clean up a frat-house culture, but its DNA remains focused on growth over regulation.

site_title: China vice-premier to visit US amid heightened trade tensions
summary: Chinese Vice-Premier Liu He will visit the US this week for trade talks amid heightened tensions. US officials claim China has backtracked on substantial commitments made during months of negotiations, prompting President Donald Trump to announce new tariffs on $200 billion of Chinese goods. China has confirmed the visit, saying it will remain calm and focus on talks, with Foreign Ministry spokesman Geng Shuang stating that mutual respect is key to a trade agreement. The visit comes as the US is set to impose 25% tariffs on $50 billion of Chinese machinery and technology goods.

site_title: Returning Singapore to the global stage of semiconductor production
summary: Singapore's semiconductor industry, once a key player, has fallen behind global leaders such as the US, Taiwan, South Korea, and China. Despite its early start in 1986, Singapore's credentials are now in jeopardy due to high costs, lack of integrated support, and ownership models. The nation needs to adapt its policies to fit locally-competitive versus globally-competitive industries, enabling a level playing field for industries competing globally. With $19 billion allocated to research, innovation, and enterprise, Singapore must work together to utilize its talent and capabilities to generate greater commercial success and carve a place as global champions.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Koufu Group reported a 4.9% year-on-year increase in revenue to S$57.8 million, with core earnings rising 17% to S$7.2 million. DBS Equity Research downgraded Koufu to neutral due to re-rated valuation. NetLink NBN Trust maintained a buy rating, expecting FY2019 net profit of S$73 million and attractive dividend yields. Key drivers for NetLink include StarHub's fibre migration plan and expansion into new housing estates.

site_title: RBA holds rates, signals cuts if jobless rate doesn't improve
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) held interest rates at 1.5% despite inflation coming in below expectations, signaling potential future cuts if the unemployment rate doesn't improve. The RBA characterized the labor market as "strong" but noted spare capacity, indicating a need for a further improvement in the labor market for inflation to reach its target. The decision comes ahead of a national election, with economists expecting some form of fiscal stimulus regardless of the outcome.

site_title: Trump awards Presidential Medal of Freedom to Tiger Woods
summary: US President Donald Trump awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom to American golf legend Tiger Woods at the White House, praising his "relentless will to win, win, win" following his epic comeback victory in the Masters.

images.alt_text: Woods said his Masters victory was "probably the highlight" of what he has accomplished so far in his career on the golf course.

site_title: Economic outlook a little subdued - but keep calm and carry on
summary: Singapore's economic growth is expected to slow, but not necessarily enter a recession. The country's factory output contracted 4.8% year-on-year in March, and April's manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index fell to its lowest reading since 2016. Economists predict the first-quarter GDP growth will be slightly below the midpoint of its 1.5-3.5% forecast range. Despite this, growth forecasts for 2019 and 2020 remain optimistic, with some economists predicting 1.8% growth in 2019 and 2.1% in 2020. The US-China trade tensions have raised concerns, but experts believe a sustained slowdown is unlikely.

site_title: Global bond traders betting against latest Trump threat
summary: Global bond investors are betting that US-China trade tensions will ease, causing yields to rise. Investors are buying put options on Treasuries and German bunds, anticipating a short-term trade deal. Yields on US 10-year bonds rose one basis point to 2.48% after US President Trump announced tariffs on $200 billion of Chinese imports would increase to 25% from 10%. Investors expect China to capitulate and a US-China trade deal to be struck, with some targeting 10-year yields to rise 9 basis points by July.

site_title: Ritz-Carlton supports Smile Asia for 6th consecutive year
summary: The Ritz-Carlton, Millenia Singapore has supported Smile Asia for the sixth consecutive year, with the luxury brand participating in Smile Asia Week 2019. The charity, which offers life-changing surgeries to children and adults with facial deformities, has seen over 70,000 cakes sold since 2014, contributing to over 2,600 life-changing surgeries and aiming to raise S$700,000 annually. Smile Asia is a global alliance of independent charities with activities in countries such as Bangladesh, Cambodia, and Uzbekistan, deploying medical volunteers to perform corrective and reconstructive surgeries in remote areas.

site_title: Yuan struggles near 2½-month low after Trump's threats
summary: The Chinese offshore yuan dropped to near 2½-month lows after US President Donald Trump threatened additional tariffs on Chinese goods, but traders remained calm due to ongoing negotiations. Trump's tweets on Sunday sparked initial panic, but the yuan recovered some losses and remained under pressure. The offshore yuan was down 0.1% at 6.7833 yuan per dollar, its weakest since February 19, as investors awaited a meeting between Chinese Vice Premier Liu and US officials.

site_title: Winter has come; and so has Starbucks
summary: A disposable coffee cup from Starbucks briefly appeared in the final episode of Game of Thrones, sparking widespread memes and online discussions. The show's executive producer, Bernadette Caulfield, confirmed that the cup was a mistake, stating that Daenerys had ordered an herbal tea. The incident highlights the challenges of maintaining historical accuracy in productions set in the past, with even meticulous directors unable to avoid modern artifacts.

site_title: Kimly doubles interim dividend despite 13.2% fall in Q2 profit
summary: Kimly, a Singaporean coffee shop operator, reported a 13.2% decline in Q2 profit due to higher expenses. Despite this, the company's board recommended an interim dividend of 0.56 Singapore cent per share, doubling last year's amount. Revenue rose 4.7% to S$51.5 million, driven by contributions from acquired restaurant chains. Kimly plans to launch its own lower-sugar coffee and tea brands and will use technology to strengthen its outlets and central kitchens. The company has a healthy net cash position with S$86.5 million in cash and equivalents.

site_title: EU plots ahead to 2020s amid troubled times
summary: European leaders will meet in Romania for a landmark summit to set the EU's strategic agenda for the next five years. The session, held just before the May 23 European Parliament election, aims to address challenges and opportunities, and will review progress in key areas such as jobs, growth, and climate policies. The summit will also consider the future of the EU, with scenarios ranging from "carrying on" to "doing more together" and the potential impact of Brexit and rising Euroscepticism across the continent. The EU's current strategic direction, agreed in 2014, will be reviewed, and decisions will shape the bloc's future well into the 2020s.

site_title: Park Hotels to buy Chesapeake Lodging in US$2.7b deal
summary: Park Hotels & Resorts agreed to acquire Chesapeake Lodging Trust in a US$2.7 billion deal, valuing Chesapeake at US$31.71 per share, an 8.2% premium. The acquisition will secure Park's position as the second-largest lodging REIT, with Chesapeake's 20 properties and Park's 51 Hilton-branded properties combined to form 66 hotels. Five Chesapeake hotels will be sold prior to the deal's completion. The deal is expected to close in the second half of 2023 and is expected to increase adjusted funds from operations per share by 2% in 2020 and at least 3% in 2021.

site_title: Fake news law: appeal process would be fast, simple and low-cost: Shanmugam
summary: Singapore's proposed fake news law will have a fast and simple appeals process, with a minister's decision due within 2 days, a court hearing in 6 days, and no court fees for the first 3 days. The appeals process involves filing with the minister, then the High Court, with timelines allowing for a case to be heard in as little as 9 days. Standard forms will be used to simplify the process, and the courts will have the power to waive fees.

images.alt_text: Under the proposed fake news law, a minister has to make a decision within two days of receiving an application against his direction, Home Affairs and Law Minister K Shanmugam said in Parliament on Tuesday.

site_title: Modi ignoring the two elephants in the room
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi and his ruling Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) are ignoring the pressing issues of massive unemployment and declining economic growth, despite worsening data. The youth, comprising 175 million young people, are excluded from education, training, or jobs, with many awaiting election results due to be announced on May 23. The BJP has shifted its focus to nationalism and security, while young people and loan-strapped farmers demand solutions to their economic problems. Economic data shows a six-quarter low of 6.6% real GDP growth in the third quarter of 2019, and the government has lowered its economic growth forecast to 6.5% for the fourth quarter.

site_title: Perennial Hldgs posts Q1 net loss of S$26.9m
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings reported a net loss of S$26.9 million in Q1 2019, primarily due to higher finance costs and the absence of a one-off gain. Revenue increased 66.3% to S$24.9 million, driven by revenue from Capitol Singapore and Perennial International Health and Medical Hub. The group expects to be profitable in Q2 2019 after the completion of its divestment. Despite the loss, the company remains optimistic about its future prospects, particularly with its management businesses and upcoming projects.

site_title: Iron ore miners fuel gains in Australian shares
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% on Tuesday, driven by gains in iron ore miners following concerns over supply, despite the Reserve Bank of Australia keeping interest rates unchanged. Fortescue Metals Group Ltd strengthened to an almost two-week peak, while BHP Group Ltd and Rio Tinto Ltd advanced 1.4% and 2.3%, respectively. Gold miners also gained due to US President Donald Trump's threat to hike tariffs on Chinese imports. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,295.7.

site_title: Not time to go risk-on, say strategists
summary: US strategists remain optimistic about a potential US-China trade deal, despite Donald Trump's threat to hike tariffs on Chinese imports. Most assign a 60-70% probability to a deal materializing, but advise investors to brace for near-term volatility. Strategists warn of a "tug of war" market, with risk appetite deteriorating, and a one-in-three chance of trade talks breaking down. Those who expect a deal, like Credit Suisse and Lombard Odier, recommend defensive strategies, such as options trading and shifting to higher-quality equities.

site_title: Hyflux fends off move by seven banks to opt out of moratorium
summary: Seven Singapore banks have applied to be carved out of Hyflux's debt moratorium, but a Singapore High Court judge, Justice Aedit Abdullah, did not approve the application, leaving it open for revival if circumstances change. The moratorium, which expires on May 29, gives Hyflux breathing space to restructure, but creditors will have to wait until then to apply for a judicial manager. Justice Aedit warned that Hyflux will be kept "on a tight leash" and will have to disclose its running costs and restructuring timeline to creditors.

site_title: Purplebricks CEO leaves amid shakeup of ops
summary: Purplebricks CEO Michael Bruce is stepping down amid a company-wide shakeup, including the winding down of its Australian operation and review of its US operations. The company attributed the decision to a "rate of geographic expansion that was too rapid," resulting in poor execution quality. Bruce's departure follows a disappointing performance last year, with the company's stock plummeting over 64% and a revised revenue forecast of £130-140 million. Vic Darvey, chief operating officer, has taken over as CEO.

site_title: Singapore 3D cluster ties up with global network
summary: Singapore's National Additive Manufacturing Innovation Cluster (Namic) has signed a memorandum of understanding with Berlin-based Mobility goes Additive (MgA) to identify parts suitable for additive manufacturing in various sectors. The collaboration aims to facilitate tie-ups between AM players and provide plug-and-play solutions from MgA's 99 network members. Singapore is well-positioned to adopt AM technologies, driven by its manufacturing base and government efforts to train engineers in AM design and process capabilities. The collaboration is expected to boost cooperation between European and Singaporean companies in the AM industry.

site_title: LNG, a fuel for the future? Not everyone agrees
summary: Pavilion Energy successfully performed the first commercial ship-to-ship LNG bunkering in Singapore, loading 2,000 cubic meters of LNG onto a tanker at the SLNG Terminal. The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) welcomed the operation, highlighting its commitment to providing LNG bunkering solutions to meet the global shipping industry's energy needs. This milestone marks a significant step towards routine LNG bunkering in Singapore, demonstrating the country's capabilities in delivering comprehensive LNG bunker supply solutions.

site_title: Swiber JMs urge creditors to accept Seaspan rescue deal
summary: Singapore's Swiber Holdings, a debt-racked offshore and marine services provider, is seeking creditor approval for a rescue deal with New York-listed Seaspan Corp. The deal, set for a vote on May 29, offers unsecured creditors 8.8-10% recovery rate and new shares worth 12.6% stake. Seaspan plans to invest US$200 million, with a focus on liquefied natural gas-to-power in Vietnam. Judicial managers recommend the deal, citing liquidation as the likely alternative, which could leave creditors with nothing.

site_title: Bitcoin nears US$6,000 as more institutions embrace it
summary: Bitcoin reached a fresh 2019 high, approaching US$6,000, as institutions increasingly show interest in the cryptocurrency. The largest digital coin rose 4.7% to US$5,961, driven by growing institutional involvement. Fidelity Investments plans to offer Bitcoin buying and selling services to institutional customers within weeks, citing a "critical mass" of asset managers and brokers providing retail exposure. This trend is seen as a key factor in Bitcoin's recent price surge, according to technical analysts and conventional investment firms.

site_title: US warns India against retaliatory duties over scrapping of trade privileges
summary: US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross warned India against retaliatory duties over the planned withdrawal of trade privileges, stating it would not be "appropriate" under WTO rules. India's new e-commerce rules could hurt US investments, and Ross expressed hope US firms will win defence deals. The US is ending the Generalized System of Preferences (GSP) for India, which allows duty-free imports of $5.6 billion. Ross said India's rules, such as data localisation, are discriminatory and urged cooperation to achieve a "level playing field."

images.alt_text: Any retaliatory tariff by India in response to the United States' planned withdrawal of trade privileges will not be "appropriate" under WTO rules, US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross warned on Tuesday.

site_title: Why investors love Singapore's struggling malls
summary: Investors in Singapore's struggling malls are attracted to the island's retail sector despite low spending and vacant retail space. Companies are adding new mall space, with a forecast 364,000 sq m of new retail space to hit the market this year. Despite a decline in tenant sales, real estate investment trusts (REITs) are outperforming the benchmark Straits Times Index, driven by low interest rates and a 5% dividend yield. Investors are betting on a government push to remake the city's landscape and a potential increase in plot ratios for malls, such as Starhill Global Reit.

site_title: Frencken, Jumbo among RHB's top picks for 2019
summary: RHB Securities has identified seven small- and mid-cap stocks in Singapore's technology and manufacturing sectors as top picks for 2019, including Frencken Group, which promises "potential bumper growth" despite trading below peer valuations. The company's analysts believe a resolution to the US-China trade tensions will support the sector. Frencken, a contract manufacturer, complements another listed company, Venture, with its focus on precision mechanical assembly and plastics. RHB's analysts see the sector as undervalued after a dismal 2018.

site_title: Fluid factors fiddle with upbeat outlook on oil, gold prices
summary: Oil prices appear to have fizzled out after reaching a six-month peak, with experts divided on whether the bull run has ended or still has legs. Gold prices, however, have taken a shine amid the US-China trade limbo and rising risk aversion. Experts cite factors such as rising US production and inventory gluts, and misplaced complacency over supply, as reasons for oil's stabilization. In contrast, gold prices are expected to trend higher, with forecasts ranging from US$1,380 to US$1,287 per ounce.

site_title: SoftBank sees small profit rise; all eyes on Vision Fund IPO plans
summary: SoftBank Group Corp is expected to report a small rise in fourth-quarter profit. The conglomerate is considering taking its almost $100 billion Vision Fund public through an IPO, but no formal process has been started. Shares rose 4% on Monday after trading resumed following Japan's "Golden Week" holidays. The IPO plans have investors watching closely, as SoftBank aims to monetize the Vision Fund.

site_title: US-China tensions 'threat' to world economy: IMF chief
summary: US-China trade tensions pose a threat to the world economy, according to IMF chief Christine Lagarde. The tensions, fueled by recent "rumours and tweets," make an agreement between the two countries less likely. US President Donald Trump threatened to double tariffs on Chinese exports, while French Economy Minister Bruno Le Maire warned that a trade war could accelerate global slowdown. China's top trade negotiator is set to visit the US for talks, amid a stalemate in negotiations over $360 billion in tariffs. The IMF chief and French minister urge caution and a return to "principles of transparency and multilateralism."

site_title: Japan finds parts of crashed F35 fighter jet
summary: Japan has recovered some debris from a crashed F-35 fighter jet, including a part of the flight data recorder, nearly a month after it plummeted into the sea off Japan's coast. The Defence Ministry is studying the recovered parts but still searching for the "all-important" memory that could offer clues into the accident. The jet's tail was previously found, and US and Japanese troops used data from a seabed research ship to pull up the newly discovered parts. The search for the pilot's body and the fuselage continues, with experts concerned that debris could be recovered by Russia or China.

images.alt_text: F-35A fighter aircraft from the Japan Air Self-Defense Force. Nearly a month after a high-tech F-35A plummeted into the sea off the coast of north-eastern Japan, neither the pilot's body, nor the plane's fuselage have been found.

site_title: Near-S$100m impairment on US assets pushes SingPost S$75m into red
summary: SingPost reported a net loss of S$75.1 million for the quarter ended March 31, primarily due to a nearly S$100 million impairment on its US e-commerce subsidiaries, Jagged Peak and TradeGlobal. The postal service provider expects to continue operating losses for these units until they are divested, with a sale process initiated and various parties showing interest. SingPost's underlying fourth-quarter net profit fell 6.1% to S$14.5 million, and its post and parcel business also saw weaker performance.

site_title: Singapore Kitchen Equipment explains why it's seeking HK dual listing
summary: Singapore Kitchen Equipment is seeking a dual listing in Hong Kong to fund its expansion into China. The company's board considers a Hong Kong listing "the most attractive and viable option" to raise funds and gain exposure to the markets. A fresh application was made in February, incurring costs of approximately S$1.61 million. The company plans to move upstream into manufacturing and expand into Hong Kong and mainland China markets. The decision comes despite most of its turnover coming from the Singapore business.

site_title: BMW quarterly profit tumbles 78%, hit by 1.4b euro legal provision
summary: BMW's first-quarter operating profit plummeted 78% to 589 million euros due to higher investment spending and a 1.4 billion euro legal provision related to alleged collusion in emissions filtering technology. Despite higher luxury vehicle deliveries, sales of electric and hybrid cars were underwhelming. BMW reiterated that it expects group profit before tax to be below the previous year's level, citing investments in new technologies and rising costs. The carmaker will cut engine and gearbox combinations by 50% and seek efficiency savings of over 12 billion euros by 2022.

site_title: Sheng Siong's growth story intact even as consumer sentiment weakens
summary: Sheng Siong Group, a local grocery chain, reported a 10.1% increase in revenue to S$251.44 million in its first quarter, driven by the launch of new stores and a 6% rise in net profit to S$19.36 million. Despite a 1% decline in same-store sales due to cautious consumer sentiment, the company maintained its market share of supermarket sales. Sheng Siong plans to open a second store in Kunming, China, and secure new HDB shops in Singapore, but faces potential costs and competition from online retailers.

site_title: Henkel's beauty, adhesives units weigh on first-quarter results
summary: Henkel, a German consumer goods company, reported a disappointing first quarter due to falling industrial production and underperformance in its beauty unit. The adhesives business was also affected. Henkel shares declined 2.9% in early trade. The company's earnings and sales fell short of expectations, with the beauty unit struggling in western Europe and China.

site_title: Fed issues more warnings on danger of high-risk company debt
summary: The Federal Reserve issued a financial stability report warning that high-risk company debt is increasing, with leveraged-lending issuance growing 20% last year. The report also noted that protections in loan documents are eroding. Despite unanimous approval of the report, the Fed did not indicate any course of action to rein in the market. The Fed's warnings come as firms with poor credit profiles are taking on more debt, raising concerns about the stability of the financial system.

site_title: Indonesia is chasing Asean mfg hub dream: Minister
summary: Indonesia aims to become a regional manufacturing powerhouse, rivaling Germany and South Korea, by 2025. Industry Minister Airlangga Hartarto plans to boost the manufacturing sector's contribution to 25% of the nation's economy, driven by the automotive, chemicals, and electronics industries. The government will relax labor laws, implement tax holidays, and reform regulations to attract foreign investors. President Joko Widodo's government seeks to create millions of jobs and tackle the current account deficit, with a focus on electric vehicles and petrochemical products.

site_title: Indonesia to cap foreign ownership in electronic trading platforms
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, has set a maximum foreign ownership of 49% in electronic trading platforms for foreign exchange and money markets. The new rules, effective October 31, require companies to have a minimum equity of 10 billion rupiah and a paid-up capital of 30 billion rupiah. Existing providers will have a three-year transition period to comply with the rules, which also mandate safe and reliable infrastructure, good governance, and data security. The move aims to improve market management and enhance the country's financial sector.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 6.57 points to 1,639.37, with gains outnumbering losses 555 to 309. The market saw a 3 billion lots worth RM2.2 billion in volume.

site_title: GM autonomous unit Cruise valued at US$19b in funding round
summary: General Motors' autonomous driving division Cruise raised $1.15 billion in a funding round, valuing the unit at $19 billion. The new investment comes from institutional investors and existing partners, including GM, SoftBank Vision Fund, and Honda. Cruise plans to deploy self-driving ride-hailing vehicles, with GM aiming to launch self-driving taxis this year. The company's CEO, Dan Ammann, sees the funding as a critical competitive advantage in the self-driving vehicle market, racing against rivals like Uber and Waymo.

site_title: Domino's warns of loss in international segment
summary: Domino's Pizza warned of a loss in its international segment for the year, citing disappointing performance and limited trading visibility. The company, which generates 90% of its business in the UK and Ireland, reported a 2% decline in international sales. CEO David Wild stated the company would focus on controlling costs and capital deployment in its international operations, which have struggled to break even. Shares fell 6.4% following the announcement, with analysts cutting their 2019 pretax profit forecast due to expected losses in the international segment.

site_title: Resale of older HDB flats continues upswing in face of policy tweaks: OrangeTee
summary: Resale transactions of older HDB flats in Singapore have seen an upswing, with 628 units sold in the first quarter of this year, accounting for 13.9% of total resale transactions. This is the highest percentage of older flats sold on record. The rising demand is attributed to a narrowing price gap between buyers and sellers, as well as the increasing supply of older flats, with more transactions in general due to more flats reaching their five-year minimum occupation period.

site_title: Work on China's third aircraft carrier 'under way'
summary: China is constructing its third aircraft carrier, dubbed Type 002, at the Jiangnan shipyard outside Shanghai. The ship is expected to be China's first large, modern platform capable of leading a full range of strike group operations. Satellite images obtained by the US think tank CSIS show considerable activity on the vessel, which is believed to be larger than France's Charles de Gaulle but smaller than US carriers. The third carrier is part of China's extensive military modernization drive, which aims to challenge decades of US strategic superiority in East Asia.

site_title: Officials from 3 countries meeting on approach to Goldman in 1MDB case
summary: US, Malaysian, and Singaporean law enforcement officials are meeting to discuss Goldman Sachs' role in the 1MDB scandal. The meetings, taking place near Kuala Lumpur, involve representatives from the US Department of Justice and the attorney-general offices in Malaysia and Singapore. The discussions aim to coordinate their legal approaches towards Goldman Sachs, which raised money for the scandal-plagued state fund. The outcome of the meetings is not specified.

site_title: Fashion industry's sustainability push isn't keeping up with growth
summary: The fashion industry's sustainability efforts are not keeping pace with its rapid growth, with carbon emissions exceeding those of flights and shipping combined. Despite improvements in 2018, progress slowed in 2019, with the industry's expected growth of 5% per year until 2030 posing an unprecedented strain on planetary resources. Fashion companies, from fast-fashion giants to luxury brands, have announced new sustainability commitments, but smaller, informal brands and producers remain largely untapped, accounting for 30% of the global market.

site_title: US job openings rebound in March, hiring little changed
summary: US job openings surged by 346,000 in March to 7.5 million, a seasonally adjusted 4.7% rate, while hiring remained steady at 5.7 million. The economy created 263,000 jobs in April, with the unemployment rate dropping to 3.6%. The rebound in job openings suggests a growing worker shortage, potentially slowing employment growth this year.

site_title: Medinex to buy business support services firm for S$1.2m
summary: Medinex, a Catalist-listed company, has agreed to buy SKI Group, a privately-held business support services firm, for S$1.2 million in cash. The deal, funded by Medinex's 2018 initial public offering, aims to expand the company's customer base in the IT and advertising sectors. Medinex plans to grow its business support services revenue beyond its core healthcare industry market. The acquisition is expected to improve Medinex's income and value, and the company anticipates increased revenue opportunities.

site_title: Official Thai election results may herald pro-junta government
summary: Thailand's official election results, due this week, may lead to a pro-junta government as the Palang Pracharath party, backed by the military, is expected to form a governing coalition. The election, held after five years of army rule, was inconclusive and disputed, with many small parties likely to support the pro-military group. A court ruling on the allocation of parliament seats may complicate the process, potentially delaying the government's formation and jeopardizing the May 9 deadline.

site_title: China's Luckin Coffee roasting a rich IPO
summary: Luckin Coffee plans to raise up to $590 million in its initial public offering (IPO) as it aims to overtake Starbucks, despite a net loss of $475 million in 2018. The Chinese chain has expanded rapidly from nine outlets to over 2,000 and aims to reach 4,500 stores by the end of 2019. Luckin's valuation is estimated to be around $90 billion, making it cheaper than Starbucks on a per-store basis. However, the company's subsidies and promotions will likely continue to be high, raising concerns about its long-term sustainability.

site_title: IMDA to look beyond price to draw more 5G bidders
summary: The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) in Singapore plans to assign 5G spectrum to mobile network operators (MNOs) through a Call For Proposal (CFP) process, incorporating non-price criteria such as mandatory wholesale arrangements and financial capability. The CFP will place 15% weightage on offer price, with other criteria given 40%, 30%, and 15% weightage. The move aims to encourage sustainable competition and reduce capital costs for MNOs, while also making wholesale services available to smaller players. The first tranche of spectrum will be assigned from next year, with at least two nationwide 5G networks to be rolled out.

images.alt_text: In a departure from typical spectrum rights auctions, the Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) plans to assign 5G spectrum to interested Mobile Network Operators through a Call For Proposal (CFP), with both price and non-price criteria.

site_title: Juncker regrets EU silence on Brexit campaign "lies"
summary: European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker regrets not intervening in the 2016 Brexit referendum campaign, where UK Prime Minister David Cameron's request to remain silent was a "biggest mistake" he made. Juncker claims that not addressing the "lies" spread by Brexit campaigners would have been the only way to counter them. This decision was made after Cameron asked him not to interfere in the referendum campaign, which ultimately led to the UK's vote to leave the EU.

site_title: Hong Kong exchange plans China metals expansion with warehouse plan
summary: Hong Kong's Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Ltd (HKEX) is in official talks with Guangdong authorities to launch a metals warehousing plan, a key step towards expanding its London Metal Exchange (LME) franchise in mainland China. The plan, under the Greater Bay Area project, aims to integrate Hong Kong and Guangdong economies and increase collaboration between financial institutions and physical users. HKEX plans to expand products on its Qianhai Mercantile Exchange, including aluminium ingots and copper, and may explore cross-listing or clearing products from other commodity exchanges.

site_title: Saudi Aramco set to sell extra oil to hungry Asian buyers
summary: Saudi Aramco is set to supply additional crude oil to Asian refiners, including India and China, as part of June loading shipments. The extra supplies will alleviate a squeeze driven by US sanctions on Iran and Venezuela. Aramco raised its selling price for June cargoes to the highest premium to Middle East benchmark prices in 11 months, but Asian buyers are expected to absorb the higher costs. Refiners will receive up to 200,000 barrels a day of incremental supplies, alleviating a shortage in the region.

site_title: UOB launches annual Painting of the Year competition
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has launched its annual Painting of the Year (POY) competition, a flagship art programme that aims to uncover talented South-east Asian artists. Established in 1982, the competition is open to Singapore citizens and permanent residents, with submissions accepted from August 16 to 18. The winners will be announced in November, with the Singapore winner also competing for a month-long residency at the Fukuoka Asian Art Museum in Japan. The competition highlights the bank's commitment to promoting artistic talent and fostering community bonds.

site_title: Planes, toys and tourism: What is US-China trade made of?
summary: The US and China exchanged $737.1 billion in goods and services in 2018, with China being the third-largest export market for US goods and the third-ranked buyer of US services. The US recorded a trade deficit of $378.7 billion with China, with US exports to China including jet aircraft, machinery, and medical instruments, while China imported a vast array of goods, including electrical machinery and toys. The US-China trade relationship supports over 1.1 million American jobs, but critics argue that offshoring of manufacturing has cost the US millions of jobs.

site_title: Indonesia's Mt Sinabung shoots column of smoke and ash into sky
summary: Indonesia's Mt Sinabung volcano erupted on May 7, 2019, sending a 2,000-meter column of ash and smoke into the air. The eruption, which has been ongoing since 2010, has the potential to affect flights but has not issued a formal notice. Local residents living near the crater were advised to be on alert for possible lava flows. No injuries or deaths were reported, and no evacuation order was issued. The eruption is part of a highly active period for the volcano, which has had deadly eruptions in 2016 and 2014.

site_title: Vote 'yes' for Swiber restructuring, say judicial managers
summary: Judicial managers are recommending creditors vote "yes" to Swiber Holdings' restructuring plan, which could see unsecured creditors recover 8.8-10% of their debts, with new shares worth 12.6% of the company. A rescue deal is being offered by Seaspan Corp, which could provide up to $200 million in exchange for an 80% stake in a new holding company. The creditors' meeting is scheduled for May 29, with over 1,200 creditors set to vote on the deal. Liquidation would leave unsecured creditors with nothing.

site_title: Perennial posts S$26.9m Q1 net loss on higher costs, absence of one-off gain
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings reported a net loss of S$26.9 million in its Q1 2019 results, primarily due to higher finance costs and the absence of a one-off gain. Revenue jumped 66.3% to S$24.9 million, driven by increased revenue from Capitol Singapore, Perennial International Health and Medical Hub, and higher fee income from management businesses. This marked a significant improvement from the previous year's net profit of S$5.1 million.

site_title: With low expectations, UK Conservatives and Labour resume Brexit talks
summary: UK Conservative and Labour parties resume Brexit talks, aiming to break the deadlock in parliament over the country's departure from the European Union. Despite low expectations, talks have been ongoing for over four weeks with no agreement reached. The clock is ticking down before European elections, where both parties face potential losses. The UK may be forced to participate in the elections, with the summer recess providing a possible deadline for a breakthrough. The talks have yielded little progress, with both parties expressing skepticism about a breakthrough.

site_title: Keppel O&M unit bags German offshore wind deal worth S$560m
summary: Keppel O&M's unit, Keppel FELS, has secured a S$560 million contract with TenneT Offshore to design and build converter stations for offshore wind farms in the North Sea. Keppel Corp will partner with Norwegian energy services provider Aibel on the project. The contract is part of Keppel's efforts to expand its renewable energy capabilities.

site_title: Indonesia chases manufacturing hub dream as commodities wither
summary: Indonesia plans to transform itself into a regional manufacturing powerhouse, aiming to boost exports and reduce its current account deficit. The country aims to increase the manufacturing sector's contribution to 25% of its economy by 2025, with a focus on automotive, chemicals, and electronics industries. The government will relax investment regulations, offer tax holidays, and reform labor laws to attract foreign investors and create millions of jobs. The move is part of President Joko Widodo's efforts to rejuvenate the country's struggling manufacturing sector and bolster growth, with a target of 7% annual growth.

site_title: Trek 2000 International posts 79.7% slide in Q1 net profit to US$112,000
summary: Trek 2000 International, a technology company, reported a 79.7% drop in Q1 net profit to US$112,000, down from US$552,000 in the same period last year. Revenue fell 48.9% to US$4.29 million. The company will not declare a dividend and plans to invest in research and development, business expansion, and strategic partnerships. It faces ongoing investigations by the police and bourse operator, which may impact financial statements.

site_title: KTL Global gets 2-year bank loan extension
summary: KTL Global, a MAINBOARD-LISTED offshore and marine equipment dealer, has secured a two-year extension of a S$13.9 million bank loan, extending a technical breach of financial covenants by 24 months. The company had previously disclosed it was working to get bank waivers for breaches related to certain loan facilities. Following the announcement, KTL Global added 1.2 Singapore cents or 30 per cent to 5.2 cents.

site_title: CWX Global wooed by suitor for 20% Thai oilfield stake
summary: CWX Global, a Catalist-listed investment firm, has received a non-binding expression of interest from an unnamed national oil company to buy its 20% stake in a Thai oilfield. The acquisition is subject to final due diligence and necessary approvals. CWX has not signed any agreements and there's no certainty the deal will proceed. The move comes as CWX aims to increase oil production volume and revenue through another drilling campaign in the second half of 2019.

site_title: Sri Lanka warns further Islamist militant attacks cannot be ruled out
summary: Sri Lanka's government says further Islamist militant attacks cannot be ruled out despite dismantling a major network linked to Easter Sunday bombings that killed over 250 people. Investigators are still tracking down 10 key players and have frozen assets worth $40 million. The government plans to introduce a new anti-terrorism law and has stepped up security measures. All indications point to Islamic State involvement, and investigators are looking into potential foreign help and funding.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as trade worries keep investors on sidelines
summary: US stocks opened lower on Tuesday, weighed down by renewed trade worries between the US and China. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 161.58 points, or 0.61%, to 26,276.90, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also dropped. Investors remained cautious due to the ongoing trade spat, which has kept investors on the sidelines.

site_title: Sabana Reit renews master lease worth S$3.76m with sponsor's subsidiary
summary: Sabana Reit has renewed a master lease worth S$3.76 million with Freight Links Express Logisticpark, a subsidiary of its sponsor Vibrant Group. The lease is for 33 & 35 Penjuru Lane, near Jurong Port, and has a successive option to renew for another year. The manager stated that the rent is in line with market conditions and will provide stable cash flow and revenue. The renewal was approved by Sabana Reit's audit committee and is considered on normal commercial terms.

site_title: China plans overhaul of state agriculture giants
summary: China is planning to overhaul its state agriculture giants, transferring Sinograin's trading assets to Cofco Corp. in several stages, with the goal of completing the restructuring by the end of 2020. The move aims to make Cofco China's largest soybean crusher and bring it closer to rivaling international commodity powerhouses. The overhaul is part of President Xi Jinping's drive to reform China's state-owned enterprises, and is expected to have a significant impact on global agricultural markets.

site_title: Singapore shares gain 0.7% on Tuesday after Monday's sell-off
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,312.52, up 21.90 points or 0.67% on Tuesday, reversing Monday's 3% slide. The market recovery was driven by news of Chinese Vice-Premier Liu He's upcoming visit to the US for trade talks, despite US President Donald Trump's vow to impose new tariffs. Defensives such as utilities and telecommunications led the gains, with China Everbright Water and Singtel advancing 4.8% and 1.9% respectively.

site_title: Kimly Q2 net profit drops 13.2% to S$4.73m on higher expenses
summary: Kimly, a Catalist-listed coffeeshop operator, reported a 13.2% drop in Q2 net profit to S$4.73m due to higher expenses. Revenue increased 4.7% to S$51.5m, driven by contributions from recent acquisitions, including Tonkichi and Rive Gauche.

site_title: HK dual listing best option for Singapore Kitchen Equipment, board tells Sias
summary: Singapore Kitchen Equipment's board recommends a dual listing in Hong Kong to fund expansion into China, citing it as the most attractive and viable option. The application, which would incur S$1.61 million in costs, is aimed at moving upstream into manufacturing and expanding into the Hong Kong and mainland China markets. The company had previously applied for a dual listing but had its application lapse six months earlier. Most of the company's turnover comes from the Singapore business, but the board plans to use the Hong Kong listing to gain exposure and funds for its expansion plans.

site_title: Far East Orchard Q1 earnings fall 55.4% on higher costs, drop in JV profits
summary: Far East Orchard's Q1 earnings dropped 55.4% to S$3.42 million due to higher finance costs and a sharp decline in joint-venture profits. Revenue decreased 3.4% to S$38 million, but gross profit rose 4.7%. The company's student housing business in Britain saw improved profitability. Finance costs nearly quadrupled to S$4.28 million, attributed to higher borrowings and interest rates. No dividend was recommended, and the group cited a subdued near-term outlook for private homes in Singapore.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) is reviewing virtual bank licensing for fintech firms. The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) is seeking public feedback on the 5G network rollout. Older HDB flats saw a record 13.9% of resale transactions in the first quarter, with 628 units sold. Singaporeans spent over S$1 billion on casino entrance fees. The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 0.7% on Tuesday, reversing Monday's 3% slide. Meanwhile, global news includes Vietnam's reaction to the US tariff announcement, China's slowing GDP growth, and a mid-2026 target for Citigroup's global equity index.

site_title: UAE drags Qatar to court over crisis
summary: The UAE has taken Qatar to the UN's International Court of Justice, accusing Qatar of "severely aggravating" a two-year-old crisis between the two countries. The UAE claims Qatar blocked a key website and used state-controlled news channels to hinder Abu Dhabi's efforts to obey a 2017 order protecting Qatari citizens. This is a tit-for-tat case, following a previous order by the court to protect Qatar's rights. The UAE seeks the court to stop Qatar's actions, which are seen as a breach of the previous order.

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei closes down after 10-day break
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index closed down 1.51% on its first trading day after a 10-day break, following global declines due to US President Donald Trump's threat of new tariffs on Chinese goods. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell to 21,923.72, while the Topix index dropped 1.12% to 1,599.84.

site_title: First class becoming rarer as Korean carriers nix priciest seats
summary: South Korean carriers Korean Air Lines Co. and Asiana Airlines Inc. are eliminating first-class seats on certain flights. Korean Air will stop first-class on 27 routes starting June 1, while Asiana will no longer offer first-class on all services starting Sept. 1. The carriers are shifting capacity to business class and expanding premium economy options, with Asiana's business suites being 30-40% cheaper than first-class fares. This move follows competitors like Singapore Airlines and Emirates in reducing first-class capacity in response to declining demand.

site_title: CSC Holdings guides for Q4 net loss on project cost over-runs
summary: CSC Holdings, a ground engineering company, announced a fourth-quarter net loss due to cost over-runs on a specific project. The company attributed the losses to strict requirements and difficult working conditions. Despite a strong order book of S$190 million, the counter closed up 5.26% before the announcement, with shareholders advised to exercise caution when dealing with their securities. The company will release more details in its financial statements.

site_title: No anticipated shipping date yet for Samsung Galaxy Fold
summary: Samsung Electronics has delayed the shipping date for its foldable device Galaxy Fold due to problems discovered with its display, according to the company. Pre-order customers in the US have been informed that their orders will be automatically cancelled if not shipped by May 31st. This delay comes after reviewers discovered issues with the device's display, causing Samsung to postpone global sales.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets steady after slide
summary: Europe's stock markets stabilized on Tuesday after a 1.0% decline the previous session. The FTSE 100 index shed 0.7% to 7,332.09 points, while the DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices lost 0.1% each. The declines were attributed to US President Donald Trump's threat to hike tariffs on $200 billion of Chinese goods. Despite this, mining and healthcare stocks in Europe helped prop up shares.

site_title: China says Vice Premier Liu to visit US on May 9-10 for trade talks
summary: China's Vice Premier Liu He will visit the US on May 9-10 for trade talks, despite US President Donald Trump's vow to impose new tariffs. The US has accused China of backtracking on substantial commitments, prompting Trump to raise tariffs on $200 billion worth of Chinese goods to 25% from 10%. China's Commerce Ministry confirmed the visit, saying it will signal China's seriousness in talks, while the US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer warned that Beijing's backtracking is unacceptable.

site_title: Pandora to cut 1,200 jobs as Q1 profit, sales fall
summary: Pandora will cut 1,200 jobs in Thailand as its new CEO seeks to turn around the struggling jewellery maker. The company's like-for-like quarterly sales fell 10% due to slower shopper numbers and fewer promotions. To revive the brand, Pandora will double marketing investments in Italy, the UK, and China, and use celebrities and digital influencers to boost sales. The firm's EBITDA fell 12% to 1.5 billion Danish crowns, slightly beating analyst expectations.

site_title: AEM Holdings Q1 net profit drops 19.7% to S$6.6m as key customer cuts orders
summary: AEM Holdings, a chip testing solutions provider, reported a 19.7% drop in Q1 net profit to S$6.6 million due to reduced orders from its main customer. Revenue also declined 19.7% to S$52.7 million. Earnings per share fell to 2.44 Singapore cents, down from 3.06 cents. The company's net asset value increased to 35.3 Singapore cents per share.

site_title: Full trade war could cut Asia growth by 2pp through 2020: economists
summary: A full-fledged US-China trade war could cut Asia's average GDP growth by 2 percentage points through 2020, according to Deutsche Bank economists. The potential impact would be felt across Asia, with developed economies like Hong Kong and Taiwan experiencing the largest cumulative cuts to growth rates. Other economies, such as Indonesia and the Philippines, would likely rely on monetary policy to support growth, while developed economies may provide fiscal support. The scenario is not currently considered the base case, but economists warn of significant economic risks if the trade war escalates.

site_title: UBS adds senior hires in China after taking 51% stake
summary: UBS has hired five managing directors for its investment banking business in China, bolstering its senior executive ranks after taking a 51% stake in the joint venture. Shen Dehua, previously HSBC's Qianhai securities venture head, joined UBS Securities Co as vice-chairman for Asia. The move is part of UBS' expansion in China, where regulators have allowed international firms to take majority stakes in local securities ventures. The business is expected to hire three more managing directors, bringing the total to around a dozen employees at that level.

site_title: MedAdvisor, Zuellig Pharma in JV to market medication management solutions in Asia
summary: MedAdvisor and Zuellig Pharma formed a 50:50 joint venture, ZP MedAdvisor, to market medication management solutions in Asia. The JV will initially focus on SMS-based digital adherence programs in the Philippines and Malaysia. A software licence agreement has been signed for exclusive use in eight key markets across Asia, including Singapore, Thailand, and Indonesia. The partnership aims to expand MedAdvisor's platform across the region.

site_title: Henkel beauty, adhesives units weigh on first quarter results
summary: Henkel, a German consumer goods company, reported disappointing first quarter earnings and sales due to falling industrial production in its adhesives business and underperforming beauty unit in western Europe and China. Sales rose 0.7% to €4.97 billion, while earnings per share dropped 6% to €1.34, missing analyst forecasts. The company expects organic sales growth of 2-4% in 2019, but faces challenges from high raw materials prices and declining demand in key sectors.

site_title: World's largest brewer AB InBev confirms it is looking at partial listing of Asian business
summary: AB InBev, the world's largest brewer, confirms it's looking into listing a minority stake in its Asian business, aiming to create a regional consumer goods champion. The move follows reports of banks working on a partial sale of the Asia-Pacific business. The company reported a 8.2% increase in first-quarter core profit to US$4.99 billion, below average forecast. This partial listing would allow AB InBev to focus on its core markets while Asian operations continue to grow independently.

site_title: Virtual banks cannot play one-size-fits-all in Singapore: OCBC CEO
summary: OCBC CEO Samuel Tsien stated that virtual banks in Singapore cannot operate on a one-size-fits-all model to compete in a well-banked environment. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is reviewing the feasibility of admitting digital-only banks, which have emerged from fintech firms. Tsien emphasized the need for regional aspirations in the digital model, citing Singapore's small domestic market and the presence of well-established incumbent financial institutions.

site_title: South-east Asia: Most stocks rise on hopes China will push ahead with US trade talks
summary: Southeast Asian stocks rose on Tuesday as investors awaited China's response to US tariffs and potential rate cuts. China's foreign ministry confirmed a delegation would travel to the US for talks, easing concerns. The Philippine index gained 0.7% due to a possible rate cut, while Indonesian and Malaysian shares rose 0.68% and 0.5% respectively. Singapore stocks rose 0.3% after shedding 3% on Monday, with DBS Group and Keppel Corp leading gains.

site_title: New Zealand two-year inflation expectations 2.01% for Q2: RBNZ
summary: New Zealand's two-year inflation expectations eased to 2.01% in Q2, according to the Reserve Bank of New Zealand's quarterly survey. This is a slight uptick from the previous quarter's 1.97% forecast for annual inflation. However, expectations for two-year inflation slipped to 2.02% from 2.02%.

site_title: Malaysia joins Asia easing cycle with first rate cut since 2016
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, cut its benchmark interest rate by a quarter percentage point to 3% for the first time since 2016, aiming to support the economy amid global risks. The move follows a similar trend by other Asian central banks, including India, as the US Federal Reserve slows down rate hikes. The central bank forecasts 4.3-4.8% growth this year, lower than the government's projection, and aims to preserve monetary accommodativeness to support a steady growth path amid price stability.

site_title: Airline built on Airbus planes prepares for another 'large' order
summary: IndiGo, Asia's largest budget airline, is in talks with Airbus for a large plane order, potentially exceeding $10 billion, according to CEO Ronojoy Dutta. The airline is considering adding the A321neo LR and A321 XLR to its fleet, which is expected to be finalized over the next two years. IndiGo aims to become one of the world's largest and most profitable airlines, with a market value of over $8.6 billion. The airline's aggressive expansion plans have allowed it to consistently make money despite a fierce fares war and high jet fuel prices.

site_title: Amazon casts itself as friend, not foe, of small businesses
summary: Amazon released a report during National Small Business Week, claiming it helped create 1.6 million jobs for small businesses in 2018, up from 900,000 the previous year. The company partnered with nearly 2 million small businesses, including authors, merchants, and engineers. Amazon's retail chief, Jeff Wilke, stated that the company is inspired by entrepreneurship and innovation. However, the report's message is unlikely to sway critics, including Senator Elizabeth Warren, who has promised to break up tech giants like Amazon, and California legislation that seeks to restrict consumer data use by e-commerce platforms.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.52% on Tuesday, rebounding from previous day's losses, as investors reacted positively to China's confirmation that its top negotiator will attend US trade talks. The Hang Seng Index rose to 29,363.02, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained 0.69% and 1.62%, respectively. The rally was attributed to the easing of US-China trade tensions, despite US President Trump's tariff threat.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks clawed back some of the previous day's hefty losses to end higher Tuesday as investors cheered China's confirmation that its top negotiator will attend this week's US trade talks despite Donald Trump's tariffs threat.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon at 3,304.94, up 0.44% on day
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.44% to 3,304.94 on Tuesday, driven by a bounce-back in early morning trade. The Straits Times Index gained 14.32 points, with 525.7 million securities worth S$530.8 million traded. Gainers outnumbered losers 202 to 127, led by Global Invacom Group's 12.9% surge. Active index stocks including DBS Group Holdings, United Overseas Bank, and OCBC Bank also saw gains.

site_title: Weapons tested by Kim could strike deep into South Korea
summary: North Korea launched multiple short-range projectiles into the stratosphere on Saturday, reaching altitudes of 20-60 kilometers and covering distances of 70-240 kilometers. The projectiles, believed to be ballistic missiles, could strike deep into South Korean territory, including the Seoul area and central city of Daejeon. The test may indicate North Korea's improved capabilities to strike the South, but US and South Korean officials played down the threat, keeping the door open for nuclear negotiations.

images.alt_text: A commercial satellite image, captured by Planet over the Hodo Peninsula at 10:54 am local time May 4, 2019, shows what analysts at the Middlebury Institute of International Studies at Monterey believe is the launch point and exhaust trail of a new short-range ballistic missile test in North Korea.

site_title: UK's Domino's no longer expects international business to break even in 2019
summary: Domino's Pizza Group Plc, the UK's largest pizza delivery firm, revised its expectations, no longer anticipating international business to break even in 2019. International sales fell 2% to £25.1 million (S$44.83 million) for the quarter ended March 31, due to weak sales across Europe. The company is tightening costs and expenditure for its international businesses in Norway, Sweden, and Switzerland, citing unseasonably warm and dry weather as a factor.

site_title: Australian shares end higher on iron ore miners; NZ up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% to 6,295.7, driven by gains in iron ore miners amid concerns over supply. The Reserve Bank of Australia kept interest rates unchanged, disappointing some investors. Despite this, the S&P/ASX 200 index still closed higher, following a 0.8% drop on Monday.

site_title: Islamic financing marketplace Alami bags funding led by Singapore-based tryb
summary: Islamic financing marketplace Alami has secured funding led by Singapore-based fintech investor tryb Group in a pre-seed round. The undisclosed investment will be used for product development and market expansion. Alami operates as a marketplace for Islamic financing, working with partners such as Syariah banks to facilitate invoice financing for small and medium enterprises. The company recently obtained a peer-to-peer registration and is set to expand into Syariah-compliant P2P financing.

site_title: As IPO looms, Uber clings to hard-knuckled tactics in pursuit of growth
summary: Uber is set to debut on Wall Street with a large US public stock offering, despite ongoing regulatory challenges and controversies. The company has been accused of using illicit tactics to handicap competitors and dodge regulators, and has clashed with local officials around the world over ride-hailing regulations. In Cape Town, South Africa, Uber is estimated to have 10 times more drivers operating illegally than licensed. The company has spent millions to reimburse drivers for impound fines, but the face-off with local officials may not resolve soon. Uber's sharp business tactics have raised concerns about its sustainability and growth.

site_title: Japanese government bonds gain as renewed trade worries stoke demand for safe-haven debt
summary: Japanese government bond prices rose as investors sought safe-haven debt amid renewed trade worries between the US and China. US President Donald Trump's threat to raise tariffs on Chinese goods led to a 1.5% drop in Japan's Nikkei index, while Japan's 5-year, 10-year, and 30-year government bond yields declined. The Bank of Japan's decision to trim its JGB purchases did not deter investors, as the central bank's balance sheet continues to balloon from extensive monetary easing.

site_title: BMW quarterly profit slumps on US$1.6b antitrust provision
summary: BMW's first-quarter profit plummeted 78% to €589 million due to sluggish car sales and a revised €1.6 billion provision for a potential EU fine related to alleged collusion. The company's earnings before interest and tax were impacted by pricing pressure, trade tensions, and new emissions tests. BMW has announced a €14 billion savings plan and lowered its Ebit automotive margin target to 4.5%. The stock fell 2.2% to €74, but has gained 4.7% year-to-date.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end morning slightly higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.16% to 29,257.23 on Tuesday, following a sharp sell-off the previous day, amid concerns over China-US trade talks. Investors were cautious after US President Donald Trump threatened new tariffs. Despite this, stocks in other regions, such as Singapore and Europe, continued their rallies, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records in the US.

site_title: Auto group tries to steer Colorado clear of California ZEV rules
summary: The Alliance of Automobile Manufacturers is negotiating with Colorado to avoid adopting California's zero emission vehicle (ZEV) mandate. Colorado Governor Jared Polis signed an executive order in January to adopt the mandate, which requires a rising number of electric vehicles. The auto group has offered to make all ZEVs available for sale in Colorado by January 2020 and commit to additional marketing efforts. Colorado officials have expressed a willingness to discuss an alternative program, and a hearing on the mandate is scheduled for this week.

site_title: Older HDB flats still in demand, saw record sales last year: OrangeTee & Tie
summary: Older HDB flats in Singapore saw a record 2,537 sales in 2018, with 628 sold in the first quarter of 2019, accounting for 13.9% of total resale transactions. Despite cooling measures and concerns over depreciating value, demand for older flats remains high, with sales observed across many towns and a rising market share. Analysts attribute the trend to a narrowing price expectation gap, smaller flat sizes, and increased confidence from government schemes. Resale prices are expected to stabilize, and HDB resale volume may rise as more flats reach their minimum occupation period.

site_title: Is conference room air making you dumber?
summary: A study suggests that conference room air may contribute to cognitive decline, as it tends to be warmer and stuffier than the surrounding office area. Researchers found that this environment can lead to decreased productivity and reduced mental performance. The study's findings are based on observations of office workers and suggest that maintaining a well-ventilated workspace could have a positive impact on employee performance and overall well-being.

site_title: Global Invacom wins US$6m in contracts to supply direct-to-home satellite units
summary: Global Invacom, a Malaysian subsidiary, won US$6 million contracts to supply direct-to-home satellite units to a major Asian broadcaster. The 24-month contracts will enhance high-definition satellite TV infrastructure, with equipment previously supplied by Global Invacom and its competitor. This marks the company's third contract with the client, following a 2012 agreement. The contract wins are expected to contribute to Global Invacom's financial performance for the 2019 fiscal year. The company's shares rose 11.3% following the announcement.

site_title: Australia central bank holds rates at 1.5%, signals rate cut
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia held interest rates at 1.5% in a decision that signaled a potential rate cut if the labor market improves. The move was seen as a cautious response to weak inflation and wage growth, with officials emphasizing the need for labor market improvement to achieve inflation targets. The decision was made during an election campaign, where a rate cut could have been detrimental to Prime Minister Scott Morrison's case. The Australian dollar strengthened, and the stock market fell slightly following the announcement.

site_title: China electric-car startup is said to seek US$500m in latest fundraising round
summary: Byton, a Chinese electric-car startup, is close to securing $500 million in funding from investors led by state-owned China FAW Group. The deal, which values Byton at over $2.5 billion, will be made up of $100 million in new investment and $400 million in existing shares. Byton plans to begin selling its first model, the M-Byte, in China by the end of the year, with expansion plans to North America and Europe. This latest funding round follows a previous $500 million round led by FAW last year.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall; China delegation's likely US visit spurs trade talk hopes
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index fell 0.88% to 2,176.99 on Tuesday, after recovering some losses on hopes of a Chinese delegation's visit to the US for bilateral trade talks. China's Vice-Premier Liu He will visit the US on May 9-10 for talks, which may ease US-China trade tensions. The South Korean won strengthened, while the benchmark bond yield fell, as investors remain cautious despite the positive news.

site_title: Oil shakes off tariff woes as US sends warships to Middle East
summary: US warships are being sent to the Middle East amid rising tensions with Iran, boosting oil prices above $62 a barrel. Oil futures held gains despite a planned US tariff hike on Chinese goods, which threatens global growth. The US National Security Advisor stated the deployment would send a "message" to Iran, while the White House confirmed talks with China will continue. Oil prices have recovered from recent declines, overshadowing concerns about Saudi Arabia and US drillers increasing production.

site_title: Japan's SoftBank set for small profit rise, mulling IPO of US$100b Vision Fund
summary: Japan's SoftBank Group is expected to report a 1% rise in operating profit to 156 billion yen (S$1.92 billion) for the fourth quarter, according to analysts. The company is also considering taking its nearly $100 billion Vision Fund public through an initial public offering (IPO), despite uncertainty over how to value the fund. This move could provide clarity on the fund's strategy and help underscore its approach to technology investments.

site_title: Bharti Airtel ekes out surprise profit on one-time gain
summary: Bharti Airtel reported a surprise profit of 1.1 billion rupees in the first quarter, driven by a one-time gain of 20.2 billion rupees due to a credit related to "re-assessment of levies". The profit contrasts with analysts' estimates of a 9.66 billion-rupee loss. Revenue rose 6% to 206 billion rupees. The company's pace of subscriber additions lags behind rival Reliance Jio Infocomm, which has been forcing industry consolidation. Bharti's debt stands at over US$17 billion, and it is set to spend billions on 5G airwaves in upcoming auctions.

site_title: Fashion's sustainability push isn't keeping up with rapid growth
summary: The fashion industry's efforts to reduce its environmental impact are not keeping pace with rapid growth, according to a report by BCG and sustainable fashion groups. Despite improved environmental and social impact in 2018, progress slowed in 2019. The industry is expected to grow 5% per year through 2030, with production increasing to over 100 million tons, straining planetary resources. Fashion companies have made new commitments to sustainability, but these changes are often insufficient to reduce their environmental impact. The industry must accelerate its efforts to address its growing environmental concerns.

site_title: Malaysia says US has returned US$57m in 1MDB funds
summary: Malaysia announced the US government has returned $57 million in funds recovered from 1MDB assets, the first installment under a US kleptocracy asset recovery initiative. The funds were forfeited from Hollywood film production company Red Granite Pictures, linked to Najib Razak's stepson Riza Aziz. Another $139 million is pending the sale of a Manhattan property linked to fugitive financier Jho Low. The US Department of Justice is pursuing billions in misappropriated funds from 1MDB.

site_title: Risks are receding in Canada's housing market, agency says
summary: Canada's housing market appears to be returning to balance, with the federal housing agency downgrading its assessment of vulnerabilities to "moderate" from "high." Recent rule changes, including tightened mortgage lending, have slowed home sales and prices. The Real Estate Board of Greater Vancouver reported benchmark home prices fell 8.5% in April, while sales were down 29%. The Bank of Canada Governor noted that speculation is coming out of the Toronto and Vancouver markets, but more time may be needed for it to settle.

site_title: Myanmar frees two Reuters journalists in amnesty: video
summary: Myanmar has freed two Reuters journalists, Wa Lone and Kyaw Soe Oo, who spent over 500 days in detention for reporting on the Rohingya crisis, following a presidential amnesty. The journalists were mobbed by media upon release.

site_title: Netlink Trust says service disruption around Marsiling resolved; UOB KH maintains 'buy'
summary: NetLink Trust, a fibre network operator, reported a service disruption in the Marsiling area that affected 2,000 end-users, which was resolved by Tuesday morning. The disruption was caused by a fibre cable cut by a third-party contractor. The company apologizes for the inconvenience and will continue to work with relevant parties to support affected users. Despite the incident, analysts from UOB KH maintained a "buy" rating on NetLink Trust, citing its defensive earnings, stable cash flow, and potential benefits from TPG's mobile coverage plan.

site_title: Federal Reserve's Kaplan says rates in right place but keeping an open mind
summary: US Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas President Robert Kaplan stated that US interest rates are in the right place, despite weak inflation, and doesn't plan to lower the Fed funds rate to address it. Kaplan noted that overall inflation pressures in the US will remain muted, with some pressures being cyclical and others structural. He also warned that trade tensions between the US and China are having a chilling effect on businesses, particularly in the Asian garment industry, but not significantly impacting US GDP growth at this point.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks slip more than 1% on US-China trade tensions
summary: South Korean stocks fell 1.02% on Tuesday due to US-China trade tensions and North Korea's "strike drill" testing. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) dropped 22.39 points to 2,173.93 points. Foreigners bought 144.2 billion won worth of shares, while shares of companies exposed to North Korea fell, while defence firms rose. The KOSPI has risen 6.51% this year, and the benchmark bond yield fell.

site_title: The best restaurant in the US is in Philadelphia
summary: Zahav, a Philadelphia restaurant, won the title of outstanding restaurant at the 2019 James Beard Foundation awards. Frenchette in New York took the Best New Restaurant award, while Ashley Christensen of Poole's Diner in Raleigh, N.C., was named America's outstanding chef. Co-owner Michael Solomonov previously won outstanding chef in 2017, and pastry chef Camille Cogswell won rising star last year. This win solidifies Philadelphia's dominance in the US food world, with Zahav considered a front-runner for the title.

site_title: Yorkshine Q1 loss widens to US$4m on suspension of business
summary: Yorkshine Holdings reported a widened net loss of US$4.0 million in its Q1 fiscal 2019, with a loss per share of 2.08 US cents, compared to a US$1.3 million loss and 0.67 US cent LPS in the prior year. The company recorded US$1.3 million in revenue, down from none in the prior year period. No dividend was declared.

site_title: IMDA seeks public feedback on 5G network rollout
summary: Singapore's Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) has launched a public consultation on the implementation of 5G regulatory frameworks and policies ahead of the planned 2020 rollout. The consultation seeks views on spectrum allocation, baseline regulatory requirements, and innovative use cases for 5G networks. IMDA plans to assign 5G spectrum through a call for proposals, with the goal of supporting at least two nationwide 5G networks. The public consultation closes on June 19.

site_title: Singapore additive manufacturing cluster ties up with global network
summary: Singapore's National Additive Manufacturing Innovation Cluster (Namic) has partnered with Berlin-based Mobility goes Additive (MgA) to identify suitable parts for additive manufacturing in various sectors. The collaboration aims to facilitate tie-ups between AM players globally. The partnership will allow Singaporean SMEs to tap into plug-and-play solutions from MgA's 99 network members, including Siemens and TÜV SÜD. This move is expected to drive the adoption of additive manufacturing technologies in Singapore, leveraging the country's manufacturing base and talent in the AM ecosystem.

site_title: French president announces moves to protect biodiversity
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron announced initiatives to protect biodiversity and the environment, following a landmark UN report on the state of the natural world. A million species are at risk of extinction due to relentless plundering and pollution, and Macron championed a series of green initiatives, including reducing chemical pesticide use by 50% by 2025 and increasing protected areas to 30% by 2022. He also plans to review fiscal aid to advance these objectives and combat food waste, aiming to profoundly change models in schools, restaurants, and retailers.

site_title: US to impose tariffs on Mexican tomatoes as new pact remains elusive
summary: The US will impose a 17.5% tariff on Mexican tomato imports starting Tuesday, as a 2013 agreement suspending an anti-dumping investigation expired. The US Commerce Department had given a 90-day notice before terminating the six-year-old agreement, which US growers and lawmakers say has failed. This move comes amid ongoing trade tensions between the US and Mexico, with no new pact in place to replace the expired agreement.

site_title: Armed robbery of Johannesburg bankers spurs security-guard boom
summary: Armed robbery in Johannesburg has prompted a security-guard boom as lenders step up measures to protect staff after the closure of a major highway diverted traffic through the city's central business district. Businesses and city officials have implemented measures such as increased security personnel, shuttle services, and satellite offices to combat crime. Despite initial concerns, crime levels have decreased significantly since the measures were implemented. The Johannesburg Metropolitan Police Department reports a decline in aggravated robbery cases, with the central police station seeing a drop in incidents since the highway closure.

site_title: Xinjiang surveillance app targets legal, everyday behaviour: rights group
summary: China's Xinjiang region is using a mass surveillance app to profile and detain Muslims, labeling "completely lawful" behavior as suspicious. The app, connected to the Integrated Joint Operations Platform (IJOP), tracks 36 categories of behavior, including not socializing with neighbors or using a smartphone. Human Rights Watch found that the system uses illegally gathered information to investigate and detain people, with reports of detentions for installing foreign messaging apps like WhatsApp. The app prompts officials to file reports and send "investigative missions" to follow up, raising concerns about the erosion of human rights in the region.

site_title: Whataburger explores options including a stake sale -sources
summary: Whataburger, a privately held US fast-food chain, is exploring options including selling a minority stake to a financial investor or private equity firm. The company, with over 820 locations and $2 billion in sales, could fetch a valuation of over $6 billion. Whataburger has hired Morgan Stanley to manage the process, which could help the founding family take cash out of the business without losing control. A stake sale could also provide the company with additional capital for investments in technology and delivery.

site_title: Philippines' annual inflation slows to 3% in April
summary: Philippines' annual inflation slowed to 3.0% in April, matching the median forecast and bolstering the view that the central bank will start unwinding policy tightening. This comes as the central bank aims to keep inflation within its 2-4% target this year. The slower inflation rate may lead to interest rate cuts, providing a boost to the economy.

site_title: Australia Q1 retail sales worst in near 7 years, rate cut bets alive
summary: Australian retailers posted their weakest Q1 sales in 7 years, with a 0.3% rise in March, beating forecasts. The decline in volumes, led by household goods retailing, suggests consumers are re-thinking spending decisions amid falling home prices. This weak result supports calls for a near-term rate cut from the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA), with 40% of economists expecting a cut to an all-time low of 1.25%. The RBA's decision is due on Tuesday.

site_title: Rio Tinto to buy autonomous mining truck fleet from Caterpillar
