summary: Rio Tinto has agreed to purchase a fleet of 20 autonomous 793F trucks and four autonomous blast drills from Caterpillar for its new Koodaideri iron ore mine in Western Australia. The mine, valued at $2.6 billion, is expected to start production by the end of 2021 and will sustain Rio's current iron ore output of over 330 million tonnes per year.

site_title: Myanmar to release 6,520 prisoners in amnesty on Tuesday: president
summary: Myanmar President Win Myint announced an amnesty, scheduled for Tuesday, to release 6,520 prisoners. This follows two mass amnesties last month. The move is customary around the traditional New Year, which began on April 17. The release does not clarify the fate of two jailed Reuters reporters, Wa Lone and Kyaw Soe Oo, who were convicted in September and sentenced to seven years in jail.

site_title: US dollar holds tight ranges, US-China trade talks in focus
summary: The US dollar remained relatively stable against major peers, holding near a five-week low against the yen, due to ongoing US-China trade tensions. The White House announced China had moved away from trade-related commitments, prompting a decline in US bond yields and stock futures. The US dollar index was unchanged at 97.53, while the yen was a shade lower at 110.685 yen. Investors await Australian retail sales data and a Reserve Bank of Australia rate decision for trading cues, with economists expecting a rate hold at 1.50%.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks open with gains
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks rose in the opening minutes of trade on May 7, 2019, despite the previous day's sharp losses. The Hang Seng Index gained 0.36% to 29,313.58, while the Shanghai Composite Index added 0.27% to 2,914.29. Investors remained cautious due to US President Donald Trump's threat to hike tariffs on Chinese imports.

site_title: China iron ore rallies as Vale holds reopen at Brucutu mine
summary: China's iron ore futures rose 4% on Tuesday due to concerns over tight supply, following Vale's halt in production resumption at its Brucutu mine. The Brazilian miner now expects 2019 sales of 307-332 million tonnes, down from its previous guidance. Global iron ore supply is expected to reduce 9.3 million tonnes, partly offset by increased supply in China, India, and Russia. China's central bank also cut reserve requirement ratios to boost the economy, improving market sentiment amid escalating trade tensions.

site_title: US risks emboldening Kim Jong Un with muted response to missile test
summary: North Korea's recent missile launch, which included a short-range ballistic missile, has sparked concerns that the US and South Korea's muted response may embolden Kim Jong Un's regime. The launch, which was the first since November 2017, was seen as a test of President Trump's limits in stalled nuclear talks. Experts warn that the lack of a strong response from the US and South Korea may be perceived as a green light for further provocations, potentially escalating tensions in the region.

site_title: Singaporeans spend over S$1b in casino entrance fees
summary: Singaporeans have spent over S$1.3 billion in entrance fees to its two casinos since 2010, despite higher levies that were introduced to deter locals from gambling. The levies, now S$150 per day or S$3,000 per year, have not stopped rich Singaporeans and those feeling lucky from visiting the casinos. Minister for Manpower Josephine Teo stated this in response to a question in parliament, highlighting the continued popularity of the casinos among local residents.

site_title: Protester throws egg at Australian prime minister
summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison was grazed in the head with an egg by a protester at an election campaign event in Albury, New South Wales. The female protester, wearing casual clothes, was swiftly dragged away by security guards. Morrison briefly rubbed his head and helped an elderly woman who was pushed to the floor. The protester claimed her action "speaks for itself" and referenced Manus Island, where Australia has detained refugees. The incident occurred in a constituency where an independent candidate is favored by rural voters.

site_title: MAS studying virtual bank licensing regime for fintech firms
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is studying the possibility of licensing digital-only banks, also known as virtual banks, that have emerged from fintech firms. This comes as Singapore's banking market is well-served by local and foreign banks offering a full suite of services. MAS aims to understand the unique value these entrants could bring and how potential risks will be managed and contained. The regulator has been engaging stakeholders to inform its decision, which could potentially lead to the introduction of new players in the Singaporean banking landscape.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand: Miners drive Australian shares higher; NZ climbs
summary: Australian shares rose 0.7% on Tuesday, driven by gains among iron ore miners following a court-ordered halt in operations at a Vale mine in Brazil. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 6,329.3, while New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.6%. Iron ore miners BHP, Rio Tinto, and Fortescue Metals advanced 1.5%, 2.7%, and 5.9%, respectively. Investors await the Reserve Bank of Australia's interest rate decision, with a slim majority expecting a rate cut to support the economy.

site_title: Money manager who called China rally triples his allocation in cash
summary: A money manager, Nader Naeimi, has tripled his cash allocation to 40% of his US$1 billion fund, shifting away from Chinese stocks after US President Trump threatened increased tariffs on China, seen as a turning point for overvalued markets. The Shanghai Composite Index sank 5.6% and the S&P 500 fell 1.6% after Trump's tweet. Naeimi now plans to short US technology giants and reduce emerging-market equities, citing crowded markets as vulnerable.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 6.03 points to 1,626.77. Volume was 50.54 million lots worth RM17.03 million. Gainers beat losers 119 to 44.

site_title: A Starbucks in Winterfell? 'Game of Thrones' coffee cup blunder spreads like wildfire
summary: A Starbucks coffee cup briefly appeared on screen during the latest episode of Game of Thrones, sparking widespread ridicule and memes. The cup was seen sitting on a table at Winterfell, amidst candlelit chandeliers and medieval decor. The show's production team initially failed to address the mistake, fueling speculation that it was a deliberate inclusion. However, HBO later acknowledged the error, stating that the cup was a mistake and Daenerys had ordered an herbal tea. The incident has become a lighthearted moment in the show's final season.

site_title: Veggie burger mania hits corporate America after Beyond Meat IPO
summary: Corporate America is shifting towards vegetarian meat products following the successful IPO of Beyond Meat. Food companies like Tyson Foods, McDonald's, Burger King, and Whole Foods are rushing to introduce meatless protein products. The trend is driven by consumer demand for healthier, more sustainable options, with millennials playing a key role. Companies are investing in plant innovation, with Bloomberg Intelligence predicting increased spending on plant-based meat substitutes. However, experts warn of the risk of a bubble, with some companies struggling to replicate the success of Beyond Meat.

site_title: A chef of modern Southern cuisine wins top US prize
summary: Chef Ashley Christensen, 42, was named the top US chef by the James Beard Foundation for her modern Southern cuisine at Poole's Diner in Raleigh, North Carolina. Christensen is the seventh woman to receive the honor, which recognizes her use of local, seasonal ingredients and French cooking techniques. The James Beard Foundation also awarded top restaurant honors to Philadelphia's Zahav and New York's Frenchette, as well as outstanding pastry chef and rising star chef awards to Kelly Fields and Kwame Onwuachi, respectively.

site_title: China sets yuan mid-point at fresh low in two and a half months
summary: China's central bank lowered its official yuan midpoint to 6.7614 per dollar, a fresh low in two and a half months, due to sharp losses in the spot yuan following US President Donald Trump's tariff threats. The move weakened the currency by 0.4% and was the largest one-day weakening since February 11. The weakening yuan reflects the growing pressure on policymakers as China's GDP growth is set to slow, raising concerns about the country's economic stability.

site_title: Brazil expects to collect at least US$47b in signing bonuses from oil auctions: official
summary: Brazil expects to collect at least $47 billion in signing bonuses from three upcoming offshore oil auctions, set for October and November. The auctions are expected to draw $27 billion from the first sale and $20 billion from the second sale. This is part of Brazil's national energy policy council's plan to set guidelines for the refining sector, following the state-controlled Petroleo Brasileiro SA's plan to sell eight refineries for $20 billion.

site_title: Healthway Medical warns of Q1 loss on refurbishment of clinics
summary: Healthway Medical Corporation expects to record a loss for the first quarter of fiscal 2019 due to reduced operating hours in clinics undergoing refurbishment works. As of now, around 31 clinics have been refurbished, with completion expected by the second quarter. The group will announce its unaudited financial results on or before May 15.

site_title: Scientists develop device to detect bacteria in minutes, not days
summary: Scientists at Penn State University have developed a device that can detect bacteria in minutes, reducing the time it takes for lab results from days to 30 minutes. The device uses microtechnology to trap and view individual bacteria cells, allowing clinicians to determine if bacteria is present and its susceptibility to treatment. The device can also classify the type of bacteria and determine if a strain is resistant to antibiotics. The team hopes to scale down the device for hospital and office use within three years, aiming to improve patient care by rapidly ruling out or confirming bacterial infections.

site_title: CWX Global calls for trading halt after posting Q3 profit on Friday
summary: CWX Global, a CATALIST-listed company with a minority stake in Thai oil concessions, has called for a trading halt after reporting a net profit of US$211,000 in its Q3 earnings. This is a significant increase from the year-ago period, with shares closing unchanged at S$0.002 on Monday. The profit was attributed to an income tax credit reported on Friday.

site_title: SingPost sinks to S$75.1m Q4 loss on impairment charges for US units
summary: SingPost reported a net loss of S$75.1 million for its fiscal fourth-quarter, reversing from a net profit of S$31.8 million in the same period last year. The loss was attributed to impairment charges for two loss-making US e-commerce businesses up for sale. This resulted in a loss per share of 3.50 Singapore cents, compared to earnings per share of 1.24 Singapore cents previously.

site_title: GIC-backed Luckin Coffee seeks to raise up to US$510m in US IPO
summary: Luckin Coffee Inc, backed by Singapore's GIC, is seeking up to $510 million in its US IPO, aiming to raise $30 million in shares priced between $15 to $17 each. The company, which has 2,370 stores in 28 cities, aims to become China's largest coffee network by the end of the year. Luckin faces stiff competition from Starbucks, which dominates the market with over 50% share. The company plans to invest in discounts and convenience, and has a partnership with Tencent Holdings.

site_title: Mexican president's new airport flies into turbulence
summary: Mexico's President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador inaugurated work on a new airport in Mexico City, despite concerns over its feasibility due to the city's mountainous terrain. The new airport, Felipe Angeles, is expected to cost around $4 billion and will be built on a military air base. Aviation experts warn that operating two airports in the same area will be a logistical nightmare, with limited routes for take-off and landing. The project faces significant challenges, including a partially blocked flight path due to a 240-meter-tall hill and concerns over air traffic safety.

site_title: Investors still love Singapore's struggling malls
summary: Despite Singapore's struggling malls, investors remain optimistic about the sector. The city-state has a large retail space, but vacant rates are still low at 8.7%. Reits, which own malls, are outperforming the benchmark Straits Times Index, driven by low interest rates and a 5% dividend yield. Companies are adding new retail space, but investors see potential in changes to the city's landscape, such as the conversion of office buildings to homes and hotels. A 29% increase in plot ratio for certain malls is also expected to boost their value.

site_title: Australia: Shares likely to open higher; New Zealand up
summary: Australian shares are expected to open higher on Tuesday, following a Wall Street recovery and investors' hopes for a China-US trade deal. The Reserve Bank of Australia is set to announce its rate decision, with a slim majority of economists predicting a rate hold. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.1% in early trade.

site_title: Pepsi to invest US$4b in Mexico in 2019-2020
summary: PepsiCo Inc plans to invest US$4 billion in Mexico between 2019 and 2020 with partner Grupo Gepp, creating around 3,000 new jobs. The investment will include a US$109 million new plant in Guanajuato, expected to operate at full capacity by 2025.

site_title: Singapore shares on Tuesday open higher after Monday's rout; STI up 0.27% to 3,299.47
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 8.85 points, or 0.27%, to 3,299.47 on Tuesday, rebounding from a 3% decline on Monday. The index gained 76 to 36 in gains to losses, with active stocks including UOB, DBS, and ComfortDelGro. The rally followed a global stocks rout on Monday, triggered by US President Donald Trump's pledge to raise tariffs on Chinese goods, but some investors expressed confidence in an eventual trade agreement.

site_title: Hong Kong stock exchange in official talks for metals warehousing in China: CEO
summary: Hong Kong's stock exchange is in official talks with Guangdong authorities to establish metals warehousing in mainland China, a step towards expanding its London Metal Exchange franchise. CEO Charles Li has long sought a China foothold, despite initial reluctance from Chinese regulators. Li stated that the process is challenging, but the exchange is working on a pilot scheme with the Guandong government. This move aims to capitalize on China's position as the world's largest metals consumer.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei opens down after 10-day break
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index opened down 0.65% on its first trading day after a 10-day break, following global declines amid US President Donald Trump's threat of new tariffs on Chinese goods. The benchmark index fell to 22,113.31, while the Topix index dropped 0.42%. The move follows a recent 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a record-breaking close for the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq.

site_title: Oil mixed, caught between US sanctions on Iran, Venezuela and trade dispute with China
summary: Oil prices were mixed on Tuesday, influenced by US sanctions on Iran and Venezuela, as well as concerns over the Sino-US trade dispute. US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose to $62.29 per barrel, while Brent crude oil futures fell to $71.16 per barrel. The mixed market sentiment was attributed to the ongoing tensions, which could impact global oil demand and supply.

images.alt_text: Oil prices were mixed on Tuesday as US sanctions on oil exporters Iran and Venezuela kept markets on edge while concerns that an escalating Sino-US trade dispute could slow the global economy also kept crude somewhat in check.

site_title: Brazil government could decree high revenue for Roraima electric line: sources
summary: Brazil's government is considering a decree that would guarantee high revenues for the operator of a proposed electricity transmission line to the state of Roraima, allowing it to move forward despite regulatory delays. The line is needed to connect Roraima to Brazil's grid, which has been supplied by Venezuela due to the country's economic collapse. The government's declaration of the project as "of national interest" allows for some approvals to be fast-tracked, and a decree would ensure the companies involved remain interested in the project, with annual revenues estimated at 396 million reais.

site_title: Ex-Goldman Sachs banker Roger Ng pleads not guilty to 1MDB charges
summary: Roger Ng, a former Goldman Sachs banker, pleaded not guilty to US charges related to the 1MDB scandal, a multibillion-dollar Malaysian state investment fund case. Ng faces up to 30 years in prison if convicted and is currently out on a $20 million bond. He was extradited from Malaysia and is cooperating with prosecutors in a potential plea deal. Ng's lawyer says his client became ill while in Malaysian jail and was released to avoid further deterioration. The case has also implicated Goldman Sachs, which is being probed by the Justice Department for its role in the scandal.

site_title: Private jet crashes in Mexico, 13 feared dead
summary: A private jet carrying 13 people crashed in a mountainous area of northern Mexico, with no survivors. The Bombardier Challenger 601 jet lost contact with air-traffic controllers while flying from Las Vegas to Monterrey. Authorities believe bad weather may have contributed to the crash, which occurred over the state of Coahuila. The wreckage was found in a difficult-to-access area, with only the wings and tail remaining intact. The victims are believed to be mostly passengers returning from a boxing match in Las Vegas.

site_title: Trump awards Tiger Woods Medal of Freedom, calling him a 'legend'
summary: US President Donald Trump awarded Tiger Woods the Presidential Medal of Freedom at the White House, calling him a "true legend" and a "global symbol of American excellence." This honor comes after Woods' 2019 Masters Tournament win, his 15th major title. Trump has maintained a close relationship with Woods despite personal scandals, and the two have played golf together multiple times. This award is the latest in a series of honors Trump has bestowed on athletes, including Roger Staubach and Babe Ruth.

site_title: US says China backtracked on commitments in trade deal: reports
summary: US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer accused China of backtracking on commitments in trade negotiations, prompting a planned tariff increase on $200 billion in Chinese goods to 25%. The US has been locked in a year-long trade war with China, affecting $360 billion in two-way trade. Despite US officials saying talks are 90% complete, Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin reported a "substantial backward" shift in talks. The US will impose tariffs on the remaining $350 billion in Chinese goods, with President Trump vowing to ratchet up existing tariffs.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Chip Eng Seng, BreadTalk, Koufu, Sunningdale Tech, CSE Global
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Four Singapore-listed companies reported significant earnings growth in the first quarter: Chip Eng Seng Corp nearly doubled its earnings to S$11.3 million, BreadTalk Group posted an 11.5% increase to S$1.32 million, Koufu Group saw a 12.3% rise to S$7 million, and CSE Global's net profit improved by 0.5% to S$5.7 million. In contrast, Sunningdale Tech's earnings plummeted 59.1% to S$793,000 due to a shrinking profit margin. The results were announced on Monday and Tuesday, with shares of the companies adjusting before the news was released.

site_title: Bernie Madoff's wife agrees to pay victims US$600,000 to settle lawsuit
summary: Bernie Madoff's wife, Ruth, agreed to pay US$600,000 to settle a decade-long lawsuit by trustee Irving Picard, who claimed she profited from her husband's US$20 billion Ponzi scheme. Ruth will pay an upfront US$250,000 and transfer US$344,000 from her grandchildren's accounts. She also agreed to cooperate with the Securities Investor Protection Corp. and transfer her remaining assets to a fund for victims after her death. The settlement resolves a lawsuit accusing Ruth of receiving US$44 million in phony profit.

site_title: Five dead, 233 arrested in Venezuela protests: Attorney General
summary: Venezuela protests turned violent, resulting in five deaths and 233 arrests, according to Attorney General Tarek William Saab. The protests were sparked by a failed military uprising against President Nicolas Maduro, with opposition leader Juan Guaido blaming the failure on unkept promises by other military members. Maduro has vowed to pursue "traitors" after the military reaffirmed its loyalty to him. Key opposition figure Leopoldo Lopez was re-arrested and has sought refuge in the Spanish ambassador's residence.

site_title: Anadarko backs Occidental's revised US$38b bid, pressuring Chevron to respond
summary: Anadarko Petroleum's board backs Occidental's revised $38 billion bid, increasing pressure on Chevron to respond. Occidental's new proposal offers 78% cash and 22% stock, removing a stock exchange requirement. Anadarko intends to terminate its Chevron merger agreement, paying a $1 billion termination fee. Chevron has four days to decide whether to alter its agreement or make a new bid. Occidental's move comes after increasing its cash pledge to $18.8 billion, avoiding a shareholder vote.

site_title: US Treasury will not hand over Trump tax returns to Congress: official
summary: The US Treasury will not hand over President Donald Trump's tax returns to Congress, defying a demand from the House Committee on Ways and Means. US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin stated that the request "lacks a legitimate purpose" and therefore, the Treasury is not authorized to release Trump's tax filings.

site_title: Bharti Airtel plans to kick off IPO of US$5b Africa phone unit
summary: Bharti Airtel, India's second-largest wireless carrier, plans to launch an initial public offering (IPO) of its Africa unit, which could raise about $1 billion. The IPO, expected to start trading in June, aims to value the unit at around $5 billion. This would be one of the largest IPOs in London this year, boosting domestic volumes. The Africa unit has operations in 14 markets, including Kenya, Tanzania, and Nigeria, and has received $1.25 billion in funding from investors last year.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall in wake of Trump threat of China tariffs
summary: European stocks plummeted 0.9% on Monday after US President Donald Trump announced plans to increase tariffs on Chinese goods, sparking concerns of retaliation from China. The move wiped out about 15.6% of the year's gains for the pan-European Stoxx 600 index. Auto-makers, chipmakers, and energy stocks were particularly hard hit, with some falling as much as 5.7% and 2.4%. The uncertainty has raised concerns about the ongoing trade war and its impact on global markets.

site_title: 7.2-magnitude quake hits Papua New Guinea, no early damage reports
summary: A 7.2-magnitude earthquake struck Papua New Guinea on May 6, 2019, at a depth of 127km, with no immediate reports of damage. The quake, 33km from Bulolo, was felt 250km away in Port Moresby. Due to its depth, there is no tsunami threat. The country's rugged highlands have experienced similar quakes in the past, including a 7.5-magnitude quake in February 2018 that killed at least 125 people. Assessments of the current quake are pending.

site_title: Risks rise as US warns Iran with aircraft carrier
summary: The US has deployed an aircraft carrier strike group to the Middle East amid heightened tensions with Iran, amid a report that Tehran would scale back its nuclear deal commitments. US Acting Defense Secretary Patrick Shanahan approved the deployment in response to "indications of a credible threat" from Iranian regime forces. Iran's Supreme National Security Council dismissed the move as a "clumsy use of an out-of-date event for psychological warfare." The deployment comes as frustration mounts in Iran over the lack of dividends from the nuclear accord.

site_title: British royal birth fires up baby name betting
summary: Prince Harry and Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, are set to reveal the name of their new baby later this week. Bookmakers' favorites for the name include "James", "Arthur", "Philip", and "Albert", reflecting traditional royal naming conventions. The couple typically chooses names from a restricted pool of those used by past royals.

site_title: US court grants stay in PDVSA US$182m debt cases due to Venezuela 'political situation'
summary: A US court granted a 120-day stay in two lawsuits against Venezuela's state-run oil company PDVSA due to the country's "political situation". The suits, brought by Red Tree Investments for US$182 million, will delay proceedings in New York courts. The ruling may set a precedent for other suits against PDVSA and the Venezuelan government, which have defaulted on US$8 billion in debt. The move was requested by Venezuelan opposition leader Juan Guaido, who has been recognized as the country's rightful leader by the US and most Western countries.

site_title: Federal Reserve sounds warning on high stock prices, corporate debt load
summary: The Federal Reserve warned of risks to the financial system due to high stock prices and corporate debt loads. Elevated stock prices, relative to expected earnings, have kept the market above its 30-year average, but conditions have eased somewhat. Corporate debt has grown faster than the economy, with the riskiest firms bearing the brunt. Trade tensions, particularly the US-China trade war, remain a concern, but worries about emerging markets have lessened. The Fed deemed major banks and insurance companies healthy and unlikely to face a crash crunch.

site_title: Trump's approval hits highest rating ever in Gallup poll
summary: US President Donald Trump's job approval rating reached its highest ever at 46% in a Gallup poll, following the release of special counsel Robert Mueller's report and positive economic news. The approval rating increased one point from 39% in early March, while disapproval remained at 50%. The poll was conducted before several significant events, including Mueller's complaints about Attorney General Bill Barr's summary of the investigation's findings and Barr's refusal to testify before a House panel. Trump's approval rating is still underwater, but the positive economic news and initial interpretation of the Mueller report contributed to the increase.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. The US stock market opened lower due to President Trump's new tariffs on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall in H2 and operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow Airport is considering higher fees for its £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS executive, is set to become OCBC's new CEO. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) will deepen cooperation on green and transition finance.

site_title: Democrats launch contempt action against US attorney general
summary: US House Democrats have scheduled a vote to hold Attorney General Bill Barr in contempt for failing to produce a full, unredacted special counsel's report on Russian election interference. The move comes after Barr missed a 9am deadline to comply with a subpoena. Democrats are seeking to enforce the subpoena and access the full report, which they claim shows improper conduct by President Donald Trump. The contempt action intensifies the showdown between Trump and Democrats controlling the House of Representatives.

site_title: Laurel Tree, Sycamore Tree dispute with buyers a private matter: URA
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has stated that the ongoing negotiations between the receivers and buyers of the unfinished Laurel Tree and Sycamore Tree residential projects are a private matter. The projects' project accounts, where buyers' payments are meant to be safeguarded, are empty. The Controller of Housing is examining the project accounts to check for statutory breaches, and buyers may have contractual rights against the developer for the delay in completion.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Coffee with Claressa: Dr Chua Chong Bing
summary: Dr. Chua Chong Bing, a renowned expert, discusses various topics on the "Coffee with Claressa" podcast, including corporate purpose, financial literacy, and zero-waste living. The conversation also touches on her experiences and insights in mod-Indian cuisine. The podcast aims to engage listeners and encourage feedback on BT's products and services. Dr. Chua's expertise and perspectives provide valuable information for viewers, promoting a better understanding of corporate purpose and its impact on society.

site_title: HSBC Singapore hires ex-OCBC exec for newly created trade finance role
summary: HSBC Singapore has hired Tze Tze Lee as head of product and propositions for its global trade and receivables finance team in Singapore. Lee joins from OCBC, where she was head of product management, trade finance since 2016. The move comes as HSBC aims to strengthen its regional coverage and increase market share. Lee's knowledge of the Singapore and regional trade finance market is seen as invaluable at a time of new challenges and opportunities for global trade.

site_title: Oil bounces up on Iran concern after touching 1-month low on trade tensions
summary: US oil futures rose after Iran concern, rebounding from a one-month low, following US President Donald Trump's threat to raise tariffs on Chinese goods. Brent crude futures rose 39 cents to $71.24 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 31 cents to $62.25 a barrel. The US is deploying a carrier strike group to the Middle East, citing a "credible threat" from Iran, and Trump reversed his decision to keep tariffs at 10% due to trade talks progress.

site_title: Russian plane makes fiery emergency landing, 41 dead
summary: A Russian passenger jet, Aeroflot Flight 1492, made an emergency landing at Moscow's Sheremetyevo airport, resulting in 41 deaths. The Sukhoi SSJ-100 plane caught fire after landing, with flames spreading on the runway and pavement. The cause of the crash is under investigation, but it's the second fatal incident involving the Sukhoi Superjet, following a 2012 crash in Indonesia that killed all 45 people on board. The incident highlights ongoing safety concerns with the aircraft.

site_title: Isetan to give up Westgate Mall store
summary: Isetan Singapore will not renew its lease for its Westgate Mall store, citing the store's "loss-making" status. The lease expires on December 22, and Isetan is exploring alternative options for the space. The company's decision is part of its ongoing efforts to realign and consolidate operations. Isetan operates five stores in Singapore, including the Westgate outlet, and has a market cap of around S$128 million.

site_title: Turning a condo into an experience
summary: Luxury real estate developers in New York are hosting experiential events in unsold condos to draw attention to their listings. This new marketing approach is a response to the high-end housing market shifting in favor of buyers. Events may include chef-curated dinner parties, designer shopping events, or exclusive previews of luxury brands. The goal is to create an immersive experience that showcases the property's unique features and builds a brand for the building. This approach is seen as a strategic way to differentiate listings in a crowded market, where buyers have numerous choices and are no longer limited to specific neighborhoods.

site_title: Ikea to invest 400m euros in French city centre stores
summary: IKEA plans to invest 400 million euros in France over the next three years, focusing on city centre stores. This transformation aims to cater to consumers who prefer online shopping and in-store pickup. The investment is part of a broader effort to overhaul the company's business model, led by CEO Jesper Brodin since 2017. France is IKEA's third-largest market, with around 10,000 employees and sales of 2.83 billion euros in the 2017/18 fiscal year.

site_title: China cuts reserve ratio following latest Trump move
summary: China's central bank announced a targeted reserve requirement ratio (RRR) cut of 2.5 percentage points for 1,000 rural commercial banks, effective May 15, releasing 280 billion yuan (S$57 billion) in liquidity to support small and medium-sized companies. The move comes amid escalating US-China trade tensions, with US President Donald Trump raising tariffs on $200 billion of goods. The cut is the smallest since January 2018 and aims to help lower funding costs for small and micro firms.

site_title: US: Wall Street falls as White House plans to raise China tariffs
summary: US stocks fell on Monday after President Donald Trump pledged to raise tariffs on Chinese goods, citing China's failure to meet commitments in trade negotiations. The S&P 500 dropped 1.6% and the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.25%. Despite some investors seeing Trump's comments as a bargaining tactic, the market was weighed down by concerns of a global slowdown. Materials, industrials, and technology shares were particularly affected. The US Trade Representative and Treasury Secretary recommended a 25% tariff increase on $200 billion worth of Chinese goods if a trade agreement is not reached by Friday.

site_title: STI dives 3% on worsening trade war fears
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 3% to 3,290.62 on Monday, its third decline of 3% or more in the last five years, due to US President Donald Trump's announcement of planned tariff hikes. Investors fled the market as trade war escalation fears intensified, with bank stocks leading the decline. Senior Minister Chee Hong Tat announced Resorts World Sentosa's plan to intensify land use and buy new land.

site_title: Occidental seeks edge over Chevron with more cash
summary: Occidental Petroleum Corp has increased its bid to acquire Anadarko Petroleum Corp to 78% cash, offering $38 billion. The move comes after French energy giant Total SA agreed to buy operations in four African nations for $8.8 billion, contingent on Occidental completing a takeover of Anadarko. Occidental CEO Vicki Hollub pledged to cover the $1 billion breakup fee, addressing concerns about debt. Anadarko has reaffirmed its existing recommendation to shareholders to accept the Chevron deal, but the revised offer may sway Anadarko's decision.

site_title: Big Tobacco's latest ploy - push vaping aggressively and get them young
summary: The tobacco industry, specifically Big Tobacco, is aggressively promoting vaping products to young people, exploiting the same tactics used to market cigarettes decades ago. Vaping rates among high school students have risen by nearly 80% since 2017, despite a decline in teenage cigarette smoking rates. Tobacco companies like Altria, Reynolds American, and Imperial Tobacco own major vaping brands, including Juul, which has more nicotine in its "pods" than a pack of cigarettes. The FDA has warned manufacturers to keep their products away from underage users, but tobacco companies have largely ignored the ultimatum, instead using loopholes to market vaping products to adults.

site_title: Facebook removes more pages tied to Russian operators
summary: Facebook has removed more pages, groups, and accounts originating from Russia, accused of deceptive behavior, including creating networks of fake accounts to mislead others about their identity and intentions. The takedown, part of an ongoing battle against "coordinated inauthentic behavior," focused on Ukraine, with 97 Facebook accounts, pages, or groups removed. The campaign used fake accounts, impersonation, and amplified false allegations about public figures, with only one dollar spent on a Facebook ad. The removed accounts posted content on local and political news, military conflict, and Russian politics, without disclosing the identities of those behind the accounts.

site_title: Brexit saga has wilted confidence in democracy
summary: Former UK Conservative leader Ian Duncan Smith has called for Prime Minister Theresa May to resign immediately after the party lost over 1,200 council seats in local elections. The Tories face a difficult European Parliament election on May 23, which could lead to a leadership contest ending May's premiership. The Brexit saga has eroded confidence in democracy, and politicians must renew efforts to engage with constituents. Trust in politics is already at historic lows, and the failure to deliver key decisions on issues like pensions, housing, and migration has the potential to undermine confidence in the democratic process.

site_title: Trump tariff threat sends yuan reeling; sterling falls
summary: US President Donald Trump threatened to raise tariffs on $200 billion of Chinese goods, triggering a significant drop in the Chinese yuan and other currencies, including the Mexican peso and Turkish lira. The yuan fell almost 1% to its lowest levels this year, while sterling declined half a percent. Investors weigh the potential impact of higher tariffs on the US economy and expect a possible interest rate cut by the US Federal Reserve. The selloff also affected European equities, with a gauge of European equities falling nearly 2%.

site_title: Secure connectivity the new growth strategy for SMEs
summary: Singapore's Small and Medium-sized Enterprises (SMEs) face significant cybersecurity concerns, with three in five admitting to data breaches over a 12-month period. Despite high awareness of government support, SMEs are slow to adopt cyber protection measures. To address this, the government aims to empower lean IT teams through automation and affordable cloud solutions. Flexible managed service options offer pay-as-you-go solutions, ideal for SMEs, and could help them compete in an increasingly digital economy.

site_title: Gold gains as Trump's tariff threat unnerves global markets
summary: US President Donald Trump's threat to raise tariffs on Chinese goods led to a surge in gold prices, with spot gold up 0.2% at US$1,281.91 per ounce. Global markets experienced risk-off sentiment, driving demand for safe-haven assets. The escalation of Sino-US trade tensions prompted investors to seek refuge in gold, boosting its value.

site_title: Australia's Treasury Wines wins case against 'copycat' for imitating Penfolds brand in China
summary: Australia's Treasury Wine Estates Ltd, the world's largest standalone winemaker, has won a lawsuit against "copycat" Rush Rich for imitating its Penfolds brand in China. The Federal Court ordered Rush Rich to cease using the Penfolds name and pay over A$375,000 in compensation. This is not the first time Treasury has protected its IP rights, having won a similar case in China in 2017. The win is seen as a significant victory for the company in protecting its brand in the lucrative Chinese market.

site_title: Philippine consumer stocks may disappoint market with Q1 results
summary: Philippine consumer stocks may disappoint investors with Q1 results, as expected earnings growth recovery from slowing inflation and election spending boost may not materialize. Despite a 8.4% year-to-date gain, analysts predict a muted sales growth and margin recovery, with some major consumer names, such as Jollibee and Puregold, warning of a slow recovery from inflation's impact. This may lead to a breather in the rally and potential disappointment for investors.

site_title: HK's surging weekend property sales show rebound underway
summary: Hong Kong's property market is showing signs of a rebound, with 1,220 new units sold over the weekend, the most in six years. Used home sales also surged, with HK$40 billion in transactions in April, the most in over eight years. This is attributed to the stock market's gains and low interest rates. Home prices have climbed for three months, regaining 10% of lost value since August's record level. Experts believe the positive sentiment is sustainable, driven by limited supply in the secondary market. A potential peak in the third quarter is forecasted.

site_title: Options for buyers when developers go bust and projects are unfinished
summary: A Singapore developer has gone bust, leaving two unfinished residential projects with 183 buyers. United Overseas Bank (UOB) will drop premium top-up requirements for Sycamore Tree development in exchange for buyers waiving liquidated damages, which are typically 10% per annum of progress payments. Buyers would still receive the benefit of money paid into the project account and only need to pay the remaining purchase price. Alternatively, UOB can sell the land and repay its outstanding loans, but this would likely leave buyers with no damages.

site_title: Singapore may allow virtual banks after Hong Kong, DBS says
summary: DBS CEO Piyush Gupta suggests Singapore may grant virtual banking licenses, following Hong Kong's lead. He downplays the potential impact on existing lenders, stating there's "no reason why" it wouldn't happen. This move could create more competition for established banks like DBS, Citigroup, and financial technology startups.

site_title: Aik Moh's digitalisation lifeline
summary: Aik Moh Paints and Chemicals, a Singapore-based SME, transformed from a small paint reseller to a leading petrochemical company over 40 years. In 2019, they won the SME Digital Leap Awards for developing their own software, OASIS, to digitalize operations and manage processes. Initially met with skepticism, the company implemented the system gradually, allowing workers to adapt and improving efficiency. Today, OASIS manages production schedules, formulation, and quality control, enabling Aik Moh to expand operations globally, with plans to enhance its capabilities further.

images.alt_text: Roy Tan, GM of Aik Moh Paints and Chemicals, has seen his efforts in digitalising the company's processes pay off. In 2019, Aik Moh was named overall winner at the SME Digital Leap Awards.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: StarHub Ltd's Q1 2019 results fell 14.2% year-over-year to S$54 million, with a 27.7% full-year forecast. The company added 74,000 post-paid subscribers but saw a drop in average revenue per user to S$39. Management is negotiating a variable Pay TV cost model and plans to explore cyber security opportunities. Despite a 16.8% decline in stock price since a downgrade, the analyst maintains a fair value of S$1.64 for now.

site_title: Fake mews?
summary: A Siamese cat was presented to Thailand's newly crowned King Maha Vajiralongkorn and his queen as part of a royal coronation ceremony, sparking confusion over whether the cat was real or a doll. According to a palace official, the ceremony used a "cat doll" instead of a live cat, but the authenticity of the photo remains unclear. The tradition of presenting a cat at royal coronations dates back centuries, symbolizing a stable home and good luck.

images.alt_text: Royal officials placing a rooster and a cat next to the bed of Thailand's King Maha Vajiralongkorn at the ceremony of Assumption of the Royal Residence on May 4.

site_title: Avengers: Endgame blasts past Titanic to be second-biggest movie of all time
summary: Avengers: Endgame continued its record-breaking box office run, earning US$145 million at the North American box office in its second weekend, bringing its worldwide total to US$2.188 billion. The Marvel film surpassed Avatar's record to become the second-biggest movie of all time. Endgame also generated US$619 million domestically and US$1.56 billion internationally, with repeat viewings and premium formats contributing to its extraordinary box office receipts.

site_title: Rules of the game - in sports as in anything else - cannot be arbitrary
summary: The Court of Arbitration for Sports (CAS) ruled that the International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) decision to require female athletes with "differences of sexual development" (DSD) to take medication or switch events is discriminatory but necessary to protect "the integrity of female athletics". The decision affects athletes like Caster Semenya and Francine Niyonsaba, who must artificially limit their testosterone levels to compete. The ruling raises concerns about the complexity of gender and the potential for reversal or changes as new evidence emerges, leaving affected athletes with limited time to compete.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng Corp cautious despite Q1 profit almost doubling
summary: Chip Eng Seng Corp reported a 83.8% increase in Q1 net profit to S$11.3 million, driven by property development and hospitality growth. Revenue rose 34.2% to S$267.3 million, despite a 10.3% decline in construction revenue. The company plans to exercise caution in bids for new projects, citing keen competition for Housing and Development Board contracts. It also announced plans to launch the Changi Garden project and grow its education operations.

site_title: Trump's new tariff threat deals body blow to equities
summary: US President Donald Trump's new tariff threat on $200 billion of Chinese goods sparked a sharp sell-off in Asian markets, with China's Shanghai Composite Index down 5.58% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index falling 2.9%. European markets also retreated, with the DAX 30 in Germany dipping 1.3%. Analysts recommend profit-taking as the bull run may pause, citing rich valuations and uncertainties from the trade war. Some experts expect the market to rebound, while others warn of potential economic slowdowns.

site_title: Thai king makes maiden speech to his people
summary: Thailand's newly-crowned King Maha Vajiralongkorn delivered his first public speech to his people, addressing tens of thousands of supporters gathered at the Grand Palace. The monarch expressed gratitude for the unity and goodwill shown by the public during his coronation, which was marked by an opulent and costly three-day event. The speech was attended by junta chief Prayuth Chan-ocha, who pledged loyalty to the new king and the Chakri dynasty. The event concluded the coronation rituals, which aimed to solidify the king's position as the head of state.

site_title: Property, finance veteran Lim Hua Tiong is first CEO of Frasers Property Vietnam
summary: Frasers Property Vietnam appointed Lim Hua Tiong as its first CEO, based in Ho Chi Minh City, with nearly 20 years of experience in the Vietnamese real estate market. He will report to Panote Sirivadhanabhakdi, group CEO of Frasers Property.

images.alt_text: Mr Lim will be based in Ho Chi Minh City, and will report to Panote Sirivadhanabhakdi, group chief executive officer of Frasers Property.

site_title: Trump vows tariff hike on Chinese goods, escalating tensions
summary: US President Donald Trump announced a significant escalation in trade tensions with China, increasing tariffs on $200 billion worth of Chinese goods to 25% and targeting hundreds of billions more. The move, made in response to China's alleged withdrawal from trade commitments, has sent global markets into a tailspin, with stocks and oil prices plummeting. China is reportedly considering cancelling this week's trade talks, and the White House declined to comment on whether the talks will proceed. The move is seen as a major shift in tone from Trump's recent statements, which had cited progress in trade talks, and has drawn rare bipartisan support from US Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer.

site_title: IBM-backed project offers Wi-Fi network for natural disasters
summary: IBM-backed Project Owl, a team of young computer nerds, has developed a Wi-Fi network using tiny electronic nodes in rubber casings to connect victims and first responders in natural disasters. The network, spanning over 259 sq km, was tested in Puerto Rico after Hurricane Maria and proved successful. The team aims to deploy the network in the US East Coast for hurricane season, with the goal of providing a simple and low-cost solution to save lives during disasters.

site_title: EU to start formal probe on Spotify's Apple complaint
summary: The European Union will launch a formal probe into Apple Inc. following Spotify's antitrust complaint, which claimed that Apple's 30% cut of revenue was a tax on competitors. Spotify accused Apple of unfairly favoring its own services over third-party music streaming platforms. The EU's antitrust agency will investigate the matter, which comes as Apple expands into new business areas that compete with third-party services on its platform.

site_title: Despite public outcry and fines, facebook doesn't budge
summary: Facebook has revealed a $3 billion war chest for potential fines related to its privacy violations, yet its revenue figures have increased 26% for the first quarter of 2019, boosting its stock by 9%. Despite CEO Mark Zuckerberg's efforts to reduce disinformation, Facebook outsources fact-checking to local contractors, weakening its ability to control operations. Economists argue that this outsourcing is a sign that Facebook prioritizes growth over public trust, a strategy that has led to scandals and regulatory issues. The company's focus on user growth and profits over public concerns has led to criticism, with experts warning that Internet companies must prioritize public trust to survive.

site_title: House judiciary committee to vote Wednesday to hold Barr in contempt
summary: The House Judiciary Committee plans to vote Wednesday to hold Attorney General William Barr in contempt of Congress, following the Justice Department's failure to deliver Robert Mueller's full report and key evidence by Monday's deadline. The committee's chairman, Rep. Jerrold Nadler, recommended that Barr be found in contempt due to his refusal to comply with a congressional subpoena. A contempt finding would mark Barr's record and push the dispute into the courts, potentially affecting the pace and scope of Democratic investigations.

site_title: Indonesia Q1 GDP growth misses forecast as investment cools
summary: Indonesia's Q1 GDP growth fell short of expectations at 5.07%, the slowest pace in a year, due to cooling investment and softening commodity prices. Household consumption also lost momentum. Despite missing forecasts, economists believe the data is "pretty good" considering external pressures. Bank Indonesia is expected to resist cutting interest rates, citing pressures on the trade balance and rupiah. Analysts expect the current account deficit to shrink this year, and some argue that Bank Indonesia has room to unwind interest rate hikes to support economic growth.

site_title: SP Group charity golf raises S$688,888
summary: SP Group's annual charity golf tournament raised S$688,888, supporting 15,000 seniors from disadvantaged backgrounds through programmes under Community Chest. The event, attended by a record number of business partners, aimed to raise funds for the community.

images.alt_text: From left: Mohd Hassan Marican, chairman of SP Group; Amos Tan, managing director of DBS Bank; Benjamin Tessier, head of Structured Solutions APEC, Credit Agricole; Quek Poh Huat, senior advisor of SP Group.

site_title: Property development a drag on OKP as Q1 earnings plunge 62.4%
summary: OKP Holdings' Q1 earnings plummeted 62.4% to S$1.07 million, primarily due to a drag from property development ventures. Revenue declined 16.8% to S$19.2 million, despite gains from rental income from a Perth office tower. The construction order book stands at S$291.6 million, with a healthy pipeline of projects until 2023. No dividend was declared, and the company's net asset value rose to 39.89 Singapore cents per share. OKP Holdings' shares closed flat at S$0.23.

site_title: Vibrant's S$227.5 million Jurong Island deal to be completed on May 10
summary: Vibrant Group's sale-and-leaseback deal for a Jurong Island warehouse facility has been confirmed, with buyer SGRE Banyan exercising its call option for S$227.5 million. The deal is expected to be completed on May 10, marking the first sale-and-leaseback transaction on Jurong Island. Vibrant Group's shares fell 0.6 cents, or 4.38%, to S$0.131 following the announcement.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: The Western Australian Supreme Court dismissed AusGroup subsidiary AGC Industries' claims of A$21.7 million in withheld payments from Karara Mining for work done at the Karara iron ore project. AusGroup is reviewing the judgment for possible grounds of appeal. Meanwhile, other companies reported varying financial results, including Koufu Group's 12.3% net profit increase, OUE Hospitality Trust's planned merger, and Sunningdale Tech's 59.1% year-on-year net profit decline.

site_title: BNP Paribas claims US$57.7m from Hyflux for Magtaa performance bond
summary: BNP Paribas has demanded US$57.7 million from Hyflux for a performance bond related to the Magtaa desalination plant in Algeria. Hyflux disputes the claim, citing a previous dispute between Hyflux and associate company Tahlyat Myah Magtaa (TMM). The demand is expected to impact Hyflux's financial performance, which has been under a court-sanctioned debt moratorium for over a year. Hyflux is taking legal action and has filed an injunction application against the performance bond issuer.

site_title: Garage takes BT's brand of hard-nosed journalism to startups
summary: The Business Times has launched Garage, a portal providing news and analysis on Singapore's startup ecosystem. The vertical brings the publication's investor-focused perspective to startup coverage, aiming to help readers understand disruption, identify value, and cut through hype. Garage features regular columns, including "The Pitch" on early-stage startups, "The Thesis" on investment rationale, and "Starting Point" on industry trends and developments. The launch coincides with growing interest in private markets, particularly in South-east Asia, where local startups raised $10.5 billion in financing deals in 2018.

site_title: Google set to launch privacy tools to limit online tracking - WSJ
summary: Google is set to launch a dashboard-like function in its Chrome browser to give users more control over tracking cookies, aiming to fend off advertisers. The tool will help users limit third-party cookies, but not Google's own data collection. This move comes after Facebook's data scandal and follows similar actions by Apple and Mozilla. The new feature is expected to press Google's advantage in the online advertising market, where it is the world's largest seller of internet ads.

site_title: Land costs to expand IRs: S$1.3b for MBS, S$1b for RWS
summary: Singapore's two integrated resorts (IRs), Marina Bay Sands and Resorts World Sentosa, will pay fair market value for their land when expanding, with costs of S$1.3 billion and S$1 billion, respectively. The government will also charge additional costs for bigger gaming areas. The IRs' expansion is expected to attract half a million more international visitors and contribute S$500 million to Singapore's GDP annually. The government will work with the IRs to implement technology measures to combat problem gambling, while maintaining the annual entry levy to discourage compulsive gambling.

site_title: UOB launches online utility marketplace
summary: UOB launches an online utility marketplace featuring 10 providers, allowing customers to search and sign up for deals on electricity, gas, water, broadband, and TV services. The platform aims to provide a one-stop-shop for customers to compare and switch providers, amid increased competition among local banks. The move is seen as a strategic effort by UOB to strengthen its presence in customers' lifestyles.

site_title: Scientists warn a million species at risk of extinction
summary: Scientists warn that one million animal and plant species are at risk of extinction due to human activities, citing industrial farming, fishing, and climate change as major drivers of the crisis. The report, compiled by the Intergovernmental Panel on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services, found that the current rate of species extinction is tens to hundreds of times higher than the average over the last 10 million years. Governments and businesses are urged to act now to save the Earth's ecosystems, or risk losing many threatened species, including the dodo, in the coming decades.

site_title: Marriott's home-sharing lacks a disruptive edge
summary: Marriott International's home-sharing venture, Homes & Villas by Marriott International, lacks a disruptive edge by borrowing Airbnb's model of renting out luxury homes. The venture may limit potential scale, as it focuses on premium properties and may cannibalize hotel room bookings. The company's strategy may also struggle with quality control and standardization, as home rentals differ from hotel rooms. Despite potential savings from centralized booking and payment, the venture's upside is likely limited due to competition from established players like Airbnb.

site_title: Telenor, Axiata in talks on creating Asian mobile giant
summary: Telenor ASA and Axiata Group Bhd, Malaysia's largest wireless carrier, are in talks to combine their Asian telecommunication operations in a "mega merger of equals" to create a company with 300 million customers in nine countries. The proposed transaction would form an entity with US$13 billion in sales and US$5.5 billion in earnings, and potential savings of US$5 billion. Telenor would own 56.5% of the new company, while Axiata would own the remainder. A final agreement is sought by the third quarter, with the aim of listing the company on an international exchange and in Malaysia.

images.alt_text: The proposed transaction will form an entity with sales of about US$13 billion and earnings of about US$5.5 billion.

site_title: Boeing left airlines, FAA in the dark on alert linked to 737 Max crashes
summary: Boeing knew about a faulty cockpit alert linked to the 737 Max crashes as early as May 2017, but didn't share the information with airlines or the FAA until after the Lion Air crash in October 2018. The alert, which warned of conflicting sensor data, was only available to customers who purchased an optional indicator. The FAA deemed the issue "low risk" but criticized Boeing for not communicating the issue earlier, which could have reduced confusion. Boeing plans to issue a software update to fix the issue before the plane returns to service.

site_title: Race to replace Draghi spurs ECB calls for Fed-style rethink
summary: A European Central Bank (ECB) review of its strategy to ensure price stability has sparked calls for a rethink, with contender Olli Rehn suggesting a post-Fed-style approach. Rehn's idea, short on specifics, has raised his profile among hopefuls for the ECB president post, but could also backfire by splitting policymakers and alarming leaders. The ECB has not dived into its policy framework in 16 years, with inflation persistently falling short of the goal of "below, but close to, 2 per cent." A potential outcome of the review is a revamped mandate, potentially including ideas like allowing inflation to temporarily overshoot.

site_title: Trump slams China on trade, says won't lose to Beijing
summary: US President Donald Trump slammed China over its trade practices, vowing to protect American commerce. He announced plans to hike tariffs on $200 billion of Chinese imports, escalating a dispute marked by tit-for-tat duties. Global stock markets plummeted in response. Trump cited a growing trade deficit between the US and China, stating, "Sorry, we're not going to be doing that anymore!" The move comes as ongoing talks between the two countries were set to continue this week.

site_title: United Engineers converts S$333m debt to green loan for private property development
summary: United Engineers has converted a S$333 million loan into a green loan for a residential property development in Singapore. The project, which will feature about 450 units, aims to achieve energy efficiency and water conservation through initiatives such as energy-efficient air conditioning and lighting, and sustainable building systems. The green features are expected to bring annual energy and water savings, and the company believes in operating in an environmentally responsible manner.

site_title: Sunningdale Tech Q1 profit down by 59.1% on lower revenue, margin woes
summary: Sunningdale Tech's Q1 profit plummeted 59.1% to S$793,000, driven by lower revenue and margin woes, particularly in its automotive operations. Group revenue slipped 5.6% to S$159.5 million. The company attributed the decline to weaker demand, delays in project launches, and end-of-life projects. Despite this, CEO Khoo Boo Hor expects margin pressures to ease in the coming quarters.

site_title: The choice facing Democratic voters
summary: The torch is being passed from the Baby Boomer generation to the Silent Generation, which includes presidential contenders Joe Biden and Bernie Sanders. The Boomers, who dominated the national agenda from 1993 to 2021, are characterized by their focus on personal scandals and their inability to work across party lines. In contrast, the Silent Generation is marked by their respect for traditional values, pragmatism, and a willingness to work with others. The transition to a new generation may bring a fresh perspective to Washington, potentially leading to a more collaborative and effective government.

site_title: GKE Corp to invest 48m yuan to build China cement plant
summary: GKE Corp, a logistics solutions company, will invest 48 million yuan (S$9.7 million) to construct a ready-mix cement plant in Cenxi City, China. The investment is through its wholly owned subsidiary, Wuzhou Xing Jian Readymix Co. The construction agreement was entered into on April 25, 2019. This move aims to expand Wuzhou's manufacturing and supply capabilities in the Chinese market.

site_title: Latest worry: Inflation not rising fast enough
summary: The US economy is experiencing a low inflation rate, with the consumer price index (CPI) increasing 1.9% and the personal consumption expenditures (PCE) deflator at 1.5% over the past year. Despite criticism from President Trump, many economists worry that inflation is too low, citing the potential for deflation, which can lead to prolonged economic downturns and increased debt defaults. However, some argue that a moderate level of inflation is necessary to stimulate economic growth and that the Federal Reserve's current inflation target of 2% is sufficient.

site_title: HKEX to launch US dollar-denominated mini contracts for base metals
summary: The Hong Kong Futures Exchange (HKEX) plans to launch US dollar-denominated mini contracts for six base metals, including copper, aluminium, zinc, lead, nickel, and tin, in the coming months. The contracts, which reference LME prices, aim to broaden access to LME-priced contracts for retail investors. This move comes after a similar product failed to gain traction on the Singapore Exchange five years ago. The new contracts are undergoing regulatory approval and are expected to be launched in the near future, with the hope of gaining support from LME members.

site_title: KKR helping Lee family finance S$0.90-a-share offer for 800 Super
summary: The Lee family, owners of 800 Super, has made a conditional offer of S$0.90 per share for the Catalist-listed rubbish collection firm, valuing the company at S$161 million. The offer remains unchanged and does not include plans to increase the price. If the offer turns unconditional, KKR will issue fixed rate bonds and convertible preference shares for subscription by its funds.

site_title: Prince Harry and Meghan welcome a boy
summary: Prince Harry and Meghan, the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, welcomed a baby boy on May 6, 2019, at Frogmore Cottage. The baby, named Baby Sussex, is seventh in line of the throne and Queen Elizabeth II's eighth great-grandchild. Meghan, a California native, remains a US citizen, potentially allowing the child to hold dual nationality. A name will be announced soon, and the couple is celebrating privately before sharing the news with the public.

site_title: BlueChilli launches healthtech accelerator for South-east Asia
summary: BlueChilli, an Australian startup accelerator, has partnered with Enterprise Singapore to launch a Singapore-based healthtech accelerator. The program aims to identify and support early-stage healthtech startups in South-east Asia. Selected founders will gain access to technology development services, training, seed funding, and a global network of advisers and mentors. The program's establishment is part of BlueChilli's vision to build a regional hub for healthtech talent and expand its operations to five countries by 2020.

site_title: Ex-Goldman banker to face 1MDB charges in US
summary: Former Goldman Sachs banker Roger Ng, who helped raise billions for 1MDB, has been temporarily extradited to the US for 10 months to face charges linked to a multi-billion-dollar scandal. Ng faces charges of laundering funds and violating the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. He will return to Malaysia after the US case is concluded. Goldman Sachs is under scrutiny for its role in 1MDB bond sales, with the US Department of Justice estimating $4.5 billion was misappropriated between 2009 and 2014. Ng was charged in Malaysia with providing misleading statements and in the US with conspiring to launder 1MDB funds.

site_title: US: Wall Street slumps at open as trade worries return
summary: US stocks plummeted at the open on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 1.30% to 26,160.62, the S&P 500 dropping 1.25% to 2,908.89, and the Nasdaq Composite falling 2.23% to 7,981.85. President Trump's surprise threat to hike tariffs on Chinese goods reignited fears of a global slowdown, overshadowing a period of relative calm in markets. Despite this, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records.

site_title: Volkswagen sounds out buyers for MAN Energy Solutions - sources
summary: Volkswagen has approached several companies to gauge interest in buying MAN Energy Solutions, a diesel engine manufacturer for ships and power generators. The company, valued at around 3 billion euros, is part of Volkswagen's efforts to slim down and simplify its 12 brands. Informal sales pitches have been made to rivals like Cummins and Wartsila, and a formal sale process may be launched later this year if interest is strong. The sale could attract interest from Mitsubishi Heavy, Alfa Laval, and private equity groups.

site_title: Sinclair CEO sees possible deals with Amazon and others seeking live sports
summary: Sinclair Broadcast Group Inc's CEO Chris Ripley said the company may consider deals with Amazon and other tech giants to offer live sports, following the acquisition of Disney's regional sports networks for $9.6 billion. Ripley believes live sports will remain a profitable business due to its scarcity, and the company views this as an opportunity to expand its distribution and capitalize on the new US sports betting market. Sinclair plans to allow viewers to place bets during live games and partner with sportsbook operators, but not become a bookie itself.

site_title: Sapphire Corp Q1 net profit falls 16.6% on interest costs and lower revenue
summary: Sapphire Corp, a Chinese infrastructure player, reported a 16.6% decline in Q1 net profit to 3.39 million yuan due to higher finance costs and lower revenue. Revenue fell 2.2% to 297 million yuan, mainly due to lower sales of railway sleepers. The company attributed higher rent and grants to offset the decline, but finance costs surged 51% to 5.75 million yuan. Sapphire Corp plans a two-pronged growth strategy focusing on engineering and construction, as well as environmental conservation and water projects.

site_title: Thai King praises 'unity' in speech on final coronation day
summary: Thailand's newly-crowned King Maha Vajiralongkorn praised a show of "unity" in his first public address on the final day of his coronation, speaking to a sea of supporters. The king, who ascended the throne in late 2016, expressed his "truly happy" with the display and urged all sides to perform their duties for the prosperity of the country. The coronation, the first in 69 years, cemented the king's position at the top of Thailand's richest monarchy, with thousands waving the national flag and wearing yellow hats.

site_title: American shoppers to feel effects of Trump's tariff grenade
summary: US President Donald Trump has threatened to double import levies on $200 billion of Chinese goods to 25%, further escalating the trade war. This move will affect consumer goods such as Nike sneakers, Apple iPhones, and household items at Walmart and Lowe's. The tariffs will also impact sporting goods, bicycles, and golf equipment. The American Apparel & Footwear Association estimates that a family of four will pay at least $500 more a year on apparel and footwear. The move is expected to increase prices for a range of consumer goods, potentially hurting American consumers and US jobs.

site_title: BreadTalk Group's Q1 net profit up by 11.5% as portfolio grows
summary: BreadTalk Group posted a 11.5% increase in Q1 net profit to S$1.32 million, driven by growth across its business divisions. Revenue rose 6.1% to S$157.6 million, attributed to improved central kitchen and procurement efficiency. The company expanded its portfolio through acquisitions, including a stake in Thailand's NPPG, and opened new stores in Beijing and Bangkok. BreadTalk expects organic growth and plans to strengthen its presence in key markets, develop its talent, and open more Din Tai Fung and Song Fa Bak Kut Teh outlets.

site_title: Crossborder payments startup Thunes bags US$10m in Series A funds from GGV Capital
summary: Thunes, a cross-border payments network for emerging economies, has secured US$10 million in Series A funding from GGV Capital. The startup plans to improve its service and platform, expand into Africa, Asia, and Latin America, and open offices in San Francisco, Dubai, and Paris. Thunes' network interconnects financial institutions and digital service providers, enabling fast and secure fund transfers to over 80 countries with more than 9,000 payout partners. The funding will also be used to build strategic partnerships and deliver alternative payment solutions.

site_title: Russia says it won't ground Sukhoi plane despite fatal crash-landing
summary: Russia's transport minister, Yevgeny Ditrikh, stated that there are no grounds to ground the domestically-produced Sukhoi Superjet 100 aircraft following a fatal crash-landing in Moscow that killed 41 people. Despite the incident, investigators are exploring various reasons, including technical failure, human error, and bad weather conditions. The plane had been serviced as recently as April and Aeroflot has a good safety record. An online petition demanding a ban on the Superjet has been signed by over 4,000 people.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 4.5 points lower at 1,632.80 on Monday, with 791 losers outweighing 149 gainers. The market saw 2.8 billion lots worth RM1.7 billion traded.

site_title: HSBC Singapore hires former OCBC executive for newly created trade finance role
summary: HSBC Singapore has hired Tze Tze Lee, former head of product management, trade finance at OCBC Bank, as the head of product and propositions for the bank's global trade and receivables finance team in Singapore. Lee joined HSBC on April 29, marking a newly created role announced in October 2018. The hire aims to strengthen the bank's regional coverage from Singapore, which plans to increase its headcount by over 10% over three years. Lee's knowledge of the Singapore and regional trade finance market will be valuable in addressing the challenges and opportunities in the trade environment.

site_title: US says deeply concerned by Turkey's intent to drill off Cyprus
summary: The US is deeply concerned by Turkey's intentions to begin offshore drilling operations in an area claimed by Cyprus as its exclusive economic zone. Turkey has issued a permit for drilling in overlapping claims with the internationally recognized Greek Cypriot government, likely to stoke tensions with Cyprus and Greece. The region is thought to be rich in natural gas, with both countries seeking to exploit its resources.

site_title: CSE Global posts 0.5% rise in Q1 profit to S$5.7 million
summary: CSE Global, a mainboard-listed company dealing in oil and gas and telecommunications, reported a 0.5% year-on-year increase in net profit to S$5.7 million for the first quarter of 2019. Despite a 7.4% decline in revenue to S$85.4 million, the company attributed the improvement to increased margins. The group expects full-year improvement in its financial performance, driven by rising activity and stable pricing.

site_title: Abe: Agree with Trump that N Korea must denuclearise
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said he and US President Donald Trump agree that North Korea must promptly denuclearize. Abe stated that he and Trump have a "singular understanding" on responding to North Korea, with the US and Japan working together. This comes after North Korea fired unidentified projectiles into the sea off its east coast, prompting South Korea to urge the communist neighbor to stop escalating military tensions.

images.alt_text: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said on Monday he and US President Donald Trump agreed completely on the need for North Korea to promptly denuclearise.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng nearly doubles Q1 profit, to S$11.3 million, on condo projects, hotels
summary: Chip Eng Seng Corp nearly doubled its Q1 profit to S$11.3 million, driven by condo projects, hotels, and increased revenue from Grandeur Park Residences and the Mercure hotel in Adelaide. Revenue swelled 34.2% year-over-year to S$267.3 million, with the hospitality division seeing a 19.7% growth. The group's construction segment saw a 10.3% decline in turnover, while property investments remained stable. The company plans to expand into education and exercise caution in bidding for new projects amid a slowdown in property sales.

site_title: Singapore integrated resorts expansion land costs: S$1.3b for MBS, S$1b for RWS
summary: Singapore's two integrated resorts, Marina Bay Sands and Resorts World Sentosa, have allocated S$1.3 billion and S$1 billion respectively for expansion land costs. The government has stated that the IRs will pay fair market value for their land, with the option to expand gaming areas at an additional cost. The expansion plans aim to attract 500,000 more international visitors annually and contribute S$500 million to the country's GDP. The government is working with the IRs to implement technology measures to prevent problem gambling.

site_title: Indonesia intervened to defend rupiah - official
summary: Indonesia's central bank intervened to defend the rupiah against the dollar amid US-China trade tensions, with the currency weakening to 14,330 per dollar earlier on Monday. The rupiah traded 0.5% lower than the previous session at 14,320. Bank Indonesia's head of monetary management, Nanang Hendarsah, attributed the weakening to fresh tensions and noted that a GDP reading above 5% was "pretty solid".

site_title: Innopac Holdings faces winding-up summons from creditor
summary: MAINBOARD-LISTED Innopac Holdings received a winding-up summons from creditor CBK Holdings for almost S$214,000 in loan principal and interest. The summons was filed on April 24 with a hearing set for May 17. Despite this, Innopac's board stated that the company's operations are not expected to be significantly impacted.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's integrated resorts expansion plans have been announced, with Marina Bay Sands' expansion costing S$1.3 billion and Resorts World Sentosa setting aside S$1 billion. The Lee family has made a cash offer for 800 Super Holdings, while United Engineers has converted a S$333m loan to a green loan for a residential property development. The STI fell 3% due to US President Trump's plans to hike tariffs. Meanwhile, UOB launched an online utility marketplace, and the US, Vietnam, and other countries are reacting to Trump's tariff announcement.

site_title: Malaysia sends ex-Goldman banker to US over 1MDB charges
summary: A former Goldman Sachs banker, Roger Ng, has been extradited to the US to face charges linked to the multi-billion-dollar 1MDB scandal. Ng, a former managing director, is accused of stealing US$2.7 billion from the Malaysian state fund and laundering it through the US financial system. He was temporarily surrendered to the US on May 3, 2019, and will face charges in both Malaysia and the US. The extradition follows a deal allowing Ng to be temporarily surrendered to the US for 10 months to allow US prosecution to proceed.

site_title: EMS Energy to return Tuas South site to JTC after racking up arrears
summary: EMS Energy, a CATALIST-listed offshore and marine company, will return its Tuas South premises to JTC Corp after accumulating over S$940,000 in arrears. The company plans to negotiate a repayment scheme and return the site as soon as possible, without impacting its operations. The return will negatively affect net tangible assets and earnings per share for the year to Dec 31, but the cost of construction will likely be written off. EMS Energy is also in talks to sell 96.1% of the company to investors in exchange for a Vietnamese shipyard.

site_title: New outlets boost Koufu's Q1 revenue, earnings
summary: Koufu Group reported a 12.3% increase in net profit to S$7 million in its Q1 results, driven by a 4.9% increase in revenue to S$57.8 million, largely attributed to contributions from new outlets opened in the first quarter. The company's outlet and mall management segment saw higher revenue due to the openings of two new food courts and one coffee shop in the first quarter of 2019.

site_title: Euro-area order growth signals some hope
summary: Economic activity in the euro area showed signs of stabilization in April, with a composite Purchasing Managers' Index at 51.5 and service sector gauge declining slightly. Order growth improved at the best rate since November, sparking hope that the bloc's slowdown may be bottoming out. First quarter GDP growth was stronger than expected, and inflation accelerated more than forecast. These mixed economic numbers suggest the euro area may be overcoming a weak patch, providing some relief after a period of uncertainty.

site_title: Opening a Central Depository account is now fully digital
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has launched a fully digital application service for Central Depository (CDP) securities accounts, allowing customers to open accounts online without presenting hard copies of paperwork.
