Singapore residents can use the government's MyInfo database service to auto-fill personal data, and applicants can also upload soft copies of documents. This move aims to improve the retail investor experience and aligns with Singapore's Smart Nation journey. The number of new direct CDP accounts has seen a 40% growth last year, driven by rising retail investor interest in Singapore Savings Bonds and other investment products.

site_title: Hyflux slapped with US$57.7m claim by BNP Paribas for Magtaa performance bond
summary: Hyflux has received a US$57.7 million claim from BNP Paribas for a performance bond related to its associate company, Tahlyat Myah Magtaa (TMM), which operates the Magtaa desalination plant in Algeria. Hyflux owns a 47% stake in TMM. The claim is for the full amount of the performance bond.

site_title: Over 60: Why own when you can rent?
summary: New York City has the largest share of households of renters aged 60 and over, with 572,132 households, according to apartment-search website RENTCafé. This represents a 20% increase over the previous decade. Many seniors are opting for renting over buying due to the city's high cost of living, reduced maintenance responsibilities, and increased access to amenities. The trend is driven by the desire for freedom, flexibility, and proximity to family and cultural attractions. As a result, the city has seen a surge in over-60 renters, with some former co-op owners and suburban empty nesters making the move to Manhattan.

site_title: PODCAST: How to get bonus interest in bank-and-earn accounts (Money Hacks, Ep 42)
summary: A podcast series, "Money Hacks," provides actionable financial tips, focusing on bank-and-earn accounts. Hosted by Priscilla Joseph, vice-president of consumer banking for DBS, the episode helps individuals, especially young married couples, understand how to earn more interest with regular monthly deposits. Key criteria to consider when choosing a bank-and-earn account include salary, credit card spend, and avoiding overstretching. Bonus interest can be earned by increasing account balances, but managing irregular bills is crucial. The episode offers a money hack for handling these challenges.

images.alt_text: Money Hacks hosts Ernest Luis (left) and Chris Lim (right) host Priscilla Joseph, vice-president of consumer banking for DBS, and discuss how to earn bonus interest for bank-and-earn accounts.

site_title: Australia shares drop to 3-week low on trade tensions; NZ falls
summary: Australia's shares dropped to a three-week low on Monday, closing 0.8% lower, amid US President Donald Trump's threat to raise tariffs on Chinese goods. This spoiled hopes for an imminent trade deal between the US and China, prompting investors to seek safe-haven assets. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell to 6,283.70, with financials and miners leading the losses. In contrast, gold miners saw gains. New Zealand's benchmark index also fell 1% due to Westpac's losses.

site_title: Norway's Telenor in talks with Malaysia's Axiata to create Asian mobile giant
summary: Norway's Telenor is in talks with Malaysia's Axiata to form a 300 million customer Asian mobile giant through a "mega merger of equals." The proposed $13 billion deal would create a company with $5.5 billion in earnings and $5 billion in potential savings. Telenor would own 56.5% of the new entity, with Axiata holding the remainder. The deal aims to create a leading pan-Asian telecom company with a stronger foothold in the region and would be the largest mobile operator in Malaysia.

site_title: Cambodian rice exports to China surge following EU tariffs
summary: Cambodian rice exports surged 45.6% to China after the European Union imposed tariffs on imports from the country, offsetting a 57.8% decline in EU-bound exports. The EU tariffs, imposed in January to curb imports from Cambodia and Myanmar, led to a decline in Cambodia's EU exports, but an increase in Chinese exports. This boost was partly due to Cambodia's trade preference with the EU, Everything But Arms (EBA), which remains in place despite EU concerns over human rights and democracy.

site_title: Novartis drug helps broader group of rare-disease patients
summary: Novartis' gene therapy Zolgensma has shown promising results in treating spinal muscular atrophy (SMA), a rare inherited disease that typically kills before age 2. The therapy, which has been filed for FDA approval, halts neuron destruction within weeks and may be effective in a broader group of patients, including those with milder forms of the disease. The treatment could benefit approximately 9,000-10,000 Americans living with SMA, offering a new hope for patients with this devastating condition. A decision on FDA approval is expected by the end of the month.

images.alt_text: Novartis AG's Zolgensma, a gene therapy under review for treating children with a rare inherited disease that typically kills before the age of 2, also appears promising for a broader group of patients where the condition slowly destroys motor function.

site_title: IKEA to invest 400m euros in French city centre stores over three years
summary: IKEA plans to invest 400 million euros in French city centre stores over three years, according to IKEA France's CEO Walter Kadnar. The investment comes as the company builds up its new city centre stores, transforming its business model from self-service out-of-town stores to cater to consumers who prefer online ordering and delivery. IKEA recently opened its first store in central Paris, in the Madeleine district.

site_title: Singapore shares dive 3%, pummelled by tariff fears
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) plummeted 3% to close at 3,290.62, driven by US President Donald Trump's plan to hike tariffs, sparking market panic. This is the third time in five years the index has dropped 3% or more in a single session. International Cement was the most actively traded counter, while Resorts World Sentosa announced a plan to intensify land use and buy new land. The decline was attributed to tariff fears, with 1.44 billion securities changing hands, resulting in a 369-100 loss-gain ratio.

site_title: Meghan, Britain's Duchess of Sussex and wife of Prince Harry, has gone into labour - Sky News
summary: Meghan, the Duchess of Sussex and wife of Prince Harry, has gone into labor, according to Sky News. The couple's first child, the seventh-in-line to the British throne, is expected to be a girl. The baby will be the eighth great-grandchild of Queen Elizabeth II and could hold joint British and American citizenship. The child's title will be decided by the queen through a letter patent, not automatically being a prince or princess. Prince Harry, 34, and Meghan, 37, married in May 2018.

site_title: OKP Holdings Q1 profit down 62.4% amid losses at property associates
summary: OKP Holdings, a construction player, reported a 62.4% year-on-year decline in net profit to S$1.07 million in Q1 2019, due to losses at its property associates and core construction segment. Revenue fell 16.8% to S$19.2 million, driven by a surge in revenue from its property investment arm. The company's order book remains strong at S$291.6 million until 2023, and management is cautious about industry prospects while seeking to diversify earnings through strategic tie-ups.

site_title: Rockefeller Center shows off its roots
summary: Rockefeller Center has re-imagined the 845-square-foot Channel Gardens to honor the nation's first public botanical garden, established by botanist David Hosack in 1801. The garden features native species, including paper birch, reflecting environments found throughout New York State. The project, a collaboration between Rockefeller Center, the New York Botanical Garden, and Future Green Studio, aims to showcase the city's natural history and history.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets open sharply lower on Trump tariff threat
summary: European stock markets plummeted on Monday after US President Donald Trump threatened to raise tariffs on Chinese imports, dealing a blow to trade war hopes. Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC fell 1.3% and 1.5%, respectively. The London FTSE 100 index was closed for a bank holiday. The news cast a shadow over the markets, despite the US stock market reaching fresh records earlier in the day.

site_title: Asian markets plunge on tariff fears
summary: Asian markets plummeted on May 6, 2019, after US President Donald Trump threatened to hike tariffs on $200 billion worth of Chinese goods if a deal is not reached by Friday. Investors were caught off guard, as markets had anticipated a resolution to trade tensions. Analysts noted that the sudden escalation marked a 180-degree swing from expectations.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end 2.90% down after Trump tariffs threat
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 2.90% on May 6, 2019, after US President Donald Trump threatened to hike tariffs on hundreds of billions of dollars worth of Chinese goods. The Hang Seng Index dropped 871.73 points to 29,209.82. The move was seen as a negative impact on the market, with investors reacting to the uncertainty surrounding US-China trade relations.

site_title: EU to start formal probe on Spotify's Apple complaint, FT says
summary: The European Union is launching a formal investigation into Apple Inc. following Spotify Technology SA's complaint that Apple's 30% revenue cut is an unfair tax on competitors. Spotify claims that the rate is applied to paid subscriptions, while Apple argues it only applies to paid apps. The EU has been surveying customers and industry rivals and could impose fines of up to 10% of global sales. Spotify CEO Daniel Ek has described the situation as "untenable," which could drive price increases. The investigation could take years to resolve.

site_title: China's war on healthcare costs lures India's biggest drugmaker
summary: India's largest drugmaker, Sun Pharmaceutical Industries Ltd., is scouting for a partner in China to tap into the country's $160 billion drug market, which is driving down healthcare costs. The Indian company, led by billionaire Dilip Shanghvi, believes the opportunity is significant and could create a new revenue stream. China has implemented an ambitious bulk drug procurement program, providing an opening for Indian manufacturers to compete, and Sun Pharma plans to scale up its China business in 6-9 months.

images.alt_text: Sun Pharmaceutical Industries Ltd. is scouting for a partner in China to help it win a larger piece of the world's second-largest drug market, where the government is on a mission to drive down the cost of healthcare.

site_title: United Engineers converts S$333m loan to green loan for residential property development
summary: United Engineers has converted a S$333 million loan into a green loan to develop a 450-unit residential property in Singapore. The project features energy-efficient and water-saving systems, with expected annual savings of up to 473,206 kWh and 21,302 cubic metres. The property will also include sustainable building systems, green products, and amenities such as a childcare centre and retail shops. The company aims to demonstrate environmentally responsible business practices and encourages other companies to consider environmental sustainability in their building plans.

site_title: US destroyers sail in disputed South China Sea amid tense relations
summary: US warships Preble and Chung Hoon sailed within 12 nautical miles of disputed islands in the South China Sea, challenging China's excessive maritime claims. The move aims to preserve access to the waterways as governed by international law. This action comes amid tense US-China relations, including a trade war and sanctions. US President Donald Trump has vowed to hike tariffs on Chinese goods, prompting China to consider cancelling trade talks. The incident highlights the growing tensions in the region and the need for China to respect international law.

site_title: IOC chief praises Brisbane as it mulls 2032 bid
summary: IOC president Thomas Bach praised Brisbane, Australia, as it considers a 2032 Summer Games bid, stating he was "impressed" by the city's early planning and detailed feasibility studies. Bach's comments came during a visit to the Queensland state capital, where officials are weighing the expense of hosting the major event.

site_title: Hong Kong, China: Stocks dive on Trump tariffs threat
summary: US President Donald Trump threatened to hike tariffs on Chinese imports, potentially derailing high-level trade talks, causing a significant sell-off in Asian stock markets. China's Shanghai Composite Index plummeted 5.19% and the Shenzhen Composite Index sank 5.86% as the Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong dropped 3.31%. The Chinese yuan also fell, exacerbating a recent contraction in Chinese shares. The move casts a shadow over the next round of negotiations set for Washington this week.

site_title: Singapore PR firm Redhill 3rd-fastest growing agency globally: report
summary: Redhill, a Singapore-based PR firm, has been named the third-fastest growing agency globally by The Holmes Report's Global PR Agency Rankings 2019. Established in 2014, the firm has grown to over 70 employees across 12 countries, with 17 offices, driven by organic growth and increased revenue. Redhill aims to expand further in Japan, India, the US, and Australia, with a focus on becoming a global brand. The firm's growth is attributed to its early client base of venture capital funds and startups, and it has not received outside investment or funding.

site_title: India sees little scope for Jet Airways revival -government sources
summary: India's government sees little hope of a bidder emerging to revive debt-laden Jet Airways Ltd, with thousands of employees pleading for a rescue. Despite initial interest from parties, no firm bids have been made, increasing the likelihood of bankruptcy proceedings. The government is willing to return slots to Jet if a bidder emerges, but creditors are expected to take Jet to the National Company Law Tribunal for recovery of dues. The airline's lenders are waiting for the formation of the next government before making a decision on Jet's fate.

images.alt_text: India's government sees little hope of a bidder emerging for debt-laden Jet Airways Ltd , two senior finance ministry officials said, even as thousands of employees plead with the government for a rescue.

site_title: Malaysia hands over ex-Goldman banker Roger Ng to US to face 1MDB charges
summary: Malaysia has handed over former Goldman Sachs banker Roger Ng to the US Department of Justice to face 1MDB charges. Ng, who has been in custody since November, was slapped with four counts of abetting Goldman Sachs in selling billions of dollars of guaranteed notes and bonds. He is also wanted to face charges in a New York federal court for allegedly laundering money and bribing government officials as part of Goldman Sachs' work for 1MDB. Ng is expected to arrive in New York on Monday.

site_title: Brunei suspends death penalty for gay sex after global backlash
summary: Brunei has suspended the death penalty for gay sex and adultery with death by stoning, following global criticism, including from human rights groups and celebrities like George Clooney. Sultan Hassanal Bolkiah announced the moratorium in a televised address, extending a two-decade ban on capital punishment. The move comes after Brunei put into effect laws penalizing homosexuality and extramarital affairs with death by stoning, prompting calls to boycott hotels owned by the monarchy.

site_title: China Vice Premier Liu will still travel to US this week but will shorten trip: SCMP
summary: China Vice Premier Liu He will travel to the US this week for trade talks, shortening his trip from four days to three. The trip, originally scheduled to begin on Thursday, will now depart on the following day. This change comes after US President Donald Trump announced plans to hike tariffs on $200 billion worth of Chinese goods, prompting concerns about the talks' progress. The shortened trip may indicate China's desire to avoid further escalation.

site_title: IBM-backed project creates Wi-Fi network for natural disasters
summary: IBM-backed Project Owl, a team of young computer nerds, has developed a Wi-Fi network for natural disasters, creating a 100-square-mile network that can connect victims and first responders in areas without cell reception. The system, called DuckLinks, uses baseball-sized rubber casings with Wi-Fi capabilities, and can be deployed in flooded areas. The team won a $200,000 grand prize for their entry in IBM's Call for Code competition and has since deployed the devices in Puerto Rico and plans to expand to the US East Coast. The system aims to provide a simple and relatively cheap solution to communication breakdowns during natural disasters.

site_title: Australia's Treasury Wines wins case against "copycat" for imitating brand in China
summary: Australia's Treasury Wine Estates Ltd, the world's largest standalone winemaker, has won a lawsuit against a Chinese company, Rush Rich, for imitating its Penfolds brand. The company was ordered to cease using the brand name "Ben Fu" and pay over A$375,000 in compensation. This is not the first time Treasury has taken action against a Chinese company for trademark infringement, having previously won a similar case in 2017. The win reaffirms Treasury's efforts to protect its intellectual property rights.

images.alt_text: Australia's Treasury Wine Estates Ltd, the world's largest standalone winemaker, said on Monday it had won a lawsuit against a "copycat" it had accused of imitating its prestigious Penfolds brand in China.

site_title: Indonesia Q1 GDP growth slower than expected as investment cools
summary: Indonesia's Q1 GDP growth slowed to 5.07% in January-March, the slowest pace in a year, due to soft investment and household consumption. This missed expectations of 5.18% growth. Analysts attribute the weaker growth to external factors, including the US-China trade dispute, and forecast the central bank to resist cutting interest rates. Despite this, economists expect the current account deficit to shrink this year, with some arguing Bank Indonesia has room to unwind interest rate hikes to support economic growth.

site_title: UOB launches online utility marketplace
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has launched an online utility marketplace, aggregating deals from 10 utility providers, including SP Group, Diamond Electric, and Singtel, to help customers manage household expenses. The platform, which also competes with DBS's online travel marketplace, aims to support UOB's customer-centric solutions. This move is part of the bank's strategy to enhance its offerings and stay competitive in the local market, where banks are vying to entrench themselves in customers' lifestyles.

site_title: Property and finance veteran Lim Hua Tiong named first Frasers Property Vietnam CEO
summary: FRASERS Property Vietnam has appointed Lim Hua Tiong as its first CEO, based in Ho Chi Minh City. Lim, with over 20 years of experience in the property and finance sectors, previously held CEO and general manager roles for CFLD International and CapitaLand in Vietnam. He will report to Panote Sirivadhanabhakdi, Frasers Property's group CEO. This appointment marks a significant milestone for Frasers Property Vietnam, marking the company's expansion in the Vietnamese market.

site_title: Forgers are forcing a US$9 trillion business into the digital age, says OCBC
summary: OCBC, a major lender in South-east Asia, emphasizes the need for the $9 trillion global trade finance industry to transition to a digital age due to the high risk of forgery. Forgers have created convincing replicas of documents, making paperless transactions a necessity. Digitalization will increase efficiency and reduce the risk of fraud. Key players, including banks and commodity traders, are experimenting with blockchain technology to track transactions and enhance security. While it's unclear when widespread adoption will occur, experts believe it's only a matter of time before the industry fully transitions to a digital platform.

site_title: Certis partners IT consulting firm Sourced for migration to Amazon Web Services cloud
summary: Certis, an integrated security provider, has partnered with IT consulting firm Sourced to migrate to Amazon Web Services (AWS) cloud. Sourced will deliver cloud infrastructure and security frameworks, and secure Certis's officer support system, Argus. The partnership aims to accelerate cloud adoption while maintaining strict security and compliance requirements. Certis plans to use AWS services, including AWS Lambda, Amazon Simple Queue Service, and Amazon Elastic Container Service, to streamline its operations and deliver superior customer outcomes.

site_title: With two tweets, Trump shatters historic calm in global markets
summary: US President Donald Trump's two tweets on May 6, 2019, sparked significant market volatility, with global stocks experiencing sharp declines. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 4.1% and US stock-index futures slid 2% amid concerns about escalating US-China trade tensions. Market experts warn of a potential significant hit to growth if tariffs increase, with Goldman Sachs economists putting the odds of tariff hikes at 40%. China is considering delaying its delegation to Washington, adding to uncertainty, and currencies, interest rates, and commodities may be affected.

site_title: Australian election rate cut calls grow as decision nears
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to keep interest rates at a record low of 1.50% amid growing calls for a rate cut due to weak inflation and slow economic momentum. A majority of economists polled by Reuters, including Bank of America-Merrill Lynch economist Tony Morriss, predict two cuts to 1.00% later this year. The decision may challenge the federal government's economic claims ahead of the national vote on May 18, and could influence New Zealand's central bank to lower rates in a similar manner.

site_title: Church calls for calm after Sri Lanka clashes
summary: The head of Sri Lanka's Catholic Church has called for calm after clashes between Christians and Muslims in Negombo, north of Colombo, resulting in damaged homes and businesses. The violence, which has not yet been confirmed to have any arrests or injuries, is the first such incident since the Easter Sunday bombings that killed 257 people. Authorities have imposed a curfew in the area.

site_title: Palm oil titan warns EU limits on biofuel use will backfire
summary: Franky Widjaja, head of Golden Agri-Resources, warns that the EU's plan to restrict palm oil use in biofuel will backfire, hurting growers and jeopardizing future supplies. The move threatens the incomes of 17 million people in Indonesia and will not meet rising demand for food and fuel. Widjaja believes the EU's claims about palm oil's environmental impact are misleading and that compromise is likely to resolve the dispute. The palm oil industry is already facing declining prices and rising costs, but demand from energy is expected to boost prices in the future.

site_title: Federal Reserve faces tough sell on inflation framework
summary: Federal Reserve policymakers are grappling with the challenge of adapting their inflation-targeting approach to a world of muted inflation and low borrowing costs. With the US economy on an even keel and interest rates on pause, the Fed is exploring new strategies to manage interest rates, including targeting economic output, committing to above-target inflation, and using negative interest rates. However, settling on a better framework before the next recession hits and explaining it to the public will be a major challenge. Fed policymakers acknowledge that the current framework may not be effective in the face of future economic shocks.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks plunge at open on trade war fears
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 2.43% at the opening on Monday, May 6, 2019, due to fears of a trade war. The Hang Seng Index dropped 730.82 points to 29,350.73, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 3.04% to 2,984.73. The US-China trade tensions escalated with Donald Trump warning of tariffs on hundreds of billions of dollars' worth of Chinese goods.

site_title: Mitsubishi plans 150b yen rescue for plant engineering firm Chiyoda: Nikkei
summary: Mitsubishi Corp and MUFG Bank plan to rescue plant engineering firm Chiyoda with a 150 billion yen (S$1.85 billion) lifeline. Chiyoda, a leading LNG plant builder, has struggled with losses after a hurricane hit its US project. The rescue is fueled by growing LNG demand, forecast to rise 11% this year, driven by a shift from coal. Mitsubishi will provide the majority of the lifeline through new preferred shares and loans, with MUFG Bank providing additional financing. Chiyoda has not yet confirmed the deal, citing no decision made.

site_title: Michael Cohen, Trump's one-time aide who turned on him, goes to jail
summary: Michael Cohen, former lawyer to Donald Trump, began serving a 3-year prison sentence on May 6, 2019, after admitting to paying hush money to women who claimed to have had affairs with Trump and lying to Congress. Despite offering information to investigators, prosecutors upheld his sentence, with Cohen expressing frustration and disappointment. Cohen, a practicing Jew, is being held at the low-security Otisville prison, where he will have access to a library and recreational facilities. His sentence is non-paroleable, with the possibility of a 15% reduction for good behavior.

site_title: China to impose stricter policy on bad-loan recognition: Bloomberg
summary: China's banking regulator has instructed major lenders to accelerate recognition of nonperforming loans, aiming to bolster lending quality. The China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission (CBIRC) now requires corporate loans overdue for more than 60 days to be classified as nonperforming, down from 90 days. This change, effective for state-owned banks and national joint-stock banks, seeks to address the nation's longstanding bad debt issue, with over 2 trillion yuan of soured loans. The new policy may weaken some banks' capital buffers and portend a new wave of bad loans on balance sheets.

site_title: China to close over 1,000 unsafe mining sites in 2019: state media
summary: China plans to close over 1,000 non-coal mining sites in 2019 due to safety concerns, according to state-run newspaper Guangming Daily. The sites, which produce ferrous and non-ferrous metals, have failed to meet safety standards despite previous orders to shut or rectify. Targeted closures also include tailings and waste-mine dams that have reached maximum capacities. The move aims to preempt accidents at these sites, which are prone to accidents and have seen a quarter decrease in number since 2012.

site_title: 41 believed dead in Russian plane disaster: investigators
summary: A Russian passenger plane made an emergency landing at Moscow's airport, catching fire and resulting in 41 fatalities, with 37 survivors. The incident occurred with 78 people, including crew members, on board.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand: Shares dive on Trump's vow to hike tariffs
summary: US President Donald Trump announced plans to hike US tariffs on Chinese goods, sparking a decline in Australian and New Zealand shares. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 1.2% and the S&P/NZX 50 index fell 0.7% as investors reacted to the threat, which comes ahead of scheduled trade talks between China and the US. The prolonged trade tensions have caused growing concerns about global economic growth, leading to a drop in financial and material stocks.

site_title: China central bank to cut reserve requirements for some banks as trade tensions rise
summary: China's central bank cut reserve requirement ratios for small and medium-sized banks, releasing 280 billion yuan ($41.23 billion) in long-term funding, starting May 15. The move aims to support companies struggling amid an economic slowdown. The cut, targeting 1,000 rural commercial banks, will help lower funding costs for small and micro firms. The move is seen as a targeted policy measure to calm the market amid escalating trade tensions with the US, following comments from US President Donald Trump.

images.alt_text: China's central bank said on Monday it will lower the reserve requirement ratio for small and medium-sized banks effective on May 15, marking the latest policy support measure by Beijing to support companies struggling amid an economic slowdown.

site_title: For British pensioners in France, Brexit is a health concern
summary: British pensioners living in France are concerned about the impact of Brexit on their healthcare, with many facing high out-of-pocket costs or uncertainty about their coverage. As the UK's exit from the EU approaches, 600,000 retired Britons are estimated to live in EU countries, with France's generous healthcare system providing them with essential treatment. Experts warn that a no-deal Brexit could strain the UK's National Health Service, exacerbating existing staffing and financing crises.

site_title: Boeing knew of 737 Max safety system glitch year before deadly crash
summary: Boeing acknowledged a 2017 safety issue with its 737 Max aircraft, a pilot warning system glitch, a year before the deadly Lion Air crash that killed 189 people. The issue was related to an optional indicator that was not standard equipment, and management was unaware of it until the crash. The planes were not grounded until after another 737 Max operated by Ethiopian Airlines crashed, killing 157 people. This revelation raises questions about Boeing's oversight and communication about the issue.

site_title: Top oil buyers rue global chaos bringing back seller's market
summary: The world's top oil buyers are facing a shift towards a seller's market due to US President Donald Trump's sanctions on Iran and Venezuela, Opec+ output curbs, and supply disruptions. This has led to higher prices for crude oil, with Abu Dhabi's Murban crude selling at 25-45 US cents a barrel above its official selling price. Industry analysts predict a tight market lasting through the third quarter, with refineries in Asia competing for limited supplies and demand forecast to rise due to refinery maintenance and summer seasonal demand.

site_title: Japan, South Korea: Markets closed on Monday
summary: Financial markets in Japan and South Korea were closed on Monday due to public holidays. Meanwhile, in Singapore, stocks continued their 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. In other news, Airalo raised US$220 million in a new funding round, lifting its valuation past US$1 billion. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq in the US also reached fresh records despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Australia job ads dip in April, pace of decline slows
summary: Australian job advertisements declined for a sixth consecutive month in April, but at a slower pace. The decline was 0.1% from March, and job ads averaged 166,464 a week, 5.6% lower than last year. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to ease policy, possibly cutting its 1.5% cash rate, due to slow employment growth. This may limit wage growth and inflation, according to ANZ's head of Australian economics.

site_title: Asia: Markets plunge as Trump threatens to hike China tariffs
summary: Asian markets plummeted on May 6, 2019, after US President Donald Trump threatened to hike tariffs on $200 billion of Chinese goods, potentially disrupting high-level trade talks. Shanghai and Hong Kong equities fell 3% and 2.5% respectively, while the Chinese yuan lost 1.3% against the dollar. The move casts a shadow over upcoming talks between the two economic superpowers, with a delegation from Beijing due in Washington this week.

site_title: Hong Kong's surging weekend property sales show rebound underway
summary: Hong Kong's property market is showing signs of a rebound, with 1,220 new units sold over the weekend, the most in six years. Used home sales also reached an eight-year high in April, with HK$40 billion in transactions. This comes as buyers regain confidence due to stock market gains and low interest rates. Home prices have risen for three consecutive months, regaining 10% of lost value from last year's record high, with analysts predicting prices may reach peak levels in the third quarter.

site_title: 800 Super: Lee family makes S$0.90 per share cash offer with KKR financing
summary: The Lee family, controlling 77.6% of 800 Super Holdings, has made a S$0.90 cash offer for each share, valuing the company at S$161 million. The offer is conditional on receiving at least 90% of shares and is being financed by private equity firm KKR. The deal is seen as a way for the company to save on expenses and focus on operational matters. The offer price represents a 16.1% premium to the company's last transacted price and a 17.6% premium to its weighted average price over the last 12 months.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 4.54 points to 1,632.76 at 9am on Monday, opening lower. The index had a trading volume of 84.56 million lots worth RM35.73 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 207 to 71.

site_title: Brunei says it won't enforce gay death penalty after backlash
summary: Brunei's Sultan Hassanal Bolkiah announced a moratorium on the death penalty for gay sex, following global backlash over the country's implementation of Islamic laws that punish sodomy, adultery, and rape with death. The move comes after criticism from celebrities and rights groups, who have boycotted hotels owned by the sultan. The Sultan stated that the death penalty will not be imposed for the new law, which was set to be implemented on May 8, citing a desire to ensure peace and harmony in the country.

site_title: GKE Corp to invest 48m yuan to build China cement plant, raise S$7m from proposed placement
summary: GKE Corp will invest 48 million yuan (S$9.7 million) to construct a ready-mix cement plant in Cenxi City, China. The project will be funded through internal resources and a proposed placement of 100 million new shares, raising S$7 million. The plant will be leased for 50 years, and construction is expected to take 15 months. The share issuance will provide S$6.95 million in net proceeds, with S$5 million for expansion and S$1.95 million for working capital.

site_title: China considers canceling trade talks with US after Trump vows new tariff hike: WSJ
summary: China is considering canceling trade talks with the US after US President Donald Trump vowed to hike tariffs on $200 billion worth of Chinese goods this week. The decision depends on whether Vice Premier Liu He attends the talks as planned. Canceling talks would conform to China's strategy of not negotiating under threat. Trump's announcement is a significant escalation in the ongoing trade tensions between the two countries.

site_title: Oil prices tumble by more than 2% after Trump announces new tariffs on Chinese goods
summary: US President Donald Trump announced new tariffs on Chinese goods, leading to a 2.4% drop in US West Texas Intermediate crude futures to $60.44 per barrel and a 2.1% decline in Brent crude oil futures to $69.34 per barrel. The move is expected to derail months of trade talks between the US and China. Beijing is reportedly considering cancelling all trade talks with Washington. Oil prices tumbled as the US becomes the world's largest oil producer, with crude production reaching a record 12.3 million barrels per day.

site_title: Hong Lai Huat to sell Cambodia investment property for US$1.12m
summary: Hong Lai Huat Group has entered into a sale and purchase agreement for its investment property in Cambodia for US$1.12 million. The property, with a land area of 8,499 sq m and a built-up area of 4,698 sq m, will be sold within 90 business days. The identity of the buyer remains undisclosed. The sale comes after the company's shares closed at 25 Singapore cents on Friday, down 1.96%.

site_title: Synagie inks deal to manage Samsonite Malaysia's e-commerce sales
summary: Synagie has partnered with Samsonite Malaysia to manage the luggage manufacturer's e-commerce sales on platforms Lazada, Shopee, and Zalora in Malaysia. This deal marks Synagie's entry into travel and lifestyle e-commerce, adding to its portfolio of 270 brand partners. Synagie will assist in managing or automating online sales for Samsonite and its brands.

site_title: US sends naval strike group to Middle East in 'message' to Iran: Bolton
summary: The US has deployed an aircraft carrier strike group and a bomber task force to the Middle East as a "clear and unmistakable" message to Iran, according to National Security Advisor John Bolton. The deployment comes in response to "troubling and escalatory indications and warnings" from Tehran, but Bolton did not specify the nature of these indications. The move aims to deter Iranian aggression and reassure allies in the region.

site_title: US stock futures tumble after Trump threatens China with steeper tariffs
summary: US stock futures plummeted after President Donald Trump announced plans to hike tariffs on $200 billion worth of Chinese goods, sparking concerns about stalled trade talks. The threat may halt progress, causing investors to question the closeness of a deal. While some analysts see Trump's comments as a negotiating tactic, others warn of potential escalation, which could lead to market headwinds. The S&P 500, Nasdaq, and Dow futures fell, with losses ranging from 1.36% to 1.51% and 1.35% respectively.

site_title: Singapore shares tumble amid Asian rout after Trump threatens China tariff hikes; STI down 3.4% at reopen
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) plummeted 3.41% on Monday, following US President Donald Trump's threat to raise tariffs on Chinese imports to 25% from 10%. The benchmark index opened down 1.9% and remained under pressure throughout the day. Asian markets also fell, with the Shanghai Composite Index sinking 5.58% and the Hang Seng Index dropping 3.03%. The yen strengthened as investors sought safe-haven assets amid the trade tensions. Financials were particularly hard hit, with UOB, OCBC, and DBS losing 6.8%, 4.7%, and 4.3% respectively.

site_title: North Korea tested rocket launchers and 'tactical guided weapons'
summary: North Korea tested rocket launchers and tactical guided weapons, with leader Kim Jong Un overseeing the drill, prompting US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo to say a path forward in denuclearisation remains. The test, which included 240-mm and 300-mm multiple rocket launchers, did not violate UN sanctions resolutions. Despite the latest provocation, US President Donald Trump believes a breakthrough is possible, citing Kim's economic potential and his own commitment to the talks.

site_title: Isetan not renewing lease of 'loss-making' Westgate store
summary: Isetan Singapore will not renew its lease for its "loss-making" store in Westgate, a Japanese department store operator said in a regulatory filing. The company had discussions with the landlord, JG Trustee, but failed to reach an agreement on renewal terms. The lease expires in December and Isetan Singapore will not renew, citing the inability to reach a favorable agreement. The decision is part of the company's efforts to realign operations and deploy resources more efficiently.

site_title: Singapore may allow virtual banks after Hong Kong move, DBS says
summary: Singapore may consider issuing virtual banking licenses after Hong Kong's move, according to DBS Group Holdings CEO Piyush Gupta. He believes the new entrants won't pose a threat to existing banks, as long as they upgrade their digital capabilities. Gupta warned that the key challenge is creating an "unlevel playing field" if virtual banks operate under different terms than traditional lenders. Singapore's Education Minister Ong Ye Kung has stated that the country should study virtual licenses carefully to determine their benefits.

site_title: Junk bond market rally turns Chinese borrowers more aggressive
summary: Chinese borrowers are successfully cutting costs for repaying bonds early, with select issuers succeeding in lowering the price of early redemption to as low as 101% of par value. This is a change from standard market practice, where the call price is typically equal to the par value plus half of the coupon. The surge in junk-rated bonds has increased investor risk appetite, driven by a dovish US Federal Reserve stance and a stock market rally. However, this development worries some investors and bankers, who see it as a potential negative precedent.

site_title: Jokowi needs free hand to pick Cabinet, finance minister says
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo is set to begin his second five-year term, but needs the power to pick a capable team to achieve his ambitious goals, including improving education and healthcare. Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati stated that Jokowi needs a free hand to decide on his Cabinet, citing the need to address a current account deficit and global uncertainties. The president plans to distribute wealth more evenly to reduce poverty and accelerate infrastructure development through partnerships with the private sector.

images.alt_text: Indonesian President Joko Widodo has an ambitious list of goals for his next term - improving education and health care, providing a social safety net and developing infrastructure.

site_title: Australia's Westpac posts worst half-year profit in six years
summary: Australia's Westpac Banking Corp posted its lowest half-year profit in six years, with cash earnings falling 22% to A$3.3 billion due to a shrinking housing market and costs associated with compensating customers. The bank attributed the decline to weaker business conditions and ongoing issues related to remediation and wealth strategy. Westpac maintained its interim dividend, but analysts expressed concerns over the bank's outlook due to an uncertain international backdrop and soft house prices until 2020.

images.alt_text: Australia's second biggest lender Westpac Banking Corp posted its lowest half-yearly profit in six years on Monday, missing analyst forecasts, as a shrinking housing market weighed on sales and the bank set aside money to compensate customers.

site_title: China considers delaying next trade talks after Trump's tariff threat
summary: China is considering delaying its top trade negotiators' trip to Washington amid US President Donald Trump's threat to increase tariffs on $200 billion of Chinese imports to 25% from 10%. Trump's move has sparked concerns of a full-blown trade war, with China's yuan plummeting and equity markets being affected. The US had been targeting a deal by May 10, but Trump's latest tweets have raised pressure on Beijing to strike a trade deal. The delay could escalate tensions and impact global trade, with the International Monetary Fund warning of a slowdown in growth if tariffs increase.

site_title: 'Avengers' blast past 'Titanic' to all-time No. 2
summary: "Avengers: Endgame" has become the No. 2 film of all time, earning $2.19 billion worldwide in under two weeks, surpassing "Star Wars: The Force Awakens" and "Titanic". The superhero blockbuster, directed by Anthony and Joe Russo, features a star-studded cast and drew a 96% rating on Rotten Tomatoes. With a long predicted run, "Avengers" has taken in $575.8 million in China alone, cementing its historic place in the box office records.

site_title: Arctic nations to meet amid tensions over environment, resources
summary: Top diplomats from the US, Russia, and other Arctic nations meet in Finland to discuss policies governing the polar region amid growing tensions over climate change and access to mineral wealth. The US has rejected China's role in shaping Arctic policy, while Russia has reopened military bases and modernized its Northern Fleet. The Arctic Council, which includes the region's indigenous populations, will also discuss climate change, with the US disagreeing with the wording on the issue. The meeting comes as the Arctic ice melts at twice the global rate, raising concerns about the region's future.

site_title: 'Thrust reverser' broken on plane that slid into Florida river
summary: A Boeing 737-800 plane chartered by the US military slid off a runway into a Florida river, injuring 22 people, after experiencing a malfunctioning "thrust reverser" component. The aircraft was landing during a thunderstorm and was traveling at 302 km/h when it touched down. The pilots had requested to change runways, reducing available landing space, and the investigation is ongoing. The cockpit voice recorder is submerged in the plane, and divers are working to remove deceased pets from the aircraft. The cause of the malfunction is being investigated by the National Transportation Safety Board.

site_title: Isetan needs more than a store refresh
summary: Isetan Singapore's flagship store at Shaw House is struggling with falling sales, despite the popularity of its basement supermarket. The retail headwinds cannot fully explain the store's stock trading below its theoretical liquidation value for years. The company's declining sales are part of a broader retail market trend, with stiff competition on Orchard Road. Isetan's financial struggles may be a casualty of the changing retail landscape in Singapore.

site_title: US-China trade dilemma: how to hold Beijing's feet to the fire
summary: US and Chinese officials are nearing a historic trade deal, but the question remains whether Beijing will uphold its end of the bargain. The US may unveil a grand agreement after months of tensions, but a key concern is enforcement. The US has proposed regular meetings and a system to verify compliance, while China may use regulatory tools to thwart implementation. The deal must address issues like forced technology transfer and intellectual property theft, and the US will not accept empty promises, with US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer insisting on verification.

site_title: Wall St to lift STI; eyes on US-China trade talks
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) is expected to rise following a positive Wall Street session, driven by better-than-expected April jobs data. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.75%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also gained 0.96% and 1.58%, respectively. This upbeat market outlook is attributed to the US economic engine continuing to run smoothly, with inflation remaining under control.

site_title: Money FM podcast: The Hot Seat: Banyan Tree's 25th anniversary
summary: The Money FM podcast "The Hot Seat" celebrated Banyan Tree's 25th anniversary. No other article content is relevant to this anniversary.

site_title: EU, UK condemn US oil and nuclear sanctions on Iran
summary: The European Union, UK, and Germany have condemned the US decision to restrict oil trade with Iran and limit nuclear non-proliferation project waivers. The US move aims to force Iran to stop producing low-enriched uranium and halt its ballistic missile program. Iran's parliament speaker stated that the country will continue with low-level uranium enrichment in line with its nuclear deal. The US also scrapped sanctions waivers for uranium storage and heavy water production, prompting concerns about escalating tensions.

site_title: China sets yuan mid-point at weakest level in two and a half months
summary: China's central bank lowered its official yuan midpoint to 6.7334 per US dollar, the weakest level in two and a half months, following US President Donald Trump's announcement to increase tariffs on Chinese goods. Trump's move marked a major escalation in trade tensions between the two largest economies. The yuan's weakening is expected to impact China's economy, which is set to slow down, raising pressure on policymakers.

images.alt_text: China's central bank lowered its official yuan midpoint to 6.7334 per US dollar on Monday, the weakest level in two and a half months, after US President Donald Trump threatened to increase tariffs on Chinese goods.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Best World, 800 Super, Cordlife, Synagie
summary: Best World International's trading halt has been extended to May 9, as the company prepares to release its quarterly results. The trading halt was initially set to end on May 6 after a shortseller report raised concerns over the company's accounting and sales practices. Meanwhile, 800 Super Holdings has received a conditional offer from the Lee family to delist the company, valued at S$161 million. Cordlife, a bloodbanker, has also had its trading halt lifted after "unusual price movements" were queried by the Singapore Exchange. Synagie has partnered with Samsonite International to manage its online sales.

site_title: Two dead, one missing as freak weather hits Italy, France
summary: Two people died and one person is missing in Italy and France due to freak weather conditions. A 65-year-old German kitesurfer was killed in Sicily, and a Romanian man is missing in northern Italy after his car rolled into the water during a fishing trip. In France, a German tourist was swept away by waves on the island of Corsica, and three French mountaineers were rescued from the Alps. The weather caused widespread damage, including destroyed vineyards, flooded fields, and snow in the Dolomite mountains, with estimated losses of millions of euros.

site_title: Indonesia to sink about 50 boats to deter illegal fishing
summary: Indonesia plans to sink up to 51 foreign boats, including those from Vietnam, Malaysia, and China, over two weeks to deter illegal fishing in its waters. The boats were impounded after clashes with Indonesian naval vessels and coastguards. Fisheries minister Susi Pudjiastuti stated that the action is necessary to warn neighboring countries and prevent further clashes. The move comes after a Vietnamese coastguard boat rammed an Indonesian navy ship attempting to seize an illegal trawler, resulting in the detention of a dozen fishermen.

site_title: Iranian non-oil exports, oil sales must counter US sanctions, says Iran's president
summary: Iranian President Hassan Rouhani emphasized the need for non-oil exports and oil sales to counter US sanctions. He stated that the US aims to decrease Iran's foreign reserves by targeting its hard currency reserves, prompting Iran to boost exports and resist US plots against oil sales.

site_title: South-east Asia a rising star for cross-border deals: poll
summary: A poll of 600 business executives in the Asia-Pacific region has found that South-east Asia is the top destination for mergers, acquisitions, and investments in the next two years, with 69% of respondents favoring Asean investments. The region's advantages include a growing middle class, an educated workforce, and expanding consumer base, as well as reasonable asset valuations. 85% of respondents believe South-east Asia will have more economic influence in the Asia-Pacific in five years.

site_title: China's war on healthcare costs lures India's Sun Pharma
summary: Sun Pharmaceutical Industries Ltd, India's largest drugmaker, is scouting a partner in China to tap the country's $160 billion drug market, driven by the government's efforts to reduce healthcare costs. The company's billionaire founder, Dilip Shanghvi, believes there's a significant opportunity for India's largest drugmaker. China's bulk procurement programme is reducing prices and providing an opening for Indian manufacturers like Sun Pharma to compete, with the unit expected to contribute to the company's $4 billion in overall sales within three years.

site_title: Trump to hike tariffs on US$200b of Chinese goods
summary: US President Donald Trump announced a plan to hike tariffs on $200 billion of Chinese goods to 25% starting this week. The move comes as a major Chinese delegation is set to arrive in Washington for trade talks aimed at ending the trade war. The tariffs, which are expected to increase to 25% from 10%, will primarily affect high-tech goods and other Chinese exports. The move is seen as a response to China's failure to address US trade concerns, with Trump stating that talks are moving "too slowly."

site_title: Trump ups pressure on China ahead of last ditch trade talks
summary: US President Donald Trump announced plans to raise tariffs on $200 billion of Chinese goods, effective immediately, ahead of last-ditch trade talks scheduled for Wednesday. The move is a warning to China to accept US demands, including structural changes and intellectual property theft prevention. Trump also threatened to slap tariffs on all Chinese imports worth $539.5 billion if a deal is not reached. The talks come after the US and China imposed tariffs on $360 billion in two-way trade since last year, with Trump seeking to reduce the US trade deficit with China.

site_title: Carbon tax best way to cut greenhouse gas emissions: IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) recommends a carbon tax as the most efficient way to cut greenhouse gas emissions. A tax of $70 per tonne of carbon dioxide would be required to meet the Paris Agreement's goal of capping global temperature increases at 2 degrees centigrade above pre-industrial levels. The IMF argues that a carbon tax can reduce energy consumption, promote cleaner energy sources, and mobilize private financing, generating revenue that can be used to finance sustainable growth. A $35 per tonne tax in China, India, and South Africa could cut emissions by 30%.

site_title: Net long dollar bets highest since Dec 2015
summary: Speculators raised their net long bets on the US dollar to $38.88 billion in the week to April 30, the highest since December 2015. This optimism is attributed to improving US economic data, low interest rates, and a likelihood of weak inflation. Despite a slip against a basket of currencies on Friday, analysts forecast the dollar's appreciation this year, citing a potential slump in risky assets.

site_title: Grab's super app goal calls for good grasp of holding on to users
summary: Grab, a Singapore-based ride-hailing startup, aims to become the dominant "super app" in South-east Asia, offering a range of services such as food delivery, finance, and hotel bookings. However, the company faces skepticism about its ability to replicate the success of China's WeChat and Alipay, which have unique propositions. Grab's strategy focuses on a less-is-more approach, launching each vertical with a carefully selected partner, but critics argue that users need to be able to choose from a range of offerings to create a strong network effect. Grab has raised billions of dollars to fund its expansion, and its early progress has been marked by concerns about its burn rate and profitability.

site_title: Peso risks losing best Asia currency tag as rate-cut bets climb
summary: The Philippine peso's rally is at risk of being reversed due to speculation that the central bank will ease monetary policy, potentially leading to a rate cut and bond outflows. Analysts predict the peso will weaken to 53.18 per dollar by end-June, reversing its 1.3% advance against the US dollar this quarter. A reduction in interest rates could also widen the current account, putting pressure on the currency. The peso's rally is attributed to economic reforms, slowing inflation, and plans to boost infrastructure spending.

site_title: Taking urban regeneration to the next level
summary: Lendlease is targeting mixed-use, urban regeneration projects worth over US$1 billion in its major markets. The developer's Paya Lebar Quarter (PLQ) mega-mixed-use development in Singapore, valued at S$3.2 billion, marks an important milestone after a decades-long hiatus in delivering residential projects. Lendlease has previously focused on redevelopment and management of shopping malls, offices, and headquarters. The company's shift towards urban regeneration projects highlights its growth strategy in the sector.

images.alt_text: While Lendlease has expertise in senior living, it does not yet see itself capitalising on that in Singapore. Chief executive for Asia Tony Lombardo says that would require land to be specially designated for such use, and come with a low price.

site_title: Tired to trendy: architects give Russian provinces urban makeover
summary: Architects from the Moscow-based firm Strelka are leading a government-backed urban regeneration project in 40 Russian cities, including Belgorod, to improve public spaces and combat the exodus of young people to Moscow. The project, launched in 2017, aims to create pleasant public spaces and encourage residents to stay in the provinces. Residents in Belgorod have been involved in the design process through public consultations and online voting, resulting in a successful riverside area that has become a hub for local activities. The goal is to extend walkways and cycle paths along the river and replicate the success in other cities.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report covers the volatile dry bulk market, with substantial fluctuations last week. The Capesize segment saw significant price movements. Meanwhile, unrelated articles include London's plan to increase fees for the £10 billion Heathrow upgrade, Tesla's expansion into India, and Japan's carmakers cutting export prices to US to offset tariffs. FedEx partners with a Singapore startup for robot deliveries, and Delta Air Lines offers an upbeat outlook on travel demand. Nissan is set to issue a record-high coupon in a $4 billion bond sale.

site_title: Bond traders on edge with inflation readings to shed light on Fed policy
summary: Bond traders are watching inflation readings closely this week, with the expectation of a higher-than-expected CPI report on Friday, potentially altering market expectations for the Federal Reserve's policy. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell described the factors behind muted price pressures as "transitory," but traders remain skeptical, with futures traders expecting a quarter-point cut in interest rates. Market experts anticipate range-bound trading, with some predicting higher yields if 10-year Treasury yields exceed 2.7% in the coming weeks.

site_title: Qatar Air returns to Syrian airspace to overcome Gulf boycott
summary: Qatar Airways has resumed flights over Syria, a move seen as part of its efforts to overcome a two-year Gulf boycott. The airline's CEO, Akbar al-Baker, stated that the decision is necessary due to the blockade, which has forced Qatar Airways to re-route flights and increase costs. The restored routes, including flights from Beirut and Larnaca to Doha, do not pose safety issues, according to al-Baker. This marks one of the first times a major airline has used Syrian airspace since the 2017 boycott.

site_title: Brexit deal prospects in doubt in 'bad faith' spat
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May urged Labour to reach a Brexit deal by this week, but the opposition party's finance spokesman, John McDonnell, expressed no trust in her after a confidential Brexit talks leak. The leak revealed the government's willingness to give on customs and goods alignment, but McDonnell accused May of acting in bad faith. The Brexit talks will resume on Tuesday, and Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn's involvement is seen as crucial for a deal.

images.alt_text: British Prime Minister Theresa May on Sunday urged Labour to do a deal on Brexit this week, but the main opposition party accused her of acting in bad faith.

site_title: Berkshire meeting offers glimpse of post-Buffett leadership
summary: Warren Buffett and Berkshire Hathaway's leadership team provided insight into the company's future plans and strategies at its annual shareholder meeting. Deputies Greg Abel and Ajit Jain fielded questions on energy investments and insurance, showcasing their expertise. Buffett expressed confidence in the pair's abilities, saying they know the businesses better and work harder than he and vice-chairman Charlie Munger. The meeting also touched on Berkshire's performance, with operating profit rising 5% and net income surging to $21.7 billion. Buffett defended his stance on avoiding technology investments, but acknowledged the success of Apple and Amazon.

site_title: China's natural gas use grows in Q1 amid air pollution fight
summary: China's natural gas consumption grew 11.6% in the first quarter to 77 billion cubic meters, driven by efforts to combat air pollution. The increase follows a 18.1% growth in 2018, as part of a three-year action plan to boost natural gas to 10% of total primary energy consumption by 2020. Meanwhile, refined oil consumption rose 0.4% to 76.9 million tonnes, with petrol consumption increasing 3.7% and diesel consumption decreasing 4.1%.

site_title: Best World's trading halt extended ahead of results release
summary: Best World International's trading halt has been extended for a third time, with the halt to be lifted by May 9, ahead of the release of its quarterly financial results on May 8. The halt was initially imposed on April 24 due to concerns over accounting and sales practices. The company has also received a two-month extension to hold its annual general meeting, which was granted by the Singapore Exchange's regulatory arm. The extension is to accommodate the completion of an independent review on Best World's franchise model in China.

site_title: Newly crowned Thai king carried through Bangkok in royal procession
summary: Thai King Maha Vajiralongkorn began a royal procession around Bangkok on May 5, 2019, as part of his coronation ceremonies. The procession, which lasted 7km, was attended by crowds of at least 200,000 people, many of whom wore yellow, the color associated with the king. The monarch was carried through the streets on a gilded palanquin and visited three royal temples, where he paid homage to Buddha images. The coronation, which took place over three days, marked the beginning of King Vajiralongkorn's 18-month reign, during which he has consolidated the monarchy's authority.

site_title: Amber Park condo sells 115 units on launch weekend
summary: Amber Park, a luxury freehold condominium in Singapore, sold 115 units at an average price of S$2,425 per sq ft during its launch weekend. The development, with 592 units, drew buyers seeking investment value and was popular among Singaporeans and foreigners from China, Malaysia, and Indonesia. The sales are seen as an achievement in the current property market, which has implemented cooling measures and seen a surge of new projects. The project is expected to be completed in 2024.

site_title: HDB unveils plans for new park in upcoming Bidadari estate
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) has unveiled plans for a 10-hectare park, Bidadari Park, in the upcoming Bidadari estate. The park, which will be 10% of the estate's space, features a rustic landscape, a boardwalk across a marshland, and a unique rain tree "island" in a lake. Efforts were made to retain over 350 trees, including a century-old tembusu tree, and more than 2,000 trees across 150 species. The park will have trails, viewing sheds, and an eco-link bridge connecting it to an adjacent park, providing a green sanctuary for residents and wildlife.

site_title: Probe begins after B737 slides off runway into Florida river
summary: Federal investigators have begun searching for the cause of a Boeing 737-800 that slid off a runway into a Florida river during a thunderstorm, injuring 22 of the 143 people on board. The chartered jet, which was attempting to land at a Jacksonville military base, came to rest in the shallow St Johns River. An undamaged flight data recorder has been recovered and sent to Washington for analysis, and investigators are hoping to interview the crew on Sunday. The cockpit voice recorder remains submerged underwater and will be recovered once the plane is lifted out of the water.

images.alt_text: Officials are determining the best way to remove the Miami Air International plane from the St Johns River at the end of the 9,000-foot runway at Naval Air Station Jacksonville.

site_title: Oil advances as jobs growth adds strong demand to supply strains
summary: US jobs growth unexpectedly fell to a 49-year low, boosting oil demand and easing supply concerns. Oil futures rose 0.2% on the day, with West Texas Intermediate crude climbing 13 cents to $61.94 a barrel. Despite supply disruptions, including Russia's pipeline shutdown and potential Opec cuts, the US shale boom and strong domestic economy are supporting prices. Brent crude rose 10 cents to $70.85 a barrel, down 1.8% for the week. Analysts attribute the market's resilience to the US's ability to meet global demand.

site_title: Amber Park condo at East Coast sells 115 units in weekend launch
summary: Singapore's freehold luxury condominium Amber Park sold 115 units at an average price of S$2,425 per sq ft during its launch weekend, out of 150 units launched out of 592 total units. The units were sold over two days, according to City Developments Limited and Hong Realty.

images.alt_text: Unit sizes at Amber Park range from 463 sq ft for a one-bedroom plus study apartment to 5,005 sq ft for the largest penthouse, which has six bedrooms plus a study. Some 150 units were launched over the weekend, out of the development's 592 units, said CDL and sister company Hong Realty.

site_title: Vodafone presses Germany for more help in broadband roll-out
summary: Vodafone is urging the German government to invest in the "last mile" of its broadband networks, a crucial step in expanding ultrafast fibre connections to homes and businesses. The company's Germany chief, Hannes Ametsreiter, believes state investment in infrastructure would be more efficient and fuel competition. Vodafone aims to increase its ultra-fast Gigabit connections to 25 million by 2022 if it can acquire Unitymedia, a unit of Liberty Global. The European Union has not raised major concerns about the deal, improving its chances of going ahead.

site_title: New Scrabble words get the 'OK'
summary: The official international Scrabble dictionary has updated its list of approved words for the first time since 2015, adding 2,800 new words to the list. The new words, approved by Collins, were previously approved by Merriam-Webster last year. The updated list is now available for use in tournaments and at home, offering players more options for game play.

site_title: Gold declines on strong US$, robust stock markets
summary: Gold prices declined to a five-month low of $1,268 an ounce due to a strong US dollar and robust global stock markets, with central banks cited as a key reason for the price fall. Venezuela, Iran, and Libya are among the central banks selling gold, with the World Gold Council reporting a 50-year high in central bank net purchases. The price may be bottoming, with hedge funds and gold jewelers in India and China potentially buying, and US dollar weakness also supporting the price.

site_title: China agrees to restructure debt owed by Republic of Congo
summary: China agreed to restructure debt owed by the Republic of Congo, a precondition for the International Monetary Fund's potential bailout. The restructuring was agreed upon on April 29 at a meeting between a Congolese government delegation and Chinese officials. Details of the restructuring are not immediately available. This move comes as the IMF seeks to address the debt-laden central African nation's economic struggles.

site_title: Pakistan appoints IMF official as new central bank governor amid bailout talks
summary: Pakistan appointed International Monetary Fund (IMF) economist Reza Baqir as its new central bank governor, aiming to finalize a bailout deal to stabilize its economy amid high inflation and declining growth. Baqir, a Pakistani national, replaces Tariq Bajwa, who was unexpectedly removed from his post. The IMF has been pushing for a flexible rupee policy to end repeated economic boom-and-bust cycles. Baqir's appointment comes amid a wobbly economy and criticism of Prime Minister Imran Khan's inability to steady the ship.

site_title: Straits Times Index slowly gaining traction
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) has been perceived as underperforming compared to its US peers since the 2008-2009 global financial crisis. However, technical analysis suggests the STI is gaining traction, with a significant recovery since 2009 and a bullish trend indicated by the Elliott wave count. The index has been testing resistance multiple times, but has shown slight bullish sentiments, indicating a potential for exponential growth.

site_title: China cashes in on cannabis boom
summary: China is cultivating cannabis to produce cannabidiol (CBD), a non-intoxicating compound, despite it not being authorized for consumption in the country. Two regions, Yunnan and Heilongjiang, have relaxed their policies, allowing over 36,000 acres of hemp to be cultivated. Companies like Hanma Investment Group are extracting CBD from the crop, selling it overseas, and planning to expand globally. While China has a history of using cannabis for textiles and traditional medicine, its strict drug-enforcement policies have previously banned cultivation. The movement towards legalization has created global demand for CBD products, with China's relaxation of policies generating significant investment and revenue.

images.alt_text: Legalisation has little chance of coming to China, but companies have begun cultivating the plant to meet overseas demand for cannabidiol. Mr Tian Wei, general manager of Hempsoul, says there will definitely be opportunities for China.

site_title: US: Green New Deal could help an industry once leery of renewables
summary: The US Green New Deal may benefit the utility industry, which was initially hesitant towards renewables. Analysts from CreditSights Inc. note that utilities like Berkshire Hathaway Energy and NextEra Energy can earn a fixed return on wind and solar assets, improving their credit quality. The plan's promotion of electric vehicles also boosts utilities' demand for electricity. However, revived subsidies for residential solar could harm utilities' pricing advantage, as they have successfully lowered the cost of rooftop solar power. The Green New Deal faces opposition in Congress.

site_title: Smart tech the new tool for African farmers
summary: A digital revolution is unfolding in Africa's agriculture sector, improving productivity and reducing costs. Smart gadgets and data analysis are being used to streamline the supply chain, from farmers to consumers. Initiatives such as Lifantou, Pix Fruit, and the Widim Pump are connecting farmers with buyers, reducing intermediaries and costs. Advanced technology, including drones and mobile apps, is providing more accurate crop counts and pricing information, allowing farmers to better negotiate prices and reduce waste. This shift is expected to increase efficiency and improve the livelihoods of African farmers.

site_title: Companies should strive to help cancer survivors continue contributing
summary: Cancer survivors in Singapore face challenges in maintaining their job prospects due to the stigma surrounding chronic health issues. However, companies can play a crucial role in helping survivors continue contributing by providing flexible arrangements and offering psychological support. According to experts, one in four to five people in Singapore will be diagnosed with cancer in their lifetime, with an ageing population leading to a rising number of survivors. Employers can create a supportive work environment by making special arrangements and acknowledging the importance of cancer survivors' contributions.

site_title: K-Reit, Tuan Sing, DFI lead share buybacks
summary: On May 5, 2019, the Straits Times Index (STI) rallied 1.8% over four trading sessions, bringing its 2019 total return to 11.8%. The rally was also seen in the Hang Seng Index and S&P/ASX 200 Index, with 0.1% gains each. Share buybacks led by K-Reit, Tuan Sing, and DFI were notable.

site_title: At least 9 dead as monster cyclone enters Bangladesh
summary: Cyclone Fani, one of the strongest to hit India in years, entered Bangladesh on May 4, 2019, leaving a trail of destruction and killing at least 9 people, including 8 in India and 1 in Bangladesh. Over 400,000 people were evacuated to shelters, with 14 villages inundated by a tidal surge. The storm weakened but still caused widespread damage, including flattened homes and destroyed infrastructure, with many more feared trapped in rubble.

site_title: Philippines taps fake news busters for elections
summary: The Philippines has formed a team of 10 government workers to combat fake news about the upcoming midterm elections. The team, in collaboration with Facebook and a fact-checking group, aims to identify and report misleading online posts. Despite efforts, fake news is expected to spread faster this time due to increased social media usage. Experts emphasize that combating disinformation requires long-term solutions and education on how to spot fake news.

site_title: Theresa May presses Labour to reach Brexit deal, but leaks jeopardise talks
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May urged Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn to reach a cross-party Brexit deal, following poor local election results for both parties. The parties have been negotiating for over a month to secure majority support in parliament. May's minority government has suffered three heavy defeats on her preferred Brexit deal, leading to a delay in Britain's departure. The negotiations come as Labour seeks to capitalize on the Conservative Party's losses in the local elections.

site_title: What the dickens is up with audit firms?
summary: Audit firms are facing scrutiny after high-profile failures, such as Hyflux and California Fitness, resulting in significant losses for investors. A scathing report found that auditors allowed gym members to fund JV Fitness for three years despite the business's financial struggles. This raises concerns about the accountability and effectiveness of audit firms in preventing such failures. The incident highlights the need for greater oversight and regulation in the industry to protect investors and prevent similar cases of corporate malfeasance.

site_title: US stocks savouring 'Goldilocks' moment but risks loom: analysts
summary: US stocks are expected to continue their upward momentum, with indices riding on strong economic growth and contained inflation, dubbed the "Goldilocks" scenario. The Dow Jones Industrial Average has seen its strongest opening to a year since 1999, with the latest jobs report showing 263,000 workers added to payrolls. Analysts warn that optimism about China is levelling off, but a trade deal between Washington and Beijing could boost markets. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite are set to defy expectations of an "earnings recession" with earnings exceeding Wall Street targets.

site_title: Darth Vader's original costume estimated to fetch US$2m at auction
summary: A rare, original Darth Vader costume from the 1980 film "The Empire Strikes Back" is set to be auctioned on May 14 at the Los Angeles Bonhams auction house. The costume, including Vader's iconic helmet, capes, and gloves, is estimated to fetch up to $2 million. This is the first time the costume has been sold at auction, and its sale would make it one of the most valuable Star Wars memorabilia items ever sold.

site_title: Championing SME interests 'is about doing, not talking'
summary: Singapore's SME Committee (SMEC) chairman Kurt Wee is championing small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) by taking action, rather than just talking. Wee, who also heads the Association of SMEs, has implemented initiatives such as the SME Cloud Exchange, a digital platform for businesses, and the Fair Tenancy Framework, which aims to promote fair rental practices. He prioritizes finding ways to cut bureaucratic red tape and simplify regulations, and is pushing for overseas economic node centres to help SMEs access global markets. Wee's goal is to create a supportive environment for SMEs to grow and succeed, both locally and internationally.

site_title: Brazil cosmetics company Natura to invest US$5m in new brands through venture capital funds
summary: Brazilian cosmetics company Natura plans to invest up to $5 million in new beauty and wellness brands in Europe and the US through venture capital funds. The investment is part of the company's efforts to expand its presence globally. Natura posted weaker-than-expected quarterly results due to a sluggish economic recovery in Brazil, but remains on track to deliver targets and reduce its net debt. The company expects to lower its net debt-to-EBITDA ratio to 1.4 by 2021.

site_title: Workforce of the future
summary: The future of work is shifting towards a skills-based and technology-enabled labour market, with collaboration and sustainable growth being key drivers. Experts emphasize the need for adaptability, thoroughness, and lifelong learning agility to stay ahead of technological disruption. Key traits for a future-ready workforce include agility, resilience, and right-skilled individuals leveraging human-technology augmented approaches. The concept of traditional employment is being redefined, with a focus on portfolio careers, flexible work arrangements, and a more integrated and multi-disciplinary approach to work.

site_title: Pakistan fires central bank, tax authority chiefs amid IMF talks
summary: Pakistan's government removed State Bank of Pakistan Governor Tariq Bajwa and Federal Board of Revenue Chairman Mohammad Jehanzeb Khan amid IMF bailout negotiations. The removal comes weeks after Finance Minister Asad Umar was asked to resign, amid criticism of the government's economic handling. The decision follows a downgrade in Pakistan's credit score and a weakened rupee, which has struggled to recover from a 26% decline in 2018. Abdul Hafeez Shaikh, the new finance adviser, is leading talks with the IMF to secure a 13th bailout program.

site_title: Not-so-lucky draws: Fake Singtel, StarHub staff scam 13 of S$30k
summary: Thirteen people in Singapore lost S$30,000 in a lucky draw scam since January. Scammers impersonated Singtel or StarHub staff, contacting victims via Viber and asking for personal info or payment details. Victims were then left with unauthorised transactions on their bank accounts or credit/debit cards. Authorities advise against giving out personal info or making payments to unknown individuals, and those with information can call 1800-255-0000 or report online.

site_title: Olympics-alternative organisation for Tokyo boxing 'not rocket science'
summary: International Olympic Committee President Thomas Bach believes an alternative organization could run the boxing competition at the 2020 Tokyo Olympics if recognition is withdrawn from AIBA due to financial and governance issues. Bach stated that organizing the competition is not "rocket science" and that the IOC will make recommendations on May 22. Bach also emphasized the importance of gender equality in the competition, with a plan to have three women's boxing events and 10 gold medals for men.

site_title: Puerto Rico announces deal to restructure power authority debt
