summary: Puerto Rico has reached a deal with creditors to restructure over $8 billion of debt for its power utility, the Puerto Rico Electric Power Authority (PREPA). The agreement, which requires 67% support from bondholders, aims to reduce debt by 32.5% and shed $3 billion in debt service payments over the next decade. The restructuring plan, which needs US judge approval, includes a special charge on customers to pay off new bonds, with rates increasing over time.

site_title: Sri Lanka catholics turn to TV mass amid bomb threat
summary: Sri Lanka's Catholic Church has cancelled public masses due to fears of a repeat of Easter suicide bombings that killed 257 people. A private Sunday mass will be televised on national television, with Cardinal Malcolm Ranjith conducting the service. The Thewatte National Basilica was suspected to be the target, but no explosives were found. The government has stepped up security and reopened public schools on Monday, while Catholic schools remain shut "until further notice".

site_title: New Bidadari Park with lake, wooded trails to be completed by 2022
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) announced plans to develop a 10-hectare Bidadari Park in Singapore by 2022, featuring a lake, heritage walk, and wooded trails. The park will conserve over 350 mature trees and introduce 2,000 new trees, including wetland and marsh habitats. A tank for Singapore's underground service reservoir will be built beneath the community lawn. The project is a collaboration between HDB, National Parks Board, PUB, and National Heritage Board, aiming to create a rustic and wooded park within the Bidadari estate.

images.alt_text: The new 10-hectare Bidadari Park will form a green lung at the heart of the 93-hectare Bidadari estate.
Lined with lush greenery, the 700-metre Heritage Walk in the new Bidadari Park will recount the estate's history and stories.

site_title: Killer asteroid flattens New York in simulation exercise
summary: An international asteroid impact simulation exercise, led by NASA, ended with a devastating outcome: New York City being flattened by a 100-300 meter asteroid. Despite a simulated 8-year preparation period, scientists were unable to deflect the asteroid, which had a 100% chance of hitting Earth on April 29, 2027. The exercise highlighted the challenges of evacuation, compensation, and global response to such a disaster, with experts debating insurance, legal, and logistical issues.

site_title: Thailand's King Vajiralongkorn formally crowned as divine monarch
summary: Thailand's King Maha Vajiralongkorn was formally crowned as a divine monarch on May 4, 2019, donning the 7.3 kg Great Crown of Victory in a coronation ceremony blending Buddhist and Hindu traditions. Following his father King Bhumibol Adulyadej's death in 2016, King Vajiralongkorn became the constitutional monarch, marking the end of a period of mourning. The coronation marked a significant milestone in Thailand's history, solidifying the king's position as the divine monarch.

site_title: Cheers and screams as new Japan emperor greets the people for the first time
summary: New Japanese Emperor Naruhito and Empress Masako made their first public appearances, greeting crowds in Tokyo on Saturday, three days after Emperor Naruhito's accession to the throne. The event marked the first abdication in 200 years, following former Emperor Akihito's simple ceremony. Cheers and screams filled the air as the royal family waved and smiled from a palace balcony. Emperor Naruhito pledged to work as a symbol of the people, seeking global peace and development, while Empress Masako wore a traditional yellow dress and hat.

site_title: US rejects Tesla bid for tariff exemption for Autopilot 'brain'
summary: US trade officials rejected Tesla's bid for tariff exemption for its Chinese-made Autopilot "brain" due to its strategic importance to China's "Made in China 2025" program. The US Trade Representative's office denied the request, citing the product's links to high-technology industries, including new energy and autonomous vehicles. This decision is part of the Trump administration's efforts to thwart China's development of high-tech industries. Tesla has pending tariff exclusion requests for other Chinese-made components, citing economic harm from increased tariffs.

site_title: GIC buys 10% stake in 6th-largest container terminal operator
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC acquired a 10% stake in Geneva-based Terminal Investment Ltd (TIL), the 6th-largest container terminal operator, at an undisclosed price. TIL's majority shareholder is Mediterranean Shipping Company (MSC), the world's 2nd-largest container shipping line. GIC expects TIL to benefit from growing demand for containerized goods and sees long-term growth potential.

site_title: Who will succeed billionaire Warren Buffett?
summary: Billionaire Warren Buffett's succession plan for Berkshire Hathaway is underway as his annual shareholder meeting begins. Analysts predict that either Gregory Abel or Ajit Jain will succeed Buffett, as he has carefully prepared for a leadership change. Buffett's unique status and the company's lack of transparency will likely lead to a negative market response to his absence. Despite this, Berkshire's solid businesses and cautious investment strategy are expected to remain intact, with the company's culture and investment approach likely unchanged under the new leadership.

site_title: Turkey expects US not to end preferential trade treatment
summary: Turkey expects the US not to terminate its preferential trade treatment under the Generalized System of Preferences (GSP) program, which allows some exports to enter the US duty-free. The US Trade Representative (USTR) had previously determined Turkey was no longer eligible due to its economic development, but the Turkish embassy says this decision will not be implemented. The decision to remove Turkey from the program was supposed to take effect 60 days after notifications to Congress and the Turkish government, but Turkey hopes it will not be enacted.

site_title: Accused operators of illicit 'darknet' market arrested in Germany, Brazil
summary: Three German nationals, Tibo Lousee, Klaus-Martin Frost, and Jonathan Kalla, accused of running the world's largest dark web site, Wall Street Market, have been arrested and charged in two countries following a two-year investigation. The site, which sold drugs, counterfeit goods, and hacking software, was shut down after its operators conducted an "exit scam" and made off with an estimated $11 million in virtual currency. A fourth suspect, Marcos Paulo De Oliveira-Annibale, was arrested in Brazil and accused of being the site's moderator.

site_title: North Korea urgently needs food aid after worst harvest in decade, UN says
summary: North Korea faces its worst harvest in a decade, with 40% of the population in urgent need of food aid. A 1.36 million-ton grain shortage has led to reduced daily state rations, and further cuts are expected between July and September. The UN warns that the situation could deteriorate further if no humanitarian actions are taken. Sanctions imposed by the UN Security Council have deprived the regime of income and undercut its ability to import food, exacerbating the crisis.

site_title: Brazil's far-right president nixes US trip in face of protests
summary: Brazil's President Jair Bolsonaro has cancelled a trip to the US after protests against him being named Person of the Year by the Brazilian-American Chamber of Commerce. Major sponsors, including Delta Air Lines, The Financial Times, and Bain & Co, pulled their support due to his past racist, homophobic, and misogynist remarks. The cancellation is seen as a blow to Bolsonaro, who has sought closer ties with the US, particularly with President Donald Trump.

site_title: SoftBank is said to consider IPO for US$100b Vision Fund
summary: SoftBank is considering an initial public offering (IPO) for its $100 billion Vision Fund, which has invested in companies like Uber and WeWork. The idea is at an early stage, with discussions taking place among executives. An IPO would allow investors to cash out part or all of their stakes. The fund has operated outside traditional venture parameters, investing in mature companies like Nvidia. SoftBank plans to raise an additional $15 billion to fund its investments and is launching a second Vision Fund and a Latin American fund.

site_title: Exxon directors face shareholder revolt over climate change
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp shareholders, including the New York State Common Retirement Fund and the Church of England, launched a proxy fight against the company's directors over its inadequate response to climate change. They urged shareholders to vote against all Exxon directors and in favor of proposals for an independent chairman, a climate change board committee, and a report on lobbying. The investors claim Exxon has failed to respond adequately to climate change despite engaging with the company since 2005, unlike peers such as BP and Royal Dutch Shell.

site_title: US Fed officials diverge on need for possible interest-rate cut
summary: US Federal Reserve officials expressed differing views on the need for a possible interest-rate cut, with two officials, James Bullard and Charles Evans, suggesting the central bank may need to act to lift inflation out of a persistently low trend. This contrasts with Chairman Jerome Powell's dismissal of the recent dip in inflation readings as temporary. Bullard stated he is "open to a rate cut" to combat low inflation, while Evans said he would "not be afraid to act" if a rate cut was warranted.

site_title: Boeing 737 goes into Florida river with 136 on board, no fatalities
summary: A Boeing 737 commercial jet with 136 people on board crashed into the St John's River near Jacksonville, Florida after landing on Friday, but there were no reported fatalities. The flight arrived from Naval Station Guantanamo Bay at around 9:40pm local time. The incident occurred at the end of the runway. An investigation into the cause of the crash has not been reported.

site_title: Main UK parties suffer Brexit battering in local elections
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative Party suffered a significant defeat in local elections, losing over 1,269 seats and control of several local authorities. The main opposition Labour Party also lost ground, with voters turning to smaller parties and independents. The results raise pressure on May and Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn to strike a Brexit deal before the European Parliament elections on May 23, where they risk being wiped out by the Brexit Party. The outcome suggests the days of two-party domination may be over, with centrist and left-wing parties gaining ground.

site_title: Scientology cruise ship faces renewed quarantine at home port in Curacao after measles case
summary: A Church of Scientology cruise ship, quarantined in St Lucia for a measles case, is set to return to its home port in Curacao, where it will face similar restrictions. Health officials plan to board the vessel to identify exposed individuals and those who have been vaccinated or previously had measles. Passengers and crew who meet these criteria may be allowed to disembark, but restrictions will remain in place. The quarantine is a precautionary measure to prevent the spread of the highly contagious disease.

site_title: Venezuela's neighbours accuse Maduro of protecting 'terrorist groups' in Colombia
summary: Venezuela's neighbors, the Lima Group, have accused President Nicolas Maduro of protecting "terrorist groups" in Colombia. The accusation comes days after an attempted military uprising failed to dislodge Maduro from power. Colombian President Ivan Duque alleges that Maduro's government orchestrated an explosion at a military base, which was carried out by Colombian ELN rebels. The Lima Group rejected the attempt to assassinate Duque and undermine regional security, increasing pressure on Maduro's government.

site_title: North Korea fires short-range missiles: Seoul
summary: North Korea launched short-range missiles into the East Sea, with the projectiles traveling 70-200 kilometers from its Hodo peninsula. The missiles were fired from near the east coast town of Wonsan, marking Pyongyang's first such action in over a year. The move aims to pressure Washington as nuclear talks remain deadlocked. The South Korean military reported the incident, which occurred between 9:06 and 9:27 am local time. The missiles' destination was not specified, but they were heading in the northeastern direction.

site_title: Oil edges up after strong economic data, but ends week lower
summary: Oil prices rose 10 cents to settle at $70.85 a barrel, despite weekly declines, due to strong US economic data and production losses in sanctions-hit Iran and Venezuela. The US jobs report showed growth and a low unemployment rate, increasing expectations for strong crude demand. Oil futures were capped by rising US crude inventories and a record 12.3 million barrels per day production. The global benchmark Brent crude oil futures shed 2.6% for the week, breaking a five-week winning streak.

site_title: China's tech companies selling convertible bonds at record pace
summary: Chinese tech companies are raising record amounts in convertible bonds, with $3.4 billion raised this year, nearly double the total in 2018. A global stock rally and low financing costs are driving the surge, with companies like iQiyi and Bilibili tapping the market. Investors are betting on convertible bonds for potential equity gains, and some companies are using a structure to sell bonds with rosier valuation targets. This is also attracting established firms, with Lenovo selling $675 million in convertibles at a lower coupon rate than its straight bonds.

site_title: Ride-hailing drivers in New York to strike ahead of Uber IPO
summary: Uber drivers in New York will strike on May 8, two hours before the ride-hailing company's IPO, protesting unfair employment conditions. The strike, part of a nationwide effort, demands job security, livable incomes, and a cap on fare collection. Drivers claim Uber sets their rates and controls their workday, treating them as independent contractors despite the company's claims. The protests come ahead of Uber's expected IPO valuation of $80.5 billion to $91.5 billion, with the company yet to turn a profit.

images.alt_text: Uber Technologies Inc's drivers in New York will go on strike next week shortly before the ride-hailing company goes public to protest what they view as unfair employment conditions, a taxi union said on Friday.

site_title: US jobs grow from strength to strength with 263,000 gain
summary: US jobs grew by 263,000 in April, exceeding forecasts, with the jobless rate dipping to a 49-year low of 3.6%. Wage gains were slightly cooler than expected, but inflation appears subdued. The solid reading supports calls for a Federal Reserve interest-rate cut, despite policymakers maintaining a patient stance. The labor market remains strong, with construction and healthcare sectors posting gains, while retail employment fell for the third straight month.

site_title: Exxon Mobil sues Cuba for US$280m over expropriated property
summary: Exxon Mobil has sued Cuba's state-owned Cupet and Cimex Corp for $280 million over seized assets, including a refinery and gasoline stations, following Fidel Castro's revolution. The lawsuit, filed under the Helms-Burton Act, allows US corporations to sue Cuban companies for nationalized property. Exxon Mobil claims the Cuban defendants trafficked in confiscated property, while Cuba argues the US has no jurisdiction over its citizens' assets. This is the first time a US corporation has sued Cuba since the Trump administration lifted previous waiver provisions.

site_title: Trump says he and Putin discussed new nuclear pact possibly including China
summary: US President Donald Trump stated that he and Russian President Vladimir Putin discussed a potential new nuclear pact that could include China, aiming to limit nuclear arms. The pact could replace the 2011 New START treaty, which expires in 2021, and would require the US, Russia, and China to limit deployed strategic nuclear warheads and delivery systems. Trump cited the expense of maintaining the US nuclear arsenal as a motivating factor, and China had "felt very strongly" about joining the agreement. The two leaders also discussed efforts to persuade North Korea to give up nuclear weapons and the political discord in Venezuela and Ukraine.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump said he and Russian President Vladimir Putin discussed on Friday the possibility of a new accord limiting nuclear arms that could eventually include China in what would be a major deal between the globe's top three atomic powers.

site_title: Disney to sell Fox regional sports networks to Sinclair for US$9.6b
summary: Disney to sell 21 regional sports networks to Sinclair Broadcast Group for $9.6 billion, clearing the way for its purchase of 21st Century Fox's film and television assets. The deal, announced on May 3, 2019, excludes the New York Yankees team's regional sports network, Yes. Sinclair, the largest US broadcast station owner, plans to add channels such as Fox Sports Detroit and Fox Sports Florida to its existing sports business. The acquisition is expected to be highly accretive to free cash flow and brings consolidated net leverage to 4.7x and 5.1x.

site_title: Thailand to crown its newlywed king in elaborate ceremonies
summary: Thailand's King Maha Vajiralongkorn is set to undergo intricate Buddhist and Brahmin ceremonies to symbolically transform him into a living god. The coronation, held after a period of mourning, marks the first monarch in nearly seven decades. King Vajiralongkorn, 66, will be joined by new Queen Suthida and will undergo a royal purification ritual, followed by a coronation ceremony, including the use of ancient cannons and sacred waters. The event is a mix of Buddhist and Hindu traditions, and marks the beginning of King Vajiralongkorn's reign as Rama X.

site_title: UOB says Singapore home loans flat, with growth coming from region
summary: UOB reported a 8% rise in its Q1 profit to S$1.05 billion, driven by growth in its regional markets. The bank's housing loans rose to S$68.7 billion, with Singapore loans remaining flat quarter-on-quarter. Despite the cooling measures, UOB expects mid single-digit loan growth for the year, mainly from regional connectivity opportunities. The bank's global network and subsidiaries in Asean, China, and other countries contributed to the growth.

site_title: Trading halt on Cordlife after its shares surge 20%
summary: Singaporean company Cordlife halted trading after its shares surged 20% due to "unusual price movements." The company attributed the price hike to a strategic review, but did not provide any specific information. The Singapore Exchange had previously queried the company about the unusual price movements. Cordlife's shares closed at a 51/2-month high before the trading halt, pending an announcement. The company requested the halt to be lifted on Monday.

site_title: US State Department approves nearly US$6b in weapons sales to Gulf allies
summary: The US State Department has approved nearly $6 billion in weapons sales to Gulf allies, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates. The sales include Patriot missile systems, F-16 fighter jets, and other munitions, with the goal of countering Iranian influence in the region. The Pentagon notified Congress of the certification, and the principal contractors for the sales are Raytheon Co and Lockheed Martin Co. The deals are part of the US's efforts to maintain its military presence in the region and align with its allies in the face of Iranian expansion.

site_title: Politics to decide Indian rupee's near-term fate
summary: India's rupee is expected to weaken nearly 2% to 70.67 US dollars in six months due to a strong US dollar, higher global oil prices, and historical seasonality patterns, according to a Reuters survey of 50 strategists. The rupee has remained under pressure despite the Reserve Bank of India's recent rate cuts, and a wider trade deficit poses a threat. Analysts predict the rupee will strengthen slightly to 70.50 in a year, driven by stable inflation and fiscal policy restraint.

site_title: Organisers taken aback by demand for women's World Cup tickets
summary: Organisers of the 2019 women's World Cup in France are surprised by the high demand for foreign tickets, with some events potentially sold out. The tournament, which takes place from June 7 to July 7, has generated significant interest from fans worldwide. Despite the surge in demand, ticket prices remain unchanged. The high demand has left tournament officials scrambling to meet the increased interest.

site_title: Jho Low's US$39m Los Angeles mansion to be put up for sale
summary: US prosecutors and Low Taek Jho's representatives plan to sell a $39 million Los Angeles mansion he bought in 2012 with allegedly stolen 1MDB funds. The empty mansion, valued at $690,000 annually in taxes, insurance, and maintenance, will be sold to recover funds. Proceeds will replace the property in the government's forfeiture case. US authorities are preparing to return $200 million of recovered funds to Malaysia, with Low denying wrongdoing and being sought by Malaysian and US authorities.

site_title: Canadian court rules Trudeau's carbon tax constitutional
summary: A Canadian court ruled that the federal carbon tax imposed by Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's government is constitutional, rejecting a challenge from the conservative provincial government of Saskatchewan. The 3-2 decision allows the tax to remain in effect, despite criticism from right-leaning parties that it disproportionately penalizes car-dependent Canadians. The ruling is a victory for Trudeau ahead of the national election in October, with the Liberal government welcoming the decision as an issue of national concern.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise on strong results, upbeat US jobs data
summary: European shares rose 0.4% on Friday, recovering from their worst day in six weeks, driven by strong US jobs data and upbeat results from Adidas and HSBC. US job growth surged in April, with the unemployment rate hitting a 49-year low of 3.6%, supporting sustained economic activity. Shares in HSBC and Adidas rose nearly 2% and 10% respectively, while the personal and household goods sector gained 1.2%.

site_title: UOB posts 8% rise in Q1 profit to S$1.05b on stronger income growth
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) reported an 8% increase in Q1 profit to S$1.05 billion, driven by stronger income growth and broad-based loan growth of 12%. Net interest income rose 8% to S$1.59 billion, while net fee and commission income declined 7% to S$479 million. The bank's group retail business saw a 1% pretax profit increase. Despite a cautious tone from management, UOB's shares closed down 0.29% to S$27.77.

site_title: SGX mulls triple listing of steel derivatives
summary: SGX is considering a triple listing of steel derivatives, aiming to create a "virtual steel mill" that offers easier access to the fragmented ferrous market via a single platform. The listings would provide exposure to steel activity in China, the world's top steel producer and consumer. Currently, steel exchange-traded products are spread across multiple global exchanges. SGX will gauge industry interest and consider a launch within the next 12 months, potentially attracting investors beyond the steel sector.

site_title: Gold falls as Fed policymakers dim outlook on rate cuts
summary: US Federal Reserve policymakers voted unanimously to keep interest rates steady, downplaying potential rate cuts in 2019. This decision strengthened the US dollar and put pressure on gold prices. Strong US economic activities and tight labor conditions have bolstered risk sentiments, curbing safe haven demand for gold. As a result, gold prices fell to four-month lows, with technical analysis suggesting a continuation of the negative trend scenario, potentially taking prices to $1,245.00.

site_title: US cracks down on Iran uranium production, nuclear plant
summary: The US has cracked down on Iran's uranium production and nuclear plant, forcing Iran to stop producing low-enriched uranium and expanding its nuclear power plant. The US has also renewed waivers for Russia, China, and European countries to pursue cooperation programs aimed at preventing Iran from reactivating a defunct nuclear weapons program. The move is part of the Trump administration's efforts to isolate Iran and impose economic sanctions, following the US withdrawal from the 2015 nuclear deal.

site_title: Carbon tax best way to cut greenhouse gas emissions: IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund recommends a carbon tax of $70 per ton of carbon dioxide as the most efficient way to cut greenhouse gas emissions. However, the proposal has faced opposition, as seen in France, where a planned increase in the carbon tax led to the Yellow Vest protest movement, forcing the government to suspend the plan.

site_title: US to return US$200m 1MDB-linked funds to Malaysia
summary: US authorities are set to return approximately US$200 million in funds allegedly misappropriated from 1MDB, a troubled Malaysian state fund, to Malaysia. The funds include US$140 million from the sale of a New York hotel stake and US$60 million from a Wolf of Wall Street movie settlement. The transfer may occur as early as next week, according to sources familiar with the matter.

site_title: Lippo Karawaci a star performer in Asian junk-dollar bonds
summary: Lippo Karawaci, an Indonesian developer controlled by billionaire Riady family, has rebounded from distress to become a top performer in the Asia junk-dollar bond market. The company has raised US$730 million through a rights issue and secured US$280 million in cash to pay down debt. Improved sentiment for developers, a rally in emerging market assets, and a stable rupiah are contributing to the turnaround. Lippo Karawaci plans to deploy raised funds to delever its balance sheet and invest in its flagship project, Meikarta, which may require willing creditors to accept longer maturities.

site_title: Of facts and falsehoods
summary: Singapore's Protection from Online Falsehoods and Manipulation Bill (POFMB) aims to combat harmful online falsehoods while balancing freedom of speech. Critics argue the law will stifle public discourse and academic freedom, but proponents counter that it strikes a balance between protecting responsible speech and suppressing false information. Key features of the law include targeting falsehoods, not opinions, and providing a range of counter-measures, such as corrections and judicial oversight. The law also holds tech companies accountable for harmful content on their platforms. While POFMB is not perfect, it is a necessary tool in the fight against "fake news" and aims to enhance Singaporeans' resilience against deliberate online falsehoods.

site_title: Overseas commercial and industrial assets, data centres, student housing on radar of Singapore investors: CBRE
summary: Singapore investors remain keen on overseas commercial and industrial assets, with data centres and student housing gaining interest. The country overtook China as the biggest Asian investor in global property markets in 2018, with US$18 billion in capital flows. Last year's top investments included the acquisition of Shanghai's tallest twin towers and a London office building. This year, CBRE projects Asia-to-global investments will rise to US$61 billion, with Singapore investors favoring the US, UK, and China.

site_title: Formugenix seeks seed capital to help take research to the market
summary: Formugenix, a Singapore-based contract research organisation (CRO), is seeking seed funding to expand its capabilities and reach in the region. Founded in June 2018, the startup aims to help small and medium enterprises and academic institutes bring their products to the market. With expertise in product formulation and clinical trials, Formugenix plans to secure a seed raise of S$1-1.5 million by the third quarter of this year, with projected revenue from fee-for-service, collaborative, and proprietary product licensing models.

site_title: SembMarine's Q1 net profit falls 67.8% to S$1.7m
summary: SembCorp Marine's Q1 net profit fell 67.8% to S$1.7 million, due to lower revenue from rigs and floaters, and offshore platform projects. Turnover declined 31.3% to S$810.6 million and gross profit fell 49.5%. The company expects global capex spend to improve, but competition remains intense. SembMarine will manage costs and capitalise on new business opportunities. Chairman Mohd Hassan Marican suggests the firm may be approaching the bottom of a down cycle, with potential recovery in 2019 or 2020.

site_title: Beyond Meat makes history with the biggest US IPO pop since 2008 crisis
summary: Beyond Meat made history with its largest US IPO debut since 2008, with its shares nearly tripling in the first day of trading. The company's valuation soared to $3.38 billion after its opening price of $25 surged to $65.75. Backed by Leonardo DiCaprio and Bill Gates, Beyond Meat tapped into the growing trend of plant-based diets, with its products already sold in thousands of supermarkets and restaurants. Despite recording a net loss of $30 million in 2018, the company aims to expand its marketing channels, invest in production capabilities, and enhance its technology.

site_title: Watch oil price movement for clues on US$ direction
summary: US oil prices may provide clues about the direction of the US dollar, with prevailing resistance-testing patterns suggesting an upward move. However, a recent announcement by President Trump on imposing sanctions on Iran and countries dealing with it did not trigger a massive jump in oil prices, contrary to initial reports. Instead, the charts indicate a mix of falsehoods and bluster, with the US dollar expected to continue its slow and steady rise, potentially targeting a longer-term target near $100.5.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Hyflux, a water treatment firm, may receive a S$400 million emergency injection from Utico, a UAE-based utilities group, to address its debt restructuring. The funds will be used for equity and working capital purposes. Hyflux has also extended its debt moratorium to May 24. Meanwhile, Acromec secured a S$4.7 million contract for a laboratory and office fit-out project, expected to contribute positively to its earnings. Serrano, an interior design firm, announced the resignation of its CEO, Tan Han Beng, who will become a corporate adviser to the board.

site_title: Hong Kong's best stock rally since 2015 is under threat
summary: Hong Kong's benchmark Hang Seng Index, which has risen 16% this year, may face a correction due to weakening mainland equities, rising borrowing costs, and Chinese investors pulling out. The index is stuck around 30,000 points, near a key level, and has slipped 0.3% since reaching a nearly 10-month high. Economists predict a weaker local economy and a stronger greenback may further erode investor sentiment.

site_title: Saudi developer Raza plans projects for a more open society
summary: Saudi developer Raza plans mixed-use projects in Riyadh, combining offices, homes, and leisure facilities, as part of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's efforts to create a more open society. The firm's CEO, Waleed Aleisa, attributes the shift to changes in lifestyle, with a growing young population and increasing female participation in the job market. Raza aims to double its assets under management to 26 billion riyals by 2024, expanding its services to include asset management, property management, and commercial services.

site_title: How to move a masterpiece? If it's this big, very carefully
summary: The massive 1884 painting "La Jeunesse de Bacchus" by William-Adolphe Bouguereau, measuring 20 feet long and nearly 11 feet high, was carefully transported from Paris to New York for a Sotheby's auction. The 20-person team required a custom roller and a crane to move the painting, which had remained in the same studio for 135 years. The painting's original stretcher and hardware, as well as its thick, ornately carved frame, helped maintain its condition. Experts predict a high price, with estimates ranging from $25 million to $35 million, making it a rare pre-modern work in Sotheby's history.

site_title: Advantage to Barcelona, Ajax in Champions League semis
summary: English teams Liverpool and Tottenham Hotspur face a tough task to overturn their deficits after the first legs of the UEFA Champions League semi-finals. Barcelona, the bookies' favorites, secured a 3-0 win over Liverpool, while Ajax Amsterdam took a 1-0 lead over Tottenham Hotspur. Liverpool's Jurgen Klopp will look to draw motivation from their 2005 Champions League comeback, but the team's lack of away goals at the Nou Camp puts them at a disadvantage. Meanwhile, Ajax will aim to produce a disciplined performance at home to secure their spot in the final.

site_title: Great Eastern Q1 net profit more than doubles to S$342.7m
summary: Great Eastern's net profit for Q1 2019 more than doubled to S$342.7 million, driven by higher valuation of its shareholders' fund investments and favourable market conditions. Earnings per share rose to 72 cents from 32 cents a year ago, but operating profit from its insurance business declined 8% to S$150 million. Total weighted new sales rose 6% to S$249.4 million, while non-operating profit rebounded to S$74.6 million. The company's performance may be affected by volatility in global financial markets, and it will continue its digital transformation journey to elevate customer experience.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Sembcorp Marine reports back-to-back quarters of black ink, driven by improving outlook in the offshore production space. The company's gearing levels are a concern, but successful monetization of its rig inventory should ease pressure. Frasers Hospitality Trust sees stable Singapore operations, with revenue per available room rising 2.2% year-over-year, but expects muted near-term growth due to new supply in the Bugis micro-market.

site_title: Mansions move slowly, condos pop as Toronto enters spring buying season
summary: Toronto's spring buying season is underway, with condos selling quickly and at higher prices, while single-family homes remain slow to sell. Resale condo listings have surged 10% in the first quarter, and the price differential between condos and low-rise homes has narrowed to its lowest level in four years, sparking competition for condos. However, single-family homes are struggling, with prices up only half a percent in March from last year. Experts attribute the disparity to tighter mortgage regulations and foreign buyer taxes, which have led to a shift towards condo sales.

site_title: Bridgewater's Ray Dalio tops list of top-earning hedge fund managers
summary: Ray Dalio, co-founder of Bridgewater Associates, tops the list of top-earning hedge fund managers with estimated earnings of US$2 billion in 2019, surpassing James H Simons of Renaissance Technologies and Kenneth Griffin of Citadel. Dalio's earnings reflect a strong performance by Bridgewater, which saw a 14.6% gain in 2018. Despite his significant income, Dalio has raised concerns about income inequality and the shortcomings of capitalism, stating that even he thinks capitalism is "broken."

site_title: Lower prices, festive demand boost gold purchases in India, Singapore
summary: Gold demand surged in India and Singapore, driven by lower prices ahead of the Akshaya Tritiya festival. In India, retail demand improved due to falling prices, with local gold futures reaching a four-month low. Dealers in India charged up to $2 an ounce over official prices, while in Singapore, premiums remained steady. The World Gold Council expects India's gold demand to rise in the June quarter due to a higher number of auspicious days for weddings and lower local prices.

site_title: Time to buy Bitcoin, says strategist who warned of late-2018 plunge
summary: Fundstrat technical strategist Robert Sluymer recommends buying Bitcoin amid its sustained recovery, citing its rebound from a 200-week moving average and breakout from a first-quarter trading range. Bitcoin rose 5.9% to $5,724.57, with Sluymer expecting a second-half rally through $6,000 resistance. This marks a significant turnaround from his warning in November that Bitcoin had suffered "significant technical damage" that could take months to repair. Sluymer advises investors to use recent weakness to accumulate Bitcoin, citing a bullish longer-term technical profile.

site_title: Asia business powers HSBC's 31% Q1 profit rise
summary: HSBC Holdings reported a 31% rise in first-quarter profit, driven by a surge in income from its core Asian business and lower costs. The bank's operating expenses dropped 12% in the quarter, despite a poor performance from its investment banking division. Asia accounted for 81% of overall profits, with pretax profit rising 5% to $5 billion. The bank's US business continued to underperform, but its retail customer numbers increased.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 5.06 points to 1,637.30 on Friday, driven by a gain of 447 stocks versus 395 losers. The index closed at 2.8 billion lots worth RM2.1 billion.

site_title: Singapore can help EU firms looking to expand in Asia amid shifts in global economy: Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat of Singapore stated that the economic center of gravity is shifting globally towards Asia, and Singapore can play a role in helping European firms expand in the region. The EU-Singapore Free Trade Agreement and other agreements aim to strengthen economic ties between the two sides. Singapore is investing in research and innovation, a skilled workforce, and global partnerships to attract European companies, particularly those already based in Singapore. The country hopes to leverage its position as a global Asian hub for technology, innovation, and enterprise.

site_title: Brexit gives London homebuyers steep discounts
summary: London homebuyers took advantage of Brexit uncertainty to secure steep discounts in the first quarter, with prices for homes under £2 million (S$3.54 million) falling the most in a decade. Prices in the capital's most sought-after districts declined due to the ongoing disagreement among politicians on the UK's withdrawal from the European Union. This decrease marks a significant change in the market, with the uncertainty surrounding Brexit affecting the city's real estate market.

site_title: Singapore factory sentiment cools in April as exports, output slow
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector showed a decline in April, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) dipping to 50.3, down 0.5 points from the previous month. The electronics industry also saw a contraction, with the PMI falling to 49.5. The decline was attributed to slower growth in new orders, exports, and output. Experts expect manufacturing growth to continue contracting marginally in Q2 2019 due to global uncertainties and the ongoing US-China trade war.

site_title: Resources Prima confirms Chongqing property deal off the table
summary: Resources Prima Group, a Catalist-listed coal miner, has confirmed that its bid to buy a 2,332 square meter commercial property in Chongqing, China has fallen through. The binding MOU lapsed at the end of 2018 due to unsatisfactory results from a scoping exercise, and no extension of the MOU period was agreed upon. The talks failed to yield a definitive agreement, resulting in the cancellation of the deal.

site_title: Hotel chains hesitate to jump onto Airbnb bandwagon
summary: Hotel chains Hyatt and Hilton are hesitant to join the home-sharing market, citing profitability concerns. Hyatt CEO Mark Hoplamazian stated that investing in home-sharing startups, such as Onefinestay and Oasis Collections, poses a difficult path to profitability. Despite this, other companies like New World and WeWork are actively exploring home-sharing opportunities.

site_title: Sorrell's S4 Capital sets up APAC HQ in Singapore
summary: S4 Capital, a digital advertising company led by former WPP CEO Martin Sorrell, has established its Asia-Pacific headquarters in Singapore. The move aims to increase competition in the region's digital ad space and gain access to first-party data. S4 Capital promises to offer a more agile and innovative alternative to traditional advertising agencies. With Sorrell's expertise and the company's digital focus, it is poised to disrupt the market and challenge established players in the region.

site_title: Oxford Properties to sell 50% stake in 4 hotels in Canada's BC, Alberta
summary: Oxford Properties Group, a Canadian real estate firm, plans to sell a 50% stake in four iconic hotels in British Columbia and Alberta for over C$1 billion. The four Fairmont hotels in Whistler, Lake Louise, Banff Springs, and Jasper Park have over 2,200 rooms and attract 1.2 million guests annually. Oxford will retain an equity stake and manage the assets, with the hotels continuing to operate under the Fairmont brand. The sale is part of Oxford's strategy to grow its global partner program, which now manages over C$18 billion of third-party capital.

site_title: Why it could be smart to bet on climate change
summary: Investors who bet against climate change consensus models have historically lost money, suggesting it's wise to bet on climate change. A study found that some investors consistently bet on scientists being right, despite skepticism from conservatives, particularly in the US. Even those who express no concern or skepticism about climate change have successfully bet on its reality. This trend indicates a shift in investor sentiment, which could prompt governments to align policies with climate science. As a result, it may be smart to bet on climate change, as the market increasingly recognizes its inevitability.

site_title: Cyber security eats into StarHub's profit
summary: StarHub's Q1 net profit fell 14.2% to S$54 million due to increased costs from its cyber security services, which reported operating losses of S$11.4 million. The company's push into cyber security added to its top line, but the growth came at a cost. This marks a significant decline from the previous year's net profit.

site_title: Singapore stocks finish weak on low risk appetite
summary: Singapore shares ended the day flat on Friday, finishing 0.03% lower as investors turned cautious ahead of US jobs data. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,392.29, with OCBC Bank's shares falling 1.48% after reporting lower earnings. Despite this, analysts see upside potential for OCBC, and other stocks like Cordlife and CapitaLand rose 20% and 1.98% respectively. The market may remain range-bound in the coming months, with DBS Group Research predicting a range of 3,300 to 3,450 for the STI.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher after strong jobs data
summary: US stocks opened higher on Friday, driven by strong job growth in April and steady wage growth, supporting the Federal Reserve's patient view on interest rate hikes. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 71.35 points, the S&P 500 opened higher by 11.69 points, and the Nasdaq Composite gained 56.11 points, all at the opening bell.

site_title: Absolutely no room for harassment
summary: The CFA Institute emphasizes the importance of professional conduct in the workplace, stating that harassment, whether sexual or non-sexual, is prohibited. A case study highlights two instances of misconduct: one where a colleague repeatedly made personal comments and physical contact towards a colleague, and another where a colleague bullied and harassed a colleague after being disciplined for their own misconduct. The CFA Institute's Code of Ethics and Standards of Professional Conduct condemn such behavior, which undermines professional reputation and integrity. The cases underscore the need for workplaces to develop and enforce clear policies and disciplinary procedures to prevent harassment and misconduct.

site_title: Frasers Property Q2 bottom line rises 8.3% to S$120 million
summary: Frasers Property's Q2 net profit rose 8.3% to S$120.4 million, driven by fair value changes and revenue contributions from Australia. Revenue increased 11.1% to S$934.25 million, with earnings per share rising to 2.81 cents. The company also announced an interim dividend of 2.4 cents per share. For the six months ended March, net profit jumped 37.2% to S$265.99 million and revenue rose 26.9% year-on-year to S$2.01 billion.

site_title: Reits
summary:
Key real estate news includes: 
- Singapore's Good Class Bungalow prices are rising. 
- US mortgage rates have risen for the first time in five weeks. 
- A Q3 wave of condo launches in Singapore may test demand for prime projects above $3,000 psf. 
- Manhattan rents have reached a record high, with more increases expected. 
- Goldman Sachs acquired $262 billion worth of Seoul hotel and retail assets. 
- UK homebuyer demand has rebounded to a six-month high. 
- New World Group is selling China property assets.

site_title: Fold your horses
summary: BMW has unveiled its new Z4, a powerful roadster that immerses drivers in the sensations of driving. The car features a driver-focused dashboard and a minimalist design, with a roof that opens up to reveal two seats. The Z4's exterior design is aggressive and attention-grabbing, with a "phalliform" appearance that has drawn comparisons to classic roadsters. The car's interior can be easily transformed from indoors to outdoors with a switch, allowing drivers to feel connected to the environment. The Z4 is part of BMW's adrenaline tourism initiative, emphasizing the thrill of driving.

site_title: US: Wall Street climbs as jobs data supports upbeat economic outlook
summary: US stocks rose on Friday, with the Nasdaq registering a record high close, as stronger-than-expected job growth in April and muted wage gains left investors optimistic about the economy and interest rates. The Labor Department reported 263,000 jobs added in April, with the unemployment rate at 3.6%, and average hourly earnings just shy of expectations. The data supports the Federal Reserve's patient stance on raising interest rates, boosting stocks.

site_title: Rich Capital's property head joins The Place as COO
summary: The Place Holdings has appointed Kam Tin Seah, 54, as its new chief operating officer (COO), following his departure from Rich Capital Holdings, where he worked since 2018. Seah's predecessor, Meng Kuang-Yi, took over as marketing director. The announcement led to a 14.8% increase in The Place Holdings' counter price to 3.1 Singapore cents.

site_title: Beware vegan 'meat' peddled by venture capitalists
summary: Venture capitalists' involvement in the plant-based meat alternative industry raises concerns about ethics and the law. As Beyond Meat and Impossible Burgers gain popularity, the focus shifts from the industry's potential to create a more sustainable food source to the companies' motivations and values. With venture capitalists prioritizing profit over ethics, the industry may prioritize product tweaking and consumer addiction over nutritional value and environmental sustainability, potentially leading to a "Theranos of food" scenario. Regulators must step in to ensure accountability and prevent the industry from deviating from its original goal of creating a more sustainable food source.

site_title: Kingboard Copper loses free float
summary: Kingboard Copper Foil Holdings, a mainboard-listed company, has lost its free float after its controlling shareholder, Kingboard Laminates Holdings, reached 95.69% ownership. The offeror plans to delist the counter, and trading will be suspended on May 16. Minority investors will receive S$0.60 in cash for each share, deemed "not fair but reasonable" by an independent financial adviser. The buy-out price is part of a privatisation bid by the controlling shareholder, which is majority owned by Hong Kong's Kingboard Holdings.

site_title: Marriott CEO Arne Sorenson has cancer, plans to stay in role
summary: Marriott CEO Arne Sorenson, 60, has been diagnosed with stage 2 pancreatic cancer, but plans to continue working while undergoing treatment. Sorenson expects chemotherapy to begin next week, followed by surgery by the end of the year. He believes his early-stage cancer diagnosis and treatment can lead to a complete cure. Despite the challenges of the disease, Sorenson is committed to continuing his work, and Marriott's executive team is supporting him.

site_title: Hyflux says it could get S$400m from UAE utility group Utico
summary: Hyflux, a water treatment company, may receive an S$400 million emergency investment from UAE-based Utico FZC. Utico plans to invest in Hyflux's key entities to keep them "intact and operational", with funds going towards equity and working capital. This deal is part of Hyflux's restructuring efforts, which include talks with other potential investors. The move aims to address the company's debt crisis, which includes billions in claims from creditors.

site_title: Tesla raises size of share sale, Musk to buy more
summary: Tesla has raised the size of its planned share offering to 3.1 million shares at $243 apiece, with CEO Elon Musk now committing to buy up to $25 million worth of shares, more than double his initial commitment. The company aims to raise up to $2.3 billion in new capital to overcome sales challenges and develop new product lines. This move eases concerns about Tesla's ability to turn a profit, following repeated forecast delays.

site_title: Election spending props up Indonesia's GDP Q1 growth despite central bank tightening
summary: Indonesia's economy maintained steady growth in Q1 2019, expanding 5.18% year-on-year, driven by robust consumption growth from election spending. This surpasses Bank Indonesia's 5.2% projection and analysts' forecast of 5.0-5.4%. Despite central bank tightening and weak foreign investment, economists attribute the resilience to easing lending rules. President Joko Widodo's election victory is seen as a boost to economic growth prospects, but some analysts question his ability to address structural weaknesses in the economy.

site_title: 10 million North Koreans face food shortages after bleak harvest
summary: About 10 million North Koreans, 40% of the population, face food shortages due to a bleak harvest caused by heat and drought. The country collected 4.9 million tons of food crops last year, the lowest in a decade, and is short of 1.4 million tons of grains. The UN warns that further cuts to food rations could push families into a hunger crisis, with many relying on a monotonous diet of rice and kimchi with little protein. The country's economic sanctions and limited food assistance exacerbate the crisis.

site_title: UK plays catch-up on infrastructure as spending beats EU peers
summary: The UK has increased its infrastructure spending, beating its European Union peers, to catch up on years of under-investment. In 2017, government investment in infrastructure accounted for 2.3% of total public spending, higher than in Germany, France, and Italy. The UK's infrastructure stock remains smaller than in France and Italy, but has grown faster than in Germany. This increased spending may be attributed to efforts to stimulate the economy after the financial crisis, with projects including superfast broadband and the High-Speed 2 railway line.

site_title: US job growth surges; unemployment rate falls to 3.6 per cent
summary: US job growth surged in April, with nonfarm payrolls increasing by 263,000 jobs, the lowest unemployment rate in 49 years at 3.6%, and average hourly earnings rising 0.2%. Despite strong job growth, some slack remains in the labor market, as 490,000 people left the labor force in April. This suggests the economy may not be at full capacity. The Federal Reserve's decision to keep interest rates unchanged signals little desire to adjust monetary policy anytime soon.

site_title: StarHub Q1 net profit falls 14.2% on cybersecurity investment losses
summary: StarHub's Q1 net profit fell 14.2% to S$54 million due to losses in its cybersecurity business. Revenue rose 6% to S$596.8 million, driven by the enterprise business, but operating expenses increased 9.4% to S$524.7 million, with cybersecurity costs nearly tripling. The company's cybersecurity investment losses outweighed revenue growth, leading to the decline in net profit.

site_title: Broadway Industrial Group warns of likely Q1 net loss
summary: Broadway Industrial Group, a precision manufacturer, has warned of an expected Q1 net loss due to lower revenue from its hard disk drive business. The company expects to release full financial results on May 15, advising shareholders to exercise caution when dealing in shares until then. This guidance is based on a review of draft financial results, and more details will be provided in the full report.

site_title: GM recalls 368,000 larger duty trucks for fire risks
summary: General Motors is recalling 368,000 medium- and heavy-duty diesel trucks due to a fire risk. The affected vehicles, including 2019 Chevrolet Silverado and GMC Sierra trucks, have engine-block heaters with a possible short circuit. There have been 19 reported fires, but no injuries, accidents, or fatalities. The remedy is still under development, and GM has stopped building trucks with the optional combination. The company is working with the supplier to obtain the required parts as quickly as possible.

images.alt_text: General Motors Co said Friday it is recalling 368,000 medium- and heavy-duty diesel trucks equipped with engine-block heaters for fire risks after 19 reports of fires.

site_title: Electric cars and solar compete for the same parts
summary: Electric vehicle manufacturers and solar panel companies are competing for high-tech components, specifically electric transistors, which convert power between direct and alternating current. A shortage of these parts has caused wait times to surge from 8 weeks to over 50 weeks, affecting companies like Enphase Energy and SolarEdge Technologies. However, manufacturers are now ramping up output and signing long-term supply deals, with some wait times decreasing to about 45 weeks. Analysts predict the issue is largely behind them, with production capacity increasing to meet growing demand.

site_title: More Sri Lanka attacks feared as Muslims condemn Easter bombs
summary: Sri Lanka bolstered security with fears of attacks against bridges in the capital as Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe vowed to hunt down remaining Islamic State extremists behind the deadly Easter bombings. The attacks killed 257 people, and authorities believe Islamist extremists are planning further attacks. Sri Lanka's minority Muslims condemned the attacks and held prayers under tight security, while the government confirmed that most of the conspirators have been arrested or killed. The country is also receiving international help, with foreign intelligence services working alongside local counterparts to track down the remaining extremists.

images.alt_text: Banners in front of a mosque condemned the atrocities and expressed solidarity with Christians. One of the banners offered the mosque for Christians to conduct their services.

site_title: Australia shares end flat, energy shares lose most; NZ down
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index closed flat, down 0.04%, after four weeks of gains, its worst week since February. Healthcare shares rose for an eighth straight session, with ResMed Inc reporting a 12% quarterly revenue increase. Energy shares plummeted 1.3% to a three-week low due to oil price drops. New Zealand's benchmark index also fell 0.3%.

site_title: Ruling party candidate quits Australian campaign over anti-Muslim posts
summary: Australian ruling party candidate Jessica Whelan quit her campaign for the May 18 elections after admitting to anti-Muslim social media posts, including references to "filthy Muslims" and calls for a referendum to ban Muslim immigration. Whelan initially claimed the posts were doctored by hackers, but later apologized. This marks the third Liberal candidate to quit the campaign over racist or homophobic posts in the past three days, fueling concerns the party is struggling to address right-wing extremism. The incident is part of a growing trend of Liberal candidates facing backlash over online hate speech.

site_title: Thailand's new king among world's wealthiest monarchs
summary: Thailand's King Maha Vajiralongkorn, set to be crowned on May 4, is listed as the world's richest monarch with an estimated personal wealth of at least $30 billion, according to Business Insider. His wealth is primarily held in the Crown Property Bureau, which manages 6,560 hectares of land, 40,000 rental contracts, and valuable assets such as shares in Siam Cement Group and Siam Commercial Bank. The Thai royal family ranks fifth in terms of royal wealth, with Saudi Arabia holding the top spot at $1.7 trillion.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish week with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.46% on Friday, reversing early losses, to close at 30,081.55, driven by gains ahead of US jobs data release. Energy firms were hit by plunging oil prices. Mainland Chinese markets were closed for a public holiday.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall ahead of US jobs data; won hits over 2-year low
summary: South Korean stocks fell 0.74% on Friday, led by the US Federal Reserve's comments on a rate cut, while the won hit a two-year low at 1,170 per dollar. Investors await US employment data for cues. The benchmark KOSPI index rose 0.78% for the week, snapping two straight weekly losses. Foreigners were net buyers of 151.6 billion won worth of shares, while the won fell 0.77% on a weekly basis.

site_title: Euro-area inflation accelerates after string of upbeat data
summary: Euro-area inflation accelerated to 1.7% in April, the strongest since November, exceeding economist estimates. Core inflation, stripping out volatile components, jumped to a six-month high of 1.2%. This data, combined with a report showing the euro-area economy's growth doubled in the first quarter, may reduce the need for additional stimulus from the European Central Bank. Bundesbank President Jens Weidmann urged the ECB to continue exiting unconventional monetary policy if inflation remains strong, highlighting the challenge in achieving sustainable consumer price growth.

site_title: India's strongest storm since 2014 now weakening, says weather office
summary: Cyclone Fani, the strongest storm to hit India since 2014, is weakening after making landfall in Odisha, India. Heavy rains and strong winds will continue throughout Friday, affecting 1 million evacuated people. The cyclone has started weakening and is likely to enter Bangladesh by tomorrow evening. This marks a rare occurrence in April, with no cyclone lasting as long in the month.

site_title: Shell pursuing US$1b exit from Indonesia LNG project
summary: Royal Dutch Shell is selling its 35% stake in Indonesia's $15 billion Abadi liquefied natural gas (LNG) project, valued at around $1 billion, as part of its asset disposal program. The project, operated by Inpex Corp, has been delayed due to Indonesian authorities instructing a switch from an offshore to an onshore facility. The sale highlights the difficulty in attracting energy investment in Southeast Asia's largest economy. The project is not expected to be operational until at least 2026, with Shell citing LNG as a key pillar in the world's transition to lower carbon energy.

site_title: CWX Global posts Q3 net profit of US$211,000 on income tax credit
summary: CWX Global, a CATALIST-listed investment firm with a minority stake in Thai oil concessions, reported a significant increase in Q3 net profit to US$211,000, up from US$32,000 the previous year. The growth was attributed to an income tax credit of US$531,000, reversing a previous expense of US$374,000.

site_title: Serrano CEO quits, stays on as corporate adviser to board
summary: Serrano's CEO, Tan Han Beng, has quit during his probation period but will remain with the company as a corporate adviser to the board. The departure was deemed satisfactory by listing sponsor PrimePartners Corporate Finance, with no material reasons cited.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon at 3,387.76, down 0.2% on day
summary: Singapore stocks declined 0.16% to 3,387.76, with 161 losers outnumbering 140 gainers, as trading resumed on Friday. YZJ Shipbuilding and UOL fell 0.6% and 2.2% respectively, while SembMarine dropped 1.8% after posting a 67.8% fall in Q1 net profit. Hi-P rose 2.1% after announcing a 5.8% increase in Q1 net profit.

site_title: Singapore shares finish flat on Friday
summary: Singapore shares closed flat on Friday, following a weak US session, as investors turned cautious ahead of key jobs data. The Straits Times Index fell 0.03% to 3,392.29. Decliners edged out advancers 191 to 174, with OCBC Bank and UOL Group shares declining 1.48% and 1.7% respectively. Investors await tonight's US nonfarm payrolls, unemployment, and wage data, which has led to a sobering of global risk appetite.

site_title: Europe: Shares edge up, aided by banks, Adidas
summary: European shares edged 0.1% higher on Friday, aided by gains in banks and Adidas. The STOXX 600 index was on course to close the week down 0.5%, its worst weekly loss in six weeks. Adidas rose 7% after reporting a quarterly net profit increase, while bank stocks rose 0.5% following HSBC's beat of quarterly profit estimates. Copper prices rose, supporting basic resources stocks, but InterContinental Hotels fell 3.6% due to weakness in the Greater China region.

site_title: Bookie halts bets on British royal baby birth
summary: A major betting company in Britain, Paddy Power, has halted bets on the birth of Prince Harry and Meghan's baby due to a spike in wagers. The company believes the baby has already been born, contrary to the initial estimated due date in late April. The Duke and Duchess of Sussex's first-born will be Queen Elizabeth II's eighth great-grandchild and seventh in line to the throne.

site_title: Tiny Australia bird stalls divisive coal mine project
summary: Australia's Queensland government has blocked the construction of the Adani coal mine until provisions are made to protect the endangered black-throated finch. The project, which would increase coal exports, has sparked controversy over the government's environmental policies ahead of an election. The halt follows months of debate and comes after the federal government approved the mine last month. The Queensland government cited the need for more accurate information on the bird's management plan, while Adani has called on the state's premier to take charge and commit to finalizing environmental plans.

images.alt_text: Environmental campaigners hold a protest against the development of the India-backed Adani coal mine at the entrance of Abbot Point port near the Queensland state town of Bowen, where the commodity will be shipped, on May 1, 2019.

site_title: Acromec unit bags S$4.7m contract for Alexandra Technopark lab, office fit-out works
summary: Acromec, a specialist engineering service provider, has secured a S$4.7 million contract at Alexandra Technopark for a laboratory and office fit-out project. The contract is expected to contribute positively to the company's earnings per share and net tangible assets per share for the current financial year. With the project's substantial completion anticipated within fiscal 2019, Acromec's order book now stands at about S$32 million.

site_title: Thai king to pay respect to Buddha image, light auspicious candle on eve of coronation
summary: Thai King Maha Vajiralongkorn is set to pay respects to the Emerald Buddha on Friday before lighting an auspicious candle for his coronation events, which will take place from Saturday to Monday. The coronation marks the first in 69 years and is a significant event for the country. The king, 66, will also grant royal pardons to eligible prisoners, including those with disabilities or terminal diseases, and reduce sentences for some inmates. The coronation rituals will be conducted by 80 Buddhist monks and will include the presentation of royal regalia and a golden plaque.

site_title: UOB says Singapore home loans flat, with growth coming from region
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) reported a 8% increase in net profit to S$1.05 billion for the first quarter of 2019, driven by growth in its regional markets. In contrast, Singapore mortgage loans remained flat quarter-over-quarter and are expected to be low single-digit for the year due to the impact of cooling measures. UOB's housing loans rose to S$68.7 billion, while DBS Group Holdings saw a contraction in its mortgage book due to last year's property curbs. The bank expects mid single-digit loan growth for the year, mainly from regional connectivity growth opportunities.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: UOB reported flat Singapore home loan growth, with increases mainly from regional markets. Vietnam reacted to US Trump's tariff announcement, seeking a lower rate. The Asian garment industry prepares for higher US tariffs. Meanwhile, Malaysia plans to seize RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Citigroup forecasts a 1,150 MSCI global equity index by mid-2026. Thaksin Shinawatra remains confident his daughter's suspension as Thai PM in an ethics case will be cleared.

site_title: Malaysia's March exports shrank 0.5% y-o-y
summary: Malaysia's exports declined 0.5% year-over-year in March, the second consecutive monthly drop, according to government data. This is slightly better than the forecasted 0.8% decline. Meanwhile, imports dipped 0.1% in the same period. The trade surplus widened to RM14.4 billion in March, up from RM11.1 billion in the previous month.

site_title: Asia: Markets plod along as investors await US jobs report
summary: Asian markets struggled on Friday, with energy firms taking a hit from falling oil prices, amid concerns over rising supplies and demand. Analysts expect a weak month for equities in May, and investors are cautious ahead of US jobs data later in the day. The US jobs report may influence the Federal Reserve's interest rate decisions, with a strong report potentially killing off hopes for a cut. Tensions in trade talks between China and the US also remain, with some reports suggesting negotiators have hit an impasse.

site_title: HSBC Q1 profit rises 31%, beats estimates
summary: HSBC Holdings reported a 31% rise in Q1 profit to $6.21 billion, beating estimates, driven by a surge in income from its core Asian business and cost management. The bank's profit before tax surpassed the $5.58 billion average of analysts' estimates. This follows warnings in February that HSBC may delay investments due to slowing growth in China and Britain. Despite this, CEO John Flint confirmed plans to invest $15-$17 billion in areas like technology and China over three years.

site_title: MAS extends sponsorship of NUS professorship, adds LKY School of Public Policy as host school
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has extended its sponsorship of the MAS Term Professorship in Economics and Finance at the National University of Singapore (NUS) for another five years. The program now hosts scholars at the Lee Kuan Yew School of Public Policy (LKYSPP) in addition to NUS's Department of Economics and the NUS Business School. The program has attracted 19 distinguished scholars since its establishment in 2009 and aims to strengthen Singapore's financial and economic research infrastructure.

site_title: SocGen's net profit falls again as restructuring plan kicks in
summary: French bank Societe Generale's first quarter net profit fell 26% to 631 million euros due to a weak 2018 and a restructuring plan. The bank's overall revenues shrank 1.6% to 6.19 billion euros. Profits from its domestic retail bank and corporate and investment banking arm declined 13% and 16% respectively. As part of its plan, SocGen closed businesses, cut 1,600 jobs, and freed up to 10 billion euros in capital. The bank's solvency ratio improved to 11.7% and it announced the sale of its Slovenian bank to OTP Bank.

site_title: Some OCBC customers get multiple SMS alerts, duplicate transaction records; account balances not affected
summary: OCBC Bank customers experienced multiple SMS alerts and duplicate transaction records on May 2, prompting the bank to temporarily disable Internet and mobile banking services. The issue was resolved by 1:30am, with account balances unaffected. The bank apologized for the inconvenience and attributed the issue to a technical glitch. Several customers reported receiving multiple alerts and duplicate transactions, with some unable to contact customer service. The exact number of affected customers is not disclosed. The bank assures customers that their account balances remain unchanged.

site_title: Great Eastern completes sale of US$1.4m minority stake in Indonesia insurance firm
summary: Great Eastern has sold 5% of its stake in PT QBE General Insurance Indonesia to PT Suryasono Sentosa for US$1.4 million, retaining 95% ownership. The sale was made to satisfy Indonesian shareholding requirements. Great Eastern acquired the firm in 2018 for US$28 million as part of its strategy to build its general insurance operations in Indonesia. The company expects Indonesia to remain a growth engine for its business.

site_title: SPH updates S$1b medium-term note programme to debt issuance with perps
summary: SPH updates its S$1 billion multicurrency medium-term note programme to a debt issuance programme, allowing for perpetual securities. The net proceeds will be used for general working capital, capital expenditure, acquisitions, investments, and refinancing existing borrowings. This update enables SPH to issue perpetual securities in addition to notes under the medium-term note programme.

site_title: Cordlife's 20% share price surge in morning trade prompts SGX query
summary: Cordlife's shares surged 16.09% to S$0.505 on Friday morning, prompting a query from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) about unusual trading activity. The board of directors confirmed that the company is reviewing "strategic options" to enhance shareholder value, but assured there's no assurance a transaction will materialize. Trading was halted pending an announcement, and the company will resume trading on May 6. This comes after the appointment of new executive director and CEO, Tan Poh Lan, and the release of fiscal 2018 results showing a net profit of S$5.2 million.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open with losses on Friday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index falling 0.42% to 29,818.48, weighed down by a decline in oil prices. The decline followed a negative lead from Wall Street. Mainland Chinese markets were closed for a public holiday.

site_title: Australia: Shares flat; New Zealand dips on Friday
summary: Australian shares remained flat on Friday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index falling 0.04% to 6,335.7, snapping four weeks of gains. Energy stocks weighed heavily on the benchmark, with oil prices plummeting 3% due to oversupply fears. However, healthcare stocks rose 0.4% with CSL advancing 0.5% and Resmed gaining 6.7%. New Zealand's benchmark index also fell 0.3% on the day.

site_title: Japan, China: Markets closed on Friday
summary: Financial markets in China and Japan are closed on Friday due to public holidays. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks continued their 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. In other news, Airalo raised US$220 million in new funding, lifting its valuation past US$1 billion, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite US tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Friday, down 0.66 points to 1,631.58 at 9am, with volume at 40.12 million lots worth RM23.75 million. Losers beat gainers 72 to 55.

site_title: SembMarine Q1 profit falls 67.8% to S$1.7m on lower revenue
summary: SembCorp Marine reported a 67.8% fall in Q1 net profit to S$1.7 million due to lower overall business volume and overhead costs. The company's earnings per share decreased to 0.08 Singapore cents from 0.25 cents last year. This decline was partially offset by margin recognition from secured production floater projects and rig deliveries.

site_title: Macquarie Group warns of weaker FY20 after record profit
summary: Macquarie Group reported record earnings of A$2.98 billion for FY19, driven by asset sales and double-digit profit from its trading and investments units. However, the bank warned of a weaker FY20, with earnings expected to be "slightly down", sending shares 7% lower. The company's markets-facing businesses saw a 76% profit increase, while core annuity-style businesses fell 4%. Macquarie declared a final dividend of A$3.60 per share, up from A$3.20 last year.

site_title: India evacuates more than a million people ahead of cyclone Fani's landfall
summary: India has evacuated over 1 million people ahead of Cyclone Fani's landfall on Friday. The cyclone, with winds of 170-180kmh and gusts of 200kmh, is expected to make landfall in Odisha, causing widespread damage and deaths. The state government has deployed disaster management personnel, closed schools and colleges, and asked health officials to remain on duty until May 15. This evacuation effort is similar to one in 2013, where a mass evacuation saved thousands of lives.

site_title: Enterprise software vendor Beezy sets up office in Singapore
summary: Beezy, an enterprise software vendor, has established an office in Singapore as part of its expansion into the Asia-Pacific region. The Silicon Valley-based company, founded in 2011, provides an enterprise collaboration solution for Microsoft Office 365 and SharePoint. Beezy's Asia-Pacific roadshow will kick off in Singapore, followed by visits to Malaysia and Australia in April and May. This move aims to increase the company's presence in the region and support its growing customer base.

site_title: Trump says second pick to Federal Reserve board withdraws from consideration
summary: President Donald Trump announced that conservative economist Stephen Moore has withdrawn from consideration to join the Federal Reserve Board, the second candidate to pull out after businessman Herman Cain. Moore's withdrawal was seen as an attempt to bring pressure from the inside, but his lack of qualifications and past criticisms of sexism and racism raised concerns among Republicans and Democrats. Trump had previously nominated Moore and Cain despite criticism that they lacked the necessary expertise for the position.

site_title: GIC buys 10% stake in world's sixth-largest container terminal operator
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC has acquired a 10% stake in Geneva-based Terminal Investment Limited (TIL), the world's sixth-largest container terminal operator. TIL handles container volumes for major shipping lines MSC and Maersk. GIC expects TIL to benefit from increasing demand for containerized goods due to global middle class expansion and manufacturing outsourcing. The investment is seen as a long-term opportunity to support the company's future growth.

site_title: Pig 'Ebola' virus sends shock waves through global food chain
summary: African swine fever has spread globally, affecting China's 440 million-strong swine herd, with estimated 1 million culled hogs, and impacting global food prices. The disease has spread nationwide, crossed borders to Mongolia, Vietnam, and Cambodia, and boosted meat markets worldwide. China's hog herd may decline 30%, leading to increased meat imports, which could boost sales of soybean meal and influence geopolitical situations. The outbreak is expected to have a lasting impact on the animal-protein market, with increased food costs affecting economies worldwide.

site_title: Australian taxi drivers sue Uber over 'illegal operations'
summary: Australian taxi drivers are suing Uber over alleged "illegal operations" in the country, with a law firm representing approximately 6,000 drivers and taxi licence owners from four states. The class action claims Uber knowingly operated illegally, causing financial harm to drivers. Damages sought are estimated to be in the hundreds of millions of dollars, pending the case or settlement negotiations. Uber has denied receiving notification of the class action and maintains its focus on delivering a great service to riders and drivers.

site_title: Elon Musk owes US$507m to banks helping Tesla raise capital
summary: Elon Musk personally owes US$507 million to Wall Street banks involved in Tesla's capital raise, backed by his 20% stake in the electric car maker. This is down from US$624 million in 2017 loans. The loans are secured by Musk's shares, currently worth US$8 billion, and could lead to forced sales if Tesla's stock declines. The disclosure was made in Tesla's prospectus to raise up to US$2.3 billion with new shares and convertible debt.

site_title: Facebook bans conspiracy theorists, controversial black activist
summary: Facebook banned prominent conspiracy theorists, including Infowars founder Alex Jones and black activist Louis Farrakhan, in its efforts to curb hate content. The move follows pressure to address extremist content and came after Facebook banned far-right groups and individuals for promoting hate and violence. The company stated it would prohibit praise or support for those banned, and said those who spread hate have no place on its platform. The move was welcomed by a nonprofit watchdog group, which said it would help limit the spread of radical far-right ideology.

site_title: Allied Tech halts trading pending announcements
summary: Allied Technologies, a precision engineering company, halted trading pending announcements on Friday, May 3, 2019, after receiving a letter of intent for a proposed acquisition of a Singaporean dormitory operator for S$130 million. The company's board was reviewing the deal's terms.

site_title: Taiwan tycoon and presidential hopeful Gou gets tips from Trump
summary: Taiwanese tycoon and presidential hopeful Terry Gou met with US President Donald Trump at the White House, where Trump warned Gou that being president is a "tough job". The meeting did not include any discussion of support for Gou's campaign, and Trump described Gou as a "great friend". Gou, who is seeking the nomination of the Beijing-friendly Kuomintang party, emphasized his commitment to strengthening Taiwan and the US economy.

site_title: Manulife US Reit secures up to US$193m in loan facilities
summary: Manulife US Reit has secured up to US$193 million in loan facilities to refinance existing loans, finance a US property acquisition, and cover general corporate and working capital needs.
