The loan facilities, secured by share charges and assignments, include a US$110 million term loan for a Los Angeles office building, a US$33 million term loan for a US property acquisition, and a US$50 million revolving loan for general corporate purposes. The agreement is contingent on certain conditions, including changes in the Reit's management structure.

site_title: Vietnamese woman in Kim Jong Nam murder case freed from prison: lawyer
summary: A Vietnamese woman, Doan Thi Huong, was released from prison on May 3, 2019, after being accused of assassinating North Korean leader Kim Jong Nam. Despite criticism, Huong was freed without facing justice for the real culprits. Her lawyer, Hisyam Teh Poh Teik, stated she was released at 7:20am local time. Journalists witnessed a van and car with tinted windows leaving the prison.

site_title: Actor Peter Mayhew, Chewbacca in 'Star Wars' saga, dead at 74
summary: Actor Peter Mayhew, best known for playing Chewbacca in the 'Star Wars' saga, has died at 74. Mayhew, a towering British-born actor, passed away at his Texas home on Tuesday, surrounded by loved ones. He first appeared in the 1977 film 'Star Wars' and went on to star in 'The Empire Strikes Back', 'Return of the Jedi', and 'Revenge of the Sith'. Mayhew's family said he fought his way back from being wheelchair-bound to portray Chewbacca in 'The Force Awakens' and coached his successor, Joonas Suotamo. A memorial service will be held on June 29.

site_title: Amsterdam to ban polluting cars from 2030
summary: Amsterdam plans to ban petrol and diesel cars from its city by 2030 to reduce air pollution, which poses a significant health risk to residents. The city aims to replace these vehicles with emission-free alternatives such as electric and hydrogen cars, using subsidies and parking permits to encourage the switch. The ban will start with diesel cars built before 2005, with the goal of phasing out all petrol and diesel engines by the end of the decade. This move aims to improve the city's air quality and mitigate the health impacts of pollution.

site_title: Berkshire Hathaway has been buying Amazon shares: CNBC
summary: Berkshire Hathaway, led by CEO Warren Buffett, has been buying shares of Amazon.com, according to a CNBC report. Buffett, who has been a fan of Amazon but has never bought shares, stated that he's been an "idiot for not buying" earlier. The purchase was made by Berkshire's portfolio managers, Todd Combs and Ted Weschler, but details on the amount and which manager made the purchase are not disclosed.

site_title: Frasers Property Q2 earnings up 8.3% to S$120.4m; to pay out 2.4 Singapore cents per share
summary: Frasers Property reported a 8.3% increase in Q2 net profit to S$120.4 million, driven by sales and settlements of development projects in Australia. Revenue rose 11.1% to S$934.3 million. The company also recognized profits from residential developments in Australia and China. An interim dividend of 2.4 Singapore cents per share was declared for the first half of fiscal 2019.

site_title: US House passes bill to keep US in Paris climate accord
summary: The US House of Representatives passed the Climate Action Now Act, preventing President Donald Trump from withdrawing the US from the Paris climate agreement. The bill, which would bar federal funds from withdrawing from the accord, passed 231-190 with three Republicans supporting it. The measure would require the president to develop a plan to meet US obligations under the Paris agreement, including cutting greenhouse gas emissions by 26-28% by 2025. The bill is unlikely to pass in the Republican-led Senate, but aims to frame the president as opposed to fighting global warming.

site_title: Singapore shares slip at Friday's open; STI down 0.24% to 3,385.18
summary: Singapore stocks declined 0.24% to 3,385.18 at the open on Friday, following overnight US stock declines. The Straits Times Index dropped 8.15 points. Gainers and losers were almost evenly matched, with 59 stocks down and 57 up. Key movers included Yangzijiang Shipbuilding (down 1.3%) and Alliance Mineral Assets (up 6.7%). Other Asian markets also fell, with Australia's S&P/ASX 200 Index losing 0.2% and South Korea's Kospi dipping 0.2%.

site_title: Great Eastern Q1 profit more than doubles to S$342.7m on investments
summary: Great Eastern's net profit for Q1 more than doubled to S$342.7 million, driven by higher valuation of its shareholders' fund investments. Earnings per share rose to 72 cents, while operating profit from its insurance business declined 8% to S$150 million. New sales grew 6% to S$249.4 million, and non-operating profit rebounded to S$74.6 million. The group's performance may be affected by global financial market volatility, and it plans to continue its digital transformation journey.

site_title: Bombardier to shed Belfast factory in revamp, shares slide on forecast fears
summary: Bombardier is selling its Belfast wing-making factory as part of a strategic move to focus on corporate jets and passenger rail cars. The plant, which employs 3,600 workers, is expected to be sold to Airbus, a key supplier of wings. The sale comes as Bombardier faces forecast fears and struggles to meet its 2020 goals. The company's shares slid 4.7% after the announcement, amid concerns over the impact on jobs and the future of the Irish border.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOB, Great Eastern, Frasers Property, SembMarine, OUE H-Trust, Hi-P
summary: Singapore stocks saw mixed results on Friday, with UOB reporting a 8% increase in net profit to S$1.05 billion for its first quarter. Great Eastern's net profit more than doubled to S$342.7 million, while Frasers Property's net profit rose 8.3% to S$120.4 million. However, Sembcorp Marine's net profit fell 67.8% to S$1.7 million due to lower business volume. OUE Hospitality Trust's distribution per stapled security decreased 6.3% to 1.18 Singapore cents. Meanwhile, Hi-P International's net profit picked up 5.8% to S$10.7 million despite pricing pressures.

site_title: Carlsberg Q1 sales beat estimates on Asian market boost
summary: Carlsberg, the world's third-largest brewer, reported a 9% increase in Q1 sales driven by Asian market growth, with a 28% year-on-year rise in Asian sales. Positive currency movements and an acquisition in Cambodia contributed to the boost. The company attributed the sales growth to Asian drinkers switching to more expensive beers.

site_title: UOB posts 8% rise in Q1 profit to S$1.05b on stronger income growth
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) reported an 8% increase in its Q1 profit to S$1.05 billion, driven by stronger income growth. Total income rose 8% to S$2.41 billion, led by a recovery in trading and investment income and healthy loan growth. However, net fee and commission income declined 7% due to lower wealth management fees. The bank's group retail business saw a 1% increase in profit before tax, while expenses increased 9% due to investments in digitalisation and headcount growth.

site_title: Oil drops nearly 3% on oversupply worries
summary: Oil prices plummeted nearly 3% on Thursday, with US crude dropping 2.8% to $61.81 a barrel, amid oversupply fears. The market's bearish sentiment was fueled by the lack of immediate impact from US sanctions on Iran, which had previously supported oil prices. Robust US crude stockpiles, which rose to a record high, also contributed to the decline. Analysts expect Opec to eventually be forced to meet demand, with Russia potentially increasing output to fill the gap.

site_title: US: Stocks dip amid weakness in oil shares
summary: US stocks fell for a second straight session, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping 0.5% to 26,307.79. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined 0.2%, despite both closing at records in recent days. Analysts attributed the decline to Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's comments, which dampened expectations for an interest rate cut, and seasonal factors, including the historical May market pullback. Petroleum producers and chemical company Dow were particularly affected, while Tesla Motors rose 4.3% after announcing a debt and equity raise.

site_title: Christchurch mosque toll rises to 51 after man dies
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern announced that the death toll from the Christchurch mosque attacks has risen to 51, following the death of a 46-year-old Turkish man who had been in intensive care since the March 15 shootings. The victim succumbed to his injuries, bringing the total number of fatalities to 51.

site_title: Fed sees no strong case for hiking or cutting rates
summary: The US Federal Reserve held interest rates steady, citing continued economic growth and job gains, as well as the likelihood that weak inflation will edge higher. Fed Chairman Jerome Powell stated that there is no strong case for hiking or cutting rates, and that the economy is on a "good path" for the year. The Fed trimmed interest paid on excess reserves to 2.35% and signaled a "stay-the-course" approach, with policymakers citing a muted level of inflation and a recent decline in inflation rates as concerns.

images.alt_text: Mr Powell says for now, low inflation allows the Fed to be patient in deciding on any further changes to its overnight benchmark lending rate.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler, Toyota US sales slide in April
summary: Fiat Chrysler and Toyota reported a decline in US auto sales for April, with Toyota's sales dropping 4.4% to 162,506 vehicles. Rising prices, higher interest rates, and reduced incentives contributed to the decline. Despite expected sales drops this year, major US automakers are optimistic about a robust economy and strong labor market.

site_title: US Justice Department asks for hearing in Qualcomm antitrust case
summary: The US Department of Justice has asked a federal judge to hold a hearing on potential remedies if Qualcomm Inc is found liable in an antitrust lawsuit brought by the US Federal Trade Commission. The Justice Department argues that any penalties should not harm the market for 5G technology, which is expected to roll out this year and next, and could reduce competition and innovation. The FTC sued Qualcomm over alleged anticompetitive patent licensing practices, and a decision is pending.

images.alt_text: The US Department of Justice's antitrust division asked a federal judge on Thursday to hold a hearing on any possible remedies to be imposed if mobile chip supplier Qualcomm Inc is found liable in an antitrust lawsuit brought by the US Federal Trade Commission.

site_title: A new era for payments is dawning in Singapore
summary: Singapore is entering a new era for payments, driven by the growing demand for ubiquitous payment solutions. The government's Smart Nation initiative aims to digitize payments through services like PayNow and open banking. Singapore is leading the region in open banking readiness, with the Payment Services Bill 2019 paving the way. The country's merchant acquiring business has seen a boost as merchants turn to online payment solutions, positioning Singapore for a future of fast and secure digital payments.

site_title: Europe: Shares dip after Fed outlook; SAP weighs
summary: European shares dropped 0.7% after the US Federal Reserve signaled little appetite for interest rate cuts, disappointing rate cut bets. SAP fell 1.3% and weighed on the Stoxx 600 index, while gains from Volkswagen and Bayer helped cap losses. The basic resources sector declined 1.6% after copper prices fell, and consumer stocks slipped after Zalando announced delivery fee plans. Bayer rose 1.3% after the EPA cleared glyphosate, a key ingredient in its Roundup weed killer.

site_title: Speaking Out
summary: A new play by Pangdemonium tackles the issue of sexual harassment in Singapore, titled "This Is What Happens To Pretty Girls." Based on interviews with over 100 people, the play explores the widespread problem of sexism and harassment in the country, with many victims facing shame and passivity from their families and workplaces. The play aims to challenge societal norms and push for a greater conversation about consent and control, running at the Drama Centre Theatre from May 10 to 26.

site_title: Popcorn Frenzy
summary: A new snack bar, myEureka, has opened at Jewel Changi Airport in Singapore, offering 22 unique flavors, including durian, kimchi, and crispy chicken rendang. The snack bar, owned by Malaysia's myEureka brand, features mushroom-shaped kernels for a uniform crunch. The variety of flavors caters to both adventurous and less adventurous eaters, with classic options like cheese and caramel also available. The myEureka Snack Bar is located at B2-251, Jewel Changi Airport.

site_title: DBS sees fall in customer call volumes amid technology use
summary: DBS, a Singapore-based bank, reported a 12% drop in customer call volumes over the last year due to its increased use of technology, such as chatbots and predictive data analytics. The bank expects a further 20% decline in call volume over the next three years. Typically, DBS processes over four million inbound calls annually in Singapore. The shift towards technology is part of the bank's customer engagement efforts.

site_title: Cooking up a storm for a good cause
summary: Singaporean home cook Janice O'Connor is launching her debut cookbook, "Open Kitchen," which documents her charity fundraising efforts through home-cooked meals. The book will raise funds for the Make-A-Wish Foundation Singapore, with every S$100 donation netting a donor one book. Since 2001, O'Connor's charity parties have raised over S$5 million for 25 charities, with proceeds going directly to grant the wishes of children with life-threatening conditions. The book aims to share recipes and the importance of love, friendship, and family, with all proceeds supporting the Make-A-Wish Foundation.

site_title: Ayondo's full-year net loss widens to 50.2m Swiss francs
summary: Ayondo, a Catalist-listed fintech group, reported a widened net loss of 50.2 million Swiss francs (S$67.2 million) for the financial year ended December 31, 2018, compared to a loss of 9.8 million francs in the previous year. The loss was due to poor business performance, low volatility in financial markets, and regulatory tightening measures. Trading revenue edged up, but the number of active clients decreased by 8%. Ayondo's management is exploring opportunities to reduce liabilities and complete the proposed disposal of its UK subsidiary.

site_title: Fears of ultra right and left swing in upcoming European elections
summary: Growing fears of ultra-right and left-wing parties winning big in the upcoming European Parliament elections are on the rise. Currently, conservative and centre-left parties hold over 80% of the parliament, but polls indicate a worrying increase in support for extreme right and left parties. In Spain, the far-right Vox party won 10.3% of votes in the latest election, marking a significant milestone in the country's history. European leaders are concerned about the potential rise of extremist ideologies, particularly if the UK's Brexit Party gains seats.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Mind Your Business - Data analytics is the game changer for SMEs
summary: A Money FM podcast discusses how data analytics is a game-changer for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The experts emphasize the importance of leveraging data to make informed business decisions, drive growth, and gain a competitive edge. By analyzing customer behavior, market trends, and financial data, SMEs can optimize operations, reduce costs, and increase revenue. This shift towards data-driven decision-making is seen as a key factor in SMEs' success in today's fast-paced business environment.

site_title: Landmark Tower sale completion facing delays
summary: Landmark Tower's collective sale, valued at S$286 million, is facing delays due to pending in-principle lease top-up approval from the Singapore Land Authority. The consortium of buyers hopes to complete the sale by August, but the hold-up is attributed to "new technical requirements" and the purchase of adjacent state land. The buyers have applied for approval but have yet to receive it, with a revised deadline of end-May.

site_title: HK's Q1 GDP growth slows to near decade low
summary: Hong Kong's economy grew at its slowest annual pace in nearly 10 years, with a 0.5% increase in the first quarter, according to an advance government estimate. The slowdown was attributed to weakening exports and investment, with private consumption and overall investment expenditure contracting. However, a chief economist predicts a recovery in the near future due to positive wealth effects from stronger stock and property markets. The government has forecast modest growth for the year, with a predicted 2-3% expansion.

site_title: K Hotel in Geylang up for sale with S$25m asking price
summary: The K Hotel in Geylang, Singapore, has been put up for sale with an asking price of S$25 million, marking a rare opportunity for a freehold hotel in the city fringe. The eight-storey hotel offers 56 double rooms and is near three MRT stations, the CBD, and key developments like the Sports Hub and Kallang Riverside area. Foreigners are eligible to purchase, and there will be no additional buyer's stamp duty. Interest in freehold hotels and hotel land has been strong, with recent sales exceeding S$200 million.

site_title: Firm data pushes euro higher; US dollar resumes fall
summary: The US dollar declined, with a fifth of a percent increase in the euro to US$1.1219, as survey figures showed European economic weakness might be overstated. The euro is still near a two-year low. Despite Fed Chair Jerome Powell's comments, investors remained cautious, with a net US$14.8 billion short position in the euro. Interest rate futures markets price a 64% probability of a rate cut by the end of the year, while sterling held below a two-week high amid Brexit talks progress.

site_title: How does your love of wine contribute to climate change?
summary: Wine consumers can contribute to combating climate change by supporting producers who take decisive steps to address the issue. By making informed buying decisions, consumers can influence the wine industry to adopt sustainable practices. Key actions include choosing wines in lighter bottles, patronizing bars and restaurants serving wines-by-the-glass, and asking producers questions about their climate change efforts. However, reliable information is often difficult to come by, and consumers need to educate themselves to effectively distinguish between environmentally friendly and unsustainable producers.

site_title: Race Ahead
summary: Two new experiences will be introduced at the Singapore Grand Prix: The Cube and the Upper Deck. The Cube, priced at S$750, offers elevated triple-level viewing, free-flow champagne, and canapés. The Upper Deck, priced at S$2,288, features a glass-encased facility with unobstructed views of the Pit Straight and Pit Lane. Both offer exclusive dining experiences at Michelin-starred restaurants. Bookings can be made at www.singaporegp.sg.

site_title: Bigger S$3.68m scheme launched to boost tech use by Singapore law firms
summary: The Ministry of Law, in collaboration with other agencies, has launched a new S$3.68 million one-year scheme, Tech-celerate for Law, to support Singapore law firms in adopting technology solutions. The programme provides up to 70% funding for technology adoption, with a cap of S$30,000 for baseline solutions and S$100,000 for advanced solutions. The scheme aims to help law firms become future-proof and future-ready, with 85% of lawyers surveyed saying that legal technology is crucial to the development of the profession.

site_title: MAS, Bank of Canada trial could make cross-border payments cheaper, faster, safer
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Bank of Canada have successfully trialed the use of central bank digital currencies and distributed ledger technology for cross-border and cross-currency payments. The trial aims to make these payments cheaper, faster, and safer. This is the first such trial between the two central banks, marking a significant step forward in international cooperation on digital currencies.

site_title: Pewter Still Shines
summary: Royal Selangor, a Singapore-based pewter manufacturer, has been in operation for 50 years. Founded in 1968 by Yong Poh Shin, the company started as a factory in Paya Lebar Road, employing handicapped workers, including polio patients, at a time of high unemployment in Singapore. The company's approach to hiring workers proved successful, and it became one of the first to employ disabled workers. Although the factory closed in the 1990s, the brand continues to collaborate with local designers and remains relevant, with a recent launch of the Savoy collection of bathroom accessories.

site_title: SIIC Environment's Q1 profit jumps 47.3% to 150m yuan
summary: MAINBOARD-listed SIIC Environment Holdings posted a 47.3% rise in first quarter net profit to 150.1 million yuan (S$30.3 million), driven by higher water treatment and supply sales volume from existing entities. The company attributed the growth to increased demand for its services.

site_title: Consortium sees US$18b gain from Jakarta rail spin-offs
summary: An Indonesian-Chinese consortium building a Jakarta-Bandung high-speed rail link is expected to earn US$18 billion from developing satellite towns and industrial centers along the line. The project, part of China's Belt and Road Initiative, is described as the first high-speed rail in South-east Asia.

site_title: honestbee CEO replaced; firm said to be sticking to habitat growth
summary: honestbee's CEO Joel Sng has stepped down, and Brian Koo, a founding managing partner of Formation Group, will take over as interim CEO. The company will continue to focus on its tech-enabled supermarket and dining concept, habitat, despite questions about its financial viability. Honestbee plans to stick with its overseas expansion strategy, including opening brick-and-mortar stores in Singapore, Taiwan, and The Philippines. Industry watchers express mixed views on the viability of the startup's strategy, with some citing challenges in the grocery delivery and food delivery spaces.

site_title: Apichart Chutrakul
summary: Apichart Chutrakul, CEO of Sansiri, a Thai property giant, is diversifying the company's portfolio into lifestyle brands, aiming to "bring Thailand to the world and vice versa." Sansiri has invested in hotels, co-working spaces, online art galleries, and wellness condominiums, including a luxury project in Bangkok and 15 new Standard hotels worldwide. Chutrakul believes Thailand's property market is not oversupplied and is a viable option for Singaporeans looking for affordable vacation homes. Despite predictions of a recession, Chutrakul is confident in Sansiri's future, citing the company's increased equity base and global presence.

site_title: Boeing pushes to move crash suits from hometown to Indonesia
summary: Boeing is seeking to move lawsuits from the US to Indonesia over the October 2018 Lion Air crash, which killed 189 people, in an effort to reduce its financial liability. The company claims it has precedent to have cases heard in the country where the incident occurred. However, plaintiffs' lawyers argue that this move would allow Boeing to skirt responsibility and avoid US courts, which they say offer stronger protections and more favorable outcomes. The request must be made within 45 days, and the outcome is uncertain.

site_title: Journey Back In Time
summary: Hermès' latest exhibition, "In Motion," celebrates the romance of travel through the years, showcasing objects that capture the spirit of wanderlust and the brand's heritage in movement. The exhibition, curated by Bruno Gaudichon and Laurence Fontaine, features objects on loan from the Émile Hermès collection and archives, as well as modern creations. It highlights the brand's evolution from its leather saddle and harness maker roots to its current focus on creating comfortable and beautiful travel experiences. The exhibition runs from May 11 to 19 at Hermès Liat Towers in Singapore.

site_title: One For The Girls
summary: Exsto Cognac, a spirit created in partnership with World's Best Female Sommelier 2016 Julie Dupouy, is launched in Singapore with two blends: Exsto Cognac Elixir (S$688) and Exsto Cognac Or Impérial (S$2,888). The blends, inspired by a fresh and youthful approach, showcase notes of caramel and butter, and passion fruit, peaches, and roses, respectively. This sommelier-inspired cognac could redefine the image of cognac, available at hotspots like Anti:dote, Manhattan, and Odette.

site_title: Travellers' Choice
summary: The second edition of "100 Best" features top luxury hotels worldwide, curated by Sii Eawsaful. The book showcases private islands, glamping resorts, and luxury cruises, offering unique experiences. It also includes insider access to destinations' cultures, contributed by industry experts. The travel guide is available on Amazon.com, providing suggestions for travelers looking for exceptional hospitality.

site_title: OUE H-Trust gets the runs
summary: OUE Hospitality Trust (OUE H-Trust) reported a 6.3% decline in distribution per stapled security (DPS) for the first quarter, due to falls in net property income and gross revenue. Net property income fell 2.2% to S$27.7 million and gross revenue decreased 3% to S$31.7 million, primarily affected by the Mandarin Orchard hotel's disrupted banquet services and lower revenue per available room. The retail segment showed mild increases in contributions to turnover and net income.

site_title: Facebook to create privacy positions under FTC settlement
summary: The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) is negotiating a settlement with Facebook to strengthen the company's privacy practices. As part of the proposed agreement, Facebook will create a privacy committee, appoint an external assessor, and hire a head compliance officer, potentially including CEO Mark Zuckerberg. The settlement aims to address privacy violations and sets a potential blueprint for US tech companies, with the FTC seeking to regulate companies under the Trump administration. The agreement has implications for the tech industry's approach to user data protection and privacy.

site_title: US construction spending down unexpectedly in March
summary: US construction spending unexpectedly fell 0.9% in March, reversing three straight monthly gains. Private construction projects declined 0.7%, while public projects fell 1.3%. Investment in private residential projects plummeted 1.8%, the lowest since December 2016. The decline suggests a possible revision to the government's first-quarter GDP estimate, which rose to a 3.2% annualized rate. The weak construction spending also raises concerns about the housing market, which has struggled for five straight quarters despite declining mortgage rates.

site_title: Falling Porsche, Audi sales hurting VW profit
summary: Volkswagen's first-quarter profit fell 7.1% to 3.9 billion euros due to declines at Porsche and Audi brands, while costs for new electric and connected cars rose. Operating profit rose to 4.8 billion euros, excluding special items. Deliveries at Porsche and Audi fell 12% and 3.6% respectively, citing emissions tests and model changeovers. Revenue at the main VW brand rose 7.1% and CEO Herbert Diess expressed optimism about demand recovery in the second half of the year.

site_title: Investors are too relaxed on rates, says Carney
summary: Bank of England governor Mark Carney stated investors are underestimating the central bank's ability to raise interest rates, despite keeping borrowing costs on hold due to Brexit uncertainty. The BoE voted to keep its benchmark rate at 0.75% and upgraded its forecast for UK growth to 1.5%, citing better global economic prospects. Carney expressed a hawkish stance, differing from the US Federal Reserve and European Central Bank, and warned investors that the pace of rate increases may be faster than anticipated.

site_title: Designed for Life
summary: Eugene Lee, a 25-year-old design student from Nanyang Polytechnic, has been selected as a finalist in the Singapore Creator Awards for his innovative wall-mounted rain barrel, Sprout, which collects rainwater for general household use. Lee's design aims to promote water conservation and respect for this essential resource. As one of the 20 finalists, he joins other creators showcasing unique Singaporean designs that reflect the country's culture and values. The Singapore Creator Awards, now in its second year, seeks to foster innovation and creativity through design.

site_title: Oxley's Chevron House sale a better deal for buyer than seller: DBS analysts
summary: DBS analysts claim the buyer in Oxley Holdings' S$1.025 billion sale of Chevron House is the "bigger beneficiary" due to the property's high value. Oxley acquired the 32-storey office tower in 2017 for S$660 million. However, Oxley disputes this, stating the building was sold without tenancy agreements and ongoing works.

site_title: Sanofi wins US approval to sell dengue vaccine but with major restrictions
summary: The US FDA has approved Sanofi's dengue vaccine Dengvaxia, but with significant restrictions. The vaccine can only be given to people aged 9-16 with a confirmed previous dengue infection, primarily in areas like Puerto Rico and US Virgin Islands. The approval is narrower than Sanofi's initial request, following an FDA advisory panel's recommendation. The vaccine's safety concerns, including severe infections in some individuals, led to the restricted approval.

site_title: Towards asset-based welfare policies
summary: A proposed asset-based welfare policy suggests that individuals under 30 invest their taxes in a global equities index fund, encouraging risk-taking and potentially higher returns. This approach differs from traditional social welfare policies, which focus on saving and insuring for routine events. Research shows that better-educated and more affluent individuals are more likely to invest in equities, while those with lower education and income tend to save in low-risk bank deposits. This policy aims to minimize moral hazard and promote financial independence, potentially benefiting those who are currently "trapped" in low-return savings.

site_title: Reliable fare in lush surroundings at Min Jiang
summary: Min Jiang, a Sichuan restaurant, has relocated to Dempsey Village and offers a lush, garden-like atmosphere. The restaurant features a large, airy dining room with a conservatory-like design. While the food is competent, it leans towards Cantonese cuisine, with a focus on dim sum and comforting dishes like braised fish maw and sea cucumber. The chef's attempts to be contemporary are sometimes awkward, but the restaurant excels when serving familiar comfort food. Overall, Min Jiang is a good dining option, with a rating of 7 out of 10.

site_title: Goldilocks growth
summary: The US economy is expected to set a new record this month, with Wall Street hitting all-time highs. Investors who feared a recession in early January are now enjoying the strongest start to a year since 1998. The combination of moderate economic growth and low inflation has created a "Goldilocks economy," characterized by high stock prices and falling bond yields. This phenomenon is driven by the prospects for real economic activity and expected corporate profits, rather than inflation or interest rates. The global economy has shown no signs of slowing, with China's GDP growth contributing significantly to the increase in global output.

site_title: Beyond Meat IPO raises US$241m as appetite for meatless morsels increases
summary: Beyond Meat raised $241 million in its initial public offering, valuing the company at $1.5 billion. The California-based firm sold 9.625 million shares at $25 each, driven by strong investor demand for plant-based meat alternatives. Despite recording a net loss of $30 million in 2018, the company expects to address concerns related to human health, climate change, and animal welfare with its products. The funds raised will be used to expand marketing channels, distribution, and manufacturing facilities.

site_title: Default and non-default risks should be on the radar for CCPs
summary: Regulators must focus on managing both non-default and default risks for Central Counter Parties (CCPs) to ensure financial market stability. Non-default risks include operational and cyber risks, while default risks arise from clearing member defaults. CCPs have become more dependent on third-party service providers, increasing operational risk. Regulators are implementing measures to mitigate these risks, such as requiring CCPs to perform due diligence on service providers and enhancing cybersecurity. Additionally, regulators are recognizing the need to address interdependencies between CCPs and their bank clearing members, and to manage the risks associated with standardized derivatives clearing.

site_title: Kingboard Copper offer 'not fair but reasonable'
summary: Kingboard Copper Foil Holdings' independent financial adviser has deemed the buy-out offer of S$0.60 in cash per share as "not fair but reasonable". The offeror, controlling 88.41% of the company, intends to privatize the company and exercise its right of compulsory acquisition. The Securities Industry Council considers an offer fair if it equals or exceeds the target securities' value, which Kingboard Copper's net asset value is S$0.656 per share. The independent directors are advised to recommend shareholders accept the offer, which closed flat at S$0.60 on Thursday.

site_title: DBS's secret for winning awards lies in its finance team
summary: DBS, a leading Asian bank, credits its finance team for its success, particularly under CFO Chng Sok Hui, who has led the 700-strong team since 2008. The team's strategic balance sheet management enabled the bank to pre-empt the disruption of technology, reducing costs and boosting earnings. The bank's digitalisation efforts, quantified through data analytics, have created value and improved cost-income ratios. DBS holds several awards, including "World's Best Digital Bank" by Euromoney, and has seen significant growth in its wholesale funding, cash management income, and mortgage market share.

images.alt_text: The bank's CFO Chng Sok Hui said digitalisation has structurally lowered the group's cost-income ratio by half a percentage point a year. Digital customers bring in more revenue and cost the bank less to serve.

site_title: Amber Park to be launched at average price of S$2,425 psf
summary: CDL and Hong Realty will launch the freehold 592-unit condominium Amber Park in Singapore's East Coast area at an average price of S$2,425 psf. The project features one- to five-room units and penthouses, with early-bird prices starting at S$1.088 million for a one-bedroom unit and S$3.438 million for a four-bedroom unit.

images.alt_text: The distinctive feature at Amber Park is a rooftop recreational deck connecting the three residential towers. The development will be near the upcoming Tanjong Katong MRT station, which is expected to be completed in 2023.

site_title: All Hail Queen Bey
summary: Beyoncé's Netflix concert documentary "Homecoming" has been released, showcasing her 2018 Coachella performance. The film features behind-the-scenes footage, rehearsal shots, and quotes from famous black figures. Although the Netflix special is well-done, fans are advised to supplement it with YouTube bootleg clips that capture the raw audience euphoria. The live album "Homecoming" is also available simultaneously.

site_title: Asia's factories 'bottoming out' but stimulus may still provide relief
summary: Asia's factories are showing signs of "bottoming out" from a slowdown, but global demand remains subdued, and China's stimulus measures have yet to fully impact. The outlook for central banks is skewed towards easing, with Malaysia and New Zealand prime suspects for potential rate cuts. Factory surveys indicate a contraction in the eurozone's manufacturing sector, while the US manufacturing sector grew but missed expectations. A resolution in the US-China trade dispute could improve the mood, and economists expect rate cuts in Malaysia, Philippines, and Indonesia to provide further support.

site_title: Shaken And Stirred
summary: The top cocktail trends for 2019 include a focus on sustainability, with bars replacing plastic straws and aiming for minimal or zero waste behind the bar. Bartenders are also experimenting with ingredients beyond the standard supply chain, such as native herbs and foraged ingredients. Low ABV drinks are also gaining popularity, with consumers seeking quality drinks without the hangover. Additionally, there is a return to classic cocktails and a focus on minimalist, non-gimmicky drinks. Gin remains a popular spirit, and calorie-conscious consumers are seeking lower-calorie drinks, with brands creating innovative, low-calorie options.

site_title: Singapore fuel oil inventories slip from 16-month high on lower net imports
summary: Singapore's fuel oil inventories dropped to a two-week low in the week ended May 1, falling 3% from the previous week to 23.576 million barrels. This marked a 16-month low, following a high of 24.331 million barrels in the week to April 24. Net fuel oil imports decreased 13% from the previous week, reaching a two-week low of 565,000 tonnes. Meanwhile, exports to China, Japan, and the US rose, with the largest imports coming from Saudi Arabia and Malaysia.

site_title: The Beauty of Indo-China
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

Myanmar and Vietnam are emerging as unspoiled destinations in Indo-China, offering authentic experiences and a break from mass tourism. Myanmar's Yangon is a must-visit, with its bustling street scenes, historic landmarks, and handmade crafts. The country's temple complexes, including Bagan and Inle Lake, showcase its sophisticated history. Meanwhile, Vietnam is undergoing rapid development and reinvention, with Ho Chi Minh City now a hub of street vendors, hipster cafes, and eateries. From the pristine beaches of Phu Quoc to the stunning natural beauty of Ha Long Bay, both countries offer unique experiences for travelers.

site_title: Haute Cuisine In Tokyo
summary: Tokyo offers an array of fine dining options, from hidden gems to luxurious establishments. Restaurant Nanpeidai in Shibuya serves yoshoku-inspired French-Japanese cuisine with a whimsical, turn-of-the-century vibe. Chef Nanahiro Takahashi showcases European ingredients alongside Japanese ones, with dishes like French blue lobster and confit abalone. Ren in Ginza also offers classic yoshoku with a modern twist, while Kasumicho Yamagami in Nishiazabu specializes in soft-shell turtle and fugu shirako. La Paix in Nihonbashi and Hommage in Asakusa emphasize seasonal ingredients and personal service. Modern contemporary Narisawa focuses on sustainable, innovative Satoyama cuisine. Sushi Ishiyama in Ginza offers traditional sushi.

site_title: How smart logistics can enable the future of retail
summary: The rapid growth of e-commerce is transforming the retail landscape, with South-east Asia's online economy projected to exceed $240 billion by 2025. To meet changing customer expectations, retailers must rethink their supply chain processes, investing in smart logistics to ensure speed and convenience. This requires a holistic approach, integrating technology and data to drive seamless fulfillment and agility in responding to demand fluctuations. Implementing smart logistics solutions can help retailers achieve a hybrid model, combining physical stores and e-commerce, and gain a competitive edge in the market.

site_title: With sculpture, Frieze expands to Manhattan
summary: The inaugural edition of Frieze Sculpture at Rockefeller Center in Manhattan has opened to the public until June 28. The event features 20 sculptures by 14 artists, including Hank Willis Thomas, Kiki Smith, and Joan Miró, and is meant to be a free, open-platform experience that engages with the city's residents. The installation, curated by Brett Littman, aims to balance variety, small-scale sculpture, and balance with the urban setting, and includes overtly political pieces that critique globalism and labor. The event marks Frieze's expansion into Manhattan and is part of the art fair's efforts to bring public sculpture responsibly to the city.

site_title: Samsung bets it can sell smart-home tech by building the homes
summary: Samsung is launching a smart-home pilot project, building homes with integrated technology, including virtual assistants, smart appliances, and IoT systems. The company aims to create environmentally friendly and intelligent homes, analyzing data to refine its services. The first real-world test bed will be an apartment redevelopment project in Busan, South Korea, with owners able to order smart-home retrofits starting in June 2022. Samsung's construction arm, Samsung C&T, has built notable landmarks, giving the company an advantage in the $77 billion global market for internet-connected appliances and furniture.

site_title: A primer on investing
summary: Goh Yang Chye, a prominent figure in Singapore's financial advisory industry, has written a book titled "Simply Invest: Naked Truths To Grow Your Money" aimed at novice investors. The book simplifies complex investment concepts and offers advice on investing in Singapore, drawing from his experience in weathering financial crises. Goh emphasizes the importance of discipline and patience, warning against chasing trends and emotional decisions, and provides data-backed arguments on topics such as choosing stocks over property. The book is available in bookstores for S$31.

site_title: No Signboard CEO arrested and out on bail in share buyback probe
summary: No Signboard Holdings CEO Sam Lim Yong Sim was arrested on April 30 on "reasonable suspicion" of breaches in the Securities and Futures Act, including false trading and market rigging transactions. He was released on bail and has not been charged. The arrest was related to a share buyback probe. The company has not disclosed any further details on the investigation.

site_title: Ja'dore
summary: Jacintha Abishegenadan, a Singaporean jazz singer known as Ja, returns to the stage with her album "Fire & Rain," featuring covers of James Taylor hits. The concert, "Jacintha Is Her Name," will take place at the Esplanade Recital Studio on May 4, 2019, featuring local musicians Mei Sheum, Dr. Sydney Tan, Tama Goh, and Sebastian Ho.

site_title: Hi-P's Q1 gross profit hit by a tough market
summary: Hi-P International, a mainboard-listed contract manufacturer, reported a first-quarter net profit of S$10.7 million, up 5.8% year-over-year, despite a 4.3% drop in gross profit to S$36.2 million due to price pressures and a shift to low-margin products. The company attributed the better-than-forecast result to a 70.9% drop in "other expenses." Hi-P plans to turn the impact of the US-China trade war into opportunities through its corporate strategies, and expects similar profit in the second quarter.

site_title: Street Meets Star Wars
summary: UT (Uniqlo T-shirt) has collaborated with Japanese streetwear designers UNDERCOVER's Jun Takahashi, A Bathing Ape's NIGO, and WTAPS' Tetsu Nishiyama to create a Star Wars-themed collection. The collection features designs inspired by iconic characters from the franchise, including Ewoks, Yoda, and Boba Fett. Most shirts are available in both adult and kids' sizes, with exclusive designs available online and in select stores. The collection is set to be highly sought after by fans of Japanese streetwear fashion and Star Wars.

site_title: Is Asia lacking in philanthropy?
summary: A recent report suggests Asia's ultra-wealthy individuals are not giving enough to charity, despite the region's fastest rate of wealth creation. This is attributed to a lack of incentive, with inheritance taxes and tax perks being a major motivation for philanthropy in the US and Europe. However, Asian philanthropists argue that the region has a different approach to large-scale giving, with a focus on long-term investments and family foundations rather than immediate charitable donations.

site_title: Singaporeans spend more time on property searches than on bedtime stories with their children: poll
summary: A new HSBC survey found that Singaporeans spend an average of 3.29 hours per week on property searches, compared to 1.03 hours reading bedtime stories to their children and 0.94 hours speaking to their parents. 36% of Singapore house hunters decide on a property based on first impressions, and 75% view five houses or fewer in person before buying. Extreme property addicts spend over 7 hours a week researching, with 51% buying on first sight and 63% without criteria.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Delong Holdings, a Chinese steelmaker, expects lower first-quarter net profit due to decreased product prices and higher cost of sales. The company will announce its financial results on May 8. In contrast, NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Meanwhile, OCBC's incoming CEO Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, will succeed outgoing CEO Helen Wong, who is retiring.

site_title: Tulip Mania
summary: Gardens by the Bay in Singapore is set to debut its Tulipmania floral display, featuring over 35 varieties of tulips flown in from the Netherlands. The display draws inspiration from the Dutch countryside, showcasing a windmill and farmhouses. Visitors can explore the different stages of a tulip's life cycle and learn about its clockwork mechanism. The display includes tulips commemorating Singapore's Bicentennial and the vibrant 'Yellow Flight'. The exhibit runs in the Flower Dome and aims to bring a touch of the Netherlands to the city-state.

site_title: Malaysia appoints its first woman chief justice
summary: Malaysia has appointed Tengku Maimun Tuan Mat as its first female chief justice, effective immediately. She replaces Richard Malanjum, who retired on April 12. Tengku Maimun, a federal court judge since November 2018, is the only woman serving as a chief justice in Southeast Asia. Her appointment marks a historic milestone for Malaysia's judiciary.

site_title: Central banks are ditching the dollar for gold
summary: Central banks, led by Russia and China, purchased the highest amount of gold in six years in the first quarter, with global gold reserves increasing 68% from last year. This diversification away from the US dollar is driven by countries seeking to reduce their dollar dependency. Gold prices have risen 8% since September, and central bank purchases have been a key support. The World Gold Council expects another strong year for central bank purchases, with small-scale miners contributing 15-20% to global gold mine production.

site_title: Singapore Pavilion Energy marks first ship-to-ship LNG refuelling operation
summary: Singapore Pavilion Energy successfully completed the world's first commercial ship-to-ship liquefied natural gas (LNG) refuelling operation in the port of Singapore. The operation involved loading 2,000 cubic meters of LNG onto a small tanker and transferring it to a receiving vessel. The move aims to reduce polluting emissions from ships, as global shipping regulations are set to ban fuels with high sulphur content. The use of LNG as a marine fuel is expected to become the "worldwide fuel of choice" in the long term, according to SLNG CEO Tan Soo Koong.

site_title: Math doesn't lie; Musk can't dodge Tesla cash woes any longer
summary: Tesla's CEO Elon Musk acknowledged the company's cash woes, stating that additional capital is necessary to support its ambitious plans, including the development of autonomous robotaxis. Despite previous assurances of profitability, Tesla reported a record decline in deliveries and a depleted cash reserve of $2.2 billion. Analysts predict that the company may need to raise $2-3 billion in equity to support capital expenses and debt repayment, which could help stabilize the stock price. Musk's plans for a fleet of self-driving vehicles and other ventures may also distract from the company's automotive ambitions.

site_title: Hard to pick clear winner between two upcoming US hotel Reit listings
summary: Two US hotel Reits, ARA US Hospitality Trust and Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT), are set to list on the Singapore Exchange, with ARA likely to be first. Both have similar investment mandates, yield targets, and management structures, but differ in asset types, geographical spread, and rental models. ARA US Hospitality Trust owns select-service hotels with higher gross operating margins, while EHT has a mix of full-service and select-service hotels. The IPOs' timing may be due to improved market conditions, but DBS's simultaneous launch may risk diluting investor interest.

site_title: PerkinElmer opens its largest lab instruments facility in Singapore
summary: PerkinElmer, a leading medtech company, opened its largest lab instruments facility in Singapore, marking a significant expansion of its presence in the country. The 321-employee facility, located at the JTC MedTech Hub, will serve as a global manufacturing site for PerkinElmer's detection and analytical instruments. The move underscores Singapore's growing importance as a hub for medtech companies, with 60 leading multinational firms and over 240 healthcare startups already operating in the country. The facility's opening is seen as a strategic move to tap into regional growth areas and capitalize on the expected US$133 billion Asia-Pacific medtech market by 2020.

site_title: ARA US Hospitality Trust prices IPO at US$0.88 per stapled security; expects to raise US$498m
summary: ARA US Hospitality Trust has priced its initial public offering (IPO) at US$0.88 per stapled security, raising US$498 million. The trust will hold 38 upscale select-service hotels spanning 4,950 rooms in the US, with a total appraised value of US$719.5 million. The portfolio is expected to generate an 8% distribution yield from May 1, 2019, to Dec 31, 2019, and 8.2% for the projection year 2020. The trust aims to grow its portfolio, focusing on the West coast and Southern states, with a focus on yield management and driving average daily rates.

site_title: Australia's NAB cuts dividend for 1st time in decade as economy slows
summary: Australia's National Australia Bank (NAB) has cut its dividend for the first time in a decade, reducing it by 16% to comply with capital requirements. The bank reported a 7% rise in first-half cash profit, driven by strong revenue and lending growth in Australia and New Zealand, but missed analysts' expectations. NAB also set aside A$1.1 billion to compensate customers for wrongdoing exposed at a public inquiry last year. The move follows a slowdown in the Australian economy.

images.alt_text: NAB posted a 7 per cent rise in first-half cash profit on Thursday, as strong revenue and above average lending growth in Australia and New Zealand more than offset lower margins and higher bad debt charges.

site_title: Time in Technicolour
summary: Watch brands are increasingly using vibrant colors to stand out in a crowded market. Independent Swiss brand De Bethune released a fire yellow DB28 model, while Glashutte Original introduced multi-faceted orange timepieces with a degrade effect. Hublot's all-red Classic Fusion Aerofusion Chronograph Orlinski Red Magic pays homage to artist Richard Orlinksi, while Omega's De Ville Tresor 125th Anniversary Edition features a red enamel dial. Other brands, including Breguet, Bulgari, Blancpain, and Vacheron Constantin, have also released blue-dialed watches, solidifying blue as a popular color in the watch industry.

site_title: What Uber missed out in Asia
summary: Uber missed out on the opportunity of a lifetime in Asia by selling its operations to Grab, a move that has enabled the Southeast Asian ride-hailing companies to become super-apps, offering a range of services beyond ride-hailing. In contrast, the US ride-hailing pioneer struggles to compete, with drivers earning an average of $12 per hour, and investors concerned that the companies may engage in a "race to the bottom" that kills profit margins. The Asian unicorns, Go-Jek and Grab, have turned acquisitive, buying smaller startups to enhance their apps, and have a more viable path to higher earnings.

site_title: Foreign government leases at Trump World Tower stir more emoluments concerns
summary: The US State Department allowed at least seven foreign governments to rent luxury condominiums in Trump World Tower in New York without congressional approval, potentially violating the emoluments clause of the US Constitution. Documents show that foreign governments, including Iraq, Kuwait, Malaysia, Saudi Arabia, Slovakia, Thailand, and the European Union, rented combined eight units in the building between 2015 and 2017. The State Department's failure to submit lease requests to Congress has raised questions about the President's business dealings with foreign governments and the potential for emoluments violations.

site_title: 3M expands medical-products unit in record US$4.3b deal
summary: 3M has agreed to buy medical-products maker Acelity Inc for approximately US$4.3 billion, its largest acquisition ever, as new CEO Mike Roman seeks to expand the company's profitable healthcare business. The deal adds bandages and surgical-wound products to 3M's portfolio and values Acelity at US$6.7 billion, including debt. This acquisition follows 3M's struggles in markets such as automotive and electronics, and marks a change of course under Roman's leadership.

site_title: STI dips 0.2% as US Fed holds rates
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.2% on the first trading day of May, mirroring global equities, as the US Federal Reserve held interest rates steady. Losers outnumbered gainers 218 to 192, with over 878 million shares worth S$1.11 billion changing hands. DBS Group Holdings, the largest lender, slid 2.3% due to concerns over the bank's earnings growth, while Jardine Cycle & Carriage and Jardine Matheson Holdings also declined. The Straits Times Index closed at 3,393.33.

site_title: US factory orders post largest increase in seven months
summary: US factory orders rose 1.9% in March, the largest increase in seven months, driven by strong demand for transportation equipment. However, rising inventories and unfilled orders suggest slower manufacturing activity. Orders for computers and electronic products also increased, while machinery and electrical equipment orders rose 0.1% and 0.5% respectively. Despite this, economists point to sluggish global demand, trade uncertainty, and inventory build as pressures on manufacturing.

site_title: Kellogg to replace CFO, earnings dive 36.5 per cent; shares drop
summary: Kellogg Co. announced the departure of CFO Fareed Khan, who will be replaced by Amit Banati on July 1. The company reported a 36.5% decline in first-quarter earnings due to a strong US dollar and higher costs. Shares dropped 3.9% in morning trading. Kellogg cited higher spending on divestitures, transportation, and raw materials costs, despite beating analyst estimates on excluding items. The company's North America sales fell 1.8% due to a recall of RXBAR protein and lower cereal and frozen food sales.

site_title: US: Wall St opens slightly lower after mixed bag of earnings
summary: US stocks opened slightly lower on Thursday after mixed earnings reports, despite the Federal Reserve's decision not to cut interest rates. The Dow Jones fell 0.09%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.05%, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.04%. The mixed batch of earnings reports weighed on investors, who were also concerned about ongoing trade tensions and the Fed's stance on interest rates.

site_title: Saudi developer Raza plans projects for a more open society
summary: Saudi developer Raza plans to launch mixed-use projects combining offices, homes, and leisure facilities, as part of a broader effort to create a more open society. The move follows Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's relaxation of strict social rules and sanctions on previously un-Islamic entertainment. Raza aims to double assets under management to 26 billion riyals by 2024 and plans to diversify into asset management and commercial services, attracting fresh investments and partnerships. The projects are expected to cater to Saudi Arabia's young population, with women increasingly accessing the job market.

site_title: HC Surgical, Medinex associate invest in loan to dental clinic chain
summary: HC Surgical Specialists and Medinex, associates of the listed companies, have invested in a Singapore dental clinic chain through Zenmedic Capital. They jointly hold 27.8% stakes in Zenmedic, which has lent S$2.25 million to Nuffield Dental Holdings at 5% annual interest. The investment is secured by a personal guarantee from Nuffield's owner, Samintharaj Kumar Samy Raja, and the loan is subject to certain conditions. The deal is expected to have no material impact on HC Surgical Specialists' earnings or net tangible assets.

site_title: Bombardier reins in financial goals; eyes Belfast plant sale, shares drop
summary: Bombardier Inc. has adjusted its financial goals, citing headwinds in its rail division, and announced plans to sell its Belfast wing and structure-making operation, which employs 3,600 people. The company will unite its corporate and regional jet units into one aviation division and consolidate its aerostructures businesses. Shares dropped 10% as the company cited a strategic move to focus on more profitable sales of corporate jets and passenger rail cars. Bombardier Chief Financial Officer John Di Bert declined to commit to 2020 financial targets, citing a need to review the company's progress over the next few months.

site_title: RHT Holdings sells corporate advisory unit to In.Corp
summary: RHT Holdings has sold its corporate advisory unit, RHT Corporate Advisory, to In.Corp Global. The acquisition will allow RHT Holdings to streamline operations and focus on innovation and technology. Operations at RHT Corporate Advisory in Singapore and Hong Kong will continue as usual, with all staff retained. In.Corp aims to expand its services, including share registration and corporate secretarial services, in the Hong Kong market. The deal is part of In.Corp's regional expansion strategy.

site_title: Mun Siong to set up Malaysian JV for contract with Petronas
summary: Mun Siong Engineering has won a five-year service contract with Petronas, a Malaysian state-owned oil and gas company. The contract, worth integrated turnaround works and maintenance, was awarded on March 1 but announced on May 2. Mun Siong will work with a Malaysian partner to meet conditions and review joint-venture terms. The company advises caution on trading due to uncertainty over fulfilling conditions and resolving material terms.

site_title: Frasers Property Group opens third German asset in Hamburg
summary: Frasers Property Group has launched its third serviced residence in Germany, the 154-room Fraser Suites Hamburg, through its hospitality arm. This marks Frasers' third property in Germany, following two existing assets in Frankfurt and Berlin. The new property offers a mix of suites, deluxe rooms, studios, and one-bedroom apartments within a heritage-listed building in Hamburg.

site_title: Asiatic Group subsidiary extends Cambodian energy contract
summary: Asiatic Group's indirect subsidiary Colben Energy (Cambodia) has extended its power purchase agreement with Electricite Du Cambodge until April 30, 2022. The agreement now requires Colben to purchase 60% of contracted capacity, down from 65% previously. The extension maintains Colben's role in supplying power to the state-owned electricity company in Cambodia.

site_title: CNA Group told to delist after 4 years on SGX watch-list
summary: CNA Group, a Singapore-based building management company, has been ordered to delist from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) after four years on the financial watch-list due to consecutive pre-tax losses. The company must submit a reasonable exit offer for shareholders within a month. Judicial manager Deloitte & Touche warned that if the application for an extension was rejected, CNA would face liquidation and winding-up due to its significant liabilities outweighing assets. The SGX noted that there is no certainty on a viable proposal to justify further extensions.

site_title: Annica Holdings demands overdue payment for disposal of subsidiary
summary: Annica Holdings, a listed oil and gas company, has demanded S$611,835.60 in overdue payment for the disposal of its subsidiary, GPE Power Systems. The payment was due by April 30, but the deadline was pushed back from December 31, 2018. The company's board has served a letter of demand to Chong Shin Mun, who was to buy out a 70% stake in GPE.

site_title: Hong Kong's Q1 GDP growth slows to near decade low
summary: Hong Kong's economy grew at its slowest annual pace in nearly 10 years in Q1, expanding 0.5% from a year earlier, due to a slowdown in exports and investment. The city is affected by China's slowing economy and the US-China trade war, as well as cooling property prices and volatile stock markets. While economists expect conditions to stabilize around mid-year, Hong Kong's economy is likely to face subdued recoveries, influenced by China's restrained stimulus measures.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong's economy grew at its slowest annual pace in nearly 10 years in the first quarter, an advance government estimate showed on Thursday, hit by a slowdown in exports and investment.

site_title: Voters set to punish UK PM May's Conservatives over Brexit delay
summary: English voters are set to punish Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative Party over its failure to deliver Brexit, with the party expected to lose hundreds of seats in local government elections. The results will show the impact of Brexit on support for the Conservative Party and the leftist opposition Labour Party. The Liberal Democrats, who reject Brexit, are also expected to gain seats. A poor showing for the Conservatives could pressure May to resign, highlighting widespread dissatisfaction with her handling of Brexit.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust (MNACT) reported a robust Q4 FY19 results with gross revenue and net property income jumping 16.2% and 15.3% year-over-year, respectively. DPU grew 2.7% y-o-y to 1.956 Singapore cents. Occupancy was near-full at 99.6% and rental reversions were +28% for Festival Walk's retail component. However, management sounded cautious on the rental and occupancy outlook. The trust's fair value gain was S$465.2 million in FY19, with office and business park properties in tier 1-2 cities of China as the most likely destination for future acquisitions.

site_title: Bigger S$3.68m scheme launched to boost tech use by Singapore law firms
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Law has launched a new S$3.68 million scheme, Tech-celerate for Law, to support law firms in adopting technology solutions. The program provides funding for up to 70% of the first-year cost of adopting technology, capped at S$30,000 for baseline solutions and S$100,000 for advanced solutions. The program aims to help law firms become future-proof and future-ready, and is part of a series of initiatives to support lawyers in adopting technology and managing transformation and innovation.

site_title: Singapore shares dip 0.2% on Thursday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.2% on Thursday, mirroring global equities, after the US Federal Reserve signaled no policy changes. DBS Group Holdings declined 2.3%, while OCBC Bank and United Overseas Bank gained 0.33% and 0.07%, respectively. Jardine Cycle & Carriage and Creative Technology also dropped 2.11% and 1.91%. The decline was largely in line with global market trends, despite the US Fed's decision.

site_title: Tesla seeks up to US$2.3b from share, debt issues
summary: Tesla Inc. raised up to $2.3 billion in capital through new shares and debt, with CEO Elon Musk contributing $10 million, to bolster cash reserves amid Wall Street pressure. The funds will support expansion plans, including a Shanghai factory, the Model Y SUV, and ramping up Model 3 sedan production. Tesla's shares rose over 5% on the news.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims unchanged last week
summary: US jobless claims remained unchanged at 230,000 for the week ended April 27, defying economists' forecast of a decline. The four-week moving average of initial claims rose to 212,500, influenced by the Easter and Passover holidays. A strike at Stop & Shop supermarkets likely contributed to the recent surge. Despite the volatile claims data, the labor market remains strong, with job gains averaging 180,000 in the first quarter and the unemployment rate forecast to remain at 3.8%. The Federal Reserve held interest rates steady, citing sustained labor market strength.

site_title: Capital World misses bond deadline, strikes new repayment deal
summary: Capital World, a Catalist-listed developer, has struck a new repayment deal with convertible bondholder Chong Thim Peng, extending the repayment date of certain bonds from May 1 to May 31, including 10% extra interest. The company had initially missed the deadline and had already repaid another S$4.05 million in Series A Tranche 1 bonds. Minority shareholders had previously blocked the company from issuing new shares to Peng under the settlement agreement. The new deal is seen as in the best interests of the company, according to its board.

site_title: CDL, Hong Realty to launch freehold Amber Park condo at average S$2,425 psf
summary: CDL and Hong Realty will launch a freehold 592-unit condominium, Amber Park, in East Coast, Singapore on May 4. Early-bird prices start from S$1.088 million for a one-bedroom plus study apartment, averaging S$2,425 psf. The condo features a rooftop recreational deck and comes with appliances and fittings from various brands. Located near the upcoming Tanjong Katong MRT station, the site is a rare freehold of over 213,000 sq ft.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close with strong gains
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.83% to close at 29,944.18, driven by hopes for China-US trade talks. Tech firms, which had suffered losses earlier in the week, saw a much-needed rally. Mainland Chinese markets were closed for a public holiday, allowing Hong Kong shares to gain. The gains were seen as a positive sign for the market, despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Plastoform names 2 new independent directors after its only one retired
summary: Plastoform Holdings has appointed two new independent directors following the retirement of its sole director, Tan Ngiap Siew, who gave more than two months' notice of his departure. Siew stated he had no concerns over the company's operations and affairs or corporate governance. The new directors were identified and reviewed by Siew before his departure.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rise on foreign buying, improved April factory data; won gains
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 0.42% to 2,212.75, driven by foreign buying and improved April factory data. Factory activity rebounded from five months of contraction, with exports falling 2.0% year-over-year. The won strengthened, and the benchmark bond yield rose. Foreigners purchased 63.6 billion won worth of shares, while the won was quoted at 1,165.7 per dollar, 0.21% higher than its previous close.

site_title: Bank of England's Carney tells investors they are too relaxed on rates
summary: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney said investors are underestimating the central bank's ability to raise interest rates due to Brexit uncertainty, despite keeping borrowing costs on hold. Carney expressed a hawkish stance, stating that investors are too relaxed about the pace of rate increases. The BoE upgraded its forecast for UK growth to 1.5% and expects inflation to exceed its 2% target in two and three years' time. Sterling whipsawed after the announcement, and the central bank expects growth to slow to 0.2% during the current quarter.

site_title: Better business outcomes and employee experiences with digital workflows
summary: A ServiceNow report found Singapore employees are optimistic about workplace automation, believing it improves productivity and competitiveness. However, they express concerns about learning new skills. The report highlights the importance of digital education for employees, as 85% of respondents who received excellent training found adapting to automation easy. Businesses can get ahead by providing excellent training and preparation for employees, with 80% of highly automated companies reporting improved job satisfaction.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 10.05 points to 1,632.24. Volume was 2.7 billion lots worth RM2 billion, with 669 losers beating 225 gainers.

site_title: Tales of Leonardo, enigmatic genius
summary: Leonardo da Vinci, the Italian Renaissance genius, died 500 years ago on May 2, 1519, but his legacy lives on. Contrary to a 1818 painting by Jean-Auguste Dominique Ingres, which depicts him dying in the arms of King Francis I, historical records show the king was two days away at the time of Leonardo's death. The artist's fascination with flight, nature, and human anatomy is evident in his work, including his obsession with the flight of birds and his meticulous anatomical studies. Despite struggling to find the perfect faces for The Last Supper, Leonardo's artistic innovations continue to inspire and intrigue art lovers today.

site_title: India's April jobless rate rises to 7.6 per cent
summary: India's unemployment rate rose to 7.6% in April, the highest since October 2016, according to the Centre for Monitoring Indian Economy. The rate increased from 6.71% in March and is a setback for Prime Minister Narendra Modi ahead of the general election. Factory activity also contracted at its slowest pace in eight months, and optimism among manufacturing firms decreased due to concerns about the new government's policies. The data contradicts the government's claim of releasing official unemployment data only every five years, as leaked figures showed a similar trend in 2017/18.

site_title: OUE H-Trust posts 6.3% fall in Q1 DPS to 1.18 Singapore cents
summary: OUE Hospitality Trust (OUE H-Trust) reported a 6.3% decline in first-quarter distribution per stapled security (DPS) to 1.18 Singapore cents, down from 1.27 Singapore cents in the same period last year. Net property income fell 2.2% to S$27.7 million, while gross revenue declined 3% to S$31.7 million due to lower master lease income from Mandarin Orchard Singapore. The trust's hospitality segment was impacted by lower corporate and wholesale demand.

site_title: Enviro-Hub Holdings to leave SGX's financial watch-list
summary: Enviro-Hub Holdings will leave the Singapore Exchange's financial watch-list, as it met the criteria for removal after missing the financial results and minimum trading price requirements for three consecutive years. The company reported a fourth-quarter net profit of S$2.5 million and its market value is approximately S$26.8 million. Enviro-Hub Holdings will be removed from the watch-list after receiving an in-principle approval from the bourse operator, but shareholders are advised to note that the Singapore Exchange reserves the right to amend or vary its decision.

site_title: US Q1 productivity rise fastest since 2014; labour costs fall
summary: US worker productivity increased at a 3.6% annualized rate in the first quarter, the fastest pace since 2014, depressing labor costs and suggesting benign inflation. The economy grew at a 3.2% rate, and productivity rose 2.4% compared to the first quarter of 2018, the best performance since 2010. Unit labor costs fell at a 0.9% rate, the weakest pace since 2013, and hourly compensation increased at a 2.6% rate, slowing from the fourth quarter's brisk pace. This trend may suggest inflation could remain under control for a while.

images.alt_text: US worker productivity increased at its fastest pace in more than four years in the first quarter, depressing labour costs and suggesting inflation could remain benign for a while.

site_title: Singaporeans spend more time on property searches than on reading bedtime stories to their children: poll
summary: A recent HSBC survey found that Singaporeans spend an average of 3.29 hours per week on property searches, compared to 1.03 hours reading bedtime stories to their children and 0.94 hours speaking to their parents. This highlights the significant time devoted to property-related activities, even for those not currently in the market for a new home. The survey results suggest a unique aspect of Singapore's real estate culture.

site_title: honestbee CEO Joel Sng steps down, LG scion Brian Koo to be interim CEO
summary: honestbee co-founder Joel Sng has stepped down as CEO, effective immediately. Brian Koo, founding managing partner of Formation Group and LG scion, has been named interim CEO. Formation Group is one of honestbee's key backers, with ties to the Korean electronics giant LG. This move comes amid speculation of a leadership reshuffle, with no further details provided on Sng's departure or succession plans.

site_title: Buy-out offer for Kingboard Copper 'not fair but reasonable', says IFA
summary: A buy-out offer of S$0.60 in cash for each share for Kingboard Copper Foil Holdings has been deemed "not fair but reasonable" by an independent financial adviser (IFA). The offeror, Kingboard Laminates Holdings, controls 88.41% of the company and plans to privatize it. The IFA noted that the offer represents a realistic opportunity for shareholders to realize their investment in cash, considering low trading liquidity prior to the offer announcement. The offeror intends to exercise its right of compulsory acquisition once it can do so, and Kingboard Copper closed flat at the offer price.

site_title: Hi-P posts surprise Q1 earnings growth on lower forex costs
summary: Hi-P International, a contract manufacturer, posted surprise Q1 earnings growth despite lower gross profit due to pricing pressures and product mix. Net profit rose 5.8% to S$10.7 million, driven by a 70.9% drop in "other expenses". The company attributed the earnings beat to lower forex-related expenses and has guided for lower revenue but flattish earnings in the second quarter. Hi-P plans to expand its sales force and explore mergers and acquisitions to capitalize on the disruption caused by the trade war between the US and China.

site_title: Australia shares end lower on Fed comments as financials drag; NZ soars
summary: Australian shares ended 0.6% lower, their worst day in nearly a month, as financial stocks fell after the US Federal Reserve held interest rates steady and signalled little appetite for a rate cut. The financial index dropped 1.1%, with National Australia Bank and AMP Ltd. reporting disappointing results. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index surged 1.2% to a record peak, driven by gains in fuel supplier Z Energy and electricity retailer Meridian Energy.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon at 3,379.14, down 0.62% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading Thursday afternoon at 3,379.14, down 0.62% from the previous day. The Straits Times Index declined 21.06 points. Losers outnumbered gainers 183 to 151, with Netlink Nbn Trust and Mapletree Logistics Trust among the top gainers. Active index stocks, including DBS Group Holdings, United Overseas Bank, and OCBC Bank, declined. The decline follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Pavilion Energy conducts Singapore's first commercial ship-to-ship LNG bunkering
summary: Pavilion Energy successfully conducted Singapore's first commercial ship-to-ship liquefied natural gas (LNG) bunkering operation at the Port of Singapore. The operation involved transferring 2,000 cubic meters of LNG to a small-scale tanker and then to a receiving vessel. The milestone was achieved in collaboration with the Maritime and Port Authority (MPA) and Singapore LNG Corporation, with plans to facilitate LNG bunkering growth in Singapore. The event is seen as a step towards making LNG the worldwide fuel of choice for bunkering in the long term.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Honestbee co-founder Joel Sng steps down as CEO, with LG scion Brian Koo taking over as interim CEO. A trial between MAS and Bank of Canada could lead to cheaper, faster, and safer cross-border payments. Analysts at DBS Group Research say the buyer in Oxley's S$1.03b sale of Chevron House is the bigger beneficiary. No Signboard CEO has been arrested and bailed in a share buyback probe, but not charged. Singaporeans spend an average of 3.29 hours per week on property searches, while the STI dipped 0.2% on Thursday.

site_title: Scandal-hit Australian banks earmark billions to repay customers
summary: Australia's major banks, including National Australia Bank, have set aside billions of dollars to reimburse customers for years of dodgy fees. The banks, following a government probe, have earmarked A$6 billion in remediation costs to address issues such as charging fees to dead people and aggressive selling tactics. This comes after a year-long Royal Commission exposed widespread bank malpractice, leading to the departure of NAB's CEO and chairman. The banks are deferring bonuses and cutting shareholder dividends to protect their balance sheets during a challenging period.

site_title: Asia manufacturing 'bottoming out' but economies may still need more stimulus
summary: Asia's manufacturing sector showed signs of bottoming out in April, with factory activity recovering in parts of the region, but still facing subdued global demand. The outlook for central banks in Malaysia, New Zealand, and Australia suggests rate cuts, with the US Federal Reserve holding interest rates steady. A resolution to the trade dispute between the US and China could improve the mood, while China's stimulus measures appear to be kicking in more slowly than expected, with some economists calling for further support to generate sustainable growth.

site_title: Falcon Energy presents new debt plan to Series 001 noteholders
summary: Falcon Energy Group, an offshore and marine company, has presented a revised debt plan to Series 001 noteholders, offering a step-up coupon payment on certain notes due in 2020. The company also considers converting the notes into shares at S$0.05 apiece or into new notes every six months. This revised plan aims to restructure all liabilities.

site_title: Online help for private homeowners to check for foreign worker housing breaches
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) in Singapore launched the Foreign Worker Tenant Enquiry Service (FWTES), an online platform allowing private homeowners to check if foreign workers are residing at their addresses and remove their names if they have moved out. This service replaces the previous manual hardcopy form submission process, making it easier for homeowners to detect and report misuse of their home addresses.
